Title: Proposed Determination to Restrict Use of Area as Disposal Site: Pebble Deposit Area, Southwest Alaska; Proposed Withdrawal
Abstract: Federal Register of July 19, 2017, (82 FR 33123)(FRL-9965-20-Region 10)
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
Subject: EPA-R10-OW-2017-0369 Preserve Bristol Bay Proposed Determination
Dear Administrator Pruitt and Acting Region 10 Administrator Pirzadeh:
I am writing today to urge the US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to keep the 404(c) Proposed Determination in place protect Bristol Bay, Alaska, from the proposed Pebble Mine that would threaten the region's irreplaceable fish and wildlife resources and the 14,000 jobs that depend on Bristol Bay's clean, healthy waters.
According to the EPA's own study:
 The Bristol Bay watershed provides vital habitat for 29 fish species, more than 190 bird species, and more than 40 terrestrial animals. All five species of Pacific salmonsockeye, Chinook, coho, chum and pinkspawn and rear in the pristine Bristol Bay watershed.
 The Bristol Bay watershed supports the largest sockeye salmon run in the world, producing approximately 46% of the world's wild sockeye harvest, creating $1.5 billion in economic output and nearly 20,000 jobs throughout the United States annually.
 Construction of the Pebble deposit will destroy 94 miles of salmon streams and 5,350 acres of wetlands, lakes and ponds.
Mining the headwaters of the Bristol Bay river systems could cause irreparable harm to the valuable Bristol Bay fishery, wildlife, and people, and that's just in its construction and use, not even considering an accident which could have a disastrous impact in this pristine environment.
This area holds great ecological and economic value. I recommend the EPA keep in place the 404(c) Proposed Determination for Bristol Bay, Southwest Alaska. The restrictions included in that proposal and reasonable and will prevent unsustainable development that would adversely impact the region's fishery, recreation and local culture.
Please keep the agency's 404(c) action in place to protect one of the nation's greatest sustainable resourcesthe Bristol Bay, Alaska, salmon fishery.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
Bristol Bay is a pristine waterway.  It is teaming with fish that locals depend upon for subsistence. Alaska Natives have been fishing those waters for centuries.  Pebble Mine will destroy it all.  The world's copper needs can be easily met by mining copper from many, many places around the world that are much safer and more practical.
The EPA itself has accidently released toxic water stored at a mine into drinking water systems.  What is to prevent that here?  There is no safe form of mining.  Just like any other mining that takes place, Pebble mining can have a severe effect on the surrounding environment. Due to this fact, Pebble mining does not have a great reputation among those who are advocates for protecting the environment. There are a number of emissions risks involved that can damage the quality of life for humans and animals in the region where the mining takes place. The terrain that is mined experiences damages and so does the ecosystem of the area. Vegetation and tree life is placed at risk and water supplies where the mining is conducted are often unusable afterwards, thanks to toxic runoff. The soil's natural condition is also in jeopardy and it can become impossible to grow crops after the Pebble mine project has concluded. 
Since pebble mining is a fairly new development, very little research has been done regarding the long term effects. As such, we know an astonishingly small amount about the damage that will be caused to fault lines in the area and what will need to be done in order to combat this sort of effect. Until the proper research can be conducted, pebble mining could prove to be extremely problematic.  When so little is known about the long term effects as it relates to earthquakes, this places workers at greater risk of suffering injuries or fatalities. Even though mine workers are very well compensated for their time, a high salary is not always an acceptable substitute for safety. 
When a depressed economic area decides to become a mining region, this can attract the wrong type of element.  People who live near mines often report troubling activities that take place in adjacent areas, as transients and criminals will typically take advantage of the sudden influx of income in the region where the mining is being conducted.  Instances of crimes tend to be more pronounced in places where mining has recently begun. Theft, drug sales, drug addiction and sex based crimes are all more common and local residents who are against the commencement of mining often cite the horror stories of other mining based economies as a means of frightening away this particular economic stimulant. 
There are a large number of chemicals that are involved with the creation of any mining project. These toxic chemicals end up accumulating over the course of time and causing a number of issues for the local population, as well as plants and animals that have become accustomed to living in the region. The worst part of all? Scientists do not have the full scope of what these toxic chemicals are capable of.  Mining projects have a way of going awry when least expected, which can cause toxic waste to spread uncontrollably. Mercury and cyanide are often used, which can contaminate the environment and also pollute adjacent bodies of water. This has an extremely devastating overall effect on marine life, one that can take several generations to reverse.

Title: Mass comment campaign sponsoring organization unknown. Sample attached (web)
Abstract: 12 similar comments have been received to date for this web campaign
Comment:
I am opposed to withdrawing (docket EPA-R10-OW-2017-0369) the July 2014 Clean Water Act Proposed Determination because it will result in weakened protections for salmon and Alaskan jobs. Please put American jobs over mining interests and preserve the Bristol Bay Proposed Determination.
 
Bristol Bay, Alaska is one of our last great wild salmon fisheries. Tens of millions of wild salmon return annually, which support upwards of 14,000 American jobs in the commercial and sport fishing industries, serve as a one-in-a-lifetime destination for anglers from around the world, and are the cultural cornerstone for the region's communities.

These long-established American businesses and jobs are at risk from a Canadian mining company that wants to build the proposed Pebble Mine. Although Alaskans typically support resource development, more than 65 percent of Alaskans and more than 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents oppose the proposed Pebble Mine. If built, the Pebble Mine would be many times larger than America's current largest open-pit mine and require several large earthen dams to hold back billions of tons of mine waste. This waste would require perpetual remediation and be forever at the headwaters of two of the most productive salmon rivers in the world.

In 2010, frustrated with ineffective and inadequate options for addressing the proposed mine at the local level, Alaska Native Tribes, commercial fishing business owners and sportsmen asked EPA step in to ensure that this mine wouldn't jeopardize local communities, American jobs, and the region's thriving economy and culture.

The EPA responded by hosting dozens of community meetings, reviewing Pebble's many detailed filings with state and federal agencies, and conducting a twice peer-reviewed scientific assessment of the potential impacts to the region. After years of review and input from Americans, the EPA determined that a large mine of the type and scale contemplated by Pebble would have unacceptable adverse effects on the fish, recreation, and communities in the area, and based on this information proposed several restrictions that any mining in the Pebble area would have to meet.

Over the course of the EPA's own comment and public review processes, the EPA received more than 1.5 million comments asking for strong protections for Bristol Bay. Withdrawing the proposed determination would fly in the face of an overwhelming majority of Alaskans and put the short-term interests of a Canadian mining company above thousands of American jobs.  

Alaskans asked for state-level protections as well as the EPA's involvement and for up-front protections for Bristol Bay's jobs and fisheries. Please do not trade American businesses and jobs and our wild salmon for the shallow promises of a mining company. I am writing today to ask that you stand with American jobs and communities and not withdraw the Proposed Determination.

The salmon runs that will inevitably suffer and disappear means there will, obviously, be lost jobs and lives and communities  as an "unintended" consequence of this corporate grasping. Title: Comment submitted by M. Meister
Comment:
In 2014, after a thorough review, the EPA determined that the Bristol Bay watershed is too fragile to tolerate the risks of large-scale mining. It proposed restrictions under the Clean Water Act that would have limited the size and impact of the potential Pebble Mine.

On July 11, 2017, in an abrupt about-face, the EPA is seeking to withdraw these suggested protections to clear the path for the development of large-scale mining on state and federal lands. The Pebble deposit threatens Bristol Bay being located at the headwaters of two of the eight major rivers that feed Bristol Bay - it would be the largest mine in Morth America and any release of the acidic waste generated from this mining operation (as has been shown in other areas with pit mining - Arizona near Tucson for example where I have lived), could be catastrophic (the 2014 Mount Polley Mine disaster in Canada shows even the most technologically advanced mine can fail - just like pipelines and nuclear power plants and other industrial projects we were told could not fail) .

For years, commercial fishermen and women, tribes, sportsmen and women, tourism operators, chefs, and Bristol Bay's business owners have fought against this proposed mining development. Bristol Bay's salmon are integral to food security worldwide and critical locally, where subsistence accounts for an average of 80 percent of the protein area residents consume, and salmon make up over half of the subsistence harvest. I can choose a different dinner but in Bristol Bay, salmon is life.

This salmon industry generates more than $1.5 billion in economic activity annually and it supports 14,000 jobs in Bristol Bay alone. Fishing provides more jobs and state revenue in Alaska than mining. The economic benefits are felt along the entire West Coast, especially in Washington. The Pebble Mine would jeopardize this thriving fish-based economy along with the fish that feed millions.  The mine is a short term benefit for the few.  Salmon are a long term benefit for the many.  We MUST stop opting for the short term gains at the expense of long term survival of humans and the rest of the animal world (yes, we too are animals).  

Mary Meister
821 NW 52nd St.
Seattle, WA  98107

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
To whom it may Concern, 

In the response to the proposed rule change that protects Bristol Bay, I would like to highly encourage the EPA to maintain the current rule. Bristol Bay is a vital watershed that makes up the breeding grounds for millions of salmon. These salmon are a vital part of the food chain in the Pacific Northwest, not only for the local marine wildlife but also for humans. There are 14,000 jobs in the Bristol Bay Area alone that are dependent on the these salmon which are part of a $1.5 billion industry. In 2014 the EPA found this area to be so fragile that building mines on the rivers that feed into Bristol Bay would likely destroy this habitat for salmon. That has not changed. The EPA needs to say NO to the Pebble Mine and protect this beautiful area. As a native to the Pacific Northwest, I can tell you that we pride ourselves in the protection of our environment, the love of our salmon, and our beautiful waterways. We care more about investing in the long term future than making short term profits as the Pebble Mine would. The EPA should maintain their rule, and continue to protect these beautiful waters.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
In 2014, following a four-year review process and bolstered by 1.5 million public comments and verification from hundreds of scientists, the Environmental Protection Agency determined that the Bristol Bay watershed that supports wild salmon, clean water, and a fish-based economy is too fragile and unique to tolerate the risks of large-scale mining. This past July 11, in an abrupt about-face under a new administration, the EPA proposed to withdraw its previously proposed Clean Water Act protections in Alaska's Bristol Bay watershed, and to clear the path for the development of large-scale mining on state and federal lands-- including the Pebble Mine. The Pebble depositwith massive deposits of gold, copper, and molybdenumis in the headwaters of two of the eight major rivers that feed Bristol Bay. If built, it would be the largest open-pit mine in North America. Any release of the acidic waste generated from mining into surface or groundwater could be catastrophic. Contamination of surrounding watershed is pretty much guaranteed with any hard rock mine, but how much is always the question. The 2014 Mount Polley Mine disaster in Canada provides a cautionary tale that even the most technologically advanced mine can fail.

Bristol Bay supports the largest wild sockeye salmon fishery in the world, with approximately 46% of the average global abundance. Picture an average of 40 million red sockeye salmon returning annually from their years at sea to spawn in cold and crystal-clear streams of Bristol Bay. Now picture an enormous open pit mine situated directly atop these crucial headwaters. 

For years, residents of Bristol Bay have successfully fought against this proposed developmentincluding commercial fishermen and women, tribes, sportsmen and women, and local businesses including recreation and tourism. Bristol Bay's salmon are integral to food security worldwide, and they are a critical local food source. In the Bristol Bay region, subsistence accounts for an average of 80% of protein consumed by area residents, and salmon make up just over half of the subsistence harvest. 

Let's be clear, we're not choosing between profits and no profits. If we protect Bristol Bay we can have jobs and a clean environment, year after year. This salmon industry generates more than $1.5 billion in economic activity annually and it supports 14,000 jobs in Bristol Bay alone. Overall, fishing provides more jobs and state revenue in Alaska than mining. The economic benefits are also felt through-out the west coast, especially in Washington state, my home statefrom jobs in catching and processing fish to supplies and services. The Pebble Mine would jeopardize this thriving fish-based economy; revenue, jobs, and the fish that feed millions. The Pebble Mine prospect is the wrong mine in the wrong place. Mining in this watershed is unconscionable. Please live up to your name.

Title: Comment submitted by  J. Gustafson
Comment:
To whom it may concern:  It is appalling when corporate greed is allowed to destroy the resources the EPA and our government are mandated to be protecting for generations now living and those to come. A one time gain in wealth does not balance with the economic benefits from a strong sustainable ecosystem that has supported us since humans began to inhabit this region. It is like the tale of Midas who could no longer eat since all he touched turned to gold. If it were only the mine owner and shareholders who would starve from their avarice it might be a moral tale to pass on wisdom. It is all of us who will see our food ruined by the poisons needed to extract wealth for a few. Fisheries as every cod fisher knows can die and not be resurrected. The economic harm to salmon fisheries has been predicted to be massive and long term if not permanent. Resurrection is not a power the government can wield but protection is a vital function of a smart society's government. We ignore our surroundings at our peril. We are a wealthy nation but even we can not afford to squander the wealth of the land we inhabit.
I have reviewed the information from studies supporting the 2014 recommendations concerning Bristol Bay and see no change in evidence to support a reversal of that consensus. This is a raid by the rich now more politically powerful to steal from all Americans.
Julie Gustafson M.D.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
As the Environmental Protection Agency, the agency charged with protecting the environment, please continue to protect the environment by preserving Bristol Bay from mining. 

Even without a mine disaster, construction of the Pebble deposit will destroy 94 miles of salmon streams and 5,350 acres of wetlands, lakes and ponds. Overall, EPA concluded that mining the headwaters of the Bristol Bay river systems could cause irreparable harm to the valuable Bristol Bay fishery, wildlife, and people.
According to the EPA's own study, the Bristol Bay watershed provides vital habitat for 29 fish species, more than 190 bird species, and more than 40 terrestrial animals. All five species of Pacific salmonsockeye, Chinook, coho, chum and pinkspawn and rear in the pristine Bristol Bay watershed. The Bristol Bay watershed supports the largest sockeye salmon run in the world, producing approximately 46% of the world's wild sockeye harvest, creating $1.5 billion in economic output and nearly 20,000 jobs throughout the United States annually.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I strongly object to reconsideration of the former decision to restrict use of headwater areas for mine waste disposal.  Failure of containment is inevitable - just as earthquakes in that region are inevitable.  Contamination of the headwaters will contaminate critical spawning and rearing reaches for several species of salmon, especially sockeye.  Bristol Bay fisheries provide high quality protein to millions of people a year as well as the Native Americans for whom these fish are both a birthright and a treaty right.  Tens of thousands of  people make decent wages fishing Bristol Bay and providing support for the fishing industry.  The fishing industry that feeds millions of people can go on forever if the headwaters are not polluted.  Salmon resources in the lower 48 continue to dwindle from human impacts.  

Perhaps the mining company owns the mineral rights.  Clean water and prime habitat are public resources just as the fish who are owned in common by this great country - America.  

There is no great shortage for our society of gold, copper and molybdenum.   Market prices show that.  Reversing this decision and enabling the mine to move forward makes profit for the shareholders including many foreigners and gives jobs to several hundred people at most - and for only as long as removing the minerals makes economic sense.  

Trading food security for millions and jobs for tens of thousands forever for the short-term profit of a few is immoral, unscientific  and opposite of making America great.  Please reject the reconsideration and maintain the environmental integrity of the entire Bristol Bay watershed.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I am writing to oppose allowing Northern Dynasty to develop the Pebble Mine.  I am a biologist and resident of the Pacific Northwest. 

1. Northern Dynasty is not financially viable, as reported by a New York investment firm's analysis:

"Northern Dynasty's key asset, the lowgrade Pebble deposit, is not commercially viable: mining it would require so much upfront investment that it would actually destroy value. 
Kerrisdale believes Northern Dynasty's former partners concluded that the Pebble project had a negative present value - an assessment that Northern Dynasty has spent years trying to conceal from the public.
Not only that, but a law firm has announced an investigation into possible securities fraud violations. 

In contrast, the value of the Bristol Bay fishery is proven. Every year, millions upon millions of wild salmon return to Bristol Bay, like no place else on earth. It's the economic backbone of the region, supplying roughly half of the world's supply of wild sockeye salmon, and generating $1.5 billion in annual value. It can continue to play this vital role as long as the habitat is protected."  (1)

2. The proposed mine imperils the world's largest salmon run.  "A three-year Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) study in 2014 found that the proposed mine would destroy 24 to 94 miles of salmon-producing waterways in the course of normal, safe mine operations. The University of Alaska Institute of Social and Economic Research found that the Bristol Bay, the fishery affected by the mine, supports 22,000 jobs and adds $674 million of economic activity to the states of Washington, Oregon, and California. Further, restrictions on mining have the support of 90% of local residents." (2) 

Allowing development of the Pebble Mine puts short-term corporate profits ahead of the wishes of local residents, local jobs, a crucial regional food source, and environmental health.

SOURCES:
(1) https://www.earthworksaction.org/earthblog/detail/alaskas_pebble_mine?gclid=CjwKCAjwzMbLBRBzEiwAfFz4gZ2oHRfLZ22rsS9PbRljmzuo7A-Urei_Cx35eTrWMzLoR2uCIj_H5xoCepQQAvD_BwE#.WXegKIjys2z

(2) https://www.cantwell.senate.gov/news/press-releases/cantwell-delivers-warning-ahead-of-epa-settlement-pebble-mine-development-will-be-catastrophic-irreversible

Title: Comment submitted by P. Jones
Comment:
July 24, 2017
Mr. Scott Pruitt, Administrator 
Ms. Michelle Pirzadeh, Acting Regional Administrator, Region 10
US Environmental Protection Agency

Subject: Docket ID No. EPA-R10-OW-2017-0369; Pebble Mine

Dear Mr. Pruitt and Ms. Pirzadeh:
I am writing to express my most deeply held convictions that the US EPA' efforts to withdraw the 10 July 2014 Proposed Determination made in this matter of the Pebble Mine are wrong and contrary to the goals and objectives of the Clean Water Act.

I have worked in Alaskas as a naturalist dating back to the mid-1980's. I was a wetland scientist and worked for US EPA for 27 years. I have received an award for "outstanding accomplishments in the protection and wise stewardship of the national wetlands resources." While I have never worked on the Pebble Mine project, I am very familiar with the CWA Section 404 (b)(1) Guidelines and federal and state agency processes for evaluating such proposals. 

When Congress enacted the Clean Water protections, the first substantive paragraph states the "objective of this chapter is to restore and maintain the chemical, physical, and biological integrity of the Nation's waters." If ever there were a watershed of such national and even international importance, it would be this project's watershed. If ever the 404(b)(1) Guidelines (Guidelines) were put in place to protect an important aquatic resource, it would be for a proposed action of this magnitude in a location such as this. It is stunningly beautiful and pristine; supports numerous fish, mammal and bird species; is highly valued of of economic importance to the native Tribes of Alaska; and is equally treasured by sportsmen and those who enjoy the out-of-doors for intrinsic, non-extractive values.

As a remarkable show of public opposition to this project, the Alaska Bristol Bay Mining Ban Question, Ballot Measure 4, was on the November 4, 2014 ballot in Alaska as an initiated state statute, where it was approved by a stunning 66% margin. Additionally, hundreds of fishing, hunting, and recreational groups opposed the project. You should need to know nothing more than this to maintain the Proposed Determination. It would be a reflection of good government process and obviate the need for a protracted 404 permit review process which, if legitimate, should end in permit denial by the US Army Corps of Engineers (Corps). 

In my view, there are not sufficient grounds for approving this project, given the criteria provided in the Guidelines in light of the difficulty approving an extractive industrial site with its attendant risks of toxic chemical and sediment releases - to speak not of indirect effects - in a watershed that supports natural resources of the magnitude documented in the 2014 Bristol Bay Assessment. Even if that threshold could be rationalized through a tortured 404 permit process, there would remain the requirement of finding appropriate and complete compensatory mitigation under the 2008 Mitigation Rule. An example of how difficult this mitigation requirement would be comes from the Bristol Bay Assessment, which states that under the three development scenarios analyzed, there would be between 9-33 linear miles of streams that would be impacted. Stream mitigation is difficult at best and impossible in many circumstances. Just how would the project proponents meet this one requirement? And this is just one criterion, among many, that makes this project a candidate for denial.

Furthermore, the press release states "EPA may use its scientific assessment regarding the Bristol Bay Watershed without limitation." If EPA or the Corps were to use the findings in the scientific assessment (which have not changed since publication), surely there would be grounds for upholding the Proposed Determination or, if a permit action were to evaluated by the Corps, a denial. How can the Agency justify revoking the Proposed Determination if the underlying science remains unchanged? That appears arbitrary and capricious. What is the factual basis for making this significant change of proposing to withdraw the Proposed Determination that has, as its scientific underpinnings, the 2014 Bristol Bay Assessment? This implies that the Agency (or the Corps) will not rely on this existing science to make its regulatory decisions. This is blatantly contrary to the requirements of evaluation of 404 permit applications under the Guidelines. 

I urge you to uphold the Proposed Determination. The strong public opposition to the project, in combination with sound watershed science that underscores the justification for protecting this aquatic resource of national importance, are your grounds for denying this ill-conceived project. 
Sincerely yours,

Paul Jones
1190 Manzanita Drive
Pacifica, CA 94044
pauljonessailor@gmail.com

Title: Comment submitted by C. Holmes
Comment:
Relative to docket number EPA-R10-OW-2017-0369 
Dear Secretary Ross,
Please protect the Marine Sanctuaries and do not let them be exploited by short sighted, short term interests. In 1975, the first national marine sanctuaries were designated under the Marine Protection, Research, and Sanctuaries Act of 1972. Florida's Key Largo National Marine Sanctuary was the first. After years of overfishing and pollution the reef was dying, threatening the fishing industry, tourism, land value and other economic interests. A healthy reef ecosystem was key to a both a thriving economy and a healthy marine environment in that area. The office of the National Marine Sanctuary Southeast region now includes three distinctive yet interconnected healthy reef systems, Gray's Reef, Florida Keys and Flower Garden Banks national marine sanctuaries. The protection was an excellent long term investment in the regional economy and now many businesses and commercial properties thrive there.

All of our National Marine sanctuaries are protecting important natural resources that serve millions of people in the Northeast, West and beyond. In Bodega Bay for the first time in many years fisherman are experiencing a welcome resurgence of the crab industry. Last summer I had the opportunity to visit Monterey Bay where whales were seen in record numbers feeding on abundant runs of anchovies. Millions are flocking each year to visit these sanctuaries providing billions of dollars for the small business tourist industry as well as commercial operations. Your vote to protect these sanctuaries now will make an enduring difference for many future generations of Americans. Thank you for your consideration.

Sincerely,
Christine Holmes

Title: Comment submitted by D. Bohn
Comment:
It is very disturbing that as of July 11, the EPA is trying to withdraw suggestions (made by the EPA after a four year review process) for protecting the Bristol Bay watershed.  It makes no sense to go back and fish for another conclusion to an already carefully researched question.  The Pebble Mine poses a terrible risk to a vast, unspoiled, and critical watershed.  The risk also applies to the fishing industry in Alaska, and fishing generates more jobs and revenue in Alaska than mining. ["The peril of mining the pristine headwaters of Alaska's Bristol Bay", Helen Cherullo in The Seattle Times, July 22, 2017]. The salmon bred in that watershed provides food security for the area residents as well as economic footing for related jobs up and down the west coast and around the world.

Caving into the pressure of the mining industry is morally indefensible.  Supreme Court Justice Sandra Day O'Connor wrote, "In Bristol Bay, we must take the long view.  We must expand our concept of wealth, counting the riches of food for the community to be just as important, if not more import, than profits to shareholders."  We all have a share in a gift that cannot be remade if spoiled, and spoiling that treasured space is a matter of "when" and not "if" after a huge mine is installed in its headwaters. 

 Sincerely,

Dorothy Bohn

The mine is compatible with the existing salmon fishing industry.

Title: Comment submitted by A. C. Freeland
Comment:
I URGE the EPA NOT to withdraw the Clean Water Restrictions in the Bristol Bay Alaska Watershed.  Having salmon fished in this pristine area for many years, I feel the EPA should be doing more to protect this area and less to lower the environmental standards so that mining can take place here.    The Pebble Mine is not a good fit for this area, and many others feel the same way.

The economic impact derived from the salmon industry in Bristol Bay is estimate at $1.5 BILLION annually.  Additionally, there are over 14,000 jobs in Bristol Bay alone associated with the salmon industry.  Finally, the EPA must consider the residence of the area who for them salmon is not just part of their job, but also their part of their food security.  

Lowering environmental standards so that the Pebble Mine can access this legendary area is a significant mistake.  Long after the mining industry is finished their work  the detrimental effects of their mining practices will linger.

STOP the mine before it starts, save the salmon, the fisheries and communities that have and will need this precious area and it's fishing resources  for generations.

Respectfully,

Ann Casey
Freeland, WA

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
As an Alaskan, I am opposed to the Pebble mine and support common sense protections for the Bristol Bay watershed. In 2010, Bristol Bay's tribes, joined by Native corporations, commercial fishermen, the sports and recreation industry, and other supporters petitioned the EPA to protect Bristol Bay from the risks posed by the Pebble minerisks to salmon, waterways, people, and the economy. The EPA responded by undertaking a multi-year, peer-reviewed scientific study that was subject to extensive public participation. As a result, the EPA proposed common sense protections for the Bristol Bay watershed supported by millions of Americans. The EPA should not now undermine the work that has been done.

Large-scale industrial mining doesn't belong at the headwaters of our country's greatest salmon fishery. If we lose Bristol Bay to mining, we will lose a piece of ourselves, and a critical part of Alaska's culture and economy. 

I am opposed to the EPA making a deal with a foreign mining company when Alaskansi.e., Americansoppose this mine. Pebble wants to build an open pit mine near some of Alaska's and our nation's most precious waters. They are not looking after our state's health or that of our fish, cultures, livelihoods and way of life. What's at risk is the last great sockeye salmon fishery in Alaska and the country. For us, that means losing everything. 

It is the EPA's job to protect our environment, not put the financial interests of an outside mining company over protecting Bristol Bay. Our fish provide long-term jobs to Alaskans. More than 60% of Alaskans and 80% of Bristol Bay residents want Bristol Bay protected.  

Compromising Bristol Bay for a mine is unacceptable. The EPA previously recognized the threat of the mine to the area when proposing scientifically backed protections for the Bristol Bay watershed. Do not withdraw those proposed protections.

Thank you.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment: On behalf of the Natural Resources Defense Council ("NRDC") and our 2.4 million members and activists, I write in support of the request from Bristol Bay tribes, corporations, and business and community leaders to extend the public comment period to 120 days.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment: Restrictions should not be removed from the Pebble Mine. I fear for the health of all Alaskans (human and non-human) if mining begins. Please value people, animals, fish, water quality, riparian areas, and the environment as a whole over future profit the mine might bring in. The people are speaking, and they are saying NO PEBBLE MINE, EVER.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment: I strongly oppose the EPA's withdrawal of their proposed determination to block the Pebble Mine under their Clean Water Act (Section 404c) authority. The Bristol Bay watershed is much too valuable to the American economy and to small Alaskan communities to recklessly endanger it by allowing the permits for Pebble Mine to move forward. If this Administration is indeed in favor of strong U.S. jobs, then choose the 14,000 fishing jobs this fishery supports year after year. If the Administration indeed values small, rural communities, consider the dozens of villages and towns reliant on this income, and on Bristol Bay salmon as a subsistence food source. If this Administration thinks a healthy environment, clean water, and wildlife are worth protecting, then the only course of action is to maintain your 2015 proposed determination and prevent these permits from moving forward. This exact situation is why Section 404c of the CWA exists. Any claims that a mining project of this scale and Bristol Bay's incredibly productive fishery can "happily coexist" is completely delusional at best, and criminally negligent at worst. The people of this country have seen strikingly similar tailings dams fail time and time again - particularly the recent failure at the Mount Polley Mine in Canada that dumped millions of gallons of toxic slurry into the Fraser River system. We know these failures are not a question of "if" but "when", especially in such a seismically active area. Storing billions of tons of toxic waste "in perpetuity" virtually guarantees that it will fail and devastate the salmon fishery at some point in the future -- likely when this partnership of companies have dissolved/disappeared and current EPA employees are long gone. But make no mistake: for the current EPA to move forward with the Pebble permitting process is to admit you're comfortable putting the short-term interests of foreign corporations ahead of long-term jobs, food security, and natural resources for Americans - period. Please do your job - and the right thing - by maintaining your 2015 proposed determination, and prevent the permitting of Pebble. We're counting on you to take this decision in a courageous and historic direction rather than presenting another bleak disappointment in the EPA's ability to fulfill its mandate of protecting the environment. Thank you.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
Protect Bristol Bay from the Risks of Large Scale Mining

Our jobs, food and natural habitats should not be placed in danger due to politics as usual.  Following a four-year review process, the EPA determined that the Bristol Bay watershed is too fragile to tolerate the risks of large-scale mining. It proposed restrictions under the Clean Water Act that would have limited the size and impact of the potential Pebble Mine. Now the EPA is seeking to withdraw these suggested protections.

Bristol Bay supports the largest wild sockeye salmon fishery in the world. The EPA already determined that large scale mining is too risky in this area. Do not open this area up to mining. This kind of short term thinking is dangerous and threatens our Jobs as well as the environment. The Pebble deposit is in the headwaters of two of the eight major rivers that feed Bristol Bay. If built, it would be the largest mine in North America. Any release of the acidic waste generated from mining into surface or groundwater could be catastrophic.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I support the withdrawal. There are many comments here stating some 'hypothetical' environmental damage to Bristol Bay. What I do no understand is, it is well known that the Veto that was in place by the EPA was unlawful and not based on an actual mine plan from PLP, it was a fictional plan, this is fact. 

The EPA's peer review stated that there was no factual science specific to the PLP that could lend itself to the findings. Yet, I see many here arguing that there will be some damage? Until a mine plan is provided, until the Army Corps of engineers review it, there is no proof of such damage. 

Moreover, the mine itself is only close to tributaries that could affect 2-3% of Bristol Bay and the company has stated they will have mitigation plans in place. In addition, the company has recently stated they will not even be utilizing cyanide leaching in their first phase. 

Alaska is broke, we need well paying jobs, and long term jobs. We have an enormous deficit, oil and gas can no longer sustain our economy and with the advent of electric cars that will only get worse over time. The fisheries will not be hurt, we will diversify our economy and help grow the tax base for all Alaskans materially. Not only that, copper is a much needed resource for the 'green economy'. 

Many people here are making environmental claims that are not based in fact or science, I do not understand this. Do you care about the environment or do you have another agenda? It makes no sense. You'd rather have Alaskan's starve so you can feel good about protecting the environment, when no damage will occur? So you're not really achieving anything other than preventing jobs and tax revenues for the state?

I for one think Science should decide, fact should decide, not baseless opinions based on reports that have been proven to be devoid of scientific fact. 

Mines can be built safely, let's stop with the environmental hyperbole and move into the 21st century. Alaska has one of the largest copper deposits in the world, it can help enrich the state in a world in desperate need of it for electronics, electric cars, infrastructure, wind turbines, etc.

Please withdraw the determination and help create wealth for a State in desperate need of financial improvement.

Bellevue, Washington

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
Please do not allow the Pebble Mine project to go forward.

Local communities have long been opposed to Pebble Mine. More than 65 percent of all Alaskans, 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents -- including Native people -- and more than 85 percent of commercial fisherman strongly oppose it.

And it's no secret why: the mine could generate 23 billion tons of dangerous waste, wipe out 90 miles of salmon streams and pollute more than 5,000 acres of wetlands, ponds and lakes. The salmon population would likely plummet -- with catastrophic impacts for the local communities.

Do not withdraw the July 2014 Clean Water Act Proposed Determination.

They're proposing a smaller mine and different practices for reduced size and impact. They aren't asking guaranteed approval. They are asking for their legal right to put a permit through the scientific rigor of eis and army corps approval. 

EPA acted outside their law with a pre-emptive veto.

Use the advisory panel to discuss concerns about their net zero fishery loss proposals and what they can do to ensure clean up. 

For example. Bonds often are done for clean ing costs to ensure compliance.

This isn't a company like imperial metals looming to cut costs and cheap out. They are willing to engage and propose alternatives to mitigate risks.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I support the withdrawal. There are many comments here stating some 'hypothetical' environmental damage to Bristol Bay. 

The EPA's peer review stated that there was no factual science specific to the PLP that could lend itself to the findings. Yet, I see many here arguing that there will be some damage? Until a mine plan is provided, until the Army Corps of engineers review it, there is no proof of such damage.

Moreover, the mine itself is only close to tributaries that could affect 2-3% of Bristol Bay and the company has stated they will have mitigation plans in place. In addition, the company has recently stated they will not even be utilizing cyanide leaching in their first phase.

Alaska is broke, we need well paying jobs, and long term jobs. We have an enormous deficit, oil and gas can no longer sustain our economy and with the advent of electric cars that will only get worse over time. The fisheries will not be hurt, we will diversify our economy and help grow the tax base for all Alaskans materially. Not only that, copper is a much needed resource for the 'green economy'.

Many people here are making environmental claims that are not based in fact or science, I do not understand this. Do you care about the environment or do you have another agenda? It makes no sense. You'd rather have Alaskan's starve so you can feel good about protecting the environment, when no damage will occur? So you're not really achieving anything other than preventing jobs and tax revenues for the state?

I for one think Science should decide, fact should decide, not baseless opinions based on reports that have been proven to be devoid of scientific fact.

Mines can be built safely, let's stop with the environmental hyperbole and move into the 21st century. Alaska has one of the largest copper deposits in the world, it can help enrich the state in a world in desperate need of it for electronics, electric cars, infrastructure, wind turbines, etc.

Please withdraw the determination and help create wealth for a State in desperate need of financial improvement.

Title: Comment submitted by Christine "no surname provided"
Comment:
The United States of America has a long history in the pride of its constitutional freedoms. One of these freedoms is the right to "due process" which is part of the fourth and fifth amendments of the Bill of Rights. The right of "due process" guarantees the safeguard from arbitrary denial by the Government outside the sanctions of law. The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) and Northern Dynasty Minerals (NDM) entered into a legal dispute over EPA's 2014 Proposed Determination of which essentially removed NDM's right to "due process" under the National Environmental Policy Act (NEPA). Northern Dynasty Minerals won their right to due process in a settlement with the EPA in May 2017. The NEPA legislative process must be allowed its due course in permit application for NDM. 

In simplification of the permit process follows a brief outline for the layman reader. The US Army Corps of Engineers reviews all permit applications and accordingly provides the applicant an Environmental Impact Statement (EIS). The EIS outlines any and all impediments to the surrounding environment. The EIS stipulates compliance recommendations that must be adhered to, and failure of an applicant to provide satisfactory compliance mitigation(s) within their revised permit application plan thus results in denial of the permit. 

Northern Dynasty Minerals has repeated their commitment to work in concert with Environmental, Fisheries and Native Alaskan stakeholders. Allow Northern Dynasty Minerals the due process to prove their commitment. 

Most graciously,

Christine

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
The temporary financial gain of a few does not justify the long-lasting destruction of an extraordinarily productive resource that provides benefits to an incredibly diverse and numerous portion of earth's citizens. Monetarily speaking, the salmon harvested from the Bristol Bay equates to 25% of all salmon harvested throughout the state of Alaska. This economy supports not only those who fish commercially, including fisherfolk, tenders, processors, canneries, and the families who depend on the income derived from those businesses; but also sport fisherfolk and the large industry of guides, resorts, and sporting goods sales that provide services for sport fisherfolk; as well as those who depend on this critical source of subsistence to continue their long-standing way of life in Alaska.

It is critically important that this incredibly disruptive and widely disfavored location and means of extracting minerals NOT be approved. The State of Alaska, its residents and visitors all depend to a very large degree on the continuing health and productivity of the Bristol Bay watershed for economic and food security. Please do not allow this massive mine to disrupt the remarkable glory that is the Bristol Bay watershed.

Title: Comment submitted by Christine "no surname provided"
Comment:
Enough with the picturesque ideology of the Bristol Bay salmon industry. The salmon industry is a business. It is not a romantic Native Alaskan way of life as many would have you believe. The salmon industry is mainly interested in maximizing profit for as little input as possible. For example, over 80% of the processing plant workers are foreigners on a temporary visa. It is more cost efficient for the salmon industry to hire foreigners than it is to establish sustainable fair wages and maintain legally standard working conditions for their own Alaskan community. 

The salmon industry is a highly profitable business. In fact it is amongst the highest profit making industries, however it is not an industry that pays fair wages nor does it provide sustainable gainful employment for the community. It would be nice to envision the old days of fishermen on their boats working hard for the days catch and bringing the bounty of the land for the community, but those days are long gone, unfortunately. 

So, please, enough with the war against one mining company when the salmon companies have no interest in providing your community with any consideration. 

Thank you,

Christine

Title: Comment submitted by N. Redman
Comment:
Bristol Bay supports the largest wild sockeye salmon fishery in the world.  Forty-six percent of sockeye salmon in the world return each year to spawn in the cold and crystal clear streams that feed Bristol Bay.  This is a national treasure that supports 14,000 jobs in Bristol Bay.  Bristol Bay salmon are integral to food security worldwide and critical locally.  In the Pacific Northwest we treasure our salmon and the streams and rivers that nourish them.  You can't have one without the other--clean streams and rivers plus a pristine salt water Bay is required for salmon to complete their journey to the ocean and eventual return to their ancestral breeding grounds.  

Though not a Native American by birth, I was born and raised in Seattle, Washington, and know the salmon life cycle and the sacred ground and water needed to sustain them.  Please review the 2014  input of 1.5 million people verifying that the Bristol Bay watershed is too fragile to tolerate the risks of large scale mining.

You can't eat gold, copper or molybdenum.  Yes some make money from the earth's riches, but Bristol Bay is worth more than money.  It provides a safe haven for the continuation of a sacred food chain that we can all partake in.

Please, no Pebble Mine.  Heed the words of Sandra Day O'Connor, "We must take the long view.  We must expand our concept of wealth, counting riches of food for the community to be just as important, if not more important than profits to shareholders."

Respectfully submitted,  Nina Redman

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I am providing comments on this proposed determination based on my years working in the environmental field for private industry, and both the US Forest Service and the US EPA. 

The proposed determination should NOT be withdrawn for the following important reasons:

1.  The potential impacts of the proposed Pebble Mine on the health of the Bristol Bay watershed and the livelihood of thousands of people in Alaska are far too great to accept.

2.  The watershed supports the largest sockeye salmon fishery in the world. It should be protected.

3.  The watershed is home to 25 federally recognized tribal governments who have maintained a salmon-based culture and subsistence-based way of life for at least 4,000 years that would be placed in jeopardy.

4.  The watershed's ecological resources generated nearly $480 million in direct economic expenditures and sales and provided employment for over 14,000 full- and part-time workers in 2009.  The Pebble Mine will jeopardize these significant economic opportunities.

5.  Contrary to the comments provided by the backers of the Pebble Mine project, EPA's watershed assessment was scientifically based and thoroughly peer-reviewed, and the public has had an extensive opportunity to comment on it. I reviewed part of it when I worked for the EPA.  The assessment and public comments received should be key components of any future action on this issue.

6.  The overwhelming majority of residents of Bristol Bay are opposed to the project. A statewide majority of voters also oppose it, as evidenced by the 2014 State-wide ballot measure.

7.  The rationale for the proposed withdrawal is flawed. Finalizing the proposed determination would provide much more regulatory certainty than withdrawing it, and a permit application is not needed to augment the factual record.

Title: Comment submitted by Christine "no surname provided"
Comment:
Firstly, the 2014 "proposed determination" is not a piece of legislation. Legislation is not something that can be removed at whim. The "proposed determination" is just that, a proposal of determination, however it is a proposal that side steps the due process legislation of the National Environmental Policy Act. 

The side stepping of due process legislation was the reason Northern Dynasty filed legal suits against the EPA. And this is the reason the law suit reached a settlement. Furthermore, the "proposed determination" is a pre-emptive determination that is not based on any Pebble mine plan, it is based on a best guess Pebble mine plan. 

Let the due process of the environmental legislation follow its lawful course, and allow the decision of permitting for Northern Dynasty Minerals be based on merit, not fanfare.

Regards,

Christine

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
Stop the Pebble Mine for good.  I was a boat builder for the Bristol Bay fishery, understand its worth, and completely oppose the Pebble Mine, destructive, unneeded, economy wrecking.

Do not not withdraw the Bristol Bay Proposed Determination, which it made pursuant to the Clean Water Act in 2014.

Bristol Bay, Alaska, supports tens of millions of wild salmon return annually, 14,000 American jobs in the commercial and sport fishing industries, is a one-in-a-lifetime destination for anglers from around the world, and is the cultural cornerstone for the region's communities.

These long-established American businesses and jobs are at risk from a foreign-owned mining company that wants to build the proposed Pebble Mine, which is opposed by more than 65 percent of Alaskans and more than 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents. 

In 2010, led by Alaska Native Tribes, interests including commercial fishing business owners and sportsmen asked the EPA step in to ensure that this mine wouldn't jeopardize Bristol Bay. The EPA responded by listening to over 1.5 million Americans, hosting dozens of community meetings, reviewing Pebble's many detailed filings with state and federal agencies, and conducting a twice peer-reviewed scientific assessment of the potential impacts to the region.

Withdrawing the proposed determination ignores the overwhelming majority of Alaskans and puts the short-term interests of a foreign mining company above thousands of American jobs. 

Stop the Pebble Mine in its tracks.  Please do not withdraw the proposed determination.

Title: Comment submitted by L. Pollak
Comment:
To Deputy Regional Administrator Pruitt:
I urge you NOT to withdraw the restricted use determination for the Pebble Mine on Bristol Bay, Alaska. The potential risks and negative impacts of the proposed mine are far too great to accept.

The watershed supports the largest sockeye salmon fishery in the world, generates over $450 million in economic activity, and provides employment for close to 14,000 workers!  

The EPA's watershed assessment was scientifically based and thoroughly peer-reviewed, and the public has had an extensive opportunity to comment on it. The assessment and public comments received should be key components of any future action on this issue.

In addition, an overwhelming majority of residents of Bristol Bay are opposed to the project.5  A statewide majority of voters also oppose it, as evidenced by the 2014 State-wide ballot measure.

Mining operations inevitably involve breakdowns, errors, and unintended damaging consequences.  The Bristol Bay habitat is worth protecting, for reasons both economic and environmental.  Please continue to support this irreplaceable natural resource, for the benefit not only of Alaskans, but for all Americans!

Thank you,
Lauren Pollak

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I am a professional environmental engineer and have spent the last 30 years investigating and cleaning up hazardous waste sites, including former mining operations. In the course of my work I have worked in Alaska and become friends with many Alaskans whose livelihoods depend on the Bristol Bay watershed. These fisheries support thousands of Alaskans and according to the EPA's own 2014 assessment of mining impacts the watershed's ecological resources generated nearly $480 million in direct economic expenditures and sales and provided employment for over 14,000 full- and part-time workers in 2009.

Alaskans do not support mining in the Bristol Bay watershed as demonstrated by the 2014 statewide ballot measure. 

The 25 Tribal Nations who call the Bristol Bay watershed home do not support mining development. 

EPA's watershed assessment was scientifically based and thoroughly peer-reviewed, and the public has had an extensive opportunity to comment on it. The assessment and public comments received should be key components of any future action on this issue.

There are no factual or technical reasons to withdraw the EPA's original determination.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
As a recreator and resident in Alaska, as a person that respects the health of stream ecosystems, as a U.S. citizens that intends to pass down places still able to sustain us physically, economically, and emotionally, I oppose the lifting of the Clean Water Act restrictions on Pebble Mine dumping. 

Research is only beginning to understand the widespread and lasting effects of the waste products of mining, especially in our watersheds. Science is clear, however, that these chemicals accumulate up the food web. Wild caught Alaskan salmon with a side of Pebble Mine waste: does that sound like the product of legislative action meant to benefit the American people? No. It sounds like action taken by a government more interested in streamlining the efficiency of economic flow to mining industry. As a citizen of this country I reject the narrative that lifting restrictions on this project will benefit me, my country's economy. I reject this, because I cannot find a serious ecologist who wouldn't underline this legistlation as a detriment to the ecosystems Southeast Alaska relies on.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
The proposed Clean Water Act determination should NOT be withdrawn.  I am an environmental scientist and worked for many years with Native American tribes. I respect their subsistence lifestyles and value our pristine natural environments. The potential impacts of the proposed Pebble Mine on the health of the Bristol Bay watershed and the livelihood of thousands of people in Alaska are far too great. Those risks include loss of up to up to 94 miles of salmon-supporting streams and up to 4,900 acres of wetlands and ponds, and the very real potential of wastewater dam failure resulting in damage to or destruction of the salmon fishery.  The watershed supports the largest sockeye salmon fishery in the world and 25 federally recognized tribes who for 4,000 years have depended on the fishery for their subsistence-based culture. The overwhelming majority of residents of Bristol Bay are opposed to the project, and a statewide majority of voters oppose it. The watersheds unique and pristine ecological resources generate significant economic benefits and employment.  EPAs original watershed assessment was scientifically robust and thoroughly peer-reviewed.  That assessment and related public comments should strongly influence any future Agency action. References:  U.S. EPA. An Assessment of Potential Mining Impacts on Salmon Ecosystems of Bristol Bay, Alaska (Final Report). U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Washington, DC, EPA 910-R-14-001A-C, ES, 2014. EPA Region 10, Proposed Determination Pursuant to Section 404(c) of the Clean Water Act for Pebble Deposit Area, Southwest Alaska, July 21, 2014.  https://www.epa.gov/bristolbay/2014-proposed-determination-pursuant-section-404c-clean-water-act-pebble-deposit-area. 2017 EPA and Pebble Limited Partnership Agreement. https://www.epa.gov/sites/production/files/2017-05/documents/pebble-settlement-agreement-05-11-17.pdf
U.S. EPA. An Assessment of Potential Mining Impacts on Salmon Ecosystems of Bristol Bay, Alaska (Final Report). U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Washington, DC, EPA 910-R-14-001A-C, ES, 2014. Chapter 5. United Tribes of Bristol Bay. Opposition to Pebble Mine Reiterated by local tribes, fishermen, business owners. http://utbb.org/opposition-to-pebble-mine-reiterated-by-local-tribes-fishermen-business-owners/
Alaska Bristol Bay Mining Ban, Ballot Measure 4 (2014). https://ballotpedia.org/Alaska_Bristol_Bay_Mining_Ban,_Ballot_Measure_4_(2014)

My husband and I just returned from a trip to Alaska where we experienced the unbelievable beauty and wildlife of our 49th state. We kayaked and fished in Prince William Sound and Bristol Bay, hiked in Denali National Park tp see moose, bears, caribou and the state bird the Ptarmagan,and toured the Kenai Peninsula where we saw whales, porpoises, otters, seals, sea lions, many Bald eagles, and many other bird species. I just don't get it. 
WE NEED TO PROTECT THE BRISTOL BAY WATERSHED NOW.

Comment: I am strongly opposed to the EPA's proposed withdrawal of Clean Water Act restrictions for the Pebble Mine. This mine has the potential to seriously impact one of the most pristine, valuable ecosystem we have. The possibility of significant adverse effects have already been identified. The health of the Bristol Bay watershed is extremely important for, among other things, a wide range of recreation opportunities that greatly benefit Alaska's economy and benefit the residents and non-residents who engage in fishing, wildlife viewing, etc. The salmon fishery is the most valuable commercial fishery in Aaska. It would be completely irresponsible to ignore the negative impacts to Alaska's economy, residents, and millions of tourists who visit each year, for one mine. It's not worth it.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment: I am strongly opposed to the Trump administration's proposal to withdraw the EPA determination on Pebble Mine, Bristol Bay, Alaska.  This determination was made after extensive and scientifically-based peer review, with extensive comments taken into account.  The EPA determined that there is potential severe environmental harm with proceeding with the Pebble Mine, including failure of proposed dams and containment.  Bristol Bay is home to the largest sockeye salmon fishery in the world -- and we have seen declining salmon populations all over the lower 48, so we have few of these vital resources to preserve.  Both local residents and the residents of Alaska are overwhelmingly opposed to removing EPA protections to this pristine habitat.  It is a total travesty to withdraw the 2014 determination against all good science and protection of our natural resources.  I am a retired state environmental scientist and have taken part in many peer reviews on natural resources, including salmon habitats, and seen too much environmental damage when the science is ignored.  I have also spent time in Alaska and I feel a deep love for the wild beauty and wildlife there -- we should protect this wonderful place, not destroy it.  NO to this proposed action!
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I am writing you today to ask that you stand with American jobs and communities and not withdraw the Bristol Bay Proposed Determination, which it made pursuant to the Clean Water Act in 2014.

As you know, Bristol Bay, Alaska, is one of America's last great wild salmon fisheries. Tens of millions of wild salmon return annually, which support upwards of 14,000 American jobs in the commercial and sport fishing industries, serve as a one-in-a-lifetime destination for anglers from around the world, and are the cultural cornerstone for the region's communities.

These long-established American businesses and jobs are at risk from a foreign-owned mining company that wants to build the proposed Pebble Mine, which is opposed by more than 65 percent of Alaskans and more than 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents. 

In 2010, led by Alaska Native Tribes, interests including commercial fishing business owners and sportsmen asked the EPA step in to ensure that this mine wouldn't jeopardize Bristol Bay. The EPA responded by listening to over 1.5 million Americans, hosting dozens of community meetings, reviewing Pebble's many detailed filings with state and federal agencies, and conducting a twice peer-reviewed scientific assessment of the potential impacts to the region.

Withdrawing the proposed determination ignores the overwhelming majority of Alaskans and puts the short-term interests of a foreign mining company above thousands of American jobs. 

Please do not withdraw the proposed determination.

Title: Comment submitted by J. Ross
Comment:
Dear Madam or Sir,

I am unalterably opposed to withdrawing the EPA's proposed determination lifting restrictions on Pebble Mine's treatment of debris and discharge of waste water in the headwaters of Bristol Bay. So doing will poison the breeding grounds of the world's greatest population of red salmon.

Withdrawing the restrictions 1) threatens the future of Bristol Bay's commercial and recreational fishery which generates annually more than $500 million and more than 1,000 jobs in small towns in the watershed and 2) opens the door to exploitation of similar low-grade ore deposits throughout Alaska.

Further, Bristol Bay's unstable geology is plagued by earthquakes. The mine is located in the fault zone which experienced a 7.1 scale earthquake (Iniskin Quake) last year. A quake similar to the one which rocked Anchorage in 1964 could devastate not only waste treatment facilities, but the mine itself.

So flimsy is financing behind Northern Dynasty Minerals, owner of Pebble mining rights, and so scant is the prospect for expansion in the world's copper market, that it's very doubtful that the company can attract capital to ensure safe operation of the mine and related infrastructure during and beyond its proposed 78-year lifespan. 

Thank you for considering my comments. 

John Ross,
PO Box 5554
Asheville, NC 28813

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I do NOT want the EPA to withdraw the July 2014 Proposed Determination to restrict mining of the Pebble deposit.

Mining the Pebble Mine in the Bristol Bay Watershed, Alaska would entail numerous risks, including:
	Extensive quantities of mine waste, leachates and wastewater which would have to be collected, stored, treated and managed during mining and long after mining concludes.
	Failure of a tailings storage facility dam that released only a partial volume of the stored tailings would result in catastrophic effects on fishery resources.
	Many miles of streams and acres of wetlands would be destroyed.
	Construction and operation of a transportation corridor from the mine site to Cook Inlet would put salmon spawning areas in and near Iliamna Lake at risk.

Please give The Pebble Project a fighting chance

Please withdraw from pursuing any further action against the Pebble Project. 

I strongly believe in preserving the environment for future generations. A main concern of mine is we all need the vital resources that are underground ready to mined at the proposed Pebble Site. Our Country and the world needs these resources. The United States have environmental conscious regulations that keep our waterways and soil protected for future generations. If we veto any proposed mine in the United States it will force us to purchase those minerals elsewhere, and those minerals come from Countries that can care less about the environment damaging the environment to dangerous levels. It is best for the economy and for the environment to mine here in America, where we have environmental conscious regulations, rather than to resort to purchasing minerals from other Countries that simply do not care a about the environment. 

A little about me
I recently had to move out of Alaska, could not find a job other than a low paying Mcdonalds wage. I previously worked in the land surveying profession and there is virtually no surveying jobs in Alaska. This mine gives hope to the poverty stricken Alaskans, it will not only help the villages and groups of minorities but it will also aid in taking Alaska out of the skyrocketing budget deficit it currently faces. I am very poor, I live with my wife and two kids in Central Oregon and picking pine cones in the National Forest to pay the bills, but only get $5 per bag. This mine would provide a way out for people like me and so many Alaskans, a means to put food on the table and a paycheck to keep the lights on. Not only the direct jobs but its also the indirect jobs it will provide. The mine will need laborers, engineers, architects, contractors, land surveyors, heavy equipment, equipment operators, project managers,  motels, the list goes on and on. The truth of the matter is it will provide incredible job creation and yet keep mining in our home land where we do care about the environment rather than shipping our jobs overseas and letting them poison the waterways in other parts of the world. 

I strongly believe in the Pebble Project, I strongly believe it can be constructed conscious to the environment. 

Please let this mine move forward, it will give people like myself hopes and dreams. So many Alaskans struggle with alcoholism, drugs, violence and the list goes on. Having a means to provide a middle class wage and a way to raise a family will keep their minds from idle and more likely to go after their dreams and goals rather than to resort to an epidemic that is happening in some of the Alaskan villiages. 

Please, please let this mine move forward without harsh backlash, it will benefit not just Alaska but the entire world.

PLEASE give it a chance, it can and will be constructed in a matter that will keep the fish unharmed. 

Thank you for taking your time to read my email

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
The EPA estimates that mining scenarios reflecting the potential scope of impact from a mine such as that proposed by Pebble mine would result in the loss of between 5-50+ miles of spawning habitat for Salmon species, trout as well as Dolly Varden.

Furthermore, the EPAs own assessment identifies that water quality in the Bristol Bay watershed would be measurably diminished through leachate resulting from tailings, as well as routine operations.  Increased copper levels would have a direct effect on salmonids ranging from avoidance of the contaminated habitat to rapidly induced death of many or all fish.

A determination to withdraw the EPA's prior decision to restrict mining operations and disposal of tailings consistent with the authority and purpose of the Clean Water Act is an abdication of your responsibility as the Environmental Protection Agency.

I am writing you today to ask that you not withdraw the Bristol Bay Proposed Determination, made pursuant to the Clean Water Act in 2014.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
EPA's unprecedented move to initiate a preemptive veto sent shock waves through the entire regulated community and threatened to undermine the federal environmental permitting system, to say nothing of the devastating effects the specific veto would have on Bristol Bay's local economy. 

In the published notice in the Federal Register, the EPA noted that withdrawing the Proposed Determination "would remove any uncertainty, real or perceived, about PLP's ability to submit a permit application and have the permit application reviewed."

The American Exploration & Mining Association warned that EPA's actions at Pebble are "sending a chilling message to the business and investment community, and has had a negative impact on exploration and mining projects not only in Alaska, but the entire United States. In fact, the world and its investment community are watching. EPA's action at Pebble will clearly indicate whether the United States is open for investment, or closed to innovation, opportunity and job creation."

Ruling against a project at the end of an open process that prioritized science and informed decision-making is a possibility every investor faces.  Investors do not expect, however, to be shut out of a contrived, one-sided process from the beginning and informed of the rejection at the end.  That is exactly what EPA did to PLP when it initiated the preemptive veto here 

The harmful effects of continuing with EPA's veto process will go well beyond the mining industry, as 404 permits are required in so many circumstances that they affect every area of our economy.  

The Corps processes approximately 60,000 permits a year, and, according to some estimates, roughly $220 billion of investment per year depends on these permits.  These investors expect regulators to place reasonable restrictions on projects; they typically do not expect regulators to make preemptive decisions based on new policy courses before an application is even submitted.  For the process to be fair, developers must have a full opportunity to present plans, defend science, and modify projects to meet legitimate concerns.  This is good policy; it is also the law.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I urge the EPA NOT to withdraw the proposed determination to adopt restrictions protecting the habitat of Bristol Bay's world-renowned salmon.

The proposed determination was based on years of rigorous scientific study, public participation and peer review. The EPA was correct in 2014 when it found that the Pebble Mine would have "significant and unacceptable adverse effects" on "one of the most productive, pristine, valuable and vulnerable ecosystems remaining in North America today."

The EPA noted that commercial fishing in Bristol Bay generates $300 million annually in direct sales of commercially caught salmon, generating 11,000 jobs. These salmon also support a traditional Native way of life that still thrives today.

The EPA should stand by its proposed determination and take all necessary actions to protect the Bristol Bay watershed.

Title: Comment submitted by J. Griffiths
Comment:
To the Acting Regional Administrator, EPA Region 10 and Administrator Pruitt,

My public comment is to recommend against the withdrawal of the July 2014 Proposed Determination and, if a withdrawal decision is made, I recommend that the Administrator should review and reconsider to prevent the withdrawal. 

In the attached document you will find my full comment and reasons for my recommendation against the withdrawal of the Proposed Determination. 

In brief:
(1) The settlement does not require that the withdrawal should occur if there is no basis to the reasons for the withdrawal. 
(2) There can be no misunderstanding or confusion on the part of the PLP about whether or not a permit can be submitted to the Army Corps while the Proposed Determination is in effect.  EPA-R10-OW-2017-0369 clearly states that "EPA Region 10's initiation of the section 404(c) process did not prohibit PLP from filing a permit application and the Army Corps could have processed such a permit application while a section 404(c) review was ongoing."   
(3) The existence of the Proposed determination did not prevent PLP from filing a permit with the Army Corps. This proposal has failed to explain why LPL should be provided more time give that they have had at least since (but even before) the July 2014 Proposed Determination to apply for a permit with the Army Corps but they have failed to do so in the subsequent three years.  Moreover, as the Proposed Determination does not prevent the filing of a permit in the future, the stated cause of "additional time" has no basis.
(4) EPA-R10-OW-2017-0369 states  "the Agency believes that withdrawing the Proposed Determination now, while allowing the factual record regarding any forthcoming permit application to develop, is appropriate at this time for this particular matter. *Why the Proposed determine should not be withdrawn*: The statement cited here is included in the paragraph of stated reasons for withdrawal.  It is impossible to evaluate this statement and it provides no substantive argument for the claims.  Why is this an appropriate action?  Why for this time and place?  The EPA needs to provide more substantial arguments as to why 10-years of scientific research, synthesis and public comment and the Proposed Determination that came out of that work should suddenly be withdrawn because it is "appropriate."
(5) Furthermore, the withdrawal of the Proposed Determination, rather than increasing in the efficiency of the permitting process, would make it less efficient and effective.  Taxpayers support the 10-years of work that led to the Proposed Determination. If the settlement was supposed to prevent costly litigation then the EPA should not waste the taxpayer's dollars by doing away with an incredibly valuable and highly rigorous document that the tax payers spent 10 years paying for. 

Finally, if the Regional Administrators approves a withdrawal, the Administrator should reconsider.  It is unconscionable that EPA should abdicate its 404(c) authority in this way by withdrawing the Proposed Determination.  The proposed withdrawal is not consistent with the Agency's mission as stated on the EPA website (https://www.epa.gov/aboutepa/our-mission-and-what-we-do). The Proposed Determination found that there were significant risks of mining in the Bristol Bay watershed and it is EPA's mission to ensure "all Americans are protected from significant risks to human health and the environment where they live, learn and work."  EPA's mission is also that "national efforts to reduce environmental risk are based on the best available scientific information" and it is clear that the Proposed Determination had robust, extensive expert review resulting in it reflecting the best available science that should be part of the Army 404(c) permit process. The mission is also that "federal laws protecting human health and the environment are enforced fairly and effectively" - a 10-year process to obtain the determination, with ample opportunities for PLP to engage is a fair enforcement while withdrawing the Proposed Determination would be a less effective enforcement.  

Ultimately, the overall mission of the EPA is "to protect human health and the environment" (https://www.epa.gov/aboutepa). Fulfilling this mission should be the only priority of the EPA Administrator and withdrawing the Proposed Determination is in direct conflict with this mission statement. Removing the Proposed Determination will result in a potential permitting process that does not ensure that human health and the environment have the best available science and risk reduction recommendations considered. Therefore, the Administrator should reconsider and prevent any withdrawal of the Proposed Determination.

Thank you for considering my comment,
Jennifer Griffiths

Title: Comment submitted by D. Gordon-Murer
Comment:
The proposed Clean Water Act determination should NOT be withdrawn. The potential impacts of the proposed Pebble Mine on the health of the Bristol Bay watershed and the livelihood of thousands of people in Alaska are far too great. Those risks include loss of up to up to 94 miles of salmon-supporting streams and up to 4,900 acres of wetlands and ponds, and the very real potential of wastewater dam failure resulting in damage to or destruction of the salmon fishery. The watershed supports the largest sockeye salmon fishery in the world and 25 federally recognized tribes who for 4,000 years have depended on the fishery for their subsistence-based culture. The overwhelming majority of residents of Bristol Bay are opposed to the project, and a statewide majority of voters also oppose it. The watersheds unique ecological resources generate significant economic benefits and employment. EPAs original watershed assessment was scientifically robust and thoroughly peer-reviewed. That assessment and related public comments should strongly influence any future action.


Debra Gordon-Murer
