Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
Please do not consider withdrawing needed EPA protections from Bristol Bay. 

The Pebble Mine prospect is the wrong mine in the wrong place. Bristol Bay's salmon fishery are integral to food security worldwide and critical to local subsistence, as well as to economic survival of commercial fishermen, tribes, sportsmen, tourist operators, chefs and local businesses. This productive and responsibly managed fishery is the largest wild salmon run in the world. Developing the largest mine in North America on top this sensitive and wild eco-system is short sighted, valuing mining profits over long-term sustainable economic gains and food security through fishing. 

Bristol Bay salmon runs are worth preserving. They have thrived for thousands of years and could continue to do so. Their preservation should be the fundamental priority in this area. 

Please do not even consider short-term mine profits that would threaten the Bristol Bay fishery and way of life. It is far too risky to put mine on such a critically important and fragile ecosystem. 

Monique Couture
Commercial Fisherman

Title: Comment submitted by M. Gimera
Comment:
In Re: The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Notice: Proposed Determination to Restrict Use of Area as Disposal Site: Pebble Deposit Area, Southwest Alaska; Proposed Withdrawal.

It is my belief that the Pebble mine should be allowed to proceed; that new clean mining technologies allow for the co-existence of mining and clean water/fisheries in the region.

I am in full support of Scott Pruitt removing E.P.A. Roadblocks to the permitting and development of a facility that would enrich the State of Alaska with jobs, infrastructure and tax revenue.

While nobody wants to see the earth polluted, watersheds destroyed or wildlife harmed, especially in a beautiful and pristine wilderness area; those same people generally do not want to see all progress halted, nor their State & Nation driven into poverty.  Those same people would prefer not to be personally driven to poverty and left destitute by overreaching draconian "policies and procedures".

Much of the outcry on the issue is based on assumptions about mining that are outdated.  And I reiterate that many advances have been made in mining technologies, making processes "Green" and in many cases having no or minimal impact on the environment.  Is this the only mine in Alaska?  Is it going to destroy the entire state?  Will it have any effect on fisheries for hundreds of miles around?  I think the answers to all those questions is a resounding NO.  Which begs the question: What is the point to the regulatory bulwark?  There is no point.

I urge for progress and support the removal of E.P.A. interference in the area.

Kind Regards,
Mike Gimera

Title: Comment submitted by F. Yaeger
Comment:
I write this comment in regard to the Proposal to Withdraw Proposed Determination to Restrict the Use of an Area as a Disposal Site; Pebble Deposit Area in Southwest Alaska.

If the proposed withdrawal is granted/approved, it will most assuredly result in the PLP (Pebble Limited Partnership) and its subsidiary Northern Dynasty Minerals Limited creating a copper-gold mine within the Bristol Bay Watershed, including creation of a tailings storage facility dam to store tailings created by development of said mine.

That watershed is home to a very large percentage of all the wild sockeye salmon (over 45%) that are responsibly caught for human consumption.  Wild sockeye salmon are a resource of great value to humans.  While some people may deem the risk of partial failure of the dam to contain/confine stored tailings as an acceptable risk, I do not.  The destruction to sockeye salmon fishermen businesses would be quite devastating.  And, the loss of this food would be too.

The failure of other retention dams in other parts of the US have resulted in devastating affects on human life nearby and on nearby non-human life.  I believe the risk of dam failure is too high to justify withdrawal of the Determination to Restrict the proposed mining use.

Respectfully submitted by Fred Yaeger, 3890 Drakewood Drive, Cincinnati, OH 45209

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I urge the EPA NOT to withdraw the proposed determination to adopt restrictions protecting the habitat of Bristol Bay's world-renowned salmon.

The proposed determination was based on years of rigorous scientific study, public participation and peer review. The EPA was correct in 2014 when it found that the Pebble Mine would have "significant and unacceptable adverse effects" on "one of the most productive, pristine, valuable and vulnerable ecosystems remaining in North America today."

The EPA noted that commercial fishing in Bristol Bay generates $300 million annually in direct sales of commercially caught salmon, generating 11,000 jobs. These salmon also support a traditional Native way of life that still thrives today.

The EPA should stand by its proposed determination and take all necessary actions to protect the Bristol Bay watershed

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
The proposed Clean Water Act determination should NOT be withdrawn. 

Bristol Bay is a crucial component of the ecosystem that supports the largest sockeye salmon fishery in the world. Thousands of individuals rely on this fishery for sustenance, and the risk of wastewater dam failure destroying this important natural resource is far too great.

It is my understanding that the EPA has already conducted a scientifically rigorous, peer-reviewed evaluation of this watershed and found it to have significant economic and ecological benefits that would be threatened by the proposed Pebble Mine. Furthermore, the majority of statewide voters and Bristol Bay residents are opposed to the Pebble project. The original EPA assessment in combination with these public comments from local residents should be more than enough evidence to preserve the initial CWA determination.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I oppose the proposed withdrawal of Clean Water Act protection for the Bristol Bay watershed, which would be threatened by the Pebble Mine. The Bristol Bay watershed deserves the highest levels of protection the Clean Water Act can provide because it is home to a fishery resource of global importance, including the largest sockeye salmon fishery in the world.

According to EPA's own documents (U.S. EPA. An Assessment of Potential Mining Impacts on Salmon Ecosystems of Bristol Bay, Alaska (Final Report). U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Washington, DC, EPA 910-R-14-001A-C, ES, 2014. Chapter 5.), the watershed's ecological resources generated nearly a half a billion dollars in direct economic activity and provided more than 14,000 jobs in 2009 alone. Importantly, this valuable economic activity is sustained by the renewable nature of the ecological resources that underlie it.

In addition to being a resource of enormous economic importance, the Bristol Bay watershed is extremely significant from a cultural standpoint because it has been a source of Alaskan Native People's subsistence for at least four millennia. Only by maintaining the fullest protections afforded by the Clean Water Act can our Nation ensure that the irreplaceable ecological resources of the watershed will continue to provide subsistence, jobs and salmon for a worldwide market

Mining and the infrastructure required to support it in this area is simply too risky, and Northern Dynasty, the company that wants to exploit the mineral deposits in the watershed, does not appear to have the technical and financial capability to operate in a way that would protect Bristol Bay and its watershed. Thus, EPA should not withdraw its July 2014 determination restricting dumping of mining waste in the Bristol Bay watershed.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
Reference: docket number EPA-R10-OW-2017-0369

Please reconsider withdrawing the 2014 Proposed Determination allowing Pebble Mine to begin its application for the mine. Plans for Pebble Mine SHOULD NOT BE ALLOWED TO CONTINUE. 

Three of Bristol Bay's eight major rivers, The Kvichak (Kwee-Jack), Naknek, and Nushagek, collectively support the greatest wild salmon fishery in the world. The sockeye salmon are at the center of the ecosystem. Their eggs and their flesh, once the salmon die after spawning, feed everything in the system, from invertebrates and bears, to eagles, wolves, beluga and killer whales. A negative impact on the sockeye population could result in the collapse of the ecosystem. It would also create a collapse of an incredibly important fishing industry.

The proposed Pebble Mine is to be situated immediately up-gradient of this renowned, salmon fishery

EPA has a part of the Clean Water Act called Section 404(c), which allows the EPA to "restrict, prohibit, deny or withdraw the use of an area as a disposal site for dredged or fill material if the discharge will have unacceptable adverse effects on municipal water supplies, shellfish beds and fishery areas, wildlife or recreational areas." There are many reasons that the mine should not be allowed to progress, and that the Proposed Determination should not be withdrawn. The notice for public comment states that EPA "is not soliciting comment on the proposed restrictions or on science or technical information underlying the Proposed Determination." HOW else do you make this type of decision? Since there is not another way to make that decision, I am adding some science below. 

The proposed site has sulfide rock that when exposed to air and water creates acid that can increase copper and other harmful pollutants concentrations downstream. Rain can also mobilize and wash copper and other pollutants into salmon habitat. Copper in small amounts can be lethal and have sub-lethal effects that increases mortality rates and decrease survival and production. Salmon and their food sources have a very low tolerance for this pollutant [copper]
The mine site includes an open pit along with a road. Two toxic tailing lakes would be required, contained by earthen dams. These dams would be huge.  While NDM states it will use a layer of water on top of the tailing lakes to help limit available oxygen (thus the amount of acid and metals created) these earthen dams would be sited in a seismically active region with volatile weather patterns, extreme flooding events, severe winters, and high winds. The dams would also need to contain the tailings and would need permanent maintenance, not just for decades, but forever, long after NDM is gone.


Even economic prognosis of this project is poor: A number of the world's largest mining corporations have pulled out of the project, including Mitsubishi, Rio Tinto and Anglo American - the last of which had about $500 million in the project. Why ruin an ecosystem for companies that are not sure it will a valuable asset?

PLEASE do not withdraw the Proposed Determination that prevents Pebble from progressing.

Title: Anonymous public comment

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
The following comments relate to Docket ID: EPA-R10-OW-2017-0369.

The potential impacts of the proposed Pebble Mine on the health of the Bristol Bay watershed and the livelihood of thousands of people in Alaska are too great to accept:

The watershed supports the largest sockeye salmon fishery in the world.

The watershed is home to 25 federally recognized tribal governments who have maintained a salmon-based culture and subsistence-based way of life for at least 4,000 years that would be placed in jeopardy.

The watershed's ecological resources generated nearly $480 million in direct economic expenditures and sales and provided employment for over 14,000 full- and part-time workers in 2009.

Contrary to comments by the backers of the Pebble Mine project, EPA's watershed assessment was scientifically based and thoroughly peer-reviewed, and the public has had an extensive opportunity to comment on it. The assessment and public comments received should be key components of any future action on this issue.

The overwhelming majority of residents of Bristol Bay are opposed to the project.  A statewide majority of voters also oppose it, as evidenced by the 2014 State-wide ballot measure.

The rationale for the proposed withdrawal is flawed. Finalizing the proposed determination would provide much more regulatory certainty than withdrawing it, and a permit application is not needed to augment the factual record.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I request that you do not withdraw the EPA Region 10 July 2014 Proposed Determination that was issued under the Clean Water Act, to restrict the use of waters in the Koktuli River and Upper Talarik Creek watersheds in southwest Alaska as disposal sites for tailings that would result from mining the Pebble ore body.

This area is the epicenter of the most productive salmon habitat in the world.  Upper Talarik Creek is a tributary to Lake Iliamna, and the Koktuli is a tributary of the Nushagak River. Opening the doors to let mine operators dump tailings in these waters will poison and devastate this hugely valuable sustainable natural resource. The July 2014 determination was made for a great quantity of good reasons, and should not be reversed.

I live in Bellingham, Washington. I know many fellow residents, commercial fishermen, whose livelihood depends on the Bristol Bay fishery. It is no good trading a vast natural resource with a rich and sustainable economic impact for a one-time harvest of minerals with its irreversible destruction, for the benefit of foreign companies. I have seen these mining operations and the destruction they cause, in Canada, Chile, Colorado, Utah, Indonesia. Some of these mines were opened over a hundred years ago, and they are still leaching uncontrolled acid mine drainage into natural waters. They without exception create permanent sacrifice areas and destroyed streams for the rest of time -- despite the bland promises and pious assurances of the mine interests that everything will be ok and no damage will happen.

It is extremely important that the 2014 determination not be withdrawn.

Sincerely,

Peter Willing

Bellingham, Washington

Title: Anonymous public comment

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment: It is outrageous that the EPA is now proposing to withdraw the restrictions it recommended earlier to protect Bristol Bay from mining. Allowing the Pepple Mine to proceed would be foolhardy. This open pit gold and copper mine would produce mountains of hazardous waste at the headwaters of Bristol Bay which would be contained by huge (60 story plus) earthen dams. Yet this is an active earthquake zone! A similar containment dam failed in 2014 at the Mount Polly copper and gold mine in British Columbia decimating the surrounding area. President Obama's EPA decided after much studying that mega-mines like the proposed Pebble Mine would likely destroy the ecology of Bristol Bay and its headwaters and therefore should be prohibited. The science and the risks have not changed. Preventing adoption of the protective restrictions proposed by the EPA earlier could well be the death knell for the most important sock eye salmon fishing industry in the world and could destroy one of the ecologically richest regions of the world. Alaskans are against this project, their fishing and tourism industries risk great losses. This mine would not benefit America, more likely it would destroy a great part of America.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
Please ensure previous withdrawal baseline information and decisions made from baseline are bias free, and not politically or economically driven.  If the areas under current withdrawal are based on factual investigation as it relates to existing and future fisheries condition and overall habitat/water quality, the withdrawal determination should stand in whole or part. If not, these watersheds should be re-evaluated for focused withdrawal now or as included during the NEPA process in the alternative, mitigation discussion in order  to select the preferred alternative.   This NEPA document is required to assess all related and connected activities, not just the USACE action. Additionally the NEPA document is required to include an in-depth discussion of cumulative and foreseeable future (overlay similar mine development in the same area and environmental setting) impacts of all proposed activities and alternatives (port, power, roads and all support/ancillary facilities and related activities) including waterways, wetlands and fishery habitat among others. 

Thank you.

Title: Comment submitted by Mary S.
Comment:
Docket #EPA-R10-OW-2017-0369

This comment is submitted regarding the EPA's Proposed Determination on the Pebble Mine under Section 404(c) of the Clean Water Act.

I support and agree with the EPA's finding that mining activity on any level within the Bristol Bay, Alaska watershed poses unacceptable risks to the fragile Bristol Bay watershed.  The watershed is a fragile ecosystem of global significance that supports almost half of the world's sockeye salmon population.  Any sort of mining development or mining accident will directly cause irreversible environmental damage.  The watershed supports 14,000 jobs and generates hundreds of millions of dollars annually in economic activity. 

The EPA's own analysis found that the proposed mine would harm this critically important watershed and I support a decision to move forward with the EPA Proposed Determination on the Pebble Mine under Section 404(c) of the Clean Water Act without further delay.

Sincerely,
Mary S.
Washington State

Title: Comment submitted by R. Carle
Comment:
Dear EPA, 
Please do not withdraw the Bristol Bay Proposed Determination, which it made pursuant to the Clean Water Act in 2014.

Bristol Bay, Alaska, is one of America's last great wild salmon fisheries, supporting tens of millions of wild running salmon. The region support thousands of fisheries and recreation-based jobs that would be jeopardized by using these watersheds as a dump for mining waste. 65% of Alaskans and 80% of Bristol Bay residents oppose the proposed Pebble Mine. 

In 2010, led by Alaska Native Tribes, interests including commercial fishing business owners and sportsmen asked the EPA step in to ensure that this mine wouldn't jeopardize Bristol Bay. The EPA responded by listening to over 1.5 million Americans, hosting dozens of community meetings, reviewing Pebble's many detailed filings with state and federal agencies, and conducting a twice peer-reviewed scientific assessment of the potential impacts to the region.

Withdrawing the proposed determination ignores the overwhelming majority of Alaskans and puts the short-term interests of a foreign mining company above thousands of American jobs. 
Sincerely, 
Ryan Carle 

Please do not withdraw the proposed determination.

In 2010, led by Alaska Native Tribes, commercial fishing business owners, sportsmen and others asked the EPA to ensure that this mine wouldn't jeopardize Bristol Bay. The EPA responded by listening to over 1.5 million Americans, hosting dozens of community meetings, reviewing the mine's many detailed filings with state and federal agencies, and conducting a twice peer-reviewed scientific assessment of the potential impacts to the region.

Withdrawing the proposed determination ignores the overwhelming majority of Alaskans and puts the short-term interests of a foreign mining company above thousands of American jobs.

Please do not withdraw the proposed determination.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I am writing to request that the EPA  not change the protections it itself put in place for the Bristol Bay salmon fishery waters.
Please do not withdraw the Bristol Bay Proposed Determination,  made in accord with the guidelines of the Clean Water Act, in 2014.

The native people and others who fish these waters, the fish stocks themselves, are of immeasurable value, economic and ecological. Local residents of Bristol Bay themselves requested this protection be put in place. To allow the interests of a foreign mining company to jeopardize fishery and tourism jobs is short sighted and goes against this administration's stated belief in "America First." 

An excellent decision was made after peer reviewed scientific study and significant community input. To reverse that decision is a slap in the face of all the citizens who participated in this process, and a wasting of not only the funds spent in that process but of future resources for many generations.

Title: Mass comment campaign sponsoring organization unknown. Sample attached (web)
Abstract: 21 similar comments have been received to date for this web campaign
Comment:
As a concerned voter and a seafood lover who cares about responsible stewardship, I respectfully urge the Environmental Protection Agency to ensure that the Bristol Bay watershed is off limits to mining activity. Please do not withdraw EPA's July 2014 Proposed Determination to restrict the use of the watershed for disposal activity associated with mining the Pebble deposit.

The proposed open-pit Pebble gold mine poses an unacceptable risk to Bristol Bay, a world-class fishery that supplies 40 percent of the fresh seafood caught annually in the United States, producing more than $2.4 billion annually in economic value.

Bristol Bay is the heart of this nation's seafood industry. Its waters produce an abundance of King Crab, halibut, cod, herring, pollock, and salmon - including the world's largest wild run of Sockeye Salmon. As an economic engine and a vital natural resource, Bristol Bay is a national treasure deserving of our most diligent stewardship.

There could not be a worse place to locate a large mining operation, which includes huge toxic tailings lagoons. In addition to destroying more than 22 square miles of this vital watershed, the risk of a dam blowout is high due to a high level of geologic activity in the area, including volcanoes and earthquakes. Such a blowout would devastate the Alaska fishing industry and one of America's most productive natural resources.

No doubt, this is why more than 80 percent of those who live in the region oppose the Pebble Mine proposal being pursued by the foreign-owned Pebble Limited Partnership.

The fisheries and clean water of Bristol Bay are too ecologically, economically, and societally important for Alaska and our nation to jeopardize them with a massive, risky and non-essential project.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment submitted by L. Grisby III
Comment:
Please. The proposed Clean Water Act determination should NOT be withdrawn. 

I fear the potential impacts of the proposed Pebble Mine on the health of the Bristol Bay watershed and the livelihood of thousands of people in Alaska are far too great. Some of those risks include loss of up to up to 94 miles of salmon-supporting streams and up to 4,900 acres of wetlands and ponds, and the very real potential of wastewater dam failure resulting in damage to or destruction of the salmon fishery. The watershed supports the largest sockeye salmon fishery in the world and 25 federally recognized tribes who have depended on the fishery for their subsistence-based culture. The overwhelming majority of residents of Bristol Bay are opposed to the project, and a statewide majority of voters also oppose it. Listen to and act on their concerns. The watersheds unique ecological resources generate significant economic benefits and employment. EPAs original watershed assessment was scientifically robust and thoroughly peer-reviewed. That assessment and related public comments should strongly influence any future action.

References:
U.S. EPA. An Assessment of Potential Mining Impacts on Salmon Ecosystems of Bristol Bay, Alaska (Final Report). U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Washington, DC, EPA 910-R-14-001A-C, ES, 2014.
EPA Region 10, Proposed Determination Pursuant to Section 404(c) of the Clean Water Act for Pebble Deposit Area, Southwest Alaska, July 21, 2014.
2017 EPA and Pebble Limited Partnership Agreement.
U.S. EPA. An Assessment of Potential Mining Impacts on Salmon Ecosystems of Bristol Bay, Alaska (Final Report). U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Washington, DC, EPA 910-R-14-001A-C, ES, 2014. Chapter 5.
United Tribes of Bristol Bay. Opposition to Pebble Mine Reiterated by local tribes, fishermen, business owners.
Alaska Bristol Bay Mining Ban, Ballot Measure 4 (2014).
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I am writing ask the EPA stand with American jobs and communities by not withdrawing the Bristol Bay Proposed Determination, which it made pursuant to the Clean Water Act in 2014.

Bristol Bay, Alaska, is one of America's last great wild salmon fisheries. Tens of millions of wild salmon return annually, which support upwards of 14,000 American jobs in the commercial and sport fishing industries, serve as a one-in-a-lifetime destination for anglers from around the world, and are the cultural cornerstone for the region's communities.These long-established American businesses and jobs are at risk from a foreign-owned mining company that wants to build the proposed Pebble Mine, which is opposed by more than 65 percent of Alaskans and more than 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents.


Even investors are have found the Pebble Project to be an unworthy investment. 

John Doody, gold stock analyst, stated in an interview that "The problem is that the deposit doesn't work... [the pebble deposit may] have tens of millions of ounces, but there are a billion ounces [of gold] in the ocean that doesn't mean it is economic to go get it"; "The problem is that the economics don't work in Northern Dynasty's Pebble Project" he continues. 


After calculating the total desired mineral concentration (gold, copper, silver and Molybdenum combined), with Pebble Partnership's data,  is .0472%, which is very low grade ore. It also means that there will be about 10.7949 billion tons of waste rock from the 10.8 billion tons of ore. The Pebble Partnership claims that, in addition to a 1300 acre mine pit (that is about 4000 ft deep), a 3600 acre tailings compound and a  2300 acre waste rock pile, there will be a processing plant and a natural gas power plant. The Pebble Partnership also claims that there will be four 86-mile buried pipelines to transport mineral concentrates, water and fuel to the Iniskin Bay Port to be shipped away.  The mine has been estimated to use over 36 million gallons of diesel fuel a year and 378 MW of electricity, which is equivalent to 21.6% of Alaska's total energy capacity. It would also use 35 billion gallons of fresh water per year- more water than the entire city of Anchorage uses.

There are a multitude of potential issues that can occur. The buried pipelines that care mineral concentrates and fuel could leak unnoticed due to extreme temperature changes and ground movements from dynamite use. The fuel and concentrates could also spill while at the port. With its remote location it is very far from rescue  and spill response teams. A pit that goes that far into the ground could breach numerous streams and aquifers, the pit would fill faster than it's being pumped, much like the Berkeley Pit Mine in Montana. The extensive glacial gravel deposits in the region are highly permeable and that can allow mine waste to move from between surface and groundwater. 

Even without any accidents or spills, the Pebble Mine would have an extremely big environmental footprint that would eliminate 87 miles of salmon streams and at least 4200 acres of critical wetland habitat. Taking away billions of gallons of groundwater from the Bristol Bay watershed could also lower the flow of the streams and tributaries that feed into the Nushagak and Kvichak Rivers.  The mining operation would require the use of: greases, antifreeze, water treatment chemicals, herbicides, pesticides, and road deicing compounds. These substances can come in contact with groundwater and rivers through runoff, harming any aquatic life present.The total carbon dioxide emissions have been estimated to be around 1.9 million tons per year, contributing to ocean acidification and climate change. Even if leached waste material doesn't harm salmon directly, tiny traces of it can hinder the development of the eggs and kill off zooplankton-the salmon's primary food source. Salmon are very fatty fish, which mean that they can store traces of pollutants and heavy metals in their fatty tissue through bioaccumulation. One of the reasons that make Alaskan wild-caught salmon so valuable is that the it has almost non-existent levels of mercury and pollutants because the waters they live in are so pristine and undeveloped. Therefore, even if loose tailings don't disturb adult fish, fry, or zooplankton etc. it would still lower the quality of the meat since there would be higher concentrations of pollutants in the fatty tissue of the fish.  

Please do not withdraw the proposed determination to restrict the proposed Pebble Mine.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment: Having been born and raised as an Alaskan I have grown up experiencing first-hand the many natural miracles that make up what is Alaska. Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
Yes to Pebble!  Yes to jobs!  and yes to Salmon too!

I am a life-long Alaskan, residing in Anchorage.  My background is in heavy equipment operation and road construction, and I can tell you the Pebble mine would be a great thing for us.  I have long suffered the cyclical nature of construction in Alaska, and a lucrative, year-round job like the ones Pebble will offer would be fantastic.  My son who is about to graduate high school could look to the Pebble mine as a potential for lifetime employment as well, as he plans to follow me into construction.

The people I have spoken to who oppose or are uninformed about Pebble, all seem to dwell on the mistaken idea that the mine will "wipeout all the salmon"  or "devastate the Bristol Bay".  As I have seen time and again, the environmentalists and extremists are painting a picture that is way over the top, and greatly understates the vast size of our State and resources, as well as the Bristol Bay itself.  I can't see a scenario where even a huge mine would do that.  And it's my understanding anyway that they are scaling it back to appease these groups, making such a thing even less likely.

I would be first in line to apply for a reliable, consistent job there.  I can tell you with my work experience I'd be a shoe-in and if not, I would defiantly be employed on the massive build-out of infrastructure necessary to make that mine a reality.  A win-win for myself, my family and the State too!

Over my working career I have seen the technology, techniques and safety standards in construction increase incredibly.  I have every bit of faith that the engineers designing this will do their jobs, and you folks at the EPA will do yours as well, insuring the highest standards are met.  I do it every day I'm at work, and I know you will to.  Many of our biggest projects have met with the same vocal resistance only to work out just fine and operate for decades problem-free.

Let the qualified professionals - and this includes yourselves - do their jobs and design, approve and build a state of the art mine, held to the highest safety standards, for all of us to profit from for generations to come.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
Hi, I hope that the EPA does not proceed with the withdrawal of the 2014 Proposed Determination. The Bristol Bay salmon fishery produces nearly 20% of all US salmon, and 46% of all sockeye salmon. The annual economic value of this business is $1.5 billion, and employs thousands of people.

The proposed Pebble Mine project -- and its toxic waste -- will put Bristol Bay at risk, and could have severe negative economic impact on the local economy. It will also create irreparable harm the environment in the immediate area, as well as to the wildlife, such as grizzly bears and wolves, who depend on salmon as a source of food, in and around the watershed. Finally, the thought of eating fish that would be swimming in and near the disposal site of the Pebble Mine project should be enough to make everyone sick.

Pebble Mine creates much more harm than good to both the environment and the economy. The proposed withdrawal should not proceed. We need to preserve this pristine and important area of the country, and save jobs and the local economy that depends so much on the annual salmon migration.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I agree that is is proper to withdraw the EPA Region 10 July 2014 Proposed Determination that was issued pursuant to Section 404(c) of the Clean Water Act, to restrict the use of certain waters in the region of the Pebble prospect.  The EPA has no right or authority to take such unprecedented preemptive action to shut down resource development anywhere, and especially not on State of Alaska lands which were selected for their mineral prospectively and conveyed to Alaska under terms of the Statehood Act.

The proposition that the development of one mine could destroy the Bristol Bay salmon fishery is ludicrous, even one the size of Bingham Canyon Mine in Utah.

There is a permitting process which is in place to ensure that if such a mine were to be developed, it would be developed in an environmentally responsible manner.

The State of Alaska's economy is based on natural resource development, and the Pebble mineral belt holds great potential to create long term employment, a local tax base in the region, and a general underpinning of the supply and logistics industries in south central Alaska.

Title: Meetings: Proposal to Withdraw Proposed Determination to Restrict the Use of an Area as a Disposal Site; Pebble Deposit Area, Southwest Alaska; Public Hearing
Abstract: Federal Register of September 21, 2017, (82 FR 44176)(FRL-9968-06-Region 10)
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
Northern Dynasty should be afforded due process!  Otherwise we have no democracy, just special interests on both sides flexing their ability to manipulate the system to meet their objectives.  I am a long time shareholder of NDM and would not want them to harm salmon but I do want the company to be given due process which includes a full review by Army Corp of Engineers.

If the mine can't be built safely then fisheries should win out.  If however, a mine can be built safely and if it can co-exist with salmon then it should allowed to proceed. After all, this area has been designated for mining.

Only after following due process with all of its checks and balances can we make the correct determination as to whether the mine belongs.  Only then can we believe and trust the results.  That is why I strongly believe the motion to withdraw should be enacted.  This would go a long ways to correcting a major injustice that has been inflicted on this company and hopefully would help restore badly needed faith in the system.  Either we believe in our checks and balances or we don't.  The real question here is whether or not this mine can co-exist with salmon.  Let's find out through proper channels and due process. 

I've already posted a version of this comment.  Was not certain whether or not it went through.  Just wanted to make sure my views were objectively shared.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
Dear EPA, 
Please do not withdraw the Bristol Bay Proposed Determination, which it made pursuant to the Clean Water Act in 2014.

It is critical that all watersheds supplying sockeye stocks to Bristol Bay be protected, as >70 years of study (Schindler, Quinn, and Hilborn, Univ. of Washington, Seattle) have shown that individual watersheds wax and wane in their  importance as sources to the ocean populations, but the portfolio of all watersheds together sustains steady high returns of valuable salmon from the ocean to the Bay.  Bristol Bay, Alaska, is one of America's last great wild salmon fisheries, supporting tens of millions of wild running salmon. The region support thousands of fisheries and recreation-based jobs that would be jeopardized by using these watersheds as a dump for mining waste. 65% of Alaskans and 80% of Bristol Bay residents oppose the proposed Pebble Mine. 

In 2010, led by Alaska Native Tribes, interests including commercial fishing business owners and sportsmen asked the EPA step in to ensure that this mine wouldn't jeopardize Bristol Bay. The EPA responded by listening to over 1.5 million Americans, hosting dozens of community meetings, reviewing Pebble's many detailed filings with state and federal agencies, and conducting a twice peer-reviewed scientific assessment of the potential impacts to the region.

Withdrawing the proposed determination ignores the overwhelming majority of Alaskans and puts the short-term interests of a foreign mining company above thousands of American jobs. 

Please do not withdraw the proposed determination.

Thank you,

Jessie Beck

The EPA responded by listening to over 1.5 million Americans, hosting dozens of community meetings, reviewing Pebble's many detailed filings with state and federal agencies, and conducting a twice peer-reviewed scientific assessment of the potential impacts to the region. Withdrawing the proposed determination ignores the overwhelming majority of Alaskans and puts the short-term interests of a foreign mining company above thousands of local jobs. 

For the sake of our wildlife, waterways, and communities, I urge you to protect Bristol Bay and prevent this horrible open-pit mine from destroying one of our nation's most precious ecosystems.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment: it is absolutely mandatory that everyone follow the rule of law. the usa as a nation has policies and procedures to follow. these policies and procedures cover everything from getting a motor vehicle license to building nuclear power plants. it is absolutely necessary to our society that everyone receives  due process. there are processes and procedures for mining companies to follow in the development of mines. these mining companies are entitled to due process without delay. even this period to comment on the withdrawal of the determination is an affront to well founded policies and procedures. this process legitimizes the illegal action by the epa in relation to plp. plp must be allowed to immediately proceed  with a normal course of permitting. we cannot and must not allow over reach and law breaking to be tolerated when it comes to governmental agencies. tolerating these breaches of sound policy and procedure lead to anarchy as is found in third world countries that are ruled by fear. as a matter of national security and national interest plp must be granted due process. plp is and will be a strategic asset to the great state of alaska and all of the good citizens of the usa.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
Good day,
I would like to voice my support of the withdraw of this determination. 
 I have followed this case very closely.  I have watched hours of testimony, and read dozens of pages pn how this was handled by the EPA.  It was nothing short of criminal.
 If the people who want to build this mine submit their plans, and the ACoE determines it is unsafe then by all means deny them their permits. Or make the changes needed to protect the Sockeye salmon run.   But the process is the process.  You don't tell a man who wants to build a house that you wont look at his plans. And you dont tell the rest of the Natural resource Investment world that they are unsafe putting their dollars in America.
AND MOST IMPORTANTLY, if they can do it safely, I would prefer to have America secure in its access to resources, AND to be overseeing the mine and its use.
 All the people who say "Not here" don't seem to realize that  in America we have the best chance of making ANY miner be responsible and make them pay for proper disposal, and safe practice. The world will get its copper. If not here then from somewhere where the labor could be children or slaves for that matter. The waste will be dumped right into the environment..
I am for the normal course of permitting to be followed here. And to hold these miners to the high standard here in America to get the resources responsibly.
  Thank you

Title: Comment submitted by B. Fleming
Comment:
I would like to OBJECT to the proposed withdrawal of clean water act restrictions on mining pebble deposit.

Throughout our nations history, despite assurances and mitigation, we've seen mining efforts wreak havoc on fisheries.  As a regular visitor to Alaska, and recreational fisherman, Bristol Bay is a destination and renewable natural resource worthy of rigorous protection.  

The concentrated and relatively short term rewards of opening/empowering mining in this area are lesser than the continued and perpetual returns of salmon and wildlife we gain by protecting Bristol Bay.  Do your job and PROTECT THE ENVIRONMENT (like it says in your job title).


Brian Fleming
Seattle, WA
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I somehow came across this post.  It could not have been stated any better in terms of why and for what reasons I think the proposed determination should be withdrawn.  It covers much of how I feel.  I simply added the last paragragh to fully express my thoughts:

Alaska and specifically Bristol Bay is in dire need of the Pebble mine. The younger generation of Alaskans deserve to have meaningful and decent paying jobs. Of 5,394 working age residents in Bristol Bay, only 63% worked in 2011 and only 35% were employed throughout the year. By providing Alaska and Bristol Bay 3,000 high wage jobs (mine workers average over $100,000/year), Pebble will provide a much needed boost to the regional economy in Bristol Bay. Pebble mine would increase Lake and Peninsula Borough tax base by a staggering 600% over 2013 levels while the infrastructure build out for the project would provide affordable electricity for Southwest Alaska. Pebble-related economic activity in Alaska will boost the state's GDP by more than 3% over 2011 levels as the mine will generate $1 billion in annual operating expenditures in the area. Northern Dynasty has publicly stated that they won't go ahead with the mine if it means sacrificing the salmon. Ultimately, the rule of law needs to be upheld and the Army Corps of Engineers should have the final say on whether the project should go ahead. To not allow this mine to go through without valid reasoning is to deny thousands of Alaskans good paying jobs without a reason and to prevent the greater Alaskan economy from reaching its potential. 

Allow a normalized full review to take place so that we can all find out once and for all whether or not this mine is viable.  Nothing more nothing less.  This project has been unduly manipulated for too many years and at an incredible cost to the company.  Again special interests.  Take them out of the equation by finally truly normailizing back to the established processes.  Unless of course you don't trust the process.  If that is the case, it truly is a sad day for everyone!

Title: Comment submitted by K. Gould
Comment:
Hello, my name is Kyle Gould, and I am a concerned citizen from New York State.

I'm writing to the Environmental Protection Agency to urge the agency  to continue to restrict Pebble Limited Partnership from using Bristol Bay in Southeast Alaska as a deposit site for their mining operations. The bay is one of the world's most important wild salmon fisheries, which supports 14,000 full and part-time jobs. 

Also, the 2014 decision to restrict mining has been examined and peer-reviewed by many in the scientific community, and it shows that mining would cause a tremendous amount of environmental damage, as well as negatively affect the livelihood of those that depend on the bay to produce a healthy fishery.

For these reasons, I urge the EPA to continue restricting mining access to Bristol Bay. Mines will undoubtedly destroy the salmon fishery and the surrounding environment, as well as destroy the livelihoods and economies of the surrounding Native American communities and fishermen.

I thank you for both your time and the opportunity to voice my concerns on this matter.

Sincerely,
Kyle Gould

There is no reason good enough to destroy that.

Title: Comment submitted  by K.��S.��Roche
Comment:
In your Proposal To Withdraw Proposed Determination To Restrict the Use of an Area as a Disposal Site; Pebble Deposit Area, Southwest Alaska, you, the EPA indicate that "Pursuant to the settlement agreement and policy direction from EPA's Administrator, EPA is proposing to withdraw the July 2014 Proposed Determination at this time and is taking public comment on this proposal. The proposal reflects the Administrator's decision to provide PLP with additional time to submit a permit application to the Army Corps and potentially allow the Army Corps permitting process to initiate without having an open and unresolved section 404(c) review...While the pendency of a section 404(c) review would not preclude PLP from submitting an application and the Army Corps from reviewing that application, as noted above, the Army Corps could not have issued a permit while a section 404(c) process was ongoing...The Agency is only seeking public comment on whether to withdraw the July 2014 Proposed Determination...Specifically, EPA is also taking public comment now on whether the Administrator should review and reconsider a final withdrawal decision, if such a decision is made...In summary, the EPA is seeking comments on:  Whether to withdraw the July 2014 Proposed Determination at this time for the reasons stated above; and  if a final withdrawal decision is made following this comment period, whether the Administrator should review and reconsider the withdrawal decision.
Based on information in your assessment, Bristol Bay should be declared an "Aquatic Resource of National Importance", the proposed determination should not be withdrawn until and unless there is a new proposal that does not include the need to restrict the use of certain waters in the South Fork Koktuli River, North Fork Koktuli River, and Upper Talarik Creek watersheds (located within the larger Bristol Bay watershed) as disposal sites for dredged or fill material associated with mining the Pebble deposit.  All efforts should be made to protect the water, the salmon and other aquatic resources in this area.
Thank you for this opportunity to comment.  Please put my name on the mailing list for this project.

I oppose the authorization of mining development that in any way would jeopardize or introduce a future environmental risk to the Bristol Bay Alaska area or watershed.

On behalf of myself, a US citizen, a Distinguished Eagle Scout, outdoorsman and sportsman. 

Douglas L. Whitley
12851 North Island View Drive
Northport, Michigan 49670

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I strongly oppose development of the Pebble Mine.  There simply is no way to develop a mine of this scope without having severe adverse consequences to the fisheries and other resources in the area.  It is particularly disturbing to hear that the principal advocate of the project is a Canadian company that is looking for partners because it lacks experience in designing or operating mines of this scope.  

I also urge EPA conduct a thorough NEPA analysis (notwithstanding EPA's assertions that it is exempt from complying with NEPA) should it move forward with project approval.  A project of such immense scope and adverse effects really needs to be subjected to a rigorous environmental analysis that the public can scrutinize and understand.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
More than 65 percent of Alaskans, 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents and Native communities, and 85 percent of commercial fishermen oppose the mine. Why? Because the Bristol Bay watershed:

    Supplies nearly half the world's sockeye salmon
    Generates $1.5 billion annually, making it the most valuable wild salmon fishery in the world
    Supports 14,000 jobs, including commercial fishers, world-class sports fishers, and Alaska Natives
    Is a beloved tourism spot for individuals and families every summer
    Sustains the culture and traditions of Alaska Natives, including the Yup'ik and Denai'na, two of the last intact, sustainable, salmon-based cultures in the world


The Pebble Mine  which would produce 10 billion tons of mining wastejeopardizes all of that. It would turn this unspoiled wilderness into a toxic wasteland for decades to come.

Title: Comment submitted by Thomas Riegelman, Life Member, Trout Unlimited
Comment:
I oppose the withdrawal of the Proposed Determination of the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency Region 10 Pursuant to Section 404(c) of the Clean Water Act Pebble Deposit Area, Southwest Alaska.

While I am a firm believer in the rule of law, and following due process in environmental matters, the importance of protecting this watershed from the potential affects of the extensive open pit mining operations proposed by PLP overshadow any concerns I may have regarding the EPA's initial filing of a Proposed Determination in 2014.

The Proposed Determination should stand.

Thomas Riegelman
Life Member - Trout Unlimited
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment: As a U.S. citizen, I am commenting to request that protections not be withdrawn in the Pebble Deposit Area of Alaska.  I am concerned about the ecological impact of the proposed mining activities.  A prior study has concluded that one of the most important remaining Sockeye salmon fisheries would suffer substantial negative impact, and this impact would in turn affect the regional food chain.  Many of our salmon fisheries have already been destroyed by dams and mining, and it would be tremendously wasteful to ruin this fishery as well for a temporary gain.  Even if I never have a chance to see this area, I want my children to grow up knowing that such an intact Arctic ecosystem remains.  I am also concerned about the impact the proposed mining activities would have on local native cultures, which rely heavily on the region's fisheries.  Given the substantial nature of the potential impacts and the long-term/likely permanent nature of the impacts, I strongly oppose the withdrawing of protections in this region of Alaska.  Thank you for considering my views.

Title: Comment submitted by J. Jasper
Comment:
Dear EPA Administrator Scott Pruitt: 

I'm deeply concerned about your proposal to repeal the Clean Water Rule. This is a reckless attack on our waters and health.
 
The Clean Water Rule was adopted to help protect crucial waterways, including streams that feed the drinking water sources of more than 117 million Americans -- that's approximately one in three Americans. 
 
Without Clean Water Rule protections, mining companies, factory farms and other industries could more easily pollute some our nation's most vital waterways.
 
It's the EPA's responsibility to do everything in its power to make sure that every American has access to clean drinking water. Clean water is not just a right -- it's a necessity.
 
I urge you to reverse course and stop this attack on the Clean Water Rule, to defend critical waterways and protect our nation's drinking water!  Thank you.
-Jessica Jasper
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I am opposed to EPAs proposal to rescind the 2014 Proposed Determination designed to protect Bristol Bays world class fisheries. Please stand with American jobs and communities and preserve the Bristol Bay Proposed Determination.

Bristol Bay, Alaska, is one of America's last great wild salmon fisheries. Each year, tens of millions of wild salmon return, supporting upwards of 14,000 jobs in the commercial and sport fishing industries, and serving as a one-in-a-lifetime destination for anglers from around the world as well as the cultural cornerstone for the region's communities. These long-established businesses are at risk from a foreign-owned mining company that wants to build the proposed Pebble Mine, which is opposed by more than 65 percent of Alaskans and more than 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents. 

In 2014, led by Alaska Native Tribes, interests including commercial fishing business owners and sportsmen asked the EPA step in to ensure that this mine wouldn't jeopardize Bristol Bay. The EPA responded by listening to over 1.5 million Americans, hosting dozens of community meetings, reviewing Pebble's many detailed filings with state and federal agencies, and conducting a twice peer-reviewed scientific assessment of the potential impacts to the region. Withdrawing the proposed determination ignores the overwhelming majority of Alaskans and puts the short-term interests of a foreign mining company above thousands of local jobs. 

If a foreign group proposed this, it would be considered terrorism due to its threat to clean water and salmon.  It is time to protect the resources of our country.

For the sake of our wildlife, waterways, and communities, I urge you to protect Bristol Bay and prevent this horrible open-pit mine from destroying one of our nation's most precious ecosystems.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment submitted by EC (no surname provided)
Comment:
I strongly urge the EPA to not allow dumping of mine waste that could harm Bristol Bay. Alaska is amazing and unique due to its scenery, wildlife and wildness. We cannot let Alaska turn into the lower 48 by having mines and pollution on the scale of the Pebble Beach mine. Decisions like this can't be undone. Please, please save Bristol Bay and reject the mine and the proposed dumping site. 

Thank you,
EC

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment: There is no reason to reopen the decision to permit mining in Bristol Bay. The environment is too fragile to expose to the risks associated with mining. Accidents can happen and no one can guarantee otherwise. The rights of nature and of the people who rely on the area for their way of life should not be negotiable.

Title: Comment submitted by J. Garrison
Comment:
Regarding Docket ID No. EPA-R10-OW-2017-0369 

Request that the EPA Administrator:
1) Not withdraw from the July 2014 Proposed Determination,
2) If a decision to withdraw is made that the Administrator review and reconsider the withdrawal prior to taking any action.

Basis: 
The research and science shows that the risks created by the proposed project cannot, within acceptable certainty, protect the fisheries of the area.  The Bristol Bay is the largest fishery of wild salmon in the world. 
The people of the area, region, and state have opposed the proposed project.  There is no evidence that the proposed project carries a higher priority for the nation than continued protection for the fishery and dependent industry. 
The dependent fishery industry supports some 14,000 people.  Many family owned and small independent business are dependent on a healthy and long term fishery.  Their interest should be given higher consideration than a proposed conflicting new industry. 

John Garrison

Title: Comment submitted by R. Diesch
Comment:
As a consulting engineer, I have witnessed first hand how ignorance and greed override sound judgment and common sense.
In the case of the Pebble Mine, it is clear that any large scale mining operation will negatively impact the local environment. Mines are a short term extraction processes with long term negative impacts. The trade-off of probability of negative impact versus benefit to the people and the environment is clearly unbalanced in favor of a disaster.
It is incumbent upon the EPA to apply good science and engineering in weighing these outcomes. I fail to see how a lawsuit by a disinterested corporation would change the science of the problem.
Thank you for the opportunity to voice and opinion.
Respectfully, Robert Diesch P.E.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment: Our nation's pristine areas are fast disappearing and the role of our government agencies should always be to protect our environment for current and future generations. Mining, especially mining for copper and gold, dredges up numerous harmful agents (as well as chemicals used to separate the metals) that impact many generations to come. The idea that dredged or fill materials can simply be dumped in watersheds is immoral. It's one thing to take such action from a position of ignorance, but quite another to do so knowing the consequences of such actions that has been evidenced here in the United States as well as countries all over the world. To do so is not only immoral, it is a crime against nature. There is already a problem with EPA having to clean up the detritus left by numerous irresponsible mining operations that have caused pollution to our waterways, fisheries, and land. Why make it easier for such pollution to occur? Please enact the proposed determination to restrict the use of the area as a disposal site.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
The controversy of the Pebble Mine in the southwest region of Alaska is one of formidable proportions. So much has been said, shouted, written and speculated about Pebble that facts have all but been conveniently swept askew. There have been blatant inaccuracies and distortions of truths in the ever fluctuating compendium of the Pebble Mine, all intended to persuade public opinion, whether it be for or against. The story of the Pebble Mine is besieged by elements and influences in which flow on continuum.

Southwest Alaska is without a doubt a spectacular ecosystem. The panorama ranges from the surreal volcanic landscape of Katmai National Park, tens of thousands of square miles of interior boreal forests, swamps, highlands and the immense mountain barrier of the Aleutian Islands. Alaska is a land of volcanoes, situated on the Pacific Rim along the aforementioned Ring of Fire. The Pebble Deposit itself is at the end of a long chain of volcanoes that comprise the 1,600 mile-long Aleutian Peninsula. 

Right now Pebble is an idea. Absolutely! But, ideas have propelled humankind to achieve things no one thought achievable. Electricity was an idea, flight was an idea, electric vehicles was an idea. It has taken over ten years of geological, environmental and socioeconomic analysis, studies and documentation, as well as intensive engineering effort to determine that Pebble can become the largest existing copper reserve in the world. The prefeasibility and feasibility studies have yet to be completed to indicate the economic viability of Pebble.

It took vision and courage, exhaustive effort and legal battles to be where Pebble stands today, at the precipice of possibly something magnificent. Many questions left unanswered in this story, but will one day will be unveiled. But until then, yes, Pebble is an idea.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
The Pebble Partnership states"The Pebble Deposit, located in Southwest Alaska, is one of the world's most significant undeveloped deposits of copper, gold, and molybdenum."
Let's keep it that way and do not withdraw the July 2014 Proposed Determination. The project is dead. Currently, the area:
	Supplies nearly half the world's sockeye salmon
	Generates $1.5 billion annually, making it the most valuable wild salmon fishery in the world
	Supports 14,000 jobs, including commercial fishers, world-class sports fishers, and Alaska Natives
	Is a beloved tourism spot for individuals and families every summer
	Sustains the culture and traditions of Alaska Natives, including the Yup'ik and Denai'na, two of the last intact, sustainable, salmon-based cultures in the world

These are benefits far greater than any benefits Pebble Mine will support.

I am writing to ask that the 2014 EPA position protecting the Bristol Bay area be maintained. The Pebble Mine would pose unnecessary risk to natural resources upon which native peoples depend. As a wildlife biologist, I am very concerned about the long-term negative effects of anthropogenic activities on natural communities. Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment submitted by M. Miller
Comment:
To whom it may concern,

I urge you not to withdraw the July 2014 Proposed Determination as this would allow for our natural places such as South Fork Koktuli River, North Fork Koktuli River, and Upper Talarik Creek watersheds in southwest Alaska to be used as disposal sites for dredged or fill material associated with mining the Pebble deposit. It is an unsustainable line of reasoning to assume that mining of these heavy metals such as copper-, gold-, and molybdenum-bearing ore will have no ill effect on the environment or the local peoples who rely on it for sustenance and income. The EPA must use whatever tools it has to protect our shared wild resources, of this there can be no question. 

After the final withdraw decision is made, I urge the Administrator to review and reconsider it in light of the large amount of proven scientific evidence which points to the impact this mining operation will have on the local resources. It would be extremely irresponsible to ignore this body of work, much of it completed by EPA scientists themselves, when making a final decision on this proposed determination.

Thank you,

Mark Miller
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment: Please do not withdraw or rescind the EPA July 2014 Clean Water Act Section 404(c) Proposed Determination to veto Bristol Bay mining. Please do not at any future time accept or approve any permit applications from Pebble Limited Partnership or any other mining company to mine for copper or anything else in the Bristol Bay watershed. Home to the indigenous Yupik peoples, brown bears, and all five Pacific salmon (sockeye, Chinook, coho, chum, pink), Bristol Bay waterways, watershed, wetlands, and wildlife are too important to risk any environmental impact.

Title: Comment submitted by M. Babcock
Comment:
To whom it may concern,

Please uphold the July 14th Clean Water Act determination. Bristol Bay has been a haven for salmon, and thousands of other creatures, long before man strutted his way upon the stage.  The idea that one would choose a brief 45-year option to extract minerals and metals along with toxic materials in an area that is pristine and teaming with life is difficult to imagine. 

Designing the infrastructure to support this massive extraction and the impoundments that must be built to contain the toxic waste, in an earthquake prone area, should cause us to pause.  The likelihood that, as in every other open mine on earth, there will be leaks and contamination should make us uphold the EPA's July 2014 Clean Water Act Determination. 

I pray that the citizens now tasked with the planet choose to protect this bountiful and irreplaceable ecosystem over short-term misguided industrial development projects. 

I am told that the mines life span is 45 years. 45 years of extraction. I am a fifty-year-old woman, born in Alaska, and I can attest 45 years is an infinitesimal amount of time compared to the lifespan of the Bristol Bay watershed. The past, present and future of the billions of organisms should far outweigh the billions of dollars sought. 

The dollars generated by the pebble mine are a poor exchange for thousands of years and organisms that would live on a precipitous with the threat of destruction. We are stewards of this planet or we are parasites.  
Yours Truly,
Meredyth Babcock 
Becket MA. 01223

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
Docket ID No. EPA-R10-OW-2017-0369

It is clear that this administration does not want any of the branches of government to actually fulfill each of their missions. And to this I disagree very strongly in the name of what is actually for the common good. No amount of jobs and profit are going to make the destruction of our limited resources worthwhile. The time lines do not pencil out.

 Watersheds keep what we all need to exist: clean air, clean water and to carve out piece meal, disrupting natural cycles on large scale with have a disastrous cost.. we have limited resources now.. Manifest Destiny is over! Tell me why it is ok for a few to profit on resources we all need? Who are they that they get to do this? We need our wilds to stay wild and our public lands to stay public.

Where is the concern for the general good? Disregarding the Clean Water Act is not patriotic, it is a direct hit on our land.. do not twist this. Not following the Clean Water Act means they intend to pollute for profit.  This is Our Land.not theirs!..not some company who is fouling the land and not being responsible to clean while profiting. It is not the best interest of the US, really.

 The passion is watching short term gain thinking leaving the long term destruction for a dying industry flexing it last hurrah over a finite supply.. How is that clear thinking?  Those who want the Clean Water rescinded are not passionate.. they are blind and do not see down the line far enough. That is what the EPA is for.. to see far down the line.. Those who uphold the Clean Water Act are the ones who are patriotic and loyal to the flag in the decades and generations to come for the lands of this Great Country.

Title: Comment submitted by E. Winchester
Comment:
Dear Administrator Pruitt & Acting Region 10 Administrator Pirzadeh:

The proposed Pebble Mine is a bad idea.  Unfortunately, the plan to rollback years of public input and additional protections for the Bristol Bay watershed is at stake.  Bristol Bay supports the world's largest wild sockeye salmon fishery, generating one half billion dollars in annual revenue and supporting 14,000 American jobs in the commercial and sport fishing sectors.

Bristol Bay holds a special place in my heart.  As a veteran guide, and now operating a fly fishing outfitter in northern Michigan, I cut my teeth as a guide in the Bristol Bay region.  I worked, fished, and lived with many people who call Bristol Bay home, and many others who travelled to the region for work or pleasure.  I saw the true nature of the largest wild salmon runs in the world, and the dependence that nearly every animal - wild and human - has on the salmon.  The best part, barring a large environmental disaster - such as is possible with the proposed Pebble mine - the salmon runs do not only provide significant contribution to the Alaskan economy, but they are fully sustainable as well.

Bristol Bay, Alaskans, and Alaska Natives are at risk due to the foreign-owned mining company looking to exploit a region with a noteworthy history and sustainable resources.  More than 65 percent of Alaskans and more than 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents opposed the proposed Pebble Mine.  Furthermore, more than 1.5 million Americans have urged the EPA to provide strong protections for the Bristol Bay watershed.  Foreign-owned interests should not dictate what is best for Alaska, its resources, or the American public.

I do not oppose resource development.  As a land manager and outfitter, I manage timber, water and mineral resource development using sound environmental practices for the betterment of the property.  However, I do oppose resource development in the wrong place, for the wrong reasons.  The proposed Pebble Mine is the wrong mine, in the wrong place, for the wrong reasons.  Approving this mine will set a dangerous precedent for American resource exploitation by foreign interests and the implications of an environmental mishap will affect the region for generations to come.

Some places and resources are just too good to take risks.  Bristol Bay is one of those places, and its salmon runs are one of those resources.

I urge you to keep the protections in place for Bristol Bay.

Sincerely,

Ethan Winchester

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I am writing to ask you not to withdraw the Bristol Bay Proposed Determination, which it made pursuant to the Clean Water Act in 2014.

As you know, Bristol Bay, Alaska, is one of America's last great wild salmon fisheries. Tens of millions of wild salmon return annually, which support upwards of 14,000 American jobs in the commercial and sport fishing industries, serve as a one-in-a-lifetime destination for anglers from around the world, and are the cultural cornerstone for the region's communities.

These long-established American businesses and jobs are at risk from a foreign-owned mining company that wants to build the proposed Pebble Mine, which is opposed by more than 65 percent of Alaskans and more than 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents. 

This mine would generate 10 billion tons of toxic waste held in retaining dams that have failed in similar sites, contaminating the watershed for many years with devastating effects on both wildlife and human populations. This mine would also consume tremendous volumes of water that would be diverted from fisheries, agriculture, recreational and domestic uses.

In 2010, led by Alaska Native Tribes, interests including commercial fishing business owners and sportsmen asked the EPA step in to ensure that this mine wouldn't jeopardize Bristol Bay. The EPA responded by listening to over 1.5 million Americans, hosting dozens of community meetings, reviewing Pebble's many detailed filings with state and federal agencies, and conducting a twice peer-reviewed scientific assessment of the potential impacts to the region.

Withdrawing the proposed determination ignores the overwhelming majority of Alaskans and puts the short-term interests of a foreign mining company above thousands of American jobs. 

Please do not withdraw the proposed determination.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
Dear Administrator Pruitt & Acting Administrator Pirzadeh: 

I am outraged that you plan to reverse course and open for consideration a potential green light on the proposed Pebble Mine, despite the catastrophic risks any such mining operation necessarily poses to Alaska's Bristol Bay watershed, its world-renowned salmon runs and its Native communities. No mining whatsoever should be considered in this highly sensitive, ecologically priceless area.

Under the Obama administration, the EPA, after years of rigorous study, proposed science-based restrictions that would have banned the dangerous Pebble Mine to protect Bristol Bay from the myriad of environmental risks this massive gold and copper mine would pose. Your recent settlement with Northern Dynasty Minerals to reverse those common-sense restrictions is a blatant giveaway to the mining industry at the expense of the American people, our environment and our economy.

Bristol Bay's wild salmon fishery supports 14,000 jobs and is valued at more than $1.5 billion annually. It also supplies nearly half of the world's sockeye salmon. More than 65 percent of Alaskans, 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents and Native communities, and 85 percent of commercial fishermen oppose the mine.

I urge you to listen to those voices, and for the sake of the Bristol Bay watershed, its world-class salmon fishery and its people, keep the door closed on Pebble Mine. If you don't, you will have to answer to me and hundreds of thousands of people in Alaska and across the United States and the world who stand in fervent opposition to this toxic mega-mine.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment: The environmental review on the proposed Pebble Mine was immense, thorough, based in scientific fact. As this nation has seen on other major mining projects, the spoils and dredge of these mines damage waterways through the pollution of heavy metals and toxic minerals. The US government should simply buy back the mineral rights that belong to the people of Alaska. Foreign corporations have no business attaining rights over American land, especially lands that were not originally the US government's. The value of the Sockeye fishery is known. The economic impacts to the fishery would be devastating. To those commentators who speak to the creation of jobs with the Pebble Mine, they are misinformed. Just as in the coal industry and all other industry associated with mineral extraction, jobs are being lost to technological development and automation. It is not economically feasible, if this mine were to go into operation, that a company would hire a large number of personnel given the remote location and hazards associated with the job. They will do like in Germany and Canada and build massive mining machines in order to reduce the human element. The US government does not need to conduct anymore studies into what is already known and a proven point. Regardless of how much mitigation is done, there is no replacing the largest Sockeye fishery on the planet once it has been polluted by the mine spoils. The company that owns the mineral rights made a bad business decision and should absorb the costs of their failures and move on. The US has nothing to gain by losing this economic powerhouse in a region where jobs revolve around the fishery. No matter how big the mine gets, it will NOT replace all of the jobs lost if the fishery is destroyed. Thank you
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
The proposed mining project is potentially catastrophic to half of the world's wild-caught salmon.  If developed, the mine will be among the largest mines in North America and the highly toxic waste will be stored in a seismically active area. Independent scientists doubt whether the waste dam would survive an earthquake like the one in Anchorage in 1964. This is a "disaster in waiting" for the salmon as well as many species of marine birds (including Emperor Geese and ESA listed Steller's Eiders) that use Bristol Bay as a foraging area during migration.  In 2014, after extensive investigations, the area was declared by the EPA to be too valuable and vulnerable to mine. What was true then remains true today, regardless of the money the developers stand to earn.
As far as the economy is concerned, the salmon fishery in the bay is sustainably managed and supports 14,000 seasonal and full-time jobs that would be jeopardized by the mine.

Bottom line:  Pebble mine has a high probability of having disastrous impacts on the most important sockeye salmon fishery in the world with incalculable environmental and economic damage waiting to happen. As the old saying goes, an ounce of prevention is worth a pound of cure!

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment: Dredged and fill material has been proven to have harmful effects on not only the surrounding environment, but also on the world-reknown, economically invaluable, and culturally important fisheries of Bristol Bay. For the EPA to allow Pebble Limited Partnership to go ahead and continue with the Pebble Mine would directly oppose the mission of the Environmental Protection Agency to protect human health and the environment. Bristol Bay is priceless. We have learned our lesson again and again with fisheries all over the Lower 48 and in elsewhere in the world. The reason people, including myself, love and move to Alaska is to be able to witness and explore amazing natural places which have not been destroyed by the interests of mining and oil. The more we allow those interests to control our lands and waters, the less valuable this State becomes. Alaska' fisheries are like nowhere else in the world and there is nothing that should come in the way of protecting them and protecting the livelihoods of those who live in the region.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
Please stand with American sportsmen, Alaska communities and the thousands of businesses that depend on Bristol Bay's robust fishery and cold, clean waters by upholding the Bristol Bay Proposed Determination, which was made pursuant to the Clean Water Act in 2014.

Bristol Bay is home to one of America's last great wild salmon fisheries. Tens of millions of wild salmon return annually to the bay, resulting in a range of benefits that include the following: 
-It supports 14,000 fishing related jobs.
-It attracts anglers from around the world.
-It serves as the cultural cornerstone for the region's native tribes and communities.

These established American businesses are at risk from a foreign-owned mining company behind the Pebble proposal, which is opposed by more than 65 percent of Alaskans and more than 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents. 

In 2010, the EPA initiated a formal review process aimed at ensuring the proposed Pebble Mine wouldn't jeopardize Bristol Bay's healthy fishery. In response, over 1.5 million Americans weighed in urging the EPA to protect Bristol Bay. In addition, the EPA hosted dozens of community meetings, reviewed Pebble's many detailed filings with state and federal agencies, and conducted a twice peer-reviewed scientific assessment of the potential impacts to the region.

The results of this public process remain clear: The risks posed to the Bristol Bay fishery and the thousands of Alaskan jobs that it supports far outweigh the potential benefits associated with developing the Pebble Mine. 

Please stand with American sportsmen in maintaining Bristol Bay's fishery. Please do not withdraw the proposed determination.
