Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
QUIT trying to destroy our country, pull up your big boy shorts and show you care about the people and this land.  Don't be a sycophant as so many are in today,s government.  Prove you have a mind of your own and PROTECT this beautiful land - i.e. DO YOUR JOB!!!  I am opposed to EPAs proposal to rescind the 2014 Proposed Determination designed to protect Bristol Bays world class fisheries. Please stand with American jobs and communities and preserve the Bristol Bay Proposed Determination.

Bristol Bay, Alaska, is one of America's last great wild salmon fisheries. Each year, tens of millions of wild salmon return, supporting upwards of 14,000 jobs in the commercial and sport fishing industries, and serving as a one-in-a-lifetime destination for anglers from around the world as well as the cultural cornerstone for the region's communities. These long-established businesses are at risk from a foreign-owned mining company that wants to build the proposed Pebble Mine, which is opposed by more than 65 percent of Alaskans and more than 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents. 

In 2014, led by Alaska Native Tribes, interests including commercial fishing business owners and sportsmen asked the EPA step in to ensure that this mine wouldn't jeopardize Bristol Bay. The EPA responded by listening to over 1.5 million Americans, hosting dozens of community meetings, reviewing Pebble's many detailed filings with state and federal agencies, and conducting a twice peer-reviewed scientific assessment of the potential impacts to the region. Withdrawing the proposed determination ignores the overwhelming majority of Alaskans and puts the short-term interests of a foreign mining company above thousands of local jobs. 

For the sake of our wildlife, waterways, and communities, I urge you to protect Bristol Bay and prevent this horrible open-pit mine from destroying one of our nation's most precious ecosystems.

Title: Comment submitted by Mark (no surname provided)
Comment:
Dear Scott Pruitt and the EPA,

I would strongly urge the EPA to not reversing the Obama administration policy of restricting the use of areas near Bristol Bay as disposal sites for the Pebble Mine.

Consider option one.  The EPA opens the path to the construction of the Pebble Mine that can produce ore for max 75 years that is also in tectonically active zone.  Peer-reviewed scientific studies (which are and have been the gold standard of scientific research for centuries) have shown that even construction of the Pebble Mine can cause severe and irreparable damage to salmon breeding and nursery grounds. Not to mention that any sort of significant tectonic activity could result in a comprise of the mine-tailing containment, leading to a massive impact and catastrophic loss of the Bristol fishery -- a fishery that creates 14,000 jobs and $480 million annually and will continue to do so for hundreds of years if managed correctly. And, while I do forgive the EPA for past mistakes, let's acknowledge that the EPA doesn't have a good record of ensuring that toxic mine tailings do not spill into ecologically and economically important waterways (e.g. see the Gold King Mine for an example). Why should the public have confidence that the EPA can prevent this similar type of event to happen near Bristol Bay in a much more challenging environment?   

Consider option two.  The EPA continues the Obama-era restrictions on construction of the Pebble Mine. They thus prevent what scientists have identified as inevitable harm to the Bristol Bay fishery and ensure that a job and money producing industry continues to thrive (i.e. if the Pebble Mine is built the fishery WILL BE impacted according to our best, most successful means of procuring knowledge -- scientific peer review).  I am sorry if the administration "feels in their gut" that the Pebble Mine won't be a problem to the fishery.  Gut feelings that are not supported by evidence do not do much to persuade me and are poor ways by which to make decisions.

Of course, the monkey in the room is this 300 billion dollar revenue tag that is placed on the mine. I will be honest, that is a lot of money and people claim that it could be a boost for the Alaskan economy creating 5,000 jobs in Alaska. But keep in mind that this is a finite resource, with production lasting for a maximum of 75 years.  In contrast, the Bristol Bay fishery will, if managed correctly, will consistently generate 300 billion dollars in 600 years (and if you want to talk about climate change now to potentially rebuttal this argument, recognize how hypocritical that will sound...).  Not to mention the billions already generated by this industry. Sure, 600 years sounds like a lot, but this a steady press of half a billion dollars into the Alaskan economy over that time compared to a pulse of of 300 billion dollars over 75 years, with most of that coming in the first 25 years. Moreover, the jobs created by these two industries are not even comparable.  Actually, they are so let's do that too!  Even if the Alaskan Pebble Mine creates 5,000 jobs in Alaska every year for 75 years, that would be 375,000, compared to over a million jobs created by the fishery over that same time period (and, keep in mind, for many years after that).

Please consider this decision in terms of the long-term Alaskan economy.  The choice seems obvious.

Best,
Mark
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment submitted by D. W. French
Comment:
Stories of Euro-American settlers to the Pacific Northwest in the 19th and early 20th centuries report of rivers being filled to the gills with salmon. Tales of walking across the backs of salmon to ford a river are not uncommon. Yet, where have these salmon gone? Atlantic salmon have been nearly extirpated from the US east coast. Many waterways comprising the western drainages of America have been dammed, developed, mined, or logged to the point of putting most Pacific salmonid populations on the Endangered Species list. Why should we repeat these mistakes in Alaska? 

The Pebble Mine is a short-lived project, relative to the historic populations of Native Alaskans that have fished and lived in this landscape for millenia, as well as future Alaskans. Those who rely on Bristol Bay salmon also include commercial and recreational fishermen from the lower 48, and the international community, who buys billions of dollars in sockeye salmon and related products annually. More than 60 percent of commercial fishing permits for Bristol Bay are held by non-Alaskans. Projects that pose a threat to this fishery reach far beyond the 7,000 residents of Bristol Bay.  

Sure, the mine will create jobs for the next 50 to 100 years. It will bring wads of cash to the pockets of a Canadian owned mine company and a few executives. It will make some Alaskans feel like the mine is a good idea, but 80 to 90 percent of Bristol Bay residents think that Pebble is a bad idea. Why? Because there is uncertainty. There are unknowns. We may think we fully understand the engineering complexities of a pit mine, but we have no idea what the implications of such an extensive project are for the ecosystem in which it is placed. The short term gains are not worth the long term risks. 

Rivers are the circulatory system of Alaska's fisheries. The complex hydrologic cycle and local geology of Bristol Bay is unique in that it provides the necessary nutrients, water temperatures, and geomorphic features to sustain the complex life history of salmon. Features such as gravel and clay lenses in this drainage encourage subsurface or hyporheic flow. This, in turn, provides for stable water temperatures that keep salmon eggs cool during warm periods, and prevent the gravel beds from freezing during the winter. All of these components allow for a small portion of adult salmon spawners to support a viable population. We can harvest more than half the adult salmon returning to their natal habitats, and still have a healthy return in subsequent years. No single tributary is more important than others. It is the mosaic of these streams that provide for the long-term stability of the overall Bristol Bay sockeye salmon run. In economics and more recently in ecology, we have adopted the portfolio effect, in which a diverse mix of stocks (or in this case, habitats) yield a more stable return over time. A diversity of habitats allows for resiliency, in which individual populations ebb and flow over time, but the overall population remains moderately stable as a result of a diverse portfolio. 

Rivers are not wastewater treatment facilities. They are not flumes for moving contaminants, garbage, or mine tailings from one place to another. They are ecosystems, rich with life and impossible to restore to their natural state. We cannot rebuild something that takes geologic timescales to develop. We cannot afford to put these places at risk. 

I urge you to impose the restrictions on use of waterways as disposal sites, and to maintain protections for the ecosystem that comprises the location of the proposed Pebble Mine site. Please do not withdraw these restrictions. Our future generations will not benefit from another mine. They will, however, appreciate the abundant resources and beauty that Bristol Bay has to offer in its natural state. 

Thank you for your time.
Sincerely,
David William French

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
The EPA's mission is to protect and restore the environment and public health for current and future generations.  Therefore, they should absolutely NOT withdraw the 2014 Proposed Determination; and if such a decision is made then the Administrator should review such decision.  The recommended determination should be forward to EPA Headquarters.
The EPA took the time to assess potential impacts and evaluate available information and found that; "the infrastructure necessary to mine the Pebble deposit jeopardizes the longterm health and sustainability of the Bristol Bay ecosystem."; "These stream, wetland, and other aquatic resource losses also would reverberate downstream, depriving downstream fish habitats of nutrients, groundwater inputs, and other subsidies from lost upstream aquatic resources."; and that there is "reason to believe that unacceptable adverse effects on fishery areas (including spawning and breeding areas) could result from the discharge of dredge or fill material associated with mining the Pebble deposit."
Restrictions on the discharge of dredged or fill material associated with mining the Pebble deposit is necessary to avoid these "unacceptable adverse effects".  In fact, this pebble mining operation should not be permitted AT ALL!  The protection of this landscape of "unparalleled ecological value", is much more cost effective than trying to restore it after the pebble mine destroys it.

Title: Comment submitted by R. Reid
Comment:
The EPA has already done a very extensive study of the environmental impact study spanning years., which determined that the damage to this vital area would be too vast and destructive, that it was decided NOT to approve this. 

Don't allow this mine to be built. Human quality of life is much moreimportant. Miners need to be trained in newer technologies like solar. The rest of the world is adapting and so should we. Don't give China the ammunition it needs to pass us up in changing to cleaner energy and laugh at us for being so stupid.

I write in support of the communities of Alaska's Bristol Bay and ask you not to withdraw the proposed determination to adopt restrictions protecting the habitat of Bristol Bay's world-renowned salmon. The proposed determination was made at the request of local communities and adopted only after years of rigorous scientific study, public participation and peer review. The EPA was correct in 2014 when it
found that the Pebble Mine would have "significant and unacceptable adverse effects" on "one of the most productive, pristine, valuable and vulnerable ecosystems remaining in North America today."

The EPA has noted that commercial fishing in Bristol Bay generates $300 million annually in direct sales of commercially caught salmon, generating 11,000 jobs. These salmon support not only the commercial and sportfishing industries, but a traditional Native way of life that has endured for millennia and thrives today. The EPA should stand by its proposed determination and take all necessary actions to protect the Bristol Bay watershed.

Rebecca Reid
PO Box 1072
Coupeville, WA 98239

Title: Comment submitted by K. Olson
Comment:
I urge you NOT to withdraw the July 2014 Proposed Determination at this time. The May 2017 settlement agreement already appears to give preference to the interests of the mining company, over the substantial risks of lasting and widespread harm to the unique and irreplaceable environment of Bristol Bay. 

Why pave the way for a mining company to profit, while Bristol Bay's communities, fish, animals, and native cultures suffer harm? I object strongly to this set of priorities and I want the current use restrictions to be maintained so that Bristol Bay will be protected from contamination. There is more to be gained over the long term from the tourism, fishing, and healthy populations o animals that thrive in this region now. I visited Alaska myself this past August, for the first time in many years. I was born in Alaska before it was a state. The natural beauty and wilderness of Alaska is breathtaking, and leaves me filled with gratitude for the past efforts undertaken by many people to protect it. Native populations have lived here for thousands of years without ruining this ecosystem. It would be tragic if this treasure were to be destroyed by environmental disasters, all within the span of one person's lifetime, and even more so because this risk of harm is entirely preventable. 

Do not withdraw the proposed determination. The science is clear and convincing, showing emphatically that using this area as a disposal site would be hazardous to the environment. It is the EPA's job to protect Bristol Bay's pristine waters, world-renowned salmon runs, abundant wildlife, and Native communities, not threaten them. 

Thank you,
Karen Olson

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
Please do not consider withdrawing needed EPA protections from Bristol Bay. 

Cui Bono?

For Whose Benefit? 

We live in a world of limited resources. As the world's population continues to grow, it's quality food resources get spread thinner and will continue to grow more necessary and valuable. Leaving the minerals in the ground will also increase their value. 

Large-scale mining in Bristol Bay's headwaters will be a flash in the pan, as all nonrenewable resource extraction is. Inevitably it will either damage or destroy the largest sockeye salmon run in the world. It is not a matter of if, but when. 

Prioritizing a finite resource over, and at the expense of, a renewable resource is a fools errand. 

Nothing lasts forever. Let's not speed up the process. 

Please, No Pebble Mine.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I am outraged that you plan to reverse course and green-light the proposed Pebble Mine, despite the catastrophic risks it poses to Alaska's Bristol Bay watershed, its world-renowned salmon runs, and its Native communities. 

President Obama's Environmental Protection Agency proposed common-sense restrictions that would have banned this dangerous mine because of the obvious environmental risks it would pose. The EPA's recent settlement with Northern Dynasty Minerals to reverse those common-sense restrictions is a blatant giveaway to the mining industry at the expense of the American people, our environment, and our economy.

Bristol Bay's wild salmon fishery supports 14,000 jobs and is valued at more than $1.5 billion annually. It also supplies nearly half of the world's sockeye salmon. More than 65 percent of Alaskans, 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents and Native communities, and 85 percent of commercial fishermen oppose the mine.

I urge you to listen to those voices, and for the sake of the Bristol Bay watershed, its world-class salmon fishery, and its people, keep the door closed on Pebble Mine. If you don't, you will have to answer to me and hundreds of thousands of people in Alaska and across the United States and the world who stand in fervent opposition to this toxic mega-mine.

Title: Comment submitted by K. Anderson
Comment:
Greetings. My name is Karen Anderson and I live in Rollinsville, CO. The Pebble Mine has been a disaster since its inception  a number of years ago. The livelihood of many in Bristol Bay is negatively impacted by this horrific idea. This would benefit only a few wealthy mining companies, while imperiling the lives of many. Furthermore, one needs to consider the magnificence of this area, to be destroyed for the wealth of a few.
Thank you,
Karen Anderson
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
The plan to reverse course and green light the proposed Pebble Mine, despite the catastrophic risks it poses to Alaska's Bristol Bay watershed, its world-renowned salmon runs and its Native communities, would be catastrophic. 

The very EPA, after years of rigorous study, proposed science-based restrictions that would have banned the dangerous Pebble Mine to protect Bristol Bay from the myriad of environmental risks this massive gold and copper mine would pose. Your recent settlement with Northern Dynasty Minerals to reverse those common-sense restrictions is a blatant giveaway to the mining industry at the expense of the American people, our environment and our economy.

Bristol Bay's wild salmon fishery supports 14,000 jobs and is valued at more than $1.5 billion annually. It also supplies nearly half of the world's sockeye salmon. More than 65 percent of Alaskans, 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents and Native communities, and 85 percent of commercial fishermen oppose the mine.

I urge you to listen to those voices, and for the sake of the Bristol Bay watershed, its world-class salmon fishery and its people, keep the door closed on Pebble Mine. If you don't, you will have to answer to me and hundreds of thousands of people in Alaska and across the United States and the world who stand in fervent opposition to this toxic mega-mine.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment: The Bristol Bay supports 14,000 jobs valued at $1.5 billion per year. The presently pristine Bristol Bay supplies approximately 50% of the world's sockeye salmon market. Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I am appalled that the current version of the once-excellent Environmental Protection Agency seems now openly to serve the interests of polluters and profiteers.

The Pebble Mine would serve these interests alone--at catastrophic cost to the environment you are charged and paid to protect. On a grotesque scale, this mine would deface and pollute wild America. It stands to despoil a place of extraordinary natural beauty and poison a life-sustaining watershed.  

It would destroy wildlife--and it would destroy a way of life for First Nations people whose ancestral home this project will poison with toxic waste.  

It would destroy wild salmon fisheries that support 14,000 jobs75% of local employmentand provide almost half of the entire world's supply of sockeye salmon.  It would end this unmatched natural resource.

It would fly directly in the face of the expressed desires of the American people most closely affected:  the clear majority of Alaskans, of residents of Bristol Bay, and of commercial fishermen stand in opposition to this filthy project.   It would horrify me and every other American who cares about our environment, our wild things, and the future of this increasingly polluted nation.

All this would serve to enable polluters from another country extract profit at irrecoverable cost to America's natural treasure.    

With what respect is due, please:  you are the ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION Agency.  I beg you to do your job and protect America's wilderness from those who will destroy it with the Pebble Mine.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I am opposed to EPAs proposal to rescind the 2014 Proposed Determination designed to protect Bristol Bays world class fisheries. Please stand with American jobs and communities and preserve the Bristol Bay Proposed Determination. I bet the workers, minors and native Americans like to eat salmon too. Keep Alaska free of any more pollution. It is home to thousands of caribou, and bears.

Bristol Bay, Alaska, is one of America's last great wild salmon fisheries. Each year, tens of millions of wild salmon return, supporting upwards of 14,000 jobs in the commercial and sport fishing industries, and serving as a one-in-a-lifetime destination for anglers from around the world as well as the cultural cornerstone for the region's communities. These long-established businesses are at risk from a foreign-owned mining company that wants to build the proposed Pebble Mine, which is opposed by more than 65 percent of Alaskans and more than 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents. 

In 2014, led by Alaska Native Tribes, interests including commercial fishing business owners and sportsmen asked the EPA step in to ensure that this mine wouldn't jeopardize Bristol Bay. The EPA responded by listening to over 1.5 million Americans, hosting dozens of community meetings, reviewing Pebble's many detailed filings with state and federal agencies, and conducting a twice peer-reviewed scientific assessment of the potential impacts to the region. Withdrawing the proposed determination ignores the overwhelming majority of Alaskans and puts the short-term interests of a foreign mining company above thousands of local jobs. 

For the sake of our wildlife, waterways, and communities, I urge you to protect Bristol Bay and prevent this horrible open-pit mine from destroying one of our nation's most precious ecosystems.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment submitted by M. Bell
Comment:
I urge you, please do not lift any of the 2014 proposed restrictions to the Pebble Mine project. The potential impacts to the environment and the Pacific salmon runs continue to be severe, and the need to maintain the health of the Bristol Bay ecosystem is critical. 

"Open-pit mines typically contain their byproducts in large dam systems, which have been known to leak or fail. This is precisely what happened at the Mount Polly gold mine in 2014, where a dam failure unleashed about 4.5 billion gallons of water and toxic debris into the surrounding salmon habitat.

Such a disaster, Northern Dynasty is quick to point out, will not happen at Pebble, as modern engineering techniques will be used to prevent any failure. And they're right: the probability of a dam failure is extremely low. But as with any probability, it increases with time. And the EPA report explains that, while all of the gold and copper would be mined out of Pebble in about a century, the waste would need to be maintained 'for centuries and potentially in perpetuity.'"

(Lucas Isakowitz, from the article for Project Earth - https://projectearth.earther.com/copper-gold-or-fish-how-a-massive-mining-project-is-t-1818507080).

Sincerely,
Morgan Bell
Seattle, WA

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment: Do not withdraw these clean water protections. From the background of this announcement, I easily found the following: "In 2014, EPA's Region 10 completed a multi-year effort to assess the Bristol Bay watershed." A 10-year review process! That sounds very detailed and careful, and by definition spanned two previous administrations, not just the Obama administration. The Bristol Bay fishery generates $500 million a year, could continue indefinitely as long as the watershed is not contaminated and destroyed by extraction, and provides income is spread over far more citizens than would be employed at the mine. And mining would ruin not only the fishery, but opportunities for lots of other use of this area in the future: it would ruin landscapes, curb enthusiasm for tourism and recreation, and harm wildlife. Many local people, including indigenous communities who are routinely ignored in decisionmaking, are against the mine as is the current governor of Alaska. Withdrawing clean water protections is an incredible short-sighted decision. Do not do it.

Title: Comment submitted by A. Weiner
Comment:
Dear EPA Administrators:
           Please do not withdraw the July 2014 Proposed determination to restrict mining of the Pebble Deposit.  This area is pristine and too valuable in terms of subsistence fishing and recreational value as well as ecosystem value.  Your mission is to uphold rights of the public need for clean water and air and this withdraw, although possibly required as far as the 404 Army Corps permit process is too dangerous to be allowed.  When human error is possible in any mining or other dangerous activity (radiation refining or nuclear weapons/power generation;  oil drilling in waterways) the next seven generations need to be protected.   This "Question" of whether to gut environmental protection aspects which this proposed withdrawal equals is a travesty and is inconsistent with your mission.  
          If the needs of this case is such that the foreign mining interest Trumps the needs of our citizens and environment,  there need to be trade agreement clauses that allow an international tribunal to accurately weigh benefits and risks with deference to traditional people's WAY OF LIFE, HEALTH, SAFETY AND LEVELS OF STRESS -in the event of a dam failure which may not happen immediately, but could very well happen in the near term-- of Alaskans, Canadians and all peoples who depend on fish for their sustainance.  
           In the event that this withdrawal of the July 2014 Proposed Determination to Restrict mining of the Pebble deposit is allowed, I am asking that the Administrator of the EPA and the area administrator replace the determination with a DECISIVE RULE that will protect these valuable waters with the same or more strict protections  as the above proposed determination limits on amount of material able to be disposed in the public domain.
            Thank you for considering seriously all of the comments that are delivered, and also the effect that your decisions will have on your family, descendants and friends, many of whom will depend on resources and recreation that could be decimated if the wrong decisions are made!!    I would like to be informed of ongoing events in this sphere by email or regular mail.                                                                                                                                                                asweiner@fuse.net
Alan Weiner   7102 GRacely DR. #1 Cincinnati, OH  45233

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
The Pebble Deposit has countless benefits that will aid the US in becoming an exporter of Copper - an element that we will soon see demand far exceed the supply for. Environmentally friendly advances, automation, electronics - all require copper. It is also a VERY large resource for gold and many other precious metals. And it just so happens to be on US soil, where it will be regulated and followed through to the highest degree of scrutiny by US standards. This is important for both the local populations in native Alaska, and also for longevity/integrity of the project. 

The many jobs and economical benefits for not only the US, but Alaska as a whole.. a state in dire need of an economic boost.. the Pebble Project will create all of these opportunities and more for many generations to come.

Northern Dynasty Minerals is taking the utmost care with this project, ensuring all environmental concerns are addressed and mitigated. They have been open and honest during the entire process, spent millions on scientific and environmental impact studies, and have shown the ways to avoid Salmon population impacts, as well as ways to strengthen and increase the population in the area.

I believe those opposed to this project need to look at this through unbiased eyes. If one considers all aspects of this project, it becomes abundantly clear that when the benefits (and risk mitigation) are considered, this project needs to happen.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
EPA never had the statutory authority to initiate a Section 404(c) process in the absence of a permit application.  Under the Clean Water Act (CWA), the Corps has the authority to grant permits while EPA has only the authority to veto permits.  The CWA does not permit EPA to impose pre-permit (or preemptive) restrictions on development over large areas of land, as EPA has attempted to do in Bristol Bay.

Under Section 404(a), the Corps evaluates a permit application (proposing a specific mine with specific control and mitigation measures) using guidelines it developed in conjunction with EPA and complies with NEPA and regulations developed by the Council on Environmental Quality.  EPA, under 404(c), may then prohibit "the specification ... of any defined area" or deny or restrict the use of "any defined area for specification."  Thus, EPA cannot act in the absence of a permit application detailing the specification and area of development.

The conduct of EPA over the last 40 years confirms that its issuance of a preemptive veto is unprecedented.  EPA has only exercised its authority under Section 404(c) thirteen times.  In each instance, EPA invoked Section 404(c) only after receipt of a permit application that described the scope and details of the project being proposed, the anticipated environmental impact, and techniques to be employed to mitigate or control that impact.

The House Oversight Committee in 2015 concluded that "EPA's use of a preemptive veto (at Pebble) was unprecedented and without a legal basis."  The Committee described EPA's course of action as "an unprecedented change in the agency's process for regulating resource and development projects," and called on EPA to "cease all preemptive 404(c) activity" to allow for the normal permitting process to take place. 

Many Alaska industry and trade associations expressed concern about the EPA abandoning the normal process for evaluating projects such as Pebble.  They joined with national trade associations in expressing this concern multiple time.  The rules and the rule of law matter.  Removing the Proposed Determination is an important step in returning fair and due process to the EPA.
Withdrawal of the Proposed Determination will not harm the environment; it only allows PLP to engage in the normal permitting process.

EPA must withdraw its Proposed Determination because it was based on an untested, ad hoc analysis that is not sanctioned by the CWA or NEPA.

Normally, a proposed developer submits a Section 404 CWA permit application to the Corps.  Once the permit application is filed, NEPA requires the Corps to "take a hard look" at potential impacts of the development application and prepare an Environmental Impact Statement ("EIS"). 

Rather than waiting for PLP to file a Section 404 permit application, and adhering to the traditional permitting process, EPA commissioned a watershed assessment of the Bristol Bay region - the Bristol Bay Watershed Assessment ("BBWA").  The BBWA - the scientific analysis underlying the Proposed Determination - was fatally flawed.

The BBWA examines the effects of three hypothetical mining scenarios on salmon fisheries, but none of these hypothetical mining scenarios incorporated industry best practices, and were in fact demonstrably un-permittable under U.S. and Alaska regulations.

The BBWA also largely dismisses the possibility of compensatory mitigation, which would be an obvious and required feature of any robust permit application review process. 

Ruling against a project at the end of an open process that prioritized science and informed decision-making is a possibility every investor faces.  Investors do not expect, however, to be shut out of a contrived, one-sided process from the beginning and informed of the rejection at the end.  That is exactly what EPA did to PLP when it initiated the preemptive veto here 

The harmful effects of continuing with EPA's veto process will go well beyond the mining industry, as 404 permits are required in so many circumstances that they affect every area of our economy.  

The Corps processes approximately 60,000 permits a year, and, according to some estimates, roughly $220 billion of investment per year depends on these permits.  These investors expect regulators to place reasonable restrictions on projects; they typically do not expect regulators to make preemptive decisions based on new policy courses before an application is even submitted.  For the process to be fair, developers must have a full opportunity to present plans, defend science, and modify projects to meet legitimate concerns.  This is good policy; it is also the law.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
The proposed Clean Water Act determination should NOT be withdrawn. The potential impacts of the proposed Pebble Mine on the health of the Bristol Bay watershed and the livelihood of thousands of people in Alaska are far too great. Those risks include loss of up to up to 94 miles of salmon-supporting streams and up to 4,900 acres of wetlands and ponds, and the very real potential of wastewater dam failure resulting in damage to or destruction of the salmon fishery. The watershed supports the largest sockeye salmon fishery in the world and 25 federally recognized tribes who for 4,000 years have depended on the fishery for their subsistence-based culture. The overwhelming majority of residents of Bristol Bay are opposed to the project, and a statewide majority of voters also oppose it. The watersheds unique ecological resources generate significant economic benefits and employment. EPAs original watershed assessment was scientifically robust and thoroughly peer-reviewed. That assessment and related public comments should strongly influence any future action.

References:
U.S. EPA. An Assessment of Potential Mining Impacts on Salmon Ecosystems of Bristol Bay, Alaska (Final Report). U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Washington, DC, EPA 910-R-14-001A-C, ES, 2014.
EPA Region 10, Proposed Determination Pursuant to Section 404(c) of the Clean Water Act for Pebble Deposit Area, Southwest Alaska, July 21, 2014.
2017 EPA and Pebble Limited Partnership Agreement.
U.S. EPA. An Assessment of Potential Mining Impacts on Salmon Ecosystems of Bristol Bay, Alaska (Final Report). U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Washington, DC, EPA 910-R-14-001A-C, ES, 2014. Chapter 5.
United Tribes of Bristol Bay. Opposition to Pebble Mine Reiterated by local tribes, fishermen, business owners.
Alaska Bristol Bay Mining Ban, Ballot Measure 4 (2014).

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
Please do not withdraw the Bristol Bay Proposed Determination, which it made pursuant to the Clean Water Act in 2014.

Bristol Bay, Alaska, is one of America's last great wild salmon fisheries, supporting tens of millions of wild running salmon. The region support thousands of fisheries and recreation-based jobs that would be jeopardized by using these watersheds as a dump for mining waste. 65% of Alaskans and 80% of Bristol Bay residents oppose the proposed Pebble Mine.

In 2010, led by Alaska Native Tribes, interests including commercial fishing business owners and sportsmen asked the EPA step in to ensure that this mine wouldn't jeopardize Bristol Bay. The EPA responded by listening to over 1.5 million Americans, hosting dozens of community meetings, reviewing Pebble's many detailed filings with state and federal agencies, and conducting a twice peer-reviewed scientific assessment of the potential impacts to the region.

Withdrawing the proposed determination ignores the overwhelming majority of Alaskans and puts the short-term interests of a foreign mining company above thousands of American jobs.

Please do not withdraw the proposed determination.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment: Alaska and specifically Bristol Bay is in dire need of the Pebble mine. The younger generation of Alaskans deserve to have meaningful and decent paying jobs. Of 5,394 working age residents in Bristol Bay, only 63% worked in 2011 and only 35% were employed throughout the year. By providing Alaska and Bristol Bay 3,000 high wage jobs (mine workers average over $100,000/year), Pebble will provide a much needed boost to the regional economy in Bristol Bay. Pebble mine would increase Lake and Peninsula Borough tax base by a staggering 600% over 2013 levels while the infrastructure build out for the project would provide affordable electricity for Southwest Alaska. Pebble-related economic activity in Alaska will boost the state's GDP by more than 3% over 2011 levels as the mine will generate $1 billion in annual operating expenditures in the area. Northern Dynasty has publicly stated that they won't go ahead with the mine if it means sacrificing the salmon. Ultimately, the rule of law needs to be upheld and the Army Corps of Engineers should have the final say on whether the project should go ahead. To not allow this mine to go through without valid reasoning is to deny thousands of Alaskans good paying jobs without a reason and to prevent the greater Alaskan economy from reaching its potential.

Title: Comment submitted by J. Plum
Comment:
The Proposed Determination must be withdrawn to remedy the EPA's prior overreach. Under the Clean Water Act, the Corps of Engineers has the authority to grant permits while the EPA only has the authority to veto permits, not impose pre-permit restrictions on development over large areas of land.  Rather than waiting for PLP to file a Section 404 permit application, and adhering to the traditional permitting process, EPA commissioned an assessment of the Bristol Bay region - the flawed Bristol Bay Watershed Assessment.  Many Alaska industry and trade associations expressed concern about the EPA abandoning the normal process for evaluating projects such as Pebble.  They joined with national trade associations in expressing this concern multiple times.  Removing the Proposed Determination is an important step in returning fair and due process to the EPA.  The rules and the rule of law matter. 

Sincerely,
Junius Plum

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
This issue was debated ad naseum before the 2014 decision to restrict discharged of mining material into the Bristol Bay watershed, and it was clear that there was an overwhelming consensus that the net impact of allowing discharge would be negative. The impact studies conducted prior to 2014 were thorough and rigorous. Impact studies, meetings, and public comment all overwhelmingly agreed that it would be terrible to allow the Bristol Bay mining project to continue.The American people were led to believe that this decision was final, and that the decision to not allow discharge in the watershed was in the interest of the American public. 

The only thing that has changed since the 2014 decision is EPA leadership. Nothing else has changed, and there is absolutely no objective reason that this should be subject to reevaluate. The American people spoke very loud in voicing overwhelming opposition to this project. The ecological impacts are potentially devastating; the economic impacts are potentially devastating; and the political impacts are potentially devastating. 

The only people that stand to benefit from this project are a small group of associates of the new EPA administrator. It's unfathomable that this would be up for reevaluation. There is no other way to explain it other than patent political corruption.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
After three years of peer-reviewed study, the EPA found that a copper mine above Bristol Bay "would result in complete loss of fish habitat due to elimination, dewatering, and fragmentation of streams, wetlands, and other aquatic resources." 
The EPA also found that "All of these losses would be irreversible."
This region produces nearly half of the world's annual sockeye salmon catch. Its ecological resources support 4,000-year-old indigenous cultures, as well as about 14,000 full- and part-time jobs. 
With the proposed action, this will all be lost to create a copper mine that is not needed.  
The fact that this proposed change is happening because Tom Collier met with Secretary Pruitt came to a settlement seems clearly done for the sake fo business and not for the needs and interests of the American people and the protection of the environment.
Re-read the Mission Statement of the EPA, "The mission of EPA is to protect human health and the environment." 
The proposed action would do neither!

Title: Comment submitted by  V. L. Massachusetts
Comment:
If I understand the scenario, Pebble LP had the chance to submit their application, but didn't do so?  Why should the government extend the application process for them?  If the argument is about upholding the law then why would we change the "rules" for a single company?  That is not right or fair.  Donald Trump recinded DACA because he felt that Obama had changed the "rules" for this group of people.  Is it not contradictory to then change the application process for Pebble, a single company??  The ruling should stand as was passed and not be withdrawn.  It has been made very clear in factual data that the Bristol Bay area provides 40% of the world's Sockeye Salmon - why would we do anything to risk polluting this area, contaminating the fish, and poisoning the people who eat this extremely important food?  In addition, should harm occur to this area there are thousands of people at risk for either a severe reduction in their income or their jobs would be wiped out entirely.  Why would our government chose to open a process that could harm the American people??  The job of the government is to PROTECT its people!!!!  Do not rescind the 2014 EPA determination to close the application process.
Thank you.
Valerie Lin
Massachusetts

Title: Comment submitted by S. Saunders
Comment:
I respectfully request you do not allow this Pebble Co. to mine in the Alaskan Salmon Fishery or Bristol Bay. I understand you want to be friendly to business, that America system enables businesses to make as much money as they can. I agree with this principle. But not when it threatens one of the most productive fisheries and most beautiful places on this planet. Surely there are other areas where this can occur? Is there not another area where this business can make money? Is there not a monetary value to the salmon this bay provides? The jobs the fishing industry provides? The tourism Alaska's wilderness and beauty  brings to the state?
This area provides half the world's salmon! "The area is regarded as one of the world's most important salmon fisheries, producing nearly half of the world's annual sockeye salmon catch. Its ecological resources also support 4,000-year-old indigenous cultures, as well as about 14,000 full- and part-time jobs, according to the EPA's 2014 report." The EPA scientific studies have said this mining would irreversibly harm this bay. 
You have gone too far and this will end up costing taxpayers millions of dollars because the Environmental Groups will fight you tooth and nail, as they should. Please do the right thing and halt this application which you will in all likelihood approve if you are not willing to stop it now.
Sincerely,
Susannah Saunders
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
My sisters and I travel to southwest Alaska on cruises every August, visit salmon hatcheries, and see bear and eagles feeding on them.  Every year there are more cruise ships.  A huge amount of Alaska's income and residents livelihood is dependent on the natural migration of the salmon in this area.  Salmon farms have parasites and don't look healthy.  These wild salmons are the ones served on cruise ships and excursions and sold in vacuum packed packages.  They are the ones tourist come to see running up natural streams.  They are the ones eagles and bear depend on.  

As a CPA, I'm positive the jobs and tax revenue provided by mining this area cannot come close to the tax revenue and jobs generated by tourists and fishing.  Eagles will starve, and bears we currently photograph from a distance will begin to come dangerously  close to people and increase attacks as they come into town looking for food with increasing frequency.

The jobs and tax revenue from mining is finite while tourism, fishing and photographing wildlife goes on in perpetuity.  Once they exhaust the resources, there is nothing but irreversible damage to the habitat.  They can't return to where they were born, they will not spawn, the population of one of the most prolific salmon habitats in the world will ceases to reproduce.  The price of salmon and salmon oil supplements will sky rocket.  Fisherman, tour guides, boat captains, bus drivers, and chefs will be unemployed due to fewer salmon.

Title: Comment submitted by S. K. McLaren
Comment:
EPA:

Nearly half the world's sockeye salmon comes from Bristol Bay. Given our ever increasing populations, I think it's foolish to do anything to potentially reduce a major food source.

I was in Durango, Colorado when old mining toxins turned the river yellow-orange in 2015. That's the thing. The mine might be safe for some years, but one year it won't be, and the mining company will be long gone when a major disaster happens, leaving the tax payers and a government agency to attempt to undo permanent damage. When no more abandoned mines pollute rivers in the Rockies, I might have more faith in mining companies, but time and time again, they show us they are not worthy of that faith.

Alaska is a seismically active area. Because of that, a lot can go wrong here. 

We get one earth. One. And it needs to sustain life for many, many, many generations. We have to make smart, conservative choices so that future generations may live. I worry that greedy minds are thinking far too short term. Future generations will live with the consequences of this decision forever. 

I strongly oppose disturbing this important salmon ecosystem-- not just because I love eating salmon, and because all living things there depend on salmon, but the livelihoods of thousands of fishermen deserve to be protected too. It is a delicate enough balance without throwing a mine into it.

Thank you for your consideration.
Sherry Kaya McLaren
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
This comment is in favor of keeping the restrictions in place set by the EPA for the waters in the South Fork Koktuli River, North Fork Koktuli River, and Upper Talarik Creek watersheds in southwest Alaska. 

Restrictions must continue because of several proven facts that all students learn in elementary school. 

1.	Fish eggs and shellfish need sediment-free water to survive. If you bury salmon eggs in sediment they will not get the oxygen it needs to survive. That is why salmon do not bury their eggs in mud banks. Shellfish need oxygen as well and unlike fish, they cannot move if they are covered in sediment.  

2.	Sediment is created by the disruption of the soil combined with a means to transport that soil, namely wind, water, and ice. This process is known as erosion.  

3.	In nature, erosion is limited by plant growth. The foliage slows the rate of water hitting the soil surface and then the roots of the plants help to hold the soil in place acting like a large sponge. This basic balance in known and understood by the vast majority of elementary students across the world. 

4.	Mining is equally easy to understand, you dig a hole to get what is buried underneath. In the process, you create a pile of overburden that you dug out of the hole. The bigger the hole the bigger the pile of overburden.

With these four basic and universally agreed upon facts, it is simple to determine that any mining operation in the watershed of these rivers will create sediment which will be transported by erosion to the watershed which will then cause damage to the surrounding ecosystem. There is no mining system in the world that does not create overburden, erosion, and sedimentation. The question, in this case, is the size and scale of this damage.  

To address the size and scope of the damage comes the next question, "What is the unacceptable adverse effect?"

Lawyers for the mining company will start to argue that some small percentage of damage is acceptable - who cares about 1 or 2 percent damage to the ecosystem. The moment one allows any concession on the percentage of damage that is acceptable you have lost the argument for all the people and wildlife affected by those changes.   

For example, if there was a 1% change in the number of salmon. Fishermen in the area catch roughly 35 million fish a year, a 1% loss is a drop of 350,000 fish a year which translates into roughly 7 million pounds of salmon. Losing that much salmon is a significant blow both to the local economy and the global food supply as a whole. Looking at the real impact of even slight percentages of damage shows that any damage is an unacceptable adverse effect on someone or something.  

If showing the simple process of soil disruption wasn't enough to demonstrate the importance to keep the restrictions in place there always the toxic chemicals that will be released. These too will cause an unacceptable adverse effect.

The EPA was created to protect and regulate our air, water, and soil, to allow mining lawyers who's interest is not in protecting the environment set the acceptable level of "adverse effect" is a disservice to citizens and wildlife of this country. 

EPA please do your duty and keep the restrictions in place.

Thank you for your consideration.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
Free market capitalism is not inherently evil.  Free markets naturally produce economic activity which, allowed to take there course, maximize economic benefit of a particular resource.  When a resource is abundant and there to be exploited, the free market system will ensure that the resource is converted to economic value with the highest economic efficiency.

In the case of fisheries and other natural resources, this process can be too efficient resulting incremental economic benefit far slighter than the long term consequences of full exploitation of a resource.   That is, free markets are terrible at putting on the brakes and managing, rather than exploiting, a given resource.

My point here is that managing fisheries is required even when they are protected, and fishermen have learned to live with the regulations that ultimately ensure the ongoing availability of the underlying resource.

In the case of Bristol bay, we have a situation where it is not the fishermen that are the threat, but an alternate use of the resource.  This is not a clean water issue, that is a technicality and a loophole.  The direct environmental impact of diverting the estuaries and rivers in which wild salmon spawn could have devastating economic consequences to fishermen, even if one has no empathy for the fish.

There are two important questions to answer here: 1) Is there scientific, peer-reviewed evidence to suggest that Bristol Bay would be negatively impacted, and 2) does the EPA have standing to prevent it.  I believe that the answer in both cases is yes, and therefore the EPA should NOT reverse the scientific conclusion reached over years of study, but continue to soberly apply the law.

The free-market system only works well in the context of well regulated public resources.  We cannot have commerce without policemen.  We cannot have peace without an army.  We cannot have fish without an effective EPA.

Title: Comment submitted by W. Rems
Comment:
Aloha,

I'm writing to oppose the recent EPA decision to lift Mining restrictions placed on Bristol Bay under the Clean Water Act of 1972. Bristol Bay is a pristine natural resource which supports thousands of local fisherman, and should be preserved for future generations in perpetuity.

Copper mining is a notoriously dirty process even with advances in mining technology in recent years. Heavy metals from mining tailings can leach into groundwater and nearby streams, and impact sensitive wildlife: https://www.nature.org/ourinitiatives/regions/northamerica/unitedstates/alaska/explore/final-lit-review-amd.pdf .

Other mining operations in Alaska near sensitive environmental areas demonstrate the difficulty in enforcing environmental regulation and holding mining companies accountable for pollution and remediation of natural resources http://juneauempire.com/news/2017-03-05/toxic-water-leaches-prime-alaska-canada-salmon-habitat .

Given the risks associated with open pit mining, the probability of polluting another pristine natural environment is far too great in this case to allow any mining operations in this area. The EPA should pursue all avenues (including legal and regulatory action) to preserve Bristol Bay and other sensitive areas in the US for future generations of Americans.

Aloha,

William Rems

Title: Comment submitted by P. A. Miller
Comment:
RE: Docket ID No. EPA- R10-OW-2017-0369

Dear Mr. Pruitt,

As an Alaskan resident, I supported the sensible pro-active measures laid out in the EPA Region 10, July 2014  Determination, pursuant to the Clean Water Act.  At this time I am writing to urge you not to withdraw the EPA Region 10, July 2014 Determination which would prohibit the Pebble Limited Partnership (PLP) access to copper, gold, and molybdenum ore deposits in the watersheds of Bristol Bay.

The advance protection of critical wetlands at the watershed level is a smart step in this area because half of the world's remaining wild sockeye salmon runs come from the Bristol Bay watershed, and these in turn support local resident's existing economies from subsistence to sport and commercial fishing and other vital hunting and fishing tied to the cultural values of the land and waters.

No matter whether the size of the proposed mine, the July 2014 ruling laid out the facts that these remarkable wetlands should not be sacrificed for unavoidable conflict.  It is better to have in place this Determinination, and continue to support it, than to continue the conflict and the waste of state, private, and individual time for a project that would only lead to a boom bust situation and long term degradation of the environment, water quality and the salmon habitats.  
As EPA director you make a legacy decision for generations of Alaskans.  Please keep the July 2014 determination in place.  Do not allow PLP or any entity access to these rich wetland habitats and watershed.

Sincerely,

Pamela A Miller
1800 Musk Ox Trail
Fairbanks AK 99709
pammillerarctic@gmail.com

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I am opposed to EPAs proposal to rescind the 2014 Proposed Determination designed to protect Bristol Bays world class fisheries. Please stand with American jobs and communities and preserve the Bristol Bay Proposed Determination.

Bristol Bay, Alaska, is one of America's last great wild salmon fisheries. Each year, tens of millions of wild salmon return, supporting upwards of 14,000 jobs in the commercial and sport fishing industries, and serving as a one-in-a-lifetime destination for anglers from around the world as well as the cultural cornerstone for the region's communities. These long-established businesses are at risk from a foreign-owned mining company that wants to build the proposed Pebble Mine, which is opposed by more than 65 percent of Alaskans and more than 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents. 

In 2014, led by Alaska Native Tribes, interests including commercial fishing business owners and sportsmen asked the EPA step in to ensure that this mine wouldn't jeopardize Bristol Bay. The EPA responded by listening to over 1.5 million Americans, hosting dozens of community meetings, reviewing Pebble's many detailed filings with state and federal agencies, and conducting a twice peer-reviewed scientific assessment of the potential impacts to the region. Withdrawing the proposed determination ignores the overwhelming majority of Alaskans and puts the short-term interests of a foreign mining company above thousands of local jobs. 

For the sake of our wildlife, waterways, and communities, I urge you to protect Bristol Bay and prevent this horrible open-pit mine from destroying one of our nation's most precious ecosystems.

You need to do your job correctly! Must I remind you that you are supposed to PROTECT the environment instead of destroying it! YOU work for the American people not the polluters of the world! Do your job or RESIGN!

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
These comments are regarding Docket ID No. EPA-R10-OW-2017-0369.

I strongly oppose the withdrawal of the July 2014 Proposed Determination.  
If a decision is made to withdraw the July 2014 Proposed Determination following the comment period, the Administrator should review and reconsider the withdrawal decision, as allowed by EPA regulations.  
  
As a retired water resources specialist, and resident of the Pacific Coast, I am strongly opposed to opening the watersheds of Bristol Bay to mining. I specifically object to the current EPA proposal to withdraw the July 2014 Proposed Determination to restrict the discharge of dredged or fill material associated with the potential "Pebble Mine" in Alaska's Bristol Bay watershed.  

Land use changes in the lower 48 states have been major contributors to the dramatic decline of the salmon fishery in the Pacific Ocean, adding sediment and pollutants to rivers and streams in which these fish spawn. This has led to severe restrictions on commercial and sport salmon fishing along the US west coast, with economic ripple effects through fishing communities.  

In 2014, the EPA conducted a thorough risk assessment of the potential impacts of large-scale mining on Bristol Bay's world-class commercial, recreational, and subsistence fisheries as well as on the native Alaskan peoples whose culture is strongly rooted in the fishing tradition. On the basis of this evaluation, they proposed to restrict discharge of dredged or fill material, pursuant to the Clean Water Act.  This is a rational conclusion, protective of the natural resources of this vast watershed, and of the interests of future generations of Native Alaskans.    

Please stand behind the science and recommendations represented by the EPA's 2014 Proposed Determination.  There is no compelling reason to allow large mining companies to profit at the expense of the public trust.  Opening the permitting door has no clear beneficial outcome to the parties involved.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I am writing to urge that the proposed determination to withdraw the EPA Region 10 July 2014 NOT be carried out for a number of reasons:

1) The potential impacts of the proposed Pebble Mine on the health of the Bristol Bay watershed and the livelihood of thousands of people in Alaska are too great to accept:
2) The watershed supports the largest sockeye salmon fishery in the world.
3) The watershed is home to 25 federally recognized tribal governments who have maintained a salmon-based culture and subsistence-based way of life for at least 4,000 years that would be placed in jeopardy.
4) The watershed's ecological resources generated nearly $480 million in direct economic expenditures and sales and provided employment for over 14,000 full- and part-time workers in 2009.4
Contrary to comments by the backers of the Pebble Mine project, EPA's watershed assessment was scientifically based and thoroughly peer-reviewed, and the public has had an extensive opportunity to comment on it. The assessment and public comments received should be key components of any future action on this issue.
5) The overwhelming majority of residents of Bristol Bay are opposed to the project. A statewide majority of voters also oppose it, as evidenced by the 2014 State-wide ballot measure.
6) The rationale for the proposed withdrawal is flawed. Finalizing the proposed determination would provide much more regulatory certainty than withdrawing it, and a permit application is not needed to augment the factual record.
7) Over its lifetime, this copper and gold mine could generate nearly 23 billion tons of dangerous waste, wiping out over 90 miles of salmon streams and almost 5,000 acres of intertwined wetlands, ponds and lakesthe very heart of this rich salmon ecosystem. I could not be more adamant about protecting one of the most productive, pristine, valuable and vulnerable ecosystems remaining in North America today, for the sake of all Americans.

I appreciate the opportunity to submit my comments, and sincerely hope that Bristol Bay's precious ecosystem continues to thrive without interference by any mining or other development.

Contrary to comments by the backers of the Pebble Mine project, EPAs watershed assessment was scientifically based and thoroughly peer-reviewed, and the public has had an extensive opportunity to comment on it. The assessment and public comments received should be key components of any future action on this issue.
5) The overwhelming majority of residents of Bristol Bay are opposed to the project. A statewide majority of voters also oppose it, as evidenced by the 2014 State-wide ballot measure.
6) The rationale for the proposed withdrawal is flawed. Finalizing the proposed determination would provide much more regulatory certainty than withdrawing it, and a permit application is not needed to augment the factual record.
7) Over its lifetime, this copper and gold mine could generate nearly 23 billion tons of dangerous waste, wiping out over 90 miles of salmon streams and almost 5,000 acres of intertwined wetlands, ponds and lakesthe very heart of this rich salmon ecosystem. Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment submitted by J.  Hanson
Comment:
I am writing as a concerned citizen and a recent visitor to the Bristol Bay watershed in Alaska. I urge you to not withdraw the Bristol Bay Proposed Determination, which it made pursuant to the Clean Water Act in 2014.

I was fortunate to recently visit Bristol Bay, Alaska, one of America's last great wild salmon fisheries. I spent a significant amount of money to visit Katmai National Park to view wildlife (coastal brown bears) and experience the salmon run. This is an important, sustainable form of the tourist industry and I hope that many more people can experience this pristine wilderness.

Further, Bristol Bay is critical for the fishing industry and local jobs. millions of wild salmon return annually, which support upwards of 14,000 American jobs in the commercial and sport fishing industries, serve as a one-in-a-lifetime destination for anglers from around the world, and are the cultural cornerstone for the region's communities.

These long-established American businesses and jobs are at risk from a foreign-owned mining company that wants to build the proposed Pebble Mine, which is opposed by more than 65 percent of Alaskans and more than 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents. 

In 2010, led by Alaska Native Tribes, interests including commercial fishing business owners and sportsmen asked the EPA step in to ensure that this mine wouldn't jeopardize Bristol Bay. The EPA responded by listening to over 1.5 million Americans, hosting dozens of community meetings, reviewing Pebble's many detailed filings with state and federal agencies, and conducting a twice peer-reviewed scientific assessment of the potential impacts to the region.

Withdrawing the proposed determination ignores the overwhelming majority of Alaskans, millions of tourist who visit Alaska to view wildlife and experience wilderness, and puts the short-term interests of a foreign mining company above thousands of American jobs. 

Please do not withdraw the proposed determination.

Thank you for your consideration.

Sincerely,
Justine Hanson
Boston, MA

Title: Comment submitted by D. Weir and R. Sternberg
Comment:
Dear EPA,

We are writing to express our opposition to the EPA's May 2017 settlement agreement with Pebble Partnership, a subsidiary of Northern Dynasty Mining Company.   The EPA determined back in 2014 that the Clean Water Act prohibited this  type of project proposed for Bristol Bay.  Despite this conclusion, in May of 2017 the EPA agreed to a settlement with Northern Dynasty Mining Company.  In a nutshell, the settlement terms were as follows: Northern Dynasty would drop the lawsuits it filed against the EPA in exchange for the EPA agreeing to withdraw its regulatory conclusion that Northern Dynasty Mining Company's proposed mining operation violated the Clean Water Act.  The public was not allowed to engage, comment, or otherwise take part in the settlement, which was negotiated behind closed doors.

EPA Administrator Scott Pruitt heralded the settlement, noting that while the EPA was "committed to due process and the rule of law... [the settlement would] help steer EPA away from costly and time-consuming litigation..."  Yet Mr. Pruitt's assertion completely contradicts due process and the rule of law.  The EPA made its Clean Water Act ruling in 2014, prompting Northern Dynasty Mining Company to immediately file suit, as Northern Dynasty Mining Company was entitled to do.  But now, the EPA is allowing Northern Dynasty Mining Company to submit its permit despite the EPA having already determined the proposed mine would violate the Clean Water Act.  In effect, the EPA's settlement completely nullifies due process and the rule of law, which dictate that the matter is settled vis--vis the Administrative Agency (the EPA) and the Northern Dynasty Mining Company.  If the Northern Dynasty Mining Company wants to fight the EPAs's ruling, they should do so through the Judicial Branch.  

 In 2016, Donald Trump ran on a pledge to put America first.  Yet nothing could be more antithetical to putting Americans first than allowing foreign profiteers to bypass the Clean Water Act and imperil Bristol Bay's unparalleled salmon fishery, which accounts for over 14,000 American jobs.  As a result, we request that the EPA not agree to this settlement. 

 
Sincerely,

Diana Weir and Roger Sternberg

Title: Comment submitted by A. Foster
Comment:
To the EPA,

The function of the EPA is to protect the environment, not corporate America. I am from Ohio and have vivid recollections of the river of fire, i.e, the days the Cuyahoga River caught fire and burned because of the terrible pollution. It's not a coincidence that the EPA came into existence shortly thereafter.

Alaska is a tremendous resource for this country and even the world. It is one of the last pristine places and should be treated as such. I have great faith in the idea that the scientists working in the EPA during the Obama administration undertook the study of this issue with due diligence and returned the correct decision. Why would the EPA now go back? 

Bristol Bay is one of the most important salmon fisheries in the world. That's a fact. That fishery generates 14,000 jobs. That matters. So does the continued health of the fishery. Certainly that's more important to Alaska, the U.S. and humanity than a copper mine that will blight the pristine landscape and, potentially, kill the fishery with its run off.

It is not worth the risk

Aimee Foster
Stuart, FL 34997

Title: Comment submitted by S. Stegoc
Comment:
Having just read about Scott Pruit's decision to withdraw the proposal to protect Bristol Bay, I am writing to encourage the EPA to change course, and continue to fight for protection of these wetlands in Alaska. Here is a quote from the CNN article. I hope you have the common decency to govern for the people, not the corporations. 

'Within hours of meeting with a mining company CEO, the new head of the US Environmental Protection Agency directed his staff to withdraw a plan to protect the watershed of Bristol Bay, Alaska, one of the most valuable wild salmon fisheries on Earth, according to interviews and government emails obtained by CNN.

The meeting between EPA Administrator Scott Pruitt and Tom Collier, CEO of Pebble Limited Partnership, took place on May 1, Collier and his staff confirmed in an interview with CNN. At 10:36 a.m. that same day, the EPA's acting general counsel, Kevin Minoli, sent an email to agency staff saying the administrator had "directed" the agency to withdraw an Obama-era proposal to protect the ecologically valuable wetland in southwest Alaska from certain mining activities.
In 2014, after three years of peer-reviewed study, the Obama administration's EPA invoked a rarely used provision of the Clean Water Act to try to protect Bristol Bay after finding that a mine "would result in complete loss of fish habitat due to elimination, dewatering, and fragmentation of streams, wetlands, and other aquatic resources" in some areas of the bay.
"All of these losses would be irreversible," the agency said.'

Suzanne Stegic
1904 Jame Ave. So.
Minneapolis, MN 55403

Title: Comment submitted by H. Siegel
Comment:
To whom it may concern,

The EPA first and foremost is required under the Clean Water Act to protect the nations waters. Both for their ecological value and economic value. The Bristol Bay area is "home to more than 20 fish species, 190 bird species, and more than 40 terrestrial mammal species, including bears, moose, and caribou". It's also the largest stockeye salmon run in the world producing 480 million dollars in economic benefit and 14,000 jobs each year. Allowing an exception from the Clean Water Act at Bristol Bay will not only destroy this environment and industry it will impact the people who call this area home, including 31 local tribes. 

The assessment is clear, the degradation of this area resulting from mining operations and waste disposal will be permanent, irreversible, and detrimental. If the EPA's decisions are to be based on solid science they must follow the suggestions of the research that has been done.

In regards to following "the rule of law" by allowing the withdrawal of this proposal, as the EPA's Scott Pruitt has claimed, the proposed determination is not outside the realm of the EPA. "The Clean Water Act generally requires a permit under Section 404 from the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers before any person places dredge or fill material into wetlands, lakes and streams.  Mining operations typically involve such activities and must obtain Clean Water Act Section 404 permits. Section 404 directs EPA to develop the environmental criteria the Army Corps uses to make permit decisions. It also authorizes EPA to prohibit or restrict fill activities if EPA determines such actions would have unacceptable adverse effects on fishery areas, shellfish beds, water supplies, wildlife, or recreational areas". Mining actions in Bristol Bay have been determined to have unacceptable adverse effects and thus should not be considered.

Finally, this issue concerns me directly as a citizen of this country where the profits of companies are considered before sound science and those that will be directly impacted. 

Thank you for your time,

Helen Siegel

Title: Comment submitted by E. Forrer
Comment:
Aug  9, 2017

Environmental Protection Agency:


During the State of Alaska Frank Murkowski administration (2002 - 2006) the Alaska state government engaged in a process described as the 2005 Bristol Bay Area Plan in order to determine the designation of state lands, among them the lands that include the Bristol Bay river headwaters.  While these lands are obviously critical habitat for fisheries, Governor Murkowski and his commissioner of natural resources made sure that the chosen designation made these lands open to future development.   This ideologically driven decision was widely seen as a misuse of power and the Nondalton Tribal Council, leading a coalition of 5 village councils, Trout Unlimited, and The Alaska Fisherman's Marketing Association sued to reverse the decision and initiate a new process of determination.  (State, Dept. of Natural Resources v. Nondalton Tribal Council (1/20/2012) sp-6638)
In this they were not successful as the Alaska Supreme Court sided with administrative power on what amounts to a technicality and against the local area people.  This event set the stage for the Pebble controversy because if the Bristol Bay uplands had the habitat designation they should have had, mining would never have been on the table in the first place.

Now for some years a number of companies with varying degrees of financial backing have been doing small-bore drill analysis of the mineral deposits and outlining an open pit and deep rock mining proposal primarily for copper in the Bristol Bay uplands.  Seeking to defend their lands, the last remaining world class sockeye fishery,  and their way of life, a group of villages asked the EPA to do an analysis of the situation and the land and waters with a view to obtaining a designation that would do what the Murkowski administration should have done in the first place, namely to protect critical habitat.    Many voices joined in the discussion, or the confrontation if you want, and as these voices became more frustrated by corporate legal tactics and conservative political maneuvering, they were told to be patient and trust the process.   "There is a process, just hang in and trust the process."   This advice came from the Congressional offices of both Begich and Murkowski.  (Same name, definitely related.) After tens of thousands of hours of travel, testimony, public meetings, and following the process, the EPA came to a determination under the clean water act and proposed a designation and rule regarding dumping in the Bristol Bay river systems that would prevent the Pebble Mine and other mines from being developed.   So hats off to you Senators Murkowski, Begich, and now Sullivan, the process you impressed upon us worked and we got protection for the Bay.  

Except for one little remaining maneuver.  A new federal administration and a new EPA commissioner have informed us that we just need to start over.  The old process: all the testimony, all the statements, all the science, all the meetings from Seattle to Bristol Bay: it turns out it was all smoke and mirrors.  We were told to trust something that ghosted through our fingers and became nothing.  We can trust the new process though, right?  

To this new public process I submit all the testimony, all the science, all the petitions, all the process documentation that went before, amounting to some ten years of work by civic groups, by government agencies, and by scientists of different stripes.  Based on the substance of this process the EPA came to a decision and that is the only acceptable decision that can be concluded now.  Any other decision than the one already reached makes liars out of the congressional delegation who knew full well that the 'process' could and would be manipulated to achieve a pro-industrial development agenda. If the EPA does not verify and certify the decision it already reached, it constitutes a massive betrayal of the people and the process we were told to trust.  Any other decision is incontestable evidence that the current administration is in fact not a government but is instead the creature of a self serving and ideologically driven private agenda, determined to manipulate the mechanics of government for its own ends.  Any other decision than the one made to defend the Bristol Bay uplands under the clean water act is a defacto declaration of war on the people and their sacred lands and waters.

I am,

In mortal fear of my own government and their willingness to trash their own rules,

Eric Forrer
resident of Alaska since 1962
907 321 5630

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment: It saddens me that the 'rule of law' should be up for debate in a country that was founded on the law being supreme over its leaders rather than vice versa. When the EPA illegally shut down Pebble's opportunity to move forward with permitting, the government showed its willingness to be 'above the law' in quite unprecedented though not surprising ways. 'Protecting the environment' sounds like a noble cause, just like when the tag line 'its for the children' is added to some piece of legislation. Well if it saves the earth or the lives of children, how can it be questioned? If you have traveled to Nicaragua, the wealthiest country in Latin America in terms of natural resources, and compare its economy to Costa Rica, its neighbor to the south, also compare what happens to the children when a government withholds a countries' natural resources from the people who actually should receive the benefits. A government that allows its people to reap the rewards of their own natural resources provides opportunities for the economy to grow and children to be taken care of for generations. A government that doesn't is destroying opportunities for its people to grow economically and enjoy personal freedoms that make life the blessing that it should be. Who owns the land Pebble is on? A governmental bureaucracy in Washington? A government 'for the people, by the people' doesn't impoverish its people with its own self-serving platitudes. And while we are saving the environment with electric cars, a noble cause, let's also ask how much copper EACH of those cars requires to operate. The Toyota Prius requires 64 pounds! Where will that copper come from and which countries' children will reap the benefit of having found and sold that copper? I don't believe that environmental health and the prosperity of a country have to always be in a battle with each other. Let's take a look at the $150 million dollar research which has already been spent on Pebble's environmental impact studies, and see if there is a way to help an area of our country desperate for economic development while maintaining an amazing and beautiful environment. If the rule of law is to be maintained, there is no question that Pebble should be allowed to move forward with a process that only guarantees fairness and objectivity, allowing the people of Bristol Bay to clearly assess the decisions they alone should be making.
