Title: Comment submitted by D. Swasey
Comment:
As an Alaskan resident, I am concerned about the possible outcomes of the Pebble Mine. The communities and ecosystem that will be affected by this mine are rich in culture and biodiversity. 

The salmon populations that call these possibly affected watersheds home are important to the entire ecosystem in Southwestern Alaska and watersheds downstream. The salmon feed all predators and scavengers in the areas of the watersheds. They also feed the surrounding ecosystem with nutrient from their carcasses as they spawn in the waterways. These salmon are also massive food source and culturally important for the people that call the watershed areas home. They are also economically important to not only those people that live within the watersheds, but for the entire State of Alaska. 
Both the science from the 2014 Proposed Determination findings and my personal beliefs agree that the economic revenue and jobs that this mine can create, cannot possibly outweigh the cultural and ecosystem significance of the watersheds that will be involved of the proposed Pebble Mine.

Please do not allow the Pebble Mine to make irrevocable harm. 


Very Respectfully,

Dillon Swasey
Anchorage, AK

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment: I am a professional fisheries scientist and have worked in Bristol Bay on sockeye salmon, including field work in the Iliamna Lake basin, for 30 years. I feel very qualified to pass judgement on this issue, based on this extensive research in Alaska, and also in British Columbia and Washington. I teach fisheries science at the University of Washington, and wrote a book on The Behavior and Ecology of Pacific Salmon and Trout. It is my considered view that this recent step, re-opening the door to mining in the region (Pebble Site, and other claims) in extremely unwise and represents a total abandonment of the fundamental responsibility of the EPA. What are you thinking? Years of hearings, testimony, and scientific evidence would be swept away in a hasty and totally biased change of heart. You will not want to admit it, but the Obama administration's EPA did a really careful, thoughtful, and objective job. No need to revisit it at all.

I am writing to comment strongly against the 2017 Proposal to Withdraw Proposed Clean Water Act Restrictions on Mining Pebble Deposit. The Clean Water Act is there to protect the safety of the people, animals, and environment of the United States, and in the long run, the world.

Allowing a lifting of this ban so that Pebble Mining Company does not have restrictions on the discharge of dredged or fill material from the potential mining of the Pebble deposit in Alaska's Bristol Bay watershed is a gross injustice to the law itself, our safety, and the vitality of the environment and animals who live there.

Why should a mining company be given favor in the lifting of restrictive bans that would make their mining more difficult? Is the ease of their process more important than the irreversible damage that this could cause to the local ecosystem, and eventually the publics health?

I think not. And if the lifting of this restriction happens then we will know that the EPA is no longer supporting its purpose.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
Note to EPA..
It saddens me that the 'rule of law' should be up for debate in a country that was founded on the law being supreme over its leaders rather than vice versa. When the EPA illegally shut down Pebble's opportunity to move forward with permitting, the government showed its willingness to be 'above the law' in quite unprecedented though not surprising ways. 'Protecting the environment' sounds like a noble cause, just like when the tag line 'its for the children' is added to some piece of legislation. Well if it saves the earth or the lives of children, how can it be questioned? If you have traveled to Nicaragua, the wealthiest country in Latin America in terms of natural resources, and compare its economy to Costa Rica, its neighbor to the south, also compare what happens to the children when a government withholds a countries' natural resources from the people who actually should receive the benefits. A government that allows its people to reap the rewards of their own natural resources provides opportunities for the economy to grow and children to be taken care of for generations. A government that doesn't is destroying opportunities for its people to grow economically and enjoy personal freedoms that make life the blessing that it should be. Who owns the land Pebble is on? A governmental bureaucracy in Washington? A government 'for the people, by the people' doesn't impoverish its people with its own self-serving platitudes. And while we are saving the environment with electric cars, a noble cause, let's also ask how much copper EACH of those cars requires to operate. The Toyota Prius requires 64 pounds! Where will that copper come from and which countries' children will reap the benefit of having found and sold that copper? I don't believe that environmental health and the prosperity of a country have to always be in a battle with each other. Let's take a look at the $150 million dollar research which has already been spent on Pebble's environmental impact studies, and see if there is a way to help an area of our country desperate for economic development while maintaining an amazing and beautiful environment. If the rule of law is to be maintained, there is no question that Pebble should be allowed to move forward with a process that only guarantees fairness and objectivity, allowing the people of Bristol Bay to clearly assess the decisions they alone should be making

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
A marine scientist and commercial salmon fisher in Alaska has informed me about this proposed change in the rules. I am also strongly opposed to opening the watersheds of Bristol Bay to mining. I join her in specifically objecting  to the current EPA proposal to withdraw the July 2014 Proposed Determination to restrict the discharge of dredged or fill material associated with the potential "Pebble Mine" in Alaska's Bristol Bay watershed.

 Land use changes in the lower 48 states have been major contributors to the dramatic decline of the salmon fishery in the Pacific Ocean, adding sediment and pollutants to rivers in which these fish spawn. This has led to severe restrictions on commercial and sport salmon fishing along the US west coast, with economic ripple effects through fishing communities.

 In 2014, the EPA conducted a thorough risk assessment of the potential impacts of large-scale mining on Bristol Bay's world-class commercial, recreational, and subsistence fisheries as well as on the native Alaskan peoples whose culture is strongly rooted in the fishing tradition. On the basis of this evaluation, they proposed to restrict discharge of dredged or fill material, pursuant to the Clean Water Act.

 The current Director of the EPA seeks to reverse this decision. This action would be a terrible mistake, with impacts not only to the fishery itself, but to the many fishermen (including Native Americans) and to the entire ecosystem based on salmon-derived nutrients.

 Opening the door to the Pebble Mine would be the only the beginning of a disastrous crash in the Alaskan salmon fishery and all those that depend on it. We've done this already in the lower 48 states. Let's learn from the past, and keep the July 2014 Proposed Determination in place."

Comment: No pebble mine!
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I urge you to uphold and maintain the EPAs determination, under EPA Clean Water Act 404(c) authority, that Alaskas Bristol Bay is inappropriate for the proposed Pebble Mine  The mining companys continued effort to destroy the country's most productive salmon fishery in exchange for short-term mineral wealth is morally offensive and a gross misuse of this precious watershed.
 
The prospect of a hardrock mineral mining operation as such gargantuan proportions as envisioned by Northern Dynasty would devastate an exquisitely sensitive watershed and the rich productivity of aquatic life, capped by a salmon population of awesome fecundity. The food chain of Bristol Bay is inextricably dependent upon a watershed that yields a reliably low sediment, high-oxygen water supply. The proposed mining operation would disfigure and transform the watershed, with a sprawling network of infrastructure bleeding sediment at every rain, exposed ore seams that shed acidic runoff, and large pits that interrupt the subterranean movement of water.
 
Bristol Bay epitomizes the aquatic resources that EPA was entrusted to protect through the Clean Water Act 404(c) review process, and it has done so correctly. You have a sacred moral obligation, as well as a legal responsibility as EPA Administrator, to protect this priceless of vital aquatic ecosystem. The Clean Water Act enshrines Americas determination that certain levels of aquatic ecosystem destruction are unacceptable, and the transparent, scientifically rigorous process conducted by EPA found correctly that Bristol Bay epitomizes this category.
 
Bristol Bay salmon support thousands of fishermen from across Alaska, the west coast, and other parts of the nation who descend on this remote and pristine region every summer to harvest the "red gold."  The fishery represents a multi-million dollar industry whose impact is felt across the country. Salmon are also the life-blood of local village economies and support centuries old subsistence traditions of the Native cultures in western Alaska. The compelling, overriding importance of Bristol bays intact ecosystem is illustrated by the support for EPAs finding among both Native and Anglo Alaskans, who traditionally and well-disposed to resource development, but correctly recognized the singular importance of Bristol Bay.
 
This ecosystem is a priceless treasure; the minerals and the trinkets they would be used to manufacture are not. Even if EPA limits its analysis to a mere utilitarian calculation of economic productivity, no question exists that maintaining the salmon production is more valuable than any mineral extraction. Any dilution or repeal of the prior administrations Clean Water Act finding would be a gross miscarriage and abdication of your responsibility. Thank you for your attention to this urgent issue.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
We all need clean air and water and unpolluted food in order to stay alive. Our environment is not for sale to the highest bidder. Your immoral agenda violates nature and humanity!  
I am opposed to EPAs proposal to rescind the 2014 Proposed Determination designed to protect Bristol Bays world class fisheries. Please stand with American jobs and communities and preserve the Bristol Bay Proposed Determination.

Bristol Bay, Alaska, is one of America's last great wild salmon fisheries. Each year, tens of millions of wild salmon return, supporting upwards of 14,000 jobs in the commercial and sport fishing industries, and serving as a one-in-a-lifetime destination for anglers from around the world as well as the cultural cornerstone for the region's communities. These long-established businesses are at risk from a foreign-owned mining company that wants to build the proposed Pebble Mine, which is opposed by more than 65 percent of Alaskans and more than 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents. 

In 2014, led by Alaska Native Tribes, interests including commercial fishing business owners and sportsmen asked the EPA step in to ensure that this mine wouldn't jeopardize Bristol Bay. The EPA responded by listening to over 1.5 million Americans, hosting dozens of community meetings, reviewing Pebble's many detailed filings with state and federal agencies, and conducting a twice peer-reviewed scientific assessment of the potential impacts to the region. Withdrawing the proposed determination ignores the overwhelming majority of Alaskans and puts the short-term interests of a foreign mining company above thousands of local jobs. 

For the sake of our wildlife, waterways, and communities, I urge you to protect Bristol Bay and prevent this horrible open-pit mine from destroying one of our nation's most precious ecosystems.

Title: Comment submitted by J. A. Benucci
Comment:
Dear Administrator Pruitt and Acting Administrator EPA Region 10 Michelle Pirzadeh 

My name is Joseph A. Benucci, a resident of Alaska.  This is NOT a form letter.  This is NOT a "bot."  This is not a cyber attack.  This is a father, an Alaskan, a Military veteran with 21+ years of service, AND a conservationist, writing to you to tell you that your attempt to withdraw clean water act determination for the proposed Pebble mine, which your own agency determined would cause great harm to Bristol Bay's world-renowned salmon runs, local fishery, and Native communities, is a bad deal for ALL Alaskans!

Bristol Bay is home to the most productive salmon ecosystem in the world.  It supports more than 14,000 American jobs and is valued at more than $1.5 billion annually.  While I know you think you are doing something good for the American economy, what you're really doing is destroying a way of life in Alaska, and potentially harming the worlds LAST great Salmon run.  Please, do not do what Russia has done.  Please do not do what dictators in Argentina and Chile have done.  Please, do not put short-term mineral extraction profits over the renewable resource of Salmon provided by mother nature.  

After years of rigorous study, I think you agency proposed science-based restrictions on the Pebble mine. Even with a scaled back mine, if you believe Pebble LLC's (ask yourself, why are they an LLC?) recent updated press release, the mine has the potential to be the largest open pit ever constructed in North America and generate billions of tons of dangerous waste, including antimony, arsenic, copper, manganese, molybdenum, selenium, zinc, and sulfate.  YOUR own scientist and independent subject experts agree, to store mine waste, there will need to be miles of dams reaching up to 740 feet high (that's taller than your building in DC by a factor of 10) to hold back what is essentially poison.  I don't know if you've ever been to Alaska, or know that the largest earthquake in North American history struck here on Good Friday a few years back, but the region's seismic activity and extreme weather conditions could trigger catastrophic dam failures.  Your recent move to reverse course and cut a deal with Northern Dynasty Minerals against the will of nearly two-thirds of Alaskans, 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents and Native communities, and 85 percent of commercial fishermen, strike of DC arrogance you are so quick to accuse your predecessors of.  For over 16 years, Alaska Native Tribes and commercial fishing business owners have been advocating against this toxic mega-mine. The EPA itself has hosted dozens of community meetings and conducted a twice peer-reviewed scientific assessment of the potential impacts to the region. In addition, more than 1.5 million Americans wrote to the EPA asking for strong protections for Bristol Bay.

While the mining company has said it will introduce plans for a smaller mine. It frankly doesn't matter, whatever size, pebble mine's infrastructure would include a network of roads, pipelines, a port, and an energy-generating station which will impact where our Alaska salmon fry grow prior to leaving for the Pacific Ocean.  Once established, this infrastructure could lead to the development of a mining district many times larger than the original Pebble mine lease with devastating consequences for the Bristol Bay watershed and local people.  I urge you to listen to the voices of local communities and businesses, joined by hundreds of thousands of people in Alaska and across the United States who oppose this dangerous mega-mine.
Don't put the interests of a foreign mining company above thousands of American jobs and keep the EPA's Clean Water Act protections for Bristol Bay in place.

Joseph A. Benucci
Concerned Alaska Resident & Veteran

Title: Comment submitted by N. Wilder
Comment:
Hello, as a lifelong Alaskan resident, I am writing about an issue close to my heart.
I am writing you today to ask that you stand with American jobs and communities and not withdraw the Bristol Bay Proposed Determination, which it made pursuant to the Clean Water Act in 2014.

As you know, Bristol Bay, Alaska, is one of America's last great wild salmon fisheries. Tens of millions of wild salmon return annually, which support upwards of 14,000 American jobs in the commercial and sport fishing industries, serve as a one-in-a-lifetime destination for anglers from around the world, and are the cultural cornerstone for the region's communities.

These long-established American businesses and jobs are at risk from a foreign-owned mining company that wants to build the proposed Pebble Mine, which is opposed by more than 65 percent of Alaskans and more than 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents. 

In 2010, led by Alaska Native Tribes, interests including commercial fishing business owners and sportsmen asked the EPA step in to ensure that this mine wouldn't jeopardize Bristol Bay. The EPA responded by listening to over 1.5 million Americans, hosting dozens of community meetings, reviewing Pebble's many detailed filings with state and federal agencies, and conducting a twice peer-reviewed scientific assessment of the potential impacts to the region.

Withdrawing the proposed determination ignores the overwhelming majority of Alaskans and puts the short-term interests of a foreign mining company above thousands of American jobs. 

Please do not withdraw the proposed determination.

Thank you.
Alaskan resident, 
Nathaniel Wilder
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment submitted by S. Lightcap
Comment:
As a professional Fisheries Biologist, I would respectfully ask the EPA not to withdraw the Clean Water Act protections currently afforded to the Bristol Bay watershed.  The environmental risks posed by allowing mining to proceed in this watershed are substantial, regardless of company claims to the contrary.  These risks have unfortunately been born out in the form of real impacts in countless watersheds throughout the country.  One only needs to look at the numerous Superfund sites, or the recent mining impacts that have been in the news, to get a feel for what's at stake here.  For additional site-specific details on these examples, please refer to the comment letter submitted by my professional society - the American Fisheries Society.

While I support the concept of business profits, I would ask that the EPA weigh the costs and benefits of a mining development scenario vs those of a fully protected, functioning watershed.  In the Pebble Mine scenario, profits (minerals) would be made by a one-time extractive process, that leaves behind a potentially devastating legacy of post mining impacts.  In the protected watershed scenario, profits (salmon harvest) would be made annually and in perpetuity, with no environmental risk or negative legacy.

As a restoration specialist in the lower 48, we no longer have the functioning watersheds at the scale of Bristol Bay.  While none of the extractive industries partially responsible for this situation set out to intentionally degrade these systems, we simply did not understand the consequences of our actions in time.   Now that we do understand the cause and effect relationships of these industries -we should utilize that information to make more informed choices.  A fully functioning watershed with all 5 species of wild, naturally produced Pacific Salmon is an amazingly rare resource, and one worthy of permanent protection.

Thank you for the opportunity to comment.  

Respectfully,

Scott Lightcap 
Fisheries Biologist 
Roseburg, OR

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
Mr. Pruitt and Colleagues,

I am writing to ask that you not approve Pebble Limited Partnership's application to mine gold and minerals in Bristol Bay. The health of the nation and our children depends on responsible and earth-first decision making. Further, closing the bay to mining would also be pro-business as it would support the Bay's multi-million dollar salmon fishing industry. Making sure that chemicals and harmful machinery are unable to reach fish and pollute the bay's waters is paramount to keeping the salmon thriving. 

In addition, chemicals that enter the water would harm the environment overall, reaching birds and other aquatic species, and, of course, humans. So many of America's waters, iconic ones like the Hudson River, have already been polluted by a number of different industries. When business is put over the health of the land and the people who depend on it, these things happen. 


I ask that you look at the wild fires in California, the hurricanes that ravaged Texas, Mexico, and Puerto Rico, and consider whether our environment can bear yet another blow at the hands of humans. And if being pro-business is still more important in your eyes, consider the hundreds of millions of dollars fishers, grocers, and restaurants produce thanks to the thriving salmon population in Bristol Bay. It is important to protect that business and the consumers who eat the fish that Pebble Limited Partnership's project would sicken. Please make the only responsible decision here and deny the application.

Thank You.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
Dear Administrator Pruitt,

I am writing to express my opposition to the US EPA's decision to withdraw Clean Water Act restrictions in regards to the Pebble Mine proposed for the Bristol Bay watershed. I have participated in instream fish surveys and habitat assessments in all three of the watersheds in question: Upper Talarik Creek as well as the North and South Fork Koktuli River (The Nature Conservancy 2010). Additionally, I have assisted with fish surveys in downstream and neighboring watersheds. During these surveys, my colleagues and I found fish in nearly 90% of the small tributaries and salmon in nearly 75% of each waterbody that we sampled.  Based upon this first hand experience as well as extensive additional study of the region, I agree with US EPA original watershed assessment's decision. 

This mine is incompatible with the long term health of the natural, renewable resources of the region and therefore incompatible with the long term health of the region's people. A mine of Pebble's scale would require water treatment and facility maintenance in perpetuity.  The mining industry in Alaska as in so many other states cannot identify large scale mines that have been properly closed in a safe and environmentally sound manner.  Examples of abandoned mines with lingering environmental problems in Alaska include the Platinum and Red Devil mines.  

I grew up going fishing with my grandfather and uncles in Pennsylvania coal country. Despite streams that were often crystal clear, we usually had trouble finding any fish especially trout.  The reason that the streams were so clear is the same one that there were no fish, acid mine drainage. I do not want to leave such a legacy for my own child or generations of Alaskans to follow me.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment: The development of the kind of mine proposed has been demonstrated to be possible without long term pollution to water quality anywhere in the World, ever before. In addition, the scale of this mine is completely out of proportion with the ability of any entity, be it private industry or government, to ensure that two major watersheds that host the largest sockeye salmon runs in the world can be protected into the future. This mine is the worst idea since smoking tobacco was promoted as a health aid. I have been an Alaska resident for 35 years and I resoundingly reject the concept of a "safe" mine with completely unproven technology to ensure environmental protection for the salmon producing watersheds and estuaries in the Bristol Bay region in perpetuity. This is not a wise use of a fisheries habitat that will never be rehabilitated in the event of a mining disaster like so many on the record around the world. Do not promote the development of this mine, it's wrongheaded and plain wrong. I'd like to close by thanking you for the opportunity to comment, but also to make sure you understand I am dead set against the development of the Pebble Mine.

Title: Comment submitted by D. Ransy
Comment:
Docket No. EPA-R10-OW-2017
	The Proposed Determination of July 2014, to restrict discharge of dredge and fill materials at the proposed Pebble Mine, should not be withdrawn. The proposed determination will uphold the Clean Water Act's legal requirements.
	Dumping earth overburden mine tailings or dredged and fill material into fish-bearing waters is a death-sentence for fish, if not all aquatic species. Mines are notorious for degrading water quality in the United States and throughout many other countries.
	Some of Bristol Bays critical watersheds are in the proposed mine areas of Koktuli River and Talarik Creek. Discharging mine waste, etc. into these waterways is irresponsible and a direct threat to the fishery. 
	I am a retired Bristol Bay commercial fisherman, and derived my livelihood from this and other Alaskan fisheries for years. Every year, thousands of commercial, subsistence, and sport fishermen and fisherwomen harvest the Bay's fish for both food and livelihood. 
	Mine development would require the development of the equivalent of a city in the headwaters. There are quite enough towns and villages in the Bristol Bay region at present. They serve both the permanent residents and the summer fishermen well. This new city would have an enormous footprint with water and sewer discharges, air pollution, fuel emissions, and all the rest. Loss of habitat would be widespread.
	Four major global mining companies have pulled out of this fiasco knowing it is not going to succeed either environmentally or financially. Many mines typically run until bankruptcy, then they are left to ooze toxic waste into Rivers for decades with no one to pick up the tab for clean-up.
	Conclusion: EPA's proposed determination should stand and should not be changed or withdrawn.
Denis Ransy
Box 344
Talkeetna AK 99676

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I vigorously disagree with EPA's s removal of the restricted use designation for the Koktuli River and Upper Talarik Creek 
watersheds, that would prevent these areas from being used as disposal sites for materials associated with mining activities 
at the Pebble Mine. As a professionally licensed hydrologic engineer, I have served as a Qualified Person (as defined by the 
National Instrument 43-101) to international mining clients of comparable scale, on projects spanning many years. As such,
I am obligated to comment in an objective manner.

I understand the potential impact associated with a relaxation of federal regulation on a mining project of this scale and nature, 
set within this unique ecosystem. My experience has been that robust regulation may not provide the most economical plan 
for a mine, but may serve as the only means to prevent a potentially irreversible catastrophic impact on what is oftentimes a
truly remarkable environmental resource. 

Additionally, lifting the restriction allows the Pebble Mine to operate to a lower standard not imposed on existing mines, setting
an unfair advantage to the new mine, and possibly paving the way for future mines to be held to a much less rigorous 
environmental standard. Please consider maintaining the restricted use designation and demanding that the Pebble Mine 
investigate alternatives for the disposal of mine affected materials. Existing mines have been held to a much higher standard, 
Pebble Mine should as well.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
EPA Administrator Scott Pruitt's backroom deal with a foreign mining company -- to bring back from the dead the massive Pebble Mine gold and copper mine -- seems to be only in the "best" interests of the mine company's owners. The significant collateral damage -- the loss of 14,000 jobs, the loss of a world-critical salmon fishery, the irreversible ruin of the spectacular Bristol Bay wilderness, and the irreparable harm to the indigenous people and culture -- is an unacceptable affront to American citizens and our public commons, resources, and trust.

As EPA Administrator Pruitt and his staff well-know: After three years of peer-reviewed study, the Obama administration's EPA invoked a provision of the Clean Water Act to protect Bristol Bay after finding that a mine "would result in complete loss of fish habitat due to elimination, dewatering, and fragmentation of streams, wetlands, and other aquatic resources" in some areas of the bay. "All of these losses would be irreversible," the agency said. The area is regarded as one of the world's most important salmon fisheries, producing nearly half of the world's annual sockeye salmon catch. Its ecological resources also support 4,000-year-old indigenous cultures, as well as about 14,000 full- and part-time jobs, according to the EPA's 2014 report.

This project must not move forward as the pollution and environmental destruction would be a catastrophe for the communities and wildlife of Bristol Bay. In fact, the Pebble Mine would turn this unspoiled wilderness into a toxic wasteland for decades to come. For these reasons, please do not withdraw the proposal to restrict the use of this area as a disposal site.

Please do not allow this project to move forward, for the good of the American people -- the general public and their grandchildren-- that you serve. You are responsible and accountable to the American public, not just the self-serving interests of one corporate executive team (of a foreign company) with their eyes on some hefty short-term profits that provide absolutely no public benefit. Thank you for serving the best interests of the American people.

Title: Comment submitted by  N. B. Furey
Comment:
Dear EPA,

I submit this letter in response to the proposal to withdraw the EPA's July 2014 Clean Water Act determination to restrict the use of certain waters as disposal sites for material associated with the proposed Pebble mine in Alaska. I am extremely concerned by the possibility that the Pebble mine will be allowed to move forward, and that it would result in catastrophic environmental and economic damage to the Bristol Bay region in Alaska and American fisheries.

It is apparent that the current administration probably cares little for the ecological value of Bristol Bay, so I'm going to focus on the economic benefits of Bristol Bay's sockeye salmon fishery. Roughly half of the world's sockeye salmon catch is from Bristol Bay and its tributaries, and the Bristol Bay salmon fishery is worth hundreds of millions of dollars annually ($300 million in 2009 as per the EPA's own website). The sum of indirect benefits of the Bristol Bay fishery are astounding - $1.5 billion in 2010. The Bristol Bay fishery also employs >11,000 workers each year. This is ten-times the number of workers the PLP would employ at the Pebble mine operation (1,000 employees for the first 20 to 25 years of the project). Thus the Bristol Bay salmon fishery represents a more consistent economic boon to a greater number of workers in the region. I would also add that the relative value of Bristol Bay salmon is likely to increase. With climate change, it is likely that the proportion of the world's sockeye salmon that is from Bristol Bay will increase as productivity of British Columbian sockeye decreases (namely from the Fraser River watershed). Aside from sockeye salmon, our American fisheries are more likely to increase dependence on Bristol Bay for other salmon species such as Chinook, chum, coho, and pink salmon, as their productivity in the Pacific northwest of the contiguous US continues to decline. 

I also strongly caution against assumptions or wishful thinking that the Pebble mine project could coexist with the salmon fishery. Sockeye salmon are highly adapted to their environment and sensitive to changes in water condition. Several closely related species (in both Oncorhynchus and Salmo genera) have been shown to avoid or even be physiologically impaired by low concentrations of heavy metal contamination. The Bristol Bay fishery is so productive because of the pristine conditions of its watersheds and tributaries. Any failure to keep mining byproducts out of salmon-rearing watersheds would be catastrophic with immediate and likely long-lasting economic losses to the region. I am not optimistic that the Pebble mine project could guarantee against catastrophic failures, particularly given the instability of the geology in the region (e.g. earthquake prone).

Lastly, I implore the agency to listen to the public on this matter, and to follow the desires of constituents rather than large commercial industries. A series of polls in the region (including independent ones conducted by the Hays Research Group, Dittman, and the BBNC) have demonstrated that the public is in favor of prohibiting the Pebble mine project, often by substantial margins.

In short, the Pebble mine project does not make economic nor environmental sense, and is not wanted by the public.

Sincerely,

Nathan B. Furey, PhD

Title: Comment submitted by J. P. Baumlin
Comment:
Removing a mine waste disposal restriction benefits no one, save the entity wishing to dispose of its waste in a slovenly and expedited manner, I suppose in order to save a few dollars in profits. 

Unregulated disposal can only lead to a degraded environment upon which all life, human and animal, depends for its sustenance, a consideration that I am aware means almost nothing to an administration that seems indifferent to science and environmental integrity. 

I remember a time when some of our waterways were so polluted that they caught fire. Please don't return the United States to an era of unregulated waste disposal. One of the things that makes our country great is the quality of life afforded its citizens, a quality that is directly a consequence of a healthy, functioning ecosystem. 

Thank you,
John P. Baumlin

Dear EPA,

Don't destroy this land because "we feel like it". 

I hope this letter finds someone in the EPA so you can realise that we, the people, are watching. While it may not get the sexy headlines of other issues, these are the type of proposals that get passed around quietly. Please do you job and stop this mine from being built. 

Thanks, 

Kevin McSpadden

Title: Comment submitted by A. Richards
Comment:
After reading the regulatory document I have several concerns and opinions:

1) Most importantly I believe the EPA should ABSOLUTELY NOT withdraw the July 2014 Proposed Determination at this time for the reasons stated above. I believe the reasons above are not sufficient reason to withdraw the proposal (as a settlement would not have altered the reasons the determination was reached in the first place - that is, the science and the reasons for protecting the land HAVE NOT CHANGED and if it was a bad idea to use the location as a dump site in the past it is a bad idea to use it as one now).

2) If a final withdrawal decision is made following this comment period, the Administrator should ABSOLUTELY review and reconsider the withdrawal decision. As I have said above - all evidence points to the dumping of waste at this location being environmentally destructive, and in particular devastating to the local sockeye salmon population. Any protections the EPA can issue concerning this area - particularly the current ones that preclude the Army Corps of Engineers from issuing a permit to dump waste in this location - must continue.

3) I understand that a settlement was reached and that the organization feels they must follow through with it. However, the settlement and the terms of it were not something that appears to be sufficiently reviewed - and that preserving the genetic diversity of a species (which in turn preserves valuable biodiversity that can never be regained if lost) is far more valuable than whatever economic consequences might develop from not following through with the settlement, or whatever might be lost if Pebble Limited Partnership once again sued.

4) This entire process of commenting has felt designed to inhibit public comment on this issue through excessive use of legalese, separating documents, and language discouraging a discussion of the science involved. An argument on the reasons NOT to allow PLP to apply for an Army Corps of Engineers permit to dump waste in this location (which they will almost certainly do, and which will almost certainly be approved - particularly without the EPA encouraging the Army Corps not to allow the permit) MUST involve discussion of what the science is, and how it has not changed. The idea that one can discuss environmental regulation without reference to the science involved is, quite frankly, appalling and demonstrates a certain duplicity on the part of the individuals attempting to drive this decision to withdraw the July 2014 Proposed Determination.

Sincerely,
- Aubin Richards
Citizen of the United States

Title: Comment submitted by N. Langston
Comment:
I strongly disagree with the proposed withdrawal of restricted use of area as a disposal site. The EPA found in 2014 that the mine development proposed by Pebble would create "unacceptable adverse effects" on salmon spawning and breeding areas.

No research since that date has shown that mining would benefit salmon. The proposed rollback of the restrictions is inconsistent with science. A mine would threaten the Bristol Bay region and economy and might devastate commercial and recreational salmon fishing. The headwaters of the Bristol Bay region sustains the world's largest sockeye salmon runs, and risking these waters and salmon runs to benefit a Canadian mining company is unacceptable.

Dr. Nancy Langston

Title: Mass comment campaign sponsoring organization unknown. Sample attached (web)
Abstract: 850 similar comments have been received to date for this web campaign
Comment:
I am writing you today to ask that you not withdraw the Bristol Bay Proposed Determination, which was made pursuant to the Clean Water Act in 2014.

As you know, Bristol Bay, Alaska, is one of America's last great wild salmon fisheries. Tens of millions of wild salmon return annually, which support upwards of 14,000 American jobs in the commercial and sport fishing industries, serve as a one-in-a-lifetime destination for anglers from around the world, and are the cultural cornerstone for the region's communities.

These long-established American businesses and jobs are at risk from a foreign-owned mining company that wants to build the proposed Pebble Mine, which is opposed by more than 65 percent of Alaskans and more than 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents. 

Please do not withdraw the proposed determination.

Title: Comment submitted by B. Bergstrom
Comment:
Hello,
	My name is Bailey Bergstrom and I am a senior at Humboldt State University. I am writing this comment on the EPA's proposal to withdraw the 2014 determination that the Pebble Mine should not be allowed as disposal sites for the Pebble Mine in Bristol Bay. Proposal to Withdraw Proposed Determination to Restrict the Use of an Area as a Disposal Site; Pebble Deposit Are, Southwest Alaska, 82 Fed. Reg. 33,123 (July 19, 2017).   I am concerned for the Bristol Bay fishery because my favorite animal is salmon. Because of this, I understand how important these fish are culturally, economically, and ecologically. When I was fortunate enough to visit South East Alaska, the thing that stood out to me most was the vast amount of plants and wildlife. When we were able to visit the Anan bear conservatory where we saw an incredibly healthy salmon run with bears, eagles, and other smaller animals. The incredible amount of life that congregated around the stream to consume the salmon was astonishing. The bears would catch the fish and the eagles and other critters would eat the carrion spreading the nutrients from the carcass all the way into forest and sometimes even into the trees. After seeing this beautiful feast, I could not imagine all of these animals convening around a dirty and polluted stream. Bristol Bay has a lot to lose if the EPA decides to withdraw the 2014 Clean Water Act Proposal Determination. 
	I do believe that the EPAs original proposed determination was correct and they should continue to protect the 50 million salmon that return to Bristol Bay every year. By continuing to restrict the use of dredged or fill material associated with mining the Pebble deposit, the EPA can avoid a total disaster. The Bristol Bay Fishery provides 12,000 jobs locally, and millions of jobs in total. Bristol Bays travel industry is also dedicated to fishing and hunting. If the salmon don't return both of these industries could take a dangerous economic plunge. The Pebble Limited Partnership (owners of Pebble Mine) also have not yet filed a Clean Water Act Section 404 permit application. This is concerning because Section 404 of the CWA establishes a program to regulate the discharge of dredged or fill material into waters of the United States. This permit is exactly what The Pebble Limited Partnership should have had to apply for and complete. The only industries that are exempt from Section 404 regulation are things like certain farming and forestry activities which of course this mine does not fall under either of these categories. If The Pebble Limited Partnership were to get a Section 404 permit, they would be subject to a permit review process. This is important because if the effects of the Pebble Mine, which will be the largest open pit mine in Northern America, are significant than they can lose their permit and would have to clean up the waterway to be able to reapply.  I believe that if the EPA withdraws its proposed determination it won't be meeting the mandate it was given based on the Clean Water Act. In the Act it states that "[The Clean Water Act was to] provide for the protection and propagation of fish, shellfish, and wildlife...and to eliminate all discharge of pollutants into the nation's waterways by 1985." Although we have obviously not met this goa,l the EPA could make change in our environment for better or for worse. I believe the EPA should follow the Clean Water Act and continue to make Bristol Bay a refuge for five species of salmon and a thriving fishery. Now is the time to be on the right side of history.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment submitted by E. Reibsome
Comment:
Dear EPA Region 10 Acting Administrator EPA Region 10 Administrator Michelle Pirzadeh,

	I am writing this comment about the EPA's decision to withdraw the previous conclusion that Pebble Mine would be restricted in using the area and its surround rivers as a disposal site located in Pebble Deposit Area, Southwest Alaska, 82 Fed. Reg. 33123 (July 19, 2017). It is absurd to think that it would be acceptable to withdraw the decision to restrict the use of certain waters in the South Fork Koktuli River, North Fork Koktuli River, and Upper Talarik Creek watersheds in southwest Alaska as disposal sites for the Pebble deposit. The original consensus in 2014 was correctly determined and should not be withdrawn. Reasons to withdraw such as the economic value of the minerals are not sufficient and completely ignore the impact to the ecosystem present and the Alaskan citizens who currently reside in Bristol Bay.
	In 79 Fed. Reg. page 42315 (July 21, 2014) of the original decision, the argument was made for the restriction of the site, "...because of the high ecological and economic value of the Bristol Bay watershed and the assessed unacceptable environmental effects that would result from such mining." The Bristol Bay, home to the sockeye species of salmon, has a high environmental value in the surrounding ecosystem. This species stated in the same decision are among, "the most abundant and diverse populations of this species remaining in the United States." Endangering this population of salmon endangers diversity, an area of environmentalism that is essential to both ecosystems and humans. For the EPA to allow the polluting of these waters and affect approximately half of the sockeye salmon population in the world, would be a decision that goes for everything the EPA stands for. It is appalling to think that the decision for the restricting, it now being withdrawn only three years later.
	Although this site is underdeveloped and has a high economic value, it does not make an excuse as to why it is okay to pollute this area. In the 79 Fed. Reg. page 42315, it states, "These salmon populations, in turn, maintain the productivity of the entire ecosystem, including numerous other fish and wildlife species." If down the road, the whole Pebble Mine operation pollution becomes a burdening problem in the surrounding area, the EPA would no doubt look to this withdrawal as a black eye on the administration as a whole. Salmon are extremely sensitive to the pollutants that would be introduced, even in trace amounts. Meaning salmon populations would inevitably be affected and so would the food chain in which it serves, destroying an ecosystem in entirety. It is safe to say that with the new EPA administrator, the EPA has begun to change the direction of the agency in favor of President Donald Trump's agenda; an agenda that does not take into account the environmental impact of developing and harvesting resources.
	Not only is the environmental impact ignored, but so is the economic and cultural impact on the surrounding area. Bristol Bay has a high investment in the surround fishing industry as noted in the original decision, 79 Fed. Reg. page 42315, "The Bristol Bay watershed's streams, wetlands, and other aquatic resources support world-class, economically important commercial and sport fisheries for salmon and other fishes..." The salmon population, being a renewable resource every year, brings in hundred of millions of dollars to the economy. To damage that industry in favor of a resource that takes thousands of years, essentially non-renewable in our lifetimes, would show a lack of intelligence and lack of planning for the future.
	Both Alaskans and the environment would feel the impact of withdrawing this decision given the reasons above. The EPA has a vital decision to make. Declining the withdrawal would be a correct step in protecting the wildlife present. Withdrawing a decision that was correctly made in the first place would show carelessness in decision making. It is essential that the EPA protects this area for environmental diversity, truly renewable resources, and American jobs for the future.

Thank you,
Ethan Reibsome

Title: Comment submitted by L. Cohen
Comment:
The EPA should move forward with its Proposed Determination (PD) under Clean Water Act Section 404(c) to protect the Bristol Bay Watershed. While mining is necessary to support our current lifestyles, large scale mining operations should not be located in the sensitive and unique ecosystems of Bristol Bay. There are two compelling reasons for this:

First, EPA should move forward using the scientific information that it has gathered to support this PD.

The EPA conducted a thorough, multiyear scientific investigation of the Bristol Bay Watershed and potential impacts from the proposal(s) by Northern Dynasty to mine the Pebble Deposit. Based on the projected impacts of a mine far smaller than those proposed to the company's investors, EPA concluded that mining operations would cause unacceptable adverse effects on fish and animal habitats in the Bristol Bay Watershed.  Consider the 29 species of fish, 40 terrestrial mammals and 190 species of birds that would be impacted; the losses of streams and wetlands; and the contamination of the land and water.  The magnitude of the projected environmental impacts are well documented in EPA's peer reviewed report, and these losses will be irreversible. The largest sockeye salmon fishery in the world will be destroyed forever, and the livelihood of those that depend on the salmon will also be destroyed. 

Second, EPA should move forward on this PD because it already followed an extensive public process on this matter, and it is a complete waste of government resources to ignore the existing scientific work and its conclusions and to begin a new project review process.

 EPA provided opportunities for public comment on two draft scientific assessments, which generated hundreds of thousands of comments. The current proposed to withdraw the PD is essentially waste, fraud and abuse of the Agency's procedures and its resources.  The EPA followed the Clean Water Act and its procedures.  In fact, EPA went above and beyond   the required procedures and offered two draft reports for public comment prior to publishing its final assessment. Administrator Pruitt, as reported in several newspapers, concluded that the PD should be withdrawn after meeting with advocates for the Pebble Mine. The Administrator has provided no information or evidence as to why the existing scientific assessment is flawed; in fact, to the contrary, the Administration states that the mining companies should have an opportunity to submit proposals and conduct environmental impact statements and as such, a fair process for moving forward. The process to date - with EPA's publication of the Final Bristol Bay Assessment in January 2014 -- was a fair process and compliant with the Clean Water Act. The existing EPA assessment is a thorough and legitimate basis for moving forward with the Clean Water Act 404(c) protections. 

Thank you for consideration of these comments.
Lori Cohen
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment submitted by J. Rowley
Comment:
The EPA should not withdraw from the EPA Region 10 Proposed Determination that was issued pursuant of the Clean Water Act. I fail to see what has changed with the land since the original assessment conducted by the EPA in 2012. The 2014 Determination proposed by the EPA to limit mining within the Bristol Bay area on the basis that the mine would cause "irreversible and unacceptable damage to the Bristol Bay salmon ecosystem." The EPA Office of Inspector General investigation stated that "The EPA addressed guidelines and followed policies and procedures when conducting the Bristol Bay watershed assessment. We found no evidence of bias or a predetermined outcome." There is no reason for the EPA to withdraw from the proposed determination if the assessment of the Bristol Bay area was accurate and conducted without bias. Which it was. The creation of this mine would harm some of the nation's best waterways for commercial and recreation fishing. Bristol Bay supports the largest Sockeye- Salmon run in the world, with around 46 percent of the world's population being produced in this region. The mine would impact waterways that support 29 of species of fish, 190 bird species, and more than 40 species of mammals, some of which depend on the salmon spawning. Damages to the Bristol Bay waterways would also have a negative impact on 31 Alaskan Native Villages that depend on the Salmon both for food and survival and the $480 million of economic activity that the fish produce. The salmon runs also contribute to more than 14,000 full and part time jobs to this region. The idea of destroying one source of income for the area to implement a new one that destroys the fragile ecosystem is ludicrous to me. The Native Alaskans have been using Bristol Bay as a fishing source for thousands of years and losing this fishery would change their way of life dramatically. If the fishery were destroyed, food for the local communities, commercial fishing exports, and tourism from recreational fishing in this world class spot would also be destroyed. The Pebble mine has no guarantees of economic increase to the area, only the guarantee of destroying a unique and valuable ecosystem.   

Thank You,
Jesse Rowley
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment submitted by S. Bowler
Comment:
To whom it may concern,
	My name is Stephanie Bowler and I am an Environmental Science and Management student at Humboldt State University in Northern California. I am writing this comment on behalf of the EPAs proposal to withdraw the 2014 Proposed Determination of the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency Region 10 Pursuant to Section 404(c) of the Clean Water Act. The EPAs 2014 decision on the Pebble Mine states in the Effective Summary (page ES-3) that The Bristol Bay Assessment established that the extraction, storage, treatment, and transportation activities associated with building, operating, and maintaining one of the largest mines ever built would pose significant risks to the unparalleled ecosystem that produces one of the greatest wild salmon fisheries left in the world. I deeply agree with this ruling because the deposit of wastewater from the mining of copper, gold, and molybdenum-bearing minerals will destroy the pristine ecosystem of Bristol Bay to such a degree that the ecological impacts will be irreversible. My position on this matter is to keep the 2014 decision on the Pebble Mine.
	The 2017 decision to withdraw the 2014 determination clearly goes against The Clean Water Act (CWA). The CWA is an essential law that helps the EPA reach their objective to protect and restore the environment and public health for current and future generations. Section 404(c) of the CWA authorizes EPA to prohibit, restrict, or deny the use of any defined area in waters of the United States for specification as a disposal site whenever it determines, after notice and opportunity for public hearing, that the discharge of dredged or fill material into the area will have an unacceptable adverse effect on fishery areas (including spawning and breeding areas). The Pebble Mine deposits will cause direct toxicity which will result in reduced survival and reproduction of fish, specifically the sockeye salmon and the Chinook salmon populations. On page ES-1of the 2014 Proposed Determination, it is mindful of the economic significance of the salmon ecosystem. The commercial wild salmon fishery in the Bristol Bay region has an estimated value of $300 million in sales from fishers to processors (EPA 2014: Chapter 5). The original policy decision of 2014 is a valid and extremely valuable rule because it will protect the ecosystem of the precious salmon resources for future generations. The proposed site of Pebble Mine is adjacent to two major watersheds that spread throughout the South-West of Alaska. The intrinsically complex network of wetlands, river, and streams in the Nushagak and Kvichak watersheds are very sensitive to changes and will result in widespread destruction because they are all connected to each other. The wastewater contaminates will spread throughout the watersheds and will exponentially damage the neighboring streams and wetlands. 
	In conclusion, the decision to withdraw from the 2014 ruling on Pebble Mine will have terrible impacts to the environment, the coveted salmon populations, and the communities that rely on them. The negative effects of the Pebble Mine will outlive the short term profit gain from the materials extracted in Bristol Bay. The EPA should resist submitting to the mining industry by striving to protect the watersheds and the people of Alaska. I urge the agency to deeply consider the environmental impacts of this project that were outlined in the 2014 ruling and ask oneself if these impacts are truly not valid in 2017. Many aspects of the environment are at stake with the implementation of this project. The consequences of this decision are a direct threat to over 14,000 fisheries jobs in the community. For many generations, the locals of Bristol Bay have relied on salmon to continue the traditions of their ancestors and to protect their way of life. The cultural and economic value of this ecosystem and its organisms are too great to be ignored by short term profits.

I, Stephanie Bowler, do not support the decision to withdraw from the 2014 determination. Thank you for your time.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment submitted by T. Garcia
Comment:
Hello,

I am a student at Humboldt State University pursuing a major in an Environmental Planning and Policy degree. I believe that the EPA's decision to propose to withdraw the proposed determination to restrict the use of an area as a disposal site; Pebble deposit area, Southwest Alaska, 82 Fed. Reg. 33,123 (July 19, 2017) violates the regulations outlined in paragraphs (a) and (c) of 40 CFR 231.5 of the Clean Water Act (CWA), Section 404 (c). Decisions such as these will result in harm to the people of Alaska and the wilderness and waterways that they depend upon for subsistence resources.

40 CFR 231.5 paragraph (a) outlines the time frame allowed to the regional administrator to either recommend determination or withdrawal after an initial proposed determination. Being that the public comments and hearings occurred in August and September of 2014 and the notice of withdraw of proposed determination occurred in July of 2017, due to an injunction proposed by Pebble Limited Partnership (PLP), this two year time period greatly exceeds the acceptable amount of time allowed for region 10's administrator to either recommend determination or withdrawal. As PLP is the holding company to the subsidiaries who own the mineral rights in question, it is clear that the lawsuit producing the injunction was intended to prohibit the EPA's final recommendation from being made.

40 CFR 231.5 paragraph (c) states that when a proposed determination is made, the regional administrator himself, or a designee, must decide on whether or not a withdrawal of a proposed determination should be made and the appropriate actions to take following this decision. Because the EPA's decision to withdraw the proposed determination was made under a settlement agreement created by the EPA and PLP, the decision was not the EPA's alone. Furthermore, accepting the negotiated settlement terms created by PLP, which excepts the project from review by Section 404(c) for a certain amount of time, temporarily forfeits the responsibility of enforcing CWA mandate. The agency does not possess the right to decide to ignore mandates, nor can these terms be agreed upon between an outside party, other than those specific situations outlined by Congress. 

Overall, the EPA's decision to propose to withdraw the proposed determination to restrict the use of an area as a disposal site; Pebble deposit area, Southwest Alaska, is arbitrary and capricious because it runs against the agencies initial decision of determination for no scientifically backed reasons. Withdrawing the proposed determination negates the EPA's responsibilities to uphold the CWA, thus endangering the Bristol Bay watershed fisheries, the Alaska Native people and their cultures, and the wildlife present in the region. Regardless of complaints put forth, the EPA does have authority to initiate a Section 404(c) review and the Bristol Bay Assessment (BBA), which was extensively peer reviewed and follows EPA guidelines for ecological risk assessment, does hold scientific credibility as well as the ability to influence the Section 404(c) process. For these reasons, the EPA should not go forward with its decision to withdraw the proposed determination of the site in question.


Thank you, 

Tatiana Garcia
trg163@humboldt.edu

Title: Comment submitted by P. Hogan
Comment:
Allowing this mine to begin operations would be a great mistake. Sacrificing pristine wilderness in favor of short-term gains would be an irreversible blunder of an immense magnitude. The American people, if given the opportunity to express themselves, would gladly note that we would rather pay the higher economic costs of not adding the relatively few jobs to the economy, and not having decreased prices associated with bringing added goods to the market. The aforementioned economic benefits would, in absolutely no way, outweigh the immense costs of destroying the region. 

I would love to discuss this further, if given the chance. 

Yours in conservation, 

-Patrick J. Hogan

Title: Comment submitted by J. Manker
Comment: My name is Jeff Manker and I am a registered voter of the USA. There are no circumstances under which this mining project should go forward. The salmon and other fish that live in these streams are too valuable as a food and cultural resource to put them at risk for the temporary enrichment of a few. Once this run of fish is destroyed by the inevitable mining "accident" they are gone forever. If we want more copper, go mine our garbage dumps for scrap.

Title: Comment submitted by C. Nichols
Comment:
I am opposed to the  pebble mine. Or any mines in the Bristol Bay watersheds. The Bristol Bay fisheries are the greatest sockeye runs in the world! To even think of endangering a totally renewable resource like this for a mine is so short sighted. 
The state of Alaska voted it down overwhelmingly. The EPA studied it for years and came to the conclusion it is too risky. Many many Americans have written in and voiced opposition. 
I don't believe for one  instant that NorthenDynansty is thinking of a "small" mine. They will be required to maximize profits for its shareholders. Once in there it is my belief that they will mine all they can and others will follow. The infrastructure to just get there will determine that more mining will happen. 
The waste from these open pit mines would have to be contained FOREVER without failures. The likely hood of a leak is too high. 
I am not opposed to all mining. But Bristol Bay watersheds is not the place for it!!! 
You can not buy back a clean healthy watershed full of the greatest salmon runs in the world once contaminated.
Please  reflect on that and tell Pebble mine and  any other wanting to ruin the amazing Bristol Bay watersheds NO NO NO!!!
Carolyn Nichols
111 Knutson Drive
Sitka, Ak 99835
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment submitted by D. Putman
Comment:
Environmental Protection Agency,
I am a concerned citizen writing to comment on the EPAs proposal to withdraw its previous proposed determination that Pebble Mine should not use certain waters in the Bristol Bay watershed as disposal sites. Proposal to Withdraw Proposed Determination to Restrict the Use of an Area as a Disposal Site; Pebble Deposit Area, Southwest Alaska, 82 Fed. Reg. 33,123 (July 19, 2017). In 2014, the EPA properly exercised its authority under the Clean Water Act, Section 404(c), when it issued the proposed determination that should not be withdrawn due to the severe environmental, economic, and cultural consequences.
Page 33,123 of the Federal Register states that the proposed withdrawal of the proposed determination is part of the settlement agreement of the lawsuit that Pebble Limited Partnership (PLP) filed against the EPA. PLP claimed that the proposed determination was a violation of federal law. However, section 404(c) of the Clean Water Act authorizes the EPA to restrict, prohibit, deny, or withdraw the use of an area as a disposal site for dredged or fill material if the discharge will have unacceptable adverse effects on municipal water supplies, shellfish beds and fishery areas, wildlife, or recreational areas. In January, 2014, The EPA completed an assessment of the potential impacts of large-scale mining of the area on fisheries, wildlife, and native cultures of the region. Subsequently, the EPA correctly exercised its authority to propose a determination that would restrict the discharge of pebble mine and protect the area from degradation. This process does not prevent a potential applicant from submitting a permit application to the Army Corps. Therefore, PLP could have done so while the 404(c) action was in process.
Bristol Bay contains an incredibly productive fishery where salmon play a very important role in the functioning of its ecosystem and the local communities. And according to the EPAs draft assessment of Pebble Mine, the fishery provides 35.5 million sockeye salmon annually, at least 14,000 jobs, habitat for an abundance of wildlife species, and subsistence to Alaska Natives. However, disposal of the dredged or fill material into these waters could have detrimental effects on the salmon as well as other aquatic organisms. Other impacts include a reduction in amount and quality of fish habitat, and loss of thousands of acres of wetlands. Wetlands are also of great ecological importance as they help to maintain water quality, serve as erosion and flood control, and provide habitat and recreation. I would certainly call these unacceptable adverse effects.
Proponents of the mine claim that it will provide jobs and benefit the local economy, but in doing so it would also take away many jobs that currently exist such as those of fishermen. The benefits are simply not worth the risk. Whats more, the sheer size of the mine is too much of a risk, for if it fails the effects could be disastrous and irreparable. Therefore, I am urging the EPA to protect the livelihood of the local community and fulfill its duty to protect the environment by exercising its authority to under the CWA to prohibit the discharge of dredged or fill material from Pebble Mine into the Bristol Bay Watershed. 

Thank you,
Danielle Putman
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment submitted by K. Hu
Comment:
I write in support of the communities of Alaska's Bristol Bay and ask
you not to withdraw the proposed determination to adopt restrictions
protecting the habitat of Bristol Bay's world-renowned salmon.

The proposed determination was made at the request of local
communities and adopted only after years of rigorous scientific study,
public participation and peer review. The EPA was correct in 2014 when
it found that the Pebble Mine would have "significant and unacceptable
adverse effects" on "one of the most productive, pristine, valuable
and vulnerable ecosystems remaining in North America today."

The EPA has noted that commercial fishing in Bristol Bay generates
hundreds of millions of dollars annually in direct sales of
commercially caught salmon, generating 11,000 jobs. These salmon
support not only the commercial and sportfishing industries, but a
traditional Native way of life that has endured for millennia and
thrives today.

The EPA should stand by its proposed determination and take all
necessary actions to protect the Bristol Bay watershed.

Sincerely,

Kochun Hu
Seattle, WA

Title: Comment submitted by R. Querin
Comment:
Please, please... DO NO HARM. If we can simply look beyond the end of our noses we can see that the chances for long-term environmental destruction are extraordinarily high. The disaster in Butte should be instructive -- mining companies do not have the technology or the desire to protect the area surrounding the mine site for generations to come. Please consider that 100 years from now, when all of us are dead and gone, the destruction created by this mine will still be tormenting the current generation. The same story 200 years from now. And 300 years. In short, in every American century to come, people who think and act with a conscience will marvel at the greed and shortsightedness that led to the creation of this Pebble Creek mining disaster. Please look beyond short term profits for a select few people and consider the big picture before voting on this important decision!
Best Regards, Randy Querin

Title: Comment submitted by K. Soderlund
Comment:
Please do not withdraw or rescind the Proposed Determination for Docket EPA-R10-OW-2017-0369. Please finalize the protections for the last great wild-sockeye salmon fishery on the planet. Alaskans depend on the salmon run here, not just for recreation but for their livelihoods. Bristol Bay provides so much to so many people, and historically we know that mining often leads to contaminated resources which negatively impact the area. We should be protecting these lands which we rely on, not selling them to the highest bidder. 

Thank you,

Krista Soderlund
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment submitted by W. Owens
Comment:
Growing up in rural north central Idaho, allowed me to visit and enjoy pristine wilderness.  Part of my young adult life was spent out along the Selway and Lochsa Rivers.  Rivers abundant with fish and recreational opportunities.  I have never personally been out to the proposed site of the Pebble Mine, but I am sure that the environment that encompasses the area is just as pristine and beautiful as my native area of personal growth.  These places were about spiritual maturation and respect for one's self and the environment.  John Muir wrote about the beauty of these wild places, holding them up as temples and places of worship.  I am writing to point out my disagreement on the EPA decision to withdraw its 2104 decision on the Pebble Mine Proposal to Withdraw Proposed Determination to Restrict the Use of an Area as a Disposal Site; Pebble Deposit Area, Southwest Alaska, 82 Fed. Reg. 33,123 (July 19, 2017).
In the Code of Federal Regulations under title 40, section 404C, the "Purpose and Scope" section clearly states that the regulations will restrict and deny anyone from causing any "unacceptable adverse effects" to a healthy ecosystem.  This also restricts the use of rivers and creeks in a watershed, and any large scale dredging operations. The scope and size of the Pebble Mine mining operations would drastically alter the watershed causing a collapse of the Bristol Bay Watershed.  Under the "Extension of time" section the administrator of EPA Region 10 may extend the deadline for the regulation. The drastic turn of events from the Obama administration and today's administration clearly states this.  Section 404C clearly states its intentions to protect water resources in and around a proposed project site by rejecting permits.
	When it comes down to it litigation, money, and a supply and demand economy will determine the outcome of an important decision.  Much of the problem lies in the public policy, a policy that can be misguided by the President of the United States.  The decisions and outcomes form these actions can polarize the public citizen, and put into jeopardy the natural environment.  The actions of the executive branch can be an overreach of power.  I think certain decisions can be irresponsible without careful consideration of all stakeholders. It's important that we follow the rule of law and to place our decisions on sound science and public participation on any level.  We must follow the process alone without the pressures of need and desire.  There needs to be more of an analysis and full public knowledge of the project.  I agree with this law with some reservations.
	Clean air and water should be a right and not a discretionary issue.  Where do we decide to change course?  When will we say "enough extraction and consuming?"  It's not an easy decision to make, due to our appetite for "more is better" attitude.  Our indifference towards understanding the world we live is evident throughout time.  But I am hopeful that we will gain an appreciation towards one's self identity.  


Sincerely,
William Owens
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment submitted by D. Layfield
Comment:
My name is Dylan Layfield and I'm currently a student at Humboldt State University studying environmental science and management with an emphasis in ecological restoration. I am writing to comment on the EPA's proposal to withdraw its 2014 determination that the Pebble Mine should not be allowed to use certain tributaries as disposal sites for the Pebble Mine. Proposal To Withdraw Proposed Determination To Restrict the Use of an Area as a Disposal Site; Pebble Deposit Area, Southwest Alaska, 82 Fed. Reg. 33,123 July 19, 2017. EPA's decision in 2014 carefully looked at the impact of mine waste disposal in tributaries. However, now it appears the agency is more concerned with mining interests rather than the watershed ecosystems and people of Alaska. One reason I am interested in this proposal is because of a watershed class that I am taking this semester. We have discussed the negative effects that large sediment deposits can have on fish populations. This will clearly be an issue if the EPA withdraws its 2014 decision. 
This proposal can threaten many, if not all, of the organisms in the watershed such as salmon and other fisheries. Rivers and streams typically have a certain load of sediment they can suppress. If more sediment is added in from the mine, the quality of the water will be reduced, which will impact the fish. If this material is discharged into tributaries the fish would not be able to see and they would be ingesting large amounts of sediments from the water. Additionally, the Bristol Bay is one of the last places on earth that has the largest salmon runs. Many fear that the disposal of mining material in the Bay will negatively impact the fish as well as animals that depend on them. Moreover, fish are not the only ones negatively impacted. In fact, many people who live close to the proposed Pebble Mine will be affected too. Fishermen (and fisherwomen) rely on these fish for a steady income and fishing in the Bristol Bay has been sustainable for many years; though Pebble Mine could bring in a number of jobs, the fact that those jobs will only last up to fifty years should not be forgotten. Another issue relevant to state is that accidents can happen. Even if the mine were to become operational and if they are not allowed to dispose of anything in the tributaries, accidents are bound to happen. Deposits from the mine could infiltrate into the soil and down into the ground water. In turn, this could then travel to streams and rivers, which could affect fish and other species. 
I do not believe EPA's proposal to withdraw its 2014 determination is good policy. I think EPA's first proposal in 2014 had a better understanding of the harm that can come from this proposed mine. The purpose of the Clean Water Act (CWA) is to govern water pollution. One section of the CWA that is worth mentioning is section 404; this particular program establishes ways to regulate the amount of dredged or fill material in bodies of water. One part of section 404 is especially interesting, which states that there will be no discharge of materials if there are alternatives that are less damaging to the ecosystem. Fishing is that alternative and it is one people in that area have used for many years. There are more than 14,000 jobs nationwide that rely on the bay and the fishing industry generates more than 1.5 billion each year. Sure the mine will bring in jobs and money too, but the fishing industry will fail because of it. In addition, to me it seems as though the EPA should have the authority to restrict the disposal of mining material in the watershed because this would be a point source. Also, in order to attempt to do this, Pebble Mine will have to get a permit from the National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System (NPDES), which is managed by the EPA. It appears Pebble Limited Partnership (PLP) does not have this permit from the readings that I have done. This is a good thing because PLP cannot legally dump anything into the waters until the permit is received. 
The proposed Pebble Mine in the Bristol watershed area will have a negative effect on fish species and human populations in the area. EPA's new proposal appears to be looking at mining interests rather than the communities that are around Bristol Bay. The mine will bring in jobs and money into the economy; however, the fishing industry is already so large in Bristol Bay and they accumulate a large amount of money each year that section 404 of the Clean Water Act should apply to this. Furthermore, if the mine were to become operational, nearly all the fishers in Bristol Bay would lose their jobs due to the impact that the dredged and fill material would have on the fish. Overall, I think the EPA needs to review its decision again and look at the impacts that this mine will have on communities in the bay.
