Title: Comment submitted by Ali [no surname provided]
Comment:
My name is Ali and I am currently pursuing a Bachelor's in Environmental Science with an emphasis in Ecological Restoration and Botany at Humboldt State University in northern California. As a naturalist with an aspiration to protect and restore wild lands, I am disheartened by the EPA's proposal to withdraw its prior 2014 Proposed 404c Determination. Large scale mining will not only result in adverse effects to wildlife and habitat, it will also have detrimental effects to the indigenous communities of Bristol Bay. I am writing to comment on my position against the Proposal To Withdraw Proposed Determination To Restrict the Use of an Area as a Disposal Site; Pebble Deposit Area, Southwest Alaska, 82 Fed. Reg. 33,123 (July 19, 2017.) 

This proposal seeks to reverse the efforts made by the Obama EPA to assess the impacts of mining the pebble deposit in the South Fork Koktuli River, North Fork Koktuli River, and Upper Talarik Creek watersheds. An extensive assessment, The Effects of Large Scale Mining on the Salmon Ecosystems of the Nushagak and Kvichak Rivers found that large scale mining would cause significant harm to the fishery. This finding violates the Clean Water Act and under Section 404(c): the EPA is authorized to prohibit or restrict fill activities if the Agency determines the project would have unacceptable or adverse effects on fishery areas. "The assessment indicates that the proposed Pebble Mine would likely cause irreversible destruction of streams that support salmon and other important fish species, as well as extensive areas of wetlands, ponds and lakes" (EPA 2017). These effects include loss of streams, loss of wetlands, lands and ponds and stream flow alterations. 

Bristol Bay is home to the largest sockeye fishery in the world, the salmon runs have been supporting native subsistence fishing communities for over a millennium. In return these communities have assumed the position of stewarding the Bristol Bay watershed. As a collective, the United Tribes of Bristol Bay are strongly against the mining operations and have continually rallied and petitioned to express their opposition. These salmon runs not only sustain the income of Native residents, but are also the basis for Alaska Native culture, social relations, and spirituality (EPA 2017). The EPA has claimed to consider the Native's deep connection to the land and dependence on it however, its actions are proving otherwise. Rather, if the EPA carries out the withdrawal of the 2014 proposed determination it is certain to jeopardize decades of relationship and trust building with Tribes of the US. 

On page 33123 and continuing onto 33124 the proposal states, "If Pebble Limited Partnership (PLP) submits a permit application to the Army Corps within 30 months from the date of settlement...the EPA may not move forward with a signed Recommended Determination for 48 months from the effective date of the settlement agreement..." Section 404 of the Clean Water Act directs the EPA to develop the environmental criteria the Army Corps uses to make permit decisions (EPA 2017). It does not seem productive or appropriate to have a setback date for the EPA to take action. This is a process that fully encompasses the purpose and responsibility of the Agency, and should not be taken away for PLP to gain time towards swaying Trump EPA Administrator Scott Pruitt. 

If the PLP is granted the opportunity to mine one of the worlds most productive marine ecosystems, the EPA will have changed the course and meaning of everything environmental protection represents. 



References

 "Bristol Bay" United States Environmental Protection Agency. Last modified July, 24 2017. Accessed October 05, 2017. https://www.epa.gov/bristolbay

"Our Work." United Tribes of Bristol Bay. 2014. Accessed October 05, 2017. http://utbb.org/our-work/

Title: Comment submitted by J. Heath
Comment:
Please do not withdraw the proposed determination, which adopts restrictions protecting Bristol Bay's habitat. This determination is the result of years of scientific study, and was made at the request of local communities. It would be unfortunate to disregard a decision which was undertaken with so much effort and care. The EPA found in 2014 that the Pebble Mine would have 'significant and unacceptable adverse affects' on ' one of the most productive, pristine, valuable, and vulnerable ecosystems remaining in N American today. ' Not only would the mine have an irreversable ecological impact, but the local economy and the traditional way of life are dependent on healthy salmon populations. The EPA has noted that commercial fishing in Bristol Bay generates hundreds of millions of dollars annually in direct sales, generating 11,000 jobs. The EPA should stand by their prior determination, and take all necessary actions to protect the Bristol Bay watershed.


Sincerely,
Jennifer Heath

Title: Comment submitted by J. Hakala
Comment:
My name is Jennifer Hakala and I am currently an environmental science student at Humboldt State University. The main reason why I believe 82 FR 33123 should not be reconsidering the fate of Bristol Bay, Alaska is for the sockeye salmon. Here in California we are consistently struggling with saving our salmon population and it is very concerning. Globally, our main principle should be to protect those habitats which are still thriving greatly as diverse systems. With many other pollutants on this planet, I can say that we do not need to add to this amount any longer. We should be protecting our waters at all costs, not going back on previous decisions to get rid of this protection for these ecosystems.
The Bristol Bay watershed in Alaska  is extremely important for the United States in many ways: there are jobs, food and other benefits from these waters. But more importantly it's crucial to the lifestyle of its numerous inhabitants. The headwaters are the beginning of the whole river system, disturbance at the start can be highly detrimental to the functionality of every player trying to contribute to the well-being of the ecosystem. Due to mining, the river could become extremely polluted and demolish all standards that were previously set. These standards were created to put the watershed under protection. There is clearly a purpose for why the originally proposed determination (79 FR 42314) stated that the river should not be subjected to such pollution from mining practices. The Clean Water Act was established for reasons to protect United States from polluted waters due to types of dredged or filled material from mining. The clean water is beneficial for the inhabitants but also the survival of other wildlife. There are many endangered salmon and this location is a huge sanctuary for these fish. We should not risk getting rid of one of the last great salmon habitats. I don't believe that the permit can even justify the true impact that creating this mine could have on the environment. In order to maintain quality water, no changes should be made to the previous decision.  
To be completely honest , I'm sure we can find more alternatives to mining such as recycling products of similar resources. We are in a day and age where there should be more renewable and sustainable practices.I feel there hasn't been many alternatives considered in this case. The developers of Pebble Mine want to say that there will be no effect on the wildlife but where is the proof? I really doubt they can prove there will be no significant impact on the salmon and the surrounding habitat due to mining practices.  If the mining begins, the destruction will actually affect many organisms along the Koktuli River and Talarik Creek. Increase of sulfur from the soil creates acid harmful to not only the fish, but the other organisms, creatures and mammals that rely on this water system. The gold and copper can be highly beneficial to the economy but also causes more concern about the future of the environment.  It is a debate between environmental or economic stability. Economic stability is what we lean for but there are other approaches and the Bristol Bay still supports its own healthy economy. Without the clean water there is no diversity. Without this diversity, it is harder for communities of organisms to collaborate in a healthy manner. And often, we forget how these ecosystems can affect our lives in the long run. The Pebble Mine developers should absolutely not be able to discharge into these thriving streams.

Title: Comment submitted by B. O'Brien
Comment: I am submitting my response to address the following issue of permitting the continued mining operations by Pebble Limited Partnership in the Bristol Bay watershed. Northern Dynasty is 100% owner of the Pebble Partnership, which is advancing the world-class Pebble deposit in Alaska towards permitting and development [1]. This group wants to develop mines in a relatively pristine wilderness area. This is a one of a kind fishery and is relevant throughout the entire fishing community. Numerous freshwater nursery lakes and shallow estuaries make up Bristol Bay and it is the largest commercial sockeye salmon producing region in the world [2]. This is a very significant species of fish which migrates upstream to spawn and the populations of these fish are relevant to the health of the entire ecosystem. The proposed withdrawal of preventative measures from allowing the dumping of pollutants as discharge from mining into the surrounding rivers. What is helping to prevent this area from exploitation is the Clean Water Act and the amendments which were made in section 404(c),  as this authorizes the EPA to prohibit, restrict, or deny the discharge of dredged or fill material at defined sites in waters of the United States [3]. There seems to be a conflict with the water quality and the proposed mining operations. I would like to oppose the proposal 82 FR 33123 (July 19, 2017) to withdraw to proposed determination to restrict the use of the Bristol Bay area as a disposal site. This site should be protected, not exploited. The mining will only support jobs for roughly the next 50 years. If taken care of, this seasonal run of salmon could support jobs for the locals and food for Americans and the world for centuries to come as long as proper regulation and management practices can be implemented and followed. The mining operations in Bristol Bay are backed by Northern Dynasty Minerals Ltd. Their mission statement is to develop the Pebble Project: a strategic resource of copper, gold, molybdenum and silver, representing the future of US mining and metals [2].  This value statement is very specific in what they determine to be about. Their objectives are about material objects with monetary value. The supply of minerals in the area will only be sustained for a limited number of years with the proposed mining operations.The salmon are a more important renewable energy resource than the copper mined for new electronics. There are populations of an important species which will equate to more money and potential profits in a number of years. Over time the monetary value of the salmon will supersede the value of the proposed mineral extractions and not to mention the implicit costs of restoring the rivers and surrounding watershed afterwards when it has been massively polluted with discharged sediments and particulates. The minerals have been there since the cretaceous period and will not be going anywhere by themselves. To jeopardize the watershed which has supported this particular ecosystem for centuries is not worth the environmental degradation, even if it is literally for gold.If there is even a possibility for continued mining near the area, it must be done without contributing to stream pollution and sedimentation of native spawning gravels. This will be nearly impossible to do and to remove the regulations which are supposed to protect the wildlife could have severely negative repercussions. These fish are anadromous, traveling from the ocean upstream to spawn and their success depends on a combination of many different factors as it is Northern Dynasty Minerals Ltd is a company which values to design, permit, build and operate a modern mine at Pebble that fully co-exists with healthy fish and wildlife populations and traditional ways of life in southwest Alaska, and enhances the economic and social well-being of all Alaskans [2]. This companies listed values does not correlate very well with them destroying the river systems. Proportionately these head waters support most of the world's sockeye salmon and would be largely affected by the dumping of discharge and sediments into the streams and rivers. This would not be good considering the fish are for human consumption as well. If there were ways to go about mining with a very large buffer between any major river pathways than maybe it could work, but there are no shown proposals that have proven safe mining practices can occur here. They claim responsible mining, but do not directly layout their methods of how they will be extracting the precious metals from the earth. This proposal for removal seems to be nothing but a large lump sum land grab. The vote should go to support the continued enforcement of the regulations in place which protect the environment and we should vote against the effort to repeal the 2014 amendments to the Clean Water Act. Do not remove these protections

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I am commenting today to OPPOSE the EPA withdrawing from the 2014 Proposed Determination to Restrict Use of Area as Disposal Site. That determination, put in place by the Obama administration, was done so because they recognized the grave environmental risks associated with opening up these areas for mining. Opening up Bristol Bay to Northern Dynasty Minerals is a blatant giveaway to the mining industry at the expense of Alaskan residents, Native American communities, and Americans as a whole. It's appalling.

The Bristol Bay watershed generates over $1 billion dollars annually, and supports over 14,000 jobs. This makes it the most valuable wild salmon fishery in the world. It's also an incredibly popular tourist spot for individuals and families, and it's part of the culture and traditions of multiple Alaska Natives. All of this will be wiped out if the Pebble Mine project is allowed to move forward. This mining project would produce 10 billion tons of waste, turning this pristine area into a toxic wasteland for decades to come. There's no way to gauge how long it would take to clean something like that up, or if restoring it would even be an option. 

Additionally, withdrawing from the Proposed Determination and allowing mining is a deeply unpopular proposition. More than 65 percent of Alaskans, 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents and Native communities, and 85 percent of commercial fishermen oppose the mine.

The EPA needs to do its job - protect the environment - and not allow the Pebble Mine to move forward. It's toxic and has no place in Bristol Bay.

Title: Comment submitted by Jerry McCune, President and Mark Vinsel, Executive Administrator, United Fishermen of Alaska (UFA)
Comment:
United Fishermen of Alaska (UFA) is the statewide commercial fishing trade association, representing 34 commercial fishing organizations participating in fisheries throughout the state, and the federal fisheries off Alaska's coast.

Consistent with previously stated positions, UFA is opposed to withdrawal of the EPA's July 2014 404(c) Proposed Determination for the Pebble Mine in the Bristol Bay watershed.  UFA expressed support for proactive 404(c) action in an October 2010 letter to the EPA Administrator and reiterated support for the Proposed Determination in a September 2014 letter.  UFA's position against any presently conceivable development of the Pebble Mine remains unchanged. Previously submitted letters are attached for reference.

The risks of large-scale mining in the Bristol Bay watershed have been well-documented prior to and throughout the investigative process that led to EPA's Proposed Determination. UFA's position opposing development of the Pebble deposit with respect to conceivable mining options is largely based on a well-documented and practical reality that extraction of desired minerals from the area's low-grade, acid-generating ore requires massive amounts of excavation and containment that is certain to damage salmon spawning and rearing habitat.  In addition, there is an unacceptable risk of a catastrophic event or multiple events at the mining site that could severely compromise downstream environments, particularly for salmon. EPA investigations and analyses that led to the 2014 Proposed Determination served to clearly corroborate those concerns. 

UFA's support of the proactive use of the 404(c) is also based on a desire to have a more stable seafood business climate that is free from the risks of potential disruption from mining development.  Part of the market value for Bristol Bay salmon is based on the perception of puritylarge-scale mining in the watershed would compromise those attributes and any mine failures such as a tailings dam breach would be especially difficult to overcome in the market. Record salmon runs and favorable market conditions of the last few years underscore the importance of a healthy salmon fishery to the Bristol Bay region, the State of Alaska and the entire country.  In 2017, the Nushagak River saw the largest run of sockeye salmon in recorded historyit is one of the major drainages downstream of the Pebble Mine site.  Although the Nushagak River is not typically known for its sockeye production, it is by far the biggest king salmon system in the Bristol Bay Region.  In contrast to commercial fishery prospects, financial backing for the Pebble project has largely evaporated as its economic viability and environmental risk has been more fully understood by private and public interests through EPA's investigations and analyses related to the Proposed Determination.   

The following points are listed as reasons considered by UFA over the years in supporting the Proposed 404(c) Determination and opposing EPA's proposed withdrawal: 
The Bristol Bay salmon fishery is a significant and integral part of the Alaska's statewide commercial fishing industry with economic benefits that accrue far beyond the state's borders. 
The 2017 run of 56.5 Million fish ranks second highest of the last twenty years. 
2017 preliminary ex-vessel value at $214 Million
First wholesale value of $417 Million in 2014
Accounts for 25% or more of the value of Alaska's overall salmon harvest.
Provided 8,395 harvester jobs and an additional 3,485 processing worker jobs in 2014. 
Low-grade, acid-generating ore would require massive excavations and storage of tailings in perpetuity.
Site development and transportation corridor requirements that would cross multiple salmon spawning and rearing streams and affect adjoining aquatic habitats. 
Inadequacy of technologic mitigation of mine development and operation impacts on salmon. (Note failures of Columbia River hatchery and other mitigation projects as an example) 
Complex hydrology of region makes prediction of mining impacts and risks on groundwater and streamflow difficult.
High seismic risk at mine site and in the region. 
Salmon markets that are sensitive to environmental perceptions and seafood industry desire to have business stability.
Indemnity and legal protection for losses to fishermen not well established and historically difficult to uphold. (Note US Supreme Court overturning of jury verdict on Exxon Valdez oil spill)
Questionable economic viability of the Pebble Mine as indicated by 2013 divestment by Anglo-American and February 2017 Kerrisdale Capital report and recommendation to short-sell.

UFA urges the EPA to refrain from withdrawal of the 2014 Proposed Determination based on the factors outlined above.

Sincerely,
							
Jerry McCune						Mark Vinsel
President						Executive Administrator

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I am strongly opposed to EPAs proposal to rescind the 2014 Proposed Determination designed to protect Bristol Bays world class fisheries. Please stand with American jobs and communities and preserve the Bristol Bay Proposed Determination.

Bristol Bay, Alaska, is one of America's last great wild salmon fisheries. Each year, tens of millions of wild salmon return, supporting upwards of 14,000 jobs in the commercial and sport fishing industries, and serving as a one-in-a-lifetime destination for anglers from around the world as well as the cultural cornerstone for the region's communities. This mine will need to store it's waste forever. Any leak from the waste from mining copper and gold will destroy the last true salmon spawning ground. Salmon is practically extinct on the East coast. 
These long-established businesses are at risk from a foreign-owned mining company that wants to build the proposed Pebble Mine, which is opposed by more than 65 percent of Alaskans and more than 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents. It is not even a US company!!! All this risk for a foreign corporation to send US metals back to their homeland.

In 2014, led by Alaska Native Tribes, interests including commercial fishing business owners and sportsmen asked the EPA step in to ensure that this mine wouldn't jeopardize Bristol Bay. The EPA responded by listening to over 1.5 million Americans, hosting dozens of community meetings, reviewing Pebble's many detailed filings with state and federal agencies, and conducting a twice peer-reviewed scientific assessment of the potential impacts to the region. Withdrawing the proposed determination ignores the overwhelming majority of Alaskans and puts the short-term interests of a foreign mining company above thousands of local jobs. 

For the sake of our wildlife, waterways, and communities, I urge you to protect Bristol Bay and prevent this horrible open-pit mine from destroying one of our nation's most precious ecosystems. Do not let short sighted greed destroy America's fishermen.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
The fact that the EPA is considering reopening the ruling which blocked the Pebble Limited Partnership from proceeding over concern on management of the 10 Billion tons of mining waste going into a critical salmon spawning habitat is a travesty.

Bristol Bay's wild salmon fishery supports 14,000 jobs and is valued at more than $1.5 billion annually. It also supplies nearly half of the world's sockeye salmon. More than 65 percent of Alaskans, 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents and Native communities, and 85 percent of commercial fishermen oppose the mine.

Please honor the process which preceded this restriction. Honor the wishes of the people of this region and the future of our planet.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I am opposed to EPAs proposal to rescind the 2014 Proposed Determination designed to protect Bristol Bays world class fisheries. Please stand with American jobs and communities and preserve the Bristol Bay Proposed Determination.

Bristol Bay, Alaska, is one of America's last great wild salmon fisheries. Each year, tens of millions of wild salmon return, supporting upwards of 14,000 jobs in the commercial and sport fishing industries, and serving as a one-in-a-lifetime destination for anglers from around the world as well as the cultural cornerstone for the region's communities. These long-established businesses are at risk from a foreign-owned mining company that wants to build the proposed Pebble Mine, which is opposed by more than 65 percent of Alaskans and more than 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents. 

In 2014, led by Alaska Native Tribes, interests including commercial fishing business owners and sportsmen asked the EPA step in to ensure that this mine wouldn't jeopardize Bristol Bay. The EPA responded by listening to over 1.5 million Americans, hosting dozens of community meetings, reviewing Pebble's many detailed filings with state and federal agencies, and conducting a twice peer-reviewed scientific assessment of the potential impacts to the region. Withdrawing the proposed determination ignores the overwhelming majority of Alaskans and puts the short-term interests of a foreign mining company above thousands of local jobs. 

For the sake of our wildlife, waterways, and communities, I urge you to protect Bristol Bay and prevent this horrible open-pit mine from destroying one of our nation's most precious ecosystems.

Title: Comment submitted by L. S. Bushatz
Comment:
Reference Identification:EPA-R10-OW-2017-0369-0001
Luke S. Bushatz
2381 N. Broadway Drive, Palmer, AK 99645
(703)859-0889
9 October 2017

This comment will address the proposal by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency to withdraw its July 2014 Clean Water Act Proposed Determination that would, if finalized, have imposed restrictions on the discharge of dredged or fill material associated with the potential "Pebble Mine" in Alaska's Bristol Bay watershed.

Synopsis: It is not in the economic, commercial or political interest of the United States, the state of Alaska or the Environmental Protection Agency to permit Northern Dynasty to continue with the Pebble mining project. It clearly endangers future economic and social conditions in Bristol Bay with the most powerful of indicators betting against it. Free market capitalism says this project is a bust and if the EPA waives 404(c) protections for this project it will still fail and will only damage the community it is impacting with no long term benefits.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I am against withdrawing the protections applied under the Clean Water Act to
the South Fork Koktuli River, North Fork Koktuli River, and Upper Talarik Creek watersheds in southwest Alaska.
I am against constructing a mining operation, whether it be Pebble or any other company, in the Bristol Bay watershed
or in any watershed that is important to fisheries, especially those of Pacific salmon. It is irresponsible and shortsighted to 
alter and damage an ecosystem that supports a SELF- SUSTAINING and RENEWABLE economy (salmon fishery) 
and replace it with an economic base that will produce toxins while withdrawing a LIMITED resource. 
It is ignorant to ignore the three year study conducted by the EPA that identified the importance of the Bristol Bay ecosystem
and its fishery. And it is ignorant to ignore history. Regardless of the study, mines are boom and bust. It will end. 
Any town created, any economic bolstering and any profit that goes into the hands of a few will end. Relics of this industrial 
fact are strewn across the country as abandoned mining towns. Ghost towns. That is the inevitable future of this project;
A toxic skeleton of a human operation dedicated only to maximizing profit, surrounded by the decaying mass
of its irreversibly damaged ecosystem.
However, if the protection on this watershed is upheld and is partnered with the continued responsible 
management of the Sockeye salmon fishery, then there exists a mine that will continue to produce. 
As a concerned citizen, I plead that the protections of the Bristol Bay watershed are kept in place. Let there be an
American legacy of protecting this pristine ecosystem.

Title: Comment submitted by P. Hammer
Comment:
Greetings,
My name is Payton Hammer and I am a senior at Humboldt State University. I am studying environmental economics and have a minor in Natural Resources and Management Planning. I am commenting on the EPA's decision to withdraw the 2014 proposed determination of the Pebble Mine near the head waters of the Bristol Bay watershed. Proposal to Withdraw Proposed Determination to Restrict the Use of an Area as a Disposal Site; Pebble Deposit Area, Southwest Alaska, 82 Fed. Reg. 44,176 (July 19, 2017). I think that the proposed pebble mine deserves to be able to take all the steps necessary to see if they can go through with this proposed mine, however, I do not support the mine at all and would need substantial evidence from an EIS. The risks are far greater than the benefits and if the EPA approves this project I will be deeply disappointed in the EPA under our current administration.
First, I would like to address that I think Northern Dynasty Minerals does not have the right to go through the Environmental Impact assessment process. The EPA has already struck down the Pebble Mine project under section 404 (c) of the Clean Water Act which restricts any discharges of dredged materials into wetlands or watersheds. The environmental impacts of a mine as large as this is going to have an immense impact on the environment around it. I would also like to comment on the fact that in Alaska there has been strong resistance against the mine from the very beginning. Most Alaskans think the mine is a bad idea and will have adverse economic and environmental effect.
The proposed Pebble Mine is a gross misjudgment that if goes through with the development will result in an environmental, economic and spiritual tragedy. Bristol Bay is a billion dollar fishery that provides over 14,000 full and part time jobs. Bristol bay and the Kvichak and Nushagak Rivers are home to all five of the pacific salmon species and is the only places in the world with a fully functioning salmon based ecosystem. The Kvichak and Nushagak watersheds are home to Native Americans who, like their ancestors whom have lived there for over 4,000 years, live a sustainable way of life based on the annual salmon runs. 
The people of Bristol Bay are dependent on the annual salmon runs either for subsistence or a wage and if the pebble mine is allowed to go through it will have serious consequences on the people. We cannot allow the idea of short term monetary gain win out against one of the sustainable ecosystems in the world.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment submitted by Curtis . Thayer, President and CEO, Alaska Chamber
Comment:
October 5, 2017


Water Docket, Environmental Protection Agency
Mail Code 28221T
ATTN: Docket #EPA-R10-OW-2017-0369
1200 Pennsylvania Ave., NW
Washington, DC  20460


RE: Call for comments on proposal to withdraw proposed determination to restrict the use of an area as a disposal site; Pebble Deposit area, Southwest Alaska 

To whom it may concern:

Thank you for the opportunity to convey the Alaska Chamber's support of withdrawing the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) determination on the Pebble Deposit Area.  

The Alaska Chamber is a non-profit founded in 1953 working to promote a positive business environment in Alaska.  The Chamber is the voice of small and large business representing hundreds of employers and local chambers across Alaska.  Our member companies employ over 100,000 hard-working Alaskans.  We support resource development that is both done in a responsible manner and brings economic opportunity to Alaska and its residents.

In an unprecedented move the EPA adopted a proposed determination regarding the Pebble Deposit Area that ignored existing processes, undermining agency responsibilities on both the state and federal level.  The Alaska Chamber believes that any project should have the opportunity to go through the existing legal processes.  In the case of a mining project like Pebble there are more than 60 major permits from local, state, and federal agencies.  If the process determines a project as designed cannot protect the environment and other resources, it will not advance. Until an application is filed describing in detail and an Environmental Impact Statement is completed, the EPA is making determinations based on hypotheticals and assumptive modeling.

If the Pebble Project makes it through the existing legal process proving they can operate the mine in a responsible manner, the economic benefits are enormous not just to the local economy in the immediate area but to the State.  Mining provides for good paying jobs, some of the best-paid in the state, at almost $100,000/year.  Pebble anticipates employing up to 1,000 full-time workers throughout the first 25 years of production, and as a whole mining companies operating in Alaska have a workforce that is 75% Alaska resident. Beyond that they also pay up to $165 million in taxes, rents, royalties, and fees to state and local governments, and $172 million to Alaska Native Corporations.  

The Alaska Chamber encourages the EPA to withdraw its determination on the Pebble Deposit Area and let the project succeed or fail on the merits of the project as designed and not by speculating on what might happen.


Best regards,



Curtis W. Thayer
President & CEO

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I am writing you today to ask that you not withdraw the Bristol Bay Proposed Determination, which was made pursuant to the Clean Water Act in 2014.I'm a conservative republican from TN who visits the region for fishing. Thus improving the economy for the local community and preserving wildlife. I will be writing Lamar Alexander and Bob Corker as well as my congressman for support. 

As you know, Bristol Bay, Alaska, is one of America's last great wild salmon fisheries. Tens of millions of wild salmon return annually, which support upwards of 14,000 American jobs in the commercial and sport fishing industries, serve as a one-in-a-lifetime destination for anglers from around the world, and are the cultural cornerstone for the region's communities.

These long-established American businesses and jobs are at risk from a foreign-owned mining company that wants to build the proposed Pebble Mine, which is opposed by more than 65 percent of Alaskans and more than 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents. 

Please do not withdraw the proposed determination.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
Please do not allow development of the Pebble Mine. 
EPA studies have documented that the mine would have a hugely negative impact on the clean waters and on the fish that live and spawn there. And this is assuming there are no spills, leaks, or illegal dumping, which of course happens too often.
 
It's getting to the point that there is little food that we can be sure is still safe to eat. Fish may contain mercury and/or plastic micro-beads. Crops may contain high levels of pesticides. Farm animals may contain antibiotics or growth hormones.

Please do not allow any company - a non-American company, no less - to jeopardize one of our best sources for healthy food.

Contaminated waters are contributing to high rates of cancers and various serious illnesses. Contaminated foods are also taking heavy tolls on Americans' health. This puts burdens on our already expensive health care system (best case scenario) and reduces our work force (worst case scenario).

As another aspect to consider, suppose this mine were to go forward. Who is going to monitor regulation compliance?  Who is going to enforce regulations?  Who is going to clean up any accidental contamination?  Given that the current administration would like to decimate the EPA, who is going to look out for our food & health safety? Because the mining company certainly won't.

I beg you to please protect Bristol Bay.  Thank you.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
Alaskans do not want the Pebble Mine. More than 65 percent of Alaskans, 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents and Native communities, and 85 percent of commercial fishermen oppose the mine.

Trump's EPA would sell off Bristol Bay to FOREIGN mining interests. This is UN-AMERICAN. 

REAL AMERICANS, like The Bristol Bay Native Corporation (the largest private for-profit development corporation in the region representing more than 10,000 Native shareholders), the Bristol Bay Native Association, the Bristol Bay Economic Development Corporation, United Tribes for Bristol Bay (representing 14 federally-recognized tribes in the region), Nunamta Aulukestai (representing ten tribes and ten native village corporations in the region), and Alaska Speaker of the House Bryce Edgmon say this, "Don't give away our bay to foreign mining interests. Bristol Bay's thousands of fishing jobs and way of life cannot be put at risk by the Pebble Mine. Pebble Mine will always be the wrong mine in the wrong place."  "Fish First. Pebble Never."

The EPA has already determined that the planned pebble mine would cause great damage to the unparalleled salmon runs and local fisheries as well as to local Native communities.  

The FOREIGN-OWNED pebble mine would cause significant damage to the world-renowned salmon runs of Bristol Bay. This fishery is worth moth than 1.5 million dollars a year and supports 14,000 jobs. All of this would be put at risk for the interests of a FOREIGN mining company. 

Like thousands of REAL AMERICANS, I've worked in the fish industry in Bristol Bay. Pebble Mine would destroy current and future REAL AMERICANS in doing the same.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I lived in Dillingham, AK for five years.  If there is an oil spill, the whole town and the people who live around there will have no means to live. They live a  subsistence economy and live on salmon for not only their livelihood but to feed themselves.  

I am opposed to EPAs proposal to rescind the 2014 Proposed Determination designed to protect Bristol Bays world class fisheries. Please stand with American jobs and communities and preserve the Bristol Bay Proposed Determination.

Bristol Bay, Alaska, is one of America's last great wild salmon fisheries. Each year, tens of millions of wild salmon return, supporting upwards of 14,000 jobs in the commercial and sport fishing industries, and serving as a one-in-a-lifetime destination for anglers from around the world as well as the cultural cornerstone for the region's communities. These long-established businesses are at risk from a foreign-owned mining company that wants to build the proposed Pebble Mine, which is opposed by more than 65 percent of Alaskans and more than 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents. 

In 2014, led by Alaska Native Tribes, interests including commercial fishing business owners and sportsmen asked the EPA step in to ensure that this mine wouldn't jeopardize Bristol Bay. The EPA responded by listening to over 1.5 million Americans, hosting dozens of community meetings, reviewing Pebble's many detailed filings with state and federal agencies, and conducting a twice peer-reviewed scientific assessment of the potential impacts to the region. Withdrawing the proposed determination ignores the overwhelming majority of Alaskans and puts the short-term interests of a foreign mining company above thousands of local jobs. 

For the sake of our wildlife, waterways, and communities, I urge you to protect Bristol Bay and prevent this horrible open-pit mine from destroying one of our nation's most precious ecosystems.

Title: Anonymous public comment

I am absolutely opposed to your   proposal to rescind the 2014 Proposed Determination designed to protect Bristol Bays world class fisheries. You apparently believe that the risk to the fisheries that a foreign owned open pit mine would clearly pose is irrelevant, and at  best an example of federal regulatory overreach.

industry jobs will surely be affected by the inevitable degradation in the quality of water that your EPA will surely do everything in its power to  neglect until it is too late. 

You need to  defend those  American jobs  that already exist, not threaten them with the allure of a different and  environmentally dangerous industry that has little local support. This you should do by  preserving the Bristol Bay Proposed Determination.

Apparently you and your toxic industry henchmen who now run EPA dismiss as painfully irrelevant that fact that Bristol Bay, Alaska, is one of America's last great wild salmon fisheries. Each year, tens of millions of wild salmon return, supporting upwards of 14,000 jobs in the commercial and sport fishing industries, and serving as a one-in-a-lifetime destination for anglers from around the world as well as the cultural cornerstone for the region's communities. 

How many of these jobs are going to survive the daily degradation in water quality that this project will be responsible for? 

These long-established businesses are at risk from a foreign-owned mining company that wants to build the proposed Pebble Mine, which is opposed by more than 65 percent of Alaskans and more than 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents. 

Why does this absence of support leave you so indifferent? How can you not realize that approval of this mine is a perfect example of federal overreach? How hypocritical can you really be?

In 2014, led by Alaska Native Tribes, interests including commercial fishing business owners and sportsmen asked the EPA step in to ensure that this mine wouldn't jeopardize Bristol Bay. The EPA responded by listening to over 1.5 million Americans, hosting dozens of community meetings, reviewing Pebble's many detailed filings with state and federal agencies, and conducting a twice peer-reviewed scientific assessment of the potential impacts to the region. Withdrawing the proposed determination ignores the overwhelming majority of Alaskans and puts the short-term interests of a foreign mining company above thousands of local jobs. 

That you are responsible for such an obscene display of federal overreach is ample evidence that   you are completely incapable of deciding what is in the best interests of the population at large. That you fail to acknowledge that this decision is, indeed,  a perfect example of federal overreach is a perfect example of the bizarre Soviet like mentality that dictates its policy decisions,  whether or not they make any sense, and uses whatever pathetic rationale  seems most  convenient without regard to   whether it is defensible or holds up to rigorous scrutiny. 

For the sake of our wildlife, waterways, and communities, I demand that you  protect Bristol Bay and prevent this horrible open-pit mine from destroying one of our nation's most precious ecosystems.

You will be responsible for the toxic spills, the fish kills, and the resulting  collapse of the fishing industry in the area. You alone.

I object in the strongest way possible to the reversal the EPA may make with respect to the Pebble Mine project at Bristol Bay. In 2014, after a four-year review process, the EPA said Bristol Bay Watershed was too fragile to support large scale mining.

Title: Comment submitted by M. V. Dyke
Comment:
Dear EPA Administrator,

The July 2014 proposed determination should not be lifted or reconsidered.  History has proven time after time that pristine natural environments have intrinsic as well as monetary value.  Jobs and precious metals are valuable but to place any kind of mine in Bristol Bay would be short sighted in the worst way.  My home in the Pacific Northwest has experienced salmon habitat destruction and the resultant salmon population decline.  It has affected our region negatively both economically and spiritually.  The decline of salmon populations have cost fishing jobs, fish processing jobs not to mention all the tourism losses as sport fishing has declined.  To build a mine and to subject Bristol Bay to the effluent and waste that is unavoidable when mining would be unethical at best.  Years of peer reviewed scientific research clearly demonstrate the fragility of the Bristol Bay ecosystem as it pertains to salmon.  There is then no need to lift the proposed determination as any mining operation would threaten the fragile balance and the salmon.  Therefore, I emphatically implore the EPA to keep the July 2014 proposed determination that will keep Bristol Bay safe and prevent any analysis of mine building or other deleterious use of that pristine fishery.  

Respectfully,

Dr. Michael Van Dyke D.O.

Title: Comment submitted by B. Lewis
Comment:
The sustainable Sockeye Salmon fishery in Bristol Bay should be preserved, and therefore the restrictions put in place at the Pebble Deposit area should not be withdrawn.

The fishery supports thousands of jobs and provides federal and state tax dollars, and does so on a sustainable basis, meaning that the revenue will continue to flow into coffers and provide economic benefits to the area in perpetuity.  The same cannot be said for a mining operation, which, at best, would provide jobs for a period of time and then close after resource extraction was no longer economically viable.  Approving mining in this area would therefore be extremely short-sighted, and would be likely to have a long term negative impact on the local economy (by potentially harming the sustainable fishery) without having a similar long-term benefit.

Please do not withdraw the restrictions imposed on this area.

Best regards,
Bret Lewis

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment: I have traveled to Alaska on many occasions, often to fish in the Goodnews River, which is a short distance north of the proposed Pebble Mine site.  It is difficult to describe the spectacular Salmon fishery that is present in the beautiful, wild area.  We must do everything possible to preserve this Salmon fishery and the habitat that supports it.  It is not possible to allow even a limited mining operation in the proposed area without risking the annihilation of the Bristol Bay Salmon fishery, especially the Sockeye Salmon.  I urge you to leave in place the regulations that currently protect this area and to deny a permit for any mining in this area.  Thank you for your attention to my comments.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I am vehemently against the building of a mine in this delicate and already commercially valuable habitat.  Across the world, salmon populations have been wiped out or greatly diminished, to the point that "Atlantic Salmon" is only available through farming, even as global appetite for salmon has increased significantly.  Bristol Bay is already a great economic boon to the local economy as it currently is - a sustainably managed fishery that employs thousands of people.  And that is money that stays with the local community, not siphoned away to a foreign parent company.  If President Trump and his administration is as committed to supporting American workers, they should be looking at this in the long term.  The mine would employ 1000 while it's being developed - a few year at most - and another 1000 during its short life, with the profits going to a Canadian company.  Eventually, the mine's resources will be depleted and it will employ no-one other than EPA and hazardous waste crews.  Because that is all that will be left - a wasteland of toxic materials.  Compare this to a sustainably managed fishery that will last FOREVER - a God-given gift - and create no such terrible externalities.

The Mining company will insist that its footprint is small and that it will take proper precautions, but ecosystems are so delicately balanced that even slight disturbances can cause ripple effects.  And even proper precautions would not be enough.  Remember the the torrent of toxic waste that was released when the EPA itself was in the process of securing an old mine?  Please remember that.  Please remember that this country has so much more to offer than dead metals from the ground and that we are smart enough and courageous enough and bold enough to create economic opportunities that don't destroy our natural heritage.

And if money is the only thing that matters, remember that it costs FAR less to protect existing habitats and ecosystems than to seek to restore them after we humans have made our mark.  And a mark we will make indeed if we let this mine go forward - from oil spills, to natural disasters in areas where homes have replace natural barriers, to a floating pile of garbage in the ocean larger than the size of Texas, when have we humans ever gotten things perfectly right?  Or truly calculated the costs.

Please make the brave decision and protect Bristol Bay from mining.

The returning salmon and other ecological resources create some 14,000 full- and part-time jobs, generate about $480 million annually -- and support 4,000-year-old Alaska Native cultures." Title: Comment submitted  by N. Stephenson
Comment:
Dear EPA,

I beg and implore the EPA to not reverse the protections for Bristol Bay. Save the jobs, the salmon, and the land from the all too well known detriments of mining. There is no alternative but to let Bristol Bay be. If "America First" is part of Mr. Pruitt's agenda, then rescind the rights/permits of Canada based Northern Dynasty Minerals. Do not let a brief meeting with their subsidy reverse and destroy years of scientific effort and a way of life of Americans.

"...Nearly half of the world's sockeye catch comes from this one region, which is one of the last, great salmon fisheries on Earth. The returning salmon and other ecological resources create some 14,000 full- and part-time jobs, generate about $480 million annually -- and support 4,000-year-old Alaska Native cultures." - John D. Sutter and Scott Bronstein, CNN Oct. 10, 2017

"This is the jewel in the crown of America's fisheries resources, this salmon," -Thomas Quinn, University of Washington, CNN Oct. 10, 2017

The sound reasoning and science is already before the EPA in the wonderful research that was done. The EPA is already aware that a dam or other barrier will not be able to contain the toxic wastes of mineral mining entering and polluting the waterways. The short term gains are not worth the irreversible desecration and damage to the land.

Please, for all things of meaning do not let corporate wants outweigh the will of the American People.

Please let Bristol Bay be.

Thank you for your time and consideration -Neil Stephenson 1038 Main St. Haverhill, Massachusetts

Title: Comment submitted by J. Hall
Comment:
Administrator Pruitt,

I am writing against the withdrawal of the EPA's 2014 Clean Water Act Proposed Determination that would have placed restrictions on the discharge of dredged or fill material from the potential mining of the Pebble deposit in Alaska's Bristol Bay watershed.

The decision by the prior Office of the EPA to move forward with the 2014 Clean Water Act Proposed Determination was based on sound science and a desire to protect the highly sensitive, highly productive waters of Bristol Bay, Alaska. Due to the integrity of the science in hand, an EIS is an unnecessary and costly exercise. Tax payer dollars should not be allocated to any further consideration of a loosening of restrictions on mining activities in Bristol Bay, Alaska. 

I do not support one company's - Pebble Limited Partnership - over the business of hundreds of fishing boats, or the health of the Bay and all the animals, fauna and flora that rely on the health of the Bristol Bay ecosystem for their own health and survival. The multi-decade process of constructing the mine would have damaging and irreversible impacts on Bristol Bay. The activities of the mine in operation would lead to its ultimate destruction as a source of one of the largest wild salmon fisheries in the world. It would mean economic and cultural devastation to the many communities who rely on the fishery for survival. 

Please proceed forward with the EPA's 2014 Clean Water Act Proposed Determination, as they are designed to balance all interests in this vital environmental and economic resource.

Jennifer Hall
Spokane, WA

Title: Comment submitted by Barbara Lee, Sydney Thomas, U.S. House of Representative
Comment:
The proposed Clean Water Act determination should NOT be withdrawn. The potential impacts of the proposed Pebble Mine on the health of the Bristol Bay watershed and the livelihood of thousands of people in Alaska are far too great. Those risks include loss of up to up to 94 miles of salmon-supporting streams and up to 4,900 acres of wetlands and ponds, and the very real potential of wastewater dam failure resulting in damage to or destruction of the salmon fishery. The watershed supports the largest sockeye salmon fishery in the world and 25 federally recognized tribes who for 4,000 years have depended on the fishery for their subsistence-based culture. The overwhelming majority of residents of Bristol Bay are opposed to the project, and a statewide majority of voters also oppose it. The watersheds unique ecological resources generate significant economic benefits and employment. EPAs original watershed assessment was scientifically robust and thoroughly peer-reviewed. That assessment and related public comments should strongly influence any future action.

References:
U.S. EPA. An Assessment of Potential Mining Impacts on Salmon Ecosystems of Bristol Bay, Alaska (Final Report). U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Washington, DC, EPA 910-R-14-001A-C, ES, 2014.
EPA Region 10, Proposed Determination Pursuant to Section 404(c) of the Clean Water Act for Pebble Deposit Area, Southwest Alaska, July 21, 2014.
2017 EPA and Pebble Limited Partnership Agreement.
U.S. EPA. An Assessment of Potential Mining Impacts on Salmon Ecosystems of Bristol Bay, Alaska (Final Report). U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Washington, DC, EPA 910-R-14-001A-C, ES, 2014. Chapter 5.
United Tribes of Bristol Bay. Opposition to Pebble Mine Reiterated by local tribes, fishermen, business owners.
Alaska Bristol Bay Mining Ban, Ballot Measure 4 (2014).

There is simply no reason to open new copper pits when there are so many superfund sites and other depositories of copper and such resources that are lying around unused. We have the technologies today to address these issues by economically recovering the valuable and useful resources left in tailings piles etc. My partners  and I are working with a micronization milling system that is ideal for these uses. We are able to process tailings and other such "waste" piles, and recover the coppers, gold and other metals and resources, without causing harm to the environment, and by doing so will mitigate the need to dig more holes in our precious planet. 

Please do not hesitate to reach out to me at chad@cornucpoiagroup.org with any questions, We are ready and willing to help solve this issue. 

As humans, on Earth, its our duty to clean up our act, lets work together to do it, before we no longer have an Earth to clean.

Sincerely,

Chad Knutsen
Co-Founder of Cornucopia Group

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I am a current undergraduate student studying environmental science and management at Humboldt State University in Arcata, California. I deeply care about protecting the environment globally and the statutes that were created to honor that. I am commenting against the withdrawal of the EPA's 2014 Clean Water Act Proposed Determination: The Proposal To Withdraw Proposed Determination To Restrict the Use of an Area as a Disposal Site; Pebble Deposit Area, Southwest Alaska, 82 Fed. Reg. 33,123 (July 19, 2017). I would like to argue against this withdrawal for many reasons.
Bristol Bay, Alaska is one of the most valued salmon fisheries on earth. It includes all coastal and inland waters east of a line from Cape Newenham to Cape Menshikof, including 9 major river systems. Several freshwater nursery lakes and shallow estuaries make Bristol Bay the largest commercial sockeye salmon producing region in the world. Bristol Bay has long been recognized as a vital contributor to Alaska's commercial fishing economy. The bay has been such an important contributor that in 1972 the Alaska legislature determined that it was in the best interest of the state to establish the Bristol Bay Fisheries Reserve. The reserve was designed to protect Bristol Bay fisheries' longstanding and valuable commercial, subsistence, and sport fishing from oil and gas development. We need to maintain this protection, not only for the fish but also all other living things that are within that ecosystem in Alaska.
Why now? After decades of protection and work that has been put into the Bristol Bay Fisheries Reserve and the Clean Water Act, now is the time to let mining interests in to destroy the habitat? The area is regarded as one of the world's most important salmon fisheries, producing nearly half of the world's annual sockeye salmon catch. Its ecological resources also support 4,000-year-old indigenous cultures, as well as about 14,000 jobs, according to the EPA's 2014 report.
 The original determination would have placed restrictions on the discharge of dredged or fill material from the potential mining of the Pebble deposit in Alaska's Bristol Bay watershed. Years of work have been put into preventing harm to Bristol Bay. Now, the EPA agreed to initiate a proposed withdrawal process pursuant to policy direction from EPA's Administrator, as part of a settlement agreement in May 2017 with the Pebble Limited Partnership. Pebble Limited Partnership's subsidiaries own the mineral claims to the Pebble deposit. 
After years of work and planning that have been put into the Bristol Bay watershed to maintain the wildlife and clean water, the EPA is now entertaining mining companies interests. Scott Pruitt, the new head of the EPA made this decision moments after meeting with a mining company. According to CNN, after three years of peer-reviewed study in 2014, the Obama administration's EPA invoked a rarely used provision of the Clean Water Act to try to protect Bristol Bay after finding that a mine "would result in complete loss of fish habitat due to elimination, dewatering, and fragmentation of streams, wetlands, and other aquatic resources" in some areas of the bay. The withdrawal of the determination would clearly mean the United States as a whole would be worse off. Because Bristol Bay supplies so much of our salmon, creating a mine and allowing the runoff would take away the international importance of the beautiful land and state of Alaska. Do not let corporate interests ruin this country. Do not let large scale mining companies ruin such a precious and fragile part of this country.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I am a student at Humboldt State University pursuing a degree in Environmental Science. I am writing to you today regarding the EPA's newest proposal to waive the restriction of the Pebble Mines disposal of mine tailings and other waste. In other words, the "Proposal to Withdraw Proposed Determination to Restrict the Use of an Area as a Disposal Site; Pebble Deposit Area, Southwest Alaska, 82 Fed. Reg. 33,123 (July 19, 2017)". The withdraw of the 2014 proposal may lead to the detriment of the surrounding environment and might cause long term water pollution in Bristol Bay. I fully agree with the EPA's original decision to restrict Pebble mine waste disposal without a proper permit as stated in the Clean Water Act, section 404 (c).  Allowing this mine to dispose in the area violates the Clean Water Act; the potential pollution is too great and seems too costly to repair. I am also requesting response for what possible measures can be taken to prevent this issue. 

This proposal should not be instated and review for a permit to dispose of mine tailings or any kind should be a requirement due to the possible negative impact that pollution could cause on the Bristol Bay waters. If the waste were to escape into the surrounding water environment, the pH levels will drastically fluctuate and in turn, as stated in the 2014 proposal, "[deprive] fish habitats of nutrients, groundwater inputs, and other subsidies". Salmon can only survive in a narrow window of pH water levels. A study done by J. J. Magnuson, J. P. Baker, E. J. Rahel and J. R. Kramer in the published journal called "A Critical Assessment of Effects of Acidification on Fisheries in North America [and Discussion] (1984)", shows that the salmon fish can populate with stability in waters with the pH window of 4.5-6.9. Possible contamination from the mine tailings could change the water pH well out of this range.  I have come to the awareness that one of the main resources that the Pebble mine is attracted to in the area is the copper. Copper water contamination can negatively affect the fish habitats. I have done some research on the effects of copper mine tailings and found that the particle size of these tailings, when mixed with water and oxygen gas, can create a wide array of pH concentrations. The variability of particle size affects the amount of acid or base that is needed for neutralization.  How will those who are responsible for taking care of contamination be able to neutralize a leak? I believe it will be especially difficult to maintain the proper pH for the fish habitat granted that there be a spill. Another study done by Robertson and Bryan incorporated in a writing called "PH Requirements of Freshwater Aquatic Life" explains that there is a "deterioration "that occurs to the aquatic life when habitat pH water levels change out of range. I fear that the overall Bristol Bay pH water levels will be too costly to try to control/ neutralize if part of the area was used as a disposal site.

The plan to withdraw EPA's "Determination to Restrict the Use of an Area as a Disposal Site; Pebble Deposit Area, Southwest Alaska, 82 Fed. Reg. 33,123 (July 19, 2017)" is an idea that might seriously alter the chemical composition of the waters in Bristol Bay. I agree with the 2014 proposal in that the Pebble mine deposits could leave "unacceptable adverse effects on fishing areas." I think that the plans of pebble miners should go through the permitting process stated in the Clean Water Act Section 404 (c) before being allowed to dispose.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I am writing to comment on the EPA's proposal to withdraw its 2014 determination that the Pebble Mine should not be allowed to use certain tributaries as disposal sites for the Pebble Mine. Proposal To Withdraw Proposed Determination To Restrict the Use of an Area as a Disposal Site; Pebble Deposit Area, Southwest Alaska, 82 Fed. Reg. 33,123 (July 19, 2017).  The agency's 2014 determination correctly addressed the harm to the ecosystem of the Bristol Bay watershed that would be caused by the mine. Upholding the 2014 proposal is the right thing to do to ensure that the Pebble Mine does not infringe on the rights of the local citizens to live in a healthy environment. 
On page 33124, the Federal Register states that the EPA, "believes that withdrawing the Proposed Determination ... is appropriate at this time for this particular matter," in order to  "remove any uncertainty ... about PLP's ability to submit a permit application and have that permit application reviewed". The Register is sure to note on the same page however that the initiation of the 404(c) process "does not preclude PLP from submitting an application and the Army Corps from reviewing that application," the only halt is that "the Army Corps could not have issued a permit while a section 404(c) process was ongoing." The 2014 proposal should be upheld in order to keep the mine accountable. 
The Bristol Bay watershed is a very diverse and important ecosystem; the largest natural salmon run is intact in these waters. Fish are very finicky, especially salmon, so the smallest change in the surrounding environment can devastate salmon populations. The amount and quality of salmon impact fishermen and recreationalists, neither of which enjoy fewer and sicker fish.  As fish are rather sensitive to environmental changes, they would fall victim to water pollution from the mine before the human communities would notice symptoms of lowered water quality. While the mining lease may be under a century, the effects are everlasting. 
Submitting the 2014 proposal is the best way to ensure that Pebble Mine is able to operate sustainably and not ruin the livelihoods of other industries using the same area. The value of minerals fluctuate greatly, whereas water always has inherent value. The withdrawal of the 2014 proposal would show priority the government takes for businesses over it's citizens. Corporations have no right to deteriorate the health of the public simply because it would make it easier for them to make more money that would be better dispersed throughout the wealth distribution anyway. There has to be a point where the health and well-being of the American public are a priority over a few number of elites making more millions. The past has proven that there are consequences to disregarding the environment and ignoring public health. The mine will impact the area for at least decades after its last dredge. The health of the people and ecosystem of the Bristol Bay watershed should have higher priority over a business that sees the possibility of an opportunity to extract wealth for a short period of time. The 2014 proposal is a good use of the EPA's discretion in order to keep the Bristol Bay healthy.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
The Pebble mining site represents a significant mineral asset for our country. Its future warrants an assessment by educated and knowledgeable personnel who have the authority to set a course of action that is a logical progression from information gathered to date.

As a long time observer of the Pebble project, periodically as a stockholder in NAK, it has been appalling to see the impediments set in place by government regulatory bodies toward the development of a mine. After-all, the site is within the Alaska State Mining District. This fact alone should have removed many of the obstacles that the project has faced.

Only due to the tenacity of Hunter Dickinson, the parent company of Northern Dynasty, has this massive project progressed to the current status.

I know of no NAK stockholder who wants to bring harm to the salmon life cycle in the vacinity or to the local inhabitants. All any of us have ever asked is to allow NAK to present its case to proper decision makers. 

Many mining experts, some from the university setting, have stated that the mine can be developed in parallel with the salmon industry. 

It would seem that the only prudent course of action at this point would be to allow the permitting process to run its course and listen to the US Army Corp of Engineers in their evaluation. From this outcome, a plan take of action can be taken with regard to the future of the proposed mine.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I am writing to comment on the EPA's proposition to withdraw the 2014 Proposed Determination where Pebble Mine is barred from using specific watersheds within the Bristol Bay as dumping locations for dredged or fill material associated with mining the Pebble deposit. Proposal To Withdraw Proposed Determination To Restrict the Use of an Area as a Disposal Site; Pebble Deposit Area, Southwest Alaska, 82 Fed. Reg. 33,123 (July 19, 2017). Under the Clean Water Act, the decision (based on the peer-reviewed scientific and technical findings) to restrict Pebble Mine from utilizing certain water bodies in the South Fork Koktuli River, North Fork Koktuli River, and Upper Talarik Creek watersheds as disposal sites in 2014 was appropriately analyzed and should not be withdrawn. If the determination is to be withdrawn, it only proves that the new EPA administration is prioritizing the profit of a foreign mining company, completely neglecting the economic, environmental, social, and cultural value of Bristol Bay to the residents of Alaska.
On 79 Fed. Reg. page 42315 (July 21, 2014) of the Proposed Determination, EPA Region 10 decided to restrict Pebble Mine from using the said specific water bodies due to the "high ecological and economic value of the Bristol Bay watershed". Bristol Bay, generating almost $500 million in economic expenses and sales, provide employment for more than 14,000 workers. If the EPA persists on the withdrawal of the accurate determination, the Pebble Mine would take away Bristol Bay's residents and Alaskan communities' source of income for indefinite generations only to create roughly 1,000 temporary mining jobs. The mine would strip from the people of Alaska the healthy ecosystem they have depended on to remain sustainable for many years. 
Again, on page 42315, EPA Region 10 specified under the Clean Water Act, peer-reviewed scientific and technical findings determined "unacceptable environmental effects that would result from such mining".  "In total, the three mine components: mine pit, tailings impoundments, and waste rock piles, would cover an area larger than Manhattan." "Given the extent of streams, wetlands, lakes, and ponds both overlying the Pebble deposit and within adjacent watersheds, excavation of a massive mine pit and construction of large tailings impoundments and waste rock piles would result in discharge of dredged or fill material into these waters". According to the Clean Water Act Section 404(c), "no discharge of dredged or fill material may be permitted if the nation's waters would be significantly degraded". If the Proposed Determination is withdrawn, the Pebble Mine will pollute these bodies of water stated and there will be a complete loss of fish habitat and the wetlands, streams, and other aquatic resources will no longer be able to contribute to the economy and sustainability of Alaskan people. The Pebble Mine will leave irreversible effects on the environment. Bristol Bay, being the last place on Earth with "bountiful and sustainable harvest of wild salmon" will never be as diverse and striking as it is ever again. If the EPA allows Pebble Mine to have this tremendous negative effect on the environment, one can say that the agency no longer adheres to what it should wholly stand for. 
Furthermore, on page 42315, "One of the main factors leading to the success of this fishery is the fact that its aquatic habitats are untouched and pristine". "These salmon populations, in turn, maintain the productivity of the entire ecosystem, including numerous other fish and wildlife species". The respect and significance given to salmon and other wildlife, along with traditional knowledge of the environment, have formed a continual sustenance-based way of life that is a key element of Alaska Native identity. This is preserved due to the undisturbed state of the Bristol Bay watershed. EPA's withdrawal of the Proposed Determination, would lead to the impairment of such a rich culture.
Bristol Bay is one of the last places on Earth that has a prosperous wildlife able to sustain its people. Prioritizing foreign mining interests at the expense of the American people and the economy would be absurd. It would be arbitrary to withdraw a decision accurately made from the beginning. The 2014 Proposed Determination to restrict Pebble Mine from utilizing Bristol Bay as an area for disposal should be maintained. It is the EPA's job to conserve the area for the people and the future of Alaska.
