Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
Today I am writing as a supporter of the environment and a believer in our current principal law governing pollution of the nation's surface waters: the Clean Water Act. I am writing to comment on the EPA's proposal to withdraw the Clean Water Act restrictions for Pebble Mine in Alaska's Bristol Bay watershed. These restrictions, determined in 2014, made it so the Pebble Mine would not be allowed to use certain tributaries as disposal sites within the Bristol Bay watershed. Proposal To Withdraw Proposed Determination To Restrict the Use of an Area as a Disposal Site; Pebble Deposit Area, Southwest Alaska, 82 Fed. Reg. 33,123 (July 19, 2017). It is clear that the original 2014 determination was created with a purpose, which was to protect the tributaries of the Bristol Bay from the previously determined potential environmental harm that would result from the Pebble Mine using said tributaries as disposal sites. The EPA is going back on the original decision that is directly supported by section 404c of the Clean Water Act, and that tells me that their perspective has been corrupted. Whether it's because money or the power of the Pebble Limited Partnership, the EPA is changing its mind on a determination that is only in place to protect the tributaries of a river ecosystem and to ensure the safety of Alaska's citizens. 
	On page 33123, the notice states that if the Pebble Limited Partnership files a permit application during the months from the date of settlement, the EPA may not move forward with a signed Recommended Determination for 48 months. This catches my attention because I am not willing to endanger the environment in and around the Bristol Bay for another four years while the PLP may or may not attempt to apply for a permit. The EPA needs to act on broken laws and enforce the Clean Water Act to its fullest extent. 
	On page 33123 it also states that the EPA's Administrator is choosing to withdraw the 2014 determination in order to provide PLP with additional time to submit a permit application to the Army Corps. Since when is it alright for a governmental agency choose to look past their purpose, which in this case is environmental protection, and give those who are polluting our waters a break from the law? The EPA's initial determination was put in place for a reason, and we should be doing everything in our power to ensure that our waters and ecosystems are safe before assessing the impact on a mining company. Because of these reasons, I do not deem it fit for the PLP to be given more time to submit a permit application that should have been submitted previous to the initial determination. In fact, the application could have been submitted while the determination was placed on the PLP, but it was not. 
	The initial 2014 determination to enforce section 404c of the Clean Water Act and restrict the disposal sites in Bristol Bay for the Pebble Mine was undeniably the correct decision by the EPA. It is solely in the EPA's power to restrict and/or deny the discharge of a material into defined sites of water in the United States. It is made blatantly clear on epa.gov that the decision to enforce section 404c will be made after concluding that the dumping sites will have "unacceptable adverse impact on one or more of the various resources" in the ecosystem. Since none of the practices from the Pebble Mine have changed between the 2014 determination and present-day, those items that the EPA had previously labeled to have "unacceptable adverse impacts" on the environment are still in existence. With that knowledge, the EPA is changing its standards and expectations by withdrawing the 2014 determination to form to the interest of the mining company instead of the interest of the environment. 
	In conclusion, the EPA's proposal to withdraw its 2014 determination and allow the Pebble Mine to use tributaries in Bristol Bay as disposal sites for even more time than they already have is unacceptable. It is the EPA's job to enforce the laws and regulations within their power in order to protect the environment and the people of this country, not to protect the interests of the Pebble Mine. The EPA's Administrator should review and reconsider the withdrawal decision in order to fulfill the standards of the EPA.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I am writing to comment on the EPA's proposal to withdraw the Proposed Determination that would not allow PLP to dispose of mining waste into waterways. Proposal To Withdraw Proposed Determination To Restrict the Use of an Area as a Disposal Site; Pebble Deposit Area, Southwest Alaska, 82 Fed. Reg. 33,123 (July 19, 2017).   
I am a senior environmental science major and have studied not only environmental laws and policies but the ecology of watersheds throughout my time at university. I therefore cannot support the proposal to withdraw the EPA Region 10 July 2014 Proposed Determination; I do not believe that PLP should be allowed to dispose of dredged or fill material into the Bristol Bay watershed due to the environmental harm this would cause and I believe that the EPA should use their authority under the Clean Water Act to stop this. 
Under the Clean Water Act this withdrawal clearly should not be allowed. The Clean Water Act does not allow for point-source pollution into navigable waterways and waterways that are important to and connected to navigable waterways. The South Fork Koktuli River, North Fork Koktuli River, and Upper Talarik Creek watersheds are all a part of the larger, navigable Bristol Bay watershed, which supports a large commercial and sport fishing industry that nearby communities rely on. 
Bristol Bay and the surrounding tributaries has the largest sockeye salmon population in the world as well as large populations of other anadromous fish, all of which are sensitive and keystone species, and all of which the local communities, especially indigenous, rely on for subsistence. Disposing of mining waste and other sediments into these waterways would severely impact these species and the communities that depend on them. Impacting these fisheries would ruin the economy of this area and deprive most of the locals of their jobs and source of income.  
I understand the argument that the mine would create new jobs and new income for the area, and while that sounds like a great thing, it'd be at the sacrifice of the jobs and income from the fisheries industry. The fishing industry around Bristol Bay isn't a small one either; this area provides half the world's sockeye salmon harvest! The area is known as America's "fish basket". Anadromous fish are not the only species that use these waterways; seals, walrus, whales live here as well, and these species all have ecological and cultural significance as well. 
On page 33123, the notice states that "the Agency agreed to not exercise its discretion regarding Section 404(c) review for a certain period of time." The EPA should in no way give up the authority to deny PLP's permit under Section 404(c), because PLP's mining operation would cause "unacceptable adverse effect on municipal water supplies, shellfish beds and fishery areas," and this is unacceptable under the Clean Water Act. 
If the EPA does withdraw the Proposed Determination, the EPA will be putting industry above the health of people and the environment. The EPA originally concluded that the Pebble Mine would cause unacceptable adverse environmental impacts, and the EPA should stand by their original decision and use their authority to prevent the pollution of these waterways and the destruction of economically and ecologically important natural resources. If the waters of Bristol Bay are sacrificed for industry, this sets a precedent that could be frightening in its implications and would result in a loss of faith in the EPA and its intentions.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I am writing to comment on the EPA's proposal to withdraw its 2014 determination that the Pebble Mine should not be allowed to pollute the headwaters of Bristol Bay by discharging dredged or fill material into its streams, wetlands, lakes, and ponds.  Proposal to Withdraw Proposed Determination to Restrict the Use of an Area as a Disposal Site; Pebble Deposit Area, Southwest Alaska, 82 Fed. Reg. 33,124 (July 19, 2017).  The 2014 determination was issued by the EPA in order to protect the areas pristine environment that sustains one of the largest salmon fishery's in the world.   After years of collecting scientific data, the EPA had indicated the potential threats an open mine, like Pebble Mine, would have on its ecosystem.  Thereby, they authorized under the Clean Water Act Section 404(c) to "prohibit, restrict, or deny the use of any defined area in waters of the United States for specification as a disposal site whenever it determines, after notice and opportunity for public hearing, that the discharge of dredged or fill material into the area will have an unacceptable adverse effect on fishery areas (including spawning and breeding areas)".  The determination of 2014 was decided because of the scientific evidence that reveled the adverse effects PLP, or any mining company, would have on the Bristol Bay watershed.  
To begin, on page 33124, the notice states that the Administer is proposing to give additional time to Pebble Limited Partnership (PLP) so that they may have sufficient time to submit their application to the Army Corps.  This is in hopes that PLP may be able to continue on with the rest of their permitting process without having the EPA finish, and possibly having to enforce, the initial determination proposed in 2014 under Section 404(c) of the Clean Water Act.  Though, the permitting process by the Army Corps would typically decide whether to approve or deny the permit, the EPA determined, after sufficient evidence was collected, to administer their power given in section 404(c) of the Clean Water Act.  This indefinitely would have prevented the PLP permit from being passed.  The EPA in 2014 made this decision based off of the scientific data that illustrated the detrimental effects a mine would have on the economy, environment, and social capital in the local region  The EPA's only objective is to protect the people of Alaska, the people of the United States, and their natural resources.   
The EPA also states on page 33124 that the "withdrawal of the Proposed Determination would remove any uncertainty, real or perceived, about PLP's ability to submit a permit application and have that permit application reviewed".  I begin by questioning why this this section is even in the withdrawal? I say this because it was not the withdrawal of the Proposed Determination that kept PLP from submitting a permit; it was PLP itself that decided not to after the 2014 Proposed Determination.  The Clean Water Act, specifically section 404, is a respectable policy that the EPA can use to determine the criteria used by the Army Corps to issue permits.  As history displays, majority of the time the EPA, Army Corps, and industries can, and will, negotiate terms in order to allow industries to move forward in the permitting process while still following certain environmental criteria to ensure the protection of the watersheds of the United States of America.  With that being said, under Section 404(c), it allows the EPA to "prohibit or restrict fill activities if EPA determines a project would have unacceptable adverse effects on fishery areas." There are only thirty instances, according to the EPA website, of section 404(c) being enforced by the EPA.  Of those 30 times, there have been only 13 final determinations issued.  This demonstrates how limited these issues are used and it also demonstrates why Section 404(c) was written in the Clean Water Act in the first place.  Each determination, including the one on Bristol Bay, was issued on behalf of projects that would've had degraded a piece of environment that is vital for the United States of America.  

-Caitlin Castle

I am writing you today to ask that you not withdraw the Bristol Bay Proposed Determination, which was made pursuant to the Clean Water Act in 2014.

As you know, Bristol Bay, Alaska, is one of America's last great wild salmon fisheries. Tens of millions of wild salmon return annually, which support upwards of 14,000 American jobs in the commercial and sport fishing industries, serve as a one-in-a-lifetime destination for anglers from around the world, and are the cultural cornerstone for the region's communities.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
Dear Administrator Pruitt & Acting Administrator Pirzadeh: 

I am very disappointed that you plan to reverse course and green light the proposed Pebble Mine, despite the catastrophic risks it poses to Alaska's Bristol Bay watershed, its world-renowned salmon runs and its Native communities. 

Under the Obama administration, the EPA, after years of rigorous study, proposed science-based restrictions that would have banned the dangerous Pebble Mine to protect Bristol Bay from the myriad of environmental risks this massive gold and copper mine would pose. Your recent settlement with Northern Dynasty Minerals to reverse those common-sense restrictions is a blatant giveaway to the mining industry at the expense of the American people, our environment and our economy.

Bristol Bay's wild salmon fishery supports 14,000 jobs and is valued at more than $1.5 billion annually. It also supplies nearly half of the world's sockeye salmon. More than 65 percent of Alaskans, 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents and Native communities, and 85 percent of commercial fishermen oppose the mine.

I urge you to listen to those voices, and for the sake of the Bristol Bay watershed, its world-class salmon fishery and its people, keep the door closed on Pebble Mine.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
October 5, 2017
As an Alaskan, and a citizen of the world, I am asking you to keep in place the Clean Water Act restrictions on mining the Pebble ore deposit in the Bristol Bay Watershed. Do not allow these pristine waters to serve as a disposal site for dredged or fill material associated with mining the Pebble deposit.
Bristol Bay, and its surrounding watershed in southwest Alaska, is home to the world's largest sockeye salmon fishery, and one of the largest and most prolific king salmon fisheries.  Bristol Bay produces half of the world's salmon.  This ecosystem is tremendously productive, and depends on an abundant supply of clean, fresh water. Thirty Alaska Native tribes in this region depend on salmon for their subsistence, culture and livelihoods.  The salmon fishery is estimated to support 14,000 full and part time jobs at a value of $1.5 billion annually.  In addition, recreation and tourism in the area is responsible for another $90 million of State revenue due to licenses and taxes.  All of this is threatened by the proposed Pebble Mine.
The Pebble ore body is acidic, requiring treatment in perpetuity. It is totally unrealistic to assume that mining an acid-producing ore body this large, and in the heart of a pristine watershed, could be managed to prevent acid drainage from leaching into adjacent streams, wetlands and estuaries.  There is no example on the planet that would give you hope that this is possible.  To say this could be an impact on the $1.5 billion Bristol Bay salmon fishery is an understatement.
And, if one needed any further reason for concern, look what is happening to fisheries around the world. Two insightful articles were published this summer which illuminate why Bristol Bay needs protection. The farmed salmon industry is threatened by sea lice which are proliferating in stocks worldwide 
http://www.chicagotribune.com/lifestyles/health/ct-sea-lice-salmon-industry-20170918-story.html and salmon caught in Seattle's Puget Sound were found to have a variety of drugs and personal care items from Prozac to caffeine, from ibuprofen to bug spray. 
https://www.seattletimes.com/seattle-news/environment/drugs-flooding-into-puget-sound-and-its-salmon/
So the 1.5 billion dollar question is....why would we want to put one of the last wild fish stocks at risk? Keep the Clean Water Act restrictions in place and give the world an abundant supply of healthy salmon. 
Thank you for the opportunity to comment.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I am opposed to EPAs proposal to rescind the 2014 Proposed Determination designed to protect Bristol Bays world class fisheries. Please stand with American jobs and communities and preserve tohe Bristol Bay Proposed Determination.

Bristol Bay, Alaska, is one of America's last great wild salmon fisheries. Each year, tens of millions of wild salmon return, supporting upwards of 14,000 jobs in the commercial and sport fishing industries, and serving as a one-in-a-lifetime destination for anglers from around the world as well as the cultural cornerstone for the region's communities. These long-established businesses are at risk from a foreign-owned mining company that wants to build the proposed Pebble Mine, which is opposed by more than 65 percent of Alaskans and more than 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents. 

In 2014, led by Alaska Native Tribes, interests including commercial fishing business owners and sportsmen asked the EPA step in to ensure that this mine wouldn't jeopardize Bristol Bay. The EPA responded by listening to over 1.5 million Americans, hosting dozens of community meetings, reviewing Pebble's many detailed filings with state and federal agencies, and conducting a twice peer-reviewed scientific assessment of the potential impacts to the region. Withdrawing the proposed determination ignores the overwhelming majority of Alaskans and puts the short-term interests of a foreign mining company above thousands of local jobs. 

For the sake of our wildlife, waterways, and communities, I urge you to protect Bristol Bay and prevent this horrible open-pit mine from destroying one of our nation's most precious ecosystems.  Pebble has an atrocious track record.

The EPA was right to stop this in 2014 and nothing has changed. Mining of this type has no place in most of the world, certainly not in Bristol Bay. 

Mr. Pruitt: hands off Bristol Bay!

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment: I urge the EPA to not lift the Clean Water Act restrictions that were proposed. Alaska is an incredibly vulnerable environment and any perturbations to the ecosystem such as heavy metal mining waste contamination to water bodies can have unpredictable and lasting consequences. The state of Alaska is currently in a budget crisis and relies heavily upon its fishing industry, which Bristol Bay is located in the heart of. Any threat to the livelihood of the salmon population can have the capacity to further cripple our economic state. Additionally, many Alaskans rely on subsistence harvesting, therefore a contamination event as a result of less stringent restrictions on mining waste also threatens human health in addition to environmental and economic health. It is also unpredictable how long any deleterious effects would remain in the environment, fish, and humans following contamination. I do not see the purpose or benefit of lifting the Clean Water Act restrictions and doing so only increases the risk of a catastrophic contamination event occurring. Any money that would be saved by not disposing of mining waste properly will eventually be superseded by the even larger amount of money spent to mediate the repercussions of a contamination event that could have been easily prevented by having these regulations in place.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I oppose withdrawing the EPA Region 10 July 2014 Proposed Determination that was issued pursuant of the Clean Water Act for the Bristol Bay area. It's unfathomable to me why you think we should allow a fully foreign-owned company to pollute and destroy one of our own more pristine environments. There are many arguments against this move, including:
1) Local communities are against this, including 80% of Bristol Bay locals and 85% of their commercial fisherman. Remember, this is their environment that will be destroyed.
2) It would adversely affect the salmon fisheries in Bristol Bay, which would be economically devastating to the area and to my belly. I don't know about you, but I love wild salmon. 
3) You might dismiss the EPA under previous administrations, but their science is solid. Allowing a mine in Bristol Bay and allowing it to pollute the waters there would be deleterious to the environment and economy.
4) An accidental discharge from the mine into the waters or surrounding environment would have devastating consequences.
5) Studies show that mines regularly violate water protections and pollution regulations. Mining operations continually pollute our waterways. They do not have a good track record, and I don't see how this will be any different.
6) The economic advantages of such an operation are questionable. The fishery already supports 14,000 jobs.
7) Thoughtlessly exploiting areas like Bristol Bay for questionable economic purposes goes against the entire purpose of the EPA. It's called the Environmental Protection Agency, not the Polluter Protection Agency. Please do your job and protect the environment.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I am vehemently opposed to EPAs proposal to rescind the 2014 Proposed Determination designed to protect Bristol Bays world class fisheries and the life that surrounds these most precious fisheries. I, my family and the majority of the American People and all Native People stand with American jobs and communities and with rising voices and actions demand that you preserve the Bristol Bay Proposed Determination.

Bristol Bay, Alaska, is one of America's last great wild salmon fisheries. Each year, tens of millions of wild salmon return, supporting upwards of 14,000 jobs in the commercial and sport fishing industries, and serving as a one-in-a-lifetime destination for anglers from around the world as well as the cultural cornerstone for the region's communities. These long-established businesses are at risk from a foreign-owned mining company that wants to build the proposed Pebble Mine, which is opposed by more than 65 percent of Alaskans and more than 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents. 

In 2014, led by Alaska Native Tribes, interests including commercial fishing business owners and sportsmen asked the EPA step in to ensure that this mine wouldn't jeopardize Bristol Bay. The EPA responded by listening to over 1.5 million Americans, hosting dozens of community meetings, reviewing Pebble's many detailed filings with state and federal agencies, and conducting a twice peer-reviewed scientific assessment of the potential impacts to the region. Withdrawing the proposed determination ignores the overwhelming majority of Alaskans and puts the short-term interests of a foreign mining company above thousands of local jobs. 

For the sake of our wildlife, waterways, and communities, I urge you to protect Bristol Bay and prevent this horrible open-pit mine from destroying one of our nation's most precious ecosystems.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I am outraged that the EPA plans to reverse course and allow Northern Dynasty to apply for federal permits for the proposed Pebble Mine, despite the catastrophic risks it poses to Alaska's Bristol Bay watershed, its world-renowned salmon runs, and its Native communities. In 2014 the Environmental Protection Agency proposed common-sense science-based restrictions that would have banned this dangerous mine because of the obvious environmental risks it would pose. The EPA's recent settlement with Northern Dynasty Minerals to reverse those common-sense restrictions is a blatant giveaway to the mining industry at the expense of the American people, our environment, and our economy.

In addition to the engineering, legal, and economic problems (as in, completely non-viable) the mine faces, there is the obvious issue that no one can predict earthquakes and no one know with certainty the position of the Lake Clark fault near the proposed Pebble Mine site. Northern Dynasty's current plans indicate that the four earthen tailing dams would be engineered to withstand 7.8 magnitude quakes at a distance of 18 miles when two USGS studies suggest the fault may actually lie within 5 to 10 miles of the mine site, effectively tripling the effects of a similar magnitude quake.  Extremely powerful earthquakes, quite common in Southern Alaska, could corrupt the massive earthen containment dams either through dam failure during shaking or landslides that cause dam failure -- dams holding 10 billion tons of highly toxic mining waste, a miniscule percentage of which, if released, would be devastating to the health and survival of aquatic life in the Upper and Lower Talarik creeks, the Koktuli, Stoyahok, Chulitna and Newhalen rivers, as well as Iliamna Lake and the Kvichak River that drains the lake into Bristol Bay.  

Salmon are acutely, fatally, sensitive to copper and other heavy metals and even the smallest release of these compounds could have catastrophic effects, not only on the Sockeye, Chinook, Coho, Chum, and Pink salmon, but on several species of trout, and their prey species as well.  It could harm 28 additional fish species, 190 types of birds, and numerous species of land animals that rely on these crucial waters. 

Even ignoring the toxicity, the huge freshwater withdrawals and the perpetual (centuries long) water treatment and waste management poses significant long term environment risks (and financial risks to the public if the cost of treating acid rock drainage and heavy metal leaching has been underestimated, as it almost always is with similar large sulfide mines in wet climates).

Such large scale mining projects are abhorrent anywhere, but in places such as Bristol Bay - places of such pristine beauty and flourishing abundance of wildlife - they are completely unacceptable and beyond contemplation for any reasonable person.  Even the damage caused by preliminary testing and infrastructure development is significant, let alone the full scale development of the open-pit monstrosity and toxic wasteland that would be the Pebble Mine legacy for centuries.

As you well know, these headwaters and bays are home to the most productive salmon fishery on earth.  The Bristol Bay watershed is an ecosystem of international significance as it is the world's largest remaining wild sockeye salmon run which produces roughly half of the world's commercial sockeye salmon. These abundant salmon cycles have sustained native peoples and legions of wildlife species in the surrounding wetlands and tundra for many thousands of years, and today the salmon fishery is a healthy $1.5 billion industry seasonally employing more than 14,000 people. The Bristol Bay watershed sustains the culture and traditions of Alaska Natives, including the Yup'ik and Denai'na, two of the last intact, sustainable, salmon-based cultures in the world.

Even assuming the mine operator intended to be extremely cautious in regards to the environment, it wouldn't matter!  The very construction, operation, and decades-long toxic mine-waste generation and centuries-long waste containment issues would ensure the permanent destruction and utter ruination of the premier salmon habitat and fishery on earth.

The public has overwhelmingly rejected the Pebble Mine project. More than 65 percent of all Alaskans, 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents, and 85 percent of commercial fisherman strongly oppose the Pebble Mine.  Indigenous peoples, commercial fishing operations, hunting and fishing groups, retailers, outfitters, conservation organizations, 58 major jewelers, and MILLIONS of concerned individuals in the United States and around the world are opposed to this project and will not cease in their efforts to stop the Pebble Mine from being developed.

Teck, Mitsubishi, Rio Tinto, and Anglo American saw the writing on the wall and bailed on this environmentally catastrophic and money-losing project.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
Will Curtiss
B.S. Univerrsity of Colorado Boulder
Geology

Copper adds convenience to my everyday life.  More importantly my standard of living is massively improved in terms of health, productivity and comfort as a result of an affordable and reliable source of copper and the products it makes available to us.

Fish are important, clean water is important, ecosystems are important - but we will lose the countless benefits we get from cheap domestic copper and other hard rock materials if we always make concessions in the interest of other resources.

Copper mining has allowed us to advance our technology to the unprecedented scale it is today. We can use this technology to evermore efficiently and safely mine new resources.  This is not a pipe dream.  We can all clearly see evidence of this truth just by comparing the way we live now to the way we lived 50, or 100 years ago. 

Their is opportunity for both the responsible treatment of the environment and that of sustaining the maintenance of our current infrastructure as well as the less impacting, more efficient, clean and exciting one to be from the ever advancing state of our technological capabilities.

Preservation can be pervasive in our mindset as we extract the materials we need to sustain the thriving living standards and equality among diverse communities that is available to modern societies.

Title: Comment submitted by A. Peloza
Comment:
Dear EPA:
Please consider my comments to support the withdrawal of the Proposed Determination of the Pebble Deposit Area, as follows:

The proposed determination ignored existing processes, undermining agency responsibilities on both the state and federal
level. Further, the EPA does not have the authority under the Clean Water Act to preemptively block development in the 
absence of a permit application.  The EPA must withdraw its proposed determination because it was based on an untested, 
ad hoc analysis that is not sanctioned by the CWA or NEPA. Once the NEPA process is initiated, the U.S. Army Corps of 
Engineers will prepare an Environmental Impact Statement based on project plans.  A preemptive decision, prior to permit 
or project application and completion of the National Environmental Policy Act (NEPA) process, is unacceptable, whether it
be approval or denial of any project in any industry.

Every project, no matter the size or location, should have an opportunity to be reviewed under existing legal processes. In
the case of mining, there are more than 60 major permits and hundreds more from local, state, and federal agencies that 
must be successfully obtained. If the process determines a project as designed cannot protect the environment and other 
resources, it will not advance. The process will not permit one industry or resource to advance at the expense of another.

Any 404(c) action outside the existing permitting process would be an extreme case of federal overreach and an assault on
Alaska sovereignty. The Pebble deposit is not located on federal land, nor inside a refuge or park. It is located on state land 
designated for mineral exploration. The State of Alaska depends on the responsible development of natural resources on its
lands to diversify and support its economy.

Until an application is filed describing the project in detail and an Environmental Impact Statement is completed, the EPA is 
prematurely determining adverse impacts based on hypothetical assessments and inapplicable modeling.

The fate of a project, including Pebble, cannot be rationally decided without consideration of the full social, economic and 
environmental impacts of the project. This information will be developed through the rigorous NEPA process.

Thank you, 
Amy Peloza

More than 65 percent of Alaskans, 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents and Native communities, and 85 percent of commercial fishermen oppose this mine according to surveys.  The existing restrictions that were put in place are appropriate and necessary to protect this watershed and its value from both a ecological and commercial standpoint.   Why a Canadian-owned mining concern should be permitted to dump what has been estimated to be up to 10 billion tons of mining waste into a critical United States salmon spawning habitat and destroy it is unfathomable.  There should be no withdrawal of this restriction.

Title: Comment submitted by D. Briggs
Comment:
I am writing to express my opposition to withdrawing the proposed 2014 restrictions on "the use of certain waters in the Bristol Bay watershed for disposal of dredged or fill material associated with mining the Pebble deposit." The proposed Pebble mine project would sit at the headwaters of Bristol Bay's watershed, which is home to annual wild salmon runs that exceed 50 million fish. Bristol Bay's $1.5 billion annual sustainable commercial fishery provides 14,000 jobs and supplies half of the world's sockeye salmon. The Obama EPA conducted an extensive study that left little uncertainty to the potential hazards of the project. In its proposed determination, the EPA said peer-reviewed scientific and technical research determined that the effects of the mining would have "unacceptable environmental effects." This study was an extensive three-year, twice-peer reviewed scientific assessment that found a mine like that proposed for the Pebble would have "significant" and potentially "catastrophic" impacts on the Bristol Bay watershed. According to polls, though, more than 65 percent of Alaskans, 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents and Native communities, and 85 percent of commercial fishermen oppose the mining project. I am outraged that the current EPA feels obliged to put commercial interests and profits before the obvious negative impacts that this mine will have for the area, its resources, and its economy.

This is the worst place for a project like this. The volume of toxic waste produced from the smallest mine proposed at the Pebble Mine project in the Bristol Bay watershed of Alaska would be enough to fill a professional football stadium more than 880 times. The toxic waste produced by the largest of the proposed mines at the site would do so more than 3,900 times. Disposal of the waste material from the mining would require the construction of up to three mine-waste impoundments, covering an additional 19 square miles and including waste-rock piles covering up to 8.7 squares. All of these deposits will be occurring in an area that contains highly productive streams and wetlands, the EPA said. In addition the geology of the area is very porous, would not contain these toxic ponds, and would further contaminate the surrounding waterways and fishery habitats.

I voice my strongest opposition to withdrawing the proposed 2014 restrictions on "the use of certain waters in the Bristol Bay watershed for disposal of dredged or fill material associated with mining the Pebble deposit." Science can not be ignored!

David Briggs
retired marine biologist and concerned citizen
Shaker Heights, OH 44122

Title: Comment submitted by K. Emerson
Comment:
I am completely against the withdrawal of restrictions for use of the Pebble Deposit area as a disposal site.

The area under consideration is where half of the world's sockeye salmon population is harvested.  It is one of the last, great salmon fisheries left in the world.  If this change in regulations is allowed to go through we will be destroying this valuable population. The returning salmon and other ecological resources create some 14,000 full- and part-time jobs, generate about $480 million annually -- and support 4,000-year-old Alaska Native cultures. 

It is dangerous to even allow applications for permits for mining in this area.  Such a mine would result in complete loss of fish habitat due to elimination, dewatering, and fragmentation of streams, wetlands, and other aquatic resources in some areas of the bay watershed, It is estimated that 22 miles of streams and more than 6 square miles of wetlands and other habitats that are important to salmon and other fish would be lost to a large-scale mine. These losses would be IRREVERSIBLE.

Please do not allow the withdrawal of the restrictions to take place

Sincerely, 
Kathy Emerson

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I do not support the withdrawal of the protections initiated in 2014 that are noted in The Bristol Bay area Docket ID No. EPA-R10-OW-2017-0369. The important findings of the July 2014 Clean Water Act Proposed Determination must stand.

This area is well known as the largest natural fish hatchery of Sockeye Salmon in the world, and results in the harvesting of as many as 30 million individual fish by fisherman annually according to Alaska Fish and Game's website. This is a very significant number, as the world consumes roughly 65 million Sockeye annually, therefore this single area represents nearly half of salmon supply in the world, feeding millions of people.

Beyond those facts, the local fishing industry supports as many as 14,000 full and part-time jobs and over $400 million dollars in revenue for the local economy. Not to mention the additional revenue generated through the distribution, sale, preparation, and consumption of these fish throughout the country. The residents of the Bristol Bay area have spoken time and again in opposition to the mine. I live in Colorado and see "No Pebble Mine" stickers on cars even driving around here. The EPA has agreed that the proposed Pebble mine would be catastrophic to Bristol Bay's salmon and to the economic vitality of its communities, and should stand by these facts and not reverse course at this time. 

The study is being driven by the interests of a Canadian mining company who wishes to mine in the area and use the waters to dispose of dredged or fill material associated with mining from the Pebble deposit. For an administration that claims to want to put "America First" to pander to a Canadian mining company is beyond hypocritical.

How can anyone believe this administration is working to "Make America Great Again" when withdrawal of this protection directly has the potential for the elimination of 14,000 jobs and risks cutting the food supply of millions of people? These are good paying jobs for American citizens, jobs that help feed millions of people and supply half of the salmon consumed in the world. This area deserves the protections afforded to it under the July 2014 Clean Water Act Proposed Determination, and the people of Bristol Bay deserve to keep their jobs. Do not withdraw this study.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment submitted by E. Chester
Comment: My name is Emily Chester, a biologist from Bloomington, Indiana. I am opposing the proposed policy reversal regarding the protections for Bristol Bay. This is a critical habitat, and disruption and destruction of it would have negative impacts on US interests and on the ecosystem. For example, currently this area is one of the most productive fisheries in America. Protecting this resource maintains jobs for those in the fishing industry, those who make livings utilizing the ecosystem dependent on the salmon, such as hunters and those involved in ecotourism, and offshore fishing. Mining can completely destroy this ecosystem, since operational mines wreak havoc on the flow of the river and long term the chemicals produced in the mining leech out into the surrounding areas making them acidic wastelands. There is likely no recovery from this, except perhaps with extremely costly efforts. It is much better to make use of the renewable resources of the land in its natural state than to destroy it while stripping it of non-renewable resources that poison the area. By keeping the area federally protected, it is safe from mining considerations now and in the future. The people who live around and depend on the Bristol Bay are protected from pollution and losing their jobs. The native cultures that celebrate the life in and on the river are free to continue the lifestyles they've always known. It is important to realize that how important waterways are to the people and non-human organisms that depend on them. Where relatively untouched and healthy ecosystems exist, it is crucial to protect them. Thank you for your consideration.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment submitted by D. Read
Comment:
Dear EPA,
I am a conservative republican leaning American.  I love my country and I love the natural outdoor
opportunities and wilderness areas that some of our prior administrations have protected.  In addition to the 
joy that comes from being able to spend time in some of these areas, these areas also
provide jobs and a way of life for thousands of other Americans.  To have pristine areas such as
Bristol Bay in Alaska as a true wilderness unfettered by human presence is a treasure not only for
current Americans but also for generations to come.

I have witnessed first hand the environmental damage caused from a long closed mining operation near
the headwaters of the Animas river in SW Colorado in August 2015.  While on vacation and fly fishing
the beautiful streams in the area including the lower Animas, a major breach occurred while the EPA was trying
to mitigate residual pollution and toxic tailings from the Gold King Mine. The river was shut down and locals had 
to rely on bottled water while paying to have their wells tested.  The river turned an ugly orange.  All from toxic 
waste from a mine that was abandoned 100 years prior.  The economic impact just on the town of Durango, where
we were staying, was significant.

Why do you feel removing protection for wilderness areas and allowing material extraction from these areas
will result in anything different than we have seen in countless other wilderness areas subjected to mining
interests?  A hundred years have passed and many of these mines are still causing huge problems.  

You can save your future colleagues and future EPA employees from future headaches!
Please do not reverse the protection afforded to wilderness areas, including Bristol Bay, by the prior administration!

David Read
Belleville, IL

This watershed provides jobs for families like those of Iliamna and food for families like mine. Northern Dynasty Minerals and the Pebble Mine group promises 1,000 permanent jobs and an additional 2,000 jobs during the construction process.  By my calculations, that is a very sizeable NET LOSS OF JOBS in a very rural area.  Devastating.   Please, protect the environment as your agency's name states.  But also, I ask you to protect the JOBS, FOOD SOURCE, and CULTURAL IDENTITY that the Bristol Bay watershed supports.  Administrator Pruitt's meeting with the Pebble Limited Partnership's CEO should not be the deciding factor in a decision to roll back the 2014 Proposed Determination.

Comment: The Environmental Protection Agency is supposed to protect delicate ecosystems from damaging development. That is your purpose and why your agency was created. Please don't abandon this goal in sacrifice to big business and the all-mighty dollar.  You cannot put a price on our environment and once we damage this earth, we may never be able to restore it. A recent article on cnn.com states: "For more than 15 years, Northern Dynasty Minerals, a Canadian mining company, has sought to build a gold and copper mine in Bristol Bay." The Obama administration, and rightly so, chose to protect this fragile ecosystem from such reckless development because "Such a mine "would result in complete loss of fish habitat due to elimination, dewatering, and fragmentation of streams, wetlands, and other aquatic resources" in some areas of the bay watershed, the EPA found after three years of peer-reviewed research. In particular, the EPA estimated 22 miles of streams and more than 6 square miles of wetlands and other habitats that are important to salmon and other fish would be lost to a large-scale mine. "All of these losses would be irreversible," the agency said." How can this agency ignore its own scientific study and try to walk back these important protections? Should this mine be established, there is no way to recover the habitat. This decision, in my opinion, would be unconscionable. Please do not allow this proposed withdrawal to proceed. Thank you for your consideration in this matter. I hope that you will choose to do the right thing.

Title: Comment submitted by S. Kalter
Comment:
I am fully against any lifting of the restrictions against gold mining and other mining at or near Bristol Bay.  No approval for any gold mine or other mine should ever be issued for this area.  Scott Pruitt is involved in a corrupt, insane and criminal collusion with the Pebble Limited Partnership to destroy this area and with it to destroy the salmon fisheries economy of the region.  He is not simply "following the law" as the CEO of that group claimed.  Salmon in this region must not only be protected in their own right regardless of human harvesting of them, but to allow sustainable fishing of them to continue into perpetuity.  The head of the EPA should listen to the science and his own staff, not to moneyed interests who are plainly lying about their ability to mine without irreversible environmental degradation.  The tribal nations and Alaskan tribal corporations should be heeded in their opposition to development in this area.

Susan Kalter, Director, Native American Studies, Illinois State University

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I am writing to express my complete disgust with the possibility of lifting restrictions on mining in Bristol Bay Alaska.  This is one of the last great natural spawning grounds for salmon in the world.  Repeated environmental impact studies have indicated that allowing mining in this region would likely result in near total destruction of the ecosystem.  This should give you pause on multiple levels.  One should ask do we as a species even have a right to destroy something that has taken millions of years to develop and likely cannot be replaced, but if notions of justice do not appeal to your sensibilities, then the economics also make no sense.  This proposal threatens a beloved, sustainable source of income and commerce for the state of Alaska that will benefit thousands of locals as well as the greater US economy in exchange for a finite operation that will ultimately uproot and deprive the surrounding communities of a means of sustainability while enriching a foreign company.  

I sincerely hope that you will consider your decisions with regard to the long term viability of the communities that have built their livelihoods on this precious natural resource and to the irreplaceable beauty of an ecosystem that can only be squandered by allowing mining here.

Trust the environmental and scientific studies that have found that this mining project is a horrible idea. Protect the environment and not big business.

Title: Anonymous public comment

The proposal to withdraw these protections from the Bristol Bay area is a BLATANT and DISGUSTING ignoring of years of scientific research and reporting on the ecological importance and fragility of the area in favor of mining interests.  Although it is 100% certain that the people now running the EPA will ignore all comments like mine, not to mention the the scientists who research and people who rely on and enjoy the fisheries of Bristol Bay, I am voicing my condemnation of the proposal to withdraw the restrictions on use.  The Pebble Mine would destroy forever the area for a short-term profit.  Scott Pruitt's meeting with the CEO of the company and then instantly proposing to withdraw protections highlight his complete LACK OF ETHICS and SUITABILITY to serve in the EPA as the most junior intern, let alone as its head.  The EPA is there to PROTECT the environment, not to find every excuse to let companies do whatever the Hell they want no matter the cost to the environment and the people.  

Show a modicum of responsibility and take back the proposal to withdraw protections from Bristol Bay.  The mining companies do not own the lands and waters of the US...the people do.  And the EPA's responsibility is to us, not to industry special interest.

Comment:
The natural world is shrinking at a pace unseen in modern times.  This is happening even as technology enables less
destructive actions be taken to support the growing need for natural resources.  It is perplexing and extremely disappointing that the wealthiest country in the world would possibly give up one of its most sacred, treasured, and important natural
landmarks, to be altered for ever, for the profit of few, and a foreign corporation.  

The tar sands project, the destruction of the Amazon, the continued cutting of old growth forests, the destruction of African savannah and poaching of its great wildlift, are all unnecessary acts considering the technology available today.  Their destruction is based on the low cost, take from the weak mentality that is destroying the last untouched wildernesses in the world today.  

We must set aside areas of our country, and the world so that future generations can experience and enjoy the natural world unaltered by man.  These same lands provide income, jobs, food, and enjoyment to millions of people directly and indirectly. But once alterned and polluted the value of these lands will be lost forever.  

I urge the government to do the right thing and protect these few remaining, and vital natual areas for the betterment of all mankind.

Title: Anonymous public comment

The mine could potentially wipe out the sockey due to elimination, dewatering, and and fragmentation of streams, wetlands, and other aquatic resources.  These losses would be irreversible.  My family went on a cruise to Alaska and enjoyed a fishing trip while there. We saw a wealth of aquatic life while on our fishing adventure.  My husband even caught a salmon. Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment: Please do NOT allow mining in Bristol Bay. No resources we extract from this last bit of wilderness will compensate for the loss of its salmon, its pristine waters, its capacity to function as a relatively healthy natural habitat. We have so little left, in terms of true wilderness, and the current administration and the EPA seem intent on destroying even that. Please listen to the will of the people, and to the rigorous scientific data that has been collected, and protect this priceless jewel. If you truly are patriotic and truly love this country, you will cease and desist destroying the remnants of Wild America. What you allow to be destroyed will never heal--we know too well the destruction that mining leaves in its wake: airborne toxins, poisoned topsoil & watersheds, wildlife populations decimated or eliminated; what a legacy to leave behind. America's wild lands are not yours to doal out to the highest bidder; they belong to the people of this country, and to future generations and your job is to safeguard them, to gather as much scientific information as possible concerning their role in keeping our planet healthy, and to protect the public from the threats caused by environmental damage. I implore you to stop this mad dash towards environmental collapse, and stand up for America's wilderness.

Title: Comment submitted by J. Kennedy
Comment:
As an Alaskan state citizen I am apposed  to the withdrawal of the Determination of EPA Region 10 July 2014 Determination to Restrict the  Use of the Area as a Disposal Site for mining waste.

I think it is important to protect the fishing industry in Bristol Bay from the pollution that will be caused 
by any large scale mining operation.

Please allow the preemptive EPA protections based on the clean water act to stay in place.  

Jodi Kennedy
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment submitted by D. Butt
Comment:
No, NO! Not only is this proposal for a mine, but it is also for building a deep water port to facilitate shipping the metal. This area is simply too important and too pristine to be at the risk that this proposal brings. The salmon are too important to be put at risk, Cook Inlet and Illiamna Lake are more important that a copper mine, no matter how important copper may become. America's copper needs are not so critical as to put so much of our environment at risk. 
    Do NOT withdraw the current restrictions. 
When taken in its totality, this project is just a land grab to "privatize the profits and socialize the costs".  No one can be 100% certain that nothing will go terribly wrong with this project, and, if the past is any indicator, if something does go wrong, we the people, and not the shareholders/owners of the company, will end up paying for the cleanup and restoration needed. Enough.
Do NOT withdraw the current restrictions. 

Sincerely,
Douglas Butt

Title: Anonymous Public Comment
Comment: Please do not allow mining on Bristol Bay; listen to the scientists; protect the valuable salmon runs; save Alaskan jobs. Please.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment submitted by S. Gillis
Comment:
Do not withdraw the July 2014 proposed determination. These lawsuits by PLP are an end run around the CWA by a foreign entity whose claim about an unfair process is laughable. PLP could have submitted the CWA Section 404 permit during the application process and waited for a final decision from the Army Corps - even though a final decision could not have been rendered until the process was complete but they didn't. This is like a student not submitting a final exam because they don't know how it might affect their final grade. PLP should have adhered to the process and submitted the application when they had ample time rather than crying foul and filing lawsuits to circumvent the CWA that protects the largest wild sockeye run in the world and those that depend upon it.  

Stephen Gillis

Title: Anonymous Public Comment
Comment:
I am writing to express grave concerns over the decision to reverse the Obama-era protections for Bristol Bay. The salmon industry there creates over ten thousand jobs, as well as generating hundreds of millions of dollars in revenue. Local Alaska Natives and scientists all agree that this could be catastrophic for the area. The severe ecological consequences could cripple the local industry, causing a rippling effect locally all the way outwards to the consumers. Despite assurances that the mine would be built responsibly, the effects would be irreversibly damaging. 

The current administration has already made countless horrible decisions in the name of money, but please strongly reconsider this decision.

The Environmental Protection Agency should stand up to Trump and his minions and do what you are supposed to do - PROTECT THE ENVIRONMENT!

Title: Anonymous Public Comment
Comment: The proposed withdrawal from the Clean Air act determination is an abomination. This Alaska area is one of the few places left in the world where salmon are free to spawn. Allowing mining in this area will destroy the salmon habitat and reduce naturally spawning salmon even further than the low current level. It is far easier to find other good and copper deposits than it is salmon spawning habitats; spawning salmon is the true precious resource that is at risk, not gold and copper! Do not allow mining, and do not withdraw the the Clean Act determination!

Title: Anonymous Public Comment
Comment:
I ask you to use common sense and respect the majority of the scientific community and its conclusions regarding mining in Bristol Bay.  Protections in the Bay were enacted after years of scientific reveiw and reversing those protections will irreparably harm the source of 1/2 the world's sockeye, will threaten around 14,000 full and part time jobs and the approximately $480 million in annual revenues generated.  These results, while horrendous, pale in comparison to the threat to the 4000 year old Alaska Native cultures that have depended on the salmon provided by Bristol Bay.

Title: Comment submitted by D. F. Caithamer
Comment:
I urge the EPA to maintain maximum protection of Bristol Bay area of Alaska and to immediately prohibit any mining operations in the rivers entering this Bay.

The rivers entering Bristol Bay provide spawning habitat for the very last great migratory populations of salmon.  These rivers are essential for the survival of these salmon.  Mining operations would present an extreme risk to these ecosystems and very likely cause the collapse of the salmon populations.  

Besides being a valuable natural resource, these rivers are a financial and cultural resource to the people of Alaska and the World.  

Prohibit mining in the Bristol Bay watershed.

Sincerely,
David F. Caithamer, Ph.D., M.S., B.S.
Spooner, Wisconsin

Title: Comment submitted by J. Tremonti
Comment:
Dear Ms. Pirzadeh,

I'm writing to express my strong opposition to the proposal to withdraw the July 2014 Proposed Determination that was issued pursuant to the Clean Water Act. This determination was the result of three years of peer-reviewed study, which clearly documented the tremendous economic and cultural value of the Bristol Bay salmon fishery. Rejecting scientific consensus is antithetical to the EPA's mission. The Bristol Bay salmon fishery is a renewable resource that supports thousands of jobs, and generates $300 million annually in direct sales of commercially caught salmon. The Pebble Mine cannot be developed without significantly and irreparably degrading this vital resource. Fragmentation of streams, wetlands, and other aquatic resources would permanently destroy one of the world's most important salmon fisheries.

The EPA should stand by its proposed determination and protect the Bristol Bay watershed. Thank you for your consideration in this matter. 

Kind Regards,
Joseph Tremonti

Title: Comment submitted by R. Kovach
Comment:
I am writing in strong opposition to any withdrawal of the EPA Region 10 July 2014 Proposed Determination issued pursuant of the Clean Water Act in Bristol Bay, Alaska.  Changing regulation and policy simply to appease a single, non-American company (Northern Dynasty is Canadian) represents an extraordinary example of irresponsible bureaucracy.  Worse, the Pebble Mine has already undergone US Government review, including the Determination at issue.  Revisiting these pre-existing decisions - decisions based on best-available science (two peer reviews) that was strongly supported by local communities (the mine threatens thousands of jobs and tribal rights) and the greater public (1.5 million comments) - is a striking waste of public resources and funds.  As a member of the public and previous resident of Alaska, cease these efforts once and for all.  They are deeply unpopular, dangerous and unwelcome.  

Ryan Kovach, PhD
Missoula, Montana 59802

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment: I am asking you to not withdrawal the study. Do not build the Pebble Mine.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
Sirs, we are opposed to withdrawing Clean Water Act restrictions on the mining of the Pebble deposit in the Bristol Bay watershed in southwestern Alaska.  Due to the presence of a very pristine environment within this watershed as well as the healthy offshore fishery industry of Bristol Bay, we recommend that the mining proposal be eliminated in its entirety.  There is no national need to mine this deposit and the resulting job loss due to mining pollution, which is unavoidable, will be catastrophic.

In closing, Bristol Bay is a pristine environment and one of the largest salmon fisheries in the world.  Please protect it.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I am extremely disappointed in the recent decision by Scott Pruitt and his EPA to remove the Obama-era regulation keeping mining companies out of Bristol Bay. The mining will do catastrophic damage to the ecosystem of the Bay, which is responsible for profound fish stocks (nearly half of the world's sockeye stocks). 29 fish species, more than 40 mammals, and more than 190 bird species call the Bay their home, and a two-mile-wide crater with predicted 10-billion tons of waste will without a doubt  impact their quality of life and ability to live in the region. Not only is the decision inconsiderate in terms of the wildlife, the native populations of Alaskans are being shoved aside for the mining company's gains. These populations do not have the proper representation to fight for themselves, and with more than 25 indigenous groups in the region they need the area to stay as it is to survive how they have for years.

This decision is not popular with a majority of Americans, and the EPA's decision represents a dismissal of the impact of the mine and a blatant disregard for how future Americans will be affected. It is irresponsible, it is disrespectful, and I cannot express enough my disapproval.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I am opposed to EPAs proposal to rescind the 2014 Proposed Determination designed to protect Bristol Bays world class fisheries. Please stand with American jobs and communities and preserve the Bristol Bay Proposed Determination.

Bristol Bay, Alaska, is one of America's last great wild salmon fisheries. Each year, tens of millions of wild salmon return, supporting upwards of 14,000 jobs in the commercial and sport fishing industries, and serving as a one-in-a-lifetime destination for anglers from around the world as well as the cultural cornerstone for the region's communities. These long-established businesses are at risk from a foreign-owned mining company that wants to build the proposed Pebble Mine, which is opposed by more than 65 percent of Alaskans and more than 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents. 

In 2014, led by Alaska Native Tribes, interests including commercial fishing business owners and sportsmen asked the EPA step in to ensure that this mine wouldn't jeopardize Bristol Bay. The EPA responded by listening to over 1.5 million Americans, hosting dozens of community meetings, reviewing Pebble's many detailed filings with state and federal agencies, and conducting a twice peer-reviewed scientific assessment of the potential impacts to the region. Withdrawing the proposed determination ignores the overwhelming majority of Alaskans and puts the short-term interests of a foreign mining company above thousands of local jobs. 

For the sake of our wildlife, waterways, and communities, I urge you to protect Bristol Bay and prevent this horrible open-pit mine from destroying one of our nation's most precious ecosystems.
Yes I know this is a canned letter but I agree with the premise that protecting some things is more important than money.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I live on the ocean and daily see the effects of various types of pollutants.  I have visited Alaska several times, including the pristine Bristol Bay.  I write this to you based on first-hand observation and experience.
I am opposed to EPAs proposal to rescind the 2014 Proposed Determination designed to protect Bristol Bays world class fisheries. Please stand with American jobs and communities and preserve the Bristol Bay Proposed Determination.

Bristol Bay, Alaska, is one of America's last great wild salmon fisheries. Each year, tens of millions of wild salmon return, supporting upwards of 14,000 jobs in the commercial and sport fishing industries, and serving as a one-in-a-lifetime destination for anglers from around the world as well as the cultural cornerstone for the region's communities. These long-established businesses are at risk from a foreign-owned mining company that wants to build the proposed Pebble Mine, which is opposed by more than 65 percent of Alaskans and more than 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents. 

In 2014, led by Alaska Native Tribes, interests including commercial fishing business owners and sportsmen asked the EPA step in to ensure that this mine wouldn't jeopardize Bristol Bay. The EPA responded by listening to over 1.5 million Americans, hosting dozens of community meetings, reviewing Pebble's many detailed filings with state and federal agencies, and conducting a twice peer-reviewed scientific assessment of the potential impacts to the region. Withdrawing the proposed determination ignores the overwhelming majority of Alaskans and puts the short-term interests of a foreign mining company above thousands of local jobs. 

For the sake of our wildlife, waterways, and communities, I urge you to protect Bristol Bay and prevent this horrible open-pit mine from destroying one of our nation's most precious ecosystems.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I feel like this article retrieved from CNN sums up my feelings quite well - "This is the jewel in the crown of America's fisheries resources, this salmon," Quinn told CNN. "If you don't think this is worth saving, what is? If you don't think that (a gold and copper mine) is going to constitute a threat, what would? To me, if you don't draw a line in the sand here, there's none to be drawn anywhere. You're saying that no resource, no matter how valuable, is off-limits to development -- no matter how obviously deleterious."
Quinn's concerns are based on his years researching the bay, which were incorporated into a 2014 EPA report on Bristol Bay under the Obama administration. The report, which also was based on Pebble's filings with the US Securities and Exchange Commission, estimated the total mine site could be larger than Manhattan and nearly as deep as the Grand Canyon.
Such a mine "would result in complete loss of fish habitat due to elimination, dewatering, and fragmentation of streams, wetlands, and other aquatic resources" in some areas of the bay watershed, the EPA found after three years of peer-reviewed research. In particular, the EPA estimated 22 miles of streams and more than 6 square miles of wetlands and other habitats that are important to salmon and other fish would be lost to a large-scale mine.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment: The reversal of protections for Bristol Bay would be devastating to a salmon fishery that sustains thousands of jobs and helps literally and figuratively put food on people's tables. The protection of Bristol Bay from mining operations was planned based on years of careful scientific study. The plans by Mr. Pruitt and the EPA to choose to ignore the agency's mandate to protect the environment in favor of allowing mineral extraction are irresponsible and a dereliction of duty. Mining in Bristol Bay would provide finite resources, while the salmon fishery, if properly managed, is a renewable resource that will benefit Alaskans and consumers for generations to come. Bristol Bay should continue to be protected, and the Pebble Deposit Area should not be allowed to became a dumping ground for mining waste.

Title: Mass comment campaign sponsored by Alaska Wilderness League (web)
Comment:
October 16, 2017

The Honorable Scott Pruitt
Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency
U.S. Environmental Protection Agency
1200 Pennsylvania Ave NW
Washington, DC 20004

Dear Administrator Pruitt, 

I am submitting comments on behalf of Alaska Wilderness League members opposed to the proposed withdrawal of Clean Water Act protections in Bristol Bay, Alaska, by your agency. Some of our nation's most important salmon habitat are found in Bristol Bay, which supports a 1.5 billion dollar fishery and a heavily tourism-dependent economy. The mine developers plan to build an open pit mine, putting at risk fish, wildlife and the livelihoods of people who depend on this area.

Even without a spill, mining the Pebble deposit will destroy 94 miles of salmon streams and more than 5,000 acres of wetlands, lakes, and ponds in the pristine Bristol Bay watershed.

Below please find the letter signed by our members for your consideration.

------------------------------

Dear Administrator Pruitt, 

Don't withdraw Clean Water Act restrictions for Pebble Mine! Bristol Bay provides some of our nation's most important salmon habitat, and Pebble Mine threatens not just the world's most productive sockeye salmon run, but the people, jobs and wildlife thriving in the region.

--------------------------------

Included in the attached files are 12,536 comments and signatures. 

Thank you for considering this public input on Pebble Mine and protecting salmon habitat.

Sincerely, 

Andy Moderow
Alaska State Director
Alaska Wilderness League

Title: Mass comment campaign sponsored by Slow Food USA. Sample attached (web)
Abstract: 119 similar comments have been received for this web campaign
Comment:
Honorable Scott Pruitt, Administrator
US Environmental Protection Agency 

Honorable Michelle L. Pirzadeh, Acting Administrator, Region 10
US Environmental Protection Agency 

RE: Bristol Bay, Alaska/Pebble Mine - Docket: EPA-R10-OW-2017-0369

Dear Administrator Pruitt and Acting Region 10 Administrator Pirzadeh:

I am a supporter of Slow Food USA, the national, not-for-profit organization dedicated to a food chain that is good, clean, and fair for all.  I write to urge the US Environmental Protection Agency to protect Bristol Bay, Alaska, from the Pebble Mine that would threaten the region's irreplaceable fish and wildlife resources and the 14,000 jobs that depend on Bristol Bay's clean, healthy waters and fishery.  EPA must keep in place the 2014 Bristol Bay 404(c) Proposed Determination.

According to EPA study, the Bristol Bay watershed provides vital habitat for 29 fish species, more than 190 bird species, and more than 40 terrestrial animals. All five species of Pacific salmonsockeye, Chinook, coho, chum, and pinkspawn and rear in the pristine Bristol Bay watershed. The Bristol Bay watershed supports the largest sockeye salmon run in the world, producing approximately 46% of the world's wild sockeye harvest, creating $1.5 billion in economic output and nearly 20,000 jobs throughout the United States annually.

EPA's scientific study contains highly concerning facts about the proposed Pebble Mine: even without a mine disaster, exploitation of the Pebble deposit will destroy 94 miles of salmon streams and 5,350 acres of wetlands, lakes, and ponds. Overall, EPA concluded that mining the headwaters of the Bristol Bay river systems could cause irreparable harm to the valuable Bristol Bay fishery, wildlife, and communities.

I stand with more than 65 percent of Alaskans, 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents and Native communities, and 85 percent of commercial fishermen who oppose the Pebble Mine.  Because of its great, ecological, economic, and cultural value, I implore the EPA to stand with us by keeping in place the 404(c) Proposed Determination for Bristol Bay, Southwest Alaska.

Thank you for your attention.

Sincerely,
Anna Maria Sorrentino
PO Box 415
Short Hills, NJ 07078
annamaria@shopwineanddine.com

Title: Mass comment campaign sponsoring organization unknown. Sample attached (web)
Abstract: 9 similar comments have been received for this web campaign
Comment:
Hello, 
 
I am writing to express my deep concern of the EPA's proposal to reverse decisions made during the Obama administration regarding mining in the Bristol Bay region of Alaska. The health of the endemic salmon population needs to be prioritized over the private interests of the Pebble Partnership. Bristol Bay provides about half of the world's catch of sockeye salmon and is one of the last large scale sustainable fisheries in the United States. 
 
According to a recent University of Alaska study, the Bristol Bay fishery is worth 1.5 billion and supports 10,000 auxiliary jobs. If the fishery is continuously managed properly, and is not affected by the potentially devastating impacts of mining activity, the fishery will continue to generate revenue on the scale of billions. While the worth of the minerals may be large in the short run, in contrast to the salmon fishery, the mineral reserve is finite and will soon be depleted. Additionally, the mining activity is projected to generate only 1,000 jobs compared to the 10,00 already supported by the fishery. 
 
The Bristol Bay fishery and Pebble Mine unfortunately cannot co-exist. Mining activities in the area will permanently mar the environment, leading to a collapse of the salmon fishery.
 
Though this is wrongly framed as a partisan issue, the American people need to understand that this should be in everyone's best interest. It is not hard to understand that protecting an established, prolific, renewable resource is paramount compared to catering to a temporary, non-renewable industry. 
 
I implore the EPA to refrain from making a nearsighted decision and to consider the undeniable benefit of prohibiting mining in the Bristol Bay region to protect the long term health of the salmon fishery  

Thank you for reading this comment and taking into account public opinion on this important issue. 
Lauren H.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment submitted by P.  Hammer
Comment:
Greetings,
My name is Payton Hammer and I am a senior at Humboldt State University. I am studying environmental economics and have a minor in Natural Resources and Management Planning. I am commenting on the EPA's decision to withdraw the 2014 proposed determination of the Pebble Mine near the head waters of the Bristol Bay watershed. Proposal to Withdraw Proposed Determination to Restrict the Use of an Area as a Disposal Site; Pebble Deposit Area, Southwest Alaska, 82 Fed. Reg. 44,176 (July 19, 2017). I think that the proposed pebble mine deserves to be able to take all the steps necessary to see if they can go through with this proposed mine, however, I do not support the mine at all and would need substantial evidence from an EIS. The risks are far greater than the benefits and if the EPA approves this project I will be deeply disappointed in the EPA under our current administration.
First, I would like to address that I think Northern Dynasty Minerals does not have the right to go through the Environmental Impact assessment process. The EPA has already struck down the Pebble Mine project under section 404 (c) of the Clean Water Act which restricts any discharges of dredged materials into wetlands or watersheds. The environmental impacts of a mine as large as this is going to have an immense impact on the environment around it. I would also like to comment on the fact that in Alaska there has been strong resistance against the mine from the very beginning. Most Alaskans think the mine is a bad idea and will have adverse economic and environmental effect.
The proposed Pebble Mine is a gross misjudgment that if goes through with the development will result in an environmental, economic and spiritual tragedy. Bristol Bay is a billion dollar fishery that provides over 14,000 full and part time jobs. Bristol bay and the Kvichak and Nushagak Rivers are home to all five of the pacific salmon species and is the only places in the world with a fully functioning salmon based ecosystem. The Kvichak and Nushagak watersheds are home to Native Americans who, like their ancestors whom have lived there for over 4,000 years, live a sustainable way of life based on the annual salmon runs. 
The people of Bristol Bay are dependent on the annual salmon runs either for subsistence or a wage and if the pebble mine is allowed to go through it will have serious consequences on the people. We cannot allow the idea of short term monetary gain win out against one of the sustainable ecosystems in the world.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I am opposed to EPAs proposal to rescind the 2014 Proposed Determination designed to protect Bristol Bays world class fisheries. Please stand with American jobs and communities and preserve the Bristol Bay Proposed Determination.

Bristol Bay, Alaska, is one of America's last great wild salmon fisheries. Each year, tens of millions of wild salmon return, supporting upwards of 14,000 jobs in the commercial and sport fishing industries, as well as in the marketplace that relies on salmon as a healthy staple in our diets, and serving as a one-in-a-lifetime destination for anglers from around the world as well as the cultural cornerstone for the region's communities. These long-established businesses are at risk from a foreign-owned mining company that wants to build the proposed Pebble Mine, which is opposed by more than 65 percent of Alaskans and more than 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents. 

In 2014, led by Alaska Native Tribes, interests including commercial fishing business owners and sportsmen asked the EPA step in to ensure that this mine wouldn't jeopardize Bristol Bay. The EPA responded by listening to over 1.5 million Americans, hosting dozens of community meetings, reviewing Pebble's many detailed filings with state and federal agencies, and conducting a twice peer-reviewed scientific assessment of the potential impacts to the region. Withdrawing the proposed determination ignores the overwhelming majority of Alaskans and puts the short-term interests of a foreign mining company above thousands of local jobs. Surely the wants and needs of the many outstep that of the few mega corporations who would deface this important resource area.

For the sake of our wildlife, waterways, and communities, I urge you to protect Bristol Bay and prevent this horrible open-pit mine from destroying one of our nation's most precious ecosystems.

For the sake of our wildlife, waterways, and communities, I urge you to protect Bristol Bay and prevent this horrible open-pit mine from destroying one of our nation's most precious ecosystems.
I don't believe a few people should be able to drastically effect what the majority of Americans can opposed to ---just to line the pockets of themselves and a few of their "friends". It's shameful.
