Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment: The Pebble Mine has been an intensely controversial topic here in Alaska for years, and that isn't likely to change, but withdrawing this rule as yet another way to dismantle the Obama administration's legacy is not the way to fix it. It's becoming increasingly obvious that our economy can't continue to rely on nonrenewable resources like oil or the proposed Pebble mines, which means that for Alaska's economy to survive, we have to place a higher value on renewable resources like salmon even if the short-term payout from mining seems higher (although that itself is debatable). I work at the Alaska Dept. of Fish & Game, so I see every day how important both commercial and sport fisheries are to Alaskans across the state; commercial fishing is a major part of our economy, many Alaskans rely on subsistence fishing, and our fisheries are a cornerstone of our equally important tourism economy. Risking the destruction of a key fishery for short-term mining gains--against the wishes of Alaska Natives who have lived there for centuries, at that--is short-sighed and irresponsible.

Do not withdraw the EPA Region 10 July 2016 Proposed Determination that was issued pursuant of the Clean Water Act. This Determination offers protection for waters of the United States in the South Fork Koktuli River, North Fork Koktuli River and Upper Talarick Creek. These rivers, and indeed any waters of the United States should never be considered as disposal sites for dredged or fill materials of any kind, much less material associated with mining. 

These comments are submitted in regards Docket ID No. EPA-R10-OW-2017-0369, refer to section I.C. of the SUPPLEMENTARY INFORMATION. I support wholeheartedly the July 21, 2014, EPA Region 10 Federal Register (79 FR 42314) Notice of Proposed Determination under section 404(c) of the Clean Water Act (CWA). This restriction protects valuable waters of United States and protects the well being of the People of the United States. You are directed to restrict the use of the waters in the South Fork Koktuli River, North Fork Koktuli River, and Upper Talarik Creek watersheds (located within the larger Bristol Bay watershed) and prevent the disposal of fill dredged or associated with mining the Pebble deposit. Your failure to protect these waters would be a serious dereliction of your duties.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I am an Alaskan, a physician, and though I am not a lawyer, I do hold a Management degree.  One thing that I think is overlooked here, aside from the non-zero possibility of destroying one of Alaska's most important resources, is the almost certainty of destroying or diminishing Alaska's brand.

To most people, Alaska is synonymous with wild, natural, and pristine.  The branding of many products is based on this, from Wild Alaskan Salmon to Alaskan Adventure Cruises, promising products and services from an untouched and untarnished last frontier.  The unique thing about a brand is that it can be diminished by the perception of the consumer, even if no actual change in the product has occurred.  Whatever the risks of mining in Bristol Bay are - small or large - we can all agree that there is no such thing as a zero risk.  Just the perception that there may be some small chance of contamination from the mine is antithetical to the natural and pristine qualities that the Alaska brand is built on.  Especially in such a highly public ruling, creation of Pebble Mine - even without a catastrophic spill - could therefore diminish the value of all products and services that rely on Alaska's reputation and branding for their commercial worth.  A good example is the ripple effects from the Exxon Valdez spill - it was not just commerce in the Prince William Sound that was effected, but many others were harmed as well from the perception of that contamination.  

Who owns the Alaska brand is another parallel question - one could argue it is the state, or all the people in the state (the majority of which are opposed to the mine), but I think there also could be a strong argument that the original owners are the Alaska Native population - and obviously the vast majority of Native organizations oppose the construction of Pebble Mine.

My family is originally from Butte, Montana, a current Superfund site and previous copper mining town.  It was, briefly, one of the richest cities in the state because of the mine.  Now, it has had an incredibly depressed economy for many many years.  The mine site (Berkeley Pit) has left behind an uncleanable pool of perpetual water so toxic that every couple years a migrating flock of geese land in it and then die by the hundreds, their bodies dropping all over town.  Even if there is a 1:1,000,000 chance of that happening in Bristol Bay, it would be a catastrophe that would never be repairable - or forgivable.

Please, do not trade the identity of an entire state and multiple cultures for the possibility of big profits and 1,000 temporary jobs.

And may I add, why is the head of the EPA, Pruitt, letting a mining company decide what happens in this Bay.  The people of Alaska and the U.S. want this Bay protected.  The people of America want Pruitt to stop trying to destroy every good thing President Obama did to protect our air, land and water and the beauty that is America.  

PROTECT BRISTOL BAY!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
Please do NOT allow the withdrawal of Clean Water Act restrictions on the Pebble Mining Deposit. 

The fishery, in addition to supporting many jobs and the local economy, is worth untold amounts in ecosystem services. The salmon are vital to tribal traditions and provide food to many people. 

Tourism, a vital part of the local economy, would be greatly damaged. Having lived in Butte, Montana, the home of the largest Superfund site, I can personally attest to how mining (and a view of the mine's remains - sickly yellow strip-mined terraces of destroyed earth) keep tourists from visiting the area.

The proposed mine would provide jobs for a VERY SHORT time but its detrimental effects would be long-lasting. Please do NOT prioritize short-term gain over long-term environmental impacts, which will no doubt cost far more to clean up than the mine will make in profits! Destroying the way of life for many people and the fishery for decades to come is not worth it! 

Look at the costs of mining in Lake Superior - I recommend Nancy Langston's book "Sustaining Lake Superior" for an in-depth examination of mining's effects on the lake and fishery. We should not repeat the mistakes of the past.

Do NOT allow the withdrawal of the Clean Water Act restrictions on the Pebble Mining Deposit!

Dear Sirs:

I strongly oppose a mining presence in Bristol Bay. Title: Comment submitted by R. Haley
Comment:
Dear EPA,

I am writing to urge you to retain the current regulations restricting the use of rivers in the area of the proposed Pebble Mine.  This mine is an extremely bad idea, situated at the headwaters of the most important salmon fishery in the world.  The Bristol Bay salmon fishery employs thousands and those fish are vitally important to local wildlife as well.  And the mine itself would destroy a pristine area which should be protected.

All mines have the potential for disaster (e.g. the recent Mt. Polley mine disaster in British Columbia).  A disaster in the Pebble deposit area would destroy the last great salmon fishery on the planet.  

Please do not put short term profits of the mine owners ahead of ecological integrity, a robust salmon fishery, and the thousands of people who depend on it for their livelihood.  The Pebble Mine is a terrible idea and should not be allowed to proceed.

Sincerely,

Rick Haley
Anacortes, WA

Title: Comment submitted by D. D. Houston
Comment:
October 10, 2017

Administer E. Scott Pruitt

Dear Administrator Pruitt,

It would be a mistake to jeopardize one of the last pristine salmon fisheries for the short term gains of allowing a copper mine to operate in the area. This mine would very likely create a new Superfund site that would cost tax payers millions of dollars. Not worth it!

Rigorous scientific study over the course of many years show clearly that the mine will negatively impact the area. Local communities are against it, including many of Alaskas indigenous people. This would directly impact their heritage and local economy. Salmon, if managed properly, are a renewable resource. Putting the short-term gains of mining a non-renewable resource ahead of a fishery that would continue to produce long after the copper deposits have been extracted and all thats left is the toxic waste. 

The EPA has already determined that the Pebble Mine would have significant and adverse effects on this pristine salmon fishery. The EPA has already considered the contributions of this salmon fishery on the local economy, with direct sales generating ~$300 million annually, and creating 11,000 jobs, many of which are held by Alaskan Natives. The EPA should continue to protect the Bristol Bay watershed and preserve this fishery.

Sincerely,

Derek D. Houston, PhD
700 N 11th St Unit A1
Gunnison, CO 81230

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment: Restrictions against the possiblilty that Pebble Mine will be allowed to pollute the Bristol Bay Area must be upheld. Too many people and kinds of wildlife depend on the salmon run that moves through it.  If Pebble Mine is allowed a permit, then deadly pollutants will enter this pristine water and the salmon will be affected. Everyone and everything that uses the salmon for sustenance will be affected, if indeed there are any salmon left in a few years. The Native Alaskans harvest these fish for consumption and depend on them for food for the winter. How can you risk eliminating that?  The bears, wolves, lynx, martens, minks, wolverines, eagles, and many other species depend on the salmon to make it through hibernation and the harsh winter climate. Bears like the ones in the family picture attached will likely not have enough to eat to survive the winter. They must have a voice in this decision! The very eco system depends on the salmon for its rich nutrients in the soil of the land there. We have simply got to protect this fragile environment from being mined. Devastation would result. Please do not take away the restrictions that prevent the Pebble Mine fiasco. Thank you.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
Dear President Trump, Administrator Pruitt, and Acting Region 10 Administrator Pirzadeh:

I am writing to express my deep concern and disappointment with the EPA's plan to to reverse course and green-light the proposed Pebble Mine, despite the catastrophic risks it poses to Alaska's Bristol Bay watershed, its world-renowned salmon runs, and its Native communities. 

I was fortunate enough to spend three years as a resident of Bristol Bay. I worked as a legal aid attorney in Dillingham and traveled throughout the region to meet with clients in every one of the Alaska Native villages. To say this region is unique is an understatement of staggering proportion. Bristol Bay, especially the regions surrounding the Nushagak and Kvichak Rivers, is the most pristine and painfully breathtaking place I have ever been. It is also the most productive salmon ecosystem in North America, and it is unmatched in its productivity. All five species of Pacific salmonsockeye, Chinook, coho, chum, and pinkspawn and rear in the Bristol Bay watershed, supporting wildlife like brown bears and eagles, as well as human industry and culture. The watershed supports the largest sockeye salmon run in the world, producing about 46% of the world's wild sockeye harvest. It generates $1.5 billion a year and provides nearly 20,000 jobs throughout the United States annually. Over 4,000 locals, including many native Yup'ik and Dena'ina, rely on fish, moose, and other subsistence foods for 80% of their protein. 

In the Spring of 2012 I traveled to Kokhanok, Igiugig, and Iliamna. I saw the location of Pebble's proposed mine and there is no way that a mine in this area, right near the headwaters of the two greatest salmon-producing rivers in North America, will result in anything less than complete destruction of the fishery. Whether it happens in year one or year five, something will go wrong and when it does, there's no turning back. And even if everything goes right, the inevitable consequences of large scale mining on an ecosystem are incompatible with marine life. Salmon are extremely sensitive to their environment and the smallest increase in water temperature, pH or turbidity can be catastrophic.  

In addition to the inevitable decimation of the salmon population, if a mine is allowed to proceed in this region, there will be similar consequences for the human population. When the Pebble people came into Bristol Bay, it was like a cancer. They started buying off communities and stakeholders in an attempt to gain favor, while all the while planning to rob them of their most valued resource - their fish. Pebble doesn't care about the lives of Alaska Natives, it only cares about profits and when the profits dry up, they will pull out of the region and leave behind a mess that's impossible to clean up. 

President Obama's Environmental Protection Agency proposed common-sense restrictions that would have banned this dangerous mine because of the obvious environmental risks it would pose. The EPA's recent settlement with Northern Dynasty Minerals to reverse those common-sense restrictions is a blatant giveaway to the mining industry at the expense of the American people, our environment, and our economy.

More than 65 percent of Alaskans, 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents and Native communities, and 85 percent of commercial fishermen oppose the mine.

I urge you to listen to those voices, and for the sake of the Bristol Bay watershed, its world-class salmon fishery, and its people, keep the door closed on Pebble Mine. If you don't, you will have to answer to me and hundreds of thousands of people in Alaska and across the United States and the world who stand in fervent opposition to this toxic mega-mine.

Title: Mass comment campaign sponsoring organization unknown. Sample attached (web)
Abstract: 113 similar comments have been received to date for this web campaign. Comment mentions docket ORD-2012-0276 but it's intended for this docket.
Comment:
Dear Administrator, 

I'm writing in reference to Docket # EPA-HQ-ORD-2012-0276. Please prohibit the disposal of mine waste in Alaska's Bristol Bay watershed. The proposed Pebble Mine presents a long-term risk to the sustainability of this important fishery, and all the people and businesses that rely on it. In 2010, Bristol Bay salmon fishermen harvested 29 million sockeye salmon worth $165 million in direct harvest value alone. That represented 31% of the total Alaska salmon harvest value.

Many families rely on wild salmon as a uniquely nutritious source of protein, rich in essential omega-3 fats and vitamin D. Farmed salmon is not nutritionally identical (much lower in vitamin D, much higher in saturated fats and pro-inflammatory omega-6 fats) and poses its own environmental risks. I urge the EPA to take immediate action to use existing provisions of the Clean Water Act to protect this large and irreplaceable wild salmon fishery. 

Sincerely, 
Piper Gordon
#13-103 Wilson Street
Victoria, BC V9A 6X1

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I am opposed to EPAs proposal to rescind the 2014 Proposed Determination designed to protect Bristol Bays world class fisheries. Please stand with American jobs and communities and preserve the Bristol Bay Proposed Determination.

Bristol Bay, Alaska, is one of America's last great wild salmon fisheries. Each year, tens of millions of wild salmon return, supporting upwards of 14,000 jobs in the commercial and sport fishing industries, and serving as a one-in-a-lifetime destination for anglers from around the world as well as the cultural cornerstone for the region's communities. These long-established businesses are at risk from a foreign-owned mining company that wants to build the proposed Pebble Mine, which is opposed by more than 65 percent of Alaskans and more than 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents. 

In 2014, led by Alaska Native Tribes, interests including commercial fishing business owners and sportsmen asked the EPA step in to ensure that this mine wouldn't jeopardize Bristol Bay. The EPA responded by listening to over 1.5 million Americans, hosting dozens of community meetings, reviewing Pebble's many detailed filings with state and federal agencies, and conducting a twice peer-reviewed scientific assessment of the potential impacts to the region. Withdrawing the proposed determination ignores the overwhelming majority of Alaskans and puts the short-term interests of a foreign mining company above thousands of local jobs. 

For the sake of our wildlife, waterways, and communities, I urge you to protect Bristol Bay and prevent this horrible open-pit mine from destroying one of our nation's most precious ecosystems. When will you learn that there are more important concerns in life than exploitation of our precious environment for the sake of profits?

These long-established businesses are at risk from a foreign-owned mining company that wants to build the proposed Pebble Mine, which is opposed by more than 65 percent of Alaskans and more than 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents. 

In 2014, led by Alaska Native Tribes, interests including commercial fishing business owners and sportsmen asked the EPA step in to ensure that this mine wouldn't jeopardize Bristol Bay. The EPA responded by listening to over 1.5 million Americans, hosting dozens of community meetings, reviewing Pebble's many detailed filings with state and federal agencies, and conducting a twice peer-reviewed scientific assessment of the potential impacts to the region. Withdrawing the proposed determination ignores the overwhelming majority of Alaskans and puts the short-term interests of a foreign mining company above thousands of local jobs. 

For the sake of our wildlife, waterways, and communities, I urge you to protect Bristol Bay and prevent this horrible open-pit mine from destroying one of our nation's most precious ecosystems.

These long-established businesses are at risk from a foreign-owned mining company that wants to build the proposed Pebble Mine, which is opposed by more than 65 percent of Alaskans and more than 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents. 

In 2014, led by Alaska Native Tribes, interests including commercial fishing business owners and sportsmen asked the EPA step in to ensure that this mine wouldn't jeopardize Bristol Bay. The EPA responded by listening to over 1.5 million Americans, hosting dozens of community meetings, reviewing Pebble's many detailed filings with state and federal agencies, and conducting a twice peer-reviewed scientific assessment of the potential impacts to the region. Withdrawing the proposed determination ignores the overwhelming majority of Alaskans and puts the short-term interests of a foreign mining company above thousands of local jobs. 

For the sake of our wildlife, waterways, and communities, I urge you to protect Bristol Bay and prevent this horrible open-pit mine from destroying one of our nation's most precious ecosystems.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment: I believe that the decision to restrict the use of certain waters in the South Fork Koktuli River, North Fork Koktuli River, and Upper Talarik Creek watersheds (located within the larger Bristol Bay watershed) as disposal sites for dredged or fill material associated with mining the Pebble deposit was the correct decision and the only way to insure the protection of the fisheries associated with Bristol Bay. The long term sustainability of the fishery is much more valuable to the region than allowing the mining of gold and copper and all the environmental devastation that comes with it. The decision published on July 21, 2014 is well supported and vetted. This attempt to undo that is serving special interests and is an unreasonable action trying to reverse environmental protections, which is the EPA's job,  in favor of mining operations that are not sustainable and only will only benefit a few. With the state of the Pacific salmon species and the fact that gold and copper aren't threatened in the way these salmon are, some choices need to be made. For the greater good, protecting Bristol Bay and from mining activities is the right thing to do. I also feel it is important for First Nations people to have their historical fisheries intact.  I say do not withdraw this action and let it stand.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment: As you know, Bristol Bay is one of the most pristine areas of Alaska and home to the most valuable salmon fishery in the world. It supports half the world's supply of salmon, thousands of jobs, and several indigenous cultures. To risk all of this for the sake of mining, it unconscionable. The fact that Scott Pruitt is even considering it speaks to the corruption the man has brought to the EPA and his lack of support for the environment in general. The 2014 decision to protect this area indefinitely was made after years of scientific review and these protections should not be removed at the whim of one man who has shown repeatedly he places the interest of fossil fuel and big companies before the integrity of our environment. Although you might argue that he is just allowing permits to be submitted, we all know that the current administration cannot be trusted to follow the advice of the people charged with reviewing those permits. This area is too important to risk! Please do not allow these permit filings to go forward!

Title: Comment submitted by T. P. Hammond
Comment:
To Whom It May Concern,
I am strongly opposed to the proposed withdrawal of the Proposed Determination to Restrict Use for the Pebble Partnership.
Application of the Clean Water Act is appropriate for the watershed(s) of Bristol Bay, as evidenced by the extensive scientific and social research that went in to to decision to prevent the development of the Pebble Mine.
Bristol Bay represents the largest salmon fishery in the United States, and provides thousands of jobs across the entire region.  Fishing fleets based as far away as Seattle and throughout southeast Alaska provide SUSTAINABLE jobs directly and indirectly through manufacturing, maintenance and support of the fishery.  These jobs are not "boom and bust" as are mining jobs--the fishery jobs are generational, promising employment decade after decade.  As well, the fish themselves provide food for millions of people across the world, most notably in the United States.
Meanwhile, mining has a tragic and terrible environmental record, leaving vast areas contaminated, always leaving taxpayers to pay the bills for "cleanup" long after the minerals are taken and the mining companies have left.  Every mine, even in modern history has resulted in significant environmental degradation that taxpayers, not the mining companies have to pay to mitigate (note:  not clean up since it is impossible to clean up such material/sites).  Factor in that many foreign companies come to the United States, take billions of dollars worth of minerals and pay pennies on the millions as "royalties" and this is a terrible "lose-lose" for the taxpayers and citizens of the United States.
Do NOT ALLOW PEBBLE MINE.
Thanks for the opportunity to comment.
Sincerely, 

Thomas P Hammond
2010 NE 96th Street
Seattle, WA 98115
(206) 685-6203
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment submitted by R. Temple
Comment:
To Whom It May Concern: 


My name is Reba Temple and I live in Homer, Alaska. I am a third generation Alaskan fisherman and started fishing with my family in Bristol Bay in 2004. I now have my own operation and hope to continue fishing with my children and grandchildren for years to come. After spending every summer in Bristol Bay since 2004, I can truly say there is nowhere else in Alaska that holds such a special place in my heart. 

Salmon continue to return each summer to the headwaters of Bristol Bay due to the fact that the waters are so pristine. This is something that is increasingly rare in today's world, as we see run after run of salmon failing as their natal streams are compromised. The salmon that return to Bristol Bay each summer provide for the animals of the region. They provide for the subsistence ways of life of the Yup'ik, Dena'ina, and Alutiq indigenous peoples of the region. They provide for the economy, as over 14,000 people come to the region to harvest salmon and support the fishing industry each summer. This is last great salmon run in the world and we must not take any chances with it. 

Putting a mine, of any size, at the headwaters of Bristol Bay is putting the well-being of these animals, locals, and fishermen who depend on the fishery in danger. But most importantly, we are gambling with the future of the salmon. We must not put them in harm's way. We must preserve the pristine waters that have existed in Bristol Bay for thousands of years. Please listen to the people of Alaska. There is nothing that Alaskans value more than clean water and healthy salmon. Please do not withdraw or rescind the Proposed Determination for Docket EPA-R10-OW-2017-0369. Instead, please finalize the protections for the last great wild-sockeye salmon fishery on the planet.

Sincerely, 




Reba Temple
rebamaetemple@gmail.com
488 Elderberry Drive
Homer, AK 99603
(907) 399-3776
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment submitted by C. Laben
Comment:
Mr. Pruitt,

No doubt a great many people have already pointed out to you the utter foolishness of withdrawing protection from the Pebble Deposit Area from a scientific and humanitarian standpoint. Endangering a vital cultural heritage and one of the finest remaining salmon runs in the world is clearly a violation of the EPA's mission and trust. But while you may wish to justify your decision on economic grounds, it is also foolish in that regard. Providing a handful of jobs, mostly temporary, and benefiting a single mining company cannot provide the same level of long-term economic reward as maintaining a unique, renewable natural resource, especially in a world where overfishing and ongoing oceanic pollution are likely to raise the demand on remaining wild fish stocks.

Moreover, you are part of an administration that promised to cut government waste and cronyism. Every time a permit is filed with regard to mining in this area and has to be denied (see utter foolishness from a scientific standpoint, above) that is simply useless time spent spinning the wheels of government employees, wasting money. Since, from any logical standpoint, every permit for this are should and must be denied, far better that they are never filed in the first place.

Please do the sensible thing and retain the existing protections for this area.

- Carrie Laben
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment submitted by T. Branch
Comment:
As a professor of aquatic and fishery sciences at the University of Washington, I am appalled at the process that led to this reversal. A short meeting with the CEO of the Pebble Mine company leads the head of the EPA to reverse years of science-based decision making (see story here: http://www.cnn.com/2017/10/10/politics/bristol-bay-salmon-invs/index.html). It is clear that the reversal has nothing to do with the carefully thought out process, with the goal of the EPA, or with any consideration of weighting of industrial development vs. effects on ecosystems and fisheries.

Bristol Bay is the last major pristine salmon habitat left in North America, and supports the most valuable salmon fishery in the world, worth in excess of $400 million a year, in addition to substantial native Alaskan traditions and sustenance. It deserves more than this. 

Prof. Trevor Branch
University of Washington

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment: The pebble deposit area is home to one of the most economically sustainable salmon fisheries in the world. Introducing mining to this area will be detrimental to both the fisheries and the local economy. Pebble Deposit mining will create significantly fewer jobs than the Bristol Bay salmon fishery will lose due to pollution of of the waterways and poisoning of the salmon and their breeding habitat due to mining run-off and slag. The economics do not add up. And while the salmon fisheries tend to be locally run operated, keeping the economic benefits local, the Pebble Deposit area mining rights are owned by a foreign entity that has no interest in sustain local economies. The continued health of the fishery is more important to American economic interests than mining the Pebble Deposit area. Withdrawal of protections for the Pebble Deposit area does not serve American interests, only foreign interests. Do not withdraw protections that this incredibly important fishery relies upon to sustain itself and to grow.

The 2014 Clean Water Act had bipartisan input with a long process of review and has benefited citizens' health, economic growth, and accommodated mining and maintaining clean water. Profits are important and so is CLEAN WATER. Our natural, limited resource of water must be protected.

Title: Comment submitted by J. Taylor
Comment:
Administrator E. Scott Pruitt

Dear Administrator Pruitt, 

It's unfortunate that science is ignored once gain.  In 2010, the Environmental Protection Agency, then under more credible leadership, took on a rigorous, peer-reviewed scientific study of the proposal for the Bristol Bay watershed, concluding that the proposed mine would have unacceptable adverse effects on the rich salmon fishery. After completing this study, the EPA in 2014 proposed new restrictions needed to protect the habitat. This is not a case of "excessive regulation". This is minimal support of a vital ecosystem. Please do not allow the mining to move forward. I write in support of the communities of Alaska's Bristol Bay and ask you not to withdraw the proposed determination to adopt restrictions protecting the habitat of Bristol Bay's world-renowned salmon. The proposed determination was made at the request of local communities and adopted only after years of rigorous scientific study, public participation and peer review. 

The EPA was correct in 2014 when it found that the Pebble Mine would have "significant and unacceptable adverse effects" on "one of the most productive, pristine, valuable and vulnerable ecosystems remaining in North America today." The EPA has noted that commercial fishing in Bristol Bay generates $300 million annually in direct sales of commercially caught salmon, generating 11,000 jobs. These salmon support not only the commercial and sportfishing industries, but a traditional Native way of life that has endured for millennia and thrives today. The EPA should stand by its proposed determination and take all necessary actions to protect the Bristol Bay watershed. 

Regards,

Jessica Taylor
13360 Burbank Blvd. #19
Sherman Oaks, CA 91401
626-318-1492

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment: I'm writing to urge the EPA not to allow for permit applications by Pebble Limited Partnership or any other company to mine or store waste in any part of the Bristol Bay region. This area is an extremely ecologically important site for wild sockeye salmon reproduction, and as such culturally important for many indigenous people as well. The area also engenders a vast fish resource. The EPA itself, while steered by a more honest hand in 2014, estimated total irreversible loss of fish habitat in miles of streams and huge tracts of wetlands, devastating to this vital fish hatchery. Moreover, experts fear that the porous substrate in bristol bay would not allow a dam to hold toxic waste away from the surrounding ecosystem for long. This would be a glaring example of a reusable resource being obliterated to fill the coffers of an extractive resource company, with blatant disregard for native culture and ecological diversity. The EPA was formed to PROTECT the environment, not sell it to the highest bidder.

Title: Comment submitted by D. B. de Treville
Comment:
I beg you not to withdraw the 2014 Clean Water Act Proposed Determination.

I strongly agree with restrictions on the discharge of dredged or fill material from the potential mining of the Pebble deposit in Alaska's Bristol Bay watershed. I strongly disagree with the 2017 Proposal to Withdraw Proposed Clean Water Act Restrictions on Mining Pebble Deposit

It is unquestionable, that each and every marine and aquatic habitat is extremely sensitive to changes caused by the actions involved in human industrial endeavor. We can now see massive plastic islands growing in the oceans through our species thoughtlessness and how the resulting plastic micro- & nano-particulates are appearing throughout the marine food chain, which will severely affect our ability to consume fish safely.

By placing dredged or fill material from mining into Alaska's Bristol Bay watershed, we would be placing an insurmountable challenge to the life cycle of salmon, which already have long odds against them, from one of the most arduous reproductive cycles of any species.

I love wild salmon. By dumping dredged or fill material from mining into Alaska's Bristol Bay watershed, you may temporarily be able to enjoy higher salmon prices, as the ability of the species to survive is impeded, but not only would I no longer be able to afford to buy wild salmon, the wild salmon industry would slowly dwindle and die with the species.

It isn't merely my diet which would be affected but, as with all intertwined and interdependent ecosystems, many other species would suffer from the loss of salmon as a food source. We cannot derive much nutrition from mined products, nor would bears try to scrape up the ground for a tasty bit soil. Salmon helps them put on the fat they need to survive the winter. When you kill off salmon, you are writing off the bears, too, in addition to the tribal/native populace which has relied upon wild salmon as a food source for thousands of years.

This is another instance where, "Let them eat cake!" won't be very appropriate, as species dependent upon salmon, both marine and on land, would suffer greatly at the loss.

I beg you once again, not to withdraw the 2014 Clean Water Act Proposed Determination.

Sincerely,

D. B. de Treville

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
It is vitally important that the EPA protects the Bristol Bay environment and ecosystems. Withdrawing the 2014 protections for the region would result in devastating environmental and economic losses. If the concept of environmental protection isn't a strong enough motivator, then please at least consider the economic impact: this region is home to half of the world's Sockeye salmon fishery population. Sockeye salmon is a common product sold in grocery stores across the USA, and the Bristol Bay fishery is one of the most valuable salmon fisheries worldwide. The Bristol Bay region produces approximately half of the world's Sockeye salmon, and this salmon is distributed nationwide in the US. Here are some facts from a 2013 study for the Bristol Bay Regional Seafood Development Association:

"In 2010, Bristol Bay salmon fishermen harvested 29 million sockeye salmon worth $165 million in direct
harvest value alone. That represented 31% of the total Alaska salmon harvest value, and was greater
than the total value of fish harvests in 41 states. Salmon processing in Bristol Bay increased the value by
$225 million, for a total first wholesale value after processing of $390 million. The total value of Bristol
Bay salmon product exports in 2010 was about $250 million, or about 6% of the total value of all U.S.
seafood exports."

With fisheries worldwide in rapid depletion, is the economic value of withdrawing the 2014 protections really worth destroying a valuable and irreplaceable fishery? Is it worth the risk to the USA's seafood supply?
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
Please do not withdraw the proposed determination. If the proposed determination is withdrawn, please review the decision as a separate and distinct action, not just as an administrative add-on. Withdrawing the proposed determination does not put America First. The salmon fishery in this watershed is a great American example of sustainable resource extraction, a win-win for America. A mine of any size or design would place this resource in jeopardy, for a short-term gain that does NOT Make America Great Again. It's a foreign-owned mining company. 

I question whether the administrator even has the authority to pull the agency's earlier findings. EPA is charged with implementing the Clean Water Act. It did so by enacting 404(c) under the rule of law. How can it now step away from that legal process? It is not a fair way to do regulation, to interrupt due process at the administrator's discretion.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
The use of this site as a dumping ground for mining waste would would be an environmental and economic mistake, and would set an extremely dangerous precedent for the use of our natural resources in the future. 

Nearly half of the world's sockeye catch comes from this one region, leaving aside the other fish, marine mammals, and other marine life in this region. According to CNN (http://www.cnn.com/2017/10/10/politics/bristol-bay-salmon-invs/index.html), the returning salmon and other ecological resources create some 14,000 full- and part-time jobs, generate about $480 million annually, and support 4,000-year-old Alaska Native cultures. 

As a US citizen who grew up in the Pacific Northwest, I am strongly against the use of our marine ecosystem as a dumping ground. My neighborhood in Seattle has a strong history with the fishing industry, and to this day our economy is tightly tied to the fishing boats that come and go from our port up into the Alaskan waters every year. This decision would not just affect US citizens in Alaska; it would affect the entire region, and it would be a terribly short-sighted decision to risk our economy and our natural resources for such a purpose, and an irreversible loss for the United States. Please do NOT allow this to happen.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I aware Scott Pruit does not care about the environment, that is why he was appointed to this position, to dismantle the agency and advance the profits of his benefactors. Despite this obvious issue of this being a hostage agency, I wish to object in some likely fruitless way to an uncaring excuse for a human being. Perhaps if business is your only angle then that will be appealing enough. However I'm sure that it's only businesses that benefit you and your friends directly that are of concern. 

 In 2010, Bristol Bay salmon fishermen harvested 29 million sockeye salmon worth $165 million in direct harvest value alone. That represented 31% of the total Alaska salmon harvest value, and was greater than the total value of fish harvests in 41 states. Salmon processing in Bristol Bay increased the value by $225 million, for a total first wholesale value after processing of $390 million. The total value of Bristol Bay salmon product exports in 2010 was about $250 million, or about 6% of the total value of all U.S. seafood exports. 

The proposed determination was made at the request of local communities and adopted only after years of rigorous scientific study, public participation and peer review. The EPA was correct in 2014 when it found that the Pebble Mine would have "significant and unacceptable adverse effects" on "one of the most productive, pristine, valuable and vulnerable ecosystems remaining in North America today."

The EPA has noted that commercial fishing in Bristol Bay generates $300 million annually in direct sales of commercially caught salmon, generating 11,000 jobs. These salmon support not only the commercial and sport-fishing industries, but a traditional Native way of life that has endured for millennia and thrives today. The EPA should stand by its proposed determination and take all necessary actions to protect the Bristol Bay watershed.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
Bristol Bay must remain free of mines and mining activity. 

Those waters are home to fully half of the world's sockeye salmon population; these fish are hugely valuable as an economic resource (sockeye roe and flesh being among some of the most highly-prized of salmon products), and as a social resource. Native peoples rely on salmon for cultural cohesion and food; their cultures rely on the salmon, for food and for spiritual importance. 
Non-Native peoples hold thousands of jobs in the fisheries and the canneries, processing the wealth of the salmon for distribution. Thousands of human lives and jobs rely on these fish being able to come back year after year after year to their traditional grounds; these grounds must be protected. 

Additionally, sockeye are an immensely-important piece of the ecosystem. These animals form a fundamental link between the land and the ocean, transferring oceanic nutrients onto land. If you care at all for the forests, and the game animals that live within those forests, salmon must be protected; without the sockeye runs, the amount of life in the area will decrease a thousandfold. 

Hatcheries will not be able to make up the difference in salmon stocks if Bristol Bay is lost; I promise you this as a veteran of PSWAC's Main Bay Hatchery, the United States' gold-standard sockeye hatchery. Half of the world's sockeye are found here; we will all suffer if Bristol Bay is no longer able to sustain a salmon population. 

So long as there are salmon in the Bay, there will always be jobs. Mines will run dry, and will run out. If their environment is protected and taken care of, salmon are infinite. If their spawning grounds are clean, and cold, and free of dams, salmon will always come back. There will always be jobs in the harvest and the canning, jobs enough for thousands of people, with enough fish left over for subsistence fishing. 

We need sockeye salmon. We need Bristol Bay. We need clean water and fish more than we will ever need mines.

Title: Comment submitted by N. Harvey
Comment:
Dear Administrator,

I'm writing in reference to Docket # EPA-HQ-ORD-2012-0276. Please prohibit the disposal of mine waste in Alaska's Bristol Bay watershed. The proposed Pebble Mine presents a long-term risk to the sustainability of this important fishery, and all the people and businesses that rely on it. In 2010, Bristol Bay salmon fishermen harvested 29 million sockeye salmon worth $165 million in direct harvest value alone. That represented 31% of the total Alaska salmon harvest value.

Many families rely on wild salmon as a uniquely nutritious source of protein, rich in essential omega-3 fats and vitamin D. Farmed salmon is not nutritionally identical (much lower in vitamin D, much higher in saturated fats and pro-inflammatory omega-6 fats) and poses its own environmental risks.  Such environmental risks include ecosystem deconstruction and decay from the significant loss of the salmon population.  

I urge the EPA to take immediate action to use existing provisions of the Clean Water Act to protect this large and irreplaceable wild salmon fishery.

Sincerely, 

Norma-Jean Harvey, Alberta, Canada

Title: Comment submitted by R. Mullins
Comment:
Dear Administrator, 

I'm writing concerning Docket # EPA-HQ-ORD-2012-0276. Please prohibit the disposal of mine waste in Alaska's Bristol Bay watershed. The risk posed by the proposed Pebble Mine cannot be ignored. It would endanger the sustainability of this essential fishery long-term. Bristol Bay represented 31% of the total Alaska salmon harvest in 2010--that was $165 million direct harvest value in sockeye salmon. 

Salmon is known to be a healthy source of protein, vitamin D, and omega-3 fats (essential for brain and eye development in children, and linked to numerous health benefits for people of all ages). Farmed salmon is a poor substitute for wild salmon, with lower concentrations of vitamins and omega-3s and higher concentrations of saturated fats and unhealthy omega-6s. Farmed salmon also poses massive environmental risks. This is why sustainable fisheries are so important--they represent a valuable, healthy food source that we can't mimic with farmed fish.

I urge the EPA most strongly to take immediate action, and use the existing provisions of the Clean Water Act to protect this large, irreplaceable wild salmon fishery.

Sincerely, 

Regina Mullins
1216 Delham Rd
Knightdale, NC 27545

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I oppose this proposal to withdraw these restrictions. 

The region in question, Bristol Bay, is one of the largest spawning grounds for sockeye salmon in the world. And it supports the largest salmon fishery still in existence. Over 10,000 fisherman make a living providing almost half of the world's sockeye salmon harvest. Almost all of America's Pacific salmon populations have collapsed recently and are in danger of local extinction - this is the last great salmon fishery left.

To allow a mine - one run by a foreign company - to be built in this area will irreversibly destroy over six square miles of important fish habitat, not to mention the inevitable pollution of the remaining waterways by runoff. This will kill off the salmon, topple the local fishing industry, and destroy thousands of jobs. The mine would employ less than one tenth the amount of people who would lose jobs without the salmon. It would harm job growth.

Removing protections of this area to allow the construction of a mine will gravely endanger sockeye salmon, topple the local ecosystem, and destroy thousands of fishing jobs. It is detrimental to both the environment and the economy. I urge you to keep them in place.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
Bristol Bay is a wilderness area that not only supports some of the last true wild salmon stocks, but also is the root of indigenous culture and livelihoods. To develop surrounding area into a mine (1) perpetuates the constant devaluation of indigenous people, (2) disregards the importance of the Bristol Bay ecosystem, (3) emphasizes finite gain over sustainable incomes and jobs, (4) imposes corporate interests over the interests of the community at large, and (5) reminds the American public that our government prefers industrial development over environmental protection, despite comparable benefits.

(1) Building this mine and its associated processing facilities destroys the livelihoods and cultural traditions of the Yupik people and other indigenous groups that rely on the salmon and general well-being of the ecosystem. We have an infamous history in this country of constantly devaluing indigenous people and traditions and this would be yet another example of corporate and political American steamrolling these communities.

(2) No development on this scale doesn't have environmental consequences. Of course this project is utilizing the best available resources, but that doesn't negate the possible disastrous outcomes that are an underlying worry in all such endeavors. By developing in such a wilderness area as is proposed would be to reject that the wilderness and inhabitants are worth anything other than what economic utility they may provide. Ask anyone who has seen the area in its beauty--the gulls careening over the water, the alpenglow as the sun falls, or the backs of salmon slowly capping the water--and they understand the value that this place has.

(3) According to National Geographic, this mine would produce only 800-1,000 sustainable jobs, whereas the current fishing industry employs over 11,000. To argue that this project benefits the locals is a gross exaggeration. Perhaps it will bring a boost to the economy, but not in the sustainable, long-term ways that the area needs. It is also focused on extracting finite wealth. Although the overall worth of the metals in the proposed mine would be greater than the annual value of the salmon fishery, this is, again, finite wealth. Whereas the fishery wealth is a well-executed, sustainable, well-managed production. To value finite wealth over sustainable wealth and resources is to embrace the short-term mentality that gets our country into bigger issues.

(4) The mine company only proposes to hire 50% of their staff locally--a vacuous attempt at making this mine a community project. In reality, it's yet another example of America preferring corporate, industrial interests over other economic options. Other plans to improve the economy of the area include jobs and small-business ventures focused on recreation and tourism. In other words, jobs that spread the reverence and respect for the area instead of the exploitation of a mine. 

(5) Bristol Bay accounts for 50% of the world's sockeye salmon. Cook Inlet houses an endangered beluga population. And the area at large holds birds, mammals, and fish that people travel across the world to see. To prioritize industrial development over the environment has time and time again caused the United States to lose natural beauty and value. 

We constantly monetize natural resources, without accounting for the intangible and non-monetary benefits that are derived from those areas. Once a mine is developed and a fishery has collapsed, there's no going back. We cannot lose Bristol Bay.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment submitted by L. Cruden
Comment:
From: Lorraine Cruden
To: Pruitt, Scott
Date: 10/11/2017
Subject: Docket ID No. EPA-R10-OW-2017-0369

Dear Administrator Pruitt, 

I am writing in support of the communities of Alaska's Bristol Bay, the Alaskan fishing industry and the pristine and economically productive Bristol Bay watershed and ask you not to withdraw the proposed determination to adopt restrictions protecting the habitat of Bristol Bay and all the myriad activities, both commercial and recreational, that rely on the Bristol Bay watershed.  The EPA created the proposed determination after years of rigorous scientific study, public input and peer review and determined that "unacceptable adverse effects on fishery areas (including spawning and breeding areas) could result from the discharge of dredge or fill material associated with mining the Pebble deposit."

According to the EPA's proposed determination "Nearly 70% of the sockeye and large numbers of the coho, Chinook, pink and chum salmon are harvested in commercial, subsistence and recreational fisheries before they can return to their natal lakes and streams to spawn.  Thus, these salmon resources have significant economic, nutritional, cultural and recreational value, both within and beyond the Bristol Bay region.  The Bristol Bay watershed's ecological resources generated nearly $480 million in direct economic expenditures and sales and provided employment for over 14,000 full- and part-time workers in 2009.  The Bristol Bay commercial salmon fishery generates the largest component of this economic activity, with an estimated value of $300 million (sales from fishers to processors) and employment for over 11,000 full- and part-time workers (EPA 2014: Chapter 5)".   It is obvious that the Bristol Bay watershed is indispensable and irreplaceable and must be protected!

In addition, the EPA's estimates of potential damage created by mining at the head of the Bristol Bay watershed, for even the smallest mine (0.25 stage mine) proposed by Northern Dynasty Minerals Ltd. (NDM), would be significant.  Habitat losses would "include nearly 24 miles of streams, representing approximately 5 miles of streams with documented androgynous fish occurrence and 19 miles of tributaries of those streams (EPA 2014: Chapter 7).  Total habitat losses would also include more than 1,200 acres of wetlands, lakes and ponds".  And yet, according to the EPA, "NDM has stated to the public that "the Pebble deposit supports open pit mining utilizing conventional drill, blast and truck-haul methods, with an initial mine life of 25 years and potential mine extensions to 78 years and beyond"  (NDM 2011).  This statement, along with others to investors, indicates that NDM is actively considering a mine size between 2.0 and 6.5 billion tons."  A mine that could potentially be 26 times larger!!

In assessing the potential adverse effects to the area the EPA findings have been underestimated as "This evaluation does not include footprint impacts associated with all of the components necessary to construct and operate such a mine (e.g., a major transportation corridor, pipelines, a power-generating station, wastewater, treatment plants, housing and support services for workers, administrative offices, and other infrastructure). It also does not rely upon impacts resulting from potential accidents and failures".  Given the proposed duration of the mine's operations, 25 to 78 years, it is not unreasonable to assume that an accident would occur especially in "such a geographically remote area subject to climate extremes" and that and accident or failure "would have profound ecological ramifications".

The Bristol Bay watershed is an ecological, economical and culturally significant American natural resource and any damage done by allowing an open pit mine, as proposed by NDM, would be irreversible.  Therefore I urge you in the strongest language possible stand by the EPA's proposed determination and take all necessary actions to protect the Bristol Bay watershed for generations of Americans to come.

Sincerely

Lorraine Cruden
Glendale, AZ, 85310

Title: Comment submitted by C. Ward
Comment:
Dear Administrator, 

I'm writing in reference to Docket # EPA-HQ-ORD-2012-0276. Please prohibit the disposal of mine waste in Alaska's Bristol Bay watershed. The proposed Pebble Mine presents a long-term risk to the sustainability of this important fishery, and all the people and businesses that rely on it. In 2010, Bristol Bay salmon fishermen harvested 29 million sockeye salmon worth $165 million in direct harvest value alone. That represented 31% of the total Alaska salmon harvest value.

Many families rely on wild salmon as a uniquely nutritious source of protein, rich in essential omega-3 fats and vitamin D. Farmed salmon is not nutritionally identical (much lower in vitamin D, much higher in saturated fats and pro-inflammatory omega-6 fats) and poses its own environmental risks.

In addition, mine waste is incredibly toxic to the environment. Many superfund sites are former mining sites (as I am certain you are aware), and even those that are not pose substantial risks to the environment. Copper and gold mines are some of the mines that are particularly damaging, as copper and gold ores are usually sulfides. Sulfide ore tailings are a major contributor to the acidification of local waters due to the formation of sulfuric acid, to say nothing of the damage that gold and copper ions cause to animal and fish life in waters. Due to all of the above, I urge the EPA to take immediate action to use existing provisions of the Clean Water Act to protect this large and irreplaceable wild salmon fishery.

Sincerely,

Rachel Ward
2665 Fox Hollow Road
Springfield, OH, 45502

Salmon are a valuable commodity and this bay, one of their largest breeding areas, must be left intact both for their health and ours. Title: Comment submitted by T. Thompson
Comment:
The withdrawal of the Proposed Determination to Restrict Use of Area as Disposal Site: Pebble Deposit Area, Southwest Alaska without reviewing the documentation and scientific information is a disgrace. It is incumbent upon EPA Director Pruitt as a representative of the People of the United States to fairly evaluate any decisions made, let alone decisions that affect the largest wild Sockeye Salmon fishery IN THE WORLD and people who depend upon them for their livelihood. Title: Anonymous public comment

Allowing the Pebble Mineral Partnership to build mineral mines and use Bristol Bay as a disposal site for dredge materials would have negative consequences for the entire region. Dumping waste materials in the water would drastically reduce water quality and decimate the local Sockeye salmon population. This would prove disastrous for the local ecosystem, and potentially endanger an entire species in one blow. 

Not only would this decision have ecological consequences, but the local fishing industry would for all intents and purposes be lost as well, costing jobs for potentially thousands of people. The Bay is home to half the world's Sockeye salmon, and losing the fisheries here would cost Alaska nearly half its total harvested salmon, as well as millions in revenue and wholesale value. Fish harvested from the Bay total more fish than from 41 other states, and 6% of US fish exports. If this area shouldn't be protected on the basis of ecological standards alone, it is too economically significant to lose in addition to environmental concerns. 

Therefore, I strongly urge for you to not withdraw this determination restricting the use of the area as a disposal site. Thank you for taking the time to read this.

Title: Comment submitted by A. Matthews
Comment:
Alexander Mathews
42 Chesley Road
Newton, MA  02459


Dear EPA: 

I am writing in opposition to the proposal to open a mining area near Bristol  Bay, Alaska.  Specifically, I am writing during the public comment period regarding the deal with Northern Dynasty Minerals.  

Having fished commercially for salmon in Bristol Bay, I have seen first hand the beauty and abundance of that amazing natural resource.  I have seen how thousands come to harvest salmon not only for US citizens, but as an important American export around the world.  The prime attraction to foreign buyers when I was there was the pristine natural surroundings that led to such healthy, nutritious fish.  A mine next to our world-famous fishery makes no business sense at allit will damage or kill the clean Alaskan brand that has been carefully cultivated over decades.

I understand that the EPA is more interested in accessing natural resources for business and entrepreneurship than in previous years, and I understand this shift.  But trading a short-term gain in miningone that will disappear in a decade and provide far fewer jobs than you might expect due to mechanization of today's mining operationsis not smart business.

The role of EPA is not only to protect natural resources, but to balance the interests of business with the needs of the natural world to continue to sustain our nation's preeminence in the world.  We want to stay number one!  But Bristol Bay is the biggest, most productive salmon run in the world.  Trading that away to a mining company is, to put it simply, dumb.  Use your role as EPA to maintain Alaskan fisheries. Don't let mining spoil this incredible resource.

Sincerely,


Alexander Mathews
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment submitted by A. Hansen
Comment:
Dear Administrator,

I am writing in reference to Docket # EPA-HQ-ORD-2012-0276. Please prohibit the disposal of mine waste in Alaska's Bristol Bay watershed. The proposed Pebble Mine presents a long-term risk to this important fishery, and to all the people and businesses that rely on it. Salmon are a valuable commodity and this bay is one of their largest breeding areas. In 2010, Bristol Bay salmon fishermen harvested 29 million sockeye salmon worth $165 million in direct harvest value alone. That represented 31% of the total Alaska salmon harvest value.

Many families rely on wild salmon as a uniquely nutritious source of protein, rich in essential omega-3 fats and vitamin D. Farmed salmon is not nutritionally identical and poses its own environmental risks. I urge the EPA to take immediate action to use existing provisions of the Clean Water Act to protect this large and irreplaceable wild salmon fishery.

Sincerely, 
Angela Hansen

Title: Comment submitted by S. Wermus
Comment:
Dear Administrator:

Please do not withdraw the 2014 restriction protecting clean water in Pebble Deposit area, one of the largest salmon fisheries in the world.  

To do so would allow the watershed to become polluted through potential industry use, adversely affecting the environment--worth protecting in its own right--and environmental capital, in the form of jobs dependent on a health fishery in this area.  

Allowing industry to pollute our environment is shortsighted.  Clean water and clean air are very American child's birthright.  Any short term gains in job creation by lifting regulations are often overwhelmingly offset by long-term adverse health effects to human populations that toxic and carcinogenic pollutants cause.  

Thank you for your consideration.
Steve Wermus
Wilmington, DE

Title: Comment submitted by J. Tupper
Comment:
As a former salmon habitat restoration technician for a Washington State Regional Fisheries Enhancement Group, I must add my voice in opposition to the 2017 Proposal to Withdraw Proposed Clean Water Act Restrictions on Mining Pebble Deposit.

Wild Pacific salmon are part of a $1 billion annual market. And the benefits of salmon in our systems are just as clear: nutrient-rich soils for bountiful crops, reduced soil erosion for more arable farmland, hundreds of jobs from hatcheries to tourism to salmon harvesting. And in Washington state, we've already seen the benefits when salmon are just barely reintroduced - and how quickly those same benefits can be lost.

Bristol Bay is one of the most critical Pacific salmon habitats on the West Coast. Anything that risks our current precarious salmon populations risks incalculable damage to our environment, health, and future jobs. We literally cannot measure the economic devastation mining in Bristol Bay, and we should never have to.

Please reject the 2017 Proposal to Withdraw Proposed Clean Water Act Restrictions on Mining Pebble Deposit. Thank you for your time and consideration on this matter.

Regards,
Jessica Tupper, MPA

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
To Whom It May Concern-

The allowing of a Canadian owned subsidiary company to mine resources from American land while destroying both American wildlife & jobs while polluting and irreversibly poisoning American soil and waterways is inconsistent with the values and beliefs of American citizens across the rest of our great nation. Allowing Dynasty's subsidiary Pebble to come in and destroy a thriving economy and the land is wrong and will in no way benefit the United States or its economy. Please consider the downstream effects of what you are proposing to allow on this piece of land. If it will harm United States Citizens' livelihoods and affect the overall health of the surrounding human and wildlife populations then it is a bad idea to place a mine within the bounds of the Bristol Bay, AK watershed, regardless of what entity claims ownership of that stretch of land. I ask you to consider the future of the surrounding land and people before allowing any mining action in this area. Any profits that this mining company will make from mining here will go straight into its own pockets and no one in the surrounding area will benefit from a mine being placed here. Action of claiming a few billion dollars worth of resources over the life of this mine is incredibly shortsighted in comparison to the multi-billion dollar a year economy that this area currently supports - a multi-billion dollar per year economy that depends on the health and welfare of the wildlife living in it. Keeping certain federal regulations in place is not counterproductive to business interests in AK, especially when those regulations are creating very productive conditions for the current businesses and industries already present and in compliance with said clean water regulations. Lifting regulations in favor of a foreign company's shortsighted to make a quick dollar on US land is not excercising good stewardship of the land or taking care of US Citizens.

Thank you for your time.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
Do not withdraw this Clean Water Act restriction on the Pebble Deposit area of Alaska.

This watershed is extremely important for current Native Alaskan populations, and for the local fish populations. From the 2014 determination, Bristol Bay "is an area of unparalleled ecological value, boasting salmon diversity and productivity unrivaled anywhere in North America." (1) Not only is the area a draw for tourism, both for it's beauty and for recreational fishing, many important salmon species call the bay home. Adding mine tailings and slag to this watershed will irreparably harm this ecosystem. Even with certain containment practices in place, the run off from the mine and the likelihood of containment failure means heavy metals will end up in the water. We have already studies how lipophillic metals and compounds bioaccumulate into our fish, then end up in our bodies. Even if concentrations are low, people would likely become scared of fishing in that area, or eating the fish there, and it would cost the overall economy much more than any potential gain. The modest positive impact from jobs at the mine will pale in comparison to the possible loss that could occur to both fishing and travel industries.

It is extremely clear based upon the 2014 proposed determination by the EPA, even when given the chance to, neither party was able to sufficiently prove that the mining slag wouldn't harm the environment:

"Both NDM/PLP and the State of Alaska submitted information that raised scientific and technical issues, most of which had been previously raised in public comments on the Bristol Bay Assessment. However, this information did not demonstrate to the satisfaction of EPA Region 10 that no unacceptable adverse effects on fishery areas will occur should the disposal of dredged or fill material associated with mining the Pebble deposit proceed." (1) 

Read simply: Neither party submitted information able to demonstrate that no unacceptable adverse effects will occur. It is clear that withdrawing the restriction will have horrible negative impacts to the local ecosystem, water quality, fishing and tourism industries and the people living in the area. For these reasons, I urge you not to turn your back on clean water.

(1) https://www.epa.gov/sites/production/files/2014-07/documents/pebble_es_pd_071714_final.pdf
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment: I strongly urge the EPA not to withdrawal the proposed restrictions on the scale of development of the Pebble ore body.  As a mining professional with over 30 years of experience I know what is and is not achievable in terms of environmental protection, not just on paper but in the real world of business cycles and actual field activities.  A mine of even the reduced scale proposed by the Pebble Partnership is almost certain to do material damage to the Bristol Bay salmon fishery.  In reality a small mine will almost certainly not be economically viable and a large mine will have unacceptable impacts to one of the last great fisheries left on Earth.

Title: Comment submitted by N. Pasi
Comment:
Dear Administrator, 

I'm writing in reference to Docket # EPA-HQ-ORD-2012-0276. Please prohibit the disposal of mine waste in Alaska's Bristol Bay watershed. The proposed Pebble Mine presents a long-term risk to the sustainability of this important fishery, and all the people and businesses that rely on it. In 2010, Bristol Bay salmon fishermen harvested 29 million sockeye salmon worth $165 million in direct harvest value alone. That represented 31% of the total Alaska salmon harvest value.

As a citizen working on sockeye salmon restoration in the state of Washington, I have seen firsthand the impacts of extirpated salmon runs on local communities. Loss of sockeye violated the treaty rights of the Yakama Nation and threatened their cultural practices. Headwater forest habitats have declined in recent decades due to a lack of marine nutrients that would normally be provided by salmon spawning and dying in their natal streams. Salmon carcasses provide an important source of food for bears, wolves, coyotes, raccoons, bobcats and cougars, and also host insect life that support other fish and bird species. Salmon are truly the building block of northwestern ecology and economies. Threatening them threatens all aspects of life in this region.

I urge the EPA to take immediate action to use existing provisions of the Clean Water Act to protect this large and irreplaceable wild salmon fishery. 

Sincerely, 
Nicole Pasi
Thorp, WA

Title: Comment submitted by Z. R. Westbrook
Comment:
The proposed determination is set to take effect, protecting the world's largest salmon fishery. The original determination was proposed following thorough scientific study and is essential to protect Bristol Bay and the Pacific Sockeye Salmon from the environmental damage that would be caused by the Pebble LP mine set to be constructed in the area. The Bristol Bay fishery represents close to one-third of the world's Sockeye Salmon fishery by gross tonnage (Alaska Dept. of Fish and Game)

This proposal to withdraw the determination was launched at the request of the CEO of the mining company as evidenced by the decision's proximity (within an hour) to the EPA Administrator's meeting with Pebble CEO, Tom Collier ("Democrats call EPA's Bristol Bay move 'inconsistent with basic logic', CNN, October 11, 2017, https://apple.news/ALLhK0TwUT_-6sucKKvaljg).
Abandoning science and the core mission of the EPA at the behest of monied corporate and political interests is thoroughly immoral and unethical.

This proposal to withdraw should be called off and the original determination put into effect as per EPA and legal guidelines, unless and until the EPA can produce scientific, peer-reviewed, consensus research that clearly demonstrates the Pebble Mine or future mines of the same location will cause no damage to the Bristol Bay or surrounding fisheries.

Regards,

Zachary R. Westbrook
US Citizen

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
To the EPA:

The Pebble prospect is possibly in the worst place on the planet to build a large open-pit mine. It is uniquely dangerous not only because of the value of the sockeye salmon fishery, but because of the life cycle of that particular species. Spawning takes place and juveniles primarily live in lakes directly downstream of the prospect rather than spreading out widely through other adjacent tributaries. A single major leak or spill from this seismically active region with poorly-understood groundwater dynamics could contaminate the lakes and destroy the fishery. 

There are countless other places to develop natural resources in Alaska with minimal risk to important fisheries. The Fort Knox mine is in a good location. So is the Pogo mine. Livengood has acceptable prospects. Pebble is the worst.

Title: Comment submitted by B. F. Reynolds
Comment:
Dear Mr. Pruitt,
I am writing to urge you not to withdraw the protections afforded the Bristol Bay watershed by the Clean Water Act.  I am an Alaska commercial fisherman and aquatic scientist working within the Copper River Watershed, a sister watershed to Bristol Bay along Alaska's south central coast.  Bristol Bay is home to world's most prolific sockeye salmon run and generates more direct and indirect jobs than a proposed Pebble Mine could possibly achieve. Furthermore, the Bristol Bay fishery and its economic impacts are sustainable.  Pebble mine is finite; however, its impact on the landscape in the form of mining pits and toxic tailing pools is not, and the potential for serious ecological damage is not unrealistic if you consider the track record of open pit mines.  The permission and establishment of the Pebble Mine at the headwaters of one of our world's greatest sustainable natural treasures would be both reckless and unconscionable.  It would be a poor decision to remove the Clean Water Act protections for speculation of short term gain with great risks when a continuance of protections would guarantee what Bristol Bay has always provided, cultural and economic prosperity.  

Sincerely,

Brad F Reynolds
PO Box 1936
Cordova, AK 99574

bradfreynolds@gmail.com

Title: Comment submitted by H. Lau
Comment:
Dear Mr. Pruitt,

I'm writing in support of the Native communities in Bristol Bay and for everyone in the North American.  To open up Bristol Bay for Pebble Limited Partnership to mine gold and copper is a terrible and irresponsible action to take.  Leeching from the mine will wreak havoc on the waterways, the soil, the land, the wildlife and aquatic wildlife, and any other areas up and down stream of the mine, including drinking water for humans.  The damage would be irreversible.  

From an economic perspective, Bristol Bay provides thousands of jobs and generates $300 million annually from commercial caught salmon.  Why strip that away?

The EPA is supposed to be the guardian of protection against environmental pollutants and organizations, not a facilitator.  Do not reverse the findings from 2014.  Pebble Mine would have "unacceptable adverse effects on one of the most pristine, valuable and vulnerable ecosystems remaining in North America today."

Sincerely,
Holly Lau
4647 Hazel Avenue
Philadelphia, PA 19143
