Title: Comment submitted by M. Sparks
Comment:
EPA and Administrator Pruitt,

I am writing to voice my objection to opening up of the permitting process for the Pebble Partnership.  

My background is in fisheries science and I completed my Masters in Science working with populations of sockeye salmon from Bristol Bay. There are three main reasons why Bristol Bay salmon and the environment there should be protected, especially from an enormous open pit mine.  

The first main reason is an ecological one. Bristol Bay is perhaps the most intact, productive large-scale freshwater system in North America.  It's not difficult to see why. Tens of millions of salmon return annually bringing nutrients they've spent a lifetime accumulating in the ocean. This pulse of nutrients from the sea is the basis of a food web that spans freshwater and terrestrial environments and ranges from microscopic invertebrates to keystone species like brown bears. They key ingredient in all of this is the salmon, without them the entire ecological system would cease to exist as it has for millions of years.

The second reason for protection of Bristol Bay is an economic argument.  Bristol Bay supports one of the largest commercial fisheries in the world and is responsible for the majority of sockeye salmon taken to market in the US.  The salmon fishery and associated industries (processors, marine suppliers, boat mechanics, etc.) support 14000+ jobs annually and are responsible for a multi-hundred million dollar economy every year.  Better yet, sockeye salmon are a sustainable resource that if managed properly can support this economy in perpetuity.  Furthermore, the sockeye salmon fishery is also considered one of the most sustainable fisheries in the world. Managers are able to determine which stocks within the larger fishery appear to be preforming well on a year-to-year basis, which allows an adaptive fishery to shift efforts to stocks with the most robust returns while leaving other, less bountiful stocks with lower pressure.  It is a model system for managers and industry. Beyond the commercial fishery, sockeye salmon as the basis for a productive food web, contribute to one of the premier sport fisheries in the US, where individuals may spend up to $20,000 over ten days to fly out to, float on, and fish for salmon and trout.

The final reason for not following through with the permitting of the Pebble Project is a cultural one. For Native Alaskans in Bristol Bay, sockeye salmon have been the lifeblood for their table, culture, and spiritual ceremonies for tens of thousands of years.  We rail against the destruction of ancient artifacts and holy relics when it occurs in other nations, but the loss of these fish would amount to the loss of the foundation of culture and faith in the region.  Beyond Native Alaskans, salmon and natural productivity and beauty are defining characters of life and culture in Alaska.  It's why people move and stay there. Alaska is perhaps the most unique state in the Union, its character largely driven by places like Bristol Bay.

Finally, a few parting notes. First, this issue was largely settled until Administrator Pruitt sat down for a brief meeting with leader of the Pebble Partnership. While I understand that these actions may be in the purview of the agency, I also note that the EPA previously decided to protect the region with an uncommon regulatory option of the Clean Water Act. Supporters of the Pebble Mine pointed to this as an overreach of regulation.  But, for anyone who has known or visited Bristol Bay, such a remarkable place called for remarkable action.  I'll leave you with this note.  A major driver of the fear for a project like Pebble is that this particular industry (hard rock mining) has had very little accountability and one of the poorest track records for environmental regard.  The Berkeley Pit Mine in Butte Montana was built on the headwaters of Clark Fork River.  The mine poisoned the river and the region's residents for generations.  When the mine became unprofitable, ownership shuttered their doors, leaving Montanans to deal with the mess and Americans to pick up the check (now approaching $50 billion). This story has been repeated time and time again for mega-project open-pit mines. Even more recently, the tailings dam of the Mt. Polley mine burst on a tributary of the Fraser River in British Columbia, Canada, flooding BC's most productive sockeye salmon river with billions of gallons of toxic sludge.  Moreover, the toxic byproduct of projects like these are expected to be stored on the landscape in perpetuity.  How will the Pebble Partnership keep these toxic elements from this pristine landscape 1000 years from now when they no longer exist as a business.  Mine tailings always outlive the companies that produced them.  You have heard plenty from Alaskans and people supporting Bristol Bay protection. Please listen.

Thank you for your consideration of these comments,

Morgan Sparks, M.S.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment submitted by B. Rector
Comment:
To whom it may concern:

I am not an environmentalist.  I was born and raised and have lived my entire life in Montana where natural resources play a large role in my state and I am usually on the pro-development side of the fence.  However, the Pebble mine in the Bristol Bay drainage is a bad idea.

I have traveled the world and have witnessed some of the most amazing things mankind has been able to construct sometimes with the most basic tools.  It all pales in comparison to the vast, simple beauty of the Bristol Bay drainage.

I was fortunate enough to spend a week in the Katmai region this past summer and it was quite an education.  The entire ecosystem is dependent on one species of fish, the Sockeye salmon.  Without the annual Sockey migration there would be no bears which rely on plentiful salmon to prepare for hibernation.  There would be no gulls and birds of prey which feast on the scraps the bears leave behind.  There would be no trout that feast on the salmon eggs.  These trout are so big and healthy people from all over the globe travel to the region to catch a Bristol Bay rainbow.

As I said, I am from a state that develops its natural resources and more often than not, the extraction of these resources is not as neat and tidy as proposed.  In this case it is just flat not worth the risk of endangering this special place on our planet.  All the gold in the world is not worth messing with the Bristol Bay drainage.

No to the Pebble mine.

Bill Rector
Billings, MT

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
What are you thinking? This is a terrible idea. Listen to the scientists not the mining industry. I am opposed to EPAs proposal to rescind the 
2014 Proposed Determination designed to protect Bristol Bays world class fisheries. Please stand with American jobs and communities and preserve the Bristol Bay Proposed Determination.

Bristol Bay, Alaska, is one of America's last great wild salmon fisheries. Each year, tens of millions of wild salmon return, supporting upwards of 14,000 jobs in the commercial and sport fishing industries, and serving as a one-in-a-lifetime destination for anglers from around the world as well as the cultural cornerstone for the region's communities. These long-established businesses are at risk from a foreign-owned mining company that wants to build the proposed Pebble Mine, which is opposed by more than 65 percent of Alaskans and more than 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents. 

In 2014, led by Alaska Native Tribes, interests including commercial fishing business owners and sportsmen asked the EPA step in to ensure that this mine wouldn't jeopardize Bristol Bay. The EPA responded by listening to over 1.5 million Americans, hosting dozens of community meetings, reviewing Pebble's many detailed filings with state and federal agencies, and conducting a twice peer-reviewed scientific assessment of the potential impacts to the region. Withdrawing the proposed determination ignores the overwhelming majority of Alaskans and puts the short-term interests of a foreign mining company above thousands of local jobs. 

For the sake of our wildlife, waterways, and communities, I urge you to protect Bristol Bay and prevent this horrible open-pit mine from destroying one of our nation's most precious ecosystems.

Title: Comment submitted by Tim Troll, Executive Director, Bristol Bay Heritage Land Trust
Comment:
Bristol Bay Heritage Land Trust

The EPA's characterization of the Bristol Bay fishery as a world class fishery deserving of protection is correct and consistent with all previous known assessments of the fishery, including the assessment of the Alaska Department of Natural Resources that supports the continued closure of the Koktuli River and Upper Talarik Creek to mineral entry under Alaska law.  We encourage the EPA not to abandon its recommendation that the waters of Bristol Bay, and in particular the Nushagak and Kvichak watersheds, be afforded the protection of the Clean Water Act consistent with the findings of An Assessment of Potential Mining Impacts on Salmon Ecosystems of Bristol Bay, Alaska.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Anonymous Public Comment
Comment:
I write to oppose the Pebble Mine operation in Bristol Bay, Alaska proposed PLP and its partners. I am a biologist and water resources engineering graduate student. 

Current proposed pebble-mining operations in Bristol Bay will violate section 404(c) of the Clean Water Act. It will also be detrimental to wildlife, fisheries, streams, wetlands, and groundwater, regardless of compensatory efforts. 

Compensatory mitigation to improve streams or wetlands in other areas of the watershed(s) would not offset degradation and alterations caused by Pebble Mine. The watershed is already one of the most pristine in the nation, and no value would come of "improving" any area of the watershed. Given that salmon are genetically predisposed to spawn within meters of where they hatched in a stream, the creation of additional spawning channels would not be beneficial to salmon as they are not predisposed to spawn in "unfamiliar" streams. Additionally, the creation of side channels for salmon spawning assumes there would be additional water to supply these streams with enough flow. Continuity of hydraulics shows that "creating additional water" to supply adequate flow to side channels is not possible. This would lower flows in pre-existing streams. Thus, altering and degrading pre-existing, native streams would decimate fisheries in the area.

Due to the geology and hydrology of the area, surface water and groundwater regimes are tightly linked. Contamination of groundwater will negatively affect salmon. Spawning salmon rely on cold, clean upwelling of groundwater in their streams (Hancock, 2002). Any amount of groundwater contamination can detrimentally affect salmon rearing grounds. Additionally, it has been shown that water withdrawals through groundwater wells can alter the water regime in surrounding streams such that groundwater no longer flows into streams through upwelling and hyporheic exchange. Without this groundwater inflow into streams, the quality salmon spawning grounds will deteriorate.

PLP states that they would monitor sites for a minimum of 30 years after the completion of their operation in Bristol Bay. All engineering designs (including the tailings facility) have an upper limit for design lifetime. Because 30 years is not enough time for all dredged materials and contaminated waste to neutralize, and the life of the tailings facility will eventually expire, this poses threats for surface water and groundwater. When the tailings facility fails, surface water and groundwater will become contaminated, thus threatening fish, wildlife, and the surrounding ecosystems. Any amount of further cleanup would never get affected habits back to their pristine state. 

PLP also states that mine drainage at the site will be collected within the tailings facility and sent to a treatment plant prior to discharge. Engineering and hydrology calculations have shown that the treatment plant may not meet capacity for all storm events (including the likelihood of a 1000+ year storm event). Given the longevity of the proposed mining operations, it is highly likely that the wastewater treatment plants will fail. At a minimum this could mean that the inflow to the treatment plant is greater than the outflow (due to a heavy storm event), causing an overflow of contaminated mine drainage directly to the environment. Just one contamination spill can irreversibly damage surrounding habitats and decimate fish populations.

In short, the current proposed mining operations in Bristol Bay will violate section 404(c) of the Clean Water Act. The science PLP has put into their proposed mining operation is incomplete and of poor quality. As a biologist, hydrologist, and engineer in training it is clear that the 2014 Proposed Determination of the US EPA Region 10 Pursuant to section 404(c) of the Clean Water Act must be upheld. Because of this, any further Pebble Mine plans in the Bristol Bay Area should be terminated.

References
Hancock, P.J. 2002. Human Impacts on the Stream-Groundwater Exchange Zone. Ecosystem Management.

Title: Comment submitted by Owen Graham, Executive Director, Alaska Forest Association (AFA)
Comment:
October 17, 2017


Water Docket, Environmental Protection Agency
Mail Code 28221T
Attn.: Docket #EPA-R10-OW-2017-0369
1200 Pennsylvania Ave., N.W.
Washington, DC 20460

Gentlemen,

The Alaska Forest Association supports the proposed decision to withdraw the July 2014 Proposed Determination from the Bristol Bay Watershed Assessment of the Pebble Deposit Area.

The Alaska Forest Association (AFA) is a non-profit business association that was formed in 1957 to represent the interests of the timber industry in Southeast Alaska. The AFA currently manages a pension program, a group health insurance program, a scholarship program for the timber industry and also sponsors the Sustainable Forestry Initiative program for Alaska.

We support the responsible development of Alaska's natural resources and we believe that development can be accomplished with minimal risk to other resources. Our environments are in a constant state of change, both natural and man-caused.  Further, the environment is not fragile and impacts from development can be minimized and, if necessary, mitigated. Even the Mount Saint Helens eruption had mostly temporary impacts on fish, wildlife and the forests surrounding the volcano (https://www.fs.fed.us/pnw/mtsthelens/faq/q10.shtml).

Thank you for the opportunity to comment.

Sincerely, 
 
Owen Graham
Executive Director
Alaska Forest Association
111 Stedman Suite 200
Ketchikan, AK  99901

Title: Anonymous Public Comment
Comment:
I am opposed to EPAs proposal to rescind the 2014 Proposed Determination designed to protect Bristol Bays world class fisheries. Please stand with American jobs and communities and preserve the Bristol Bay Proposed Determination.

Bristol Bay, Alaska, is one of America's last great wild salmon fisheries. Each year, tens of millions of wild salmon return, supporting upwards of 14,000 jobs in the commercial and sport fishing industries, and serving as a one-in-a-lifetime destination for anglers from around the world as well as the cultural cornerstone for the region's communities. These long-established businesses are at risk from a foreign-owned mining company that wants to build the proposed Pebble Mine, which is opposed by more than 65 percent of Alaskans and more than 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents. 

In 2014, led by Alaska Native Tribes, interests including commercial fishing business owners and sportsmen asked the EPA step in to ensure that this mine wouldn't jeopardize Bristol Bay. The EPA responded by listening to over 1.5 million Americans, hosting dozens of community meetings, reviewing Pebble's many detailed filings with state and federal agencies, and conducting a twice peer-reviewed scientific assessment of the potential impacts to the region. Withdrawing the proposed determination ignores the overwhelming majority of Alaskans and puts the short-term interests of a foreign mining company above thousands of local jobs. 

For the sake of our wildlife, waterways, and communities, I urge you to protect Bristol Bay and prevent this horrible open-pit mine from destroying one of our nation's most precious ecosystems.  

Stop the disruption of this wealth of environment in Bristol Bay which provides livelihoods for many people salmon fishing, sport fishing and native Americans livelihood, as well as an economy based on these natural resources and a salmon run that has existed for multi hundreds of years; all for an open pit pebble mine. The short term profit of this one company will disrupt permanent and long lasting profit sources of the fishing industry and this food source all Americans and others need for a good diet.  Once ruined it can not be bought back with monies made from ruining this Bay and all of its natural benefits for mankind in the area and nationwide.   Pebbles can NOT replace a food source for the nation.

Title: Anonymous Public Comment

Bristol Bay is home to one of the most valuable fishing grounds in the United States, contributing more than $1 billion in annual revenue and thousands of jobs. This, like numerous other issues (climate change, food labeling, gun regulation, immigration reform, prison reform, education reform, short-term lending regulation, healthcare reform, banking regulation) remains a vexing problem primarily due to corporations' ability to curry favor with elected officials.  The corrupting influence of money in our political system is undermining our democratic traditions and discouraging Americans from voting and/or running for office.  This ominous development may well end our experiment in representative democracy unless we alter this decades-long trend.  For the sake of the republic, we must amend the US Constitution to state that corporations are not people (and do not have constitutional rights) and money is not speech (and thus can be regulated by state and/or federal campaign finance laws).  Short of accomplishing this, no other reform of significance will be achieved.  The moneyed interests will turn any reform to their benefit, often at the expense of the nation as a whole.

Title: Anonymous Public Comment
Comment:
We are strongly opposed to EPAs proposal to rescind the 2014 Proposed Determination designed to protect Bristol Bays world class fisheries. 

We urge you to stand with American jobs and communities and preserve the Bristol Bay Proposed Determination.

As you know, tens of millions of wild salmon return annually to Bristol Bay, supporting upwards of 14,000 jobs in the commercial and sport fishing industries, and serving as a one-in-a-lifetime destination for anglers from around the world as well as the cultural cornerstone for the region's communities. These long-established businesses are at risk from the foreign-owned mining company that wants to build the proposed Pebble Mine, which is opposed by more than 65 percent of Alaskans and more than 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents. 

EPA has heard from over 1.5 million Americans, hosted dozens of community meetings, reviewed Pebble's many detailed filings with state and federal agencies, and conducted a twice peer-reviewed scientific assessment of the potential impacts to the region. 

Withdrawing the proposed determination ignores the overwhelming majority of Alaskans and puts the short-term interests of a foreign mining company above thousands of local jobs and the health of a vital, irreplaceable, priceless ecosystem. 

We implore you to protect our wildlife, waterways, and communities by do everything that you can to protect Bristol Bay and keep this gigantic open-pit mine from destroying one of our nation's (and our planet's) most precious ecosystems.

We are counting on you.  Thank you.

- Please listen to the local communities, the best available science and the American people and do not reverse course on this pebble mine.

Title: Anonymous Public Comment
Comment:
Dear Administrator Pruitt & Acting Administrator Pirzadeh: 

I am very disappointed that you plan to reverse course and green light the proposed Pebble Mine, despite the catastrophic risks it poses to Alaska's Bristol Bay watershed, its world-renowned salmon runs and its Native communities. 

Under the Obama administration, the EPA, after years of rigorous study, proposed science-based restrictions that would have banned the dangerous Pebble Mine to protect Bristol Bay from the myriad of environmental risks this massive gold and copper mine would pose. Your recent settlement with Northern Dynasty Minerals to reverse those common-sense restrictions is a blatant giveaway to the mining industry at the expense of the American people, our environment and our economy.

Bristol Bay's wild salmon fishery supports 14,000 jobs and is valued at more than $1.5 billion annually. It also supplies nearly half of the world's sockeye salmon. More than 65 percent of Alaskans, 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents and Native communities, and 85 percent of commercial fishermen oppose the mine.

I urge you to listen to those voices, and for the sake of the Bristol Bay watershed, its world-class salmon fishery and its people, keep the door closed on Pebble Mine.

Title: Comment submitted by K. R. Sweeney
Comment:
To whom it may concern, United States Environmental Protection Agency:

Don't put the interests of a foreign mining company above thousands of American jobs! Keep the EPA's Clean Water Act protections for Bristol Bay in place.

I oppose this plan which basically puts the interests of a foreign mining company above those of two-thirds of Alaskans, 80% of Bristol Bay residents and indigenous communities, and 85% of commercial fishermen. Take care of Americans FIRST!

The EPA has previously determined that the planned pebble mine would cause great damage to the unparalleled salmon runs and local fisheries as well as to local Native communities. Protect America FIRST!

The foreign owned pebble mine would cause significant damage to the world-renowned salmon runs of Bristol Bay. This fishery is worth more than 1.5 million dollars a year and supports 14,000 jobs. All of this would be put at risk for the interests of a non-American mining company. Put American citizens FIRST!

More than 1.5 million Americans have previously submitted public comments opposing this pebble mine. Listen to Americans FIRST!

Please consider the needs of the local communities, consult the best available science and hear the voices of the American people-do not reverse course on this pebble mine.

Sincerely,

Kelly R Sweeney

Title: Comment submitted by Tritia M. (no surname provided)
Comment:
Administrator E. Scott Pruitt 

Dear Administrator Pruitt,

Please protect the natural ecosystems, the Native economy and lifestyle. and local wildlife. Oil and water do not mix, and mines WILL lead toxins into the environment, it's just a matter of time. Do not allow the Pebble Mine to operate in the Bristol Bay. Once it is ruined, it is gone forever.

I write in support of the communities of Alaska's Bristol Bay and ask you not to withdraw the proposed determination to adopt restrictions protecting the habitat of Bristol Bay's world-renowned salmon.

The proposed determination was made at the request of local communities and adopted only after years of rigorous scientific study, public participation and peer review. The EPA was correct in 2014 when it found that the Pebble Mine would have "significant and unacceptable adverse effects" on "one of the most productive, pristine, valuable and vulnerable ecosystems remaining in North America today."

The EPA has noted that commercial fishing in Bristol Bay generates $300 million annually in direct sales of commercially caught salmon, generating 11,000 jobs. These salmon support not only the commercial and sportfishing industries, but a traditional Native way of life that has endured for millennia and thrives today.

The EPA should stand by its proposed determination and take all necessary actions to protect the Bristol Bay watershed.

Sincerely,
Tritia M.
Seaside, CA

Title: Comment submitted by P. Schmidt
Comment:
Mr. Pruitt,
I strongly object to the "about face" the EPA may make with respect to the Pebble Mine project at Bristol Bay. In 2014,
after a 4-year review process, the EPA said Bristol Bay Watershed was too fragile to support large scale mining.
Because of the proximity to the watershed this will threaten the salmon industry (1.5 billion, 14000 jobs in Bristol Bay
area). Salmon is life to this area. It can not be contaminated.
Please do not allow short-term interests to destroy the environment for future generations.

Thank you, 

Philipp Schmidt

Title: Comment submitted by R. Woods
Comment:
Dear Administrator Pruitt and Acting Region 10 Administrator Pirzadeh:

I am writing today to encourage the US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to protect Bristol Bay, Alaska, from the proposed Pebble Mine that would threaten the region's irreplaceable fish and wildlife resources and the 14,000 jobs that depend on Bristol Bay's clean, healthy waters. EPA must keep the Bristol Bay 404(c) Proposed Determination in place to protect Bristol Bay, its salmon, waters, people, and sustainable economy from the proposed Pebble Mine.

EPA's own scientific study contains highly concerning facts: even without a mine disaster, construction of the Pebble deposit will destroy 94 miles of salmon streams and 5,350 acres of wetlands, lakes and ponds. Overall, EPA concluded that mining the headwaters of the Bristol Bay river systems could cause irreparable harm to the valuable Bristol Bay fishery, wildlife, and people.

According to the EPA's own study, the Bristol Bay watershed provides vital habitat for 29 fish species, more than 190 bird species, and more than 40 terrestrial animals. All five species of Pacific salmonsockeye, Chinook, coho, chum and pinkspawn and rear in the pristine Bristol Bay watershed. The Bristol Bay watershed supports the largest sockeye salmon run in the world, producing approximately 46% of the world's wild sockeye harvest, creating $1.5 billion in economic output and nearly 20,000 jobs throughout the United States annually.

Because of its great ecological and economic value, I recommend the EPA keep in place the 404(c) Proposed Determination for Bristol Bay, Southwest Alaska. The reasonable restrictions included in that proposal will prevent unsustainable development that would adversely impact the region's fishery, recreation and local culture.

Please keep the agency's 404(c) action in place to protect one of the nation's greatest sustainable resourcesthe Bristol Bay, Alaska, salmon fishery.

Sincerely,

Rebecca Woods

Title: Anonymous Public Comment
Comment:
I am asking that you do not withdraw the Bristol Bay Proposed Determination, which it made pursuant to the Clean Water Act in 2014.

As you know, Bristol Bay, Alaska, is one of America's last great wild salmon fisheries. Tens of millions of wild salmon return annually, which support upwards of 14,000 American jobs in the commercial and sport fishing industries, serve as a one-in-a-lifetime destination for anglers from around the world, and are the cultural cornerstone for the region's communities.

These long-established American businesses and jobs are at risk from a foreign-owned mining company that wants to build the proposed Pebble Mine, which is opposed by more than 65 percent of Alaskans and more than 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents. 

In 2010, led by Alaska Native Tribes, interests including commercial fishing business owners and sportsmen asked the EPA step in to ensure that this mine wouldn't jeopardize Bristol Bay. The EPA responded by listening to over 1.5 million Americans, hosting dozens of community meetings, reviewing Pebble's many detailed filings with state and federal agencies, and conducting a twice peer-reviewed scientific assessment of the potential impacts to the region.

Withdrawing the proposed determination ignores the overwhelming majority of Alaskans and puts the short-term interests of a foreign mining company above thousands of American jobs. 

Please do not withdraw the proposed determination.

Title: Anonymous Public Comment
Comment:
The Pebble Mine and any other mining project should NEVER be allowed in Bristol Bay. Such mining would result in complete loss of fish habitat due to elimination, dewatering, and fragmentation of streams, wetlands, and other aquatic resources in some areas of the bay watershed, the EPA itself found after three years of peer-reviewed research. In particular, the EPA estimated 22 miles of streams and more than 6 square miles of wetlands and other habitats that are important to salmon and other fish would be lost to mining. All of these losses would be irreversible. 

End this insane march to destruction of the last pristine places on earth. We DO NOT need this mine. The health of our planet must come before profit.

Title: Anonymous Public Comment
Comment: I am opposed to the withdrawal of the 2014 Clean Water Act Proposed Determination. I currently have many pounds of wild-caught Sockeye salmon from the Bristol Bay watershed in my freezer at home. I participate in a "salmon share" with Iliamna Fish Company, a family run company in SW Alaska that has been sustainably fishing for salmon in this pristine environment for generations. This watershed provides jobs for families like those of Iliamna and food for families like mine. In fact, the Bristol Bay fishery supports over 14,000 full and part time jobs for Alaskans, and is vitally important for native communities, both culturally and financially. Northern Dynasty Minerals and the Pebble Mine group promises 1,000 permanent jobs and an additional 2,000 jobs during the construction process. By my calculations, that is a very sizeable NET LOSS OF JOBS in a very rural area.  Devastating.  Please, protect the environment as your agency's name states.  But also, I ask you to protect the JOBS, FOOD SOURCE, and CULTURAL IDENTITY that the Bristol Bay watershed supports. Administrator Pruitt's meeting with the Pebble Limited Partnership's CEO should not be the deciding factor in a decision to roll back the 2014 Proposed Determination.

Title: Comment submitted by A. Eninsche
Comment:
Dear Administrator, 

I'm writing in reference to Docket # EPA-HQ-ORD-2012-0276. Please prohibit the disposal of mine waste in Alaska's Bristol Bay watershed. The proposed Pebble Mine presents a long-term risk to the sustainability of this important fishery, and all the people and businesses that rely on it. 

I live in Minnesota, home of the Boundary Waters, and have helped fight expanding mining interests from damaging that sacred land from pollution. I believe this mission, to protect our natural water systems is not just something to strive for in my home, but across the country. This is why I am so concerned about the risk the Pebble Mine poses to the Bristol Bay.

In 2010, Bristol Bay salmon fishermen harvested 29 million sockeye salmon worth $165 million in direct harvest value alone. That represented 31% of the total Alaska salmon harvest value.

Many families rely on wild salmon as a uniquely nutritious source of protein, rich in essential omega-3 fats and vitamin D. Farmed salmon is not nutritionally identical (much lower in vitamin D, much higher in saturated fats and pro-inflammatory omega-6 fats) and poses its own environmental risks. I urge the EPA to take immediate action to use existing provisions of the Clean Water Act to protect this large and irreplaceable wild salmon fishery. The EPA has been an stalwart institution in the past, protecting our citizens and the beautiful land we inhabit - please continue this tradition and protect Bristol Bay.

Sincerely, Alexandra Eninsche
                214 4th St SE 
                Minneapolis, MN 55414

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
Thinking logically, Bristol Bay is home to over 59% of the world's Sockeye salmon population. Salmon is also one of the most popular fish people buy regularly at supermarkets and the like. Starting from the bottom and working our way up, removing all of these protections will cause FAR more harm than a copper/gold mine will ever do. 

For starters, it will destroy a whole ecosystem. It doesn't matter who does what, why they do it, or where, destroying an ecosystem is NEVER good. AFTER completely destroying an ecosystem that is vital to the areas surrounding, which will all probably begin to collapse if this mine goes in, you will be DECIMATING thousands of jobs. People who work in Bristol Bay will be out of work because of this mine, and the number is far higher than the jobs and income the mine will bring in due to the mechanization of minework. Fisheries and the like will obviously be most affected but so many more are going to be reached by this.

Thirdly, due to the loss of jobs, loss of ecosystem, and general loss of quality of the nearby environment, the people who live in Bristol Bay are going to suffer. Once again, it takes a few dozen people to monitor machinery compared to the THOUSANDS of individuals that will lose their jobs from the fishing industry alone. Putting in this mine will cause a major local recession that will likely spread further than just the Bristol Bay area. It's not just the people near the bay that will be affected, it is the people that those go to for food, clothing, cleaners, everything. Putting all these people out of work gives much less disposable income to these households. The households will then stop buying as many goods as they did before. Producers will start to lay off workers and lower production. It is simple economics, but it seems to have been overlooked in your need for removing protections out on this area for a good reason.

It does not matter whether you who reads this is Democrat, Republican, or any other party, you cannot argue that these regulations and protections were put in place without good, scientifically-backed reason.

Title: Comment submitted by T. W. Hendrickson
Comment:
Dear EPA,

The Trump administration has the goal of increasing middle-class jobs and job pay.

Thousands of USA citizens work in the Alaska fisheries business, and have done so for many years. Indigenous people are doing the same, for sustenance, over eons.

It is not in the interests of the USA to put in a copper pit mine, with associated toxic waste, at the headwaters of rivers draining into Bristol Bay. Sure, there will be some short-term jobs to set up this operation, but once running, new mining automated methods will minimize jobs. When the wastes inevitably leak into the headwaters and bay, one of the most abundant fisheries in the world will be destroyed.

So not only are jobs on net lost, but a major food source will be contaminated and disappear. This situation is unconscionable. The EPA is charged with protecting the environment, not destroying it.

Please cease this action.

Thanks. --Terrill W. Hendrickson

Title: Comment submitted by C. Thompson
Comment:
Administrator E. Scott Pruitt
Dear Administrator Pruitt,

This is possibly the worst location to build a copper and gold mine which would generate incredibly toxic waste. The company which proposes to build and operate the mine has already been shown to be irresponsible in the Mount Polley Mine Disaster, and I have no faith in them or anyone to conduct a mining operation without impacting the environment.

I write in support of the communities of Alaska's Bristol Bay and ask you not to withdraw the proposed determination to adopt restrictions protecting the habitat of Bristol Bay's world-renowned salmon. The proposed determination was made at the request of local communities and adopted only after years of rigorous scientific study, public participation and peer review. The EPA was correct in 2014 when it found that the Pebble Mine would have "significant and unacceptable adverse effects" on "one of the most productive, pristine, valuable and vulnerable ecosystems remaining in North America today." 

The EPA has noted that commercial fishing in Bristol Bay generates $300 million annually in direct sales of commercially caught salmon, generating 11,000 jobs. These salmon support not only the commercial and sportfishing industries, but a traditional Native way of life that has endured for millennia and thrives today. 

The EPA should stand by its proposed determination and take all necessary actions to protect the Bristol Bay watershed.

Sincerely,

Cameron Thompson

Title: Anonymous Public Comment
Comment:
This is the worst idea ever. There is no way on earth that EPA should withdraw the original Clean Water Act designation. I have the sinking feeling that this entire process is a sham. Clearly, Administrator Pruitt has no desire to uphold the actual mission of the EPA, or to hear concerns from constituents who actually have a stake in the pending destruction of this habitat. He took one meeting with the CFO of PLP, mulled it over for an hour without considering the multi-year study already undertaken by the EPA, and disregarded any science underpinning the original CWA designation. Here's what Pruitt had to say in his brief comments:

"We are committed to due process and the rule of law, and regulations that are 'regular.'  We understand how much the community cares about this issue, with passionate advocates on all sides.  The agreement will not guarantee or prejudge a particular outcome, but will provide Pebble a fair process for their permit application and help steer EPA away from costly and time-consuming litigation. We are committed to listening to all voices as this process unfolds."

Who are the passionate advocates in favor of this open-pit mine? This is baffling to me. I have only heard vocal opposition to PLP's desire to rip open swaths of Bristol Bay, extract some copper and gold, and dump literally millions of tons of toxic waste into the watershed in the process. PLP and Scott Pruitt appear to be the only people delusional enough to think that this is a good idea. EPA is committed to listening to all voices? They are holding a public hearing in a town of 109 people to assure that no dissenting voices are heard. The only costly and time-consuming part of this process will be cleaning up the mess that PLP leaves behind. There is no way to create an open-pit mine in a pristine watershed, and then store tailings and acid waste behind earthen dams on a known sesimic faultline.  Good luck getting PLP to pay for cleaning up anything. 

I heartily oppose withdrawing the EPA's original designation.

Title: Comment submitted by Charles F. Newby President/CEO Colorado Environmental Analytics, LLC
Comment:
Public Comments of Colorado Environmental Analytics, LLC

October 12, 2017

Proposed Pebble Mine
The Proposed Pebble Mine is Against the Interests of the American People, the People of Alaska, and Local AlaskansIncluding Indigenous PeopleLiving Within the Watershed of the Nushagak and Kvichak Rivers
After three years of scientifically rigorous study, the EPA released its final assessment of the proposed Pebble Mine entitled, The Effects of Large Scale Mining on the Salmon Ecosystems of the Nushagak and Kvichak Rivers, in January 2014.  This EPA assessment concluded that, if proposed Pebble Mine operations were to be undertaken, "It is expected that the North Fork Koktuli River ... and much of the Koktuli River would not support salmonids [that is, all forms of salmon] in the short term (less than 10 years)."  Given that the totality of the scientific evidence presented in its assessment indicates complete destruction of Salmon habitat in the watershed, under law, the EPA cannot exempt the proposed Pebble Mine from provisions of the Clean Water Act nor can the agency do anything but recommend against proposed mining operation at the Pebbles Mine.
The Bristol Bay watershed, located in southwestern Alaska, is home to 25 federally recognized tribal governments representing Alaska Native peoples who have maintained a salmon-based way of life for the last 4,000 years, at least, probably for much longer.  Clearly, large-scale mining operations in the watershed proposed by the Pebbles Mine will destroy the sustainability of Bristol Bay's world-class commercial, recreational, as well as the subsistence fisheries upon which the future of Alaska Native tribes in the watershed depends.  Given the potential impact on the way of life of Alaskan Native peoples, under law, the EPA cannot allow the proposed Pebbles Mine to move forward in any form.

The proposed Pebbles Mine project, with mineral rights, is controlled by Canadian, British, Australian, and Japanese corporations; therefore, little economic benefit will accrue to the United States yet the Alaskan people living within the watershed will bear a tremendous burden as their way of life is destroyed.

The Arguments Made by Pebble Mine Proponents Are Specious
Proponents of the Pebble Mine claim that the mine would provide significant tax revenue to the State of Alaska; however, no amount of tax revenue accruing from proposed mining operations can offset the costs that local, state, and federal governments would bear as the Bristol Bay watershed is destroyed.

Proponents of the Pebble Mine claim that the mine will create well-paying jobs in an increasingly poverty-stricken regionroughly 2,000 jobs for construction, dropping to 1,000 permanent jobs during the 30 to 60-year expected life span of the mine.  However, the returning salmon and other ecological resources of the Bristol Bay watershed creates more than 14,000 full and part-time jobs, generates approximately $480 million annually, and supports a 4,000-year-old Alaska Native way of life.
Proponents of the Pebble Mine claim that the mine would provide a domestic resource of important raw materials thus lowering the United States reliance on foreign sources.  However, because markets for these and similar raw materials are global, such claims are clearly specious.  Furthermore, such a "domestic resource of raw materials" does not now exist nor will mining operations at the proposed Pebble Mine create one.

EPA Must Follow Mandates Established by Law

Environment Protection Agency Mandates Established by Law
By law, it is the mandate of the EPA to protect both the health of the American people and the environment of the United States and its territories.  Protecting the American people from significant health risks requires that the EPA must develop science-based regulations that are protective of the environment, wherever people live, work, and learn.  

Assault on the Environment Protection Agency Must Stop Immediately
The Trump/Pence Administration's unnecessary assault on the EPA is against the interests of the American people in that the assault directly undermines the fundamental basis of human health; the assault promotes the continuation of the widespread pollution of critical segments of the county's environment; and, to the extent that the administration deliberately fails to uphold environmental protection law, the assault is clearly unlawful.  For the reasons cited above, the Trump/Pence Administration must immediately stop its increasingly unlawful assault on the Environmental Protection Agency and its mission!

Submitted by,
Charles F. Newby
President/CEO
Colorado Environmental Analytics
Evergreen, Colorado

Title: Anonymous Public Comment
Comment: The proposed Clean Water Act determination should NOT be withdrawn.  The potential impacts of the proposed Pebble Mine on the health of the Bristol Bay watershed and the livelihood of thousands of people in Alaska are far too great. Those risks include loss of up to up to 94 miles of salmon-supporting streams and up to 4,900 acres of wetlands and ponds, and the very real potential of wastewater dam failure resulting in damage to or destruction of the salmon fishery.  The watershed supports the largest sockeye salmon fishery in the world and 25 federally recognized tribes who for 4,000 years have depended on the fishery for their subsistence-based culture. The overwhelming majority of residents of Bristol Bay are opposed to the project, and a statewide majority of voters also oppose it. The watersheds unique ecological resources generate significant economic benefits and employment.  EPAs original watershed assessment was scientifically robust and thoroughly peer-reviewed.  That assessment and related public comments should strongly influence any future action.

Title: Comment submitted by C. Lawrence
Comment:
Administrator E. Scott Pruitt
Dear Administrator Pruitt,
This is a very bad idea! Not only will an open pit mine scar this
beautiful land, it will negatively affect the abundant salmon
population (some of the most abundant in the world)! It will also be a
devastating blow to Native communities who rely on this salmon for
their livelihoods, as well as sustenance.
I write in support of the communities of Alaska's Bristol Bay and ask
you not to withdraw the proposed determination to adopt restrictions
protecting the habitat of Bristol Bay's world-renowned salmon.
The proposed determination was made at the request of local communities
and adopted only after years of rigorous scientific study, public
participation and peer review. The EPA was correct in 2014 when it
found that the Pebble Mine would have "significant and
unacceptable adverse effects" on "one of the most productive,
pristine, valuable and vulnerable ecosystems remaining in North America
today."
The EPA has noted that commercial fishing in Bristol Bay generates $300
million annually in direct sales of commercially caught salmon,
generating 11,000 jobs. These salmon support not only the commercial
and sportfishing industries, but a traditional Native way of life that
has endured for millennia and thrives today.
The EPA should stand by its proposed determination and take all
necessary actions to protect the Bristol Bay watershed.
Sincerely,
Conor Lawrence

Title: Comment submitted by J. Vilders
Comment:
To Scott Pruitt 

 The proposed Clean Water Act determination should NOT be removed. The proposed impacts of the Pebble Mine on the Bristol Bay Area and the livelihood of those depending on it is tremendous.

The science is CLEAR:  this area is home to the largest salmon run in the world; 31 Alaskan tribes depend on this area not only for their food, but their living; this area provides habitat for 29 fish species, 190 bird species,and over  40 terrestrial animal species; all 5 species of salmon spawn and rear in the Bristol Bay watershed.

How can you believe that an open pit mine that is 7 miles in area and 3/4 mile deep will not have a NEGATIVE impact on the above statements?  What science can you send me that proves otherwise.  How can you believe that the tailings, runoff, road building, additional infrastructure will not NEGATIVELY impact human and animal existence?  Please send me the science; not the economic benefit for one company and a few investors. 

Scott Pruitt and this administration needs to look into the future of our planet and make the ethical decision for Alaska and our planet.
Jane Vilders,  concerned citizen

Title: Comment submitted by C. Becker
Comment:
Dear Administrator, 

I'm writing in reference to Docket # EPA-HQ-ORD-2012-0276. Please prohibit the disposal of mine waste in Alaska's Bristol Bay watershed. NGOS have been working hard to protect this vital wildlife area from the Pebble Mine project from years. If allowed to go through, the Pebble Mine project would prove disastrous on an ecological and economic level. This project presents a long-term risk to the sustainability of this important fishery, and all the people and businesses that rely on it. The current protections must remain in order to protect a significant sockeye salmon population. In 2010, Bristol Bay salmon fishermen harvested 29 million sockeye salmon worth $165 million in direct harvest value alone -- 31% of the total Alaska salmon harvest value.

For many people, the Bristol Bay area is a source of necessary sustainable income and healthy food unavailable through other means. Many families rely on wild salmon as a uniquely nutritious source of protein, rich in essential omega-3 fats and vitamin D. Farmed salmon is not nutritionally identical (much lower in vitamin D, much higher in saturated fats and pro-inflammatory omega-6 fats) and poses its own environmental risks. I urge the EPA to take immediate action to use existing provisions of the Clean Water Act to protect this large and irreplaceable wild salmon fishery. 

Sincerely, 
Christine Becker
Boulder, CO 80301

Title: Comment submitted by A. Winter
Comment:
Hi,
My name is Amy Winter and I am from Atlanta, Georgia and I am vehemently opposed to the Pebble Mine initiative for the following reasons:

The potential impacts of the proposed Pebble Mine on the health of the Bristol Bay watershed and the livelihood of thousands of people in Alaska are too great to accept:

The watershed supports the largest sockeye salmon fishery in the world.

The watershed is home to 25 federally recognized tribal governments who have maintained a salmon-based culture and subsistence-based way of life for at least 4,000 years that would be placed in jeopardy.

The watershed's ecological resources generated nearly $480 million in direct economic expenditures and sales and provided employment for over 14,000 full- and part-time workers in 2009.4

Contrary to comments by the backers of the Pebble Mine project, EPA's watershed assessment was scientifically based and thoroughly peer-reviewed, and the public has had an extensive opportunity to comment on it. The assessment and public comments received should be key components of any future action on this issue.

The overwhelming majority of residents of Bristol Bay are opposed to the project.5  A statewide majority of voters also oppose it, as evidenced by the 2014 State-wide ballot measure.6

The rationale for the proposed withdrawal is flawed. Finalizing the proposed determination would provide much more regulatory certainty than withdrawing it, and a permit application is not needed to augment the factual record.

Listed below are the resources for the facts above. 

Thank you,
Amy Winter

1 U.S. EPA. An Assessment of Potential Mining Impacts on Salmon Ecosystems of Bristol Bay, Alaska (Final Report). U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Washington, DC, EPA 910-R-14-001A-C, ES, 2014.

2 EPA Region 10, Proposed Determination Pursuant to Section 404(c) of the Clean Water Act for Pebble Deposit Area, Southwest Alaska, July 21, 2014.  https://www.epa.gov/bristolbay/2014-proposed-determination-pursuant-section-404c-clean-water-act-pebble-deposit-area.

3 2017 EPA and Pebble Limited Partnership Agreement. https://www.epa.gov/sites/production/files/2017-05/documents/pebble-settlement-agreement-05-11-17.pdf

4 U.S. EPA. An Assessment of Potential Mining Impacts on Salmon Ecosystems of Bristol Bay, Alaska (Final Report). U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Washington, DC, EPA 910-R-14-001A-C, ES, 2014. Chapter 5.

Title: Anonymous Public Comment
Comment:
Dear President Trump, Administrator Pruitt, and Acting Region 10 Administrator Pirzadeh:

I am outraged that you plan to reverse course and green-light the proposed Pebble Mine, despite the catastrophic risks it poses to Alaska's Bristol Bay watershed, its world-renowned salmon runs, and its Native communities. 

President Obama's Environmental Protection Agency proposed common-sense restrictions that would have banned this dangerous mine because of the obvious environmental risks it would pose. The EPA's recent settlement with Northern Dynasty Minerals to reverse those common-sense restrictions is a blatant giveaway to the mining industry at the expense of the American people, our environment, and our economy.

Bristol Bay's wild salmon fishery supports 14,000 jobs and is valued at more than $1.5 billion annually. It also supplies nearly half of the world's sockeye salmon. More than 65 percent of Alaskans, 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents and Native communities, and 85 percent of commercial fishermen oppose the mine.

I urge you to listen to those voices, and for the sake of the Bristol Bay watershed, its world-class salmon fishery, and its people, keep the door closed on Pebble Mine. If you don't, you will have to answer to me and hundreds of thousands of people in Alaska and across the United States and the world who stand in fervent opposition to this toxic mega-mine.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I am writing you today to ask that you stand with American jobs and communities and not withdraw the Bristol Bay Proposed Determination, which it made pursuant to the Clean Water Act in 2014.

As you know, Bristol Bay, Alaska, is one of America's last great wild salmon fisheries. Tens of millions of wild salmon return annually, which support upwards of 14,000 American jobs in the commercial and sport fishing industries, serve as a one-in-a-lifetime destination for anglers from around the world, and are the cultural cornerstone for the region's communities.

These long-established American businesses and jobs are at risk from a foreign-owned mining company that wants to build the proposed Pebble Mine, which is opposed by more than 65 percent of Alaskans and more than 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents. 

In 2010, led by Alaska Native Tribes, interests including commercial fishing business owners and sportsmen asked the EPA step in to ensure that this mine wouldn't jeopardize Bristol Bay. The EPA responded by listening to over 1.5 million Americans, hosting dozens of community meetings, reviewing Pebble's many detailed filings with state and federal agencies, and conducting a twice peer-reviewed scientific assessment of the potential impacts to the region.

Withdrawing the proposed determination ignores the overwhelming majority of Alaskans and puts the short-term interests of a foreign mining company above thousands of American jobs. 

Please do not withdraw the proposed determination.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
Do not withdraw the proposed determination to restrict the use of an area as a disposal site pertaining to the proposed Pebble Mine. The CWA section 404 allows the EPA to override the Corp and veto the "404 permit for dredge and fill discharge if it is having or will have an unacceptable adverse effect on municipal water supplies, shellfish beds and fishery areas (including spawning and breeding areas), wildlife, or recreational areas," (EPA). The EPA's 3 year study of the area showed negative impacts on water from the start and it's their duty to use the 404-C veto in such large scale projects, in highly valued areas, with relatively high possibilities of catastrophic events. Have no doubt that this is a highly valued area because of both its intrinsic and economic value. Extensive studies done pertaining to the environmental externalities that would be associated with mining in the area, prove over and over that mining here is a terrible decision. Also from an economic standpoint it is stated that the mine will only provide 1,000 temporary jobs, but it will threaten 14,000 commercial fishing jobs that are a part of the local salmon fishery (Bautista). While this fishing industry will likely be wiped out as the salmon spawning grounds are poisoned from the mine and its disposal site. 
So it is the EPA's duty not to withdraw the proposed determination in this case, because the Pebble Mine needs to be stopped before it even has a chance to start due to the extensive and negative impacts it would have on human-environmental health; and the health of the commercial fishing industry.

Bautista, Kendall. Hunting, Fishing coalition urges presidential canidates to oppose Pebble Mine. News Station. Anchorage: KTUU, 2016. 3 March 2016. <http://www.ktuu.com/news/news/hunting-fishing-coalition-urges-presidential-candidates-to-oppose-pebble-mine/38198298>.

Title: Comment submitted by W. Dokai
Comment:
Hello,

My Name is William Dokai and I am an undergraduate fisheries biology student. I am writing today to urge that the current EPA respect years of scientific review that found that the risk posed by a potential mining project in the Pebble deposit was too great to risk. There is currently no evidence to support the claim that a mine here can be created and operated without causing severe, perhaps even devastating, and long lasting negative effects to the salmon, and water quality of the Bristol Bay watershed. Bristol Bay is a unique location, home to nearly half of the global abundance of sockeye salmon on the planet. It is simply irreplaceable as a natural resource, and a biological wonder. As such, the Bristol Bay area is far too important to risk by allowing a mining project to go forward. I strongly and wholeheartedly oppose the withdrawal of clean water protection for Bristol bay. It is simply too risky to create mine waste, which would last and remain potent for hundreds of years, upstream and uphill from the world's most productive salmon habitat. The mining waste would need to be contained, and mine drainage mitigated in perpetuity all in a seismically active, and remote wilderness, for hundreds of years. There is simply no precedent suggesting this can be done, and as such, a mine here is absolutely too much of a liability to allow. Please respect the years of scientific review that concluded that Bristol Bay deserves Clean Water Act protection.

Thank you for your time,
William Dokai

Title: Comment submitted by A. Dedman-Tillemans
Comment:
Like a beacon, under scrutiny for mining of copper resources, stands the Bristol Bay area. For thousands of years, supporting the long term health of communities, this area has been and continues to be a rich natural resource for fish and wildlife, including one of the richest salmon spawning grounds in the world. This proposal will remove the Proposed Determination of the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency Region 10 Pursuant to Section 404(c) of the Clean Water Act Pebble Deposit Area, Southwest Alaska (July 2014), which would have served to protect this watershed from exploitation and destructive practices; while, the Pebble Limited Partnership, seeking private profit in a relatively short term, tells us that the area is depressed and people need jobs. This, they tell us, even though the jobs will be gone when the boom is over and the lands and waters fouled forever. 

The associated earthen dam alone, which will be expected to hold toxic sludge and tailings byproducts from the copper sulfide mining, into perpetuity, could not stand the test of time in this ecologically fragile area located in an earthquake zone. In addition, repercussions from an onslaught of torrential rains and weather conditions over time associated with a changing climate can be guaranteed. A failed dam would be tragic enough, but this does not preclude ongoing degradation during construction, operation and maintenance from blasting, transportation corridors, dewatering, dispersal of contaminants into the watershed, noise pollution and air pollution in the midst of a pristine invaluable natural environment. Fifteen years of research and study into a copper sulfide mine's possible effects in this sensitive area have only made the proposed mine more toxic.

Copper-sulfide mining in the Bristol Bay watershed would be devastating on our fresh water resources, the health of communities who depend on this watershed, the flora, fauna, unspoiled lakes, like Lake Iliamna, the long term profitability and viability of world class salmon and sports fishing, tourism and natural habitats. As if these things were not enough, how does monetary profit compare to true wealth? Do we choose short term boom and bust economies over the health of our planet? What is true wealth but an environment like that in the Bristol Bay watershed; and who in their right mind would give this up for any amount of financial gain? This watershed would be changed forever by permitting any copper sulfide mine to operate within its boundaries. 

I formally and respectfully request that the proposal herewith to withdraw proposed 404(c) protections for the Bristol Bay area be denied. The withdrawal legalese found under the name "Proposed Determination to Restrict Use of Area as Disposal Site: Pebble Deposit Area, Southwest Alaska; Proposed Withdrawal" will allow the permitting process for this mine to begin, an outcome that we cannot sanction for the sake of future generations who depend upon decisions we make today. 

Anita Suzanne Dedman-Tillemans
October 12, 2017

These long-established businesses are at risk from a foreign-owned mining company that wants to build the proposed Pebble Mine, which is opposed by more than 65 percent of Alaskans and more than 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents. 

In 2014, led by Alaska Native Tribes, interests including commercial fishing business owners and sportsmen asked the EPA step in to ensure that this mine wouldn't jeopardize Bristol Bay. The EPA responded by listening to over 1.5 million Americans, hosting dozens of community meetings, reviewing Pebble's many detailed filings with state and federal agencies, and conducting a twice peer-reviewed scientific assessment of the potential impacts to the region. Withdrawing the proposed determination ignores the overwhelming majority of Alaskans and puts the short-term interests of a foreign mining company above thousands of local jobs. 

For the sake of our wildlife, waterways, and communities, I urge you to protect Bristol Bay and prevent this horrible open-pit mine from destroying one of our nation's most precious ecosystems.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment: When my family lived in Alaska, my dad was a part of the coast guard, and my mom worked day and night shifts at the local hospital. It was hard, they were poor, and unable to leave their situation until they saved up enough money. Even with that pressure, even with their destitution, even though they got to see each other but once a month, they still have fond memories of Alaska. Its lands are beautiful, snowy places, huge forests and lakes teeming with unique wildlife you can see nowhere else. My dad is still proud of a 'Bear Survival Guide' he brought from up there! All of that would be ruined with the death of this bill. Corporations are lining up to mine, drill, and chop down the Alaskan wilderness, and have proven time and time again that they cannot be trusted to preserve the environment. It is more than within your power to stop this lake from dying, to stop the erosion of our beautiful wildlife by greed and money, and all you have to do is keep this bill active. Preserve the environment, preserve our memories, and most of all, preserve this bill. Thank you very much.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
EPA. Environmental Protection Agency. Let me repeat that. ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AGENCY. Because it seems
 you have forgotten the purpose of your agency. It is to "PROTECT" the environment on behalf of the citizens of the America. 
Not protect the interests of the mining and oil industry. You have such a blatant disregard for this planet, you actually despise 
this planet yet love the fossil fuel and mining industry. Explain to me how this is in the best interest of the country, the land, 
the environment, the water shed, the ocean, the salmon. I only see this as being in the best interest of the mining company and 
your own personal interests and those of your friends. After a private meeting with the Pebble mining executive you 
sign this order. Talk about a backdoor backroom deal. The only interest you have is to open as much land to mining and fossil 
fuel extraction as possible. With absolutely no regard to the environment or climate. Your actions are on behalf of the fossil fuel 
and mining industry. In absolute contradiction to the purpose of this agency. You're a sickening disgrace. Explain how the  heavy metals 
brought to the surface and dumped in the watershed are a benefit to the environment. Explain how molybdenum , which exposure can cause 
severe health issues and even death.Is a benefit.  Living next to a molybdenum plant I saw the devastating health effects it had on cattle. That were exposed
to it by drinking contaminated water. Then eating hay from contaminated fields. Waiting to hear how this is a benefit to the 
environment or to the citizens of this country. Explain how the profits of Pebble benefit the environment or enhance national security
They don't. You have total disregard for the Native American community which considering who you are this isn't surprising. 
The impact on the fishing industry as a whole will be devastating. The salmon as a whole will be wiped out. Your total disregard for the scientific
community is sickening and is a dereliction of your duty. The only compassion you have is for your own interests and those of the mining and fossil fuel industry.
The damage you are doing is irreversible. You don't even care. You're a disgrace.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I am writing to express my deep concern over the EPA's proposal to reverse its decision to protect Bristol Bay from all mining activity under section 404(c) of the Clean Water Act. Bristol Bay should continue to be protected and Scott Pruitt's attempt to allow for a mine the size of Manhattan and the depth of the Grand Canyon to be built in the last wild and unadulterated salmon run left in the world is wrong. Not only is it wrong but it is in DIRECT VIOLATION OF THE EPA'S MISSION to protect and restore the environment for current and future generations based on scientifically sound data. 

Bristol Bay is some of the last remaining pristine wildlands of our country, as well as an economic powerhouse supporting tens of thousands of jobs. In 2010 the Bristol Bay Regional Seafood Development Association executive summary demonstrated the creation of $1.5 billion in output and sales values that was felt across the whole of the United States. While the Pebble Mine would have economic benefits, they would be brief in comparison to the sustainability of the salmon industry in Bristol Bay. We have a country littered with closed mines that continue pollute our lands and harm our communities. Let us not be so short-sighted but learn the lessons our past has to teach us about stewardship of land and its' resources.

Please, DO NOT REVERSE the decision to protect Bristol Bay!

Because it seems as though the EPA's administrator, Scott Pruitt, has not read the findings of his own agency on this matter I have attached that document here as well as the report on the economic benefits of the salmon industry of Bristol Bay.

Title: Comment submitted by E. Kizzia
Comment:
To the EPA,

I am concerned about the proposed withdrawal of the protections in place at the Pebble Deposit Area, and I urge you to keep the protections in place. I was born and raised in Homer, Alaska and grew up taking the Bristol Bay salmon fishery for granted. Practically every family I knew fished there commercially for sockeye salmon that fed the world -- it is the livelihood of our community and so many others in Alaska. My friends who grew up working on their family's commercial boats learned discipline and hard work and could see an economic future for themselves from an early age. It's a rare gift to be able to provide that for a kid growing up in our country today. Even though some of them may not have felt that college was their path, through that hard work and dedication and love of the fishing industry, they can thrive as lifelong fishermen. How many industries in our country can say the same? In a world where technology accelerates so much faster than many people can keep up with, the Bristol Bay salmon fishery is a constant for so many of us. 

I never considered that all this could one day be in jeopardy. It has been proven over and over that Pebble Mine poses an enormous risk to the Bristol Bay watershed, no matter which way you look at it. Not only is the Bristol Bay salmon fishery an incredible and sustainable economic powerhouse of our state, it also provides so many of those things that can't be measured -- a sense of place and belonging, truly sustainable vocational work, economic independence for those who depend on it, a connection to our food, an opportunity for kids to grow up knowing how to work hard, environmental stewardship. These are things that the Pebble Mine can never give Alaska, and the Pebble Mine will not last forever. The Bristol Bay watershed, which can last forever if we protect it, should be allowed to do so. Please make the right decision and protect this area.

Sincerely,
Emily Kizzia

Title: Comment submitted by J. Olson
Comment:
The EPA should move forward with its Proposed Determination (PD) under Clean Water Act Section 404(c) to protect the Bristol Bay Watershed.  Large scale mining operations should not be located in the sensitive and unique ecosystems of Bristol Bay.  The Proposed Determination is a clear case for using Section 404(c) to give an advanced decision to preclude unacceptable impacts.
 The EPA conducted a thorough, multiyear scientific investigation of the Bristol Bay Watershed and potential impacts from the mining proposals.  EPA concluded that mining operations would cause unacceptable adverse effects on fish and animal habitats in the Bristol Bay Watershed.  The magnitude of the projected environmental impacts are well documented in EPA's peer reviewed report, and these losses will be irreversible. Impacts to sockeye salmon will be extreme.  Anyone who has followed the loss of salmon in Europe, followed by losses in North America's Atlantic Ocean, and finally the losses and continuing impacts to salmon in the Pacific Ocean and its watersheds in the western United States and Canada should recognize that our opportunities to sustain salmon are rapidly disappearing.  Failure to learn from our past mistakes by allowing more impacts to salmon from proposed mining is both ignorant and unforgivable.
EPA should move forward on this PD because it already followed an extensive public process on this matter, and it is a waste of government resources to ignore the existing scientific work and its conclusions and to begin a new project review process.  EPA provided opportunities for public comment on two draft scientific assessments.  The EPA followed the Clean Water Act and its procedures.  In fact, EPA went above and beyond the required procedures and offered two draft reports for public comment prior to publishing its final assessment. No information or evidence as to why the existing scientific assessment is flawed has been presented. The process to date - with EPA's publication of the Final Bristol Bay Assessment in January 2014 -- was a fair process and compliant with the Clean Water Act. The existing EPA assessment is a thorough and legitimate basis for moving forward with the Clean Water Act 404(c) protections. 
Thank you for consideration of these comments.
John Olson, Winthrop, Washington

Title: Comment submitted by S. O'Neal
Comment:
Water Docket, United States Environmental Protection Agency
Mail Code 28221T
1200 Pennsylvania Ave NW
Washington DC 20460
Attn:  Docket ID No. EPA-R10-OW-2017-0369

To Whom It May Concern:

I am utterly dismayed at having to write EPA yet again in regards to the extremely thorough, extensively peer reviewed Bristol Bay Watershed Assessment and resulting Proposed Determination to limit discharge of dredged or fill material in the Bristol Bay watershed.  I am a freshwater ecologist who has conducted research on the proposed Pebble site for a decade where I collect and analyze data regarding physical habitat, water chemistry, primary producers (diatoms including algae), aquatic insects, and fish.  Our dataindeed ALL relevant data meticulously reviewed by EPA under the previous administrationclearly indicate, beyond doubt, that even the smallest mine described by Pebble proponents simply can NOT be built without harm to salmon and the habitat upon which they rely.

I am writing to request that you finalize the Proposed Determination once and for all, and limit discharge of dredged of filled material as described within.

When I started work on the Pebble site in 2009, I was legitimately unbiased and frankly rather ignorant of the factors related to mining that could put the salmon fishery at risk.  Within the first few days of walking on the siteand nearly sinking to my thighs in the wet, swampy tundraI began to understand the magnitude of subsurface water flow in the region.  It is a giant sponge.  And those characteristics are what will make containment of waste to any one watershed absolutely impossible.  As time went on, I also learned more about the chemistry of the area.  Unfortunately, what so perfectly fosters salmon spawning and rearing also makes waters extremely sensitive to chemical changes resulting from copper-porphyry mining.  The waters lack the ability to buffer acid inevitably generated by all porphyry mining activity.  Waters also lack organic constituents to reduce the toxicity of metals that will be leached by acid if mining occurs.  Consequently, Pebble, or any other large scale mining activity in the area will undoubtedly produce an acidic, toxins-laden environment.  We have learned the hard way in so many other parts of the world that salmon are extremely sensitive to toxins like copper.  At increases of just 2-10 parts per billion of copper (often within legally allowable discharge limits), salmon lose their ability to smell.  Smell is absolutely essential to a salmon's ability to detect prey and mates, and to navigate back to their natal habitat to spawna behavior which has evolved over millennia and is the key to maintaining the genetic and environmental structure necessary for population persistence.  

These risks include only the most basic, lowest level impacts of mine operation itself.  In addition to mine workings, development will require road building and increased access to the area, energy generation, and a deepwater port.  All told, these industrial activities amount to exactly the kinds of habitat degradation that salmon ecologists all agree were responsible for the demise first of Atlantic salmon runs in Europe and the east coast of North America, and then for Pacific salmon of the West Coast.  We have come too far in our understanding both of salmon ecology and population loss globally, and of the specifics of mining in Bristol Bay to discard the work of dozens, if not hundreds, of people over an accumulation of more than a decade.

The science speaks for itself.  While it seems this administration tends to discredit and/or ignore science, it is also important to consider the economics of this project.  As you know, the Bristol Bay commercial salmon fishery alone supports upwards of 14,000mostly AMERICANjobs.  These are jobs that could last centuries into the future given the world-class management of this fishery.  Those jobs are ALL at risk in light of potential mining activities.  And mining jobs would be much fewer and highly specialized, last only decades, and in all likelihood be outsourced to Canadians in many cases, given Canadian ownership of the mine claims.  Given this administration touts their support for American jobsa sentiment which I supportdevelopment of Pebble Mine flies in the face of basic economic arguments.

For these reasons and many, many more, I urge you once again to please provide certainty to the people of the Bristol Bay region, and to those of us globally who depend on the last great runs of wild sockeye salmon, and finalize the Proposed Determination to limit discharge of dredged and filled material.

Thank you kindly for your consideration.

Sincerely,

Sarah O'Neal
PhD Student
Schindler Lab
School of Aquatic and Fishery Sciences
University of Washington
1122 NE Boat St.
Seattle, WA 98105
email: soneal@uw.edu | cell:  (360) 918-4352

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
Having visited the wild salmon watershed area for Bristol Bay Alaska many times I stand in STRONG OPPOSITION to the renewed interest by our Federal Government in allowing the senseless and short sighted opening of this area for mineral exploration and mining.
The truly important natural resource of this area is the native salmon species and their annual migration through this area.  These native fish spawn, hatch and develop in the currently pristine waters of this region.  To risk this self sustaining natural resource in the interest of corporate greed is senseless and criminal.
Too many examples of similar mining endeavors with consequent significant and sustained enviornmental damage already exist.  Corporate bottom line should not outweigh enviornmental integrity and protection.  Those of us in Washington, Oregon and California continue to see our native fish returns dwindle and disappear.
Now is the time to take a firm stand and protect this irreplaceable native salmon resource from likely harm.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
To the EPA, I am strongly against any proposed mining operations being considered int the Pebble Deposit Area in Alaska. I've had the pleasure of visitig that majestic area when I was able to spend time fishing and viewing the bears feed on the salmon. The chances of any gold mining disrupting the natural wonders of this ecosystem are far to high to even consider opening up mining in this area. The mine will do nothing for the world other than enrich those who own the mine. Please do NOT allow this incredible piece of nature be disturbed by something as totally unnecessary as yet another gold mine. Our children deserve to be able to grow up and visit this place. I eagerly wait for the day when I will visit with my daughter and my son and we can capture this priceless experience together.  

Thank you for your readiness to protect the beauty that nature has provided us. 
A concerned Californian Citizen
