Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I am opposed to EPAs proposal to rescind the 2014 Proposed Determination designed to protect Bristol Bays world class fisheries. Please stand with American jobs and communities and preserve the Bristol Bay Proposed Determination.

Stop attacking our environment.  You are supposed to protect it and preserve what we have.  This is just a terrible, harmful idea.


Bristol Bay, Alaska, is one of America's last great wild salmon fisheries. Each year, tens of millions of wild salmon return, supporting upwards of 14,000 jobs in the commercial and sport fishing industries, and serving as a one-in-a-lifetime destination for anglers from around the world as well as the cultural cornerstone for the region's communities. These long-established businesses are at risk from a foreign-owned mining company that wants to build the proposed Pebble Mine, which is opposed by more than 65 percent of Alaskans and more than 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents. 

In 2014, led by Alaska Native Tribes, interests including commercial fishing business owners and sportsmen asked the EPA step in to ensure that this mine wouldn't jeopardize Bristol Bay. The EPA responded by listening to over 1.5 million Americans, hosting dozens of community meetings, reviewing Pebble's many detailed filings with state and federal agencies, and conducting a twice peer-reviewed scientific assessment of the potential impacts to the region. Withdrawing the proposed determination ignores the overwhelming majority of Alaskans and puts the short-term interests of a foreign mining company above thousands of local jobs. 

For the sake of our wildlife, waterways, and communities, I urge you to protect Bristol Bay and prevent this horrible open-pit mine from destroying one of our nation's most precious ecosystems.

Title: Comment submitted by S. A. Silvers
Comment: It is my strong recommendation that the Environmental Protection Agency do everything in its power to prevent any possibility that the proposed Pebble Mine receives any approvals to proceed with construction of this project. Title: Comment submitted by B. Smith
Comment:
Hi, my name is Bryson Smith and I am 10 years old. I oppose removing the Clean Water Act designation. I need you to keep 
the sockeye salmon spawning grounds in Bristol Bay, Alaska protected by the EPA. The thing is, you don't have a deep 
understanding of what is going on there. Almost half of the world's salmon comes from that one spawning ground. And The 
Pebble Mining Company wants to destroy that spawning ground for copper and gold. Even though they think they can mine that 
area safely and not harm the salmon, the way we mine now is blowing up the land. You would think that would be good, but in 
the process heavy metals like mercury, arsenic, and uranium are dispersed into the water because mining companies think that 
the world is a giant trash can for the garbage they blow up. The thing is, is that that trash can is full and nowhere else to put the 
garbage (by the way, there is no space garbage truck). They think they can litter into the salmon populated waters of that bay. 
That would be REALLY bad if you think about it. About half of the world's salmon gone because The Pebble Mining Company 
want nothing else but money and commerce. The sockeye salmon of that area are beautiful fish and do not deserve to go from 
that area.

I am a Pacific Northwest native, and salmon are a vital part of the regional culture, especially the vibrant and uniquely-patterned Sockeye that rely heavily on Bristol Bay's availability and cleanliness for their lifecycle. Allowing for corporate interests to damage and pollute this region would irrevocably threaten and harm salmon across the entire western coast of the continent.

Do not approve this proposal.

Title: Comment submitted by A. Turpening
Comment:
Based on the facts presented in the Assessment of Potential Mining Impacts on Salmon Ecosystems in Bristol Bay, Alaska (EPA 2014), it is a profound mistake to allow the dredging and fill material to be stored in the Koktuli and Upper Talarik rivers.  

The proposed mine's infrastructure and waste would have significant and negative impacts on the ecosystems we thrive on.  Many miles of the surrounding rivers would be rendered uninhabitable, and many fish populations would be destroyed.

While mining the mineral and ore in this region can be valuable, it is not nearly as valuable as the communities and ecosystems this open pit mine may destroy.  The mine that Pebble Limited Partnership is proposing has a negative net present value when taking into account all of the impacts (community, environment, economic, etc.) the mine will have, and is a poor alternative to the current economies that are in this region.

It is possible for mines to operate with minimal environmental impact and still boost the local economy, however the removal of the restrictions on the use of the rivers for dredge and fill is in every way contradictory to conscientious, minimally invasive projects.  Additionally, it is extremely difficult to mitigate the accidental spill of such material in the Pebble area due to the surrounding terrain and conditions.  Indeed, the Pebble Mine executives claim that such mines can be environmentally friendly and work with local fishing populations, such as the Red Dog Mine.  However, the Red Dog Mine released over one billion pounds of toxic chemicals in 2014 alone, making it the largest polluter in the United States at the time.

It is with great sincerity that I ask you to keep the restrictions proposed in the 2014 Proposed determination and not proceed with the 2017 settlement to remove those restrictions.  Pebble Limited Partnership should have to work with these restrictions and respect the surrounding environment.

Aren Turpening
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
My family relies on the Bristol Bay fishery for our livelihood. For decades, my family members have relied on the health and sustainability of Alaska's regulated fisheries. It is very clear the impact a project like the Pebble Mine would have on this unique and powerful environmental resource--there is absolutely no way to deny the impact to local fisheries, fishing communities, native lands and the plants and animals that thrive and rely on Bristol Bay. Bristol Bay is known around the world as a pristine, highly regulated fishery, one of the rare, truly sustainable fisheries that continues to give each season--to feed us, to support us financially, and to enrich our ecosystems. 

The Environmental Protection Agency has it's name for a reason. It is there to protect our environment and the resources that come from our planet. The function of the EPA is not to open doors to massive corporations to develop projects that future generations will need to continuously monitor for decades to come in order to avoid environmental disaster. The function of the EPA is to be grounded in science, not in proposed profits or corporate lobbyists. The EPA can do some of the most critical work in our nation by protecting our water sources. As the EPA, and an American citizen and active voter, I expect you do to do. Recent developments have made us citizens wonder who the EPA is protecting. Removing the protections offered by the the previous administration's EPA (wise as they were) in Bristol Bay is alarming. I do not support the removal of protections the EPA placed in Bristol Bay in 2014. Any advancement of this project is a direct attack on the safety, health, and well-being of American citizens and the environment we all rely on.

Title: Comment submitted by E. Poteet
Comment:
Dear Administrator, 

This comment is in regard to Docket # EPA-HQ-ORD-2012-0276. I support OPPOSING waste disposal into Alaska's Bristol Bay watershed. If Pebble Mine is supported by the EPA, it could become a detrimental long-term risk to sustainability in the area and the economic significance of the fishery that depends on the area fish. A full 31% of the total Alaska salmon harvest value, valued at $165 million for 29 healthy salmon, came from Bristol Bay alone. It is an economic powerhouse and in need of vital economic protection.

Wild salmon is proven to be healthier than farmed salmon. Bristol Bay is obviously a huge provider of nutritious wild salmon. The environment of Bristol Bay and the economic profit it provides should not be devastated in favor of the Pebble Mine. I am asking the EPA to immediately OPPOSE the Pebble Mine and instead support existing provisions of the Clean Water Act to preserve this invaluable wild salmon fishery. 

Sincerely,
Elizabeth Poteet
Canandaigua, NY 14424

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment: The EPA should not withdraw the EPA Region 10 July 2014 Proposed Determination. Polluting these watersheds with mine waste would almost certainly decimate the salmon population, endangering the lives of the citizens that rely on the waters for livelihood and animals that depend on salmon as part of their main diet. The current head of the EPA does not believe in protecting the environment, air, water, or citizens of the this country but would rather make a profit by being in bed with the fossil fuel and mining industries.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
Dear Reader, 

I'm writing in reference to Docket # EPA-HQ-ORD-2012-0276. Please prohibit the disposal of mine waste in Alaska's Bristol Bay watershed. The proposed Pebble Mine presents a long-term risk to the sustainability of this important fishery, and all the people and businesses that rely on it. In 2010, Bristol Bay salmon fishermen harvested 29 million sockeye salmon worth $165 million in direct harvest value alone. That represented 31% of the total Alaska salmon harvest value.

Not only is it a risk to the fisheries, however, but also to public health and safety. Run off from copper mines often contains sulfuric compounds, which usually safely covered by dirt, react with air to form sufuric acid, causing acid drainage. Not only this, but heavy metals, such as copper, found in run off commonly build up in the fatty tissues of forementioned salmon, and, with high enough concentrations, makes these fish dangerous for people to consume, accutely so in the case of pregnant women as will as children. As many families in the area rely upon the  reliability of the wild salmon in the area, you can understand why this is particularly concerning.

By the EPA's own assessment, up to 91 miles of streams and 4,900 acres of wetland, which support 3 Federal Wildlife preserves, may be lost in the event of failure. I urge the EPA to take immediate action to use existing provisions of the Clean Water Act to protect this large and irreplaceable watershed, as such a development is a plea for disaster. Irreplaceable as it is to the state, ecosystem, and people of Alaska, I feel that it is best not to tempt fate, for as long as Murphy's Law applies.

With hopes for both the present and the future, 
A Concerned Resident of the State of New Mexico

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment: I am strongly opposed to the very short-sighted proposal to withdraw the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) restriction of the use of certain waters in the South Fork Koktuli River, North Fork Koktuli River, and Upper Talarik Creek watersheds in southwest Alaska as disposal sites for dredged or fill material associated with mining the Pebble deposit. This proposal would adversely affect the Bristol Bay watershed with consequences to fish populations, including damage to the world's largest salmon runs. The risk of mining effluents escaping planned containments, as well as the damage to one of the last pristine areas in the United States, including flora and fauna, are simply too great to risk.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I am opposed to EPAs proposal to rescind the 2014 Proposed Determination designed to protect Bristol Bays world class fisheries. Please stand with American jobs and communities and preserve the Bristol Bay Proposed Determination.

Bristol Bay, Alaska, is one of America's last great wild salmon fisheries. Each year, tens of millions of wild salmon return, supporting upwards of 14,000 jobs in the commercial and sport fishing industries, and serving as a one-in-a-lifetime destination for anglers from around the world as well as the cultural cornerstone for the region's communities. These long-established businesses are at risk from a foreign-owned mining company that wants to build the proposed Pebble Mine, which is opposed by more than 65 percent of Alaskans and more than 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents. 

In 2014, led by Alaska Native Tribes, interests including commercial fishing business owners and sportsmen asked the EPA step in to ensure that this mine wouldn't jeopardize Bristol Bay. The EPA responded by listening to over 1.5 million Americans, hosting dozens of community meetings, reviewing Pebble's many detailed filings with state and federal agencies, and conducting a twice peer-reviewed scientific assessment of the potential impacts to the region. Withdrawing the proposed determination ignores the overwhelming majority of Alaskans and puts the short-term interests of a foreign mining company above thousands of local jobs. 

For the sake of our wildlife, waterways, and communities, I urge you to protect Bristol Bay and prevent this horrible open-pit mine from destroying one of our nation's most precious ecosystems.

This includes a direct assault against the polar ice cap which is slowly destroying the coastal regions of the United States not to mention its effect on weather patterns and climate change.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
Dear EPA,
I am deeply concerned about the recent trends of the EPA toward reducing environmental protections without adequate scientific reasoning or evidence. I am writing as an environmental scientist and geologist with formal training and scientific  knowledge in these topics. I live in a small city which is hydrologically downstream of several abandoned copper and gold mines, including the superfund site Iron Mountain Mine. The environmental impact of these sites, including their waste disposal areas, is significant and cannot be ignored. They have cost US taxpayers tens of millions of dollars to clean up and cleanup is still a work in progress. They have negatively impacted ground- and surface- waters. They have negatively impacted air quality. And while at one time they provided an economic boom to the area, they now continue to cost us, the citizens, millions. 

I ask  that you maintain the Clean Water Act as it was written and honor its intention. Protect the vital economy generated by the salmon industry in the area of the proposed project. Do not approve mining operations or disposal sites in the Pebble Deposit Area of Southwest Alaska.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
Cutting to the chase: No, do not withdraw any restrictions in  this watershed to enable mining of any sort.

To do so would be an egregious example of short sightedness - sacrificing natural beauty and recreational opportunities that have been in existence for thousands of years to enable profiteering from resources that don't actually seem to even be in short supply.  They just offer a chance to make someone some money today.  I first went fishing in Katmai National Park eight years ago, finally fulfilling one of my bucket list items with a once in a lifetime opportunity to experience the beauty of this land firsthand.  I have just completed my eighth such once-in-a-lifetime trips - as the call of this remote and beautiful landscape is irresistible.  Once destroyed, it can never be replaced.  Yet the mining opportunity will be there forever.  Preferably this land will always remain in its current condition, but if for some reason we actually NEED the resources there why not wait - 50 or even 100 years, when no doubt the innovative miners will have found much better and environmentally friendly ways to extract them?  Again - this mine is a solution in search of a problem - there is no need for this mine at this time, if ever.  I implore you not to destroy one of the most beautiful places in America, if not on the planet, in favor of nominal profiteering.  To do so would surely change this natural wonder from "Seward's Folly" to "Pruitt's and Trump's Folly.

Again - NO!

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
Please preserve the Bristol Bay area.  Sockeye salmon is a hugely important part of our ecology throughout the western coast of the pacific ocean.  Allowing these areas to be filled with refuse from mining operations would destroy generations of sockeye salmon, and other fish.  It will decimate fishing jobs in the region and greater areas of the pacific northwest.  It will further harm indigenous peoples that we have already done enough damage too.

I am thoroughly opposed as a registered U.S voter, to the withdrawal EPA Region 10 July 2014 Proposed Determination.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment: I am opposed to EPAs proposal to rescind the 2014 Proposed Determination. This is a completely irrational decision. The short-term monetary benefits from mining these areas are minimal compared to the potential long-term threat of irreversible damage to the area, its inhabitants, and the wildlife of Southwest Alaska. Please do your job and stand up for the people of the United States instead of catering to large, destructive companies.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
Currently, the Bristol Bay Salmon fishery employs thousands of people and plays a large part in the state economy. I live in Kodiak, Alaska ( far from Bristol Bay) and know local fishermen who depend on the Bristol Bay fishery for income. It is one of the last great salmon fisheries in the world.

By comparison, an open pit mine is a short term, low gain, high risk enterprise that would only benefit a few people. Why are we still having to consider this possibility? Open pit mines, whatever size, are a threat to the environment. There are no minerals or metals critical to our nation's needs to be found in the area- this is about greed.

There is no such thing as a mining operation that does not adversely affect the environment no matter how many safety precautions are taken or "environmental standards" are adhered to. Lets quit kidding ourselves- this is about the future of salmon in Bristol Bay.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment: The withdrawal of this proposal has the potential to destroy the livelihood of my family and friends. I am begging that the EPA and Trump administration listen to our fishermen & businesses before removing the environmental rules that protect Bristol Bay. If you remove these rules, you may very well destroy one of the most profitable and sustainable fisheries in the world. Not to mention you would ruin the lives of thousands of Americans.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment: I haven't done a whole lot of research on the situation, so I apologize for the uncited details. But you're proposing to lift protection on a body of water that supplies a large amount of food and revenue for the locals in favor of creating revenue for other parties? These protections were established after years of research done by the Obama Administration, and the proposal is coming out of a meeting between the head of the EPA and a subsidiary to the company that has been lobbying for mining rights for years? If the head of the Environmental Protection Agency does not actually care about the environmental research done in regards to this subject, then maybe he should care about the basic principles of resources- when you remove a food source like salmon it has to be replaced with an alternative food source. So before the EPA is allowed to destroy years of rational protection laws, they should have to propose equivalent rational replacement plans. Without these proposals the EPA should be blocked on removing any previously placed protection on the Bristol Bay Area.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
The fishing industry and our planet as a whole cannot withstand the loss of more salmon habitat. Salmon are the very definition of a keystone species responsible for the movement of nutrients from the ocean into the upper elevations. No pit mine has ever been safe or clean, period. I grew up in Arizona surrounded by open pit copper mines that devastated our landscape, poisoned our streams, and eliminated the traditional practices of Native Americans (access to which is legally obligated under international law). These pit mines in Arizona are so hated that one of the largest groups opposing any new mine development is a coalition of retired mine workers who do not wish for their children or anyone's children to work in the conditions that they did. We have lost so much to mining in the west and many other countries (Australia, New Guinea, Chile) continue to lose their natural places. This is why our country set itself apart by forming the EPA. It is moments like this, when the greed of a few threaten the simple lives and sacred places of many, for which this department was founded. Please do what is right and deny the Pebble Mine their permit. The scientists have already submitted their work over the past three years. There is no ambiguity here. Pebble Mine would do irreparable damage to the most valuable fishery in the world. As a citizen of the Northwest (Spokane, WA) I know the value of wild salmon to the overall ecosystem. We cannot allow Alaska to lose the fish runs that we once had here in Washington and Idaho.

God bless America, let's try to save some of it.

P.S. Remove the four Lower Snake River dams.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment submitted by M. Baxter
Comment:
I strongly oppose the EPA's proposal to withdraw the 2014 Clean Water Act Proposed Determination, which would, if finalized, have imposed restrictions on the discharge of dredged or fill material associated with the potential "Pebble Mine" in Alaska's Bristol Bay watershed. 

Rather, I strongly support the Proposed Determination and the associated restrictions to the potential "Pebble Mine". Please listen to the scientific evidence and all the fisherman and businesses that oppose the Proposed Withdrawal before removing the science-based environmental rules that protect Alaska's Bristol Bay and the livelihoods of thousands of fishermen who fish in the watershed as well as the ESA-listed fishes that inhabit that system. Please do not allow this proposed mine, which the EPA itself determined could destroy 24 to 94 miles of salmon-producing waterways and pristine environment even using safe mining practices, to ruin an economically, socially, and environmentally important part of our country just to allow a private, foreign company to profit. That is irresponsible, disrespectful, and does not support American values.
Thank You,
Mackenzie Baxter
Fisheries Biologist, Oregon
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: , Mackenzie Baxter
Comment: Opening the door for the world's most pristine ecosystem for wild salmon to be destroyed so a foreign mining company can build a copper mine of marginal value would  be one of the stupidest and most corrupt decisions in the history of this country.  EPA should be ashamed of this proposal.  "Drain the swamp" in this case means the EPA should do its job and protect the environment rather than help wealthy corporate donors line their pockets.  "America first" means protecting American jobs.  The inevitable degradation this misguided project would cause to a pristine ecosystem would cause far more jobs to be lost in the fishing and tourism industry than it would create. This company is not even American!  Do the right thing and scrap this proposal!

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment: I do NOT want the EPA to withdraw the July 2014 Proposed Determination to restrict mining of the Pebble deposit. The proposed mining project, or any other mining project in the watershed, would inevitably result in irreparable damage to Bristol Bay salmon fisheries. The Bristol Bay salmon fishery generates massive revenue and thousands of jobs while providing a valuable food source to Alaskans and a sustainable seafood source for the entire United States. Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
The July 2014 Proposed Determination under the Clean Waters Act was the correct decision and should be upheld indefinitely. That decision was based on proven science and thorough analysis of the South Fork Koktuli River, North Fork Koktuli River, and Upper Talarik Creek watersheds. To reverse the decision based on the findings of the environmental impact study would only benefit one party, PLP. However, it would devastate some of the worlds most fertile watersheds and cripple communities, households and sustainable industries that rely on the resources in southwest Alaska.

If the withdrawal is made, against the wishes and pleading hearts of hundreds of thousands of people, the Administrator should review and reconsider the withdrawal decision. The Administrator should take into consideration each and every comment provided by opponents to this decision. The Administrator should look at the reason why a withdrawal of this decision would be made, and consider that PLP's greed is the only explanation. The EPA made its decision in 2014, and that should have been final. The withdrawal of that decision will completely discredit the EPA, turning it into an agency that doesn't stand behind its decisions because of what a foreign corporation wants.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment submitted by L. Knowles
Comment:
Dear EPA,
I just spent $2000 on a weeklong fishing trip on the Naknek River. It was incredible - we caught huge rainbow trout and dolly varden, saw dozens of brown bears, and the remnants and benefits of a record salmon year for the region. What, ultimately, made this possible? Clean water. I urge you to maintain your restriction on mine development in the ecologically sensitive, undeveloped, and economically important headwaters of Bristol Bay. As we've seen with Mt. Polley in Canada and even the Berkeley Pit in Montana, gold mining is a terrible deal for locals and people who care about a place, instead benefitting massive international mining corporations. Please join me and millions of other tourists (and thousands of locals) in saying no to Pebble Mine - at any size - and all other mines like it in Bristol Bay.

Lucas Knowles
1146 S Street
Anchorage, AK 9501

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment: I vehemently oppose the  withdrawal the EPA Region 10 July 2014 Proposed Determination. Title: Comment submitted by A. Spidle

The determination to restrict use of Pebble Deposit area as a disposal site should absolutely not be withdrawn.

Title: Comment submitted by A. Brown
Comment:
To Mr. Pruitt and Colleagues at the EPA:

I ask that you do not approve Pebble Limited Partnership's application to mine metals and minerals in Bristol Bay. As a citizen, professional, and mother concerned about the health and future of our nation, I vote in every election--local and national--and reach out to my elected officials frequently. It is out of concern for the U.S. environment and economy that I state my strong opposition to the project, for the following reasons:

1.	The mining would cause harm to the aquatic environment by introducing foreign contaminants. 
2.	Chemical contaminants and mechanical processes would be disastrous to the health of native species, specifically the sockeye salmon beloved by American consumers. Further, through the process of biomagnification, any chemicals consumed by the fish would then be ingested by humans, whose health would be jeopardized. 
3.	Approving the project would be anti-business. Salmon harvests in the Bristol Bay region produce upwards of 200 millions dollars in revenue. Allowing open-pit mining, or mining of any kind, in this region would deal a serious blow to the U.S.'s GDP. 
4.	Allowing any additional pollution of American waters, waters that were pristine at the dawn of this wondrous nation just a few short centuries ago, would be a direct threat to the continued growth of this nation and the immediate health of those living and working in the bay or consuming its products.

I appreciate your careful consideration of this comment, one that represents the voices of so many other friends, family, and colleagues who are firmly against the approval of the Pebble Limited Partnership project. I ask that you consider the health of U.S. citizens, the environment, and the economy in making this decision. It is one in which you can be pro-business (the multi-million dollar sockeye business in Bristol Bay) and pro-health simultaneously, and the right move for this country.

Thank You,

Asia Brown

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment: Please do not withdraw the EPA Region 10 July 2014 Proposed Determination. I would strongly prefer that the determination be kept in place and the water of Bristol bay be protected than allow a Canadian mining company to make more money. The salmon in Bristol bay are an important driver in the region's economy and threatening that stock would have negative consequences for many Americans.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
Please do not sacrifice one of last natural salmon fisheries on the west coast for a commercial mine producing non-vital resources.  The establishment of the Pebble Mine would have disastrous economic, social and ecological effects.

The sustainable salmon industry provides thousands of jobs every year to local communities in the Bristol Bay area.  As the sockeye salmon population would be destroyed by the mine, these jobs would also disappear.

The cultural importance of the fishing industry for all members of the Bristol Bay community should not be downplayed.  For the Native American population, the lifecycle of the salmon has been an intrinsic part of their culture for generations.  There have been articles as recently as December, 2016 in the Journal of Marine and Island Cultures advocating for the importance of fishing in giving communities sense of place and value for their home.  The Pebble Mine would jeopardize those communities.  

The ecological consequences of the Pebble Mine grossly outweigh any potential advantages.  Bristol Bay is home to 56 million sockeye salmon, nearly half the world's population.  As a keystone species, 137 other species depend on the salmon for survival.  This includes other fish, reptiles, and birds including the American bald eagle.  Beyond the direct danger for the salmon, the effects of a mine in a gravel bay like Bristol Bay are unthinkable.  It would be impossible to contain water contamination that could lead to health and safety risks for millions of people. 

I ask you to think about what's at stake in this decision.  Protecting the environment is literally your job.  Allowing Pebble Limited Partnership to continue with their plans would permanently destroy vital habitat for a keystone species along with countless others.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
Frankly, I found the legal mumbo jumbo in this notice difficult to get-through and understand, so let me be clear here. 

There is absolutely no way the proposed Pebble Mine should even be considered, let alone be approved. I find the relaxation of the Sockeye fishery protections to be disturbing, and I find the possibility of an open pit mine (no matter what the size) in this area to be obscene.

Proponents argue that the mine is 100 miles away and the nearby tributaries feed only 1% of the total watershed. If there are no concerns here, then why did the Sockyeye fishery protections go away?

As a Montanan who has seen first-hand reclamation disasters of open pit gold mines (Berkeley Pit Superfund Site), and the cost to the taxpayer (Arco Superfund Site, Pony) for reclamation, this proposal is the classic; greed over common good scenario. 

Anyone with a shred of stewardship in their value system would completely reject the Pebble Mine out-of-hand. I wonder how many people are aware of the thousands of Snow Geese that have been killed just by landing in the Berkeley Pit over the years? A mine that was shut down decades ago.

I hope that clear heads will prevail and this proposal be rejected for what it is; powerful, wealthy interests getting special treatment in the form of relaxed regulations, and flat-out corporate greed.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
Hello,

Thanks for taking the time to review and consider my comments. I will keep this short as I see the large amounts of comments inbound for you to review.

In light of the Settlement Agreement, I firmly believe that the EPA should allow permitting on the Pebble mine to be initiated and for the proposed determination to be based off of the permit application. This enforces my view that the legal and regulatory pathways to development must be respected and adhered to, further the rule of law and equity should be honoured.

Northern Dynasty Minerals deserves the opportunity to rightfully engage all stakeholders and submit a permit application of which future EPA consideration and review should then be based off of. 

I, too, am concerned about our environment but also see a preemptive determination to set a dangerous and imbalanced precedent. 

Thank you for your time

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment: Do not allow development of the Pebble Mine in Alaska in any way, shape, or form.  No economic benefit is worth the level of permanent destruction it would cause to that extremely fragile arctic region.  Not only would it pose an immediate risk to the entire ecosystem -- the fish, fauna, and cultures downstream but there are untold future catastrophes that are likely to be precipitated by the region's extremely active earthquake or volcanic forces no matter how cautious the engineering.  Cleanup, should any such adverse effect transpire, would be impossible and immediately deemed NOT economically viable.  So, too, would the region, equipment, and facilities be abandoned and/or permanently scarred should the price of the minerals plummet.  The monetary benefits to the company, local employment, and Alaska's economies are simply not worth selling the soul of the region.  The region is too valuable in its native, pristine state to risk ending up as a soup of toxic metals like Butte, Montana.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
Do not withdraw the Proposed Determination to Restrict Use of Area as Disposal Site.  Bristol Bay exhibits unparalleled ecological values.  Disposals, fill, sediment, and toxic chemicals kill salmon. Native salmon populations along the eastern Pacific are at risk and this is one of the most productive salmon populations existing.  Over 14,000 people depend on these salmon for their jobs.  Native tribes depend on subsistence lifestyles with salmon as a critical component of their diet and culture.  It is unfathomable that a Federal Government agency such as the EPA is even thinking about disregarding the recommendations of staff and scientists to accommodate the demands of industry over the future of our planet. 

In my lifetime I have witness the demise of salmon.  Little by little, whether it be land use decisions (development), dumping, overfishing, poorly managed forests, dams and water diversion, climate change or other impacts, we are now witnessing population declines in species dependent on salmon, such as the Southern Resident pods of Orcas.  Juvenile Orcas in these pods are dying prematurely due to malnutrition. Salmon is the staple of their diet.

Please do not withdraw the earlier decision.

Title: Comment submitted by J. E. Moloney
Comment:
Mr. Pruitt, and Environmental Protection Agency administrators, 
       I am writing to express my objection to approval of any mining project on the Pebble mineral deposit. The watershed is truly one of the last great places in the world. The ecology and geology of the area are not in any way conducive to any large scal mining or milling/processing opearation. With consideration to the numbers of salmon produces in the rivers that flow in to the Bristol Bay, and the massive fishing industry that revolves around them, including the crabbing, food fish, and gamefishing industries...any accidental discharge of any chemicals in to these pristine rivers would be catastrophic. In that area, all life relies on the salmon. It is imperative that these rivers remain in their pristine condition. I urge you to restore clean water protection to the entire Bristol Bay watershed, and prohibit the Pebble Mine project from ever turning one shovel of dirt.

Sincerely,

Joseph E. Moloney

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I am writing to strongly denounce and disagree with the decision of Scott Pruitt and President Trump's EPA to dismantle the necessary 2014 Clean Water Act Proposed Determination of Bristol Bay's Nushagak and Kvichak watersheds. This is the last place on Earth where an intact ecosystem exists to support culturally, economically, and ecologically critical wild salmon populations. Its destruction is not worth the trade off for more copper and gold on cultural, economic and ecological grounds. There is no way to balance the benefits of developing the mine with its risks and costs. This resource and the ecosystem that supports it is the backbone of Southwest Alaska and the future of wild salmon populations. This designation was determined during a rigorous peer-reviewed scientific process that took place over many years, not to mention the 80 years of fishery data and ecosystem data and analysis to back it up on Bristol Bay's salmon populations. This reeks of yet another example of big mining companies getting their way through their disproportionate influence on politicians and government agencies over the will of the people most dependent on such a resource, and the good sense of science. Has Scott Pruitt seen a map of all recorded earthquakes in Alaska with the location of the proposed Pebble Mine also indicated on the map? This risk by itself (one of many) indicates that a person has to be either crazy, completely blinded by greed, or utterly ignorant to the risks of such a mine to convince themselves that placing a mine of this size and type in this region can be done with no harm to the ecosystem. Its not worth the trade off and in the long run (as in, perpetuity) this mine will cost the people of Alaska, and of the USA, and of the World, the value of gold and copper stored at this site many many times over its value. 

Please, I urge the EPA to keep the 2014 Clean Water Act Designation in Place. There is only one right decision on this issue and the wrong one can't be undone.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
The Clean Water regulations MUST stay in place, and the Pebble mine should be stopped to protect bothe the animals and people of the Bristol Bay region. The long term cost of this mining project (as proposed) will far outweigh the short-term benefits and/or profits associated with the mineral deposits involved, especially the loss of jobs and income related to  the loss of wildlife populations (primarily Pacific salmon species) as well as the sport fishing and hunting industries in the area. 

PLEASE keep this area protected, Alaska is one of the few wild places left in this country.

Title: Comment submitted by G. Matz
Comment:
Water Docket, U.S. Environmental Protection Agency
Mail Code 28221T
1200 Pennsylvania Avenue NW
Washington, DC 20460

Attention: Docket ID No. EPA-R10-OW-2017-0369

Dear EPA:

The bottom-line, with regards to EPA's Clean Water Act authority, is to internalize potential environmental externalities that might occur with any development that requires a Section 404 permit so that these costs (including opportunity costs due to limitations imposed on project development) are borne by the project developer rather than public resources and/or users of those resources.  Adding these costs (which should be considered the actual price of doing business) to a proposed project might make it less attractive economically or even unfeasible, but that choice is the developers as long as EPA does it job and clearly lays out, based on accepted scientific and economic analysis, the boundary between internal and external costs and avoids being hamstrung by politics, which often attempts to blur these boundaries.  If EPA gets too involved in the politics, it risks picking winners and losers, which is not its role. The complexity of this analysis depends on the scale of the project and its potential for damaging public resources and externalizing these diseconomies to the public.  In the case of the proposed Pebble Mine, or any other large mine in the Bristol Bay watershed, a rigorous approach is essential to a legitimate permitting process which serves both the public and responsible project developers and gives needed protection to one of the world's most valuable and sustainable fisheries.

Living in Homer, Alaska, where I can literally see where some of the infrastructure for the proposed Pebble Mine would be, I have followed this issue over its years of claims, counterclaims, and obfuscations. The one strong impression I have is that the EPA has done things right in its review of the proposed project, despite the moving target presented by its sponsors of what the project entails.  The EPA has been methodical in its analysis, thorough in its review, and fair in its public process.  In doing so, it has provided the guidance that industry usually asks for; stating at an early stage of project development the conditions that the project needs to abide by.  This certainty reduces wasted effort in project design and permitting and, in the rare case where a proposed project has fatal flaws, informs project sponsors of the risk it might be taking in proceeding with the project.  It also provides some stability to the permitting process, another condition that industry usually insists on.

In the action recently proposed by EPA to withdraw the Proposed Determination for Bristol Bay, it is not clear to me what EPA expects to accomplish consistent with EPA's mandate embodied in the Clean Water Act.  It appears to be backing away from having done the right thing with respect to the permitting process for any large-scale open-pit mine in the Bristol Bay watershed.  While revisiting previous decisions may serve the Pebble Partnership in its Quixote quest to obtain permits for their proposed mine, it injects uncertainty into the entire Section 404 permitting process as well as undermines agency confidence as perceived by many Alaskan stakeholders who also seek some kind of permitting stability.  

It appears to me that the withdrawal of the Proposed Determination is displacing an emphasis on science as the basis for decision-making with an emphasis on legal interpretation that might result in a different decision.  This concerns me.  When the intent of the law and the consensus of science don't match, the law needs to be changed, not the science.  The reason is that although the legal process is rigorous, laws themselves are ephemeral.  In essence, if you have the votes, a law (hence court decisions) can be dramatically changed overnight.  On the other hand, unlike court decisions which are based on deciding a winner and loser and often influenced by legal technicalities rather than substantive fact, science is based on reaching consensus among peers, which takes a long time to accomplish and thereby is not ephemeral.  Since this notice to withdraw is still a proposal, I strongly suggest that if any changes are made, then the law needs to be changed to match and support what is currently accepted science.   

Thank you for the opportunity to comment on this issue.  The integrity of how this proposed withdrawal is handled has major consequences for many Alaskans, as we have seen from previous public process.  

Sincerely,
George Matz
geomatz@alaska.net
PO Box 15182
Fritz Creek (Homer), AK  99603

Title: Comment submitted by A. Lu
Comment:
EPA: Please do your job and make decisions based on empirical evidence.  The facts are that the watershed feeding Bristol Bay is one of the last remaining of its kind.  It is a source of irreplaceable natural resources, the most prominent of which is its salmon.

The Pebble mining project will alter the ecosystem negatively, even in the best circumstances. It's likely that the mine will destroy the salmon habitat, ruin the economic viability of the people who depend on the salmon resource, and erase the culture of indigenous people who have been living there for millenia.  

Put America First by protecting American people, American culture, and American resources.  Put America first by not enriching the Canadian mining company.

Yours truly,
Adrian Lu

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment: The proposed development of the Pebble mine by a foreign company should be rejected.  This pristine area is the spawning and rearing habitat for one of the earth's most productive salmon resources.  This valuable and sustainable food resource has provided sustenance for people and wildlife for millennia, and has been commercially exploited for over a hundred years.  It provides thousands of jobs with no government subsidies, and supplies markets all over the world with a high quality wonderful tasting protein resource.  Development of a mine in this area would be a short term extraction process that would forever have a risk of damaging an incredible food resource.  This incompatible mine development must not be allowed!

Title: Comment submitted by B. Hlina
Comment:
Dear Scott Pruit and the EPA,

We have one planet that provides us with tremendous resources wheather it's life itself, the trees and the water, or the copper and gold buried in the ground. Some of these resources are finite while others are not. To access some of these resources, which have economic importance, we have to destroy other resources. However, we can limit our destruction of other resources by realizing the impacts we are having and  mitigate the impacts. By allowing for pebble mine to have greater access to the resources it seeks, copper, gold, and molybdenum, we are allowing a greater destruction of resources that we need for basic life, food, water, and shelter. The impacts that a mine like pebble could have on salmon, fish and other marine life is huge and that's just the food side of the argument. Clean water which we all need will be  jeopardized  and trees and plants will also feel the brunt of a mine like pebble. Take a look at the Mount Polley disaster, a copper and gold mine in northern British Columbia, where dams holding tailings failed and 10 million cubic meters of toxic tailings water was released effecting the surrounding areas and evening having an impact on Fraser river, which provides homes to salmon, grizzly bears and other wildlife. In  addition, effecting the economy and people's livelihoods. 

I understand that  copper and gold provide myself and our economy things we couldn't even imagine, e.g. an IPhone. However at what cost. As a citizen of this great nation, for me please ask yourself this and do not allow for the pebble mine to continue to be developed. 

Sincerely, 

Benjamin Hlina, M.Sc
Aquatic Toxicology

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment: I strongly oppose the withdrawal of the July 2014 Clean Water Act Proposed Determination for the Pebble Mine Project. I write as a scientist with graduate level training and concerned Alaskan citizen. The best available science, including science compiled by the EPA, shows that development of the Pebble Mine Project would irreversibly damage one of the most productive salmon runs in the world. This salmon run cannot be replaced and it's value cannot be quantified in dollars alone. It is central to a 4,000 + year old Native Alaskan culture and livelihood as well as to Alaska's fishing industry and tourism economy, both industries which can be sustained and provide benefit to Alaskan citizens well beyond the proposed duration of mining excavation. Withdrawal of the July 2014 Clean Water Act Proposed Determination would indicate that the EPA is failing to uphold its responsibility to use the best available science to mitigate environmental risk and make environmental protection an integral part of US policy.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
Dear Administrator Pruitt:

I strongly object to the proposed withdrawal of your own agency's July 2014 Clean Water Act 404(d) determination to restrict the use of certain waters as disposal sites for dredged or fill material associated with mining the Pebble deposit in the Bristol Bay Watershed.

Instead of withdrawing this determination, I ask that the EPA use your authority to PREVENT CONTAMINATION of waters and wetlands supporting the amazingly prolific and sustainable Bristol Bay salmon fisheries by using the EPA's authority to limit contamination of waters.  

If you withdraw this determination, you are taking one step towards approving a project with environmental impacts to the Bristol Bay fisheries that cannot be mitigated. Mitigation projects in other parts of the Pacific Northwest have not been successful in maintaining sustainable fisheries. 

The Bristol Bay fishery should be maintained for natural ecosystem diversity. But do you also know that the fishery is valued at up to $1.5 billion USD back in 2010?

Again, I ask you to stop the withdrawal of the 404(d) determination and do not allow any mining project in the Bristol Bay watershed to impair waters. 

Thank you for the opportunity to comment.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
Leave the EPA regs regarding mining in the environs above Bristol Bay in place.  They are based on sound science.  Opening the Bristol Bay environs to silver/gold mining is simply a bad idea.  If EPA brazenly backtracks on what it decreed under the Obama administration, Northern Dynasty Minerals and the Pebble Limited Partnership will be given a chance now to apply for a permit. The should not be given that opportunity.  Stick with the original degree.  Mining in that pristine area is not wanted.  More than 80 percent of local residents and 62 percent statewide oppose the project.  Don't forget the ballot initiative that passed in 2014, requiring any mining development that affects the salmon fishing industry in Bristol Bay to seek approval from the State Legislature.  The people of Alaska know mining there would destroy or severely impact the coho salmon fishing industry and the attendant tourism industry.  And this is no way to treat indigenous peoples.  Indigenous people have subsisted on wild salmon in Bristol Bay for 4,000 years.

 This is the most valuable salmon fishery in the world and the habitat there for salmon that makes it such a productive salmon place is that it is basically a giant gravel bed. That means it's almost impossible to contain water that leaches into it.  There is no way a company could or should store highly toxic waste (from a mine) behind a dam there. It would leach into the bay in a heartbeat.  Any geologist can tell you that.

The EPA's 2014 assessment says the mine would employ more than 1,000 people during its lifespan, and more than 2,000 people during the shorter construction phase. The mine would be expected to create $300 billion to $500 billion in revenue over the life of the project, the EPA estimated. Revenue for whom?  The Canadian company who owns it?  Not good enough!!  Stick with sound science and reject any plan to backtrack under Pruitt's suspect leadership.  Thank you.

Title: Comment submitted by R. Stanley
Comment:
I am writing to express my opposition to the proposed action to reverse the July 2014 Proposed Determination which restricted the use of the Pebble Deposit area as a mine location. As a lifelong Alaskan, I know the importance of salmon. Salmon is integral to our way of life, both culturally and economically. I have many friends and family who have worked in the Bristol Bay fishery, on boats and in the canneries. I have eaten salmon from Bristol Bay for my entire life. I am extremely concerned that building a mine in Bristol Bay would threaten this pristine resource and the communities which rely on this resource. The proposed mine, even the smaller project, envisions construction of a large-scale development which would undoubtedly have detrimental impacts in the untouched environment. The proposed project would have a heavily polluted tailings pond which is proposed to exist "indefinitely." I am extremely concerned about the potential for such a tailings pond to fail at some point in time, which would have catastrophic effect on salmon and salmon habitat. The salmon run in Bristol Bay has existed for thousands of years and is one of the healthiest salmon runs in the world. I ask the EPA to continue to protect this resource and to not withdraw the July 2014 Proposed Determination. 

Thank you,
Rose Stanley

Title: Comment submitted by Eric P. Palkovacs, Associate Professor, Ecology and Evolutionary Biology, University of California Santa Cruz et al.
Comment:
October 16, 2017

Administrator Scott Pruitt
U.S. Environmental Protection Agency
William Jefferson Clinton Building
1200 Pennsylvania Ave., N.W., 1101A
Washington, DC 20460

Re: Docket ID No. EPA-R10-OW-2017-0369

Dear Administrator Pruitt:

We the undersigned group of 16 ecologists and fisheries biologists have joined together as a working group to research the state of Alaskan salmon, and particularly how evidence-based decision making and clean water impact salmon populations and the people who depend on them. We submit this letter in response to the proposal to withdraw the EPA's July 2014 Clean Water Act 404(c) Proposed Determination to restrict the development of mining activities within the Pebble deposit in Alaska's Bristol Bay watershed. We oppose this withdrawal on account of the substantial weight and clarity of the science reported by the EPA showing that the risks of mining in this region would lead to negative consequences to water quality, habitat for a range of species, and salmon fisheries that cannot be adequately reduced or mitigated. The Bristol Bay watershed remains one of the last intact and fully functioning wild salmon ecosystems on Earth, where last year alone over 50 million adult sockeye salmon returned, of which 37.7 million were sustainably harvested for a commercial value of $209.9 million dollars. The ability of the watershed to consistently produced salmon is directly the result of clean, cold, complex, and connected habitats which scale mining would impair. Therefore, we recommend that the EPA use its authority under section 404(c) of the Clean Water Act to preemptively prevent elimination and impairment of streams supporting the wildlife of Bristol Bay and its salmon fisheries.

As you reconsider the Clean Water 404(c) determination, we urge you to consider the EPA report entitled "An Assessment of Potential Mining Impacts on Salmon Ecosystems of Bristol Bay, Alaska". In this report, the EPA conducted a comprehensive review incorporating the best available science. This report presents an important resource to inform policy-makers of the costs, benefits, and risks of the proposed mining activities in Bristol Bay.

Sincerely,


Eric P. Palkovacs, Ph.D.
Associate Professor, Ecology and Evolutionary Biology
University of California Santa Cruz
130 McAllister Way, Santa Cruz, CA 95060

Title: Comment submitted by K. Scribner
Comment:
I, Kevin Scribner, commercially fished in Bristol Bay, Alaska, from 1980-1996, having owned a commercial salmon fishing permit from 1982-1996. And beginning this year, 2017, my Forever Wild Seafood business will market Bristol Bay Salmon Jerky under the Forever Wild brand, www.foreverwildseafood.com. 

My fishing and salmon marketing business rely upon the continued abundance of the Bristol Bay salmon fishery. My business success depends as well upon the reputation of Bristol Bay as untarnished by other resource extraction, especially that which requires habitat destruction and the substantial use of toxic substances that could be released into the Bristol Bay Watershed. 

Let us praise and protect the famous Bristol Bay, Alaska, USA, Fishery. This vibrant, sustainable Fishery is ALL-ALASKAN, ALL-AMERICAN. And it must be clearly noted that the company that proposes to open and operate a mine in Bristol Bay, the Pebble Partnership, is foreign-owned. If there was ever a chance to "Put America First," it is by taking every legal permitting precaution, be it Local, State, Tribal, and Federal, to insure that no damage is done to this healthy Alaskan/American ecosystem.  

I support implementing the Proposed Determination of the US EPA Region 10 Pursuant to Section 404 of the Clean Water Act Pebble Deposit Area, Southwest Alaska.  

In my following comment, I substantially reference EPA's documents, specifically the peer-reviewed Assessment of Potential Mining Impacts on Salmon Ecosystems of Bristol Bay, Alaska, 2014 and the Proposed Determination Executive Summary, 2014, both of which were subject to public comment, and both of which enjoyed a super-majority of approximately 70% support. I believe EPA has conducted a credible process of due diligence leading up to this Proposed Determination and submit that EPA's own reports provide the best information to support said Proposed Determination.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment submitted by Joel R. Reynolds, Attorney, Natural Resources Defense Council (NRDC) et al.
Comment:
On behalf of the Natural Resources Defense Council (NRDC) and our more than 3 million members and activists, attached please find detailed comments opposing in the strongest terms EPA's Proposal to Withdraw the Proposed Determination.

Instead of withdrawing, NRDC urges EPA finalize its Proposed Determination, or, in the alternative, to maintain the Proposed Determination as a guideline for permitting.

Such action would be responsive to science, justified by law, and clearly permissible under EPA's congressionally-instilled Clean Water Act authority.

It is also overwhelmingly supported by the Bristol Bay residents, subsistence families, commercial fishermen, business owners, and countless individuals whofor over a decadehave sought EPA protection of Bristol Bay's pristine environment and productive fishery.

Title: Comment submitted by J. Ketcham-Colwill
Comment:
Administrator Pruitt:

I support protecting the salmon fishery in Bristol Bay and the livelihood of Native Americans there who maintain a subsistence-based way of life.  Any mining development near Bristol Bay should be conducted in a manner that is consistent with Clean Water Act safeguards and that protects the ecology and recreational value of the area for all Americans.

I oppose withdrawal of the proposed Clean Water Act determination protecting the Bristol Bay watershed, for several reasons:

	The watershed supports the largest sockeye salmon fishery in the world.  Withdrawing the determination would allow mining to proceed in a manner that - according to EPA's peer-reviewed assessment - could unacceptably harm fish habitat and fisheries in the Bristol Bay watershed.  This would jeopardize the livelihood of thousands of Alaskans.

	The watershed is home to 25 federally recognized tribal governments who have maintained a salmon-based culture and subsistence-based way of life for at least 4,000 years.

	A majority of Alaska voters oppose mining development that would harm wild salmon within the fisheries preserve, as evidenced by voter approval of the 2014 state-wide ballot measure.  The measure was designed to give the legislature the power to prohibit mining projects in Bristol Bay if legislators determine the activity to be harmful to wild salmon within the fisheries reserve. [Source: Alaska Bristol Bay Mining Ban, Ballot Measure 4, 2014. https://ballotpedia.org/Alaska_Bristol_Bay_Mining_Ban,_Ballot_Measure_4_(2014).]  Also, the overwhelming majority of residents of Bristol Bay are opposed to the proposed Pebble Mine project.  (Source: United Tribes of Bristol Bay. Opposition to Pebble Mine Reiterated by local tribes, fishermen, business owners.http://utbb.org/opposition-to-pebble-mine-reiterated-by-local-tribes-fishermen-business-owners/)

	Thewatershed's ecological resources generated nearly $480 million in direct economic expenditures and sales and provided employment for over 14,000 full- and part-time workers in 2009. (Source: U.S. EPA. An Assessment of Potential Mining Impacts on Salmon Ecosystems of Bristol Bay, Alaska (Final Report). U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Washington, DC, EPA 910-R-14-001A-C, ES, 2014. Chapter 5.)

	Contrary to comments by the backers of the Pebble Mine project, EPA's watershed assessment was scientifically based and thoroughly peer-reviewed, and the public has had an extensive opportunity to comment on it. The assessment and public comments received should be key components of any future action on this issue.

	The rationale for the proposed withdrawal is flawed. Finalizing the proposed determination would provide more regulatory certainty than withdrawing it, and a permit application is not needed to augment the factual record.

Thank you for the opportunity to comment.  A formatted version of these comments is submitted as an attached file.

Jim Ketcham-Colwill
Arlington, Virginia

Title: Comment submitted by A. Wong
Comment:
Dear EPA representative:

Pebble's world class mine plan should be allowed to go through the lawful permitting process.

1) Pebble is ~100 miles from Bristol Bay. The media has been deceiving the public for years via photos and words to make some people falsely believe the proposed mine would be 'on the bay'.

2) There are no salmon streams within the proposed Pebble mine. It is a moonscape with <0.5% of Bristol Bay salmon streams within 400 sq miles. The media has been deceiving the public by stating Salmon would be threatened with 'devastation'. When in fact ~zero Salmon would be at risk. 

3) Pebble will:
-Not use cyanide
-have little contaminated waste rock
-clean to code and discharge all water (redundancy to avoid water spill if asteroid hits dam)
-store solid tailings that remain behind a wide/low dam that uses special lining and is 2x the strength needed to survive the worst possible Alaskan earthquake right at the site... even though there is no mega fault at the site.

Reality is, the worst case scenario, a dam failure, is virtually impossible. 

And if a failure did occur, the impact would be minor (<1/5000 Bristol Salmon impacted by sediments.) This is because there is redundant safety in the design. (i.e. clean & discharge waste water, separate tailings by chemical content, special linings, avoiding chemicals like cyanide, etc.)

The MSM and activist groups want us to remain ignorant of these and other facts so you will see a large 'manufactured opposition' to what in reality will be a leading example of super environmentally friendly copper mines.

I support a well regulated Federal and State permitting process for Pebble. Pebble's design plan should be given a fair chance to set the world standard and clear all requirements by a wide margin. 

Please uphold the law and uphold what is right for Alaskans and Americans. All Alaskans will benefit financially and Americans will take a leap towards regaining strategic mineral independence.

Please send a message that activists... colluding for years with the Obama EPA... to draft the 2011 proposed determination... based on false assumptions... is both unlawful and unethical.  

The corrupt former EPA officials knowingly subverted a lawful permitting process designed to ensure lawful environmental regulations for all new projects.  

Since 2011, Pebble has been red taped while Chinese mines and industry openly dump so many toxins that 750,000 Chiness die annually from water/air pollution. 

US MSM ignores that growing crisis, while Britain and others cover it in vain.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
As a Wetlands Specialist for 20 years I have a strong understanding of the ecological interconnectedness of complex wetland systems.  
Such a pristine environment is rare in today's world.  While PLP would be expected to propose robust containment systems, these BMPs cannot provide 100% assurance they will not fail.  
Mining byproducts if released either through surface flows or through seepage into groundwater would likely impact (lower) pH levels as well as introduce metals, and other toxic substances into the environment.  
These chemicals will accumulate in the sediments, affect micro invertebrates, invertebrates and will be carried up through the food chain, eventually accumulating in larger predators.  
The risk is too great. 
And if a containment failure occurs it may go undetected for months or years slowly poisoning the environment.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I am opposed to EPAs proposal to rescind the 2014 Proposed Determination designed to protect Bristol Bays world class fisheries. Please stand with American jobs and communities and preserve the Bristol Bay Proposed Determination.

Bristol Bay, Alaska, is one of America's last great wild salmon fisheries. Each year, tens of millions of wild salmon return, supporting upwards of 14,000 jobs in the commercial and sport fishing industries, and serving as a one-in-a-lifetime destination for anglers from around the world as well as the cultural cornerstone for the region's communities. These long-established businesses are at risk from a foreign-owned mining company that wants to build the proposed Pebble Mine, which is opposed by more than 65 percent of Alaskans and more than 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents. 

In 2014, led by Alaska Native Tribes, interests including commercial fishing business owners and sportsmen asked the EPA step in to ensure that this mine wouldn't jeopardize Bristol Bay. The EPA responded by listening to over 1.5 million Americans, hosting dozens of community meetings, reviewing Pebble's many detailed filings with state and federal agencies, and conducting a twice peer-reviewed scientific assessment of the potential impacts to the region. Withdrawing the proposed determination ignores the overwhelming majority of Alaskans and puts the short-term interests of a foreign mining company above thousands of local jobs. 

For the sake of our wildlife, waterways, and communities, I urge you to protect Bristol Bay and prevent this horrible open-pit mine from destroying one of our nation's most precious ecosystems.

This is a no-brainer; the present use is far more economically valuable to the Alaskans than a mine that will most probably be an ecological disaster for the area and leave after depleting the resource with Alaskans left holding the bag of junk.

Title: Comment submitted by M. Sturm
Comment:
Docket # EPA-R10-OW-2017-0369
U.S. Environmental Protection Agency
Mail Code: 2822T
1200 Pennsylvania Ave., NW
Washington, DC 20460

23 Summit Drive
Warren, RI 02885

October 17, 2017

Dear Administrator Pruitt, 

I am writing to ask you to uphold the EPA's 404c protection of Bristol Bay, Alaska and its thriving commercial fishing and seafood processing industries from large-scale mining activity. Bristol Bay is home to the world's largest wild sockeye salmon fishery, which produces nearly half of the world harvest of sockeye salmon, generates billions of dollars in economic output every year, and supports thousands of American jobs. Although I reside in Rhode Island, I have been working in Bristol Bay seasonally for the past thirteen years.

Due to the concerns over the proposed Pebble mine expressed by many Alaskans, the Environmental Protection Agency has already undertaken years of research on the effects of mining activity in the region, and released the Bristol Bay Watershed Assessment. Based on this assessment, which definitively shows that the risks of large-scale mining in Bristol Bay are significant, the EPA rightfully took preventative action against the potential devastation posed by a mine such as Pebble. Even without a disaster or major spill, large open-pit mines like Pebble would cause lasting damage to the fishery - destroying up to 94 miles of salmon-bearing streams and up to 5,300 acres of critical wetlands and salmon habitat.

After two sets of peer reviews and public comments that generated over a million responses, the final assessment served as a solid foundation for taking preemptive 404c action on the deleterious consequences of large-scale mining activity that it forecasts. Reversing this decision would undoubtedly be the wrong move, as the Pebble mine would jeopardize more jobs than it creates and put a renewable resource at risk. You have the rare opportunity to help maintain a fishery that is still healthy, for the benefit of commercial fishermen, sport fishermen, and the native Alaskans that rely on Bristol Bay for subsistence. I am not opposed to mining, but I strongly believe that Bristol Bay is the wrong place for it.

Sincerely,
Miles Sturm

Title: Comment submitted by D. A. Sevilla
Comment:
Dear Sir or Madam,

I am writing in regard to Docket ID No. EPA-R10-OW-2017-0369 the decision that EPA rollback its 2014 Proposed Determination regarding the Pebble Ore deposit. At that time EPA likely correctly determined the proposed mine would compromise existing fishery resources, indigenous subsistence-based livelihoods.

The agency undertook an extensive three-year, twice-peer reviewed scientific assessment that found a mine like Pebble would have "significant" and potentially "catastrophic" impacts on the Bristol Bay watershed. The Pebble Mine would generate up to 10 billion tons of toxic mining waste, covering an area larger than Manhattan. Giant earthen dams some larger than 700 feet tall would be constructed to hold back the leach-prone mine tailings forever, all in an active earthquake zone. According to EPA's three year, twice peer reviewed scientific assessment of mining impacts on the Bristol Bay Watershedwhich evaluated three different mining scenarioseven the smallest mining scenario would destroy numerous miles of salmon streams and thousands of acres of wetlands.

It seems imperative that as a reasoning person I must comment that rolling back EPA's 2014 Proposed Determination though stipulated in settlements, is not in standing with the interests of our nations people, their well being and their security to a living resource, which provides us all with a sense of pride in our choice to preserve and protect that, that has been in-trusted to us  was created by none of the investors and is so important to those that rely on the pristine nature of this region for inspiration and or sustenance & domicile.

Particularly at this moment in time, when there is a question regarding the security of the living world, the integrity of our seated government and instability rampant throughout the world. Now would be a good time to trust the wisdom of those that have already researched the matter, to hear the message in the proposed Determination and start upholding the trust of the people to protect our interests which are the apparently valuable Pebble Ore deposit and our magnificent Bristol Bay Fishery.

Yep! there's likely gold there, maybe even a lot but wasting the landscape with a toxic extraction process is not how my folks raised me to behave as a conservator.

Nature owes man nothing. Folk coming around offering to liquidate the assets of our nation, leave the site poorer for their being there, there's not much good going to come from that, matter of fact it's likely poor asset management.

So please Sir or Madame let's get on with protecting the interests of our people.

Thank you,
Don A. Sevilla
31984 Nichols Ln.
Cottage Grove, OR 97424

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
Docket number EPA-R10-OW-2017-0369

Scott Pruitt's movement to lift mining restrictions on Alaska's Bristol Bay to use the site for dredged or fill material disposal associated with the Pebble deposit would be irreversibly detrimental to the area's ecosystem, jobs, and culture. Bristol Bay supplies approximately half of the world's sockeye salmon and is home to grizzly bears, wolves, caribou, wolverines, foxes, otters, moose, and thousands more species. An abundance of clean water enables them to thrive. Additionally, the area in question is seismically active, so it would be at high risk for toxic waste contamination (despite promises from Pebble and associates that this would not occur). Withdrawing Bristol Bay's protections under the Clean Water Act would defy years of scientific research, public comment, and independent review that led the EPA to determine in 2014 that mining the area would be a health risk for the fishery and broader ecosystem. With one of the world's most valuable salmon watersheds, Bristol Bay's fishery supports 14,000 jobs and is valued at over $1.5 billion annually. Additionally, more than 65% of Alaskans, 80% of Bristol Bay residents and Native communities, and 85% of commercial fishermen stand against the Pebble mine.

Please use common sense, the well-established research, and your human heart to consider the grave consequences of Pruitt's unreasonable, irrational, unjustifiable motion to withdraw Bristol Bay's protections under the Obama-era Clean Water Act. Respect our planet's ecosystems and Bristol Bay's people. Thank you.

Title: Comment submitted by Jan Boyer, Fish and Wildlife Management, Montana State University
Comment:
Please do not withdraw July 2014 Clean Water Act 404(c) Proposed Determination to restrict the use of certain waters as disposal sites for dredged or fill material associated with mining the Pebble deposit in Alaska's Bristol Bay watershed.

Older mine sites throughout the country, established before Clean Water Act protections, provide examples of how mining waste can decimate fisheries. I have spent 5 years working in fisheries research and management in Montana, where many watersheds and fish populations are heavily impacted by mine pollution, even decades after mines in those watersheds have closed. One of those rivers, the Clark Fork, is downstream of Butte, a mining city on a copper deposit similar to the one at Pebble. In 1908, a flood washed mine tailings 120 miles downstream, creating what would later become the largest superfund site in the country. There were no fish in the Clark Fork for 80 years. Even today, 109 years after the flood, populations of trout are significantly lower than in nearby rivers.  It's bad enough for mine tailings to destroy a recreational trout fishery. The thought of a similar disaster happening in the most productive salmon fishery in the world is horrifying.

The geology of the Pebble area is not conducive to safely containing mine waste.  Furthermore, the mine's location upstream of Lake Iliamna means that any tailings dam failure or groundwater contamination has the potential to harm water quality and fish populations in an important sockeye salmon rearing habitat.  Please, learn from past examples of mine tailings decimating fisheries, and retain the Clean Water Act protections so the salmon fisheries in Bristol Bay are protected.

Jan Boyer
M.S. Fish and Wildlife Management, Montana State University
