Title: Comment submitted by J. Ashcraft-Johnson
Comment:
I'm writing in reference to Docket # EPA-HQ-ORD-2012-0276. The EPA must prohibit the disposal of mine waste in Alaska's Bristol Bay watershed area. 

Just 3 years ago the EPA found that the proposed mine "would result in complete loss of fish habitat due to elimination, dewatering, and fragmentation of streams, wetlands, and other aquatic resources." The digging of massive pits and piling of waste rock would disrupt the streams in the area, and the discharge of waste chemicals would make the waters inhospitable to aquatic life. The EPA determined that the losses from this would be irreversible.

The Bristol Bay area fishery produces about half of the world's sockeye salmon, and these fish require clean streams to sustain their populations. Polluted water can kill both baby salmon that are developing, and the adult salmon that are on their way to spawn. Manually disrupting the existing waterways with pit mines will stop the adult salmon from returning to the streams they were hatched in, and chemical discharge and seepage into the waters will critically impact their ability to survive in those waters. If this proposed mine is allowed to do as it pleases, it will wipe out the salmon population. This will be disastrous for the thousands of families in the area that make their livings fishing for salmon, and it will take this nutritious and delicious fish off the menu for much of the world. 

I don't have a problem with mining on principle, but we must not allow short-term corporate interests to overpower all else. If this mining company strip-mines the area, they will make a pretty penny quickly. But they won't be employing nearly as many people as make their livelihoods fishing in the area. They won't be contributing to the local economy. And after they're done, the local economy will be done for as well. The salmon fishery has sustained local American families for decades, had sustained local Inuit families for centuries before them, and could continue to sustain families indefinitely if we take care of it right. The gold and copper ores in the ground in that area isn't going anywhere. We have plenty of time to work out non-disruptive, minimally-intrusive ways of slowly extracting it, without unduly disturbing local wildlife habitats. The East coast used to have valuable salmon fisheries, until industrialization poisoned their spawning waterways. Let's not screw this up again in Alaska. If we are to mine the area, we must be very careful and put strict restrictions on the impact to the local terrain and on the waste discharged into the waterways.

The Clean Water Act gives the EPA the means to protect this irreplaceable fishery for future generations. I urge you to do so. 

Sincerely,
Jesse Ashcraft-Johnson
Cambridge MA
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment submitted by J. Ulrich
Comment:
I am writing you today to urge you to NOT ALLOW any mining in Bristol Bay Alaska. Bristol Bay one of the world's most pristine places in the world, an extremely sensitive watershed in wild Alaska. This protection was given because Bristol Bay is home to one of world's largest and most pristine sockeye salmon fisheries; roughly half the world's wild sockeye salmon come from there.

That protection was based on decades of scientific research, years of study, and public comment using EPA's due process. This protection is an assurance to those who live in the area and rely on that environment for their way of life.  Salmon and other area ecological resources create some 14,000 full and part time jobs.  Generate about $480 million annually and support 4,000-year-old Alaskan Native Cultures.  And don't forget Salmon is an important food for many, both human and animal.  

What is wrong with sticking with the judgement of scientific studies, careful studies that took 3 years to complete.  Those various groups including the EPA did extensive scientific studies and determined that this area should never be opened to certain types of mining, period. There is NO project that merits the risk. 

It is suggested that the mine would bring 1,000 jobs up to 2,000 during actual construction but weigh that against the potential loss of 14,000 full and part time jobs that could result from the damage the mine would cause.  In other words, the actions of 2,000 could cost 14,000 their jobs and the world in they live would be irreparably damaged. Sounds like a lose lose proposal. 

Thank you for taking the time to read my thoughts. Again I urge you to continue the Clean Water protections for the Bristol Bay.

Sincerely,

Jeannie Ulrich

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I am an environmental scientist and a commercial salmon fisher in Bristol Bay.  I am opposed to withdrawal ofthe July 2014 Proposed Determination to restrict the discharge of dredged or fill material associated with the potential "Pebble Mine"in Alaska's Bristol Bay watershed.

The Bristol Bay salmon run is the largest sockeye run in the world and the only sustainably-managed fish harvesting operation of its size. It serves as an example for the world of what can be accomplished through good environmental stewardship. The state of Alaska is to be commended for their support of the effort. 

The risk of contaminant release from mine-waste containment and dredge spoils - even if relatively minor -- has the potential to compromise the market for these fish through public perceptions of health risk. At the largest scale, contamination from mine waste has the potential to contaminate much of the salmon run for generations.

The risk assessment EPA conducted evaluated the potential impacts of large-scale mining on Bristol Bay's commercial, recreational, and subsistence fisheries, on native Alaskan peoples whose culture is strongly connected to salmon fishing. To protect these natural, economic and cultural resources, EPA found that discharge of dredged or fill material would violate the Clean Water Act. The conditions supporting the previous assessment have not changed and the Determination should not be withdrawn.

I live in California, where only a generation ago salmon harvest numbered in the millions. Poor management has resulted in total collapse of the runs and the end of the inland commercial fishery. We should not repeat this mistake in Bristol Bay.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I am opposed to EPAs proposal to rescind the 2014 Proposed Determination designed to protect Bristol Bays world class fisheries. Please stand with American jobs and communities and preserve the Bristol Bay Proposed Determination. In my humble opinion, you have done nothing to protect the environment and everything possible to degrade the mission of the EPA, so you should not have the position that you have been appoimted to.

Bristol Bay, Alaska, is one of America's last great wild salmon fisheries. Each year, tens of millions of wild salmon return, supporting upwards of 14,000 jobs in the commercial and sport fishing industries, and serving as a one-in-a-lifetime destination for anglers from around the world as well as the cultural cornerstone for the region's communities. These long-established businesses are at risk from a foreign-owned mining company that wants to build the proposed Pebble Mine, which is opposed by more than 65 percent of Alaskans and more than 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents. 

In 2014, led by Alaska Native Tribes, interests including commercial fishing business owners and sportsmen asked the EPA step in to ensure that this mine wouldn't jeopardize Bristol Bay. The EPA responded by listening to over 1.5 million Americans, hosting dozens of community meetings, reviewing Pebble's many detailed filings with state and federal agencies, and conducting a twice peer-reviewed scientific assessment of the potential impacts to the region. Withdrawing the proposed determination ignores the overwhelming majority of Alaskans and puts the short-term interests of a foreign mining company above thousands of local jobs. 

For the sake of our wildlife, waterways, and communities, I urge you to protect Bristol Bay and prevent this horrible open-pit mine from destroying one of our nation's most precious ecosystems.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I am writing in oppositions to Proposed Determination to Restrict Use of Area as Disposal Site: Pebble Deposit Area, Southwest Alaska Docket ID No. EPA-R10-OW-2017-0369

The Bristol Bay Salmon fisheries and the Clean Water Act are both extremely important to me as an American citizen, and I do not want to see either compromised in this withdrawn proposal. 

It is well known that the Bristol Bay Salmon runs are some of the world's most productive fisheries and have provided food and livelihoods for many Americans for generations, including myself and my neighbors. It is also becoming increasingly recognized how much the health of a watershed is reflected in the health of its fisheries, especially for highly migratory species like salmon. 

In this case, we have an obligation to protect Bristol Bay's salmon, its water, and the watershed that supports them both, so that the Bristol Bay fisheries will continue to provide food and jobs for generations to come. 

In the U.S., we only have to look at other once-great salmon rivers like the Columbia and Sacramento-San Joaquin and see that we took risks in those river systems at the expense of salmon fisheries. It should be obvious that we cannot be too careful with the Bristol Bay watershed. Far too much value is at stake, and I believe a simple long view, with our grandchildren and their grandchildren in mind, reveals the immense inter-generational value in Bristol Bay that is not worth risking.

Title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by World Wildlife Fund - US (WWF) (web)
Comment:
Administrator Pruitt and Acting Region 10 Administrator Pirzadeh:

Please see the attached letter, submitted on behalf of the attached list of 131,948 WWF-US supporters who signed WWF's comment letter on the EPA's Proposal to Withdraw the Proposed Determination to protect Bristol Bay, Alaska; EPA-R10-OW-2017-0369. The comment letter urges EPA to keep the Proposed Determination in place to protect one of the nation's greatest sustainable resources - the Bristol Bay, Alaska, salmon fishery.

Sincerely,

David Aplin
World Wildlife Fund-US 
Arctic Program
406 G Street, Suite 301
Anchorage, AK 99501

~~~


Letter to EPA Administrator Scott Pruitt and Acting Region 10 Administrator Michelle Pirzadeh

On behalf of the following 131,948 WWF-US Supporters

I am writing today to encourage the US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to protect Bristol Bay, Alaska, from the proposed Pebble Mine that would threaten the region's irreplaceable fish and wildlife resources and the 14,000 jobs that depend on Bristol Bay's clean, healthy waters. EPA must keep the Bristol Bay 404(c) Proposed Determination in place to protect Bristol Bay, its salmon, waters, people, and sustainable economy from the proposed Pebble Mine.

EPA's own scientific study contains highly concerning facts: even without a mine disaster, construction of the Pebble deposit will destroy 94 miles of salmon streams and 5,350 acres of wetlands, lakes and ponds. Overall, EPA concluded that mining the headwaters of the Bristol Bay river systems could cause irreparable harm to the valuable Bristol Bay fishery, wildlife, and people.

According to the EPA's own study, the Bristol Bay watershed provides vital habitat for 29 fish species, more than 190 bird species, and more than 40 terrestrial animals. All five species of Pacific salmonsockeye, Chinook, coho, chum and pinkspawn and rear in the pristine Bristol Bay watershed. The Bristol Bay watershed supports the largest sockeye salmon run in the world, producing approximately 46% of the world's wild sockeye harvest, creating $1.5 billion in economic output and nearly 20,000 jobs throughout the United States annually.

Because of its great ecological and economic value, I recommend the EPA keep in place the 404(c) Proposed Determination for Bristol Bay, Southwest Alaska. The reasonable restrictions included in that proposal will prevent unsustainable development that would adversely impact the region's fishery, recreation and local culture. 

Please keep the agency's 404(c) action in place to protect one of the nation's greatest sustainable resourcesthe Bristol Bay, Alaska, salmon fishery.

Title: Comment submitted by R. Pegau
Comment:
Dear Administrator,

I'm writing in reference to Docket # EPA-HQ-ORD-2012-0276. Please prohibit the disposal of mine waste in Alaska's Bristol Bay watershed. The proposed Pebble Mine presents a long-term risk to the sustainability of this important fishery, and all the people and businesses that rely on it. In 2010, Bristol Bay salmon fishermen harvested 29 million sockeye salmon worth $165 million in direct harvest value alone. That represented 31% of the total Alaska salmon harvest value.

Many families rely on wild salmon as a uniquely nutritious source of protein, rich in essential omega-3 fats and vitamin D. Farmed salmon is not nutritionally identical (much lower in vitamin D, much higher in saturated fats and pro-inflammatory omega-6 fats) and poses its own environmental risks. I urge the EPA to take immediate action to use existing provisions of the Clean Water Act to protect this large and irreplaceable wild salmon fishery.

Alaska is my home. All my time there, I have known that the Pebble Mine would lay waste to the people, the animals, and the ecosystem as a whole. The protections you wish to remove were created with science and our future in mind. By removing them, you hurt generations upon generations. These actions and the names of those who permitted them would stain the earth and our tongues. Please don't let that be.

Sincerely,
Robin Pegau
PO Box 2126
Cordova, AK 99574
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment submitted by C. J. Todd
Comment:
The proposed Clean Water Act determination should NOT be withdrawn.  The potential impacts of the proposed Pebble Mine on the health of the Bristol Bay watershed and the livelihood of thousands of people in Alaska are far too great. Those risks include loss of up to up to 94 miles of salmon-supporting streams and up to 4,900 acres of wetlands and ponds, and the very real potential of wastewater dam failure resulting in damage to or destruction of the salmon fishery.  The watershed supports the largest sockeye salmon fishery in the world and 25 federally recognized tribes who for 4,000 years have depended on the fishery for their subsistence-based culture. The overwhelming majority of residents of Bristol Bay are opposed to the project, and a statewide majority of voters also oppose it. The watersheds unique ecological resources generate significant economic benefits and employment.  EPAs original watershed assessment was scientifically robust and thoroughly peer-reviewed.  That assessment and related public comments should strongly influence any future action. 

References:  U.S. EPA. An Assessment of Potential Mining Impacts on Salmon Ecosystems of Bristol Bay, Alaska (Final Report). Title: Comment submitted by P. Humes
Comment:
Dear Administrator,

This comment is in reference to Docket # EPA-HQ-ORD-2012-0276. Please prohibit the disposal of mine waste in Alaska's Bristol Bay watershed. The proposed Pebble Mine damages the sustainability of the fishery there, and all those who rely on it. In 2010, Bristol Bay salmon fishermen harvested 29 million sockeye salmon worth $165 million in direct harvest value alone. That represented 31% of the total Alaska salmon harvest value.

So many people depend on wild salmon as a uniquely nutritious source of protein, rich in essential omega-3 fats and vitamin D. Farmed salmon is not nutritionally identical (much lower in vitamin D, much higher in saturated fats and pro-inflammatory omega-6 fats) and comes with many environmental risks. I urge the EPA to take immediate action to use existing provisions of the Clean Water Act to protect this large and irreplaceable wild salmon fishery.

Sincerely, Pine Humes
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment submitted by M. and C. Masek
Comment:
The late Alaska Republican Senator Ted Stevens had it right when he called this project, "the wrong mine in the wrong place," and I, along with over a million other Americans, wholeheartedly agree. An unprecedented coalition of native tribes, commercial fishermen, anglers and hunters, conservationists, religious groups, restaurateurs and outdoor enthusiasts have been fighting this foreign-owned mine proposal and trying to gain protections for the Bristol Bay region.

The reasons are simple and numerous. Bristol Bay's average run of 37.5 million fish produces a whopping 46% of the world's sockeye salmon. This run sustains more than 29,000 fishing trips each year and creates 14,000 commercial and recreational jobs in a salmon fishery that can last indefinitely, as opposed to the 1,000 or so jobs the Canadian mine developers can offer for a couple of decades.

The salmon's incredible migration also sustains people: nearly half of the world's sockeye catch comes from this one region, which is one of the last, great salmon fisheries on Earth. The returning salmon and other ecological resources create some 14,000 full- and part-time jobs, generate about $480 million annually -- and support 4,000-year-old Alaska Native cultures. 

Your EPA found after three years of peer-reviewed research, that such a mine "would result in complete loss of fish habitat due to elimination, de-watering, and fragmentation of streams, wetlands, and other aquatic resources" in many areas of the bay watershed. In particular, the EPA estimated 22 miles of streams and more than 6 square miles of wetlands and other habitats that are important to salmon and other fish would be lost to a large-scale mine FOREVER.

Today I urged President Trump to listen to our fishermen and businesses before removing science-based environmental rules that protect Bristol Bay. The future of Bristol Bay must be determined by science, not politics or the whining of Tom Collier, who is only pursuing this mine for the benefit of his company.

Sincerely,
Michael and Cheryl Masek

Title: Anonymous Public Comment

I am opposed to EPAs proposal to rescind the 2014 Proposed Determination designed to protect Bristol Bays world class fisheries. Please stand with American jobs and communities and preserve the Bristol Bay Proposed Determination.  Please make it possible for the people who depend on that Bay for their income to be able to continue to do so in waters not polluted by mining, oil drilling or other industries which would destroy the way for the people who live there.

Bristol Bay, Alaska, is one of America's last great wild salmon fisheries. Each year, tens of millions of wild salmon return, supporting upwards of 14,000 jobs in the commercial and sport fishing industries, and serving as a one-in-a-lifetime destination for anglers from around the world as well as the cultural cornerstone for the region's communities. These long-established businesses are at risk from a foreign-owned mining company that wants to build the proposed Pebble Mine, which is opposed by more than 65 percent of Alaskans and more than 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents. 

In 2014, led by Alaska Native Tribes, interests including commercial fishing business owners and sportsmen asked the EPA step in to ensure that this mine wouldn't jeopardize Bristol Bay. The EPA responded by listening to over 1.5 million Americans, hosting dozens of community meetings, reviewing Pebble's many detailed filings with state and federal agencies, and conducting a twice peer-reviewed scientific assessment of the potential impacts to the region. Withdrawing the proposed determination ignores the overwhelming majority of Alaskans and puts the short-term interests of a foreign mining company above thousands of local jobs. 

For the sake of our wildlife, waterways, and communities, I urge you to protect Bristol Bay and prevent this horrible open-pit mine from destroying one of our nation's most precious ecosystems.

Title: Comment submitted by E. Hanley
Comment:
The proposed Clean Water Act determination should NOT be withdrawn.  The potential impacts of the proposed Pebble Mine on the health of the Bristol Bay watershed and the livelihood of thousands of people in Alaska are far too great. Those risks include loss of up to up to 94 miles of salmon-supporting streams and up to 4,900 acres of wetlands and ponds, and the very real potential of wastewater dam failure resulting in damage to or destruction of the salmon fishery.  The watershed supports the largest sockeye salmon fishery in the world and 25 federally recognized tribes who for 4,000 years have depended on the fishery for their subsistence-based culture. The overwhelming majority of residents of Bristol Bay are opposed to the project, and a statewide majority of voters also oppose it. The watersheds unique ecological resources generate significant economic benefits and employment.  EPAs original watershed assessment was scientifically robust and thoroughly peer-reviewed.  That assessment and related public comments should strongly influence any future action.
Thank you, Ellen Hanley Ph.D.

The following are excerpts from a CNN column last updated 10/10/2017 and posted on Google (http://google.com/newsstand/s/CBIwtM7YpzY) "Thomas Quinn, a professor at the University of Washington who has been studying fish in Bristol Bay for 30 years.The salmon's incredible migration also sustains people: Nearly half of the world's sockeye catch comes from this one region, which is one of the last, great salmon fisheries on Earth. The returning salmon and other ecological resources create some 14,000 full- and part-time jobs, generate about $480 million annually -- and support 4,000-year-old Alaska Native cultures." I FEEL THIS PROVES SUSTAINABLE VALUE AS IS. "Such a mine "would result in complete loss of fish habitat due to elimination, dewatering, and fragmentation of streams, wetlands, and other aquatic resources" in some areas of the bay watershed, the EPA found after three years of peer-reviewed research. In particular, the EPA estimated 22 miles of streams and more than 6 square miles of wetlands and other habitats that are important to salmon and other fish would be lost to a large-scale mine." THIS IS BACKED BY SCIENCE. 
"All of these losses would be irreversible," the agency said."Under the Obama administration, people were willing to say, 'Look, it's very clear, this is exactly the worst place you could imagine building a mine of that kind," said Ray Hilborn, a professor in the School of Aquatic and Fishery Sciences at the University of Washington. "It's not just that you have the most valuable salmon fishery in the world, it's the nature of the habitat there. The reason it's such a productive salmon place is, it's basically this giant gravel bed. But that also means it's almost impossible to contain water. It's just a giant sponge. The idea you could store highly toxic waste (from a mine) forever behind a dam is just ridiculous."Tilden says he's not anti-development. His father was a gold miner from California. But after the mine was first proposed, he said, he started touring mines that had been shut down. 
He saw pools of toxic water, massive piles of waste-rock. At one mine in Nevada, he said, he was told to cover his shoes for fear he would track dust laden with heavy metals home -- and "not to have any contact with that dust with our eyes, not to touch any of the water."
Could Bristol Bay turn into a similar wasteland? He decided he didn't want to find out. 
PLEASE DO NOT DESTROY THIS HABITAT SO A FEW PEOPLE CAN GET RICH.

As a fish biologist who has lived in Wyoming and Idaho - dealing with the Endangered Species Act in the latter state - I have sincere concerns with the proposed development in Bristol Bay for the Pebble Mine project.  I currently live in Alaska, and have since 1998.  I'm familiar with the permitting process (NEPA, etc.) and know that just because a project has impacts that does not result in disapproval of that activity...nor it should.  NEPA merely attempts to lessen those impacts and discloses the impacts.   Although scaled down, constructing a gold and copper mine in the headwaters of the world's most productive salmon fishery  - in a place that is seismically active - is taking a huge chance, one that can have irreversible consequences.  

Projects like this have the potential to require water treatment facilities for perpetuity, not to mention huge tailings dams that have been known to fail in recent times as part of "modern" mining projects.  

Consequently, I believe that the EPA did the right thing in this situation where it required Clean Water Act restrictions by addressing a problem that has contributed to the loss of salmon in so many other places...to where the government has spent vast quantities of money trying to bring back fish populations that have been decimated by habitat degradation.

Thank you for taking my comments.

Title: Comment submitted by G. Jacobson
Comment:
Dear Environmental Protection Agency,

My name is Gabriel Jacobson and I am a deckhand for a commercial fishing boat in Bristol Bay. I am from Seattle, and currently am in my senior year at Whitman College, as an Anthropology major. I began working in Bristol Bay because my dad did so in the 1970s, while working for Dillingham Legal Services as a public defender, and had some really intriguing stories to tell about his experiences. I had never been much of a fisherman before this, but once I became interested in fishing and worked in Bristol Bay for a few years, seeing the Incredible salmon runs, the beauty of their strength and persistence and courage, I have gained an immense interest in salmon and their importance to everyone who relies on them. My experience in Bristol Bay with the salmon involves not just commercial fishing for them on a boat, but watching them and fishing for them in the upper lakes of Wood-Tikchik State Park. 
The salmon runs in the pacific northwest are all but gone, thanks to moves by industrial american society towards the west and into indigenous lands. American local and federal policy has depleted the natural resources (such as salmon) that native peoples relied on not only as an incidental side effect, but as a strategy of colonization, resulting in the decimation and relocation of almost all indigenous Americans. Alaska, and particularly Bristol Bay is, in many ways, the last remaining hope and example for Pacific Northwest indians, in their subsistence way of life and its basis on salmon. 
I am currently conducting my senior thesis project at Whitman on the First Foods movement on the Umatilla reservation in Eastern Washington state. In the process of this project, I have spoken to a great number of people (mostly tribal members) who have expressed regret and hopefulness as to the decimation and return of the once colossal and vital salmon runs in BC, Washington, Oregon, and California. The only remaining reference they have for how things used to be, lies in Bristol Bay. Seeing what these salmon runs could be like (how they are in Bristol Bay), and seeing what they will become if development is allowed to go unchecked (how they are in most of the PNW)--makes me completely convinced that measures need to be taken, if not to put the Pebble mine operations to a complete halt, to further regulate and mitigate its effects.

In summary, the ecosystem that is at risk here is so vital to historically mistreated peoples, so fragile, and has been repeatedly mistreated to the extent that it makes no sense for the agency whose job it is to protect just those ecosystems to rescind its scientifically-based decision to protect it. There are so many livelihoods, so much land and sea, and so many lives at stake here that the EPA must do its job and protect our natural environment and its resources. 

Sincerely,

Gabriel Jacobson

Title: Comment submitted by C. Lutz
Comment:
I am submitting a comment to support the American jobs and communities protected by the Bristol Bay Proposed Determination.  Bristol Bay is one of America's last great wild salmon fisheries.  Tens of millions of wild salmon return annually which (a) support upwards of 14,000 American jobs in the commercial and sport fishing industries, (b) serve as a one-in-a-lifetime destination for anglers from around the world, and (c) are the cultural cornerstone for the region's communities.  The proposed Pebble mine would put Bristol Bay at significant risk of severe environmental degradation, would devour an area almost the size of Anchorage Alaska, entail five huge earthen dams, the largest of which would be larger than the Gorges Dam in China and require substantial infrastructure development.
The Bristol Bay Proposed Determination was made pursuant to the Clean Water Act in 2014.  In 2010, led by Alaska Native Tribes, interests including commercial fishing business owners and sportsmen asked the EPA step in to ensure that the proposed Pebble mine would not jeopardize Bristol Bay.  The EPA responded by listening to over 1.5 million Americans, hosting dozens of community meetings, reviewing Pebble's many detailed filings with state and federal agencies, and conducting a twice peer-reviewed scientific assessment of the potential impacts to the region.  Withdrawing the determination would ignore the overwhelming majority of Alaskans (65 percent of Alaskans and more than 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents oppose the Pebble mine development), ignores peer reviewed scientific assessments and puts the short-term interests of a foreign mining company above thousands of American jobs.

The facts have not changed.  Keep the 2014 Bristol Bay Proposed Determination.

References:
U.S. EPA. An Assessment of Potential Mining Impacts on Salmon Ecosystems of Bristol Bay, Alaska (Final Report). U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Washington, DC, EPA 910-R-14-001A-C, ES, 2014.
EPA Region 10, Proposed Determination Pursuant to Section 404(c) of the Clean Water Act for Pebble Deposit Area, Southwest Alaska, July 21, 2014.
2017 EPA and Pebble Limited Partnership Agreement.
U.S. EPA. An Assessment of Potential Mining Impacts on Salmon Ecosystems of Bristol Bay, Alaska (Final Report). U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Washington, DC, EPA 910-R-14-001A-C, ES, 2014. Chapter 5.
United Tribes of Bristol Bay. Opposition to Pebble Mine Reiterated by local tribes, fishermen, business owners.
Alaska Bristol Bay Mining Ban, Ballot Measure 4 (2014).

Sincerely,
Christopher Lutz

Title: Comment submitted by D. Conners
Comment:
To Whom it May Concern:

I support the EPA's withdrawal of the Proposed Determination on the Pebble Mine Project. This project must be properly
evaluated using the traditional NEPA permitting process, which will allow the full social, economic, and environmental impacts
of the project to be considered.

Withdrawal of the Proposed Determination will NOT harm the environment; it only allows the Pebble Partnership to engage in
the normal permitting process.  The conduct of the EPA over the last 40 years confirms that its issuance of a preemptive veto 
is unprecedented.  The EPA has only exercised its authority under Section 404(c) thirteen times.  In each instance, the EPA 
invoked Section 404(c) only after receipt of a permit application that described the scope and details of the project being 
proposed, the anticipated environmental impact, and techniques to be employed to mitigate or control that impact.  In 2015, 
the House Oversight Committee concluded that "the EPA's use of a preemptive veto (at Pebble) was unprecedented and 
without a legal basis."  The Committee went on to describe the EPA's course of action as "an unprecedented change in the 
agency's process for regulating resource and development projects," and called on the EPA to "cease all preemptive 404(c) 
activity" to allow for the normal permitting process to take place.

The Proposed Determination must be withdrawn to remedy the EPA's prior overreach.  Under the Clean Water Act, the Corps 
of Engineers has the authority to grant permits while the EPA only has the authority to veto permits, not impose pre-permit 
restrictions on development over large areas of land.  Rather than waiting for PLP to file a Section 404 permit application, and 
adhering to the traditional permitting process, EPA commissioned an assessment of the Bristol Bay region - the flawed Bristol 
Bay Watershed Assessment.  Many Alaska industry and trade associations expressed concern about the EPA abandoning the 
normal process for evaluating projects such as Pebble.  They joined with national trade associations in expressing this 
concern multiple times.  Removing the Proposed Determination is an important step in returning fair and due process to the 
EPA.  The rules and the rule of law matter. 

Withdrawing the Proposed Determination will have a variety of beneficial effects. It will show voters that due process is still 
followed and respected in this country. And it will provide a signal to the investing community that the United States is in fact 
still open to innovation, opportunity, and job creation.

Thank you for giving me the opportunity to comment on this proposal.

Sincerely,
Dean Conners

Title: Comment submitted by E. Buchanan
Comment:
Dear Administrator Pruitt and Acting Region 10 Administrator Pirzadeh,

I am writing you today to ask that you stand with American jobs and communities and not withdraw the Bristol Bay Proposed Determination, which it made pursuant to the Clean Water Act in 2014 (Docket EPA-R10-OW-2017-0369).

As you are well aware, Bristol Bay, Alaska, is one of America's last great wild salmon fisheries. Tens of millions of wild salmon return annually, which support upwards of 14,000 American jobs in the commercial and sport fishing industries, serve as a one-in-a-lifetime destination for anglers from around the world, and are the cultural cornerstone for the region's communities.

These long-established American businesses and jobs are at risk from a foreign-owned mining company that wants to build the proposed Pebble Mine, which is opposed by more than 65 percent of Alaskans and more than 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents. 

In 2010, led by Alaska Native Tribes, interests including commercial fishing business owners and sportsmen asked the EPA step in to ensure that this mine wouldn't jeopardize Bristol Bay. The EPA responded by listening to over 1.5 million Americans, hosting dozens of community meetings, reviewing Pebble's many detailed filings with state and federal agencies, and conducting a twice peer-reviewed scientific assessment of the potential impacts to the region.

Withdrawing the proposed determination ignores the overwhelming majority of Alaskans and puts the short-term interests of a foreign mining company above thousands of American jobs. 

I urge you to listen to the voices of those who have spoke out, and for the sake of the Bristol Bay watershed, its world-class salmon fishery and its people, keep the door closed on Pebble Mine. If you don't, you will have to answer to me and hundreds of thousands of people in Alaska and across the United States and the world who stand in fervent opposition to this toxic mega-mine. 

Sincerely,

Eric Buchanan

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I am a hydrologist and one of the few people who has actually pored through Pebble's 20,000+ page report on their environmental studies. Their report contains very little accessible raw data where their conclusions can be independently evaluated. Having looked specifically at their conclusions regarding surface and groundwater (where all their modeling is based on only one faulty well drilled to the proposed mine depth), I can say that the studies have been woefully inadequate. The surface and groundwater conditions are vital to the survival of the last fully intact salmon fishery in the world.

The Pebble Limited Partnership has asked the scientific community to not judge the proposed mine based on the past failures of nearly every large-scale mining operation, but to take their work that somehow they have designed a mine that would adequately predict and mitigate for all possible contingencies. Rather than presenting these designs to the public and to EPA during the 404(c) review process, PLP withheld that information, so the EPA was forced to use PLP's older proposed design specifications and current industry best management practices to evaluate whether or not to take action. 

EPA's analysis was peer reviewed by a wide range of technical experts, including mining professionals and industry experts before reaching the conclusion that under current best practices, the proposed mine would not be able to operate without adversely affecting the watershed. While the PLP trucked out a long series of paid consultants to dispute the EPA's findings, not a single one of them presented a case for a design that would protect the Bristol Bay Watershed; they only commented on the technical flaws of EPA's general evaluative design. 

The NEPA process is quite valuable for carefully evaluating the impacts of a proposed project, but is not free from the influence of special interest groups and political pressure. The best decision for the environment is frequently trumped by promises of "world-class" mitigation that is dropped once the project has been approved and the financial realities of the mitigation are realized. One great example of this was the promised use of double-hulled vessels for hauling oil from the pipeline out of Valdez. The oil companies paraded technical specifications of the latest and greatest double-hulled ships that they all vowed to use for transportation during the NEPA process. Once the approvals were finished, the companies successfully argued that these ships were too expensive and were then allowed to use less protective ships that led to the Exxon Oil Spill; the last major environmental disaster to hit Alaska.

The Watershed Assessment that was conducted by your agency was done in a transparent and public manner, giving all stakeholders a voice in the process. The assessment was peer reviewed by environmental and industry professionals and their input was used to inform the final decision based on established EPA policy. Just because there is new political pressure does not invalidate these analyses and the EPA should not withdraw the determination.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
Please don't put the interests of a foreign mining company above thousands of American jobs and Alaska Native cultural integrity. Keep the EPA's Clean Water Act protections for Bristol Bay in place!

The EPA has previously determined that the planned Pebble mine would cause great damage to the unparalleled salmon runs and local fisheries as well as to local Native communities. This fact hasn't changed, so there is no reason to retract the determination!

The foreign-owned Pebble mine would cause significant damage to the world-renowned salmon runs of Bristol Bay. This fishery is worth moth than 1.5 million dollars a year and supports 14,000 jobs. All of this would be put at risk for the interests of a non-American mining company with limited time frame of operation and profit. Damage from this mine, however, will not be limited, it will be irreversible and permanent!

Please listen to the local communities, the best available science, and the American people. Do not reverse course on the Pebble mine! Thank you.

Title: Comment submitted by T. Chu
Comment:
Dear EPA Administrator,

I am writing regarding EPA-R10-OW-2017-0369, the proposed withdrawal of protections from the Bristol Bay. Please protect the  Bristol Bay watershed from mine waste disposal. The proposed Pebble Mine presents a long-term risk to the sustainability of this important fishery, and all the people and businesses that rely on it. The Bristol Bay sockeye salmon population is a third of the world's wild salmon, a population and ecosystem that will be irrevocably damaged if mining companies are allowed to use their home as a dumping ground. We are already entering the Anthropocene, with species and populations going extinct at an ever-increasing rate thanks to human influence and impact. We must take action to protect the species we can, including these sockeye salmon.

Please maintain and apply the existing provisions of the Clean Water Act to protect this large and irreplaceable wild salmon fishery.  

Sincerely, Tiffany Chu
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment: The EPA should not withdraw the Proposed Clean Water Act Restrictions on Mining Pebble Deposit. It's not about short-term gain. It's about long-term damage that will be done if the waste water is deposited in Alaska's Bristol Bay watershed. Discharge of dredged or fill material associated with the potential "Pebble Mine" needs to be restricted based on the fact that the watershed will be polluted beyond repair by this discharge. What about the salmon spawning? The Bristol Bay watershed is an area of exceptional ecological value with salmon fisheries unrivaled anywhere in North America. The fisheries in the area depend on those salmon to stay in business. That will all be gone if the water is polluted. The salmon populations are critical to the health of the entire ecosystem, which is home to more than 20 fish species, 190 bird species, and more than 40 terrestrial mammal species, including bears, moose, and caribou. The EPA estimates the mine would require excavation of the largest open pit ever constructed in North America and would cover nearly 7 square miles at a maximum depth of over 3/4 of a mile. Protect our water and the lives that it supports.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment: Please do not withdraw the determination to restrict use of the Pebble Deposit Area as a disposal site. The long-term risks of opening up the waters of the South Fork Koktuli River, the North Fork Koktuli River, and the Upper Talarik Creek watershed to debris from mining sites are not worth the short-term gains that a mining deposit in one of our last great resources in America would bring. Allowing the Pebble area to be mined would expose all of these waters to the types of contamination that cannot be reversed. Mining in the Pebble Deposit area would cost America 20,000 jobs, including 12,000 in the remote area of Bristol Bay, alone. We need these jobs. Countless animals depend upon the salmon who spawn in the Bristol Bay each year. Nearly half of the world's sockeye salmon catch comes from this one region. We need these fish. Withdrawing this restriction on mining deposits would drive jobs out, animals to starvation, and fish prices way up. We need not to withdraw this restriction from the Pebble Deposit Area. Thank you for your time and attention to this matter, I hope you do not approval this withdrawal.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
The Peeble Mine threatens Bristol Bay fisheries and the 14,000 jobs that depend on Bristol Bay's clean, healthy waters. EPA must keep the Bristol Bay 404(c) Proposed Determination in place to protect Bristol Bay, its salmon, waters, people, and sustainable economy from the proposed Pebble Mine.

EPA's own scientific study contains highly concerning facts: even without a mine disaster, construction of the Pebble deposit will destroy 94 miles of salmon streams and 5,350 acres of wetlands, lakes and ponds. Overall, EPA concluded that mining the headwaters of the Bristol Bay river systems could cause irreparable harm to the valuable Bristol Bay fishery, wildlife, and people.
According to the EPA's own study, the Bristol Bay watershed provides vital habitat for 29 fish species, more than 190 bird species, and more than 40 terrestrial animals. All five species of Pacific salmonsockeye, Chinook, coho, chum and pinkspawn and rear in the pristine Bristol Bay watershed. The Bristol Bay watershed supports the largest sockeye salmon run in the world, producing approximately 46% of the world's wild sockeye harvest, creating $1.5 billion in economic output and nearly 20,000 jobs throughout the United States annually.
Because of its great ecological and economic value, I recommend the EPA keep in place the 404(c) Proposed Determination for Bristol Bay, Southwest Alaska. The reasonable restrictions included in that proposal will prevent unsustainable development that would adversely impact the region's fishery, recreation and local culture.
Please keep the agency's 404(c) action in place to protect one of the nation's greatest sustainable resourcesthe Bristol Bay, Alaska, salmon fishery.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I urge the EPA not to withdraw its 2014 EPA Region 10 proposed CWA Section 404(c) determination in the matter of the Pebble Deposit Area, Southwest Alaska, a determination made after extensive consideration of the unavoidable deleterious impact of large scale mining in the Bristol Bay watershed. Further, in the event a decision were to be made allowing the withdrawal of the proposed determination I would urge the EPA Administrator to review and reconsider that decision. 

The purpose of the restrictions is to protect a watershed that is among other things home to the largest sockeye salmon fishery in the world, supporting commercial, sport, personal and traditional subsistence use. It depends on healthy, intact ecosystems which would be jeopardized by mining activity. The ability of commercially harvested seafood from the region to command top prices in international markets depends upon the purity of the seafood, and upon the world renowned purity of the environment from which it comes. Healthy, intact ecosystems are not to be squandered, particularly when the ecological and economic consequences are dire. The resources involved have value not only to Alaskans, but to the nation and to the world.

My perspective is shaped by a quarter century of professional experience. I spent a dozen years working for members of the Alaska State Legislature representing coastal communities deeply reliant on the Alaska seafood industry, and whose residents also participated in sport, personal use and subsistence activities.  I spent a couple of years working for Alaska's largest commercial fishing organization, United Fishermen of Alaska. I spent another dozen years as director with Alaska's international seafood marketing arm (the Alaska Seafood Marketing Institute, established by the commercial harvesters and seafood processors of Alaska's commercial seafood industry).  Thank you for considering my comments.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
The Pebble ore body is mainly low-grade copper-gold-moly deposit that is deeply buried and will require enormous excavation. Copper is incredibly toxic to fish and other aquatic life, never mind that the presence of pyrite in the ore virtually ensures that acid conditions will be a given. (After the pyrite is dug up and exposed to air and water, it oxidizes to form sulfuric acid). Under acidic pH, copper is even more toxic to fish.

To even think about mining this ore body is insane. Acid waters will form. The earthen dam will leak. There is no humanly possible way to prevent wholesale destruction of the fisheries, should this mine be developed. Such development WILL destroy the fisheries and the rest of the aquatic ecosystem...for thousands of years, at least.

A category 3 hurricane just hit Ireland. Ireland. Think about that. And yet this administration denies science, denies manmade global warming. To develop the Pebble ore body and think it might not permanently destroy the ecosystem is yet another instance of denial.

Comment:
I strongly oppose the withdrawal of the Bristol Bay Proposed Determination and Clean Water Act protections for the Bristol Bay Watershed. Do NOT mine here! If this place is destroyed by mining, it will never recover.  It is imperative that we protect this natural resource in a sustainable way that will not only provide jobs and resources now, but for generations to come.
This is one of the last healthy salmon fisheries in the world and accounts for nearly half of the worlds sockeye salmon.  It is a resource that provides over 14000 + jobs and millions of dollars annually to the world economy. It is vital that we take action to preserve unique and fragile ecosystems such as the Bristol Bay watershed.

Sincerely, 

Julia Byers 
Denver CO
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
Hello,

As someone who cares that healthy rivers, salmon, fishing communities, and native peoples exist when my 4-year-old is my age, I heartily oppose the construction of any mine or deposit area in or around Bristol Bay, Alaska. 

Would a mine and deposit area provide jobs in the short-term? Yes. But mineral deposits are finite. Let's not also forget the enormous, intangible value of salmon as part of Alaska's cultural heritage, and the mainstay for an entire ecosystem of bears, eagles, other fish, and humans. Salmon-fishing is a $1.5 billion RENEWABLE industry, supporting over 14,000 jobs, not just right now, but into the future. Consider, too, the $90 million fishing and outdoor-related tourism to Bristol Bay brings to Alaska. 

Development of the area is not just short-sighted, it's greedy and places the values of consumption over the value of life and the very existence of our planet's most incredible resources. In 2013, the final Bristol Bay Watershed Assessment found that a mine the size, type and location of Pebble will almost definitely harm Bristol Bay's salmon.

I do not want some place as magnificent as Bristol Bay to be turned into the next Conga Mine (or take your pick of the devastating extractive projects throughout Latin America, Africa, and Asia), where environmental destruction doesn't only impact the land, but it also breeds conflict and violence.

In summary, please do not withdraw the restricted use determination of the Pebble Deposit Area. The forever risks are too high for the time-limited rewards. 

Thank you for your consideration.

Title: Comment submitted by D. Sherman
Comment:
Regarding the proposed withdrawal of the " EPA Region 10 July 2014 Proposed Determination that was issued pursuant of the Clean Water Act, to restrict the use of certain waters in the South Fork Koktuli River, North Fork Koktuli River, and Upper Talarik Creek watersheds in southwest Alaska as disposal sites for dredged or fill material associated with mining the Pebble deposit, a copper-, gold-, and molybdenum-bearing ore body."

Title: Comment submitted by R. Wood
Comment:
I sent these via email, but then saw this is the preferred method.

Dear EPA:

Please do not withdraw the EPA Region 10 July 2014 Proposed Determination that was issued pursuant of the Clean Water Act.   As an Alaskan who has visited Bristol Bay and knows first hand the value of the incredible salmon fishery there, I supported EPA's determination "to restrict the use of certain waters in the South Fork Koktuli River, North Fork Koktuli River, and Upper Talarik Creek watersheds in southwest Alaska as disposal sites for dredged or fill material associated with mining the Pebble deposit, a copper-, gold-, and molybdenum-bearing ore body."  

Regardless of why EPA agreed to initiate this proposed withdrawal process, the determination should not be withdrawn.  The  Pebble Limited Partnership (PLP)'s subsidiaries may own the mineral claims to the Pebble deposit, but they do not own the land, the water, the fish.  Alaskans who depend on the land, the water, the fish do not support PLP or its subsidiaries, and they have been testifying so to EPA.  I hope you are listening.  

The mine, whether in its supposedly smaller form or in its potentially monstrous form, cannot be build without poisoning the land and water, and that means the fishery will be destroyed too, and we are talking millions of wild salmon.  These wild salmon are important not only to Alaskan but to other  Americans too.  Commercial fishermen and sport fishing visitors are a huge factor in Alaska's economy, and should not be put in jeopardy in order to support the foreign owned PLP.  These salmon feed Americans from local subsistence users to families all over the United States.  

EPA's determination was not made lightly.  It was made after extensive scientific research, consideration of impacts, and public comments.  It's hard to believe that this administration would put the interests of a foreign company above the interests of Americans, but that's sure what it looks like.   I hope I'm wrong and EPA will do the right thing and leave the determination in place.

Sincerely,
Ruth Wood, 
Talkeetna, Alaska
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment submitted by P. Wood
Comment:
Dear EPA,
I am writing to express my opposition to the EPA's May 2017 settlement agreement with Pebble Partnership (a more benign sounding name for Northern Dynasty Mining Company, a Canadian corporation and 100% owner of Pebble Partnership).  The EPA determined back in 2014 that the Clean Water Act prohibited the type of project Northern Dynasty Mining Company had proposed for Bristol Bay.  Yet despite this conclusion, in May of 2017 the EPA agreed to a settlement with Northern Dynasty Mining Company.  In a nutshell, the settlement terms were as follows: Northern Dynasty would drop the lawsuits it filed against the EPA in exchange for the EPA agreeing to withdraw its regulatory conclusion that Northern Dynasty Mining Company's proposed mining operation violated the Clean Water Act.  The public was not allowed to engage, comment, or otherwise take part in the settlement, which was negotiated behind closed doors.

Scott Pruitt, the EPA Administrator heralded the settlement, noting that while the EPA was "committed to due process and the rule of law... [the settlement would] help steer EPA away from costly and time-consuming litigation..."  Yet Pruitt's assertion completely contradicts due process and the rule of law.  The EPA made its Clean Water Act ruling in 2014, prompting Northern Dynasty Mining Company to immediately file suit, as Northern Dynasty Mining Company was entitled to do.  But now, with the settlement, the EPA is simply allowing Northern Dynasty Mining Company to submit its permit despite the EPA having already determined the proposed mine would violate the Clean Water Act.  In effect, the EPA's settlement completely nullifies due process and the rule of law, which dictate that the matter is settled vis--vis the Administrative Agency (the EPA) and the Northern Dynasty Mining Company.  If the Northern Dynasty Mining Company wants to fight the EPAs's ruling, they should do so through the Judicial Branch.  That is the very purpose behind our Constitution's three branches of government, which the settlement completely circumvents.  

In 2016, Donald Trump ran on a pledge to put America first.  Yet nothing could be more antithetical to putting Americans first than allowing foreign profiteers to bypass the Clean Water Act and imperil Bristol Bay's unparalleled salmon fishery, which accounts for over 14,000 American jobs!  Thus, I request that the EPA live up to its name as the Environmental Protection Agency, which begins by not agreeing to a backroom settlement with a foreign mining company that not only circumvents the rule of law, but also risks American jobs and American resources.

Sincerely, 

Pete Wood
2200 Saint Johns Ave. Apt. A-23
Billings, MT 59102
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment submitted by D. Hogg
Comment:
Please find the following as my comments.

I am opposed to the EPA's decision to withdraw Clean Water Act restrictions for the Pebble Mine. As professional civil engineer for a local municipality, I work to protect the waters of the state of Minnesota. As directed by the state of Minnesota, city engineers enforce the Clean Water Act. I want to continue to protect our waters for future generations. Rescinding the Clean Water Act means returning to a time when unregulated companies can threaten our country's water. I oppose the action for the following reasons:

 First, the facts have not changed. The proposed Pebble Mine would sit at the headwaters of Bristol Bay's watershed, which is home to record wild salmon runs exceeding 50 million fish annually. Bristol Bay's $1.5 billion annual sustainable commercial fishery provides 14,000 jobs and supplies half of the world's sockeye salmon. Salmon are not only the linchpin of the region's economy, but also its lifeblood, providing food, a subsistence-based livelihood, and the sustainable foundation for the language, spirituality, and social structure of its tribal communities.

 Second, the science has not changed. The Pebble Mineas last proposed by the Pebble Limited Partnership to its investors and the US Securities and Exchange Commissionwould generate up to 10 billion tons of toxic mining waste, covering an area larger than Manhattan and filling a major football stadium up to 3,900 times. Giant earthen damssome larger than 700 feet tallwould be constructed to hold back the leach-prone mine tailings forever, all in an active earthquake zone. According to the EPA's three-year, twice peer-reviewed scientific assessment of mining impacts on the Bristol Bay Watershedwhich evaluated three different mining scenarioseven the smallest mining scenario would destroy numerous miles of salmon streams and thousands of acres of wetlands. Contrary to comments by the backers of the Pebble Mine project, the EPA's watershed assessment was scientifically based and thoroughly peer-reviewed, and the public has had an extensive opportunity to comment on it. The assessment and public comments received should be key components of any future action on this issue.

 Third, the rationale for the proposed withdrawal is flawed. Finalizing the proposed determination would provide much more regulatory certainty than withdrawing it, and a permit application is not needed to augment the factual record.

 Most important, the opposition has not changed. More than 65 percent of Alaskans, 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents and Native communities, and 85 percent of commercial fishermen oppose the mine. The world opposes the mine too. Last year, the IUCN World Conservation Congress virtually unanimously adopted a motion opposing the Pebble Mine

The EPA's decision to withdraw Clean Water Act restrictions for the Pebble Mine is a mistake and goes against the spirit of the Clean Water Act. The peer-reviewed watershed assessment clearly illustrates the potently hazard this mine poses to the environment, economy, and way of life of hundreds of thousands of citizens.

Andrew Hogg

Title: Comment submitted by C. Check
Comment:
To whom it may concern:

Section 404 of the Clean Water Act states that discharge of dredged material may not be permitted if the nation's waters would be significantly degraded. The Pebble Mine is a massive and high risk operation that would undoubtedly cause a negative impact on one of the United States' most prolific and economically important watersheds. The EPA's assessment of mining impacts states that the probability of a failure in the product concentrate, return water, and diesel pipeline is 95% in the next 25 years, a concentrate spill in a stream or wetland is likely to occur at least once in the next 78 years, and an eventual failing of the water collection and treatment is certain. Additionally, truck accidents, culvert blockages, and tailings spills are all likely to occur. Any one of these disasters could have a serious impact on the watershed's significant salmon population (most notably, 46% of the global sockeye population), and for this reason, the EPA must not withdraw the proposed determination, and take all possible measures to prevent mining development from occurring in the Bristol Bay region. The Bristol Bay watershed is key habitat for 29 fish species, including all 5 Pacific salmon species. The salmon industry alone supports 14,000 jobs (significantly more than the 2,000 jobs created by the Pebble Mine), generates $1.5 billion in economic output. The salmon are also a key to the continued health of the Bristol Bay region, as the serve as an important annual nutrient source for the surrounding wildlife and soil. The high productivity of this ecosystem is due in large part to the pristine and undeveloped nature of the watershed, making the Pebble Mine a dangerous and unwarranted threat to not only the ecosystem, but to the livelihoods of thousands of Americans, including numerous native people who have been sustainably fishing the land for centuries. This is why 86.2% of fisherman in the area are opposed to the development of the mine. Furthermore, the mine has a predicted lifespan of only about 100 years, while the salmon fishery, if left undisturbed, could last in perpetuity. It does not make sense to degrade one of the most ecologically and economically important ecosystems of the United States for the sake of a short-term, foreign-owned development operation whose impact will be irreversible. The EPA is allowed to reject a company's ability to apply for permits if a water source will be significantly degraded, and it is clear from the EPA's initial assessment that the dangers posed by the Pebble Mine are far too great to warrant a permit application. I urge the EPA to maintain its initial Proposed Determination and to place the health of Bristol Bays ecosystem and human population at the forefront of their decision making. 

Sincerely,

Courtney Check
11616 Holly Briar Lane
Great Falls, VA 22066
courtneyecheck@gmail.com

Title: Comment submitted by J. Christensen
Comment:
I am writing you today to ask that you stand with American jobs and communities and not withdraw the Bristol Bay Proposed Determination, which it made pursuant to the Clean Water Act in 2014.

Bristol Bay, Alaska, is one of America's last great wild salmon fisheries. Tens of millions of wild salmon return annually, which support upwards of 14,000 American jobs in the commercial and sport fishing industries, serve as a one-in-a-lifetime destination for anglers from around the world, and are the cultural cornerstone for the region's communities.

These long-established American businesses and jobs are at risk from a foreign-owned mining company that wants to build the proposed Pebble Mine, which is opposed by more than 65 percent of Alaskans and more than 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents. Living in Seattle, it is clear to me that seafood is a vital and tenuous American industry that we must strive to protect.

Withdrawing the proposed determination ignores the majority of Alaskans and puts the short-term interests of a foreign mining company above thousands of American jobs and the prosperity that comes from such rich ocean resource. 

Please do not withdraw the proposed determination!

Sincerely,
Joseph Christensen

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I am opposed to the Environmental Protection Agency's proposal to withdraw the July 2014 Proposed Determination to restrict the use of certain waters in southwest Alaska as disposal sites for dredged or fill material associated with Pebble Mine. I believe the EPA's original determination was founded in scientific evidence and logic. The proposed mining activities at Pebble Mine have a high likelihood of negatively impacting the pristine ecosystem in southwest Alaska. Although the Pebble Limited Partnership (PLP) claims it can construct and operate this mine in harmony with the environment, I find this extremely doubtful. Once the mining operation begins, any failure at a mine of this magnitude would be catastrophic. As is evident throughout human history, avoiding all mistakes is impossible. Given the geological qualities of the area as being less stable, unexpected tailing dam failures or other ecological disasters are not unlikely. To allow this proposed mining operation to occur would be gross negligence on the part of the EPA.

Considering the extreme risks associated with this proposed mining project, the public is left with a choice between the salmon industry and the Pebble Mine. This portion of the world is renowned for it's salmon fishery, worth more than $1 billion dollars US. The most significant aspect of this industry is that it is renewable- so long as adult salmon continue to have access to clean freshwater systems for spawning. The salmon industry could potentially continue harvesting fish for many decades to come. In contrast, the Pebble Mine is not a renewable resource, and once the available minerals are obtained there will be no further income generated. PLP claims that the Pebble Mine will bring jobs to southwest Alaska, while ignoring the thousands of jobs that their project will put at risk.

In conclusion, I am opposed to the EPA's proposal to withdraw it's proposed determination. I believe the unique ecosystem of Bristol Bay needs to be protected, and the proposed Pebble Mine threatens the Alaskan environment. Although Pebble Mine could potentially generate jobs and revenue, these benefits would only be temporary and not worth the high risk to the currently thriving salmon industry. The logical choice is to protect Alaska's environment, salmon industry, and future by rejecting the Pebble Mine project and upholding the previous Proposed Determination.

Comment: I am a member of the public who is deeply concerned about the direction our country is heading in terms of environmental protection, sustainability, and management. The decision to withdraw regulation of the Pebble Mine site is not based on science or public opinion. It is based on the interests of corporations that see these Clean Water Act regulations as unnecessary financial burdens. Our country's history has shown the necessity of environmental regulations, and it is simply foolish to believe that we can do better without them.

Title: Comment submitted by D. Shirar
Comment:
I'm writing in reference to Docket # EPA-HQ-ORD-2012-0276. Please prohibit the storage and/or disposal of mine waste in Alaska's Bristol Bay watershed. The proposed Pebble Mine presents a long-term risk to the sustainability of this important fishery, and all the people and businesses that rely on it. In 2010, Bristol Bay salmon fishermen harvested 29 million sockeye salmon worth $165 million in direct harvest value alone. That represented 31% of the total Alaska salmon harvest value.The Bristol Bay 2017 harvest of all salmon species was 39.8 million fish; ranking second over the last 20 years (1997-2016) and worth a preliminary estimated value of $214.6 million almost double the 20-year average of $108.9 million and ranks second during that time frame , as reported by the Alaska Department of Fish and Game Division of Commercial Fisheries.
Mines come and go, but leave waste behind from the processing of ore, which under current methods is stored on-site for centuries. Bristol Bay is an earthquake heavy region making it almost certain that storage of tailings (toxic semi-liquid mine waste) will fail. January 24, of last year, Southern Alaska experienced a 7.1 magnitude earthquake that cracked roadways. It should be noted that this would be classified as a major earthquake capable of causing serious damage. In Bristol bay, this waste would most likely be Acid Mine Drainage due to oxidation of unearthed pyrite,  or "fool's gold" which is often found in conjunction with valuable metals.

Bristol Bay  has been called  the  "Salmon factory of the world", offers five species of Salmon: King, Sockeye, Chum, Pink and Silver Salmon along with 7 species of fresh water fish: Rainbow Trout, Arctic Char, Arctic Grayling, Dolly Varden, Lake Trout and Northern Pike.Many families rely on wild salmon as a uniquely nutritious source of protein, rich in essential omega-3 fats and vitamin D. Farmed salmon is not nutritionally identical (much lower in vitamin D, much higher in saturated fats and pro-inflammatory omega-6 fats) and poses its own environmental risks. I urge the EPA to take immediate action to use existing provisions of the Clean Water Act to protect this large and irreplaceable wild salmon fishery. The short-term gains of mining projects in the area outweighed by the long term risk to the environment and the economy. Please continue to ensure the well-being of this vital waterway by enforcing the EPA region 10 July 2014 Proposed Determination."
 
Sincerely, David Shirar 
dshirar77@gmail.com
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment submitted by E. Russ
Comment:
October 17, 2017
Elisa Russ
PO Box 15152
Fritz Creek, AK 99603
Re: Docket No. EPA-R10-OW-2017-0369
I strongly oppose withdrawal of the 2014 EPA Proposed Determination1.
I believe that the EPA has authority under Part 231 Section 404(c) procedures to prohibit or withdraw specification of any defined area as a disposal site regardless of whether a specific application has been filed for an area2. The EPA had legal authority to issue the 2014 Proposed Determination.
The EPA's 2014 findings showed the detrimental impact a large-scale mining operation would have on Bristol Bay fisheries and wildlife, and on the Alaska Native culture of the region.
I urge the EPA to retain the 2014 EPA Proposed Determination in the event a Recommended Determination is required after the terms of the 2017 Settlement Agreement between the EPA and Pebble Limited Partnership (PLP) have been met. The Settlement Agreement provides (Section III.A.1.),
If PLP does not submit a CWA Section 404 Permit Application regarding the Pebble
deposit to the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers (Corps) within 30 months from the
Effective Date of the Settlement Agreement, the Regional Administrator or his/her
designee may, at any time thereafter, forward a signed Recommended Determination and administrative record to EPA Headquarters pursuant to 40 C.F.R.  231.5(b).
Accordingly, the EPA must have its Proposed Determination ready for development into a Recommended Determination should PLP not timely file a CWA Section 404 Permit Application. If the existing 2014 Proposed Determination were withdrawn, the EPA would be required to develop, at great time and expense, a new proposed determination and to follow the lengthy public notice procedures pursuant to Section 404(c) Part 231.3. The EPA already has completed these procedures in developing the 2014 Proposed Determination and it would be redundant and costly to repeat them.
In the event that PLP timely files a CWA Section 404 Permit Application for the Pebble deposit,
the Settlement Agreement provides (Section III.A.1.),
The Regional Administrator or his/her designee may not forward a signed
Recommended Determination and administrative record to EPA Headquarters
pursuant to 40 C.F.R.  231.5(b) until EPA publishes a notice in the Federal Register
of the final Environmental Impact Statement (EIS) regarding PLP's Permit
Application pursuant to 40 C.F.R.  1506.lO(a) or 48 months from the Effective Date
of the Settlement Agreement, whichever is earlier in time.
The Settlement Agreement essentially provides for a DELAY in the Regional Administrator's
actions on the 2014 Proposed Determination; the Agreement does not provide for a
WITHDRAWAL of the Proposed Determination, therefore a withdrawal is premature and unnecessary, and a review of this decision by the Administrator would not add value and should not be required.
I vehemently oppose the proposed Pebble Mine. 
There are innumerable reasons why the PLP proposal for a mine at the Pebble site should
never, ever be considered or permitted:
The proposed mine conflicts with the stated mission of this administration to create jobs. Jobs
already exist in the region and would be sacrificed for a foreign owned mining company that
will take profits from the region elsewhere and leave devastation in its wake. There is no
justification for the sacrifice of the livelihood and lifestyle of local U.S. citizens for a foreign
owned mine:
- Alaska Natives, who are U.S. citizens, have lived in the region for 10,000 years and 7,500
subsistence peoples harvest 2.4 million pounds of fish a year worth $143 million a year;
- Commercial fisherman, also U.S. citizens, contribute, from this LARGEST commercial sockeye
fishery in the world, 51% of global catch at a total value of $1.5 billion and 14,000 jobs annually;
- Sport fishing generates $160 million annually from over 13,000 anglers from out of state
who spend $75 million and create 1200 jobs.
The sacrifice of local jobs is a certainty because no mine of the magnitude of that proposed by PLP has avoided the devastating effects of spills and leaching of toxic chemicals. The footprint of the proposed mine alone would destroy 100 miles of irreplaceable sensitive salmon habitat. The resulting disposal sites would need to be maintained IN PERPETUITY- FOREVER- after PLP have made their money and moved on. PLP and associated companies cannot guarantee that a mine at the Pebble site will not destroy the most pristine and valuable salmon habitat IN THE WORLD!
In summary, I believe that the EPA issuance of the 2014 Proposed Determination was the right action at the right time; I strongly oppose withdrawal of the 2014 Proposed Determination; I oppose a review by the Administrator of the decision in this docket regarding withdrawal of the 2014 Proposed Determination; AND I strongly oppose the PLP proposed mine at the Pebble site.
Respectfully submitted,
Elisa Russ

Title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by Friends of the Earth (web)

Title: Comment submitted by Robert Heyano, President, United Tribes of Bristol Bay (UTBB)
Comment: Please find attached the comments of the United Tribes of Bristol Bay concerning Docket ID No. EPA-R10-OW-2017-0369: Proposal to Withdraw Proposed Determination to Restrict the Use of an Area as a Disposal Site; Pebble Deposit Area, Southwest Alaska.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment submitted by Colles Stowell, President, One Fish Foundation
Comment:
That this measure is being considered after due process was already pursued ... thoroughly, is questionable at the least, damnable in reality. Applicants claim that building the mine will create jobs. However, the jobs created pale in comparison to the jobs already supported by the natural resource represented by the wild Pacific salmon runs. Consider that The Bristol Bay commercial fishery is valued at $1.5 billion annually and provides over 14,000 sustainable jobs. This does not include sport fishing's contribution of a total of  $1.4 billion on fishing trips, fishing equipment, and development and maintenance of land in 2007 in Alaska. Additionally, the 846 full- and part-time jobs in Bristol Bay, accounting for $27 million in total wages and benefits paid to employees and proprietors.

These numbers far exceed the estimated employment and total regional economic benefit proposed by the mine. So from a purely Alaska-centric view of jobs and total regional economic impact, the current existing economy is superior to the proposal from Northern Dynasty.

The ecological impact, which often gets swept under the rug in corporate filings, is a much more significant, and frightening prospect. The scope of the proposed mine is massive, even if the owners proposed to "downsize" the footprint, currently the size of Manhattan. The tailings impoundment alone needed to support such a huge operation would have to be mammoth. Nearly the depth of the Grand Canyon and several square miles in dimension, which by legal definition would have to hold the toxic byproduct of the mining process in perpetuity. This, perhaps is the most disturbing aspect of this entire issue. One need look no further than the recent, disastrous failure of the Mt. Polley Mine, which caused more than 26 million square yards of toxic copper, selenium and arsenic to be spilled into Hazeltine Creek, which fed the toxic waste into Quesnel Lake. Scientists are still trying to determine the long-term effects on local ecosystems, including fish, birds and other animals that depend on the watershed.

Now imagine that type of spill on a much larger scale at the headwaters of the world's largest wild salmon run, which includes the most significant sockeye salmon run. The devastation would be catastrophic in terms of ecological AND economic impacts. All of the jobs and billions of dollars tied to commercial and recreational fishing alone would likely be lost for a long term. There is no guarantee that if such a spill were to occur, that the salmon would ever come back...without suffering long-lasting damage to the gene pool. 

Finally, consider that more than 60% of Alaskans recently voted to support a measure that would ensure that any such mine that is proposed in ecologically sensitive areas --as Pebble is -- must be subjected to final state approval regarding watershed impact. In other words, Alaskans don't want the mine. 

So, if a majority of Alaskans DON'T want the mine, and likely most if not all commercial and both in-state and out-of-state recreational fishermen DON'T want the mine, and if most Native American tribes DON'T want the mine, AND the inherent risk of a devastating tailings impoundment failure looms, why build it? Moreover, why build it here?

I agree with the sentiment, Wrong Place, Wrong Mine. I say this as an educator talking to students of any age about sustainable seafood and the many impacts we have on seafood as a resource. I say this as a recreational fishermen who cares about the resource. And I say this as a father, who is teaching his daughter about the vital connection we have to nature, and the importance of balancing our needs as a modern society with preserving priceless natural resources.

Please do not void the very mission of the EPA and ignore the framework of the Clean Water Act. Doing so would only benefit a small percentage of people at the expense of much, much more.

Colles Stowell
President, One Fish Foundation
Yarmouth, Maine
