Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment: I think it's unreasonable to allow such a rich, diverse ecosystem to be destroyed just for the sake of opening up a gold and copper mine. Not only would it kill off half of the world's sockeye salmon population, but it would also ruin the livelihoods of the people who depend on these fish for food and money. It would also devastate Alaska's economy- while the metals produced by that mine may cushion it somewhat, Alaska as a whole is incredibly dependent on this vast source of food and income. Installing a mine wouldn't even come close to compensating for the losses that these people would suffer- not only to their jobs and earnings, but also to their homes. Seeing the beautiful place they have lived in and depended on for their entire lives be turned into an industrial nightmare would be unimaginably hard to cope with. This one mine is not worth the irreparable damage that would be done to the landscape, the ecosystem, the economy, or the people living there. Please continue your efforts to protect Bristol Bay.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I am opposed to the proposed action to withdrawal EPA's 2014 Clean Water Act Proposed Determination in regard to the discharge of dredged or fill material from potential mining activities in the Kvichak and Nushagak watersheds.
These watersheds form the heart of the last wild salmon fishery left in the world. The primary reason this fishery is an economic powerhouse of commercial and sport fishing is that the spawning, rearing, and migratory habitat in this area remain essentially undeveloped. Pacific salmon are unable to withstand the cumulative and far-reaching effects of modern economic development. Of all industries, mining is demonstrably incompatible with the life history and habitat requirements of Pacific salmon. To date, no large-scale mining project has shown the ability to minimize negative effects on aquatic biota to the degree by which the Pebble Partnership ensures it will safeguard freshwater resources in Bristol Bay.
Additionally, my husband is a commercial fisherman in Bristol Bay. His livelihood and our family's income depends on the health and long-term sustainability of the fishery. If the EPA cannot protect the surface and groundwater of this world treasure resource, then Bristol Bay's fishery may be lost like too many other salmon populations. Cascading effects on subsistence lifestyles, economy, and culture must be considered in weighing the merits of reopening Bristol Bay to this large-scale mining project. I ask that you do not remove the 2014 Clean Water Act Proposed Determination, on behalf of people and fish.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
As an Alaskan Native, I believe that rural Alaskans have the right to decide on the Pebble Mine. The people who actually rely on next seasons salmon run. I have experience as a commercial fisherman and have seen people who's last hope is fishing the summer salmon seasons. The salmon greatly impact the economy, and not only aid Alaskan natives in surviving in the economy brought upon us, but enrich everyone in the coastal rural areas of Alaska. Yes, Alaska is owned by the U.S., but rural Alaskans should at least have some say in the vote. Statistically, all the places in Alaska that were won over by Donald Trump, were heavily populated city's and not a rural place thriving off of the salmon run. Yes, salmon seasons have their bad years, but that's what makes the good seasons good. Donald Trump is a great person, but should not be making the decision on the pebble mine. He will not have to see the impact after the mine is through, and will not have to suffer if all the salmon are poisoned. I may only be in college and not as successful as Trump, but I am the future. Not only am I the future, but so are the salmon of next year.

Thanks for your time and enjoy your day.

Title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by National Wildlife Federation Action Fund (web)
Comment:
Attached are individual comments from 18,453 National Wildlife Federation Action Fund supporters asking the Environmental Protection Agency to protect wildlife and clean water and NOT eliminate protections for Bristol Bay, Alaska. There are 529 personalized comments. The balance of the comments include the following message:

"I urge you not to withdraw the Bristol Bay Proposed Determination that was issued in 2014 with extensive support from the public, commercial fisherman, Alaskans, and Native American Tribes. 

The Proposed Determination imposes common-sense restrictions that would protect Bristol Bay's wildlife, jobs, and communities from the dangerous Pebble Mine.  It should be approved as a Final Determination.

Pebble Mine threatens the grizzly bears and more than 250 species of fish and wildlife that depend on Bristol Bay's pure waters and pristine habitat for survival.  Pebble Mine threatens 14,000 American jobs in the commercial and sport fishing industries and the most valuable wild salmon fishery in the world.  That fishery supplies nearly half the world's sockeye salmon, generates $1.5 billion annually, sustains the traditions and salmon-based cultures of Alaska Natives, and provides a once-in-a-lifetime destination for anglers from around the world.
  
More than 65 percent of Alaskans, 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents and Native communities, and 85 percent of commercial fishermen oppose the Pebble Mine.

I urge you to listen to those voices and put the long-term health of the Bristol Bay watershed and its people, wildlife and world-class salmon fishery above the short-term interests of a foreign mining company.
 
Please retain and finalize the Proposed Determination."

Title: Mass comment campaign sponsored by Bristol Bay Native Corporation (BBNC) (web)
Abstract: Only 30 of the 33 comments mentioned by the submitter were received
Comment:
Dear Administrator Pruitt and Acting Regional Administrator Pirzadeh:

Attached please find 33 written comment letters to EPA on EPA-R10-OW-2017-0369. These letters are from Bristol Bay Native Corporation shareholders, collected at BBNC's annual shareholder meeting on October 7, 2017. All letters are from Alaska residents who live in or have close ties to Bristol Bay. All comments are supportive of EPA's actions to help protect Bristol Bay, are in opposition to the proposed Pebble mine, and/or support restrictions on mining the Pebble deposit.

BBNC will be separately submitting its own written comments on the proposed action.

Sincerely,

Daniel Cheyette
Bristol Bay Native Corporation
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
The proposed Clean Water Act determination should NOT be withdrawn. The potential impacts of the proposed Pebble Mine on the health of the Bristol Bay watershed and the livelihood of thousands of people in Alaska are far too great. Those risks include loss of up to up to 94 miles of salmon-supporting streams and up to 4,900 acres of wetlands and ponds, and the very real potential of wastewater dam failure resulting in damage to or destruction of the salmon fishery. The watershed supports the largest sockeye salmon fishery in the world and 25 federally recognized tribes who for 4,000 years have depended on the fishery for their subsistence-based culture. The overwhelming majority of residents of Bristol Bay are opposed to the project, and a statewide majority of voters also oppose it. The watersheds unique ecological resources generate significant economic benefits and employment. EPAs original watershed assessment was scientifically robust and thoroughly peer-reviewed. That assessment and related public comments should strongly influence any future action.

References:
U.S. EPA. An Assessment of Potential Mining Impacts on Salmon Ecosystems of Bristol Bay, Alaska (Final Report). U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Washington, DC, EPA 910-R-14-001A-C, ES, 2014.
EPA Region 10, Proposed Determination Pursuant to Section 404(c) of the Clean Water Act for Pebble Deposit Area, Southwest Alaska, July 21, 2014.
2017 EPA and Pebble Limited Partnership Agreement.
U.S. EPA. An Assessment of Potential Mining Impacts on Salmon Ecosystems of Bristol Bay, Alaska (Final Report). U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Washington, DC, EPA 910-R-14-001A-C, ES, 2014. Chapter 5.
United Tribes of Bristol Bay. Opposition to Pebble Mine Reiterated by local tribes, fishermen, business owners.
Alaska Bristol Bay Mining Ban, Ballot Measure 4 (2014).
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I am opposed to EPAs proposal to rescind the 2014 Proposed Determination designed to protect Bristol Bays world class fisheries. Please stand with American jobs and communities and preserve the Bristol Bay Proposed Determination.

Bristol Bay, Alaska, is one of America's last great wild salmon fisheries,
supporting upwards of 14,000 jobs in the commercial and sport fishing industries, and serving as a one-in-a-lifetime destination for anglers from around the world . These long-established businesses are at risk from a foreign-owned mining company that wants to build the proposed Pebble Mine, which is opposed by more than 65 percent of Alaskans and more than 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents. 

In 2014, led by Alaska Native Tribes, interests including commercial fishing business owners and sportsmen asked the EPA step in to ensure that this mine wouldn't jeopardize Bristol Bay. The EPA responded by listening to over 1.5 million Americans, hosting dozens of community meetings, reviewing Pebble's many detailed filings with state and federal agencies, and conducting a twice peer-reviewed scientific assessment of the potential impacts to the region. Withdrawing the proposed determination ignores the overwhelming majority of Alaskans and puts the short-term interests of a foreign mining company above thousands of local jobs. 

Clean water  and safe-to-eat salmon are more important than allowing a foreign business to make money instead of our local fishing and vacation businesses.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
Chapter four of the book SAPIENS, a Brief History Of Humankind by Yuval Noah Harare (the The Sunday Times Top Ten Bestseller) explains how our species has managed to cause mass extinction of large mammals in every continent we expand into. The author writes "Homo sapiens drove to extinction about half of the planet's big beasts long before humans invented the wheel, writing or iron tools." He backs this up with scientific evidence.  He continues with "Unlike their terrestrial counterparts, the large sea animals suffered relatively little from the Cognitive and Agricultural Revolutions. But many of them are on the brink of extinction now as a result of industrial pollution and human overuse of oceanic resources."

I am opposed to EPAs proposal to rescind the 2014 Proposed Determination designed to protect Bristol Bays world class fisheries. Please stand with American jobs and communities and preserve the Bristol Bay Proposed Determination.

Bristol Bay, Alaska, is one of America's last great wild salmon fisheries. Each year, tens of millions of wild salmon return, supporting upwards of 14,000 jobs in the commercial and sport fishing industries, and serving as a one-in-a-lifetime destination for anglers from around the world as well as the cultural cornerstone for the region's communities. These long-established businesses are at risk from a foreign-owned mining company that wants to build the proposed Pebble Mine, which is opposed by more than 65 percent of Alaskans and more than 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents. 

In 2014, led by Alaska Native Tribes, interests including commercial fishing business owners and sportsmen asked the EPA step in to ensure that this mine wouldn't jeopardize Bristol Bay. The EPA responded by listening to over 1.5 million Americans, hosting dozens of community meetings, reviewing Pebble's many detailed filings with state and federal agencies, and conducting a twice peer-reviewed scientific assessment of the potential impacts to the region. Withdrawing the proposed determination ignores the overwhelming majority of Alaskans and puts the short-term interests of a foreign mining company above thousands of local jobs. 

For the sake of our wildlife, waterways, and communities, I urge you to protect Bristol Bay and prevent this horrible open-pit mine from destroying one of our nation's most precious ecosystems.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I urge you to uphold and maintain the EPAs determination, under EPA Clean Water Act 404(c) authority, that Alaskas Bristol Bay is inappropriate for the proposed Pebble Mine  The mining companys continued effort to destroy the country's most productive salmon fishery in exchange for short-term mineral wealth is morally offensive and a gross misuse of this precious watershed.
 
The prospect of a hardrock mineral mining operation as such gargantuan proportions as envisioned by Northern Dynasty would devastate an exquisitely sensitive watershed and the rich productivity of aquatic life, capped by a salmon population of awesome fecundity. The food chain of Bristol Bay is inextricably dependent upon a watershed that yields a reliably low sediment, high-oxygen water supply. The proposed mining operation would disfigure and transform the watershed, with a sprawling network of infrastructure bleeding sediment at every rain, exposed ore seams that shed acidic runoff, and large pits that interrupt the subterranean movement of water.
 
Bristol Bay epitomizes the aquatic resources that EPA was entrusted to protect through the Clean Water Act 404(c) review process, and it has done so correctly. You have a sacred moral obligation, as well as a legal responsibility as EPA Administrator, to protect this priceless of vital aquatic ecosystem. The Clean Water Act enshrines Americas determination that certain levels of aquatic ecosystem destruction are unacceptable, and the transparent, scientifically rigorous process conducted by EPA found correctly that Bristol Bay epitomizes this category.
 
Bristol Bay salmon support thousands of fishermen from across Alaska, the west coast, and other parts of the nation who descend on this remote and pristine region every summer to harvest the "red gold."  The fishery represents a multi-million dollar industry whose impact is felt across the country. Salmon are also the life-blood of local village economies and support centuries old subsistence traditions of the Native cultures in western Alaska. The compelling, overriding importance of Bristol bays intact ecosystem is illustrated by the support for EPAs finding among both Native and Anglo Alaskans, who traditionally and well-disposed to resource development, but correctly recognized the singular importance of Bristol Bay.
 
This ecosystem is a priceless treasure; the minerals and the trinkets they would be used to manufacture are not. Even if EPA limits its analysis to a mere utilitarian calculation of economic productivity, no question exists that maintaining the salmon production is more valuable than any mineral extraction. Any dilution or repeal of the prior administrations Clean Water Act finding would be a gross miscarriage and abdication of your responsibility. Thank you for your attention to this urgent issue.

Title: Anonymous Public Comment
Comment:
Dear Administrator, 

I'm writing in reference to Docket # EPA-HQ-ORD-2012-0276. Please prohibit the disposal of mine waste in Alaska's Bristol Bay watershed. The proposed Pebble Mine presents a long-term risk to the sustainability of this important fishery, and all the people and businesses that rely on it. In 2010, Bristol Bay salmon fishermen harvested 29 million sockeye salmon worth $165 million in direct harvest value alone. That represented 31% of the total Alaska salmon harvest value. It is extremely irresponsible to sacrifice this vital and flourishing industry and its unique environs for the sake of mineral extraction which can be obtained in less ecologically sensitive deposits.

In addition, many families rely on wild salmon as a uniquely nutritious source of protein, rich in essential omega-3 fats and vitamin D. Farmed salmon is not nutritionally identical (much lower in vitamin D, much higher in saturated fats and pro-inflammatory omega-6 fats) and poses its own environmental risks. I urge the EPA to take immediate action to use existing provisions of the Clean Water Act to protect this large and irreplaceable wild salmon fishery. 

Sincerely, 

A concerned citizen from Dallas, Texas

Title: Anonymous Public Comment
Comment:
Let's not go here again. There is no rational reason to allow mining of any kind - let alone the H-bomb-scale destruction of an open pit mine - at Bristol Bay.

Why do you feel the need to sacrifice the environment and sustainable economic activity at nearly every opportunity? You should be ashamed of yourself for placing love of money (because, for the life of me, I can't imagine what else it could be) over love of the peace and beauty of our natural environment, and for ignoring the needs and demands of Native American communities.

I am opposed to EPAs proposal to rescind the 2014 Proposed Determination designed to protect Bristol Bays world class fisheries. Please stand with American jobs and communities and preserve the Bristol Bay Proposed Determination.

Bristol Bay, Alaska, is one of America's last great wild salmon fisheries. Each year, tens of millions of wild salmon return, supporting upwards of 14,000 jobs in the commercial and sport fishing industries, and serving as a one-in-a-lifetime destination for anglers from around the world as well as the cultural cornerstone for the region's communities. These long-established businesses are at risk from a foreign-owned mining company that wants to build the proposed Pebble Mine, which is opposed by more than 65 percent of Alaskans and more than 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents. 

In 2014, led by Alaska Native Tribes, interests including commercial fishing business owners and sportsmen asked the EPA step in to ensure that this mine wouldn't jeopardize Bristol Bay. The EPA responded by listening to over 1.5 million Americans, hosting dozens of community meetings, reviewing Pebble's many detailed filings with state and federal agencies, and conducting a twice peer-reviewed scientific assessment of the potential impacts to the region. Withdrawing the proposed determination ignores the overwhelming majority of Alaskans and puts the short-term interests of a foreign mining company above thousands of local jobs. 

For the sake of our wildlife, waterways, and communities, I urge you to protect Bristol Bay and prevent this horrible open-pit mine from destroying one of our nation's most precious ecosystems.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment submitted by C. Masek
Comment:
The late Alaska Republican Senator Ted Stevens had it right when he called this project, "the wrong mine in the wrong place," and I, along with over a million other Americans, wholeheartedly agree. An unprecedented coalition of native tribes, commercial fishermen, anglers and hunters, conservationists, religious groups, restaurateurs and outdoor enthusiasts have been fighting this foreign-owned mine proposal and trying to gain protections for the Bristol Bay region.

The reasons are simple and numerous. Bristol Bay's average run of 37.5 million fish produces a whopping 46% of the world's sockeye salmon. This run sustains more than 29,000 fishing trips each year and creates 14,000 commercial and recreational jobs in a salmon fishery that can last indefinitely, as opposed to the 1,000 or so jobs the Canadian mine developers can offer for a couple of decades.

The salmon's incredible migration also sustains people: nearly half of the world's sockeye catch comes from this one region, which is one of the last, great salmon fisheries on Earth. The returning salmon and other ecological resources create some 14,000 full- and part-time jobs, generate about $480 million annually -- and support 4,000-year-old Alaska Native cultures.

Our own EPA found after three years of peer-reviewed research, that such a mine "would result in complete loss of fish habitat due to elimination, de-watering, and fragmentation of streams, wetlands, and other aquatic resources" in many areas of the bay watershed. In particular, the EPA estimated 22 miles of streams and more than 6 square miles of wetlands and other habitats that are important to salmon and other fish would be lost to a large-scale mine FOREVER.

Today I urge President Trump to listen to our fishermen and businesses before removing science-based environmental rules that protect Bristol Bay. The future of Bristol Bay must be determined by science, not politics or the whining of Tom Collier, who is only pursuing this mine for the benefit of his company.

Sincerely,
Cheryl Masek

Title: Comment submitted by W. Spangler
Comment:
I'm writing in reference to Docket # EPA-HQ-ORD-2012-0276. Please prohibit the storage and/or disposal of mine waste in Alaska's Bristol Bay watershed. The proposed Pebble Mine presents a long-term risk to the sustainability of this important fishery, and all the people and businesses that rely on it. The Bristol Bay 2017 harvest of all salmon species was 39.8 million fish; ranking second over the last 20 years (1997-2016) and worth a preliminary ex-vessel value of $214.6 million almost double the 20-year average of $108.9 million and ranks second during that time frame , as reported by the Alaska Department of Fish and Game Division of Commercial Fisheries.
 
Mines come and go, but leave waste behind from the processing of ore, which under current methods is stored on-site for centuries,. Bristol Bay, like the rest of Alaska, is an earthquake heavy region making it almost certain that storage of tailings (toxic semi-liquid mine waste) will fail. In Bristol bay, these tailings  would mostly be classifieid as Acid Mine Drainage due to oxidation of unearthed pyrite, or "fool's gold" which is often found in conjunction with valuable metals. As the name suggests, this waste make water acidic and inhospitable to animal and plant life, while also promoting the growth of acid-producing bacteria that hinder recovery efforts.
 
Alaska's state government notes on its website that it has more earthquakes than any other region of the United States and is, in fact, one of the most seismically active areas of the world, having 11 percent of the planet's earthquakes. Of earthquakes capable of damaging structures, Alaska annually averages
One magnitude 7 to 8 earthquake every year
Six magnitude 6 to 7 earthquakes per year
Forty five magnitude 5 to 6 earthquakes per year
A spill or leakage occurring would be a question not of "if", but "when".
Bristol Bay  has been called  the  "Salmon factory of the world", offers five species of Salmon: King, Sockeye, Chum, Pink and Silver Salmon along with 7 species of freshwater fish: Rainbow Trout, Arctic Char, Arctic Grayling, Dolly Varden, Lake Trout and Northern Pike. Many families rely on the wild salmon as a uniquely nutritious source of protein, rich in essential omega-3 fats and vitamin D. Farmed salmon is not nutritionally identical (much lower in vitamin D, much higher in saturated fats and pro-inflammatory omega-6 fats) and poses its own environmental risks. I urge the EPA to take immediate action to use existing provisions of the Clean Water Act to protect this large and irreplaceable wild salmon fishery. The short-term gains of mining projects in the area outweighed by the long term risk to the environment and the economy. Please continue to ensure the wellbeing of this vital waterway by enforcing the EPA region 10 July 2014 Proposed Determination."

Sincerely,
William Spangler   489 East Highpoint Drive

Title: Comment submitted by Laura Twardochleb, MS Ph.D. Student, Fisheries and Wildlife, Michigan State University
Comment:
I oppose the proposal to withdraw the EPA Region 10 July 2014 Proposed Determination that would restrict the use of certain waters in the Bristol Bay watershed in southwest Alaska as disposal sites for dredged or fill material associated with mining the Pebble deposit. The Bristol Bay watershed is uniquely valuable in its pristine state because it supports one of the world's most productive salmon fisheries. 

A 2012 report prepared for the USEPA identified that this watershed has unparalleled "cultural, subsistence, commercial, recreational, economic, and environmental" importance; and these these characteristics of the watershed, combined with the size of the proposed Pebble Mine, indicate that "Pebble poses a greater threat to the environment or fishery" than other mines (Levit and Chambers 2012, COMPARISON of the PEBBLE MINE with OTHER ALASKA LARGE HARD ROCK MINES). Moreover, in the 2014 Proposed Determination, the USEPA found that the discharge of dredge or fill material into waters of the Bristol Bay Watershed "would result in complete loss of fish habitat due to elimination, fragmentation, and dewatering of streams, wetlands, and other aquatic resources. In addition, water withdrawal and capture, storage, treatment, and release of wastewater associated with the mine would significantly impair the fish habitat functions of other streams, wetlands, and aquatic resources."

As a professional freshwater ecologist, I am concerned that withdrawing this proposed determination and allowing the Pebble Mine project to move forward would result in irreparable damage to the watershed of Bristol Bay, which has both intrinsic natural value, and is irreplaceable as one of the world's most productive salmon fisheries. The short term economic gains from the Pebble Mine project can never substitute for the loss of one of the healthiest salmon watersheds in the world.  

Sincerely,
Laura Twardochleb, MS
PhD Student, Fisheries and Wildlife, Michigan State University

Title: Comment submitted by I. Kuletz
Comment:
To Whom It May Concern,

My name is Ivan Kuletz, and I am opposed to the development of the proposed Pebble Mine and any other such development in the greater Bristol Bay watershed. I am opposed on ecological, economic, sociological, ethical, and personal grounds. Additionally, I find the rhetoric and arguments of the pro-Pebble group to be unconvincing and more than a little disingenuous.

Bristol Bay is a superlative fishing ground not only for Alaska or the United States, but for the world. Saying "there are other fisheries" is like saying "there are other Mount Everests;" if the fishery were lost, it could not be replaced, replicated, or substituted. Independent, rigorous assessments from all corners have shown that the Pebble Mine and other such developments represent a danger of such magnitude that when something goes wrong with any mining development in the area, the resulting effects would cripple or kill the Bristol Bay commercial salmon fishery.

The design of the Pebble development and other proposals guarantees a catastrophic failure sometime within the next few hundred years, if not the first few decades after implementation. Given that the tailings, waters, and sediment would have to be kept and monitored into perpetuity due to the persistent toxicity of its contents, this guarantees that a catastrophe is not "if" but "when." When it does happen, the mine's position at the headwaters of the Nushagak, Naknek, and Kvichak watersheds - which account for over 50% of Bristol Bay's salmon runs every year - would be devastated.

This fishery supports not only the region's economy and beyond, but does so in a far more egalitarian way than the handful of jobs that would be supported by any mining operation. Money from the commercial fishery is dispersed among thousands of families and small businesses both within Bristol Bay and across the state and nation, rather than consolidated in the hands of a few distant stakeholders. The "economic development of Bristol Bay" argument is disingenuous and fleeting - the effects of this short-sighted development for vast corporate profits is permanent and unconscionable. Every ADF&G employee knows this, but is effectively gagged from speaking their mind, so it is up to others to do it for them.

Ultimately, this decision cannot ethically be made with monetary profits for this generation in mind, or indeed even five generations distant. This decision must be made with the needs of every generation to come forefront in our minds - that's what sustainability is at its heart. If Pebble Mine goes through, somewhere down the line there will be a generation that pays for the greed of this one. They will be the first to do so, but they won't be the last. Ask yourselves what sort of world you want to leave for all our future generations: do you want to leave Everest for others to climb, or do you want to level it for quick profit?

Thank you,

Ivan Kuletz
Master of Public Policy - Ocean and Fisheries Policy Focus
Bachelors of Science, Biology
Former deckhand, Bristol Bay, 8 years

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
NO FRIGGIN WAY !!!!!

In absolutely no way should the EPA withdraw from the 2014 proposed restrictions !!!!

I am utterly incredulous that EPA is even suggesting withdrawing from the proposed restrictions against development of the Pebble Mine in Bristol Bay !!!   NO FRIGGIN WAY !!!!!  Let alone that EPA has made a backroom deal to actually withdraw from these restrictions.  This is NOT the way EPA acts when there are credible people at the helm !!!!!!!!!

EPA's 2014 restrictions, based on the Clean Water Act, were proposed after YEARS of assessment of the area and the types of impacts that a mine like the proposed Pebble Mine would impose.  NO FRIGGIN WAY that EPA is now arbitrarily reversing course !!!

The proposed mine, humongous mine, poses catastrophic risks to Bristol Bay, its incredible salmon runs, and the Native village peoples that depend on this watershed and its resources, especially the salmon. To reverse course and allow the Pebble Mine to move forward is a clear job killer, contrary to the campaign promises of this Administration.  SHAME ON YOU and your heinous, mean-spirited, greedy ways.

And I am outraged that the EPA's notice includes, "EPA is not soliciting comment on the proposed restrictions or on science or technical information underlying the Proposed Determination."  EPA is a science-based agency !!  You throw out the science, then what's the point ?!?!?

Further, it is an INSULT to suggest to the American people that this is a decision of the Regional Administrator.  It is obvious to all that this is a decision that is being rammed down the throat of the RA and all of the American people by Pruitt.

Clearly Mr. Pruitt is utterly ignorant of science in general and is acting from a place of complete, total, absolute, utter ignorance of science and apparently complete disregard for the importance of science-based decision-making.  It is increasingly clear that this man is incompetent for the job of EPA Administrator !!!!!  He apparently acts from a place of knee-jerk reactionism, based on lots of "dark money" and ridiculous political biases, without any regard for what EPA is supposed to be about.  I suggest this is one of many actions that are outside the authorities of the EPA Administrator, as Mr. Pruitt is clearly only acting to protect private industrial entities at the expense of the environment and the wellbeing of the American people and the entire planet.  NO FRIGGIN WAY !!!!!
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment submitted by P. Woodward
Comment:
I write to respectfully request that the EPA not withdraw the Proposed Determination to Restrict Use of Area as Disposal Site: Pebble Deposit Area, Southwest Alaska.  
My family and I watched the 2014 Disney movie "Bears," which not only highlighted the bears' migration but also Alaska's salmon runs.  The area in question is one of the most valuable fisheries in the world, and salmon is a valuable part of the human (and bear) diet, providing Omega 3 oils that can help people maintain a healthy heart.  We Americans should be proud to have Bristol Bay as such as valuable natural resource and strive to preserve it for all current and future generations.  Imagine the day when we walk into a grocery store or a fish market, and we can no longer find freshwater sockeye salmon.  Imagine if a mining company caused this disappearance no matter how carefully the company tried to preserve the environment and the local ecosystems through its mining practices.
Alaska is often called America's last great frontier.  Development is a necessary part of human life as our population grows and needs to create areas to live.  But let's do what we can to preserve those "crown jewels" in our country and not do something irreversible that we may all regret later.  Yes, development and mining may seem more profitable now for the company and the local economy.  But what are the long-term profits versus the value of keeping Bristol Bay as the most valuable fishery in the world?  This salmon fishery positively impacts the local economy and sustains a way of life for Native Alaskans.  It may positively impact each of us, too, every time we eat sockeye salmon that may come from the region.  Let's keep America great by recognizing the value of this area as a great natural resource for our country's current and future generations.
Many thanks for considering my comments.  I appreciate this opportunity and hope to visit this part of Alaska one day! :)

Sincerely,
Philip Woodward
Knightdale, North Carolina

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
A mine -- no matter its size -- that doesn't impact the environment  --  who is asleep at the wheel or not reading any of the EPA reports?  NO, NO, NO! 

Read your own report: https://www.epa.gov/sites/production/files/2015-05/documents/bristol_bay_assessment_final_2014_vol3.pdf

"The mine scenarios evaluated in the assessment show that the mine
footprint alone would result in the loss (i.e., filling, blocking or otherwise eliminating) of
hundreds to thousands of acres of high-functioning wetlands and tens of miles of
salmon-supporting streams. In addition to these direct losses, these mine scenarios
would also result in extensive adverse secondary and cumulative impacts to wetlands,
streams, and fish that would have to be addressed. Such extensive habitat losses and
degradation could also result in the loss of unique salmon populations, eroding the
genetic diversity essential to the stability of the overall Bristol Bay salmon fishery."

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
The Clean Water Act was passed precisely to protect areas like the Bristol Bay watershed from the effects of water pollution derived from mining.  Whereas mining is necessary to produce elements for modern life, doing so in the Bristol Bay watershed places an unacceptable risk of contamination of a substantial food ecosystem based on the prolific salmon fishery.  It is well established that the mining of deposits like the Pebble deposit expose vast quantities of rock at the Earth's surface that include non-commercial concentrations of copper, gold, and molybdenum as well as a host of additional trace metals, subjecting them to surface weathering that leaches these elements from the rock and introduces them into the surface water system.  It is well established that some of these trace elements are toxic to ecosystems.

The risk of contaminating the Bristol Bay salmon ecosystem, a process that extends all the way up into the human food chain, far outweighs the benefits of mining in this location because toxicity develops for some elements in such low concentrations.  The Clean Water Act mandates that these types of pollution effects be weighed, and the balance of evidence indicates that the risk of contamination of a vibrant salmon food ecosystem is to great to allow mining in this location.

Title: Comment submitted by Peg Rooney, Arkansas Valley Audubon Society (AVAS)
Comment: Arkansas Valley Audubon Society (AVAS), representing 500+ members,  opposes withdrawal of Clean Water Act restrictions on discharge at the proposed Pebble Mine in Bristol Bay Alaska. Gold, copper and molybdenum extraction will decimate the sockeye salmon population upon which half the world depends. When salmon are decimated, so too, are Bald Eagles, bears, wolves, and others. Additionally, sulfur is present and when mixed with air and water produces acid. This acidic discharge will harm salmon, birds, other wildlife, and people. AVAS joins anglers, conservationists, biologists, and most native tribes in saying NO to withdrawal of this restriction and NO to the Pebble Mine.

Title: Comment submitted by B. Galvez
Comment:
To whom it may concern, 

As a fisheries biologist and an avid salmon fisherman, I do not agree that a mining company should be allowed to mine nor dispose of mining waste in the Bristol Bay watershed. History shows us what mining does to the local environment and valuable fish populations. It is imperative to consider the monetary and emotional costs of the local community's recreational and commercial fisheries compared with the profit of the mining venture. The long term value of recreational and commercial salmon fisheries in Bristol Bay, Alaska most likely trump the short term profitability of a mining venture. 

Monetary and emotional values are among the most important issues the argument against the opening of mining permits in Bristol Bay. The health risks on the local human and wildlife communities and water quality degradation associated with mining waste should also be considered. No matter the manner in which these assessments are carried out, they should be done in the most calculated and scientific way possible, free of partisan politics, with the most weight put on the long term health of the local community, both financially and emotionally. I am all for economic development, but I do not think that the mining of Bristol Bay is the right way to do it. Please do not open the bay up for mining permits. 

Thank you.


Sincerely, 

Brian Galvez

Title: Comment submitted by R. Jiorie
Comment:
Thank you for allowing me to comment on this proposed action.  I am writing to request that the EPA NOT withdraw its July 2014 Clean Water Act 404(c) Proposed Determination.  As someone who has followed this controversy since 2011, it is disheartening to see the EPA attempt to move backward on a great stride it made with that Proposed Determination.  Reviews of mining activity and the maintenance of toxic mine waste, leachates, wastewater, and tailings dams show that such maintenance cannot actually be done "in perpetuity."  The best and most recent example comes from Imperial Metals Corporation's Mount Polley copper-gold mine tailings dam, which failed in August 2014, despite being constructed using the best technology of its time.  The Pebble Mine's tailings dam was proposed with the same technology and is in a less stable and more chemically active area, making a failure of this dam even more likely.  The assurance that the Pebble Mine tailings could be feasible maintained in perpetuity is one of the underpinnings of the entire proposal.  Because of the likelihood of a failure, Pebble Mine's proposal is not in the best interest of the area.  There is no question that, if a failure occurred, it would devastate a world-renowned fishery of national and global importance.  It would devastate a sustainable fishery consisting of many stakeholders ranging from small individual operations to larger businesses.Thus, given that a failure in the Pebble Mine's tailings dam is quite feasible, it is of the utmost importance for the EPA not to withdraw its July 2014 Proposed Determination, as this was written with the best available science and information.  It does not make sense for our country to trade such a valuable, renewable resource for one that is not renewable.  As a fisheries professional, people like myself look to such pristine fisheries and habitats as we attempt to responsibly manage the fisheries in the rest of our country, many of which are in poor shape and in need of recovery.  Thank you again for your consideration.

-Ryan Jiorle

I DO NOT support withdrawal of the EPA Region 10 July 2014 Proposed Determination for the reasons stated. The economic value of the fishery and the environmental and cultural value of the in-tact watershed are more important to Alaskans and more valuable than allowing large-scale resource development in the region. The environmental and human risks posed by the proposed mining in the region cannot adequately be mitigated.  Listen to the local people.

The EPA Administrator should uphold the agency mission to protect human health and the environment and fulfill the EPA purpose to ensure that: all Americans are protected from significant risks to human health and the environment where they live, learn and work; national efforts to reduce environmental risk are based on the best available scientific information; federal laws protecting human health and the environment are enforced fairly and effectively; and environmental protection is an integral consideration in U.S. policies concerning natural resources, human health, economic growth, energy, transportation, agriculture, industry, and international trade, and these factors are similarly considered in establishing environmental policy.  As such, he should maintain withdrawal status in the Bristol Bay Region.

Title: Comment submitted by D. Moulton
Comment:
Dear Scott Pruitt and the EPA,

I am writing in response to the decision to withdraw the 2014 Clean Water act ruling protecting Bristol Bay Alaska tributaries from the deposit of Pebble Mine waste tailings. I am a PhD student from Tennessee studying Pacific salmon conservation at the University of British Columbia. I work on the Fraser River in Canada, the largest sockeye salmon producing river in Canada. Salmon populations in British Columbia and the lower 48 states are declining alarmingly, and this is projected to worsen in the future, especially as ocean and river temperatures rise. 

The more salmon research I do, the more I see that salmon have extremely important cultural importance to people of all walks of life in Alaska and elsewhere. In addition to cultural attachment, healthy salmon runs provide a healthy food source to people around the world, a livelihood for commercial fishermen, a social backbone for native people, and a bonding source of entertainment for recreational fishermen. The sockeye fishery in Bristol Bay alone has been valued at 1.5 billion dollars, a renewable resource that will grow even more valuable if properly managed while the rest of the world's fisheries decline. The continued existence of healthy populations of these and other salmonids is priceless compared to the mineral deposits sought after by the Pebble Mine. While these minerals are important, it would be extremely reckless to sacrifice the wellbeing of one of the most important fisheries in the world in order to dump mine tailings in a pristine environment. Please do a service to the world and act as you should - a steward of the agency to PROTECT THE ENVIRONMENT.

David Moulton, Master of Wildlife and Fisheries Science

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
According to the Settlement Agreement between US DOJ, EPA and PLP signed May 11, 2017 (https://www.epa.gov/bristolbay/2017-settlement-agreement-between-epa-and-pebble-limited-partnership):
EPA agrees that it will not move to the next step in its CWA process, which would be to issue a recommended determination (determination steps are: proposed, recommended, final), until 48 months from settlement or until the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers issues its final environmental impact statement, whichever comes first.  To take advantage of this period of forbearance, Pebble would have to file its permit application within 30 months.

USACE has not started an EIS since Pebble has not submitted an application, according to USACE:

From: Public Affairs POA [mailto:Public.Affairs3@usace.army.mil]
Sent: Friday, October 13, 2017 8:31 PM
To: Chaney, Ann Marie 
Subject: RE: EIS Pebble Limited Partnership (PLP) Permit (UNCLASSIFIED)

CLASSIFICATION: UNCLASSIFIED

Greetings Ms. Chaney,

Thanks for your interest in the Army Corps of Engineers here in the Last Frontier.

Per your request, we've added your email address to our Regulatory Division's distribution list for sharing future information and updates about this proposed project.

To clarify though, we have not received a permit application as of yet.

Kindest regards,

Tom Findtner
Chief, Public Affairs Office
Alaska District
U.S. Army Corps of Engineers
907-753-2522
http://www.poa.usace.army.mil
http://www.facebook.com/AlaskaCorps
http://twitter.com/AlaskaCorps
http://www.flickr.com/photos/AlaskaCorps
http://www.youtube.com/user/AlaskaCorps

"Building and Preserving Alaska's Future"

This notice is in violation of the settlement agreement since 48 has not passed and USACE has not completed an EIS.

Title: Comment submitted by J. Brakel
Comment:
I am Judith Brakel, Box 94, Gustavus, Alaska 99826, judybrakel@gmail.com (I don't see where to put our name & contact info).
I am against the EPA's proposal to rescind the 2014 proposed regulation. As a life-long resident of Alaska, I know that Alaskans - from the late Alaska Senator Ted Stevens to current Governor Bill Walker - consider salmon the highest and best use of the Bristol Bay watershed. I support the Obama Admin. 2014 decision to restrict the use of this area as a disposal site for the proposed Pebble Mine. Even though the Pebble partnership recently proposed a mine smaller than the overwhelmingly huge original plan, this would still be an extremely large mine, disrupting large acreages and the waters that flow through them. Tampering with the pristine habitat that supports one of the greatest salmon resources and fisheries in the world is a radical and unacceptable idea.

The Bristol Bay watershed supports about half of the world's sockeye salmon. Resilience of the area's sockeye population is high due to the pristine habitat and the high genetic diversity of the many smaller stocks that make up in this great population. History conclusively shows that salmon on this scale, or even on much smaller scale, do not persist in the midst of human molestation of the watersheds. This is particularly true of the mining proposed here.

Large earth-filled dams are planned for this development even though smaller such dams have failed recently in British Columbia.  The ancillary development required for very large mines - water withdrawals, impoundments and releases, ore storage and treatments, transportation corridors, industrial facilities, worker facilities, etc. - would all add up to a huge impact on this area. The water quality needed by fish is higher than that for human consumption. 

Minerals are a non-renewable resource. The salmon of this area have renewed themselves for thousands of years. The tradition of fishing them is embedded in the culture of Southwest Alaska, and of Alaska in general. DON'T MESS WITH OUR SALMON!
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment submitted by M. Leu
Comment:
Dear Administrator Pruitt,
 
I urge you not to withdraw EPAs Proposed Determination To Restrict the Use of an Area as a Disposal Site; Pebble Deposit Area, Southwest Alaska. EPAs decision is based on rigorous science, which clearly demonstrates that the Pebble mine will likely cause irreparable damage to the Bristol Bay ecosystem. For the sake of preserving native cultural heritage, maintaining secure jobs for thousands of people, and preserving a unique ecosystem for our children and future generations, I am vehemently opposed to allow a company to destroy this ecosystem.  The potential profits gained by the project are dwarfed by the exponential and long-term costs to the unique natural and cultural features of the project area and Bristol Bay. Yes, the ecosystem is of global importance, but that doesnt mean it is available for exploitation by foreign investors.
 
Please remember that you represent the people of the United States of America and not foreign companies.  The majority of Bristol Bays and Alaskas citizens are against the Pebble mine. The people and science have spoken, and as their representative, their collective voice must be reflected in your decision!

Respectfully,
 
Matthias Leu
 
Williamsburg, VA
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment: I hope that you uphold the Proposed Determination for the Pebble Deposit Area, and allow the special application of the Clean Water Act to stand in the Bristol Bay area. While I am not specifically a fisheries biologist, I am a wildlife biologist and I understand specifically what impacts an open-pit mine will have on the Bristol Bay ecosystem. I understand that salmon link the marine and terrestrial ecosystems and serve as the basis of the food web. I understand that salmon serve as a sustainable resource that is both an economically valuable contributor to the state of Alaska (in the form of jobs fisherfolks, processors, marine suppliers, boat mechanics, among others), but also provides a bigger and health-important resource for people all over the world that buy and consume fresh, wild, salmon. Not only that, sockeye salmon in the Bristol Bay area is a well managed fishery and an example of what is possible when science and management are combined for the welfare of both people and fish stocks. Bristol Bay also supports a successful salmon sport fishery where people pay thousands of dollars for the experience of fishing in this unique and pristine place, and a lot of that is invested in the communities around the bay, and the state of Alaska. Not only that, but salmon in Bristol Bay are a priceless and integral piece of Native Alaskan culture, spirituality, and subsistence practices. The loss of or damage to wild salmon in the area would be the same as the loss of or acute damage to an entire way of being. Further, the down sides of open pit mines are well documented operation is temporary and unsustainable; the mine and tailings often far outlast the profit or even the mining company itself, overrun and devastate local waterways and ecosystems, and companies often leave the damage for local communities to live with and clean up (e.g. Berkeley Pit mine in Butte, Montana). These effects can last hundreds of years. In my mind, it is clear that no amount of profit, particularly for a foreign company, justifies the risk of damaging salmon populations in Bristol Bay.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
It is unconscionable that the Pebble Mine be allowed to proceed and put one of the worlds greatest salmon fisheries at risk.   

Under the Obama administration, the EPA, after years of rigorous study, proposed science-based restrictions that would have banned the dangerous Pebble Mine to protect Bristol Bay from the myriad of environmental risks this massive gold and copper mine would pose. Your recent settlement with Northern Dynasty Minerals to reverse those common-sense restrictions is a blatant giveaway to the mining industry at the expense of the American people, our environment and our economy.

Bristol Bay's wild salmon fishery supports 14,000 jobs and is valued at more than $1.5 billion annually. It also supplies nearly half of the world's sockeye salmon. More than 65 percent of Alaskans, 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents and Native communities, and 85 percent of commercial fishermen oppose the mine.

I urge you to listen to those voices, and for the sake of the Bristol Bay watershed, its world-class salmon fishery and its people, keep the door closed on Pebble Mine.

Title: Comment submitted by J. Eller
Comment:
Dear EPA, 

I'd like to add my voice to those opposed to the proposed withdrawal of your previous Proposed Determination to Restrict Use of Area as Disposal Site: Pebble Deposit Area, Southwest Alaska. I was born in Anchorage in 1984 and grew up in Homer, Alaska. I graduated as a Homer High Mariner in May 2002. My parents were teachers, and in the summer, my dad commercial fished for salmon in the Cook Inlet. Later my sister would join him stacking corks, and I would work the slime line at Coal Point Seafood. Like most Alaskans on the coast, salmon were a large part of our lives. We ate them and made money from them.

I'd briefly work for the Park Service at Lake Clark doing radio telemetry studies with whitefish, sampling pike, and counting sockeye. Lake Clark is the same vicinity of the state that this proposed mine is in. We spoke to geologists about the pH levels of the material that would be held in Pebble's proposed tailing ponds. The implications with a spill of material with pH levels that high are enormous.

In college, I would begin working at salmon hatcheries around the state, staring in the Prince William Sound at Wally Norenburg Hatchery and then Armin F. Koernig Hatchery. I would move to Southeast and work at Macaulay Hatchery operated by DIPAC and Hidden Falls Hatchery operated by NSRAA. Eventually I would work my way into a fish culturist position in charge of the chinook and experimental saltwater coho programs. My experience has amounted to great understanding of the importance of salmon to this state. We spend millions each year at one private non-profit to raise salmon. 

Bristol Bay is the largest wild (not hatchery originated) salmon run in the world. We cannot replace that run if it is lost. The tools we have at hatcheries don't amount to what nature has created there. Please do not withdraw your Proposed Determination. Pebble would provide some jobs, but the risks to more livelihoods, lifestyles, and a way of life is much much greater. 

Alaskans love to sentimentalize that we are made of salmon, but in a lot of ways they're right. My dad's commercial fishing check bought me school clothes and mine bought me my first car; we've eaten it for school night dinners, barbecues, my sister's wedding, and Christmas dinner; and I've made salmon - spawned them for hours upon hours, days upon days. It is the EPA's job to restrict use to activities that jeopardize the health of our water, and this determination should stand to do just that.

Thank you for your consideration,

Jessica Eller
990 Mission Rd.
Homer, AK 99603

jess_eller@mac.com
(509) 964-6109
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment submitted by D. Roon
Comment:
To whom it may concern:

As a freshwater ecologist, I study how streams and rivers function as essential habitats for a wide range of aquatic species. I spent two years at the Pebble mine assisting with the baseline studies to go through the permitting process in 2012 and 2013. During this time, I saw an incredible area full of intact stream and river systems that not only support the largest populations of sockeye salmon in the world but also a myriad of anadromous and freshwater resident fish species. This area is the most pristine area I've ever been and not only does it support critical habitat for a range of species (both aquatic and terrestrial), but it also provides food and jobs for the local Alaskan natives and fisherman in Bristol Bay. I cannot think of a worse place to put an open pit mine. I highly, highly recommend against it. 

Case in point: We worked on hydrology study mapping the presence and distribution of off-channel habitats available for rearing juvenile lifestages of salmon around the proposed mine site. This work was repeated at different flows during the summer. At the end of the summer as the August rains arrived, the area where the proposed mine would take place became absolutely saturated. Water was everywhere. This landscape thrives on connectivity and at this time of year everything is connected. If this mine were ever to be built and a spill from a tailings dam occurs, there would be no way to contain the spill. And because the proposed mine site is situated at the headwaters of the two most productive salmon bearing rivers in the Bristol Bay watershed, it would inevitably spread downstream. 

I am not against mining and do see the benefits of mining taking place domestically under more stringent environmental regulations. However, this is the wrong place for a project like this to take place. The Bristol Bay watershed should be set aside as a protected area to allow one of the last intact ecosystems left in the world to thrive on its own.

Sincerely, David Roon
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment submitted by C. Peace
Comment:
I request the EPA does not withdraw the Bristol Bay Proposed Determination. 

Withdrawing the proposed determination would ignore the overwhelming majority of Alaskans. The economic, cultural, and environmental significance of the great sustainable Bristol Bay salmon runs to the region is immeasurable.

The risk of such a large open pit ore mine in a pristine ecosystem is certainly too great. No matter what the company proclaims, they honestly can't state - nor prove - they will not have a tailings dam failure now and in years to come, or other environmental issues that will cause great harm. I have zero trust the company would be there to provide adequate and actual recompensation to those that rely of the world's greatest salmon fishery for generations to come. I ask you what legal requirements would be put in place to cover economic losses for generations to come. And what of the loss of biodiversity that is irreplaceable. It is the world's largest salmon fisheries, and should be protected above all else. Salmon is food, a way of life, and a keystone species. 

One just needs to look at the great promises and failures of Canada's Mount Polley mine. The dam breach created tremendous economic and environmental consequences. Do not allow the short-term interests of a foreign mining company above thousands of long term American jobs and long standing cultural way of life.

Perhaps it takes a lower 48 PNW resident to fully grasp all that was lost with that regions salmon fisheries, to realize what is left needs to be fiercely protected. Billions of taxpayer dollars have been spent on salmon restoration efforts in the United States but few success stories have emerged. It is far less costly to us all to protect precious healthy salmon runs now then try and repair and restore afterward. 

Any new Pebble Mine EIS should be required to have a full environmental accounting - from a price of all ecosystem services of a healthy intact environment to loss of wages and full cost of recovery after any environmental impacts which are bound to happen eventually.

I thank all the dedicated EPA staff who worked on this issue for three years and with twice peer reviewed science determined - Wrong mine. Wrong Place. Large open pit mines should not be put in sensitive watersheds, and certainly have no place at all in the most productive salmon nursery grounds. Salmon is one of the healthiest sources of protein we have. I eat wild salmon only. Leave the wild rivers be.

Corinne Peace

Title: Comment submitted by J. Rue
Comment:
I grew up in Alaska and Still return every fall to fish Bristol Bay. I have introduced numerous friends from the lower 48 to the unsurpassed fishing, wildlife, and natural beauty of the area. Each year we spend thousands of dollars in the area supporting the sustainable sport fishery and all associated locally owned businesses.

The pebble mine proposal cannot be built for a few years of profits for international companies. It cannot.

I promise to spend money supporting every challenger to elected officials who let a mine in Bristol Bay go forward. That is a lifelong promise. To anyone thinking this mine should be approved, you are on the wrong side of science, culture, and economics. If the pebble mine gets built then in 30 years when the mining companies abandon it to smaller and smaller companies before bankruptcy leaves a superfund site and billions of dollars in cleanup costs (Not to mention a ruined fishery that currently generates hundreds of millions of dollars annually) then any politician who signs off on this will go down in history as a morally bankrupt, shortsighted, and willing to sacrifice one of worlds greatest treasures for political gain.

Title: Comment submitted by L. Rogers
Comment:
I am opposed to withdrawing (docket EPA-R10-OW-2017-0369) the July 2014 Clean Water Act Proposed Determination because it will put Alaskan jobs, American food security, and one of the greatest wild ecosystems on earth at risk. Please put American jobs over private mining interests and preserve the Bristol Bay Proposed Determination. A toxic mine in the middle of one of our nations greatest food-producing regions would not make America great again.

I have spent four summers in the wilderness of the Bristol Bay watershed. Having conducted research around the globe, including Antarctica, I can say that the Bristol Bay area remains one of the most astounding natural places on this planet. Without seeing it first hand, I think it is impossible to imagine the millions of salmon migrating up river, filling lakes, transforming the entire ecosystem with their red, nutrient-rich bodies. Bears, eagles, gulls, trout all congregate to feast on the salmon riches. This is a scene not repeated elsewhere on the planet at the same scale. 

This is all possible because of the pristine watersheds of the Bristol Bay region. My own research has shown how vital it is to have diverse, wild freshwater habitat available for sockeye salmon (Schindler, D. E., Hilborn, R., Chasco, B., Boatright, C. P., Quinn, T. P., Rogers, L. A., & Webster, M. S. (2010). Population diversity and the portfolio effect in an exploited species. Nature, 465(7298), 609-612.). This is not only about preserving nature for nature's sake, but also for the native communities that depend on fishing (and have for centuries), and for the millions of other world citizens who consume wild salmon as a healthy, renewable source of protein. If not wild salmon, then what? Should we import frozen fish from Asia? Or should we rather continue to utilize our own renewable natural resources to their fullest? This ecosystem makes food for us for free. 

A mine like Pebble would impact this ecosystem, and all of its services to humans, not just for a few years or decades, but forever. The EPA undertook a rigorous scientific study of the Bristol Bay watershed, finding that the risk to these sensitive habitats from a mine was too great. Why risk our nation's food security, job security, natural resources, and greatness for the interests of a private mining company (that isn't even American)?

Your agency's findings already demonstrated that building a mine of this scale in this location would be an unacceptably destructive venture. I urge you keep in place the July 2014 Clean Water Act Proposed Determination - for the sake of the Bristol Bay watershed, its world-class salmon fishery, its people, and all of humanity.

L. Rogers
Seattle, WA

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
Administrator Pruitt, 

I am frustrated and dismayed, although I suppose not surprised, that you plan to reverse course and green light the proposed Pebble Mine, despite the catastrophic risks it poses to Alaska's Bristol Bay watershed, its world-renowned salmon runs and its Native communities. 

The EPA proposed science-based restrictions that would have banned Pebble Mine and protected Bristol Bay from the massive and irreversible environmental risks the mine would pose. This decision was the result of years of study which concluded that a large-scale mine would result in the "complete loss" of salmon habitat in some areas of the watershed.  Your recent settlement with Northern Dynasty Minerals to reverse the agency's common-sense restrictions is a blatant giveaway to the mining industry at the expense of the American people, our environment and our economy. 

Bristol Bay's wild salmon fishery supports 14,000 jobs and is valued at more than $1.5 billion annually. It also supplies nearly half of the world's sockeye salmon. More than 65 percent of Alaskans, 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents and Native communities, and 85 percent of commercial fishermen oppose the mine.

I urge you to listen to those voices, and for the sake of the Bristol Bay watershed, its world-class salmon fishery and its people, keep the door closed on Pebble Mine. I also urge you to listen to the comments submitted throughout this process, your career staff, and the vast body of scientific resource at your fingertips. The consequences of your decisions at EPA affect the future of the planet, quite literally. Please don't ruin it.

Title: Comment submitted by N. Faust
Comment:
RE:  EPA-R10-OW-2017-0369

The EPA decision regarding the Pebble Mine should stand!   Alaska depends on its fishery jobs and the salmon resources of our state's waters. Do not withdraw the Bristol Bay Proposed Determination, which was made under our Clean Water Act.

Bristol Bay, Alaska, is one of America's and the world's last great wild salmon runs. The annual runs of millions of salmon, support a large number of commercial and sport fishing jobs that keep thousands of Americans and Alaskans employed.  For Alaskans they are an important subsistence resource, for indigenous cultures salmon is a keystone, and for visitors from all over who come to Alaska, it is an amazing experience to still be able to catch salmon.

These are jobs fueled by an important renewable, valuable food resource. We should not risk this resource that can endure into the future to a foreign-owned mining company.  The people of Alaska, roughly 65%, do not support the proposed Pebble Mine.  We support our present and future by taking care of our salmon.

The EPA has done the right thing by making a decision protects Bristol Bay.  This was not an arbitrary decision. They followed the rigorous procedures for public comment, participation, and hearings.  The public responded with over a million and a half responses on this topic.

Please listen to the Alaskans and our fellow citizens in other states who support the EPA decision.

Please do not withdraw the proposed determination.

Nina Faust
P.O. Box 2994 
Homer AK 99603

Title: Comment submitted by T. Peter-Contesse
Comment:
Please do not withdraw the July 2014 Proposed Determination, issued pursuant of the Clean Water Act, to restrict the use of certain waters in the South Fork Koktuli River, North Fork Koktuli River, and Upper Talarik Creek watersheds in southwest Alaska as disposal sites for dredged or fill material associated with mining the Pebble deposit.

According to an exhaustive, peer-reviewed study undertaken by EPA itself - reportedly at the request of multiple inquiries, concerns, and petitions to EPA - "the extraction, storage, treatment, and transportation activities associated with building, operating, and maintaining one of the largest mines ever built would pose significant risks to the unparalleled ecosystem that produces one of the greatest wild salmon fisheries left in the world. In simple terms, the infrastructure necessary to mine the Pebble deposit jeopardizes the longterm health and sustainability of the Bristol Bay ecosystem".

Regardless of the specifics of permit applications that Pebble Limited Partnership (PLP) may submit to permit mining activities in the Pebble deposit, the EPA's own peer-reviewed scientific analysis has already determined that the infrastructure necessary to mine that deposit jeopardizes the long-term health and sustainability of the Bristol Bay ecosystem. There cannot possibly be a clearer reason to let the July 2014 Proposed Determination stand.

Sincerely,
Tristan Peter-Contesse

Title: Comment submitted by K. Hassell
Comment:
Dear Mr. Scott Pruitt, 

I am writing to you and the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to not withdraw or rescind the Proposed Determination for Docket EPA-R10-OW-2017-0369-0001.

By allowing PLP to apply for permits for further exploration and development, I question the EPA's commitment to fulfilling and adhering to the Clean Water Act. Further, there are no roads connecting the proposed mine site and it is only accessible by air. Transportation of any materials would need to be exported using a deep-water port and transportation network. The construction of this road, deep-water port and transportation network will displace billions of metric tons of rock and waste both near shore and very deep below surface waters. This will have outstanding negative impacts such as pollution, and further degradation to coastal and wetland areas that are crucial for wildlife, recreational and fishing uses, and traditional way of life to the Alaska Native communities in the area. 

The Bristol Bay watershed is largely undisturbed and Pebble mine is in the headwaters of major tributaries. Approximately 7,500 people live within or near the area downstream of Pebble and a substantial portion of the population rely on access to wild resources and subsistence. Tourism and sport fishing are major industries that bring thousands of people in each year to partake in renowned trout and salmon fishing. 

Pebble is a proposed open pit mine with an estimated 20 to 25-year lifespan. PLP claim that the mine would generate an estimated 2,000 jobs for construction, 1,000 full-time operational jobs and could generate tax revenue for the state. However, these jobs are only temporary and will dissipate once the mine is fully exhausted. In many cases, an influx of job opportunities in the area will also require further services to accommodate said workers. This can negatively affect infrastructure, sustainable resource management and socio-economic dynamics of surrounding Alaska Native communities. Alternatively, it is estimated that the Bristol Bay watershed generates $480 million and provides employment for over 14,000 part-time and full-time workers each year. Therefore, I argue that the preservation and protection of this area far outweighs the short-term influx of jobs. 

As mentioned previously, the Bristol Bay watershed is a highly-productive ecosystem. However, mine construction and operations could have devastating impacts to the water. For instance, wastewater treatment plant discharges could enter surrounding streams that are critical fish habitat. Transportation or pipeline failures will have adverse impacts to the watershed. Additionally, tailings ponds and storage facilities can fail, causing leachates and other chemical waste to enter the ecosystem and cause major health issues to downstream populations of both wildlife and humans. Impacts to water quality and fish habitat could heavily impact regional subsistence users and Alaska Native culture. 

Further, the Bristol Bay watershed provides habitat for 29 fish species, 40 terrestrial mammals, and over 190 bird species. Sockeye salmon are the most prevalent fish species and the runs support an estimated 46% of the global average abundance of wild sockeye salmon. Watershed quality, hydrologic connectivity and the diversity of the aquatic habitat, all of which enable the system to be highly productive, could be adversely impacted. It is estimated that the mine would cause between 30 to 145 km of stream to be altered or even destroyed due to mine construction, waste rock piles, blockage or dewatering. Other impacts include, but are not limited to; wetland destruction, imbalance of surface and groundwater flows, or loss of organic materials - all of which are necessary for fish production. 

Section 404(c) of the Clean Water Act authorizes the EPA to protect streams and rivers important for critical fish spawning grounds and wildlife habitat. The 2011 EPA Bristol Bay watershed assessment evaluated the effects of Pebble mine on the surrounding ecosystem. The assessment revealed that the proposed mining-activity would indeed cause adverse impacts to important fish habitat. If this is the case, then why is the EPA still considering the project? PLP has stated that the EPA had used outdated mine modelling and was very inaccurate in terms of projected impacts of the mine. I argue that if this is true, then further assessment is required to make the best decision using the best available science.
 
In summary, I urge you and the EPA to stand by its initial decision that was issued pursuant of the Clean Water Act. The EPA should stand by its proposed determination and work towards continued protection of the Bristol Bay watershed. 

Sincerely, 

Karli T. Hassell

Title: Comment submitted by J. Nigro
Comment:
To Whom It May Concern, 

I request that the EPA not withdraw the 2014 Proposed Determination for the Bristol Bay Watershed.  Bristol Bay is home to the world's largest Sockeye Salmon run and is some of our state's most pristine wilderness. It is sacred land with generations of fishing families making their livings there. Doing anything to possibly make it easier for a mine to be developed in this pristine wilderness would fly in the face of the purpose and duty of the Environmental PROTECTION Agency. We only have one planet. Our fish are a renewable resource, mining is finite, destructive and yet another colonizing and hate filled way to treat our beautiful state. 

As a life long Alaskan I ask you to protect the Bristol Bay Watershed. It is absolutely what you are here for. 

Sincerely, 

Jorden Nigro 
Juneau

Title: Comment submitted A. Odean
Comment:
UNDER NO CIRCUMSTANCES should the permitting application process be opened to allow for any company or corporation to apply for a permit for dredging or fill material due to mining in the Bristol Bay Watershed.  Last Nov. 2016 a ballot measure to Protect Bristol Bay Salmon from a mine PASSED in every single precinct in the state of Alaska.  Every One!  The people of Alaska have made a clear and unchangeable choice.  Salmon are Sacred.  Salmon cannot co-exist with mining.  The Bristol Bay Watershed supports HALF of the WORLD'S Sockeye Salmon!  Three years of the EPA's own studies have concluded that a mine would "result in complete loss of fish habitat due to elimination, de-watering and fragmentation of streams, wetlands and other aquatic resources."  The Bristol Bay Watershed is the home territory of one of the LAST remaining natural runs of wild sockeye salmon.  Save Salmon Habitat, it is OURS TOO!  Environmental PROTECTION Agency DO YOUR JOB!  PROTECT
Sincerely, 
Annie Odean
A very concerned US citizen

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
Your lack of proper execution of duties with the EPA is both dismaying and repugnant to me. You have turned an environmentally responsible position into an environmentally destructive activity, and I'm totally disappointed in your blatent irresponsibility for the position you have taken.

I am opposed to EPAs proposal to rescind the 2014 Proposed Determination designed to protect Bristol Bays world class fisheries. Please stand with American jobs and communities and preserve the Bristol Bay Proposed Determination.

Bristol Bay, Alaska, is one of America's last great wild salmon fisheries. Each year, tens of millions of wild salmon return, supporting upwards of 14,000 jobs in the commercial and sport fishing industries, and serving as a one-in-a-lifetime destination for anglers from around the world as well as the cultural cornerstone for the region's communities. These long-established businesses are at risk from a foreign-owned mining company that wants to build the proposed Pebble Mine, which is opposed by more than 65 percent of Alaskans and more than 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents. 

In 2014, led by Alaska Native Tribes, interests including commercial fishing business owners and sportsmen asked the EPA step in to ensure that this mine wouldn't jeopardize Bristol Bay. The EPA responded by listening to over 1.5 million Americans, hosting dozens of community meetings, reviewing Pebble's many detailed filings with state and federal agencies, and conducting a twice peer-reviewed scientific assessment of the potential impacts to the region. Withdrawing the proposed determination ignores the overwhelming majority of Alaskans and puts the short-term interests of a foreign mining company above thousands of local jobs. 

For the sake of our wildlife, waterways, and communities, I urge you to protect Bristol Bay and prevent this horrible open-pit mine from destroying one of our nation's most precious ecosystems.

Title: Comment submitted by D. Solberg
Comment:
Thank you for the opportunity to comment on the EPA's "rationale for the proposed withdrawal" of the 2014 Proposed Determination issued under the Clean Water Act.

The 2014 action by the EPA to restrict the dumping of mine tailings in the Upper Talarik Creek, North Fork Koktuli River and South Fork Koktuli River watersheds was a sound decision based on a reasonable assessment of the risk associated with projects of this scope. This region of Alaska supports a financially and environmentally healthy wild salmon fishery. The EPA's 2014 action is a practical step that protects the rivers and lakes that salmon need for spawning and rearing.

I do not support the "withdrawal" now proposed by the EPA and do not understand any rationale for doing so. Please do not change course. Instead, please honor the 2014 action that promises to protect salmon waters because a salmon system of this quality and scale simply exists no place else on Earth. 

As the holder of an Alaska limited entry permit for the Bristol Bay salmon fishery, I and my business associates understand the value of the abundant salmon runs and cannot support an experiment with large-scale mining in the Bristol Bay headwaters. These salmon runs have been a valuable industrial asset to this state and this nation for more than 125 years. So long as we continue to protect the salmon streams and lakes, and the lands surrounding them, these salmon runs will continue to thrive and continue to feed a thriving industry for generations to come.  

Thank you,
Dustin Solberg
