Title: Comment submitted by S. Flores
Comment:
Dear Administrator Pruitt,
The Bristol Bay sockeye salmon run is the largest wild sockeye salmon
fishery in the world. It is the lifeblood of the Bristol Bay region and
Lake Clark National Park and Preserve.
After many years of careful study, the Environmental Protection Agency
(EPA) found that the proposed Pebble Mine would have devastating
impacts on the region's salmon. I am alarmed at EPA's recent decision
to reverse course and allow a proposal for the massive mine to move
forward. The proposed mine, and the accompanying mining district it
could facilitate, would damage the people and wildlife of Bristol Bay,
threaten Lake Clark National Park and Preserve, and undermine America's
wild heritage.
The remarkable economic, community and cultural values of the wild
salmon fishery are essential to Bristol Bay and Lake Clark National
Park. I urge you not to withdraw the proposed Clean Water Act
determination the EPA made in 2014 and keep your agency's promise to
protect Bristol Bay's economy, people and wildlife. Please do not allow
Pebble Mine development to move forward.
Thank you for considering my comments.
Sincerely,
Sergio Flores

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I am opposed to the withdrawal of the EPA protections regarding the Pebble Mine proposal in the Bristol Bay watershed.  This mine could potentially become the largest open-pit mine ever build in North America--nearly as deep as the Grand Canyon.  It is estimated it would generate nearly 23B tons of dangerous waste, wipe out over 90 miles of salmon streams and almost 5,000 acres of wetlands, ponds and lakes.  The EPA's rigorous, peer-reviewed scientific study concluded that this mine would have unacceptable adverse effects on the $1B fishing industry in the area and proposed new restrictions to protect the habitat.

These protections were arrived at from years of rigorous scientific study and overwhelming community opposition that would devastate the local fishing economy, local Native-American tribe culture and way of life.

Title: Comment submitted by J. Simpson
Comment:
Dear EPA: 

I strongly object to EPA head Scott Pruitt's decision to withdraw the Obama protections for Bristol Bay for the benefit of Pebble Limited Partnership (Dynasty Minerals -- a Canadian mining company). The EPA must not withdraw its protections for the largest sustainable salmon run on Earth (56 million annually), thousands of American fishing jobs, clean water (a human right), and rights of the indigenous people who have honored & lived on the salmon runs for thousands of years. 

The EPA has already conducted an extensive review about the disastrous nature of this project: "a larger-scale mine would result in the "complete loss" of salmon habitat in some areas of the watershed." Furthermore, experts like University of Washington Fisheries Professor Ray Hillborn have stated "The idea you could store highly toxic waste (from a mine) forever behind a dam is just ridiculous" as he notes that the very reason the area is so productive for salmon (gravel beds) means it's very difficult to keep out mining toxins.  

I do not see why Tom Collier (foreign Pebble CEO)'s secret meeting with Mr. Pruitt gives him the right to exploit one of the United States' greatest renewable resources. Why should a renewable, sustainable resource that belongs to Americans be exploited for foreign profit, so Pebble can construct the "largest open pit mine ever constructed in North America... cover an area the size of Manhattan... a pit as 80% as deep as Grand Canyon."

Please do not withdraw the protections for Bristol Bay! As a Washingtonian, I purchase wild-caught Alaska salmon all the time. It is a beautiful, amazing resource and I love visiting beautiful, unique Alaska. 

With regards, 

Jennifer Simpson 
Seattle

Title: Comment submitted by G. Maltzeff
Comment:
October 17 2017
Hello EPA Administrator,
My Name is Eugene Maltzeff, I have been commercial fishing in Bristol Bay for 46 years. I also have two other businesses that sell and promote Bristol Bay salmon. 
I have been able to raise my family from an economy derived from the pure waters of Bristol Bay region. I also plan on passing this amazing fishing culture on to my children. 
Purity of water is the fundamental attribute of the BB region and Sockeye Fishery. We as fisherman, seafood processors, sportsman and sport lodge owners. All base our business, our lives, on the knowledge that the water quality in Bristol Bay remains pure.   
The fundamental reason the area is so environmentally and economically healthy, is based on the mere fact, that the watersheds are pure and support abundant life.  
These natural systems work perfectly, as they have for thousands of years.
There are no stores, gas stations, parking lots, industries, vehicles that lead historically to the demise of wild salmon, from toxic runoff and groundwater pollution. We also know, evidenced by endless example, that mines are always toxic, cannot coexist with salmon habitat. 
The notion, that this PPL mine will be more advanced in mitigating pollution is just rhetoric and a calamity waiting to happen. It takes very little heavy metal, like trace copper, to disorient young salmon and now there is good evidence, that run off from city streets by auto brake, copper residue, is killing young and adult salmon.
The concept of permitting anyone to tamper with this priceless watershed, must always be forbidden. The very fact that this economy has served and fed humans for thousands of years must be preserved at all cost. There, is no room for even small mistakes to be made! Especially when it comes to polluting critical headwaters that are already situated in a recognized earthquake zone.    
Conclusion: Proposed Determination that was issued pursuant of the Clean Water Act, to restrict the use of certain waters in the South Fork Koktuli River, North Fork Koktuli River, and Upper Talarik Creek watersheds in southwest Alaska as disposal sites for dredged or fill material associated with mining the Pebble deposit, a copper-, gold-, and molybdenum-bearing ore body. 
The Proposed Determination must remain in effect and must override any entity who feels it should have the right to develop a contaminating industry Such as PPL anywhere in the Bristol Bay region.
Thank you for your time and consideration regarding this matter. 
Sincerely, Gene Maltzeff
3805 56th AVE NE
Olympia WA 98506

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
Dear EPA, 

I am commenting as a concerned citizen who has recently visited the Bristol Bay/Nak Nek River Region. From my personal experience, it is one of the more beautiful and healthy river systems in our country. Withdrawing the regulations currently in place will greatly put this system at risk and will undoubtably disrupt/destroy the ecosystem. In short, I do not approve the withdraw and highly oppose letting mine tailings be dumped in the area for "safe" storage. 

If history (Mount Polley) and my disproval are not enough to convince, I suggest you reconsider the economic ramifications in the case these tailings do fail to meet expectations and result in entering the river systems. I understand the dollar trumps and do not let the short term gains, to benefit the few, cloud your decision. I would like you to consider the entire economic system that is currently supported by this river system. For instance, commercial fisheries and tourism (fishing, hunting, bear viewing, eco-toursim). 

Please keep the current regulations in place. Thank you for your time and the consideration of my comments.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment submitted by T. Lewis
Comment:
I oppose the proposal to withdraw the purposed determination to restrict use of area as disposal site in the pebble deposit area.  The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) must continue to restrict the use of certain waters in the Bristol Bay watershed for disposal of dredged or fill material associated with mining the Pebble deposit, a large ore body in southwest Alaska because of the high ecological and economic value of the Bristol Bay watershed and the assessed unacceptable environmental effects that would result from such mining. 

Bristol Bay is the greatest wild salmon fisheries left in the world, supplying approximately one half of the world's sockeye salmon. All watershed salmon are wild, there being no hatchery or hatchery releases. These sockeye salmon have a very high genetic diversity in the many separate runs, leading to high resilience. A pristine habitat is another basis of the productivity and diversity.  The original Pebble Mine proposal involved massive mine pits and large tailings impoundments (dammed with earth-filled dams made mostly out of tailings) and waste rock piles. Extraction, storage, treatment and transportation would involve transportation corridors, pipelines, power generation, and support services.  

Our fish resources are one of the most highly valued in the state of Alaska and around the world.  A major mine upstream from the largest spawning salmon watershed in the world is idiotic and irresponsible.  Again and again mines around the world have polluted the water and air around them.  Bristol Bay must stay pristine for the health and livelihood of future generations as well as the food supply for the world.

Thank you,
Tania Lewis
Gustavus Alaska

Title: Comment submitted by M. Tuohy
Comment:
To Whom it may concern,

Please do not reverse the determination that the Pebble Mine poses to too great a risk to the Bristol Bay ecosystem and it's fisheries to be built. I have been a volunteer in my community for over 25 years working to protect and preserve our wild salmon fisheries. This iconic and valuable resource defines our region. It has supported a robust fishing industry (both recreational and commercial), and it is a legacy we Northwesters have worked hard to preserve for our children and grandchildren. 

The proposed construction of this mine is an ecological nightmare and a short-sighted economic mistake. Bristol Bay provides thousands of jobs and millions of dollars annually to the U.S economy; the resource is 100% renewable. These impressive figures do not include great benefits to society from an intact ecosystem and maintenance of a resource with substantial cultural and spiritual importance. Pebble mine may provide short-term economic benefit, but long term this is a foolish mistake from an economic, ecological, social, and historical perspective. 

Construction of this mine risk's the preservation of our world's last great salmon fishery. We cannot risk the loss of something this priceless. Our nation has destroyed nearly every other salmon fishery in the lower 48, and the loss of this great fishery would forever erase a livelihood that has defined the Pacific Northwest since history was first recorded in this region. Please understand the basic economics behind this: Pebble Mine may result in some short-term economic benefit; however, the long-lasting nature of its toxic legacy will inevitably destroy our last renewable salmon fishery, worth hundreds of millions of dollars forever to come. Do not repeat history and do not ignore the long-term economic benefits of protecting Bristol Bay form short-sighted corporate demands. Your children and mine will thank you for having the foresight and ethics to preserve this important legacy for their future.

Sincerely,
Marilyn Tuohy

Title: Comment submitted by C. Orman
Comment:
Before I moved to Alaska in 2010, I did not understand the connection between the ocean, the watersheds, the salmon, and the people.
For me, I learned salmon runs are the true seasonal calendar; not days of the week or months in the year.  Salmon are noble creatures: born to ultimately return to their home streams to reproduce and die.  They create life and sustain life; feeding people, bears, and forests. 
The removal of the protections for Bristol Bay to allow for a "smaller" Pebble Mine on this pristine watershed ignores the salmon and its place for Alaskans. 
Worse, it places money and corporate interests -- as realistically with mining the "jobs" created are negligible in comparison to the money returns for the investors -- above history, culture, and nature. 

Salmon returns, and anadromous returns in general, continue to decrease.  Bristol Bay, to this point, has continued to have good returns.  But with water temperatures changing and the decreasing numbers in the Taku and Southeast Alaska as a harbinger, protections must be in place to ensure the continued return of these fish.
Reducing protections for the salmon will not ensure the returns of these majestic fish to a special region of Alaska.  

I can only hope, or wish, that others can experience what I have experienced.  I urge Mr. Pruitt to visit Bristol Bay.  I urge him to spend time in the fish camps.  I urge him to fly over the region and see the watershed.  More pointedly, I urge him to catch some sockeye and coho salmon and eat them over a campfire. 
Understanding the environment and what many cannot articulate, may be the best way to show and explain why this area deserves continued protection.  I do not believe an adequate decision can be made without knowing the full scope of the area and experiencing it.  

Thank you for your time,
Christopher Orman
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment submitted by J. and R. Schutz
Comment:
We are expressing strong objection to the proposal to withdraw the EPA Region 10 July 2014 Proposed Determination at the Pebble Mine Site.   This withdrawal has the potential of creating a major negative impact on the world's largest salmon run in Bristol Bay, thereby impacting both the livelihood and  sustenance of many Alaskans in the area.  It also has the potential to have a major impact on the region's wildlife, most notable the large native population of Brown Bears as well as other species whose very existence depends on the salmon runs.   We urge you to uphold the protections necessary to limit the impact on the area, it's people and wildlife.
Jim & Rhonda Schutz
6515 Polaris Street
West Richland, WA 99353

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I am opposed to EPAs proposal to rescind the 2014 Proposed Determination designed to protect Bristol Bays world class fisheries. Please stand with American jobs and communities and preserve the Bristol Bay Proposed Determination. 

Bristol Bay, Alaska, is one of America's last great wild salmon fisheries. Each year, tens of millions of wild salmon return, supporting upwards of 14,000 jobs in the commercial and sport fishing industries, and serving as a one-in-a-lifetime destination for anglers from around the world as well as the cultural cornerstone for the region's communities. These long-established businesses are at risk from a foreign-owned mining company that wants to build the proposed Pebble Mine, which is opposed by more than 65 percent of Alaskans and more than 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents. 

In 2014, led by Alaska Native Tribes, interests including commercial fishing business owners and sportsmen asked the EPA step in to ensure that this mine wouldn't jeopardize Bristol Bay. The EPA responded by listening to over 1.5 million Americans, hosting dozens of community meetings, reviewing Pebble's many detailed filings with state and federal agencies, and conducting a twice peer-reviewed scientific assessment of the potential impacts to the region. Withdrawing the proposed determination ignores the overwhelming majority of Alaskans and puts the short-term interests of a foreign mining company above thousands of local jobs. 

For the sake of our wildlife, waterways, and communities, I urge you to protect Bristol Bay and prevent this horrible open-pit mine from destroying one of our nation's most precious ecosystems.

Their is more to life than how much oil can be  pumped out of the ground. There's a huge need for renewable energy and to cut green house gases. Let out engineer's get to work to lead and develop the technologies to solve the problem of pollution.

Title: Comment submitted by K. Twardochleb
Comment:
I oppose the proposal to withdraw the EPA Region 10 July 2014 Proposed Determination that would restrict the use of certain waters in the Bristol Bay watershed in southwest Alaska as disposal sites for dredged or fill material associated with mining the Pebble deposit. The Bristol Bay watershed is unique because it supports one of the world's most productive salmon fisheries. A 2012 report prepared for the USEPA identified that this watershed has unparalleled "cultural, subsistence, commercial, recreational, economic, and environmental" importance; and these characteristics of the watershed, combined with the size of the proposed Pebble Mine, indicate that "Pebble poses a greater threat to the environment or fishery" than other mines (Levit and Chambers 2012, COMPARISON of the PEBBLE MINE with OTHER ALASKA LARGE HARD ROCK MINES). 

I am deeply concerned that withdrawing this proposed determination and allowing the Pebble Mine project to move forward would result in irreparable damage to the watershed of Bristol Bay, which has both intrinsic natural value, and is irreplaceable as one of the world's most productive salmon fisheries. The short term economic gains from the Pebble Mine project can never substitute for the loss of one of the healthiest salmon watersheds in the world.  

Sincerely,
Kimberly Twardochleb

Title: Comment submitted by B. MacGeorge
Comment:
Dear Ladies and Gentlemen,

As a resident of Seattle, I have followed the Pebble project for many years.  Needless to say it is a controversial subject 
in this area.
At first it was simply a curiosity to me but as I learned more about what was taking place, 
it felt to me that a real injustice was being dealt to the partnership.  
In an area zoned for mining, this was nothing less than taking away personal property rights without due process and without compensation. 
I have always felt that there
was a process in place for vetting projects and that this was somehow being circumvented.  My suggestion is to let the process
play out as our system is designed.  If the project is as dangerous as its foes believe, it will not get approval.  If it does appear
that the project will gain approval, another option could be to purchase the development rights from Pebble.  The party that
seems to have the most to gain without any skin in the game are the commercial fisherman.  Maybe set up an escrow account
that charges a small $/pound fee for fish caught in Bristol Bay to eventually payoff the buyout expense.  Either way, let the 
process function as it was intended and go from there.
Thank you for your attention.
Bill MacGeorge

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment: NO PEBBLE MINE, NOT NOW NOT EVER! The needs of Alaskans and of the State itself should be met before allowing an outside corporation to come in and reap those rewards with out any pay back or consequences.  Bristol Bay is a GLOBAL economic power, generations have made their living in, on and around it, it is world famous for a reason. Any corporation that states it can guarantee that no environmental accidents/harm will happen is lying, accidents happen (like in British Columbia)and can't be controlled. Nothing can be guaranteed! Our State Government and Federal Government need to listen to the people first! Not the greedy corporations with their hands in those same State and Federal pockets. This is a resource rich state, but when a mine could wipe out an entire way of life as well as do irreparable damage to an entire ecosystem we need to take a step back and think about the REAL consequences of our actions

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I am writing in opposition to the EPA's May 2017 settlement agreement with Pebble Partnership. As an avid fly fisher-woman, I value the importance of clean water- which, I think we all can agree is necessary for fish to not only survive, but thrive as a species. It is your job and duty to protect our environment. Allowing an open mine, such as Pebble Mine, certainly threatens the Bristol Bay salmon population- and its environment.  

To allow a backdoor settlement agreement without public comment defies every American's Constitutional right to Due Process. Just as clean water is necessary for the salmon population to thrive and survive in Bristol Bay, Due Process is necessary for American Democracy to work at its highest and most efficient level.  

Because I value the environment and all that it offers, I strenuously object to any mining activity in Bristol Bay. Such actions will be detrimental to the water, the living creatures in that water, as well as to the individuals in Alaska who benefit from fishermen and fisher-women alike who travel to Alaska to partake in the salmon run in Bristol Bay.

Title: Comment submitted by D. Nicholson et al.
Comment:
The EPA should use preemptive Clean Water Act restrictions to prevent large-scale mining in the Bristol Bay watershed. This is the right thing to do. Public resources should take precedence over private extraction. Here's why (http://kdlg.org/post/pebble-opponents-hammer-epa-changed-course-dillingham-meeting#stream/0)


"If we lose our fish, were going to lose everything. My children, and their childrens childrens children will never get a chance to do what Ive done."  David Nicholson, Dillingham.

"Without the strictest of protections like 404(c), our way of life, our fish, our clean, pure water will be decimated."  Dianne Folsom, Dillingham.

"Theres a reason that we have all this fish, because we dont have any mines, we dont have any dams."  Albert Larson, Dillingham.

"This withdraw is a threat to me and my people and our very existence as a people of this land."  Anuska Wysoki, Koliganek.

"When are going to say enough is enough and stop creating other potential risks or disasters to the dwindling wildernesses, lands, and water that have provided for our peoples existence for thousands of years.  Dagan Nelson, Dillingham.

It is your trust responsibility to continue to ensure that we will have clean water in Bristol Bay. I cannot feed my children copper or gold or anything that will come out of that mine.   Robyn Chaney, Dillingham.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment submitted by J. Cross
Comment:
The Administrator's proposal to rescind the determination under 404(c)(3) is environmentally disastrous, arbitrary and capricious, hypocritical, and corrupt. This proposal must be withdrawn unless the Administrator is capable of presenting a substantive rationale for change. 

Environmentally destructive: The long-term potential environmental impacts of the Pebble are not properly regulated and their costs are not properly identified. Proposals such as Pebble Mine are advanced by businesses in the absence of a regulatory structure that identifies the full environmental costs associated with such operations. Financial responsibility requirements authorized under CERCLA section 108(b) have not been promulgated for hard rock mining, so they cannot be imposed to provide funding to cover the response costs and natural resource damages that will inevitably be caused by Pebble mine.  

The result is artificially low costs for mining. This cost distortion removes an incentive for recycling used electronics and other equipment that are dense with gold, copper and other valuable metals --- much denser than the ore deposits at Pebble.  Sufficient incentives and infrastructure for this kind of recycling are not in place, and artificially low costs for virgin materials do not encourage the development of these incentives and infrastructure.

Arbitrary and capricious: There is no evidence that the Administrator considered the decision making record, information from Agency staff, or public views before agreeing to the settlement.   

While the litigation concerning Pebble mine and the 404(c) determination has been settled, this settlement does not authorize EPA to repudiate the 404(c) determination without full consideration of all the factors considered by EPA in making its earlier determination, and a substantive reproposal that addresses the merits.

Hypocritical --- The proposal is particularly idiotic and contemptible in the face of the directive issued yesterday, October 16 2017, by Administrator Pruitt on "Promoting Transparency and Public Participation In Consent Decrees and Settlements Agreements," proclaiming that the days of "sue and settle" are over.  This proposal is a ridiculous example of "sue and settle," repudiating years of work and an intensive scientific and public process, reaching an agreement with one set of litigants without reference to the substantive work supporting the 404(c) determination.   Supposedly, "regulation by litigation" is no longer acceptable, but "deregulation by litigation" continues to blunder recklessly ahead. By law, the Administrator must apply his own pronouncements evenhandedly, however foolish they are.

CorruptThe decision to turn over American resources to poorly regulated foreign enterprises puts global corporate interests ahead of the interests of American citizens. 

John Cross
Burke Virginia

Title: Comment submitted by P. Barnes
Comment:
I am writing to STRONGLY disagree with the EPA's proposed withdrawal from their current regulation that restricts certain areas from being used as disposal sites for the insanely proposed Pebble Mine.  The current EPA is going in the wrong direction.  More should be done to protect Bristol Bay, not less!!!!  Bristol Bay has the BEST salmon spawning habitat left on our precious planet.  This year alone, over $300 million dollars was generated in connection to the returning salmon exactly because of its pristine spawning grounds.  This has been happening for thousands of years and could happen far into the future if we have vision and sense enough to just LEAVE THE AREA ALONE!!!!!!!  Humans have screwed up plenty of former salmon spawning grounds.  Let's not do it in Bristol Bay.  It is the best of the best that is left in the entire world.  For the record, I have spent 3 summers in Bristol Bay as a commercial fisherman, Fish & Game employee and private citizen exploring much of the area.  I know exactly what is at stake.  I guarantee you it is far more than could ever be gained from any mine, particularly one as ill-conceived, short sighted and horribly located as Pebble.  Let's do the right thing this time.  Leave Bristol Bay alone.  Thank you.

Paul Barnes
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment submitted by Ellie N. (no surname provided)
Comment:
Bristol Bay has become the largest sustainable wild salmon fishery in the world.  It has created thousands of jobs--14 thousand, to be more precise-- and provided food to people all around the world.  People have responsibly fished here for over 120 years.  I believe that it is irresponsible of the EPA to use the power granted to it by the United States government and its people, to make decisions--such as the Pebble Mine--that jeopardize sustainable, responsible, and widely-valued practices such as commercial fishing in Bristol Bay.  This is not what the people whose ability to put food on the table for themselves and their families depends on this salmon fishery.  This is not in the best interest of anyone whom it will directly affect; just ask them.

Thank you,

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:

The health of the salmon populations -- and consequently the ecosystem of that area and food chain -- are at risk if mining is allowed. This has real human impact as well. Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
You are helping a foreign corporation and hurting americans and the alaskan economy. 
 what happened to america first?

I am opposed to EPAs proposal to rescind the 2014 Proposed Determination designed to protect Bristol Bays world class fisheries. Please stand with American jobs and communities and preserve the Bristol Bay Proposed Determination.

Bristol Bay, Alaska, is one of America's last great wild salmon fisheries. Each year, tens of millions of wild salmon return, supporting upwards of 14,000 jobs in the commercial and sport fishing industries, and serving as a one-in-a-lifetime destination for anglers from around the world as well as the cultural cornerstone for the region's communities. These long-established businesses are at risk from a foreign-owned mining company that wants to build the proposed Pebble Mine, which is opposed by more than 65 percent of Alaskans and more than 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents. 

In 2014, led by Alaska Native Tribes, interests including commercial fishing business owners and sportsmen asked the EPA step in to ensure that this mine wouldn't jeopardize Bristol Bay. The EPA responded by listening to over 1.5 million Americans, hosting dozens of community meetings, reviewing Pebble's many detailed filings with state and federal agencies, and conducting a twice peer-reviewed scientific assessment of the potential impacts to the region. Withdrawing the proposed determination ignores the overwhelming majority of Alaskans and puts the short-term interests of a foreign mining company above thousands of local jobs. 

For the sake of our wildlife, waterways, and communities, I urge you to protect Bristol Bay and prevent this horrible open-pit mine from destroying one of our nation's most precious ecosystems.

Title: Comment submitted by Simon (No surname provided)
Comment:
Hello, 

I wanted to reach out to voice my concerns about the proposed lifting of restrictions on the disposal of material from Pebble Mine into the watersheds of SW Alaska. I grew up in Seattle, WA and have settled down in Portland, OR and despite the proximity to Alaska it was not until after I graduated from college that I made my first trip North. I have since taken several trips to many regions in Alaska to hike, fly fish, and explore. 

One of the regions I have had the opportunity to return to many times in the Bristol Bay, specifically the Naknek River. After my first day on the Naknek I knew it was a place I would be coming back to for the rest of my life. From a day on the river chasing rainbows, watching 500,000 Sockeye rush through the head water, to flying out to Brooks to watch the bears stock up on food for the winter this area is such an amazing snapshot of one of Earth's remaining heathy ecosystems. 

While I understand the need to adjust with changing times/the short term economic upsides to Pebble Mine, overlooking the long term effect on this region's wildlife and balanced functioning ecosystem would be a irreversible mistake. Harming the environment of a region so rich with wildlife and food source for humans and other animals would have a rippling affect up and down the food chain. 

Myself and so many others make annual trips to towns in Bristol Bay bringing money and tourist jobs to the region. If the animals and fish get affected by the Pebble Mine deposits in the watershed this all drys up. We would be losing another of the dwindling "untouched" regions of the world and killing a regions renewable tourist economy. 

I can't stress enough how much I have enjoyed spending time in Bristol Bay and hope to be able to bring my children there to see the same overpowering beauty. Please don't sacrifice this just to increase mineral outputs for the next decade. 

Thank you. 

Simon
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment submitted by E. Masingill
Comment:
Dear EPA,
I am writing to express my strong opposition to the EPA's May 2017 settlement agreement with Pebble Partnership (a more benign sounding name for Northern Dynasty Mining Company, a Canadian corporation and 100% owner of Pebble Partnership). Though placing a more palatable name may aid in pulling the wool over the eyes of the general public, it certainly should not alter the EPA's mandate to protect our environment. In 2014, the EPA determined that the Clean Water Act prohibited the project proposed for by the Northern Dynasty Mining Company for Bristol Bay.  Notwithstanding the EPA's environmental findings, in May of 2017 the EPA agreed to a settlement with Northern Dynasty Mining Company.  In a nutshell, the settlement terms were as follows: Northern Dynasty would drop the lawsuits it filed against the EPA in exchange for the EPA agreeing to withdraw its regulatory conclusion that Northern Dynasty Mining Company's proposed mining operation violated the Clean Water Act.  The public was not allowed to engage, comment, or otherwise take part in the settlement, which was negotiated behind closed doors. Such is a blatant disregard to the Due Process rights of all Americans who oppose, or for that matter support, the proposal. 
 
Scott Pruitt, the EPA Administrator heralded the settlement, noting that while the EPA was "committed to due process and the rule of law... [the settlement would] help steer EPA away from costly and time-consuming litigation..." In what possible world does a backdoor settlement without public comment and consideration of those comments by the EPA equate to compliance with Due Process, or the EPA's rules and regulations? The answer is obvious, it does not. Perhaps the EPA should attempt to comply with the well known mandates of the Administrative Procedures Act which govern the agency's procedural requirements, as well as the public comment period. 

The EPA is not a political party and its scientific findings in  2014 were the same as they are today--the proposal violates the Clean Water Act. However, rather than uphold the EPA's duty to the American public and rely on scientific analysis to determine the effects of a proposal and whether such proposal would violate the Clean Water Act, it is ceding the duty to protect the environment under the auspice of saving the public from costly and time-consuming litigation. Litigation to prevent violations of the Clean Water Act is exactly the type of business that the citizens provide funding (through tax dollars) to the EPA. The EPA is letting the citizens down when it does not perform its intended function, not to mention violates those pesky laws we all are bound to follow. Despite the EPA's stated purpose for the settlement agreement, the true intent is obviously to allow development which will  enrich the Canadian corporation and provide a temporary potential boost to the economy. Yet, that temporary boost would be more than offset by the potentially devastating effects on the fishery, which over the long-haul provide sustainable positions and encourages tourism that will actually be more beneficial to the economy in the long-term. The EPA is currently engaged in a short-sighted analysis that runs counter to the mission of the EPA--i.e. to ensure compliance with environmental laws and regulations. 

Rather than adhere to the law, the EPA is simply allowing Northern Dynasty Mining Company to submit its permit, after already determining the proposed mine would violate the Clean Water Act.  Essentially, the EPA's settlement completely nullifies due process and the rule of law, which dictates that the matter be settled by the Administrative Agency (the EPA) and the Northern Dynasty Mining Company.  If the Northern Dynasty Mining Company chooses to fight the EPA's ruling and continue its plan to poison the water,  the Judicial Branch provides the mechanism for such a dispute.  That is the very purpose behind our Constitution's three branches of government and the system of checks and balances, which the settlement completely circumvents. In sum, do your job and uphold the laws of the United States.
 
Donald Trump ran on a pledge to put America first.  Yet, nothing could be more antithetical to putting Americans first than allowing foreign profiteers to bypass the Clean Water Act and imperil Bristol Bay's unparalleled salmon fishery, which accounts for over 14,000 American jobs! Not to mention those are sustainable jobs, whereas a mine provides only temporary employment until the mine is fully harvested. The proposal will leave the public with a Superfund site that it will end up having to float the bill to remedy and deal with the potential environmental disasters. This short-sighted decision will allow a temporary economical boost to threaten sustained employment and a vital food source. In the long-run, this is detrimental to the economy and the environment. I ask you do your job and adhere to the law.

Very truly yours,
Eben Masingill

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
Restrictions on  the disposal of overburden and waste materials from proposed mining in Alaska, with the inevitable impact on significant river systems, must not be withdraw or weakened. Clearly mining and extraction companies operating above the 56th parallel, in both Alaska and Canada, are focused on profit over people and planet. 

Failure to place the highest expectations and requirements to ensure pristine waters will place major subsistence, commercial, and sport fisheries at grave risk.  The recent record harvests of salmon may not be repeated if adequate safe guards are not in place, mining activities are not monitored regularly, and corporation are not held accountable. 

Of course damaging or destroying watersheds have much broader implications and impact the entire riparian ecosystem. We can anticipate loss of water fowl, river otters, beaver and other creatures, large and small that depend on healthy wetlands, streams and rivers. That includes humans. The indigenous people in Southwest Alaska still rely heavily on subsistence foods. Fish, fowl, moose and caribou are critical for households along the streams at risk. Alaska is also one of the last refuges for many Americans and visitors from across the world who come here to experience the beauty, wonder and solitude of the land. The Lake Iliamna region, the Nushagak drainage (including the Mulchatna, Stuyahok, and Koktuli) are a tremendous draw to countless Alaskans and tourists potentially impacted by the failure to safeguard the environment from mining operations, espcially one the scale of Pebble Mine..

Balancing the corporate interests, relentless pursue of resources, and the intangible and prices value of a healthy ecosystem is challenging. When development is essential the the public good (Pebble is questionable as some evidence indicates proper recycling would recover as much copper as the mine would produce in the same period) the EPA is charged with finding that balance. With Pebble Mine that balancing act can begin with ensuring proper safeguards by retaining the restrictions.

I am opposed to EPAs proposal to rescind the 2014 Proposed Determination designed to protect Bristol Bays world class fisheries. Please stand with American jobs and communities and preserve the Bristol Bay Proposed Determination.

Bristol Bay, Alaska, is one of America's last great wild salmon fisheries. Each year, tens of millions of wild salmon return, supporting upwards of 14,000 jobs in the commercial and sport fishing industries, and serving as a one-in-a-lifetime destination for anglers from around the world as well as the cultural cornerstone for the region's communities. These long-established businesses are at risk from a foreign-owned mining company that wants to build the proposed Pebble Mine, which is opposed by more than 65 percent of Alaskans and more than 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents.

For the sake of our wildlife, waterways, and communities, I urge you to protect Bristol Bay and prevent this horrible open-pit mine from destroying one of our nation's most precious ecosystems.

Every time you choose potential profits for companies over maintaining a healthy environment, you are choosing to add a nail to the coffin that is becoming our children's future.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment: As a scientist, I support maintaining the Restricted Use of waters in the Bristol Bay watershed in order to sustain the important commercial, subsistence and sport fisheries in the rivers that would be impacted by the proposed Pebble Mine.  The science and public support for protecting the salmon and waters are unequivocal; we need the diversity of salmon species in order to sustain populations as they experience natural environmental variations that are becoming increasing unpredictable. Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
Dear EPA:   
I do not support the withdrawal of EPA's July 2014 Clean Water Act Proposed Determination that would impose restrictions on the discharge of dredged or fill material associated with the potential Northern Dynasty Minerals Ltd. (PLP) in Alaska's Bristol Bay in portions of the Kvichak and Nushagak watersheds. Alaska's Bristol Bay is an area of unparalleled ecological richness with salmon, other fish and wildlife species that is unrivaled anywhere in North America and beyond. The Bristol Bay watershed provides a complete, connected habitat from headwaters to ocean that support abundant, genetically diverse wild Pacific salmon populations that maintain the productivity and diversity of the entire ecosystem for other fish and wildlife. 
I do not support the withdrawal of EPA's July 2014 Clean Water Act Proposed Determination for several reasons. First, a major mine project of this type will continue to cause an unacceptable adverse effect that would "result in complete loss of fish habitat due to elimination, dewatering, and fragmentation of streams, wetlands, and other aquatic resources".  With many of the losses being irreversible.  Construction and operation of an open pit mine, management of waste materials from the mine, support facilities including a major transportation system (roads, bridges and culverts), pipelines, a power generating station, wastewater treatment plants, housing and support services for workers, administrative offices, and other infrastructure would continue to result in miles of streams and acres of wetlands and other habitats that are important to salmon and other fish to be lost. Even if PLP is thinking of a smaller project than was originally proposed in 2011, the EPA's July 2014 Clean Water Act Proposed Determination still applies and projections of adverse, irreversible and cumulative effects should the project ever expand also still apply.  The Proposed Determination was carefully prepared by expert scientists and agency officials after several years of study, public involvement and preparation and was fully accepted by an independent peer-reviewed group for scientific and technical information accuracy. 
Second, according to PLP, it would employ over 1,000 people during the mine's lifespan and over 2,000 people during the construction phase.  The projected employment rate is of limited benefit to the community relative to the high risk to the 14,000 full- and part-time workers in the commercial and sport fish fishing industry alone who could lose their livelihoods if an environment accident occurred.  Nearly half of the world's sockeye catch comes from this area and approximately $480 million is generated each year in direct economic expenditures and sales.  This area is also home to a more than 4,000-year-old subsistence-based way of life for Alaska Natives whose history, culture and survival could be devastated as well. 
Lastly, the Atlantic and Pacific coasts of the United States once had sizable wild salmon runs. What remains, mostly in the Pacific, is a faint memory of what once occurred.  Once huge wild Atlantic salmon runs have long been the target of recreational and commercial fishing, and this, as well as habitat destruction is now limited the Atlantic salmon to small remnant populations.  Living in Stanley, Idaho, I have personally seen the effects of dams blocking wild sockeye salmon runs. In the 1880's, an estimated 25,000 and 35,000 sockeye returned annually to the Sawtooth Basin. Dam building in the 1900's put salmon range and population in such peril that in 1992 only one - Lonesome Larry - made it back to Redfish Lake near Stanley.  Idaho's sockeye salmon were listed as "Endangered" under the federal Endangered Species Act in November 1991 - the first Idaho salmon species to be listed. Chinook and steelhead were listed as "Threatened" near the same time.  In 2017, Idaho's most endangered sockeye salmon has fared only slightly better with 157 salmon migrating 900-mile from the Pacific crossing eight dams and climbing 6,500-feet elevation to the Sawtooth Basin.  Wild salmon have paid a huge price for large scale projects in the lower 48 states in the name of the economic advancement.  
Alaska's Bristol Bay is an area of unmatched ecological abundance with salmon, other fish and wildlife that occurs nowhere else on Earth.  Over 14,000 Alaskan Natives, commercial and sports fisherman depend on salmon for their economic survival. Protection of the Pacific salmon species and its habitat is paramount. Activities such as mining of this size that could cause an unacceptable adverse effect on Pacific wild salmon in Bristol Bay should not be allowed to be permitted, so therefore I do not support the reversal of clean water safeguards on this special area.  I request to be placed on your mailing list to receive all future information about EPA's July 2014 Clean Water Act Proposed Determination and any activity associated with it. 
Thank you.

Title: Comment submitted by K. McElroy
Comment:
The text for this regulation (Proposal To Withdraw Proposed Determination To Restrict the Use of an Area as a Disposal Site; Pebble Deposit Area, Southwest Alaska, Docket #EPA-R10-OW-2017-0369) includes a regulatory action that the agency should revisit in light of the extensive research which suggests the outcomes of Pebble Mine would harm the economically, culturally, and ecologically significant sockeye salmon runs in Bristol Bay, Alaska. Furthermore, the agency should revisit their own work that concluded Pebble Mine would negatively impact the Bristol Bay watershed, and thus the sockeye salmon run. 

The research summarized below suggests that the outcomes of the Pebble Mine will destroy crucial sockeye spawning habitat and result in devastation of the fishery. 

Bristol Bay has supported one of the most productive sockeye salmon runs in the world since the early 1900s. The communities around Bristol Bay have been reliant on the sockeye populations for food and employment (Knapp et al. 2013), as well as for deep cultural ties to the species (Goldsmith 2007). The other species inhabiting the Bristol Bay watershed (Grizzly and Brown bears, many species of migratory birds, other freshwater fish species, wolves, hawks, eagles) are reliant on sockeye salmon for food (Willson and Halupka 1995) and for the delivery of marine-derived nutrients into the environment (Kline et al. 1993, Schindler 2003, Stockner 2003). It is estimated that Pebble Mine would produce between 2.5 and 10 billion tons of waste containing elements, such as copper and other heavy metals, that would threaten spawning and rearing grounds for sockeye salmon. The increase in acidity of the watershed due to the storage and mining of metal-sulfide ores (USEPA 1994) endangers salmonids by creating an imbalance of chloride and sodium ions in the blood (Morris et al, 1989), which can result in death by osmoregulatory or respiratory failure (Kimmel 1983). The life stages most at risk are the juvenile life stages of eggs and alevin (Rosseland 1986), which are crucial in the recruitment back to the spawning population. Low levels of copper in the water also negatively impacts juvenile salmon by ceasing or slowing growth (Buckley et al. 1982) and by eliminating the neurological and behavioral response to an alarm pheromone, making individuals more susceptible to predation (Baldwin et al. 2003). The impacts of these toxins outlined here could decrease freshwater survival and thus the population of sockeye salmon. The decrease in sockeye salmon populations that would result from Pebble Mine would threaten the rest of the Bristol Bay ecosystem (Chambers et al. 2012) and the surrounding communities. 

Please consider what this action implies regarding the largest sockeye salmon market in the world, the rural native Alaskan economy, and one of the last pristine sockeye salmon habitats.

Sincerely,
Katherine McElroy 
M.A. Ecology and Evolutionary Biology, University of California Santa Cruz
PhD student Aquatic and Fisheries Science, University of Washington 

Research Cited
Baldwin, D. et al. 2003. Sublethal effects of copper on coho salmon: impacts on non-overlapping receptor pathways in the peripheral olfactory nervous system. 
Buckley, J. et al. 1982. Chronic exposure of coho salmon to sublethal concentrations of copper-1. Effect on growth, on accumulation, and distribution of copper, and on copper tolerance. 
Chambers, D. et al. 2012. Bristol Bay's wild salmon ecosystems and the Pebble Mine: key considerations for a largescale mine proposal. 
Goldsmith, S. 2007. The remote rural economy of Alaska. Institute of Social and Economic Research, University of Alaska, Anchorage, AK. A.
Kimmel, W. 1983. The impact of acid mine drainage on the stream ecosystem. Pages 424-437 in S. Majumdar, and E. Miller, editors. Pennsylvania coal: resources, technology, and utilization. Pennsylvania Academy of Science, Easton, PA.
Kline, T.J. et al. 1993. Recycling of elements transported upstream by runs of Pacific salmon: II.15N and 13C evidence in the Kvichak River watershed, Bristol Bay, southwestern Alaska. 
Knapp, G. et al. 2013. The economic importance of the Bristol Bay salmon industry.
Morris, R. er al. 1989. Acid toxicity and aquatic animals. Society of experimental biology seminar series, No. 34. Cambridge University Press, New York, NY.
Rosseland, B. 1986. Ecological effects of acidification on tertiary consumers: fish population responses. 
Schindler, D. et al. 2003. Pacific salmon and the ecology of coastal ecosystems. 
Stockner, J., editor. 2003. Nutrients in salmonid ecosystems; sustaining production and biodiversity. American Fisheries Society, Bethesda, MD.
USEPA. 1994a. Technical document: acid mine drainage prediction. Special Waste Branch, Office of Solid Waste, USEPA, EPA530-R-94-036, Washington, D.C.
Willson, M., and K. Halupka. 1995. Anadromous fish as keystone species in vertebrate communities. Conservation Biology 9(3):4

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
Wild fisheries are vital to the survival of the fishing industry. The biodiversity of the Bristol Bay salmon contributes to the overall stability and sustainability of its fisheries.   As weather patterns and water conditions fluctuate over time, different populations flourish at different times; and different geographic regions and different life history strategies have been the major contributors to the success of the fishery.  Other historical salmon habitats across North America have been destroyed or degraded due to hydroelectric dams, pollution, irrigation and overfishing.  For example, dams permanently block more than 55 percent of the spawning and rearing habitat once available to salmon in the Columbia River Basin in the Northwestern United States.  The dramatic decrease in the Pacific Northwest salmon populations have led to the introduction of hatcheries to replace the lost wild stock.  According to the Fish and Wildlife Service, over 80% of the salmon that now return to the Columbia River Basin is hatchery-reared fish.  Although originally derived from wild populations, years of culturing under artificial conditions have resulted in adaptations and changes to hatchery reared fish.  Hatchery fish are hand-fed, and are reared in a controlled environment, void from predators and natural selection.  Millions of genetically identical hatchery fish are released into the wild each year in an effort to fill the gaps left behind by the ancestral wild salmon.  The lack of genetic variation makes entire populations prone to illnesses and diseases such as whirling disease that can wipe out an entire population.  The hatchery fish that do survive compete with the remaining wild fish for food and habitat, and in some cases spread hatchery born diseases into the wild population.  Less than 1% of the smolts released from the hatcheries return from the ocean to spawn. The Bristol Bay wild salmon populations are vital to the genetic health of the Pacific salmon species and to the livelihood of commercial fisheries that harvest the salmon.  In many waterways throughout western Canada and the United States, these species are listed under the Endangered Species Act.  Salmon habitats in the lower 48, aided by hatchery populations, expect to see a return of a few thousand adult salmon per year.  In Bristol Bay, between 25 million and 50 million wild salmon return to its watershed every year, making it the largest wild salmon fishery in the world. This migration is responsible for bringing in over $500 million a year and sustaining over 11,000 jobs. The industry is vital to not only the native population, but also to the state and national economies. This is a renewable resource that will always provide, as long as we take care of it for future generations.
The proposed site is situated at the headwaters of two of the larger watersheds within the Bristol Bay ecosystem. The proposed operation is so massive, that it would be considered the largest open pit mine ever built (7 square miles). The energy and water required to operate the facility would be greater than that of the entire state of Alaska per year. Earthen dams taller than the Hoover Dam would be built to contain the acid-rich poisonous overburden forever. The metal-containing ores at Pebble are rich in sulfide minerals.  These minerals generate acid that when exposed to air and water, produce Acid Mine Drainage.  This drainage is the main source of water pollution associated with mines.  Another potential hazard at the mine complex includes pollution from the proposed on-site power plant that in undoubtedly pollute the surrounding air and water.  Furthermore, the ore slurry dug up at mine would be transported via a haul road past Lake Iliamna to the Cook Inlet. Northern Dynasty is notorious for adversely impacting the local environment, most notably through tailing dam failures into waterways. 
The proposed Pebble Mine has a 50 year lifespan. At which point, the Canadian company will pick up and leave, leaving the mess for us to deal with. Although short term profits are alluring to investors and well-connected politicians, they are short lived. Bristol Bay is already rich with a sustainable and clean resource: Salmon. Do not jeopardize this resource by selfishly authorizing a project no one wants. $500 million a year, forever. Why can't that be enough? Protect life, protect Bristol Bay, and absolutely NO PEBBLE MINE!

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
It is a devastating & disturbing joke, Mr. Pruitt, that you are in charge of 'protecting' ANY thing other than yours & your corporate buddies bank accounts.  WE THE PEOPLE had to fight for so very many years to have the powers that be FINALLY begin to protect OUR environment, OUR national treasures & all the living breathing beings therein & YOU come along caring nothing about anything other than making $$ for you & your big oil, gas & coal buds, doing whatever you can to undo ALL the previous PROTECTION efforts.  You are a reprehensible, repugnant, valueless human being & I truly hope you get EVERTHING you so deserve in life for your lack of respect of other lives.

  
I am opposed to EPAs proposal to rescind the 2014 Proposed Determination designed to protect Bristol Bays world class fisheries. Please stand with American jobs and communities and preserve the Bristol Bay Proposed Determination.

Bristol Bay, Alaska, is one of America's last great wild salmon fisheries. Each year, tens of millions of wild salmon return, supporting upwards of 14,000 jobs in the commercial and sport fishing industries, and serving as a one-in-a-lifetime destination for anglers from around the world as well as the cultural cornerstone for the region's communities. These long-established businesses are at risk from a foreign-owned mining company that wants to build the proposed Pebble Mine, which is opposed by more than 65 percent of Alaskans and more than 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents. 

In 2014, led by Alaska Native Tribes, interests including commercial fishing business owners and sportsmen asked the EPA step in to ensure that this mine wouldn't jeopardize Bristol Bay. The EPA responded by listening to over 1.5 million Americans, hosting dozens of community meetings, reviewing Pebble's many detailed filings with state and federal agencies, and conducting a twice peer-reviewed scientific assessment of the potential impacts to the region. Withdrawing the proposed determination ignores the overwhelming majority of Alaskans and puts the short-term interests of a foreign mining company above thousands of local jobs. 

For the sake of our wildlife, waterways, and communities, I urge you to protect Bristol Bay and prevent this horrible open-pit mine from destroying one of our nation's most precious ecosystems.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
The EPA should not withdraw the EPA Region 10 July 2014 Proposed Determination to restrict the use of certain waters in the South Fork Koktuli River, North Fork Koktuli River, and Upper Talarik Creek watersheds in southwest Alaska as disposal sites for dredged or fill material associated with mining the Pebble deposit. To withdraw the prior determination now and restart the permit application process is an egregious waste of public resources and the US taxpayer's money and time, with no added benefit. 

The rationale for the EPA proposal to withdraw the 2014 determination, in this case, has been promoted as a way to adhere to process and procedures, but that rationale ignores that an equally important and legally valid process was followed for the 2014 scientific determination, under a provision of the Clean Water Act. Through a years-long process of extensive scientific study and community engagement, the 2014 determination concluded that mining activities in the region would be uniquely destructive to one of the world's most valuable salmon fisheries.

The majority of Alaskans have overwhelmingly voted to reject this project in any form.  Industries that will be affected by the mine's inevitable and unavoidable environmental impacts have rejected this project. The people employed in sustainable, broad-based industries across the region have rejected this project. Most importantly, the Native American tribes who rely on the natural resources of the Bristol Bay watershed have resoundingly rejected this project. 

The developer of the mine seeks to restart the application process without regard to the costs to taxpayers, the waste of public resources and agency resources, and the clear rejection by those most affected, for a project that has already been conclusively, scientifically demonstrated is not in the national interest. 

The data on the environmental impacts has not changed. Public opinion against the Pebble Mine project has not changed.  Any objective observer familiar with the scientific facts would conclude that mining activities in the Bristol Bay watershed region would be uniquely damaging to a crucial natural resource that is a sustainable generator of considerable economic activity.  Withdrawing the 2014 determination solely benefits a foreign private mining company, and draws out a redundant, expensive, time-consuming process with no additional benefit to the US public, at US taxpayer expense. Withdrawing the the 2014 determination is not in the national interest, and the proposal should be rejected.

Title: Comment submitted by T. Wisner
Comment:
Attn: Office of the Administrator
Environmental Protection Agency

Dear Administrator Pruitt,

I strongly urge you not to withdraw the proposed determination under the Clean Water Act to restrict the use of waters in Southeast Alaska as disposal sites for dredged or filled materials associated with mining the Pebble deposit. 

The wild salmon run in Bristol Bay is an incredible natural resource that sustains a $1.5 billion fishery and supports an estimated 14,000 jobs. As the daughter of a commercial fisherman, the Bristol Bay fishery is of incredible personal importance to me. My father has been fishing in Bristol Bay since the 1980s, and today he operates a successful seining operation through which he employs all three of my siblings. My family's livelihood quite literally depends on the continued sustainability of Bristol Bay's wild salmon run, and having grown up in Southcentral Alaska, I know countless families for which the same is true. 

A development like the Pebble Mine poses a massive threat to one of the world's last wild salmon runs, along with the thousands of small businesses that it supports. From an economic perspective alone, this mine does not make sense. The people of Alaska stand behind the protection of Bristol Bay and its vast resources, and the EPA should do the same.

Sincerely, 

Teresa Wisner
Anchor Point, AK, 99556
teresa.wisner@gmail.com

It's far easier and more economically sound to protect a functional and productive ecosystem than to try and fix it later.  It is the Environmental Protection Agency's job to PROTECT THE ENVIRONMENT.  These bans were put in place in response to peer-reviewed research showing that development in this area would cause unacceptable levels of environmental damage, and that decision needs to be upheld, not undermined.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
YOU ARE THE HEAD OF THE ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AGENCY NOT THE GIVE IT ALL AWAY TO THE CORPORATIONS AGENCY. SERVE THE CITIZENS OF THE UNITED STATES.

I am opposed to EPAs proposal to rescind the 2014 Proposed Determination designed to protect Bristol Bays world class fisheries. Please stand with American jobs and communities and preserve the Bristol Bay Proposed Determination.

Bristol Bay, Alaska, is one of America's last great wild salmon fisheries. Each year, tens of millions of wild salmon return, supporting upwards of 14,000 jobs in the commercial and sport fishing industries, and serving as a one-in-a-lifetime destination for anglers from around the world as well as the cultural cornerstone for the region's communities. These long-established businesses are at risk from a foreign-owned mining company that wants to build the proposed Pebble Mine, which is opposed by more than 65 percent of Alaskans and more than 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents. 

In 2014, led by Alaska Native Tribes, interests including commercial fishing business owners and sportsmen asked the EPA step in to ensure that this mine wouldn't jeopardize Bristol Bay. The EPA responded by listening to over 1.5 million Americans, hosting dozens of community meetings, reviewing Pebble's many detailed filings with state and federal agencies, and conducting a twice peer-reviewed scientific assessment of the potential impacts to the region. Withdrawing the proposed determination ignores the overwhelming majority of Alaskans and puts the short-term interests of a foreign mining company above thousands of local jobs. 

For the sake of our wildlife, waterways, and communities, I urge you to protect Bristol Bay and prevent this horrible open-pit mine from destroying one of our nation's most precious ecosystems.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
The EPAs proposal to withdraw the Proposed Determination of July 2014, which restricts the use of various bodies of water in the Bristol Bay watershed as disposal sites for material from the Pebble mine, is profoundly reckless. Such an unconscionable abdication of regulatory responsibility invites an environmental catastrophe of the first order and an economic disaster for Alaska.

The Bristol Bay ecosystem is a natural treasure and home to some of the richest salmon runs in the U.S. Poisoning these waters with mining debris would be a crime against nature, a venal betrayal of the public trust, and a potentially fatal blow to Alaskas fishing industry. I urge you to finalize and enforce the July 2014 Proposed Determination.

It is the EPAs public duty to protect Bristol Bay from mining disposal. Do not betray the long-term civic good for short-term corporate profit and cynical political gain. I urge you in the strongest terms: do not rescind the July 2014 Proposed Determination!
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment: The EPA Region 10 July 2014 Proposed Determination that was issued pursuant to the Clean Water Act, to restrict the use of certain waters in the South Fork Koktuli River, North Fork Koktuli River, and Upper Talarik Creek watersheds in southwest Alaska as disposal sites for dredged or fill material associated with mining the Pebble deposit, a copper-, gold-, and molybdenum-bearing ore body SHOULD NOT BE WITHDRAWN.  Preservation of the watersheds, the salmon habitat, the salmon industry and the jobs associated with the salmon industry is far more important than the mining of the ore body at this time.  Preservation of the natural habitat will provide nutritional resources for the human population and related jobs for local people for centuries to come if properly managed.  Use of the watershed as a mining dumping ground will provide economic benefit only to the mining industry and only temporarily until the ore is mined out, but will permanently destroy the biological resources and food resource for centuries to come.  There can be no justification for allowing the mining-related destruction of habitat to occur at this time.  In the future, improved technologies may be developed that would allow some of the ore deposit to be mined without habitat destruction.  In the meantime, improved recycling and ore sources in other regions can make up for some or all of the copper, gold and molybdenum present in the ground near the watersheds in question.  The ore body near the watersheds in question should be kept in the ground as a possible resource to be mined by such improved methods at such future date (if at all), and the habitat, salmon populations and salmon industry should be preserved in the present.  I am a resident of New York State, and I personally will be adversely affected at my location by a decreased supply and increased price of wild salmon--which is nutritionally superior to farmed salmon--as food.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
As a marine scientist and commercial salmon fisher in Alaska, I am strongly opposed to opening the watersheds of Bristol Bay to mining. I specifically object to the current EPA proposal to withdraw the July 2014 Proposed Determination to restrict the discharge of dredged or fill material associated with the potential "Pebble Mine" in Alaska's Bristol Bay watershed.

Land use changes in the lower 48 states have been major contributors to the dramatic decline of the salmon fishery in the Pacific Ocean, adding sediment and pollutants to rivers in which these fish spawn. This has led to severe restrictions on commercial and sport salmon fishing along the US west coast, with economic ripple effects through fishing communities. 

In 2014, the EPA conducted a thorough risk assessment of the potential impacts of large-scale mining on Bristol Bay's world-class commercial, recreational, and subsistence fisheries as well as on the native Alaskan peoples whose culture is strongly rooted in the fishing tradition. On the basis of this evaluation, they proposed to restrict discharge of dredged or fill material, pursuant to the Clean Water Act. 

The current Director of the EPA seeks to reverse this decision. This action would be a terrible mistake, with impacts not only to the fishery itself, but to the many fishermen (including Native Americans) and to the entire ecosystem based on salmon-derived nutrients. 

Opening the door to the Pebble Mine would be the only the beginning of a disastrous crash in the Alaskan salmon fishery and all those that depend on it. We've done this already in the lower 48 states. Let's learn from the past, and keep the July 2014 Proposed Determination in place.

Title: Comment submitted by T. Raymond
Comment:
Residents, Fishermen, Tribes, and private citizens numbering over a million have made it clear that this watershed must be protected from Development of the kind that the Pebble Partnership represents. I've fished in Bristol Bay since 1978, and have been one of the many petitioning the EPA to do it's job, and protect these pristine waters from this dangerous project. There has been endless review, scientific study, public testimony, that all point to it's being a dangerous risk to take even in the best of circumstances. It makes no sense to take these kind of risks in an area that has the largest wild sockeye salmon run in the world, is the breeding ground for countless other creatures, and is home to a rich indigenous culture, all which are rare things in this current world. 
The science doesn't support a "risk free" assessment.
The people don't support it.
And the potential economic benefits to a few workers locally, with most of the profits being taken by people outside the region, and indeed the country, who mostly couldn't point to Bristol Bay on a map, do not add up to make it worth the risk.

As a citizen, onetime Alaska resident, and lifetime fisherman, I implore the EPA to do it's job and protect this incredible resource and region from this development, and DO NOT withdraw the protections set forth under the Clean Water Act.
Thank you,
Tyone Raymond

Title: Comment submitted by C. Ryan
Comment:
Dear Administrator,

I'm writing in reference to Docket # EPA-HQ-ORD-2012-0276. Please prohibit the disposal of mine waste in Alaska's Bristol Bay watershed. The proposed Pebble Mine presents a long-term risk to the sustainability of this important fishery, and all the people and businesses that rely on it. In 2010, Bristol Bay salmon fishermen harvested 29 million sockeye salmon worth $165 million in direct harvest value alone. That represented 31% of the total Alaska salmon harvest value.

Many families rely on wild salmon as a uniquely nutritious source of protein, rich in essential omega-3 fats and vitamin D. Farmed salmon is not nutritionally identical (much lower in vitamin D, much higher in saturated fats and pro-inflammatory omega-6 fats) and poses its own environmental risks. Salmon is an important species for the health of the environment in keeping a balanced ecosystem and returning important nutrients to the ecosystem. The environmental impact is worth more than any price tag can capture. I urge the EPA to take immediate action to use existing provisions of the Clean Water Act to protect this large and irreplaceable wild salmon fishery.

Sincerely, 
Chloe Ryan
Portland, OR 97203

Do not withdraw this Clean Water Act restriction on the Pebble Deposit area of Alaska.

This watershed is extremely important for current Native Alaskan populations, and for the local fish populations. From the 2014 determination, Bristol Bay "is an area of unparalleled ecological value, boasting salmon diversity and productivity unrivaled anywhere in North America." (1) Not only is the area a draw for tourism, both for it's beauty and for recreational fishing, many important salmon species call the bay home. Adding mine tailings and slag to this watershed will irreparably harm this ecosystem. Even with certain containment practices in place, the run off from the mine and the likelihood of containment failure means heavy metals will end up in the water. We have already studies how lipophillic metals and compounds bioaccumulate into our fish, then end up in our bodies. Even if concentrations are low, people would likely become scared of fishing in that area, or eating the fish there, and it would cost the overall economy much more than any potential gain. The modest positive impact from jobs at the mine will pale in comparison to the possible loss that could occur to both fishing and travel industries.

It is extremely clear based upon the 2014 proposed determination by the EPA, even when given the chance to, neither party was able to sufficiently prove that the mining slag wouldn't harm the environment:

"Both NDM/PLP and the State of Alaska submitted information that raised scientific and technical issues, most of which had been previously raised in public comments on the Bristol Bay Assessment. However, this information did not demonstrate to the satisfaction of EPA Region 10 that no unacceptable adverse effects on fishery areas will occur should the disposal of dredged or fill material associated with mining the Pebble deposit proceed." (1) 

Read simply: Neither party submitted information able to demonstrate that no unacceptable adverse effects will occur. It is clear that withdrawing the restriction will have horrible negative impacts to the local ecosystem, water quality, fishing and tourism industries and the people living in the area. For these reasons, I urge you not to turn your back on clean water.

(1) https://www.epa.gov/sites/production/files/2014-07/documents/pebble_es_pd_071714_final.pdf
