Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I am writing you today to ask that you stand with American jobs and communities and not withdraw the Bristol Bay Proposed Determination, which it made pursuant to the Clean Water Act in 2014.

As you know, Bristol Bay, Alaska, is one of America's last great wild salmon fisheries, supplying roughly half of the world's commercial supply of wild sockeye salmon and generating more than $480 million in revenue. The tens of millions of wild salmon that return annually support upwards of 14,000 American jobs in the commercial and sport fishing industries, serve as a one-in-a-lifetime destination for anglers from around the world, and are the cultural cornerstone for the region's communities.  

These long-established American businesses and jobs are at risk from a foreign-owned mining company that wants to build the proposed Pebble Mine, which is opposed by more than 65 percent of Alaskans and more than 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents. 

In 2010, led by Alaska Native Tribes, interests including commercial fishing business owners and sportsmen asked the EPA to step in to ensure that this mine wouldn't jeopardize Bristol Bay. The EPA responded by listening to over 1.5 million Americans, hosting dozens of community meetings, reviewing Pebble's many detailed filings with state and federal agencies, and conducting a twice peer-reviewed scientific assessment of the potential impacts to the region.

Withdrawing the proposed determination ignores years of scientific research as well as the overwhelming majority of Alaskans and puts the short-term interests of a foreign mining company above thousands of American jobs.   

Please do not withdraw the proposed determination.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment submitted by M. Sparks
Comment:
EPA and Administrator Pruitt,

I am writing to voice my objection to opening up of the permitting process for the Pebble Partnership.  

My background is in fisheries science and I completed my Masters in Science working with populations of sockeye salmon from Bristol Bay. There are three main reasons why Bristol Bay salmon and the environment there should be protected, especially from an enormous open pit mine.  

The first main reason is an ecological one. Bristol Bay is perhaps the most intact, productive large-scale freshwater system in North America.  It's not difficult to see why. Tens of millions of salmon return annually bringing nutrients they've spent a lifetime accumulating in the ocean. This pulse of nutrients from the sea is the basis of a food web that spans freshwater and terrestrial environments and ranges from microscopic invertebrates to keystone species like brown bears. They key ingredient in all of this is the salmon, without them the entire ecological system would cease to exist as it has for millions of years.

The second reason for protection of Bristol Bay is an economic argument.  Bristol Bay supports one of the largest commercial fisheries in the world and is responsible for the majority of sockeye salmon taken to market in the US.  The salmon fishery and associated industries (processors, marine suppliers, boat mechanics, etc.) support 14000+ jobs annually and are responsible for a multi-hundred million dollar economy every year.  Better yet, sockeye salmon are a sustainable resource that if managed properly can support this economy in perpetuity.  Furthermore, the sockeye salmon fishery is also considered one of the most sustainable fisheries in the world. Managers are able to determine which stocks within the larger fishery appear to be preforming well on a year-to-year basis, which allows an adaptive fishery to shift efforts to stocks with the most robust returns while leaving other, less bountiful stocks with lower pressure.  It is a model system for managers and industry. Beyond the commercial fishery, sockeye salmon as the basis for a productive food web, contribute to one of the premier sport fisheries in the US, where individuals may spend up to $20,000 over ten days to fly out to, float on, and fish for salmon and trout.

The final reason for not following through with the permitting of the Pebble Project is a cultural one. For Native Alaskans in Bristol Bay, sockeye salmon have been the lifeblood for their table, culture, and spiritual ceremonies for tens of thousands of years.  We rail against the destruction of ancient artifacts and holy relics when it occurs in other nations, but the loss of these fish would amount to the loss of the foundation of culture and faith in the region.  Beyond Native Alaskans, salmon and natural productivity and beauty are defining characters of life and culture in Alaska.  It's why people move and stay there. Alaska is perhaps the most unique state in the Union, its character largely driven by places like Bristol Bay.

Finally, a few parting notes. First, this issue was largely settled until Administrator Pruitt sat down for a brief meeting with leader of the Pebble Partnership. While I understand that these actions may be in the purview of the agency, I also note that the EPA previously decided to protect the region with an uncommon regulatory option of the Clean Water Act. Supporters of the Pebble Mine pointed to this as an overreach of regulation.  But, for anyone who has known or visited Bristol Bay, such a remarkable place called for remarkable action.  I'll leave you with this note.  A major driver of the fear for a project like Pebble is that this particular industry (hard rock mining) has had very little accountability and one of the poorest track records for environmental regard.  The Berkeley Pit Mine in Butte Montana was built on the headwaters of Clark Fork River.  The mine poisoned the river and the region's residents for generations.  When the mine became unprofitable, ownership shuttered their doors, leaving Montanans to deal with the mess and Americans to pick up the check (now approaching $50 billion). This story has been repeated time and time again for mega-project open-pit mines. Even more recently, the tailings dam of the Mt. Polley mine burst on a tributary of the Fraser River in British Columbia, Canada, flooding BC's most productive sockeye salmon river with billions of gallons of toxic sludge.  Moreover, the toxic byproduct of projects like these are expected to be stored on the landscape in perpetuity.  How will the Pebble Partnership keep these toxic elements from this pristine landscape 1000 years from now when they no longer exist as a business.  Mine tailings always outlive the companies that produced them.  You have heard plenty from Alaskans and people supporting Bristol Bay protection. Please listen.

Thank you for your consideration of these comments,

Morgan Sparks, M.S.

Title: Comment submitted by Charles F. Newby President and Chief Executive Officer (CEO), Colorado Environmental Analytics, LLC
Comment:
Public Comments of Colorado Environmental Analytics, LLC

October 12, 2017

Proposed Pebble Mine
The Proposed Pebble Mine is Against the Interests of the American People, the People of Alaska, and Local AlaskansIncluding Indigenous PeopleLiving Within the Watershed of the Nushagak and Kvichak Rivers
After three years of scientifically rigorous study, the EPA released its final assessment of the proposed Pebble Mine entitled, The Effects of Large Scale Mining on the Salmon Ecosystems of the Nushagak and Kvichak Rivers, in January 2014. This EPA assessment concluded that, if proposed Pebble Mine operations were to be undertaken, "It is expected that the North Fork Koktuli River ... and much of the Koktuli River would not support salmonids [that is, all forms of salmon] in the short term (less than 10 years)." Given that the totality of the scientific evidence presented in its assessment indicates complete destruction of Salmon habitat in the watershed, under law, the EPA cannot exempt the proposed Pebble Mine from provisions of the Clean Water Act nor can the agency do anything but recommend against proposed mining operation at the Pebbles Mine.
The Bristol Bay watershed, located in southwestern Alaska, is home to 25 federally recognized tribal governments representing Alaska Native peoples who have maintained a salmon-based way of life for the last 4,000 years, at least, probably for much longer. Clearly, large-scale mining operations in the watershed proposed by the Pebbles Mine will destroy the sustainability of Bristol Bay's world-class commercial, recreational, as well as the subsistence fisheries upon which the future of Alaska Native tribes in the watershed depends. Given the potential impact on the way of life of Alaskan Native peoples, under law, the EPA cannot allow the proposed Pebbles Mine to move forward in any form.

The proposed Pebbles Mine project, with mineral rights, is controlled by Canadian, British, Australian, and Japanese corporations; therefore, little economic benefit will accrue to the United States yet the Alaskan people living within the watershed will bear a tremendous burden as their way of life is destroyed.

The Arguments Made by Pebble Mine Proponents Are Specious
Proponents of the Pebble Mine claim that the mine would provide significant tax revenue to the State of Alaska; however, no amount of tax revenue accruing from proposed mining operations can offset the costs that local, state, and federal governments would bear as the Bristol Bay watershed is destroyed.

Proponents of the Pebble Mine claim that the mine will create well-paying jobs in an increasingly poverty-stricken regionroughly 2,000 jobs for construction, dropping to 1,000 permanent jobs during the 30 to 60-year expected life span of the mine. However, the returning salmon and other ecological resources of the Bristol Bay watershed creates more than 14,000 full and part-time jobs, generates approximately $480 million annually, and supports a 4,000-year-old Alaska Native way of life.
Proponents of the Pebble Mine claim that the mine would provide a domestic resource of important raw materials thus lowering the United States reliance on foreign sources. However, because markets for these and similar raw materials are global, such claims are clearly specious. Furthermore, such a "domestic resource of raw materials" does not now exist nor will mining operations at the proposed Pebble Mine create one.

EPA Must Follow Mandates Established by Law

Environment Protection Agency Mandates Established by Law
By law, it is the mandate of the EPA to protect both the health of the American people and the environment of the United States and its territories. Protecting the American people from significant health risks requires that the EPA must develop science-based regulations that are protective of the environment, wherever people live, work, and learn. 

Assault on the Environment Protection Agency Must Stop Immediately
The Trump/Pence Administration's unnecessary assault on the EPA is against the interests of the American people in that the assault directly undermines the fundamental basis of human health; the assault promotes the continuation of the widespread pollution of critical segments of the county's environment; and, to the extent that the administration deliberately fails to uphold environmental protection law, the assault is clearly unlawful. For the reasons cited above, the Trump/Pence Administration must immediately stop its increasingly unlawful assault on the Environmental Protection Agency and its mission!

Submitted by,
Charles F. Newby
President/CEO
Colorado Environmental Analytics
Evergreen, Colorado

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
Do not withdraw the proposed determination to restrict the use of an area as a disposal site pertaining to the proposed Pebble Mine. The CWA section 404 allows the EPA to override the Corp and veto the "404 permit for dredge and fill discharge if it is having or will have an unacceptable adverse effect on municipal water supplies, shellfish beds and fishery areas (including spawning and breeding areas), wildlife, or recreational areas," (EPA).  The EPA's 3 year study of the area showed negative impacts on water from the start and it's their duty to use the 404-C veto in such large scale projects, in highly valued areas, with relatively high possibilities of catastrophic events. Have no doubt that this is a highly valued area because of both its intrinsic and economic value. Extensive studies done pertaining to the environmental externalities that would be associated with mining in the area, prove over and over that mining here is a terrible decision. Also from an economic standpoint it is stated that the mine will only provide 1,000 temporary jobs, but it will threaten 14,000 commercial fishing jobs that are a part of the local salmon fishery (Bautista). While this fishing industry will likely be wiped out as the salmon spawning grounds are poisoned from the mine and its disposal site.  
So it is the EPA's duty not to withdraw the proposed determination in this case, because the Pebble Mine needs to be stopped before it even has a chance to start due to the extensive and negative impacts it would have on human-environmental health; and the health of the commercial fishing industry.

Bautista, Kendall. Hunting, Fishing coalition urges presidential canidates to oppose Pebble Mine. News Station. Anchorage: KTUU, 2016. 3 March 2016. <http://www.ktuu.com/news/news/hunting-fishing-coalition-urges-presidential-candidates-to-oppose-pebble-mine/38198298>.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
To whom it may concern, 

I am writing to voice my opposition to withdrawing the determination to restrict the use of the Bristol Bay watershed as a disposal site. Section 404(c) of the Clean Water Act authorizes the EPA to "prohibit, restrict, or deny the use of any defined area in waters of the United States for specification as a disposal site" when "unacceptable adverse effects" are expected on municipal water supplies, shellfish beds and fishery areas (including spawning and breeding areas), wildlife, or recreational areas.

The proposed open pit mine, dug in seismically unstable marshland would pose a huge risk to one of the only self-sustaining salmon fisheries in the world. The tailings from the mine are highly toxic, and would need to be contained in perpetuity.Several years of independent study commissioned by the EPA have demonstrated that the mine itself and the infrastructure needed to support the mine jeopardize the health and stability of the Bristol Bay ecosystem. This ecosystem provides economic and subsistence support to tens of thousands of people, including thousands of Yupik, Alutiiq, and Dena'ina indigenous Alaskans who have relied upon the watershed for subsistence for hundreds of years. 

This proposed mine is extremely likely to become an environmental and economic disaster, and it is entirely appropriate for the EPA to exercise its regulatory authority to prevent such misuse of land that belongs to every American.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
Southwest Alaska's Bristol Bay watershed is a pristine ecosystem that is home to the world's largest remaining wild salmon run.  It provides habitat for 29 fish species, including all five species of Pacific salmonsockeye, Chinook, coho, chum, and pink.  In fact, the Bristol Bay watershed supports the largest sockeye salmon run in the world, producing approximately 46% of the world's wild sockeye harvest. That's the good news!

Here's the bad news, the Bristol Bay watershed is also home to the Pebble deposit, a large underground body of mineral ore.  And, the Pebble Limited Partnership, a project of Northern Dynasty Minerals Ltd, hopes to mine for copper and gold there, in the heart of the Bristol Bay watershed.  

According to the Pebble Partnership, mining the Pebble deposit could involve excavation of the largest open pit mine in North America, covering up to 6.9 square miles and reaching a depth of as much as 0.77 mile, nearly as deep as the Grand Canyon. Additionally, the EPA found that "mine components (mine pit, tailings impoundments (dams of mining debris), and waste rock piles) would cover an area larger than Manhattan..." and "require the construction of support facilities...and infrastructure...greatly expand(ing) the "footprint" of the mine and affect(ing) additional aquatic resources...losses would be irreversible."

In its 2014 404(c) Proposed Determination for Bristol Bay, the EPA wisely denied the Pebble Partnership permission to proceed pursuant to Section 404(c) of the Clean Water Act.

Turning its back on its own extensively researched, peer-reviewed, science-based Determination for Bristol Bay, in a startling reversal, the EPA now would allow the Pebble Partnership to proceed.

DO NOT DO THIS.  PRESERVE BRISTOL BAY!
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment submitted by M. Burland
Comment:
Honorable Scott Pruitt, Administrator
US Environmental Protection Agency 

Honorable Michelle L. Pirzadeh, Acting Administrator, Region 10
US Environmental Protection Agency 

RE: Bristol Bay, Alaska/Pebble Mine - Docket: EPA-R10-OW-2017-0369

Dear Administrator Pruitt and Acting Region 10 Administrator Pirzadeh:

Title: Comment submitted by D. Berray
Comment:
RE: Bristol Bay, Alaska/Pebble Mine - Docket: EPA-R10-OW-2017-0369

Dear Administrator Pruitt and Acting Region 10 Administrator Pirzadeh:

The single most consistent thing about the Trump Administration is that they put fossil fuel profits ahead of our health and our communities. WHAT DOES THE EPA STAND FOR?????? Profits or human health?

I am a supporter of Slow Food USA, the national, not-for-profit organization dedicated to a food chain that is good, clean, and fair for all.  I write to urge the US Environmental Protection Agency to protect Bristol Bay, Alaska, from the Pebble Mine that would threaten the region's irreplaceable fish and wildlife resources and the 14,000 jobs that depend on Bristol Bay's clean, healthy waters and fishery.  EPA must keep in place the 2014 Bristol Bay 404(c) Proposed Determination.

According to EPA study, the Bristol Bay watershed provides vital habitat for 29 fish species, more than 190 bird species, and more than 40 terrestrial animals. All five species of Pacific salmonsockeye, Chinook, coho, chum, and pinkspawn and rear in the pristine Bristol Bay watershed. The Bristol Bay watershed supports the largest sockeye salmon run in the world, producing approximately 46% of the world's wild sockeye harvest, creating $1.5 billion in economic output and nearly 20,000 jobs throughout the United States annually.

EPA's scientific study contains highly concerning facts about the proposed Pebble Mine: even without a mine disaster, exploitation of the Pebble deposit will destroy 94 miles of salmon streams and 5,350 acres of wetlands, lakes, and ponds. Overall, EPA concluded that mining the headwaters of the Bristol Bay river systems could cause irreparable harm to the valuable Bristol Bay fishery, wildlife, and communities.

I stand with more than 65 percent of Alaskans, 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents and Native communities, and 85 percent of commercial fishermen who oppose the Pebble Mine.  Because of its great, ecological, economic, and cultural value, I implore the EPA to stand with us by keeping in place the 404(c) Proposed Determination for Bristol Bay, Southwest Alaska.

Thank you for your attention.

Sincerely,
Dina Berray

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment: I do NOT want the EPA to withdraw the July 2014 Proposed Determination to restrict mining of the Pebble deposit. Title: Comment submitted by P. Anderson
Comment:
Dear Secretary Pruitt,
I am furious over your decision to withdraw the EPA Region 10 July 2014 Proposed Determination that was issued pursuant of
the Clean Water Act, to restrict the use of certain waters in the South Fork Koktuli River, North Fork Koktuli River, and Upper 
Talarik Creek watersheds in southwest Alaska. 
Have you ever been to this region? Do you understand the impact if the mine is approved? Do you ever get out in nature, in 
order to understand what we stand to lose? My guess is a loud "NO"!!
I live in Seattle, and have watched our salmon population dwindle steadily over the last few decades. Our orca population is
dwindling as well, with newborn calves dying in the first year of life, believed to be a result of starvation. The orca feed on 
salmon, so they are the canary in the coal mine for the health of Puget Sound, and the entire northwest. 
I implore you to reverse this decision!!
It's bad enough that the Trump administration is reversing decisions to save protected areas in places like the Grand 
Staircase Escalante in Utah. Having just spent time hiking in that region, I was appalled to learn that Trump is trying to reverse
its status and protection. Have you visited our national parks and monuments in Utah, or anywhere for that matter? Not just 
taking a photo or two, but actually getting out on the trails, seeing rare beauty that will bring you to tears?
Alaska is the last hope for preserving any truly natural, untouched, unspoiled land in our country, and indeed, our world. How 
can you possibly believe the Pebble Mining Company is more important than this? How can you risk FOREVER losing this 
place for SHORT TERM GAIN by a mining company???????
I'm astounded that someone who clearly does not even believe the EPA should exist was appointed to head the agency. I 
pray that you are all thrown out in 2020!!!!!!!
Most Sincerely,
Patricia Anderson

Dave Marler

Title: Comment submitted by A. Russell
Comment:
Honorable Scott Pruitt, Administrator
US Environmental Protection Agency 

Honorable Michelle L. Pirzadeh, Acting Administrator, Region 10
US Environmental Protection Agency 

RE: Bristol Bay, Alaska/Pebble Mine - Docket: EPA-R10-OW-2017-0369

Dear Administrator Pruitt and Acting Region 10 Administrator Pirzadeh:

I am a supporter of Slow Food USA, the national, not-for-profit organization dedicated to a food chain that is good, clean, and fair for all.  I write to urge the US Environmental Protection Agency to protect Bristol Bay, Alaska, from the Pebble Mine, which would threaten the region's irreplaceable fish and wildlife resources as well as the14,000 jobs that depend on Bristol Bay's clean, healthy waters and fishery.  In the interest of keeping Americans employed, fed, and protecting our environment's resources, the EPA must keep in place the 2014 Bristol Bay 404(c) Proposed Determination.

According to EPA study, the Bristol Bay watershed provides vital habitat for 29 fish species, more than 190 bird species, and more than 40 terrestrial animals. All five species of Pacific salmonsockeye, Chinook, coho, chum, and pinkspawn and rear in the pristine Bristol Bay watershed. The Bristol Bay watershed supports the largest sockeye salmon run in the world, producing approximately 46% of the world's wild sockeye harvest, creating $1.5 billion in economic output and nearly 20,000 jobs throughout the United States annually. A positive for American jobs as well as the 250+ species depending on that Bay.

EPA's scientific study contains highly concerning facts about the proposed Pebble Mine: even without a mine disaster, exploitation of the Pebble deposit will destroy 94 miles of salmon streams and 5,350 acres of wetlands, lakes, and ponds. Overall, EPA concluded that mining the headwaters of the Bristol Bay river systems could cause irreparable harm to the valuable Bristol Bay fishery, wildlife, and communities.

I stand with more than 65 percent of Alaskans, 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents and Native communities, and 85 percent of commercial fishermen who oppose the Pebble Mine.  Because of its great, ecological, economic, and cultural value, I implore the EPA to stand with us by keeping in place the 404(c) Proposed Determination for Bristol Bay, Southwest Alaska. Protect the environment, employ Americans, and keep the salmon running!

Thank you for your attention.

Sincerely,
Alanna Russell

Title: Comment submitted by D. M. Keenan
Comment:
To Administrator Pruitt: 

I write to register my comments on EPA's proposed action to withdraw the 2014 Proposed Determination to restrict mining in the waters of the Bristol Bay watershed, specifically the waters in the South Fork Koktuli River, North Fork Koktuli River, and Upper Talarik Creek watersheds in southwest Alaska.  I am vehemently opposed to the withdrawal of the Proposed Determination.  These watersheds must be protected from mining and specifically from the Pebble Limited Partnership proposed Pebble mine.    The EPA's determination in July 2014 was the correct decision and was based on through examination of the science, and the through vetting of the public and interested and affected parties.  The reversal of this decision would be clearly arbitrary and would ignore all the science and public comment that came before.  

The science is clear - - any mine, and especially the mine proposed for the Pebble Deposit would risk bringing irreparable harm to one of the few, if not the only, robust, expanding, salmon runs in the world.  One only has to look at the status of salmon in every other watershed of the United States, where they are meager if not on the edge of disappearing to understand the value of the salmon fishery of Bristol Bay watershed.  Bristol Bay is singularly unique in that its salmon populations are strong and are expanding due to the fact the watershed has not been impacted by activities such as mining and development.  

From an economic standpoint, reversing the Proposed Determination of 2014 is wrong.  Bristol Bay supports an American industry - - a thriving fishing industry and it provides thousands of jobs for Americans directly and indirectly and it supports countless American communities - -not only in Alaska, but in states throughout the United States.  Pebble Partnership is a company based in and run by a foreign government.  How can EPA pick to a one foreign company over an American industry? 

It appears that the only basis for a decision to reverse the 2014 Determination is political. I urge you with every fiber in my being not to withdraw the 2014 Determination.

Sincerely,

Title: Comment submitted by D. Frank
Comment:
To whom it may concern:

I am writing to implore the EPA to maintain its protections of the Pebble Deposit Area in Alaska's Bristol Bay watershed.  It is widely recognized that that area is home to the world's largest salmon fishery.  Removing the protections that are in place for that particular area threatens to destroy large portions, if not all, of that fishery.  This would have significant financial, societal and environmental costs to America and its citizens.  

Financially, the fishery supports thousands of jobs linked to salmon fishing.  Those jobs would be lost by removing the existing protections in the area.  A three-year study conducted by the EPA concluded in 2014 that the allowance of mining activities by companies like Northern Dynasty Minerals (a Canadian, not American, company) would result in a complete loss of salmon habitat in significant portions of the watershed.  What's more, the jobs created by Northern Dynasty Minerals' mining operations would be fewer than the fishing jobs that would be lost as a result of salmon habitat destruction by Northern Dynasty.  The net effect would be to reduce available jobs rather than to increase them.

From a societal standpoint, the watershed produces nearly half of the world's annual sockeye salmon catch.  Salmon is a prominent part of the American and world diet, with Americans consuming it raw in sushi/sashimi, smoked, and grilled, broiled, and baked.  A growing segment of the world's population has come to appreciate wild, rather than farm-raised, salmon.  Destruction of this fishery will significantly curtail the availability of wild salmon in grocery stores and restaurants. Most Americans, along with those who purchase our salmon will feel this loss.

From an environmental perspective it should be recognized that fisheries, like the one located at Bristol Bay, take many centuries to develop.  They cannot be easily replaced or repaired.  

Destroying our fisheries, poisoning a pristine environment, eliminating jobs, and reducing a significant portion of the world's salmon population does not Make America Great Again.  It, instead, undermines America.

Please maintain the existing protections of the Pebble Deposit Area and its salmon fishery.  

Thank you,

Doug Frank

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I am writing you today to ask that you stand with American jobs and communities and not withdraw the Bristol Bay Proposed Determination, which was made pursuant to the Clean Water Act in 2014.

As you know, Bristol Bay, Alaska, is one of America's last great wild salmon fisheries. Tens of millions of wild salmon return annually, supporting upwards of 14,000 American jobs in the commercial and sport fishing industries and attracting anglers from around the world.

These long-established American businesses and jobs are at risk from a foreign-owned mining company that wants to build the proposed Pebble Mine, which is opposed by more than 65 percent of Alaskans and more than 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents. 

In 2010, led by Alaska Native Tribes, interests including commercial fishing business owners and sportsmen asked the EPA step in to ensure that this mine wouldn't jeopardize Bristol Bay. The EPA responded by listening to over 1.5 million Americans, hosting dozens of community meetings, reviewing Pebble's many detailed filings with state and federal agencies, and conducting a twice peer-reviewed scientific assessment of the potential impacts to the region.

Withdrawing the proposed determination ignores the overwhelming majority of Alaskans and puts the short-term interests of a foreign mining company above thousands of American jobs. Please do not withdraw the proposed determination. 

Please do not withdraw the proposed determination.  Thank you.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment submitted by B. Galvez
Comment:
To whom it may concern, 

As a fisheries biologist and an avid salmon fisherman, I do not agree that a mining company should be allowed to mine nor dispose of mining waste in the Bristol Bay watershed. History shows us what mining does to the local environment and valuable fish populations. It is imperative to consider the monetary and emotional costs of the local community's recreational and commercial fisheries compared with the profit of the mining venture. The long term value of recreational and commercial salmon fisheries in Bristol Bay, Alaska most likely trump the short term profitability of a mining venture. 

Monetary and emotional values are among the most important issues the argument against the opening of mining permits in Bristol Bay. The health risks on the local human and wildlife communities and water quality degradation associated with mining waste should also be considered. No matter the manner in which these assessments are carried out, they should be done in the most calculated and scientific way possible, free of partisan politics, with the most weight put on the long term health of the local community, both financially and emotionally. I am all for economic development, but I do not think that the mining of Bristol Bay is the right way to do it. Please do not open the bay up for mining permits. 

Thank you.


Sincerely, 

Brian Galvez

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I am opposed to EPAs proposal to rescind the 2014 Proposed Determination designed to protect Bristol Bays world class fisheries. Please reconsider withdrawing these restrictions. They were put in place for a reason- to protect vital natural resources. 
Bristol Bay, Alaska, is one of America's last great wild salmon fisheries. Each year, tens of millions of wild salmon return, supporting upwards of 14,000 jobs in the commercial and sport fishing industries, and serving as a one-in-a-lifetime destination for anglers from around the world as well as the cultural cornerstone for the region's communities. You are doing the opposite of spurring the American economy by rescinding this act- in actuality, you are siding with a foreign owned mining company that wants to construct a mine opposed by the majority of Alaskans and, specifically, more than 80% of the residents of Bristol Bay.
In 2014, led by Alaska Native Tribes, interests including commercial fishing business owners and sportsmen asked the EPA step in to ensure that this mine wouldn't jeopardize Bristol Bay. The EPA responded by listening to over 1.5 million Americans, hosting dozens of community meetings, reviewing Pebble's many detailed filings with state and federal agencies, and conducting a twice peer-reviewed scientific assessment of the potential impacts to the region. Withdrawing the proposed determination ignores the overwhelming majority of Alaskans and puts the short-term interests of a foreign mining company above thousands of local jobs. 
For the sake of our country, and our future, please DO NOT allow for the destruction of such a beautiful and important ecosystem.

Title: Comment submitted by C. Riti
Comment:
Honorable Scott Pruitt, Administrator
US Environmental Protection Agency 

Honorable Michelle L. Pirzadeh, Acting Administrator, Region 10
US Environmental Protection Agency 

RE: Bristol Bay, Alaska/Pebble Mine - Docket: EPA-R10-OW-2017-0369

Dear Administrator Pruitt and Acting Region 10 Administrator Pirzadeh:

I am a supporter of Slow Food USA as well as an ardent environmentalist.  I write to urge the EPA to protect Bristol Bay, Alaska, from the Pebble Mine that would threaten the region's irreplaceable fish and wildlife resources and the 14,000 jobs that depend on Bristol Bay's clean, healthy waters and fishery.  EPA must keep in place the 2014 Bristol Bay 404(c) Proposed Determination.

EPA's scientific study contains highly concerning facts about the proposed Pebble Mine: even without a mine disaster, exploitation of the Pebble deposit will destroy 94 miles of salmon streams and 5,350 acres of wetlands, lakes, and ponds. Overall, EPA concluded that mining the headwaters of the Bristol Bay river systems could cause irreparable harm to the valuable Bristol Bay fishery, wildlife, and communities.

I stand with more than 65 percent of Alaskans, 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents and Native communities, and 85 percent of commercial fishermen who oppose the Pebble Mine.  Because of its great, ecological, economic, and cultural value, I implore the EPA to stand with us by keeping in place the 404(c) Proposed Determination for Bristol Bay, Southwest Alaska.

Thank you for your attention.

Christopher Riti

Title: Comment submitted by A. Roebker
Comment:
Dear Administrator Pruitt and Acting Region 10 Administrator Pirzadeh:

I am a college student in Ohio and a supporter of Alaskan wilderness conservation as one of the final regions of our world that has been left undeveloped by man, though, unfortunately, still not unaffected. As an advocate for the natural world that cannot advocate for itself, I write in partnership with Slow Food International to urge the US Environmental Protection Agency to protect Bristol Bay, Alaska, from the Pebble Mine that would threaten the region's irreplaceable fish and wildlife resources and the 14,000 jobs that depend on Bristol Bay's clean, healthy waters and fishery. EPA must keep in place the 2014 Bristol Bay 404(c) Proposed Determination.

According to EPA study, the Bristol Bay watershed provides vital habitat for 29 fish species, more than 190 bird species, and more than 40 terrestrial animals. All five species of Pacific salmonsockeye, Chinook, coho, chum, and pinkspawn and rear in the pristine Bristol Bay watershed. The Bristol Bay watershed supports the largest sockeye salmon run in the world, producing approximately 46% of the world's wild sockeye harvest, creating $1.5 billion in economic output and nearly 20,000 jobs throughout the United States annually.

EPA's scientific study contains highly concerning facts about the proposed Pebble Mine: even without a mine disaster, exploitation of the Pebble deposit will destroy 94 miles of salmon streams and 5,350 acres of wetlands, lakes, and ponds. Overall, EPA concluded that mining the headwaters of the Bristol Bay river systems could cause irreparable harm to the valuable Bristol Bay fishery, wildlife, and communities.

I stand with more than 65 percent of Alaskans, 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents and Native communities, and 85 percent of commercial fishermen who oppose the Pebble Mine. Because of its great, ecological, economic, and cultural value, I implore the EPA to stand with us by keeping in place the 404(c) Proposed Determination for Bristol Bay, Southwest Alaska.

Thank you for your attention.

Sincerely,
Abigail Roebker
Xavier University Class of 2018

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
The following are excerpts from a CNN column last updated 10/10/2017 and posted on Google (http://google.com/newsstand/s/CBIwtM7YpzY) "Thomas Quinn, a professor at the University of Washington who has been studying fish in Bristol Bay for 30 years.The salmon's incredible migration also sustains people: Nearly half of the world's sockeye catch comes from this one region, which is one of the last, great salmon fisheries on Earth. The returning salmon and other ecological resources create some 14,000 full- and part-time jobs, generate about $480 million annually -- and support 4,000-year-old Alaska Native cultures." I FEEL THIS PROVES SUSTAINABLE VALUE AS IS. "Such a mine "would result in complete loss of fish habitat due to elimination, dewatering, and fragmentation of streams, wetlands, and other aquatic resources" in some areas of the bay watershed, the EPA found after three years of peer-reviewed research. In particular, the EPA estimated 22 miles of streams and more than 6 square miles of wetlands and other habitats that are important to salmon and other fish would be lost to a large-scale mine." THIS IS BACKED BY SCIENCE. 
"All of these losses would be irreversible," the agency said."Under the Obama administration, people were willing to say, 'Look, it's very clear, this is exactly the worst place you could imagine building a mine of that kind," said Ray Hilborn, a professor in the School of Aquatic and Fishery Sciences at the University of Washington. "It's not just that you have the most valuable salmon fishery in the world, it's the nature of the habitat there. The reason it's such a productive salmon place is, it's basically this giant gravel bed. But that also means it's almost impossible to contain water. It's just a giant sponge. The idea you could store highly toxic waste (from a mine) forever behind a dam is just ridiculous."Tilden says he's not anti-development. His father was a gold miner from California. But after the mine was first proposed, he said, he started touring mines that had been shut down. 
He saw pools of toxic water, massive piles of waste-rock. At one mine in Nevada, he said, he was told to cover his shoes for fear he would track dust laden with heavy metals home -- and "not to have any contact with that dust with our eyes, not to touch any of the water."
Could Bristol Bay turn into a similar wasteland? He decided he didn't want to find out. 
PLEASE DO NOT DESTROY THIS HABITAT SO A FEW PEOPLE CAN GET RICH.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
"Under the Obama administration, people were willing to say, 'Look, it's very clear, this is exactly the worst place you could imagine building a mine of that kind," said Ray Hilborn, a professor in the School of Aquatic and Fishery Sciences at the University of Washington. "It's not just that you have the most valuable salmon fishery in the world, it's the nature of the habitat there. The reason it's such a productive salmon place is, it's basically this giant gravel bed. But that also means it's almost impossible to contain water. It's just a giant sponge. The idea you could store highly toxic waste (from a mine) forever behind a dam is just ridiculous." FROM CNN

The proposal is ridiculous, it will effect the entire pacific's salmon populations and people's ability to earn a living, not if toxic waste is released into the water shed, but when it is released. I remember in the not too distant past a dam that was supposed to be safe did rupture and release toxic waste into a watershed. That was in Colorado.

DO NOT CHANGE THE LAW=PROTECT THE SALMON

Title: Comment submitted by T. M. Jahnke
Comment:
The EPA should proceed with its Proposed Determination (PD) under Clean Water Act Section 404(c) to protect the Bristol Bay Watershed. While mining can be and often is an economic good, large scale mining operations should not be allowed in the Bristol Bay watershed. 

The EPA conducted a thorough, multi-year scientific investigation of the Bristol Bay Watershed and potential impacts of the proposal(s) by Northern Dynasty to mine the Pebble Deposit.  Based on the projected impacts of a mine far smaller than those proposed by Northern Dynasty, EPA concluded that mining operations would cause losses of streams and wetlands and contamination of the land and water to the detriment of 29 species of fish, 40 terrestrial mammals, and 190 species of birds.  The magnitude of the projected environmental impacts is well documented in EPA's peer-reviewed report, and these impacts would be irreversible. The largest sockeye salmon fishery in the world could be destroyed forever, and the livelihood of those that depend on the salmon could also be destroyed.  EPA should move forward on this PD because it already followed an extensive public process on this matter; it would be a complete waste of government resources to ignore the existing scientific work and its conclusions and begin a new project review process.

The EPA provided opportunities for public comment on two draft scientific assessments, which generated hundreds of thousands of comments. The current proposal to withdraw the PD is wasteful and abusive of the Agency's procedures and its resources.  The EPA followed the Clean Water Act and its procedures.  In fact, EPA went above and beyond the required procedures and offered two draft reports for public comment prior to publishing its final assessment.  Administrator Pruitt, as reported in several newspapers, concluded that the PD should be withdrawn based on meetings with advocates for the Pebble Mine, but the Administrator has offered no information or evidence as to why the existing scientific assessment is flawed. The process to date - with EPA's publication of the Final Bristol Bay Assessment in January 2014 -- was a scientifically valid and legally sound process and compliant with the Clean Water Act. The existing EPA assessment is a thorough and compelling basis for moving forward with the Clean Water Act 404(c) protections.
 
Thank you for consideration of these comments.

Thomas M. Jahnke,
Retired Alaska Superior Court Judge
Retired Assistant Regional Counsel
EPA Region 10
Seattle, Washington

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
Docket ID No. EPA-R10-OW-2017-0369
I adamantly object to withdrawal of the July 2014 Proposal to withdraw the Proposed Determination to restrict the Use of waters in the South Fork Koktuli River, North Fork Koktuli River and Upper Talarik Creek watersheds as mine disposal sites.  To allow these headwaters to be filled with mine rubble  would be in violation of the Clean water Act.   The EPA, by law, is obligated to enforce the Clean Water Act in all Federal Waterways.  It is also charged to protect public health and the environment from water pollution.  Mining in this watershed threatens health and the environment.   

Mining in this watershed threaten protected and scarce environments.   Toxic contamination will bioaccumulate in fish species that are consumed by the area's population and also world wide.

Years ago, with our young family, we kayaked and watched salmon swimming up a small Alaskan Creek.  Nothing has ever represented the grace of nature better than that sight.   The headwaters being threatened by your action support the richest Salmon habitat in Alaska.  Don't put it at risk.

Title: Comment submitted by A. Fuller
Comment:
Dear Mr. Pruitt,

I am writing to express my concern for the Bristol Bay watershed. As someone gravely concerned with ecology, 

The Copper River in late August is full with swarms of spawning red salmon. Everything that lives in the Bristol Bay watershed is derived from and directly dependent on these salmon, including the region's native people, who are as dependent on the fish returning to the rivers in July as they are on the sun rising in the morning.

After review of the executive summary,  I understand that quite literally skinning and gutting an entire watershed, dredging the river deltas and then dumping toxic ore derivatives into the sea will send the salmon and everything that depends on them into virtual free fall. This is what will happen if we proceed. But again, we are dangerously blind to the real fallout, the byproduct if you will of the extermination of another entire ecosystem.

Mr. Pruitt, by allowing passage of this proposal, just like your predecessors, with all that affords us a stable, liveable climate.  If you drop the proposal and let the fish maintain their ancient stabilizing role in the vast circuitry of ocean, stream and atmosphere, you will be affording humankind the most effective insurance policy imaginable in a time of great uncertainty. Please note that I am voicing my desire as a concerned citizen of the United States to protect this watershed and restrict the use of this area for mining or as a disposal site.

Sincerely, 

Abigail Fuller

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I am opposed to withdrawing (docket EPA-R10-OW-2017-0369) the July 2014 Clean Water Act Proposed Determination because it will result in weakened protections for salmon and Alaskan jobs. Please put American jobs over mining interests and preserve the Bristol Bay Proposed Determination.
 
Bristol Bay, Alaska is one of our last great wild salmon fisheries. Tens of millions of wild salmon return annually, which support upwards of 14,000 American jobs in the commercial and sport fishing industries, serve as a once-in-a-lifetime destination for anglers from around the world, and are the cultural cornerstone for the region's communities.

These long-established American businesses and jobs are at risk from a Canadian mining company that wants to build the proposed Pebble Mine. Although Alaskans typically support resource development, more than 65 percent of Alaskans and more than 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents oppose the proposed Pebble Mine. If built, the Pebble Mine would be many times larger than America's current largest open-pit mine and require several large earthen dams to hold back billions of tons of mine waste. This waste would require perpetual remediation and be forever at the headwaters of two of the most productive salmon rivers in the world.

In 2010, frustrated with ineffective and inadequate options for addressing the proposed mine at the local level, Alaska Native Tribes, commercial fishing business owners and sportsmen asked EPA step in to ensure that this mine wouldn't jeopardize local communities, American jobs, and the region's thriving economy and culture.

The EPA responded by hosting dozens of community meetings, reviewing Pebble's many detailed filings with state and federal agencies, and conducting a twice peer-reviewed scientific assessment of the potential impacts to the region. After years of review and input from Americans, the EPA determined that a large mine of the type and scale contemplated by Pebble would have unacceptable adverse effects on the fish, recreation, and communities in the area, and based on this information proposed several restrictions that any mining in the Pebble area would have to meet.

Over the course of the EPA's own comment and public review processes, the EPA received more than 1.5 million comments asking for strong protections for Bristol Bay. Withdrawing the proposed determination would fly in the face of an overwhelming majority of Alaskans and put the short-term interests of a Canadian mining company above thousands of American jobs.  

Alaskans asked for state-level protections as well as the EPA's involvement and for up-front protections for Bristol Bay's jobs and fisheries. Please do not trade American businesses and jobs and our wild salmon for the shallow promises of a mining company. I am writing today to ask that you stand with American jobs and communities and not withdraw the Proposed Determination.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment submitted by C. Quinonez
Comment:
Honorable Scott Pruitt, Administrator
US Environmental Protection Agency 

Honorable Michelle L. Pirzadeh, Acting Administrator, Region 10
US Environmental Protection Agency 

RE: Bristol Bay, Alaska/Pebble Mine - Docket: EPA-R10-OW-2017-0369

Dear Administrator Pruitt and Acting Region 10 Administrator Pirzadeh:

I am a Healthcare chef and Food Service Manager, as well as a Slow Food USA supporter, dedicated to a food chain that is good, clean, and fair for all, providing food that meets the nutritional requirements for a healthy America.  I write to urge the US Environmental Protection Agency to protect Bristol Bay, Alaska, from the Pebble Mine that would threaten the region's irreplaceable fish and wildlife resources and the 14,000 jobs that depend on Bristol Bay's clean, healthy waters and fishery.  EPA must keep in place the 2014 Bristol Bay 404(c) Proposed Determination.

At a time when the USDA and FDA are reporting on the need for and benefits of increased seafood consumption in the US -- seafood that is SAFE and SUSTAINABLE, meaning US seafood (not imported) -- destroying any national treasure of local seafood is insane, especially one as important as Bristol Bay. 

According to EPA study, the Bristol Bay watershed provides vital habitat for 29 fish species, more than 190 bird species, and more than 40 terrestrial animals. All five species of Pacific salmonsockeye, Chinook, coho, chum, and pinkspawn and rear in the pristine Bristol Bay watershed. The Bristol Bay watershed supports the largest sockeye salmon run in the world, producing approximately 46% of the world's wild sockeye harvest, creating $1.5 billion in economic output and nearly 20,000 jobs throughout the United States annually.

EPA's scientific study contains highly concerning facts about the proposed Pebble Mine: even without a mine disaster, exploitation of the Pebble deposit will destroy 94 miles of salmon streams and 5,350 acres of wetlands, lakes, and ponds. Overall, EPA concluded that mining the headwaters of the Bristol Bay river systems could cause irreparable harm to the valuable Bristol Bay fishery, wildlife, and communities.

I stand with more than 65 percent of Alaskans, 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents and Native communities, and 85 percent of commercial fishermen who oppose the Pebble Mine.  I stand with the USDA and FDA in being a proponent of increased US safe and sustainable seafood consumption for a healthy America, which is impossible without the protection of domestic seafood sources like Bristol Bay. Because of its great, ecological, economic, and cultural value, and importance for the health and well-being of  all Americans, I implore the EPA to stand with us by keeping in place the 404(c) Proposed Determination for Bristol Bay, Southwest Alaska.

Thank you for your attention.

Sincerely,

Cynthia Fuller Quinonez,
Food Service Manager & Chef,
Paradise Valley Hospital
National City, CA

Title: Comment submitted by S. Pyhala
Comment:
The Pebble Mine Partnership is looking to develop an open pit mine with an earthen tailings and waste water dam at the site where overs 56 million sockeye salmon return to spawn annually.  These fish are responsible for over 14,000 jobs and over $480 million dollars of annual revenues into the state of Alaska. Permitting the Pebble Mine would open this region up to mass devastation.  The  Alaska division of geologic and geophysical surveys report from 2003 states that the region associated with the pebble mine has an 11 to 37% probability of a 7.7 to 8.2 seismic event in the near future.  Such an event in this highly vulcanized region that is susceptible to volcanogenic tsunami's and floods would easily destroy on earthen dam.  Such a failure would result in the complete loss of any fish habitat that remains.  It is known that the proposed mine will destroy one of the largest wild runs of socket salmon in the world, and would take with it 22 miles of critical river habitat, and over 6 mi. of wetlands.  The trade off would be more than any amount of heavy metal pulled from the ground could replace or warrant. There would be no way to return this majestic region to its original state. Please remember the loss of 14,000 annual, reliable, jobs, to allow for 3,000-5,000 temporary jobs promised in order to pull the copper, gold, and silver from this pristine region of Alaska is unjustified. The lives of current and future Alaskans can be sustained, along with millions of people worldwide, on this existing renewable food resource known as wild sockeye salmon.  I urge you to say "NO!" to the Pebble Partnership, say "NO!" to the Pebble Mine, over 85% of Alaskans will thank you. 
Thank you,

Dr. Sarah Pyhala

Title: Comment submitted by N. Faust
Comment:
RE:  EPA-R10-OW-2017-0369

The EPA decision regarding the Pebble Mine should stand!   Alaska depends on its fishery jobs and the salmon resources of our state's waters. Do not withdraw the Bristol Bay Proposed Determination, which was made under our Clean Water Act.

Bristol Bay, Alaska, is one of America's and the world's last great wild salmon runs. The annual runs of millions of salmon, support a large number of commercial and sport fishing jobs that keep thousands of Americans and Alaskans employed.  For Alaskans they are an important subsistence resource, for indigenous cultures salmon is a keystone, and for visitors from all over who come to Alaska, it is an amazing experience to still be able to catch salmon.

These are jobs fueled by an important renewable, valuable food resource. We should not risk this resource that can endure into the future to a foreign-owned mining company.  The people of Alaska, roughly 65%, do not support the proposed Pebble Mine.  We support our present and future by taking care of our salmon.

The EPA has done the right thing by making a decision protects Bristol Bay.  This was not an arbitrary decision. They followed the rigorous procedures for public comment, participation, and hearings.  The public responded with over a million and a half responses on this topic.

Please listen to the Alaskans and our fellow citizens in other states who support the EPA decision.

Please do not withdraw the proposed determination.

Nina Faust
P.O. Box 2994 
Homer AK 99603

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I am the daughter of a fisherman and grew up in the waters of Southeast Alaska where my family made our livelihood catching salmon. Growing up in that lifestyle, and continuing to work in commercial fishing has shaped my life in more ways than I can tell here. I frequently talk with people from my fishing community about the shape and meaning, beyond just the obvious economic platform, that salmon have given our lives. 

Fishing for salmon is more than just a economic option. It is a culture, a family tie, a connection to the world, to seasons, to patterns greater than ourselves. When society make decisions, time and time again, that value finite commodities over the reoccurring abundance of wild fish, we cut ourselves off from a gift that has been passed down from generation to generation for thousands and thousands of years. Salmon inform our identity, keep food on our tables, give us social cohesion, send us to school, put roofs over our heads, define our years and keep us participating with this dynamic, changing planet. 

The pursuit of gold and copper, and in particular, the pursuits of the Canadian mining industry, has a TERRIBLE track record all over the globe. Displacement, complete destruction of the environment and the eradication of cultural, regional and familial knowledge and self-determination all have been done at the behest of Canadian-owned mining corporations.

To let one of those companies, proposing one of the largest open-pit mining operations the world has ever seen, to get ever closer to setting up shop upstream of the world's last great Sockeye Salmon resource, is unforgivable. 

Open-pit mining and Salmon habitat do not, have not coexisted with success. We have no examples of success. We do have, however, direct experience with failure-with damage, loss or complete eradication of Salmon habitat and of Salmon. 

DO NOT withdraw the Proposed Determination to Restrict the Use of an Area as a Disposal Site for the Pebble Mine. 
To do so would take us all one step closer to killing one of the last great Salmon places on the planet. We have an obligation to ensure that Salmon exist for the security of future generations. 

With basic, thoughtful protections Salmon can last as a source of wealth, nutrition, knowledge and security for generations and generations to come. Mining gold/copper/molybdenum will be a source of wealth for a select few, for a few decades with a mass of toxic wastes that will LAST FOREVER. 

DO NOT withdraw the Proposed Determination to Restrict the Use of an Area as a Disposal Site for the Pebble Mine.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment submitted by J. Yokoyama
Comment:
My name is Jane Yokoyama and I was a resident of Alaska for almost 40 years.  When I left Alaska in 2014, I was relieved to know that many of the major investors had withdrawn from Pebble Mine and it seemed the area was safe from mining.

Part of my time in Alaska was spent in Bethel and there was a threat of a large scale gold mine in the area and that was successfully challenged.  The threat the gold mine would have had to the salmon rich waters was understood. Salmon is such lifeblood to areas such as the Yukon-Kuskokwim Delta and Bristol Bay.  Salmon fishing, both subsistence and commercial have been and will continue to be a valuable industry and food source for Native Alaskans as well as the world.  There is also the deep cultural significance of salmon to the Yu'pik - just as the bowhead whale is to the Inupiat.

I do not understand why Pebble Mine is back on the table.  There is too much at stake to potentially destroy this important watershed.  The fisheries are productive and will benefit the communities and the world for hundreds of years to come.  Not only do the fisheries provide food and jobs, there are also the monies to the state and private business from recreation and tourism.  Also, think about the potential threat to fresh, clean water if a mine of this scale were to contaminate the local area.

Your own agencies, as well as others have stated that mining in Bristol Bay, especially on the scale of Pebble Mine, poses an unacceptable risk on salmon, clean water, and the local economy. Disasters such as the Mount Polley tailings dam spill serve as a cautionary tale of what irreversible damage can happen if such mining is allowed to occur. The fact that Northern Dynasty, one of the few remaining backers of this mine, has very little experience designing large-scale mines is quite alarming.

The data I have seen shows that large-scale mining has the potential to cause irreversible damage to the ecosystem in the Bristol Bay watershed. That is not a risk worth taking. As someone who has lived in Alaska and in a rural community, I know the importance of local resources to the area, both its subsistence and cultural value.  As a secondary science teacher, I want to model the importance of looking at the evidence and speaking out when policies are proposed go against that evidence.  In good conscience, I must speak out on this proposed determination to withdraw the restrictions on mining in Bristol Bay.  One cannot be complacent nor look at short-term profits, when it comes to the health of our world.

I urge you to keep the proposed Bristol Bay 404(c) in place.

Title: Comment submitted by S. Moore
Comment:
To:  Honorable Scott Pruitt, Administrator
US Environmental Protection Agency 

Honorable Michelle L. Pirzadeh, Acting Administrator, Region 10
US Environmental Protection Agency 

RE: Bristol Bay, Alaska/Pebble Mine - Docket: EPA-R10-OW-2017-0369

Dear Administrator Pruitt and Acting Region 10 Administrator Pirzadeh:

I am opposed to the EPA's decision to withdraw protection of the Bristol Bay Fishery in favor of a planned Pebble Copper and Gold Mine.  Home to the largest sockeye salmon fishery in the world, with approximately 46% of the average global stock of wild sockeye salmon, it is crucial to preserve this dynamic ecosystem for the preservation of salmon, as well as for environmental protection.  

The EPA's Watershed Assessment clearly indicated that the requirements of the Clean Water Act need to be invoked in order to protect this precious resource, the Bristol Bay.   This ecosystem of rivers and wetlands and an abundant and sustainable salmon fishery supports local tribal communities, fisherman, and a vibrant seafood system.

The company that will benefit the most from the ability to mine Copper and Gold in Bristol Bay have already held up this decision in the courts.  Please have the courage to require the Pebble Mine developers to comply with restrictions that will protect this large and valuable natural resource by limiting the discharge of dredged or fill material.

Sincerely,
Sandra Moore
8006 Takoma Avenue
Silver Spring, Maryland 20910
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
Fish are some of the few remaining wild foods that we eat. When properly managed, wild fish populations provide a sustainable source of food to Americans, and fisheries provide jobs for fishers, processors, and managers. Wild Alaskan sockeye salmon is not only one of the most economically valuable stocks we have in the US (an average of $152 million per year, over the last three years[1]), it is essential to the cultural wellbeing of fishermen and native people in the US. The pristine spawning habitat in Bristol Bay, and the diversity of habitat available, allows this stock to reproduce and remain resilient to environmental conditions [2,3]. Scientific evidence that mining activities would damage this habitat and harm salmon populations is overwhelming [4]. The EPA itself has already evaluated the risks associated with building the pebble mine, finding that habitat loss for salmonids would be unavoidable [5].

In evaluating risk, scientists weigh the potential seriousness of negative impacts against the possibility that those negative impacts will occur. Here, we must also weigh impacts against the potential positive outcomes of a mine: these, however are limited to a short-term economic benefit. Sustainable jobs like salmon fishing and processing may result in less short-term growth, but will provide more consistently for more local people. 

Even if the Pebble mine is smaller and "cleaner" than its original plan, there will also be a nonzero probability that some unplanned problem will occur. The potential long-term ecological and economic risks of mining in Bristol Bay are too high to risk any permitting whatsoever. Allowing the Pebble mine to build anything will also set a precedent for the several other mining companies interested in mining in the same area, and the impacts of multiple mining sites are likely to be cumulative [4]. 

One can always cast doubt on the certainty of scientific evidence. The only irrevocable evidence we would have in this scenario would be an absence of sockeye after the construction of a mine, and by that point it would be too late. Just as we concern ourselves with the security of our people, so must we concern ourselves with the security of our ecosystems and our fisheries. Building an extractive mine in the middle of a fragile, wild ecosystem- one which already provides incredibly valuable natural resources- would be an unforgivable mistake.

[1] Sands, T., T. Elison, P. Salomone, and M. Jones. 2015. Overview of the Bristol Bay salmon fishery, 2013-2015, a
report to the Alaska Board of Fisheries. Alaska Department of Fish and Game, Special Publication No.
15-17, Anchorage.
[2] Waples, R., Beechie, T. and Pess, G. (2009) Evolutionary History, Habitat Disturbance Regimes, and Anthropogenic Changes: What Do These Mean for Resilience of Pacific Salmon Populations? Ecology and Society 14.
[3] Schindler, D.E., Hilborn, R., Chasco, B., Boatright, C.P., Quinn, T.P., Rogers, L.A. and Webster, M.S. (2010) Population diversity and the portfolio effect in an exploited species. Nature 465, 609-612.
[4] McCluney, K.E., Poff, N.L., Palmer, M.A., et al. (2014) Riverine macrosystems ecology: sensitivity, resistance, and resilience of whole river basins with human alterations. Frontiers in Ecology and the Environment 12, 48-58.
[5] USEPA (U.S. Environmental Protection Agency). 2014. An Assessment of Potential
Mining Impacts on Salmon Ecosystems of Bristol Bay, Alaska. Region 10, Seattle, WA. EPA 910-R-14-001.

Title: Comment submitted by C. Vitton
Comment:
To Whom it May Concern:

I strongly support the EPA's WITHDRAWAL of the Proposed Determination against the Pebble Mine Project. 

Pebble Limited Partnership (PLP) has invested $750M+ in good faith. They have followed the law and consistently tried to meet their many regulatory, legal and environmental obligations to the region and the State of Alaska to the highest standards asked and required of them. It is now EPA's turn to also follow the law and act in good faith.

The Pebble Project is on State of Alaska land designated for mineral exploration and development and that land has been the subject of at least two democratically approved land-use assessments by the state which have reinforced and informed PLP's right to invest in, and advance the project.

If the United States prides itself on being governed by the "rule of law", then it is imperative that this project be properly evaluated on the basis of the whole record using the legislatively mandated permitting process under the National Environmental Policy Act. During NEPA an Environmental Impact Statement must be completed and this EIS will properly assess all of the impacts that the proposed project may have. It is important to remember three things: 

First, during the legally-mandated permitting process no harm will come to the environment. 

Second, PLP is only asking for the right to prove that their project deserves a permit, not a guarantee that it will be granted. PLP knows that there is a due-process and that they must perform to the well-established standards of the process or they risk failure in their effort to secure the right to proceed. 

Third, as part of the permitting process PLP must prove that it can mitigate whatever impacts its project may have on wetlands and fish habitat. PLP claims that they can indeed mitigate their impacts. The only proper "rule-of-law" framework in which to properly assess the validity of their claims is the proven, legally mandated, NEPA process. 

Again, Pebble Partnership is not asking for a predetermination in their favor but an assurance that there will be a fair and transparent vetting of the whole record to evaluate the prospective project based on its merits as governed by the legally mandated NEPA process. For EPA to preemptively deny PLP this legal right to exhaustively make its case, is a clear violation of the principals of fairness, rule-of-law and due process. 

I appreciate the opportunity to comment on this proposal.

Finally,  The US government should be thinking long term about securing domestic sources of raw materials that will be important for clean energy technologies.  Battery technology is going to change the world and allow for cleaner sources of power production.  Mines like Pebble are going to be needed for a cleaner environment.
Sincerely,
Chuck Vitton.

Hello,

This is one of the worlds LARGEST salmon runs and by taking away restrictions for the Pebble Mine in Bristol Bay it will negatively affect the already endangered salmon species. 2017 has been the lowest recorded numbers of wild salmon population EVER in history. When the salmon completely disappear it will wreak havoc on an already delicate ecosystem. The wild salmon remain one of the most important factors in the ecosystem of of the North Pacific. With a loss of salmon means a loss of whales, a loss of algae (which feeds other animals and produces oxygen and filters CO2 in the atmosphere), a loss of nutrients in our rivers our soils and thousands of other intricate webs of the food chain. This will directly affect humans and directly affect global warning. It is your responsibility as the EPA to PROTECT THE ENVIRONMENT, not to destroy it. Take accountability for the planet, humans and all life on this planet. DO NOT WITHDRAW FROM THIS CRUCIAL CLEAN WATER ACT RESTRICTIONS. If you do you can't call yourself an "Environmental Protection Agency".

Title: Comment submitted by P. Schroeder
Comment:
Honorable Scott Pruitt, Administrator
US Environmental Protection Agency 

Honorable Michelle L. Pirzadeh, Acting Administrator, Region 10
US Environmental Protection Agency 

RE: Bristol Bay, Alaska/Pebble Mine - Docket: EPA-R10-OW-2017-0369

Dear Administrator Pruitt and Acting Region 10 Administrator Pirzadeh:

I have just been informed about the potential to destroy important fish habitat in Alaska.  We have responsibility for the sustainability of wildlife, and I would think that would go without saying in this case since fisheries are important food sources.

I am a supporter of Slow Food USA, the national, not-for-profit organization dedicated to a food chain that is good, clean, and fair for all.  I urge the US Environmental Protection Agency to protect Bristol Bay, Alaska, from the Pebble Mine that would threaten the region's irreplaceable fish and wildlife resources and the 14,000 jobs that depend on Bristol Bay's clean, healthy waters and fishery.  EPA must keep in place the 2014 Bristol Bay 404(c) Proposed Determination.

According to EPA study, the Bristol Bay watershed provides vital habitat for 29 fish species, more than 190 bird species, and more than 40 terrestrial animals. All five species of Pacific salmonsockeye, Chinook, coho, chum, and pinkspawn and rear in the pristine Bristol Bay watershed. The Bristol Bay watershed supports the largest sockeye salmon run in the world, producing approximately 46% of the world's wild sockeye harvest, creating $1.5 billion in economic output and nearly 20,000 jobs throughout the United States annually.

EPA's scientific study contains highly concerning facts about the proposed Pebble Mine: even without a mine disaster, exploitation of the Pebble deposit will destroy 94 miles of salmon streams and 5,350 acres of wetlands, lakes, and ponds. Overall, EPA concluded that mining the headwaters of the Bristol Bay river systems could cause irreparable harm to the valuable Bristol Bay fishery, wildlife, and communities.  We can see in many places the effects of mining operations.  Remediation can be done, but the wildlife destroyed is gone.

I stand with more than 65 percent of Alaskans, 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents and Native communities, and 85 percent of commercial fishermen who oppose the Pebble Mine.  Because of its great, ecological, economic, and cultural value, I implore the EPA to stand with us by keeping in place the 404(c) Proposed Determination for Bristol Bay, Southwest Alaska.

Thank you for your attention.

Sincerely,

Pat Schroeder
Shawnee, KS

Comment:

I am opposed to EPA's proposal to rescind the 2014 Proposed Determination designed to save Bristol Bay's world class fisheries. Please stand with American jobs and communities and preserve the Bristol Bay Proposed Determination.
As you know, Bristol Bay, Alaska, is one of America's last great wild salmon fisheries. Over the course of the EPA's own comment and public review processes, the EPA received more than 1.5 million comments asking for strong protections for Bristol Bay. Withdrawing the proposed determination would fly in the face of an overwhelming majority of Alaskans and put the short-term interests of a foreign mining company above thousands of American jobs. 
Today I ask that you stand with American jobs and communities and not withdraw the proposed determination. Please do not trade American businesses and jobs or our wild salmon for the shallow promises of a foreign mining company.
Sincerely,

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
As a concerned citizen with a good understanding of the EPA's purpose, I know that the EPA must work to protect the invaluable natural resources of Bristol Bay. To protect the Bristol Bay Watershed, the EPA should move forward with its Proposed Determination (PD) under Clean Water Act. Although mining is necessary to support our modern way of life, large-scale mining operations should not be located in the sensitive and unique ecosystems of Bristol Bay. There are two crucial reasons for this:

One, the EPA should act based on the scientific information that it has gathered to support this PD.

The EPA conducted a thorough science-based investigation of the Bristol Bay Watershed and potential impacts from the minig proposals by Northern Dynasty. Based on the projected impacts of a mine far smaller than those proposed to the company's investors, EPA concluded that mining operations would cause unacceptable adverse effects on fish and animal habitats in the Bristol Bay Watershed. There are 29 species of fish, 40 terrestrial mammals and 190 species of birds that would be impacted; in addition to the losses of streams and wetlands and the contamination of the land and water. The magnitude of the projected environmental impacts are well documented in EPA's peer-reviewed report, and these losses will be irreversible. The largest sockeye salmon fishery in the world will be destroyed forever, and the livelihood of those who depend on the salmon will also be destroyed.

Two, EPA should move forward on this PD because it already followed an extensive public process on this matter, and it is a waste of government resources to ignore the existing scientific work and its conclusions and to begin a new project review process.

EPA provided opportunities for public comment on two draft scientific assessments, which generated many hundreds of thousands of comments. The current proposed to withdraw the PD is a waste of public resources, a fraud, and blatant abuse of the Agency's procedures. The EPA followed the Clean Water Act and its procedures. In fact, EPA went above and beyond the required procedures and offered two draft reports for public comment prior to publishing its final assessment. Administrator Pruitt, as reported in several newspapers, concluded that the PD should be withdrawn after meeting with advocates for the Pebble Mine. The Administrator has provided no information or evidence as to why the existing scientific assessment is flawed; in fact, to the contrary, the Administration states that the mining companies should have an opportunity to submit proposals and conduct environmental impact statements and as such, a fair process for moving forward. The process to date - with EPA's publication of the Final Bristol Bay Assessment in January 2014 -- was a fair process and compliant with the Clean Water Act.
The existing EPA assessment is a thorough and legitimate basis for moving forward with the Clean Water Act protections.

Thank you for consideration of these comments.
P.S. Regulations.gov is not compatible with the Google Chrome browser. I recommend updating this, in order to provide easier access for people who use that browser to participate in the public process.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I am opposed to EPAs proposal to rescind the 2014 Proposed Determination designed to protect Bristol Bays world class fisheries. Please stand with American jobs and communities and preserve the Bristol Bay Proposed Determination.

Bristol Bay, Alaska, is one of America's last great wild salmon fisheries. Each year, tens of millions of wild salmon return, supporting upwards of 14,000 jobs in the commercial and sport fishing industries, and serving as a one-in-a-lifetime destination for anglers from around the world as well as the cultural cornerstone for the region's communities. These long-established businesses are at risk from a foreign-owned mining company that wants to build the proposed Pebble Mine, which is opposed by more than 65 percent of Alaskans and more than 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents. 

In 2014, led by Alaska Native Tribes, interests including commercial fishing business owners and sportsmen asked the EPA step in to ensure that this mine wouldn't jeopardize Bristol Bay. The EPA responded by listening to over 1.5 million Americans, hosting dozens of community meetings, reviewing Pebble's many detailed filings with state and federal agencies, and conducting a twice peer-reviewed scientific assessment of the potential impacts to the region. Withdrawing the proposed determination ignores the overwhelming majority of Alaskans and puts the short-term interests of a foreign mining company above thousands of local jobs. 

For the sake of our wildlife, waterways, and communities, I urge you to protect Bristol Bay and prevent this horrible open-pit mine from destroying one of our nation's most precious ecosystems.

You will be usurping the very civic engagement process that you claim did not occur for the National Monument you are proposing to reduce or delete. Also a short term, extreme bad judgement call on your part. Remember that you work for rhe good of the American public, not large corporations.

If you allow this travesty to occur, future generations will curse your name...
