Title: Comment submitted by J. Baldock
Comment:
As a fisheries biologist that works in and around the Bristol Bay watershed, I wholeheartedly agree with the findings from both my colleagues and the EPA that mining in the watershed would pose an unacceptable risk to an ecosystem that has sustained untold generations of both human and animal communities. Pebble Mine would produce small and short-term payouts to local communities while threatening the land on which they have subsisted for thousands of years. This past year, more than 56 million sockeye salmon returned to rivers within the Bristol Bay, the fourth largest escapement on record. Similarly, commercial harvest was also the fourth greatest on record. The Bristol Bay salmon fishery is the most valuable salmon fishery in the world. Salmon runs in other parts of the world (such as British Columbia, Washington state, Oregon, and California) have been decimated by human activities, often from mining operations. Any mis-step by Pebble could irreversibly shift the Naknek-Kvichak system and the larger Bristol Bay area into a state resembling these other areas, destroying commercial and recreational fishing opportunities, subsistence livelihoods, and the animal communities that are intricately tied to a pristine landscape. Do not allow Pebble Mine to operate. The associated risks far exceed the benefits. Bristol Bay is one of the last untouched wildernesses on the planet. Please do not ruin such a precious area. 

Jeff Baldock
Fisheries Biologist
Alaska Salmon Program
University of Washington, Seattle, WA

Title: Comment submitted by J. Mosseri
Comment:
"To Whom it May Concern:

I support the EPA's withdrawal of the Proposed Determination of the Pebble Mine Project. In a nation that is governed by the "rule of law", it is imperative that this project be properly evaluated using the legislatively mandated permitting process under NEPA, which will allow "all"  impacts of the proposed project, both pro and con, to be fully vetted. What the Pebble Partnership is asking for is very simple. They are not asking for a predetermination in their favor but assurances that there will be a fair and transparent process to evaluate the prospective project based on the merits as governed by the NEPA process. The Partnership is very aware that after presenting their evidence they may or may not ultimately receive a permit. However, to preemptively deny the Pebble Partnership the ability to present the data and analysis they have exhaustively collected violates the due process clause of the Constitution and in my mind is tantamount to a "taking".

I appreciate the opportunity to comment on this proposal.

Sincerely,"

Jeffrey N. Mosseri

Email: jgmosseri@yahoo.com

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
Goodmorning Whomever it may Concern.

I am commenting not because I am going to be affected directly, but because something needs to change. Every week for the past six months I have been living in fear of what this beautiful world is going to lose next. How much environment do we as the United States have to lose before we quit? Well I am taking a stand today, along with millions of other Americans that actually care about nature and what our future holds and how our children run the risk of not seeing nature as we did. I began speaking out when our National Parks were going to take a hit and I am not about to stop. And you should not stop either. This is not about money or revenue, nature is about beauty and awe. We need to conserve that because if we do not, nobody will. If nobody will, it will be gone. So, for the sake of the living earth that seems to always get the short end of the stick, take a stand and stop the mining.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
October 17, 2017

EPA Proposed Determination to Restrict Use of Area as Disposal Site: Pebble Deposit Area, Southwest Alaska; Proposed Withdrawal  ID: EPA-R10-OW-2017-0369-0001

I support the withdrawal, I say no to mining in the Bristol Bay headwaters.  The watershed is home to the world's largest wild sockeye salmon fishery.  I am a consumer of wild sockeye salmon.  I don't want this fishery ruined.  Human forces, whether it be over-fishing or climate change have practically destroyed the Atlantic Salmon fishery.  This fishery supports 50% of the world's commercial supply.  We need to protect the sockeye salmon fishery to the furthest extent.  That means NO mining.  This fishery supports the economy, generating more than $480 million annually in revenue and employees 14,000 full and part time workers.  This is no small economic driver, plus it feeds us.  We can't afford to jeopardize in any manner this fishery.  That means NO mining.

The footprint of this proposed mine is incredibly large, 30 square miles, that's practically twice the size of the rural township in which I live.  The proposed mine will generate ten billion tons of mine waste, require massive amounts of water, earthen dams, 100 mile road, massive power plant and dewater key salmon spawning streams.  Food is necessary for life, gold is not.  That means NO mining!

I do live quite a distance from Alaska however, I am a relevant stakeholder.  I am a sockeye salmon consumer; I currently am a contributor to the Alaskan economy.  I also am a strong advocate for our environment.  I know first-hand how big resource companies come into small communities and ruin them, ruin the water, soil, air along with changing our social fabric and not for the better.  Regulations are never robust enough to prevent unintended, long lasting environmental calamity, disasters and devastation.  We can't allow this to continue.  That means NO mining!

Please accept my comment and withdraw this proposal which is most harmful to sockeye salmon, the Alaskan people and their sockeye salmon consumers.  Thank you for the commenting opportunity.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment: Please don't ignore all the scientific work done and community comments that show that the massive amount of debris from the proposed Pebble Mine could cause irreparable harm to the largest sockeye salmon ecosystem in the world.  It is not clear why the EPA reached this agreement, nor why the company even sought the injunction, as they could have submitted their application for a permit to the Army Corps of Engineers while the review was going on.  Why the EPA would agree to postpone their completion of the review process for 48 months is also unclear.  In short, the EPA does not seem to be aggressively defending its work or Bristol Bay.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I am opposed to EPAs proposal to rescind the 2014 Proposed Determination designed to protect Bristol Bays world class fisheries. Please stand with American jobs and communities and preserve the Bristol Bay Proposed Determination.
   Had to read this paragraph several times to note if it was for or against Bristol Bay.

Bristol Bay, Alaska, is one of America's last great wild salmon fisheries. Each year, tens of millions of wild salmon return, supporting upwards of 14,000 jobs in the commercial and sport fishing industries, and serving as a one-in-a-lifetime destination for anglers from around the world as well as the cultural cornerstone for the region's communities. These long-established businesses are at risk from a foreign-owned mining company that wants to build the proposed Pebble Mine, which is opposed by more than 65 percent of Alaskans and more than 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents. 

In 2014, led by Alaska Native Tribes, interests including commercial fishing business owners and sportsmen asked the EPA step in to ensure that this mine wouldn't jeopardize Bristol Bay. The EPA responded by listening to over 1.5 million Americans, hosting dozens of community meetings, reviewing Pebble's many detailed filings with state and federal agencies, and conducting a twice peer-reviewed scientific assessment of the potential impacts to the region. Withdrawing the proposed determination ignores the overwhelming majority of Alaskans and puts the short-term interests of a foreign mining company above thousands of local jobs. 

For the sake of our wildlife, waterways, and communities, I urge you to protect Bristol Bay and prevent this horrible open-pit mine from destroying one of our nation's most precious ecosystems.

May keep our life productive locations safe from industry which must be done in an area good location for them, not in our water and fish areas!
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment submitted by C. Smith
Comment:
To the EPA and Administrator Scott Pruitt,

I wish to voice my opposition to the proposition to withdraw 
from the Clean Water Act which would then allow mining companies 
such as Pebble Limited to mine the resources in the Bristol Bay
Alaska region. 

The fact that Mr. Pruitt has single-handedly submitted this
proposal is despicable. Since EPA means Environmental
Protection, how does raping the land so that a few can make 
millions protect this environment?  Mr. Pruitt as EPA chief
has been like leaving the fox in charge of the hen house.  


I,m sure that even if the laws which would allow the mining
to proceed are prevented in the current administration, 
the resources within the Bristol Bay are so greatly desired
that this attempt will be made over and over again in the 
future. 

I am so offended by this administrations' environmental
policies so far that the republican party can no longer
rely on my vote or support.

I can't help but think that the opinion of one insignificant voter has 
very little weight and will make no difference. However,
I do believe it is important to constantly remind public
officials that they serve the people (the larger common good) not 
the businesses who will make large sums of money with little
benefit to the country. If anything, this often has a detrimental
affect on the public because they get stuck with having to pay for
the environmental damages as well as having to live in the 
contaminated regions. I also don't support the counter argument which 
always says there are significant overall economic benefits from these 
operations. The so called "Trickle Down Effect" only benefits the few 
businesses who are directly involved.

Please starting doing your job to serve the public and protect the environment.

Thanks for listening,
C. Smith

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment: I think that the restriction on mining should be maintained until the Pebble LP can find a way to mine without severely affecting the surrounding environment. Require the Pebble LP, as well as an independent, impartial third party, to do much more research into the environmental impact relative to material gain before allowing them to mine. If they find that mining is likely to negatively impact the surrounding ecosystem (which by all indications I am aware of, it will), require the Pebble LP to put off their mining until such time less detrimental methods/technologies are developed. If they are able to mine without much damage, legally bind them to cover any and ALL environmental damage that may result from unseen circumstances. Hold the Pebble LP responsible for anything that happens under their watch. But above all, put the safety of the environment first! Economic gain should not come at detriment to the ecosystem.

Title: Comment submitted by S. McFeeters
Comment:
Given the findings of the EPA Assessment, "The Effects of Large Scale Mining on the Salmon Ecosystems of the Nushagak and Kvichak Rivers." I am OPPOSED  to the modification of any status to the Bristol Bay watershed that would, in all likelihood, compromise the integrity of the involved ecosystems. The mining operations would cause hundreds of millions of dollars of damage to the affected region, including the livelihoods of many residents, and, as well, cause irreversible damage to the associated ecosystems. This must NOT be allowed to happen.

Stuart K. McFeeters, Ph,D, GISP
Lecturer in Geography
California State University, Fresno

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment: I am a marine scientists who studies the intersection of ecological and human communities; I know firsthand the importance of maintaining balance between needs for both. I am for sustainable use across multiple objectives - opening up Bristol Bay is not this. Bristol Bay is *already* a shining example of working balance between a critical ecosystem and the needs of people. It is a success story, but one we are in danger of undermining if we ignore the best available science and allow one use to threaten so many others as well as the ecological importance of the region. So doing puts people and wildlife in harms way. Maintain the original and importance decision on Bristol Bay and DO NOT withdraw the Pebble Mine decision from July 2014.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment: The science regarding the safety of opening up the questioned area to mining is clear; mining will cause a significant loss of habitat for the species that live there and will have drastic negative consequences felt around the world.  The policies of the EPA must be rooted in evidence, not one's own political beliefs.  When the EPA disregards evidence that is widely accepted by the scientific community they risk jeopardizing their credibility as an "environmental protection agency."  Mining would also cause financial loss as well, something that seems to be more important to the EPA than doing what they were created to do.  One must not be so myopic as to lose sight of the long term consequences (environmental, financial, social, cultural) that opening up the questioning land to mining would cause. Preserving our natural resources must be a top priority of the EPA, especially if it claims to be truly conservative.  Please do not overturn the previous agreements on the questioned area.  As a country we need areas like this to remember the natural beauty and abundance of the United States, teach our children the importance of taking care of their environment, improve our standard of living and remain America the Beautiful.

Comment:
Bristol Bay is one of the last, fairly unpolluted regions of the United States. Many different cultures rely on this area for their livelihoods and sustenance. Bristol Bay produces a large percentage of salmon sold worldwide, and this species needs clean water and protections from the devastation that mining produces. 

The fact that the EPA is looking at reducing these protections so that a FOREIGN mining company can destroy Bristol Bay's pristine environment is to strike a blow to the indigenous cultures and other people who call this area home.  

I do not, in any way shape or form, support foreign (or even American) mining or resource extraction in Bristol Bay. I do not support defiling the waters with mine waste. 

I DO support the native cultures and people in Alaska that rely on Bristol Bay for their livelihoods and sustenance. 

DO NOT allow the desecration of this beautiful place. 

Thank you.

Title: Comment submitted by P. Perry
Comment:
October 17, 2017

Environmental Protection Agency
RE: EPA-R10-OW-2017-0369 

	I vehemently oppose Scott Pruitt's proposal that would allow Pebble Limited Partnership access to the beautiful Bristol Bay region - home to fisherman, a $200 million salmon industry, and its spectacular rivers teeming with aquatic life.
	Why is the EPA continues to tune out voices of opposition and side with lobbyists eager to exploit the wetland in confounds reason. 
	What science backs up Pruitt's proposal? Can he present any evidence to counter the earlier determination based on year of scientific study that the proposed mine would be a risk to both fisheries and the ecosystem? Science is not on his side and apparently did not play a role in his decision. And why is our EPA chief meeting with corporate executive, special interest groups, and lobbyists from the very industries he is supposed to regulate? How can the public trust a man whose office sent letters written by energy industry lobbyists to Obama and other agencies? Why did he spend $25000 on a soundproof booth? 
	The public is left to wonder: Is Scott Pruitt on their payroll as well? 
	When an EPA spokesperson says that the "EPA has been the poster child for regulatory overreach, the agency is now meeting with those ignored by the Obama administration..." Really? These companies were not ignored. Pebble filed lawsuits charging the EPA "colluded with anti-mine activists and environmental leaning scientists in drafting the assessment." And now the EPA is colluding with them? I assumed the EPA director's job is to protect our environment? According to Section 404(c) the EPA has authority to "protect the environment whenever it determines unacceptable adverse effects may result from development activities. 
	 What is the basis for the decision? "Science should be not something just thrown about to try and dictate policy in Washington, D.C.?" Really? Science should not influence environmental policy? Troubling at least.
	I do not care if Pruitt expresses his own doubts on the cause of climate change. But I do care that every administration since the 1980s has accepted the scientific evidence to protect our planet. 
	More importantly, what else will the EPA chief do with our country?
	Kick the lobbyists out of the halls of government - the administration promised to drain the swamp!
	Fulfill your mission to protect "human health and the environment... where they live, learn, and work"  it's all we ask. 
	
Sincerely,
	
Patrick Perry

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
As a person who has worked on Alaska-bound cruise ships and fished in Alaska waters, I am strongly against anything that will degrade the quality of Bristol Bay. I join Alaskans in opposing the mine proposal for the bay. Bad policy designed to help a company and hurt the economy and future of Alaska. 

Iam opposed to EPAs proposal to rescind the 2014 Proposed Determination designed to protect Bristol Bays world class fisheries. Please stand with American jobs and communities and preserve the Bristol Bay Proposed Determination.

Bristol Bay, Alaska, is one of America's last great wild salmon fisheries. Each year, tens of millions of wild salmon return, supporting upwards of 14,000 jobs in the commercial and sport fishing industries, and serving as a one-in-a-lifetime destination for anglers from around the world as well as the cultural cornerstone for the region's communities. These long-established businesses are at risk from a foreign-owned mining company that wants to build the proposed Pebble Mine, which is opposed by more than 65 percent of Alaskans and more than 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents. 

In 2014, led by Alaska Native Tribes, interests including commercial fishing business owners and sportsmen asked the EPA step in to ensure that this mine wouldn't jeopardize Bristol Bay. The EPA responded by listening to over 1.5 million Americans, hosting dozens of community meetings, reviewing Pebble's many detailed filings with state and federal agencies, and conducting a twice peer-reviewed scientific assessment of the potential impacts to the region. Withdrawing the proposed determination ignores the overwhelming majority of Alaskans and puts the short-term interests of a foreign mining company above thousands of local jobs. 

For the sake of our wildlife, waterways, and communities, I urge you to protect Bristol Bay and prevent this horrible open-pit mine from destroying one of our nation's most precious ecosystems.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
The proposed determination should NOT be withdrawn for a number of reasons:

The rationale for the proposed withdrawal is flawed. Finalizing the proposed determination would provide much more regulatory certainty than withdrawing it, and a permit application is not needed to augment the already detailed factual record.  Further, the proposal to withdraw appears to be a "sue and settle" arrangement, which this Administration has said it will not pursue.

The watershed's ecological resources generated nearly $480 million in direct economic expenditures and sales and provided employment for over 14,000 full- and part-time workers in 2009.  The watershed supports the largest sockeye salmon fishery in the world.  It is also home to 25 federally recognized tribal governments who have maintained a salmon-based culture and subsistence-based way of life for at least 4,000 years that would be placed in jeopardy.

Contrary to comments by the backers of the Pebble Mine project, EPA's watershed assessment was scientifically based and thoroughly peer-reviewed, and the public has had an extensive opportunity to comment on it. The assessment and public comments received should be key components of any future action on this issue.

The overwhelming majority of residents of Bristol Bay are opposed to the project.5  A statewide majority of voters also oppose it, as evidenced by the 2014 State-wide ballot measure.

There is no good reason to withdraw this proposed determination, and many good reasons to proceed to make it a final determination.

Title: Comment submitted by J. Betts
Comment:
As a young member of the American Fisheries Society (AFS), and a fisheries biologist, formerly working in Alaska myself, I object to the withdrawal of the proposed determination and plead that the EPA use its authority to prevent the elimination and/or impairment of waters and wetlands supporting the extraordinarily prolific, sustainable, all-wild Bristol Bay salmon fisheries. I am concerned that EPA's settlement agreement with the Pebble Limited Partnership will clear the way for a project whose impacts to fisheries and the watershed cannot be adequately reduced or mitigated. Please consider the EPA's own peer-reviewed and well designed report about the potential permanent damages such mining operations could have on the most productive salmon fishery in the US, and its associated $1.5 Billion sustaining industry. A mine is extraction industry, here for a time and then gone. But the impacts can be long lasting. On the other hand, a fishery continues to produce, when well managed. When making these policies, our administration must think long-term, if we are to maintain a healthy economy and healthy environment.

Please consider the more developed thoughts and opinions of my supervisors in the AFS, who wrote this well constructed letter to Scott Pruitt and the EPA : https://fisheries.org/2017/10/afs-objects-to-epas-withdrawal-of-pebble-mine-determination/

And please consider my opinion as you go forward with this decision.

Thank you,
Joel Betts
Master's Student in Fisheries and Wildlife
Michigan State University

Title: Comment submitted by D. Eiseman
Comment:
October 17, 2017
 
Environmental Protection Agency
RE: EPA-R10-OW-2017-0369 
 
I vehemently oppose Scott Pruitt's proposal that would allow Pebble Limited Partnership access to the beautiful Bristol Bay region - home to fisherman, a $200 million salmon industry, and its spectacular rivers teeming with aquatic life.
Why is the EPA continues to tune out voices of opposition and side with lobbyists eager to exploit the wetland in confounds reason.
What science backs up Pruitt's proposal? Can he present any evidence to counter the earlier determination based on year of scientific study that the proposed mine would be a risk to both fisheries and the ecosystem? Science is not on his side and apparently did not play a role in his decision. And why is our EPA chief meeting with corporate executive, special interest groups, and lobbyists from the very industries he is supposed to regulate? How can the public trust a man whose office sent letters written by energy industry lobbyists to Obama and other agencies? Why did he spend $25000 on a soundproof booth?
The public is left to wonder: Is Scott Pruitt on their payroll as well?
When an EPA spokesperson says that the "EPA has been the poster child for regulatory overreach, the agency is now meeting with those ignored by the Obama administration..." Really? These companies were not ignored. Pebble filed lawsuits charging the EPA "colluded with anti-mine activists and environmental leaning scientists in drafting the assessment." And now the EPA is colluding with them? I assumed the EPA director's job is to protect our environment? According to Section 404(c) the EPA has authority to "protect the environment whenever it determines unacceptable adverse effects may result from development activities.
 What is the basis for the decision? "Science should be not something just thrown about to try and dictate policy in Washington, D.C.?" Really? Science should not influence environmental policy? Troubling at least.
I do not care if Pruitt expresses his own doubts on the cause of climate change. But I do care that every administration since the 1980s has accepted the scientific evidence to protect our planet.
More importantly, what else will the EPA chief do with our country?
Kick the lobbyists out of the halls of government.
Fulfill your mission to protect "the human health and the environment... where they live, learn, and work"  it's all we ask.

David Eiseman

Title: Comment submitted by Douglas J. Austen,  Executive Director, American Fisheries Society
Comment: As a fisheries biologist, member of the American Fisheries Society, and a former public servant to Alaska's commercial fisheries, I object to the withdrawal of the proposed determination and implore that the EPA use its authority to prevent the elimination and/or impairment of waters and wetlands supporting the particularly prolific, sustainable, all-wild Bristol Bay salmon fisheries. I am deeply concerned that the EPA's settlement agreement with the Pebble Limited Partnership will lead to lasting negative impacts upon this vital watershed, impacts that will not be reduced or mitigated by this agreement. Please consider the EPA's own peer-reviewed and well-designed report about the potential permanent damages such mining operations could have on the most productive salmon fishery in the US, and its associated $1.5 Billion sustaining industry. While mining does provide temporary economic income and wealth, it is an extraction industry that cannot be sustained long-term and consequently will negatively impact economically and subsistence important fisheries that not only provide billions of dollars to our US economy but also sustain native and non-native communities alike. When making these policies, our administration must think long-term, if we are to maintain a healthy economy and healthy environment. Please consider the more developed thoughts and opinions of my supervisors in the AFS, who wrote this well constructed letter to Scott Pruitt and the EPA : [URL: https://fisheries.org/2017/10/afs-objects-to-epas-withdrawal-of-pebble-mine-determination/]. Please consider my opinion as you go forward with this decision.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
Don't do it! Don't let the Bristol Bay die. I live beside a fishery that was destroyed because of the lack of concern by a large company. Despite the fact the governmental regulations permitted this company to "safely" dispose of their waste in the river. It led to the company "forgetting" or just not caring what happened, which in turned destroyed the fishing and will have an impact on this river the rest of time. Now we are trying to reverse the damage done by previous generations but it has come at a great cost. 

This isn't just about the fish though, it's about the families. The families that depend on this bay for their livelihood. The gold and coper mine bringing more jobs? Maybe for a short season, but not for the rest of time. Perhaps, it will bring a few nice paying jobs and a decent amount of money for 4 or 5 years, but gold and copper run out. That's why you don't see masses of people still panning the rivers of California. Copper and Gold don't reproduce as the species in this bay do. 

Don't make a way for this mine to exist! There's no way they can safely dispose of their waste for the rest of time. Even if there was a 2% chance it was possible, That's a risk you should not take.

I am writing because I care about the fishery yes, but I care more about the people who live and make their income from the bay a lot more.

Title: Comment submitted by M. Brown
Comment:
To Whom It May Concern, 
I am a 4th generation commercial fisherman in Bristol Bay who has been following the Bristol Bay Watershed Assessment process since its inception and hoped it would lead to 404c being implemented as was indicated in the Proposed Determination. I request that the determination not be withdrawn and that dredge and fill material not be allowed to be deposited in the U.S. waters of Bristol Bay, Alaska. 
I firmly believe that the environment where the Pebble Deposit lies would be irreparably harmed by mining development and adversely impact the rich populations of salmon that have a relationship to the area and system in and around the deposit. My fear is that even a small mine plan will not only lead to bigger plans later but open the door for other deposits in the area to be developed, thus displacing sustainable salmon by digging up the watersheds that support them. 
The work of the EPA has been important for conserving what is exceptional and necessary to U.S. citizens and I would ask that it continue to be so by recognizing the value of the Bristol Bay fishery and the threat that large-scale mining poses to its health and future. 

Melanie Brown
Bristol Bay Commercial Permit Holder
Tribal Citizen-Naknek Native Village
Mother

Say no to Pebble Mine, any form.  Our water and salmon are too important to Alaskans to allow a company to enter, exploit this resource, and leave behind a permanent scar and environmental damage, regardless of their promises.

The proposed waste storeage dam is located near headwaters to Bristol Bay, and is in Alaska earthquake country.  Every dam like this in history has eventually failed.  It is too perilous to allow this type of development, any form.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I write to encourage the EPA to back away from consideration of rescinding the decision to not allow mining of gold/silver in the area above Bristol Bay.  Why?  Sound science has ALREADY SHOWN that to do so would be a bad idea. Northern Dynasty Minerals, a Canadian mining company, has no business raping American territories for lucre under the guise of the  Pebble Limited Partnership, a subsidiary of the mining company.  The way in which Secretary Pruitt made the decision to reconsider the ban on mining there, put in place under a LAWFUL act of the previous administration, reeks to heaven.

In 2014, EPA's exhaustive and peer-refiewed studies resulted in a report on Bristol Bay under the Obama administration. The report stated that such a mine would result in complete loss of fish habitat due to elimination, dewatering, and fragmentation of streams, wetlands, and other aquatic resources in some areas of the bay watershed. In particular, the findings are that about 22 miles of streams and more than 6 square miles of wetlands and other habitats that are important to salmon and other fish would be lost to a large-scale mine and that the losses would be irreversible.

Alaskans don't want it, and neither do their neighbors in the remaining American states.   For example, a 2014 statewide ballot resulted in two-thirds of voters choosing to give the Alaska legislature power to approve or veto large-scale mining projects in the area if the projects threaten fisheries.  that's what this mine would do. More than 80 percent of local residents and 62 percent statewide oppose the mine.

Do the right thing and stick with settled science on this issue.  Save everyone time and money.  Stop it in its tracks now and stick with the existing law that bans mining in that area completely.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
Removing the exclusion of these critical areas of salmon habitat will be detrimental to the Alaska fisheries industry, which is essential to the employment and broader welfare of the communities in southwestern Alaska that rely on these rivers. The salmon fisheries have already experienced severe decline as a result of warming waters and other pollutants. Further damaging the fishing stock will negatively affect not only the fishing community but all other commercial operations that rely on a strong fishery for their success, including housing, retail outlets, marinas, boat maintenance as well as churches, schools and municipal functions dependent upon the fishing economy. 

Of even greater concern is the fact that local communities depend upon the fish in these locations as a food source. The waters and the fish in those waters will contain an over abundance of the target mineral pebbles. Most area residents eat fish almost exclusively. Studies have shown that chronic ingestion of molybdenum can have serious and long-term health effects, including growth retardation, infertility, low birth weight and can also affect the lungs, kidneys and liver.

Fisheries are only one activity that will experience a negative impact. The minerals that will be deposited in these locations will be detrimental if not poisonous to the marine flora. So humans and animals that consume the plants that have absorbed the minerals from the pebble deposits will be exposed to the same health threats as those posed by eating the fish. 

This proposal is rife with negatives and if adopted will sacrifice the health and economic viability of the residents of the nearby communities to benefit the bottom line of the pebble corporation, whose leadership undoubtedly lives in areas not threatened by such health hazards.

Title: Anonymous public comment

I am new the the Pebble Mine controversy but after reading about it I encourage the EPA  to oppose this project.  Some statistics I read....." A threat to the fish would amount to a threat to the regional subsistence lifestyle.

Title: Comment submitted by B. Williams
Comment:
Dear Sir,

I have spent some of the best and most memorable times of my life in the watershed contiguous to the Pebble Deposit in Southwest Alaska.  It is a wilderness like no other, rich in all that so much of the developed world is not.  I am a fisherman, a hunter, an environmentalist and an educator.  I understand and appreciate many of the issues at play here, but I cannot understand why the EPA would realistically consider granting a permit for the Pebble Mine.  Too much that can never be recovered could be lost to such a decision, and the negligible potential gains in the short-term would be forever overshadowed by the ultimate loss of habitat that would inevitably ensue.  I live in Montana, so I know something about the damage a mine can do to an area or a watershed.  You might even look to the Polley Mine debacle in nearby Canada for the price of short-term thinking and the price of arrogance in the face of mother nature.  Whether the holding ponds of the proposed Pebble project will fail is not a question.  They will.  The only question is when.  And so we are left to ponder what happens when the richest fishery and eco-system in the world is lost to the selfish interests of a self-inerested mining concern.  How and why are we even considering this?  Haven't we been through it before?  Or are we just wafting with the winds of politics so that the current administration can deal a lethal blow to the Clean Water Act.  Of all the things upon which to take a stand, the EPA is going to question the value of clean water?

Perhaps the concerns here are economic, and the EPA is re-evaluating the Pebble site because of the money that might be made from the ore deposits.  I wonder, though, if such profits could hold a candle to the economy that Alaska has built around the desire of sportsmen and women to hunt and fish in the Bristol Bay region.  Mining is transient, with the revenue shared by a few.  The salmon runs - unless the EPA fails to do its job - are perpetual and eternal.  And the livelihood those runs sustain will last generations.  If you take my own case as an example and consider the funds that have been committed as a result to the Alaska economy, you could easily quantify the folly of the Pebble project as a money maker for Alaska.

It is my fervent hope, therefore, that you will deny a permit for a disposal site in the Pebble Deposit area of Southwest Alaska.  Deny it for the people of Alaska, for the wilderness that should remain, for the salmon and the rivers, and for future generations who need to know the treasure of Bristol Bay - not the gold and minerals - but the life and ecosystem that remain unprecedented in our world.  There is no choice here.  I hope you will agree.

Sincerely,

Ben Williams
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment submitted by W. Hill
Comment:
I am opposed to the proposal to withdraw from the 2014 Proposed Determination that protects Bristol Bay in Alaska. 

This proposal threatens the preservation and continuation of a waterway vital to the health of a key species. Its destruction via the byproducts of the mining process would result in the decimation of the local fishing industry and create cascading destructive effects on ecosystems upstream that depend upon healthy Sockeye Salmon spawning runs. 

The fish in the watershed, and the wildlife that depend on them, are too important to risk in exchange for the mine's economic benefits.
Accidental discharge of process chemicals and byproducts, heavy metals, and acid mine drainage to the environment are realistic concerns in mine design and operation. They are dangerous to fish and other wildlife. Downstream salmon and freshwater fish species are vulnerable to mine-generated pollutants. A threat to the fish would amount to a threat to the regional subsistence lifestyle.
According to the EPA, mining has contaminated portions of the headwaters of over 40 percent of watersheds in the western continental U.S., and reclamation of 500,000 abandoned mines in 32 states could cost tens of billions of dollars.

The short term gains outweigh the long term risks but those risks are severe as this is an earthquake heavy region which is a huge reason this place is risky to mine and increases the difficulty of storing hazardous waste. Groundtruthtrekking.org claimed that earthquake hazards in the area are poorly known, and preliminary plans by the mining company do not prepare adequately for the potential risk. It's too dangerous to mine the region for the ecosystem and the miners.

A recent study of 25 modern large hard rock metal mines compared water quality outcomes with environmental impact statement predictions from the permitting stage. 76 percent (19 mines) of the 25 mines violated water quality standards in releases to either surface or groundwater. In this study "violated water quality standards" does not necessarily mean that the mines failed to abide by their permits. When the 15 mines with high acid-drainage, high contaminant leaching potential and proximity to groundwater are considered separately, this number is 93% (14 mines).

Bristol Bay where many local families fish. If the waterway is destroyed, more than half of them their summer revenue from their fishing and teaching jobs.

To make matters worse, the mineral rights and the project are controlled by Canadian, British, Australian and Japanese corporations.
The mine may not provide significant tax revenue to the American state. Due to Alaska's tax structure, oil and gas drilling returns over 20% of resource value to the state and municipalities, fishing returns 1% to 5%, and mining returns approximately 1.5%. However, considering the mine contains over $500 Billion in resources, this 1.5% tax amounts to a maximum of $7.5 Billion in tax revenue over the course of the mine's operation or or $166 million/year or some four times the commercial tax budget in 2011 ($43 million). The annual revenue potential of the mine is yet unknown, and consequently so is the tax revenue to the State.

If this mine goes through: Thousands of jobs will be lost, an entire ecosystem will be destroyed and the world's Sockeye salmon population will be decimated.

Please continue to ensure the wellbeing of this vital waterway by enforcing the EPA region 10 July 2014 Proposed Determination.

Waldon Hill Henderson,NV

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
The rescinding of the EPA's previous position on Bristol Bay, in addition to so many other recent actions by the Trump administration since it took office in 2017, will be yet another reason that the Government of the United States cannot be permitted to continue in Power. The People of the United States of America are the power base that gives the Government of These United States, in its three branches, the Power to rule. The EPA is a construct of that government to effectively keep law. That law is always to be for the good of the People, not profit, not business, not economics; the good of the People.

If the EPA position to block any attempts to mine or otherwise jeopardize Bristol Bay's ecosystem, to include the Salmon, the Water, and all Life and People groups in the region, is reversed, the EPA will have proven itself to be acting in interests which are not for the benefit of the People of These United States, making itself a body of government whose power, while granted by the government that rules, to be effectively null and void.

Further, if the decision to act in this manner is permitted to come to pass, such passage, when considered along with the actions of the Trump administration, in particular, which have been against the benefits of the People of These United States, despite repeated protest and notice from various and many persons from within the body of the People of These United States, will give good cause for the dissolution of the Government of These United States of America, to protect the People to which it was and still is given power by.

This comment, while directly relevant to Bristol Bay and the pending decision by the EPA, further reaches across the Government Body of the United States in scope, as this is one decision to be made among many decisions which have been, are being, and will be made, by the Government of These United States.

Consider wisely, for the time is already at hand for the very credibility of the Authority, which These United States of America holds, to be held in question, not only by the People, to whom gave and still give such authority, but by the World and the Nations within it. This decision, being considered by the EPA, is just one more attempt to attack a Sovereign and Free People at the very core of their existence, the Water, the Salmon, the World they live within; such cannot be permitted; if permitted such a government cannot be allowed to stand.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I oppose EPAs proposal to rescind the 2014 Proposed Determination designed to protect Bristol Bays world class fisheries. Salmon fishing is a proud and honored way of life for thousands of small businessmen in Alaska and Washington, and our salmon are vital to the local economy--and cuisine! Bristol Bay's pristine environment also safeguards many other species and is one of the most beautiful parts of America.  Please stand with American jobs and communities and preserve the Bristol Bay Proposed Determination.

Bristol Bay, Alaska, is one of America's last great wild salmon fisheries. Each year, tens of millions of wild salmon return, supporting upwards of 14,000 jobs in the commercial and sport fishing industries, and serving as a one-in-a-lifetime destination for anglers from around the world as well as the cultural cornerstone for the region's communities. These long-established businesses are at risk from a foreign-owned mining company that wants to build the proposed Pebble Mine, which is opposed by more than 65 percent of Alaskans and more than 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents. 

In 2014, led by Alaska Native Tribes, interests including commercial fishing business owners and sportsmen asked the EPA step in to ensure that this mine wouldn't jeopardize Bristol Bay. The EPA responded by listening to over 1.5 million Americans, hosting dozens of community meetings, reviewing Pebble's many detailed filings with state and federal agencies, and conducting a twice peer-reviewed scientific assessment of the potential impacts to the region. Withdrawing the proposed determination ignores the overwhelming majority of Alaskans and puts the short-term interests of a foreign mining company above thousands of local jobs. 

For the sake of our wildlife, waterways, and communities, I urge you to protect Bristol Bay and prevent this horrible open-pit mine from destroying one of our nation's most precious ecosystems.

Title: Comment submitted by D. Handley
Comment:
Greetings,

The language of this proposal is obviously not for the layman.  I understand you are seeking very specific comments regarding the determination and whether to proceed or withdraw.  I also understand the determination to be about restricting development of this area as a disposal site in certain bodies of water (watersheds) near Bristol Bay (Pebble Deposit Area, SW AK).  I believe that the area should be restricted from being used as a disposal site - particularly when there is great risk of breaches to the watershed and the ecosystems such as what happened when a dam breached in Canada at the Mount Polley mine in August 2014. It dumped out 6.5 billion gallons of wastewater destroying part of British Columbia's watershed.  Science and the effects of the humongous drilling of the cavern as a big or larger than the Grand Canyon, and estimated to generate billions of gallons of acid generating waste, should take priority in this decision, not greed at the expense of the fishery, salmon and their eco-system.  These waters are too special and too valuable to offer up to the highest bidder."

I hope you will base your decision on science, the great inherent risks involved, and restrict this area as a disposal site.  

Thank you,

Darlene Handley
Glendale, AZ
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
The EPA must not withdraw the EPA Region 10 July 2014 Proposed Determination that was issued pursuant of the Clean Water Act, to restrict the use of certain waters in the South Fork Koktuli River, North Fork Koktuli River, and Upper Talarik Creek watersheds in southwest Alaska as disposal sites for dredged or fill material associated with mining the Pebble deposit.

In my opinion, the aforementioned disposal sites carry extreme risk because the cyanide used to leach gold out of the ore mined will probably leak out of the dams(disposal sites) used to contain the mining waste. Any amount of cyanide will pose a risk to life downstream from these sites: fish, birds, animals -- everything.   And, the risk will be catastrophic if the dams containing the waste fail because then the entire watershed downstream will be destroyed!  NOTE: if the mining company says that dam failures will not occur, don't believe it because such failures have been common in gold mining operations elsewhere in the world.  And, the results of these failures have been disastrous !!!

There is no room for error in this proposed mine because if an environmental disaster occurs, there will be no acceptable cleanup operation. (The affected area will never return to its original state.) So, please DO NOT withdraw the EPA Region 10 July 2014 Proposed Determination that was issued pursuant of the Clean Water Act to restrict the use of certain waters as disposal sites for dredged/fill material associated with this mining operation.

Title: Comment submitted by I. Zaback

As a citizen and registered voter, I strongly oppose the move to lift environmental regulations in these areas. Lifting these regulations is bad for the ecosystem and bad for economic growth.

Title: Comment submitted by Randall K.
Comment:
Do not go through with this withdraw. Do. Not. Go. Through. With. It. No matter what the benefits you think may be, withdrawing these restrictions will only do immense damage. Title: Comment submitted by C. and T. Elliott
Comment:
Dear EPA,
How is allowing mining by a Canadian company in Bristol Bay putting America first?  We spent 24 years living in Montana and we saw the damage that mining can do.  Some of the largest super fund sites are there.  We now live in Washington state and we have learned and seen how salmon are struggling to survive.  We live in Anacortes, at one time, it was considered the Salmon canning capital.  Salmon are hard to find and the local orca whales are starving because they can not find enough fish to eat.  Canada and the USA ruined an incredible resource.  

Mining in Bristol Bay is a bad idea and we do not support it.  There are other areas that can be mined. Leave this incredible resource alone. Thousands of people rely on these fish to support their families.  There just are not that many decent fisheries left in the world.  Lead by continuing to protect this one.

Catherine and Thomas Elliott
Anacortes, WA

Title: Comment submitted by M. M. Miller
Comment:
I am writing you to ask that you stand with American jobs and communities and not withdraw the Bristol Bay Proposed Determination, which it made pursuant to the Clean Water Act in 2014.

Why does this matter to me? I am a life long Alaskan, a Bristol Bay fisherman and Bristol Bay permit owner. The Bristol Bay salmon fishery represents a significant portion of my livelihood. There are upwards of 14,000 American jobs in the commercial and sport fishing industries in Bristol Bay. Both industries depend on the health of the salmon runs, as do the region's communities. 

The proposed Pebble Mine would severely impact the health of the salmon and cause detrimental harm to the entire region. The mine is opposed by more than 65 percent of Alaskans and more than 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents. 

In 2010, led by Alaska Native Tribes, interests including commercial fishing business owners and sportsmen asked the EPA step in to ensure that this mine wouldn't jeopardize Bristol Bay. The EPA responded by listening to over 1.5 million Americans, hosting dozens of community meetings, reviewing Pebble's many detailed filings with state and federal agencies, and conducting a twice peer-reviewed scientific assessment of the potential impacts to the region.

Withdrawing the proposed determination ignores the overwhelming majority of Alaskans and puts the short-term interests of a foreign mining company above thousands of American jobs. 

Please do not withdraw the proposed determination.

Sincerely,

Molly M Miller
Kodiak, Alaska
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I am writing to urge the EPA not to withdraw the Bristol Bay Proposed Determination.

Bristol Bay, Alaska is the most valuable salmon fishery in the world, supporting over 14,000 American jobs in the commercial and sport fishing industries, tourism from fishers around the world, and is an American cultural heritage.

These American businesses and jobs are at risk from a foreign-owned mining company that wants to build the proposed Pebble Mine, which is opposed by more than 65 percent of Alaskans and more than 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents. 

Withdrawing the proposed determination would put the profits of a foreign mining company before thousands of American jobs and the will of Alaskans, and would needlessly create a toxic political environment between mining and fishery interests.

Please do not withdraw the proposed determination.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
For What It's Worth

Why are we wasting our time yet again on this. Is money always going to get it's way. We have been (surprisingly) managing the Bristol Bay sockeye fishery for years now. Not to mention the whole ecosystem that helps support these fish, by not disturbing it. Thousands of jobs rely on this renewable resource yet we are willing to give this up for a thousand jobs and the top people getting filthy rich on mining. That doesn't include the wealth that will be made on wall street. I don't know why the public is allowed to make comments on rulings like these. In the past I have seen 90% of the public comment against and issue, only to have our politicians and big money pass it anyway. $400 billion is a lot of money.  50 Million sockeye, eh, who needs them, right? History has shown on the Columbia River, what can be done by man to ruin a natural resource. Lets not keep making the same mistakes.

He is saying whatever he feels he needs to to get this project permitted, but at what cost? Maybe he and some others will make money from this project, but what are they destroying in the process? Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
Bristol Bay's unimpaired watersheds and wild, sustainable, commercial, recreational, and subsistence fisheries represent an extraordinarily rare resource of national and global importance. The area boasts the world's largest and most valuable wild salmon fisheries. It is unlikely that Pebble Mine will be able to operate in this area without harming the rivers and the salmon that depend on them, and such impacts would be catastrophic to this unique, pristine fishery. Withdrawing this determination would clear the way for a project whose impacts to fisheries and the watershed cannot be adequately reduced or mitigated.
Please consider the EPA report  "An Assessment of Potential Mining Impacts on Salmon Ecosystems of Bristol Bay, Alaska" (Report) as you reconsider the Clean Water 404(c) determination. For this report, the EPA conducted a comprehensive, rigorous, professional review incorporating the best available science and addressed every substantive peer-review critique. This Report provides an indispensable resource to inform decision-makers of the costs, benefits, and risks to public salmon resources from proposed mining activities in Bristol Bay. The Report recognizes that Bristol Bay is extraordinary because it produces about half the world's wild Sockeye Salmon supply with runs averaging 37.5 million fish per year. The wild salmon fishery in Bristol Bay has been managed in a sustainable manner since 1884, and was valued at $1.5 billion U.S. in 2010. In addition to Sockeye Salmon, Bristol Bay and the watershed support one of the world's largest remaining wild Chinook Salmon runs and healthy Coho, Chum and Pink Salmon runs. These salmon sustain lucrative commercial and recreational fisheries and provide jobs and food security to 25 rural Alaska Native villages and thousands of people. Bristol Bay represents a rare, unaltered living laboratory where we can learn how healthy salmon ecosystems function. Ensuring that this area remains pristine would allow it to continue to inform salmon rehabilitation efforts in the conterminous U.S. where 40 percent of populations are extirpated from historic habitats, a third of remaining populations are threatened or endangered with extinction. The Report rigorously considered mining risks to salmon and based realistic mine scenarios on plans commissioned by mine proponents, state of the art mining and mitigation techniques. However, a major shortcoming of the Report, in my view, is the unrealistically optimistic and foolish assumptions that no significant human or engineering failures would occur. Given that EPA quantified impacts from developing approximately half of the estimated Pebble ore body and did not quantify additional impacts from port facilities, power generation and transmission, and urbanization and other infrastructure, the assessment of potential impacts is very conservative. Actual impacts would very likely be much greater. The Report estimated development of 6.5 billion tons of the estimated 10.8 billion ton Pebble ore deposit would result in a loss of 94 miles of salmon supporting streams and 5,350 acres of wetlands, ponds, and lakes in the mine footprint. Toxic mine waste, leachates, wastewater, and tailings dams (mine waste dumps) should be monitored, maintained, and managed during and after mininginto perpetuity. A tailings dam failure in Bristol Bay would have catastrophic effects on fishery resources. Based on past mining district histories and its location, it is highly likely that damage to aquatic resources from mining would be unavoidable and permanent, and compensatory mitigation and remediation would be insufficient to make up for losses to aquatic habitats. Tailings dams have failed in other areas, such as in 2014, when Imperial Metals Corporation's Mount Polley copper-gold mine tailings dam failed, sending 24 million cubic meters of water and mine tailings downstream into a tributary of British Columbia's Fraser River with contamination reaching previously pristine Quesnel Lake.The facts warrant deep considerationImperial Metals Corporation is an established Canadian mining firm, the mine and tailings dam were built to modern technical standards, the tailings were not acid-generating, and the breach occurred on a sunny summer day, not after an earthquake or a major storm event. The Mount Polley Mine tailings dam was the same type of tailings dam proposed for Pebble Mine, but the Pebble Mine and associated dams are projected to be more than 100 times larger than Mount Polley, will be in a geologically and hydrologically less stable area, and in acid generating rock. Given those facts and the best available scientific information, the potential exists for a more serious catastrophe at Pebble Mine than what is ongoing at Mount Polley. I urge the EPA to use its authority to preemptively prevent elimination/impairment of waters supporting the extraordinarily prolific, sustainable, all-wild Bristol Bay salmon fisheries.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment: I strongly support the Obama administration's 2014 determination and its proposed restrictions that would have banned the proposed Pebble Mine.  The mine poses unacceptable environmental risks to the Bristol Bay watershed, including those related to generating 10 billion tons of contaminated mining waste that would have to be stored forever in a seismically active area.  Bristol Bay area residents and Alaskans generally oppose the project by wide margins because of the risk of devastating ecological harm it presents: more than 65 percent of Alaskans, 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents and Native communities, and 85 percent of commercial fishermen oppose the mine.  As originally proposed, the Pebble mine would have been among North America's largest open-pit mines.  Although the company is now asserting it will introduce plans for a smaller mine, given the enormous infrastructure expenditures necessary to construct a mine in the area, including the building of a 100-mile road, power plant, and deep water port, proposals for a smaller project are simply unrealistic; they are neither economically feasible nor unlikely to be pursued.  Thus, the focus must continue to be on the original Pebble proposal.  The project as originally proposed poses a calamitous risk to the ecology of Bristol Bay, threatens the local economy and 14,000 American jobs, poses a danger to Native Alaskan communities, and flies in the face of the wishes of the vast majority of local residents and Alaskans generally.  Under these circumstances, a decision to withdraw the Obama administration's 2014 determination and its proposed restrictions can only be characterized as a handout to the mining industry at the expense of the American people and one of America's last wild places. I urge you to maintain the Obama administration's 2014 determination and its proposed restrictions as they currently exist, without any changes.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
The chain reaction of events that would come from this would harm more than just the native species that live in Bristol Bay, but also devastate the lives of those who depend on the ecosystem to survive. Almost half (46%) of the world's salmon harvest each year comes from Bristol Bay. It supports 14,000 jobs and is worth an estimated $1.5 billion annually. The addition of mining into the system would destroy the river ecosystem and lead to the death of salmon and the industry they provide. There is no justification for withdrawing protection and allowing the destruction of this crucial habitat. Please, I urge you not to withdraw protection.

Besides destroying the economy and the salmon industry, pebble mining will introduce toxic materials into the system. The dam that keeps this material in check will have to be maintained adequately for thousands of years in a known earthquake zone to prevent the spread of this hazardous waste. The risk that this mining would pose is too high to take, and for a foreign company nonetheless. This is United States soil, and we should consider this issue a matter of public security. Again, I urge you not to withdraw protection of this critical waterway for the benefit of a foreign company who will destroy Bristol Bay and the jobs and lives of those who rely on the natural resources it provides.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
As a born and raised Alaskan, I am commenting to voice my concern over mining in Bristol Bay. I come from a family with deep ties to the mining and oil industry but I cannot support a mine in Bristol Bay. This is a wetland area where containing any pollution from the mine will be impossible. 

We have been through the public review comment before. In 2014, following a four-year review process, 1.5 million public comments and verification from hundreds of scientists, the Environmental Protection Agency determined that the Bristol Bay watershed is too fragile to tolerate the risks of large-scale mining. It proposed restrictions under the Clean Water Act that would have limited the size and impact of the potential Pebble Mine. The people spoke then and they are speaking now - Alaskans do not want this mine and will do whatever is necessary to protect our land from corporate land robbers.

Please do not withdraw protections for this unique ecosystem.

Title: Comment submitted by Charity (surname not provided)
Comment:
I am writing to express opposition to withdrawing the protection of the Bristol Bay Proposed Determination and Clean Water Act for the Bristol Bay Watershed. It is imperative that we take into deep consideration the detrimental, and likely irreversible impacts that mining in this area may have. There is a fragile, beautiful, and impactful ecosystem that must not be disrupted. This area is home to so many species that are dependent on the delicate balance that exists. There are also over 14,000 jobs that are dependent on the fishing industry connected to this area that could be lost with the destruction of this ecosystem. I implore you to be globally minded and future thinking in your decision making so that we can protect this natural resource that is vital to generations to come. We must deeply consider the big picture and see that they impacts of loss of protection far outweigh any claimed benefits. Please maintain the protection that was so thoughtfully put in place for this essential and one-of-a kind area that is produces nearly half of the world's sockeye salmon population and supports life for so many more.
- Charity

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
Please accept the following comment on Docket ID No. EPA-R10-OW-2017-0369.

Do not withdraw the EPA Region 10 July 2014 Proposed Determination that was issued pursuant of the Clean Water Act, to restrict the use of certain waters in the South Fork Koktuli River, North Fork Koktuli River, and Upper Talarik Creek watersheds in southwest Alaska as disposal sites for dredged or fill material associated with mining the Pebble deposit, a copper-, gold-, and molybdenum-bearing ore body. This determination was made after years of research by multiple public and private interests as well as solicited input by the American voting public. All of the research and comments showed a stark conclusion that any development of Bristol Bay and its associated waterways, was not in the best interest of this country or the environment. Even former partners of the proposed Pebble Mine venture have abandoned the project as costs have skyrocketed and risks increased each year. 

In 2014, Canada's Mount Polley minewhich, though much smaller, is very similar to the type of mine that Pebble would come to beoffered the world a glimpse at what future could await Bristol Bay if Pebble were built and its tailing dam were to fail. When Polley's tailings dam burst, it released its toxic tailings slurry into Polley Lake, Hazeltine Creek, Quesnel Lake and Cariboo Creek. It has been characterized as one of the greatest environmental disasters in modern Canadian historyflooding nearby waters and wetlands with arsenic, selenium and other heavy metals. Prior to the disaster, Polley was one of the mines that the Pebble Limited Partnership (PLP) had held out as an example of mines and fisheries co-existing. PLP even hired the same engineering firm that Mount Polley hada firm that had rebutted the EPA's findings, stating that dams don't fail. Should the PLP move forward, and the tailings dam fail like Mount Polley, the EPA and the American public will be saddled with one of the largest man-made disasters ever. The Superfund site that would arise would take hundreds of years to clean up, destroying the local economy of Bristol Bay. 

In a time when organizations across the country are desperately trying to save the last surviving runs of salmon in the lower 48 states, one of the worst actions the EPA could take is to permit yet another salmon run be destroyed. Almost half (46%) of the world's salmon harvest each year comes from Bristol Bay. It supports 14,000 jobs and is worth an estimated $1.5 billion annually. And it is the sustaining force behind 4,000 year old native Alaskan cultures that continue rely on Bristol Bay's natural plenty to survive. If left unmolested, that economy can continue to generate money year after year. Whereas the PLP has a lifetime of less than fifty years and will leave the region unable to generate money after the mine has closed. 

Please, for the sake of future generations of Americans, do not allow the PLP to move forward and develop the Bristol Bay area.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment: On U.S. soil we have made mistake after mistake concerning our wild salmon fisheries.  The science and research on salmon fisheries shows that hatcheries and poor water quality are a direct detriment to healthy populations of wild Pacific salmonids.  A mine the size of the proposed Pebble Mine in Bristol Bay will directly destroy the greatest Sockeye Salmon fishery that is left on U.S. soil.  The Pebble Mine will only make a few corporate CEOs more wealthy, whereas the salmon fishery in Bristol Bay directly supports thousands of people who use it for recreation, sustenance, and tourism.  Maintaining this fishery in its natural condition will continue to benefit millions of people in the future.  It is not only the fishery that is at risk, but the economy and ecology of the region.  Many species (flora and fauna) depend on Pacific salmon returning annually for nutrition, and without these historic Sockeye Salmon returns the ecology of the watershed will certainly perish.  This fishery provides practically infinite resources in its natural condition, but can be destroyed in a short time by a mine that will only benefit a few for a finite resource.  We have the opportunity and knowledge to make the right decision in favor of the environment, not industry.  Let's make history by making the right decision to not withdraw Clean Water Act protections in Bristol Bay.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I am opposed to EPAs proposal to rescind the 2014 Proposed Determination designed to protect Bristol Bays world class fisheries. Please stand with American jobs and communities and preserve the Bristol Bay Proposed Determination.

Bristol Bay, Alaska, is one of America's last great wild salmon fisheries. Each year, tens of millions of wild salmon return, supporting upwards of 14,000 jobs in the commercial and sport fishing industries, and serving as a one-in-a-lifetime destination for anglers from around the world as well as the cultural cornerstone for the region's communities. These long-established businesses are at risk from a foreign-owned mining company that wants to build the proposed Pebble Mine, which is opposed by more than 65 percent of Alaskans and more than 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents. 

In 2014, led by Alaska Native Tribes, interests including commercial fishing business owners and sportsmen asked the EPA step in to ensure that this mine wouldn't jeopardize Bristol Bay. The EPA responded by listening to over 1.5 million Americans, hosting dozens of community meetings, reviewing Pebble's many detailed filings with state and federal agencies, and conducting a twice peer-reviewed scientific assessment of the potential impacts to the region. Withdrawing the proposed determination ignores the overwhelming majority of Alaskans and puts the short-term interests of a foreign mining company above thousands of local jobs. 

For the sake of our wildlife, waterways, and communities, I urge you to protect Bristol Bay and prevent this horrible open-pit mine from destroying one of our nation's most precious ecosystems.

The reality is that had the west had better ecosystem practices, we would have better salmon runs akin to salmon runs of decades ago making fish a larger industry than the ones it competes against.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment: The July 2014 Proposed Determination should not be withdrawn.  It seems to me that withdrawing this Proposed Determination in order to remove any perceived uncertainty about PLPs ability to submit a permit application and have it reviewed is at best short sighted and inefficient and at worst a political attempt to remove the possibility of restrictions in this critical, pristine and sensitive watershed.  Since both processes can occur at the same time there is no reason to withdraw the Proposed Determination.  Both processes should be allowed to proceed congruently on their own.  Thus once the Proposed Determination process is completed the Army Corps of Engineers can be ready to issue a final decision on the permit at that time.

Title: Comment submitted by R. N. Stocker
Comment:
I thought the Pebble Mine issue was dead. It certainly should be. But here I am today asking you to 
not withdraw the Bristol Bay Proposed Determination, which was made pursuant to the Clean Water Act in 2014.

Bristol Bay, Alaska, is one of America's last great wild salmon fisheries. As I understand the proposal,  waters in the bay would be protected by a tailings impoundment created by the biggest dam ever constructed. That impoundment and others would have to hold back 10 billion tons of sulfide waste - sulfuric acid, mercury, arsenic, lead, zinc, cadmium, and other poisons. Because sulfide waste lasts forever, it would have to be contained forever. In a seismic zone prone to major earthquakes!

I live in Colorado. Here we know how ineffective mining companies are at containing toxic waste for perpetuity. The inadvertent release of even a small percentage of toxic waste from the Pebble Mine would make the the Gold King Mine disaster, which spilled 3 million gallons of waste water and tailings including cadmium, lead, arsenic, beryllium, zinc, and copper into the Animas River, seem like a walk in the park on a sunny afternoon.

Speaking of parks, within the area influenced by Bristol Bay's watershed and threatened by the mine are: two national parks; four national wildlife refuges; a national monument; a state park; eight state-protected areas; five critical-habitat areas; two game refuges; a state wildlife sanctuary; three federal Steller's eider critical habitat units; two Western Hemispheric Shorebird Reserve Network sites; and at least eight other sites of equal importance to shorebirds. How much sulfide waste would it take to turn these places of natural beauty into ecological disaster areas? We don't want to find out.

Then there is the question of jobs. The tens of millions of wild salmon that return to Bristol Bay each year support upwards of 14,000 American jobs in the commercial and sport fishing industries. Even a small amount of pollution from the Pebble Mine would be enough to destroy these fishing industries. 

The late Senator Ted Stevens got it right: "It is the wrong mine for the wrong place."

Please do not withdraw the proposed determination.

Thank you for considering my comments.

Sincerely yours,
Robert N. Stocker
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Robert N. Stocker
Comment: The Clean Water Act has protected Bristol Bay's watershed for years. The Pebble Project would decimate the watershed and marine life living there. Half of the world's sockeye salmon is supplied from Bristol Bay's sustainable fishery. Thousands of people would lose their jobs and tens of millions of fish and other creatures would die if the Pebble Project were allowed to continue. In addition to being their livelihood, the salmon have great cultural significance for the Yup'ik people of Bristol Bay. The Pebble Limited Partnership isn't even an American company. American industries manage to crush or ignore so many efforts to preserve the environment. I can't believe the EPA is even considering dealing with foreign companies. No amount of copper, gold, or molybdenum is worth that amount of destruction. The people of Bristol Bay and of Alaska have made it clear how they feel about the project. If Scott Pruitt wouldn't accept 15 square miles of foreign mining operations in his hometown, then he shouldn't accept it anywhere.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
Bristol Bay is geographically a different place.  It has been much more isolated from development than many parts of Alaska.  Shoals, sandbars and shallows, along with high winds and the eighth most extreme tides in the world make it difficult for large ships to navigate.  This isolation has allowed fish to maintain their health and abundance.  Bristol Bay is one of the outstanding salmon fisheries left in the world.  Every year salmon fishing, for both commerce and sport, brings about $310 million to Alaska. This flow of healthy food and Alaskan income can continue for the foreseeable future if we don't interfere with it. 

The world's human population is exploding.  This is putting pressure already on our ability to feed all people, particularly the ability to get everyone adequate, healthy protein.  The oil in salmon is well known to be good for the cardiovascular system.  

No one can say for sure how long salmon would last in Bristol Bay if the Pebble Mine goes forward.  Behind a huge dam would be an unlined lake containing 10 billion tons of such toxic chemicals as sulfuric acid, mercury, arsenic, lead, zinc, and cadmium.  Furthermore, there are many other corporately held mine leases in the region that are currently inactive.  If the Pebble Mine's large corporate owners invested in the infrastructure for their mine, it likely would make it possible for smaller companies to become active on their leases.

The salmon might end through relatively slow attrition, as water is diverted to mining operations and impurities flow through the soil into the water remaining in the rivers.  Or it might end suddenly with the collapse of one of the dams holding back the impounded toxic chemicals that are inevitably a by-product of mining.  Either way, a major source of food for the world and income for Alaska will be lost forever.

No one could say it better than Ted Williams in Audubon Magazine, Nov/Dec 2012:

"What possibly could unite these diverse and in some cases adversarial players in outrage and action: 700 businesses; 700 hunting and angling groups; 77 commercial fishing groups; 200 chefs and restaurant owners; the National Council of Churches, representing 45 million people; major newspapers; leading jewelry retailers; and ultra-conservative legislators?
It would be a plan to gouge and hack the Bristol Bay watershed of southwest Alaska with the continent's biggest strip mine."
Please use your authority under the Clean Water Act to prohibit the proposed construction of the horribly destructive Pebble Mine.   

It would be a plan to gouge and hack the Bristol Bay watershed of southwest Alaska with the continent's biggest strip mine."
