Title: Comment submitted by Bob Keefe, Executive Director, E2
Comment:
October 17, 2017 
 
Water Docket No. EPA-R10-OW- 2017-0369
U.S. Environmental Protection Agency
(Mail Code: 28221T)  
1200 Pennsylvania Ave., N.W.  
Washington, DC 20460
Attention: EPA-R10-OW- 2017-0369 
Email: OW-Docket@epa.gov 
http://www.regulations.gov 
 
Re: Comments on Proposal to Withdraw Proposed Determination to Restrict the Use of an Area as a Disposal Site; Pebble Deposit Area, Southwest Alaska (Docket No. EPA-R10-OW- 2017-0369) 

Dear Administrator Pruitt:
  
On behalf of the members of E2 (Environmental Entrepreneurs), I write today in opposition to EPA's "Proposal to Withdraw Proposed Determination to Restrict the Use of an Area as a Disposal Site; Pebble Deposit Area, Southwest Alaska" (Proposed Withdrawal).  

Environmental Entrepreneurs (E2) is a national, nonpartisan group of business leaders who advocate for policies that are good for the economy and good for the environment. Our members have founded or funded more than 2,500 companies, created more than 600,000 jobs, and manage more than $100 billion in venture and private equity capital. 

In September 2014, E2 wrote to your agency in support of EPA's Proposed Determination that established common-sense restrictions on the proposed Pebble Mine in Bristol Bay, Alaska. Nothing has changed since then. Not the facts; not the science; and not the law.

Bristol Bay supports sustainable commercial, subsistence, and recreational fisheries that are the backbone of the region's economy. It is home to the largest wild sockeye salmon fishery in the world; supplies half of the world's wild sockeye salmon; generates $1.5 billion annually, and supports more than 14,000 jobs.  This year, Bristol Bay celebrated the return of almost 60 million salmon. Integral to that extraordinary run is the environmental sustainability of the regionsomething the proposed Pebble Mine would jeopardize.

After conducting a rigorous three-year, twice-peer reviewed scientific study of the potential impacts of large-scale mining on the Bristol Bay region, EPA determined the Pebble Mine would have "significant" and even "catastrophic" impacts on the region. EPA found that even the smallest mining scenarioa 0.25 billion ton mine (out of over 10 billion tons measured and inferred)would eliminate or dewater at least 4.7 miles of salmon-supporting streams; destroy nearly 24 miles of stream habitat and over 1,200 acres of wetlands, lakes, and ponds; and cause significant streamflow alterations.     

EPA has the unequivocal authority under Section 404(c) of the Clean Water Act to prohibit, restrict, deny, or withdraw the permitting of dredge and fill projects when EPA finds that the discharge "will have an unacceptable adverse effect on municipal water supplies, shellfish beds and fishery areas (including spawning and breeding areas), wildlife, or recreational areas." 

EPA assessed the impacts of three mine sizes, and found that even the smallest one would have "unacceptable adverse effects"the regulatory threshold for 404(c) action. Its Proposed Determination, therefore, applies only to mining proposals of at least 0.25 billion tons, and would allow smaller mining projects to be considered through the standard Army Corps permitting process. This is a sensible approach that places fishand the fishing economyfirst in Bristol Bay.  

EPA has offered no viable rationalebased on facts, science, or lawfor changing its position and withdrawing the Proposed Determination.

As EPA itself acknowledged, Pebble can absolutely submit permit applicationsand the Army Corps can review those permit applicationseven if the Proposed Determination remains in place.  The only uncertainty (or delay) remaining is that brought by the Pebble Partnership itselfby failing, for over a decade, to submit permit applications as repeatedly promised. As Senator Lisa Murkowski wrote: "At least as far back as . . . 2004, [Pebble] asserted that the submission of permit applications was imminent." Yet after over a decade of waiting, "it is anxiety, frustration, and confusion that have become the norm in many communities..." 

For the good of the economy and the environment in the region and beyond, I urge EPA against needlessly adding additional anxiety to the Bristol Bay region by withdrawing the Proposed Determination. Instead, please keep the Proposed Determinationwhich would protect salmon-supporting waters around the Pebble depositin place. Please prioritize preserving the jobs that the Bristol Bay fishery supports over furthering the interests of a foreign mining company. And please bring long-awaited certainty to the business owners and operators who depend on Bristol Bay's clean water and salmon.

Sincerely,

Bob Keefe
Executive Director

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
Like most Americans, including those most directly affected, I am totally opposed to your intention of rescinding the 2014 Proposed Determination designed to protect Bristol Bays world class fisheries. Since being appointed head of the EPA, you have worked only to harm the environment, particularly formerly protected areas, against the wishes of the American people and even against the best economic interests of the country. Please stand instead with American jobs and communities, their physical and financial well-being, preserve the Bristol Bay Proposed Determination and prevent all incursions of corporate polluters like the foreigners trying to build Pebble Mine.

Bristol Bay, Alaska, is one of America's last great wild salmon fisheries, and is invaluable and irreplaceable. Each year, tens of millions of wild salmon return, supporting upwards of 14,000 jobs in the commercial and sport fishing industries, and serving as a unique destination for anglers from around the world as well as the cultural cornerstone for the region's communities. These long-established businesses are at risk from a foreign-owned mining company that wants to build the proposed Pebble Mine, which is opposed by more than 65 percent of Alaskans and more than 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents. Pebble Mine is NOT what Americans want or need - why even consider this proposal?

In 2014, led by Alaska Native Tribes, interests including commercial fishing business owners and sportsmen asked the EPA step in to ensure that this mine wouldn't jeopardize Bristol Bay. The EPA responded by listening to over 1.5 million Americans, hosting dozens of community meetings, reviewing Pebble's many detailed filings with state and federal agencies, and conducting a twice peer-reviewed scientific assessment of the potential impacts to the region. Withdrawing the proposed determination ignores the overwhelming majority of Alaskans and puts the short-term interests of a foreign mining company above thousands of local jobs. Completely anti-American and unpatriotic to support foreign polluters over your own countrymen and your own country.

For the sake of our wildlife, waterways, and communities, I urge you to protect Bristol Bay and prevent this horrible open-pit mine from destroying one of our nation's most precious ecosystems - something that can never be replaced.

Title: Anonymous public comment

Title: Comment submitted by N. Thompson
Comment:
I disagree in the strongest terms possible with the withdrawal of the Proposed Determination to restrict use of South Fork Koktuli River, North Fork Koktuli River, and Upper Talarik Creek watersheds as waste dumps for mining. Putting the world's most intact and productive salmon ecosystem in danger to mine is irresponsible and brings into question what the current administration values in natural resources. There have been myriad examples of tailing pond and waste site failures that have resulted in massive amounts of pollution and contamination to the watersheds they are located in. The Mount Polley mine failure in August of 2014 is what will happen to the Bristol Bay watershed if the Pebble mine is approved.  This I am certain of. Do not allow the mining wastes anywhere near the Bristol Bay watershed, it will eventually destroy the aquatic ecosystem as we currently know it. If the Pebble Partnership would agree to transporting the wastes to a less-ecologically sensitive area that is engineered to a higher level of security (think concrete lined ponds, away from ANY surface water) that would be potentially acceptable. However, waste disposal in the Bristol Bay watershed is an unacceptable risk.

The Bristol Bay salmon fishery can not be replaced or replicated.  It is the premier wild salmon fishery in the world, bar none. Stop reading these comments and go to youtube and search for Bristol Bay sockeye. Look at the images and imagine being on the shores of those rivers and lakes. Those animals have a right to live just as you and I do. Those animals are our food. Those animals are the lifeblood of that regions ecosystem. When the Pebble tailings and mine wastes escape the engineered containment sites all of that life and that ecosystem will be forever changed and primarily exterminated. Salmon and pollution do not mix. Salmon and human development do not mix. Period. 

It is my opinion that the EPA should not revoke, reopen, re-examine or in any other way re-visit the decision to deny the Pebble Mine to use ANY watershed in the Bristol Bay region for mine tailings or mine wastes. It is at best irresponsible and we would be simply waiting to repeat history. The Mt. Polley failure will happen in Bristol Bay if the Pebble Mine is allowed. I am certain of that. Don't let that happen on our watch. Start valuing natural resources over money. You can't eat money. Salmon are delicious. 

Lastly, the Environmental Protection Agency's mission is to ensure :"all Americans are protected from significant risks to human health and the environment where they live, learn and work; national efforts to reduce environmental risk are based on the best available scientific information; environmental protection is an integral consideration in U.S. policies concerning natural resources, human health, economic growth, energy, transportation, agriculture, industry, and international trade, and these factors are similarly considered in establishing environmental policy". Evaluate that mission statement in terms of this proposed mine and waste disposal. I can find only a few benefits from allowing waste disposal in the Bristol Bay watershed and they are all financial, there will be little job creation, there will be little economic growth, there will be little international trade. I see many risks; specifically to Americans living, working and learning in the Bristol Bay watershed. The water will be at risk with toxic mine wastes in the watershed, the salmon and natural resource economy will be highly endangered. The profits generated for a foreign based mining company will be a drop in the bucket compared to the annual economic production of the salmon ecosystem of Bristol Bay. Don't let history repeat itself, learn from the mistakes humans have previously made. Mining and salmon do not co-exist; salmon always lose. Don't let that happen here and now. The Bristol Bay salmon ecosystem is too important and the only intact wild salmon ecosystem left. Don't keep destroying nature, we depend on it for our lives. 

Sincerely,
Neil Thompson, Ph.D.

Subject: Preserve Bristol Bay

Please DO NOT withdraw the proposed determination to adopt restrictions protecting the habitat of Bristol Bay's world-renowned salmon.
We must speak up and do whatever it takes to protect our earth, it's animals and our precious ecosystem. Title: Comment submitted by C. Tuohy
Comment:
To Whom it may concern,

Please do not reverse the determination that the Pebble Mine poses to too great a risk to the Bristol Bay ecosystem and it's fishery to be considered. For four generations my family has fished for salmon from the shore of our family cabin on Whidbey Island. Now my children want to do the same, but the fish are fewer now as the salmon struggle for survival in the waters of Puget Sound. Unfortunately, our wild salmon in Washington State are threatened from years of bad management by an agency more interested in industry interests than the long term sustainably of this valuable resource. When will we stop putting industry interests before the needs of American citizens?  The Bristol Bay fishery has been the exception: it has been sustainably managed since humans inhabited the region. It is the jewel of the Pacific Northwest and provides thousands of  jobs.  

The proposed construction of this mine is an ecological nightmare and a short-sighted economic mistake. Bristol Bay provides thousands of jobs and millions of dollars annually to the U.S economy; the resource is 100% renewable. These impressive figures do not include great benefits to society from an intact ecosystem and maintenance of a resource with substantial cultural and spiritual importance. Pebble mine may provide short-term economic benefit, but long term this is a foolish mistake from an economic, ecological, social, and historical perspective. 

Construction of this mine risk's the preservation of our world's last great salmon fishery. We cannot risk the loss of something this priceless. Our nation has destroyed nearly every other salmon fishery in the lower 48, and the loss of this great fishery would forever erase a livelihood that has defined the Pacific Northwest since history was first recorded in this region. Please understand the basic economics behind this: Pebble Mine may result in some short-term economic benefit; however, the long-lasting nature of its toxic legacy will inevitably destroy our last renewable salmon fishery, worth hundreds of millions of dollars. Do not repeat history and do not ignore the long-term economic benefits of protecting Bristol Bay form short-sighted corporate demands. It may be our last hope to sustain this resource for future generations.

Sincerely,
Craig Tuohy

Title: Comment submitted by T. Crawford
Comment:
October 17th 2017

Administrator E. Scott Pruitt Dear Administrator Pruitt,

There are so many things wrong with this. It is horrifying that you are tapping this region of Alaska for fossil fuels, instead of creating clean energy. You are destroying pristine habitat in one of the last remaining wild places in North America. You are leaving this destruction for our children to clean up. When will the greed end?

I write in support of the communities of Alaska's Bristol Bay and ask you not to withdraw the proposed determination to adopt restrictions protecting the habitat of Bristol Bay's world-renowned salmon.The proposed determination was made at the request of local communities and adopted only after years of rigorous scientific study, public participation and peer review. The EPA was correct in 2014 when it found that the Pebble Mine would have "significant and unacceptable adverse effects" on "one of the most productive,pristine, valuable and vulnerable ecosystems remaining in North America today."

The EPA has noted that commercial fishing in Bristol Bay generates $300 million annually in direct sales of commercially caught salmon, generating 11,000 jobs. These salmon support not only the commercial and sportfishing industries, but a traditional Native way of life that has endured for millennia and thrives today.

I just recently returned from a hunting trip to Bristol Bay area (Egegik) and was left with a feeling of awe surrounding this truly wild place. Walking across a river and feeling the salmon bounce of your leg on their journey upstream is something not commonly fealt anywhere in the world OTHER than Alaska. Watching Brown Bears fish, wolves patrolling the edges of the tundra and lovesick moose calling from their hidden place in the willows was an experience I will never forget and one I hope to share with my son some day...mining these wild lands for profit is nothing short of a travesty...

The EPA should stand by its proposed determination and take all necessary actions to protect the Bristol Bay watershed.


Sincerely,

Todd Crawford
2494 NE Jackson School Rd
Hillsboro, Oregon 97124

crayfin@gmail.com

Please do not withdraw the clean water restrictions. Establishing a mine in Bristol Bay will have devastating effects on the surrounding ecosystem as well as the local economy. 

It is a sad truth that sustainable, healthy, and valuable ecosystems are becoming more and more scarce these days, and it would be nothing short of a travesty if Bristol Bay were to become yet another destroyed landscape in a long list of destroyed landscapes, all because those in power couldn't pull their heads out of their butts long enough to recognize the unquestionable priority that protecting the environment and local communities takes over accruing wealth and power.

Please stand by your original determination and protect Bristol Bay.

-Annie T

Title: Comment submitted by D. A. Jacobsen
Comment:
Hello.  I worked in a salmon cannery office in Naknek, Alaska for 10 summers, so I know firsthand the power of the largest sockeye salmon run in the world.  It is invaluable to Alaska's economy and is vital for Alaskan native communities as well as to people who travel from all over the world to work in the fishing profession.   We must also preserve this area to protect the unique and awe-inspiring wilderness of Bristol Bay that could be destroyed by Pebble Mine.  

I urge you to visit Bristol Bay the first week of July to witness the massive salmon run at its peak.  I urge you to protect the rivers that have nurtured salmon and humans for thousands of years.  PLEASE DO NOT ALLOW PEBBLE MINE TO CONTINUE OPERATIONS THAT WOULD JEOPARDIZE AND DESTROY THE ANCIENT RITUAL of THE BRISTOL BAY SALMON RUN AND WAY OF LIFE.  It can never be replaced and would be one of the worst environmental disasters in the world.   I would not want participating in its demise on my conscience. I hope you don't, either.  Sincerely, Deborah Andrews Jacobsen

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
Oh good heavens! Is this thing still alive? There is not an American company who bid on this. They are foreign ones who are interested only in profits. 

Consider this: 
In April 2012 at a public meeting in Kodiak, Alaska, one of the two company-employed marine Master's degree level biologists had the nerve, or ignorance, to say, and I paraphrase:
'The fish only go up 50 to 75 miles to spawn. The mine tailings will be 100 to 150 miles upstream.' I so wanted to say, And if there is a leak, the water containing the heavy elements will not flow downstream?' but I couldn't think how to say that without sarcasm. 

Here is a poem I wrote, and am reading at public events where I've been invited to read some of my writings.

To Make Me Angry, by Abigail B. Calkin

To make me angry
Tell me earthquakes take right angle turns
Tell me earthquakes do not occur within the Ring of Fire
Tell me tailings or slimes, leach residue or gangue
stop before they reach spawning grounds. 
Tell me these waters will contain no trace minerals 
after you greedy pebbles mine the muskeg. 
Tell me Kvichak River has a gate that stops the gangue
from ever entering the spawning grounds. 
Insure us for the millions of dollars of fish lost each year,
each year for 500 years. 
Insure us for the boats of Bristol Bay that crumble in decay.
Insure us for these boats that will resemble
Caspian Sea skeletons
beached and bedraggled relics of land, life, and livelihood
lost to the tides of foreign grubbers. 

Three-fourths of hundreds of years of sustainable jobs will drown
in favor of tens of jobs for thirty years of mining. 
Miners compare these lands to Elko, Nevada. Folks, 
Elko is flat and dry with four percent marsh where wells 
can be a thousand feet deep.  
From Iliamna to the head of Bristol Bay it's muskeg, a bog, a swamp
where square miles of water lie on the surface. 
Do not compare mining Elko to mining Iliamna.
Do not tell me tectonic plates don't move
Do not tell me there will be no volcanoes, no earthquakes
Do not tell me your manmade earthen dams will hold
for a thousand years.  
Do not steal centuries of fish for decades of metal.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
It is absolutely appalling that you are using the EPA to not only loosen protections on the world we live in, but getting into bed with Big Business polluters to allow an open pit mine in Bristol Bay, cancelling the 2014 protections they so desperately needed.  This action to recind is in direct conflict with the word Protection in the EPA.

Along with many other patriotic citizens, I am opposed to EPAs proposal to rescind the 2014 Proposed Determination designed to protect Bristol Bays world class fisheries. Please stand with American jobs and communities and preserve the Bristol Bay Proposed Determination.

You will be stripping jobs from fishermen and associated businesses. This is no way to make America Great, suckering up to private financial interests and those of your friends. As Trump would say, It Is Disgusting!

 Bristol Bay, Alaska, is one of America's last great wild salmon fisheries. Each year, tens of millions of wild salmon return, supporting upwards of 14,000 jobs in the commercial and sport fishing industries, and serving as a one-in-a-lifetime destination for anglers from around the world as well as the cultural cornerstone for the region's communities. These long-established businesses are at risk from a foreign-owned mining company that wants to build the proposed Pebble Mine, which is opposed by more than 65 percent of Alaskans and more than 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents. 

In 2014, led by Alaska Native Tribes, interests including commercial fishing business owners and sportsmen asked the EPA step in to ensure that this mine wouldn't jeopardize Bristol Bay. The EPA responded by listening to over 1.5 million Americans, hosting dozens of community meetings, reviewing Pebble's many detailed filings with state and federal agencies, and conducting a twice peer-reviewed scientific assessment of the potential impacts to the region. Withdrawing the proposed determination ignores the overwhelming majority of Alaskans, and puts the short-term interests of a foreign mining company above thousands of local jobs. 

For the sake of our wildlife, waterways, and communities, I urge you to protect Bristol Bay and prevent this horrible open-pit mine from destroying one of our nation's most precious ecosystems.

I am in opposition to the proposition to withdraw the Clean Water Act. I'm concerned for the environmental and economical impacts (by impacting the largest salmon run in the world in Bristol Bay) that mining endeavors and other intensively polluting industries would have on the safety of our water, oceans, and on our food source of the salmon & other sea life. We need regulations in place to protect the health & safety of the water & environment which directly impacts the health & safety of our families and communities. We are in a critical time where we need to be focusing efforts on reducing every possible avenue that contributes to polluting the land, water, air - ultimately all of which are contributing to climate change, which directly effects our potential for survival on this planet.

Title: Comment submitted by D. Allen
Comment:
To Whom it May Concern:

I strongly support the EPA's WITHDRAWAL of the Proposed Determination against the Pebble Mine Project. 

Pebble Limited Partnership (PLP) has invested $750M+ in good faith. They have followed the law and consistently tried to meet their many regulatory, legal and environmental obligations to the region and the State of Alaska to the highest standards asked and required of them. It is now EPA's turn to also follow the law and act in good faith.
 
The Pebble Project is on State of Alaska land designated for mineral exploration and development and that land has been the subject of at least two democratically approved land-use assessments by the state which have reinforced and informed PLP's right to invest in, and advance the project.
  
If the United States prides itself on being governed by the "rule of law", then it is imperative that this project be properly evaluated on the basis of the whole record using the legislatively mandated permitting process under the National Environmental Policy Act. During NEPA an Environmental Impact Statement must be completed and this EIS will properly assess all of the impacts that the proposed project may have. It is important to remember three things: 

First, during the legally-mandated permitting process no harm will come to the environment. 

Second, PLP is only asking for the right to prove that their project deserves a permit, not a guarantee that it will be granted. PLP knows that there is a due-process and that they must perform to the well-established standards of the process or they risk failure in their effort to secure the right to proceed. 

Third, as part of the permitting process PLP must prove that it can mitigate whatever impacts its project may have on wetlands and fish habitat. PLP claims that they can indeed mitigate their impacts. The only proper "rule-of-law" framework in which to properly assess the validity of their claims is the proven, legally mandated, NEPA process.  

Again, Pebble Partnership is not asking for a predetermination in their favor but an assurance that there will be a fair and transparent vetting of the whole record to evaluate the prospective project based on its merits as governed by the legally mandated NEPA process. For EPA to preemptively deny PLP this legal right to exhaustively make its case, is a clear violation of the principals of fairness, rule-of-law and due process. 

I appreciate the opportunity to comment on this proposal.
Sincerely,
Doug Allen

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I am writing to express my opposition to the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) plan to withdraw the Proposed Determination for Bristol Bay published in 2014. There is no scientific or legal justification to withdraw those protections.

The Clean Water Act was designed to protect our nation's valuable watersheds - for healthy drinking water, for fisheries, for recreation. Section 404(c) gives the EPA the specific authority to protect these valuable watersheds, regardless of the stage in the permitting process. And the EPA has used that authority 13 times - and 12 were under Republican administrations (eight under Reagan). 

The Bristol Bay fishery is too valuable of an American resource to jeopardize in order to allow a Canadian mining firm to withdraw resources, take the benefits of those resources out of the country, and leave behind the long-term ecological and economic costs to be borne by the people of the Bristol Bay region, Alaska, and the rest of the United States.

I agree with the EPA's finding that mining activity in the Bristol Bay watershed poses unacceptable risks to the Bristol Bay salmon fishery. If approved, the Pebble Mine would be the largest mine of its type in North America. The mine itself would cover up to 6.9 square miles, with an 18 square mile wastewater pond to store the 10 billion tons of potentially toxic waste the mine is expected to generate.  It isn't just the potential for an irreversible environmental catastrophe that is driving widespread opposition to the Pebble Mine. As of 2009, the Bristol Bay watershed generated hundreds of millions of dollars in economic activity annually and 14,000 jobs, primarily in the fishing industry. All of that could be at risk if the disastrous Pebble Mine project is allowed to move forward.

Please move forward with a Final Determination on the proposed Pebble Mine under Section 404(c) of the Clean Water Act without delay.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment: I am submitting a comment in support of not withdrawing the proposed determination by the EPA under the Clean Water Act, as well as voicing support for review and reconsideration if the proposed determination is withdrawn.  It is my understanding that the PLP wants to store mining waste from processing gold and copper ore, in a pristine watershed in Bristol Bay, Alaska; home to the most productive wild sockeye salmon fishery in the world.  This mining waste would be stored in a seismically active zone, forever, behind a human engineered structure.  Engineers can never be sure about the stability of their structures under future circumstances, and there are multiple instances where tailings dams have failed in other parts of the world.  These previous engineering failures would not make the failure of the PLP tailings dam a one off, impossible to believe occurrence.  What I would like the PLP to consider, is transporting the mined material offsite to process, and therefore store the waste in an environment where the failure of the containment system would not be so environmentally damaging as destroying an entire fishery.  In the cases where the dams in other parts of the world (eg Brazil) have failed, massive die-offs of the fish in the affected rivers were observed.  This would be the immediate concern, but the damage to the habitat that supports such a large, renewable, sustainable means of feeding people in the world would be unthinkable.  56.5 million salmon (2nd highest amount in the last 20 years) returned to Bristol Bay this year (2017); if the proposed determination is withdrawn, that number could decrease to zero.  The mined resource is valuable, but the salmon in this case are more valuable, and I do not believe that PLP should be given the chance to meddle in this pristine habitat.  It is much easier to prevent something, then try to restore and fix it once damage has occurred.  Pebble has promised some jobs during the construction of the mine, but eventually, fewer people will be needed for daily operations, so the long term effect on the rural Alaska economy will not be as great as promised.  These temporary jobs will also come at the potential expense of 14,000 fisherman/processing/transport/supplier jobs related to the fishery that happens in Bristol Bay EVERY SUMMER.  We are able to eat high quality, nutritious, sustainable fish from this area, with no inputs to the system.  EVERY SUMMER fisherman go out to fish, and EVERY SUMMER there are fish.  This will keep happening for centuries to come if we continue to preserve and prioritize the pristine habitat that is the headlands of the Bristol Bay watershed.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I am writing you today to ask that you stand with American jobs and communities and not withdraw the EPA's Bristol Bay Proposed Determination, which it made pursuant to the Clean Water Act in 2014.

Bristol Bay, Alaska, supports the world's largest and most valuable salmon fisheries and is one of America's last sustainable wild salmon fisheries. Tens of millions of wild salmon return annually, which support upwards of 14,000 American jobs in the commercial and sport fishing industries, serve as a one-in-a-lifetime destination for anglers from around the world, and are the cultural cornerstone for the region's communities.

These long-established American businesses and jobs are at risk from a foreign-owned mining company that wants to build the proposed Pebble Mine, which is opposed by more than 65 percent of Alaskans and more than 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents. Pebble Mine is a threat to local economies and our country's natural resources.

In 2010, led by Alaska Native Tribes, interests including commercial fishing business owners and sportsmen asked the EPA step in to ensure that this mine wouldn't jeopardize Bristol Bay. The EPA responded by listening to over 1.5 million Americans, hosting dozens of community meetings, reviewing Pebble's many detailed filings with state and federal agencies, and conducting a twice peer-reviewed scientific assessment of the potential impacts to the region.

Withdrawing the proposed determination ignores the overwhelming majority of Alaskans and puts the short-term interests of a foreign mining company above thousands of American jobs. 

Please protect Bristol Bay and do not withdraw the proposed determination.

Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
The EPA should move forward with its Proposed Determination (PD) under Clean Water Act Section 404(c) to protect the Bristol Bay Watershed. While mining is necessary to support our current lifestyles, large scale mining operations should not be located in the sensitive and unique ecosystems of Bristol Bay. There are two compelling reasons for this:

First, EPA should move forward using the scientific information that it has gathered to support this PD.
The EPA conducted a thorough, multiyear scientific investigation of the Bristol Bay Watershed and potential impacts from the proposal(s) by Northern Dynasty to mine the Pebble Deposit. Based on the projected impacts of a mine far smaller than those proposed to the company's investors, EPA concluded that mining operations would cause unacceptable adverse effects on fish and animal habitats in the Bristol Bay Watershed.  Consider the 29 species of fish, 40 terrestrial mammals and 190 species of birds that would be impacted; the losses of streams and wetlands; and the contamination of the land and water.  The magnitude of the projected environmental impacts are well documented in EPA's peer reviewed report, and these losses will be irreversible. The largest sockeye salmon fishery in the world will be destroyed forever, and the livelihood of those that depend on the salmon will also be destroyed. I worked in the Bristol Bay fishery over 40 years ago. Through careful management the fishery exists today and will continue to provide jobs well into the future. Although a reduced size mining proposal has been offered, there is no guarantee it won't be enlarged. Subsequent to working in Alaska, I worked on the cleanup of abandoned mines in the western United States, I have seen the environmental destruction caused by the waste left behind and lack of long term management of these wastes. The Bristol Bay watershed is too important to the world's salmon supply to allow a mine to go forward in this sensitive watershed.

Second, EPA should move forward on this PD because it already followed an extensive public process on this matter, and it is a complete waste of government resources to ignore the existing scientific work and its conclusions and to begin a new project review process.

 EPA provided opportunities for public comment on two draft scientific assessments, which generated hundreds of thousands of comments. The current proposed to withdraw the PD is essentially waste, fraud and abuse of the Agency's procedures and its resources.  The EPA followed the Clean Water Act and its procedures.  In fact, EPA went above and beyond   the required procedures and offered two draft reports for public comment prior to publishing its final assessment. Administrator Pruitt, as reported in several newspapers, concluded that the PD should be withdrawn after meeting with advocates for the Pebble Mine. The Administrator has provided no information or evidence as to why the existing scientific assessment is flawed; in fact, to the contrary, the Administration states that the mining companies should have an opportunity to submit proposals and conduct environmental impact statements and as such, a fair process for moving forward. The process to date - with EPA's publication of the Final Bristol Bay Assessment in January 2014 -- was a fair process and compliant with the Clean Water Act. The existing EPA assessment is a thorough and legitimate basis for moving forward with the Clean Water Act 404(c) protections. 

Thank you for consideration of these comments.

Title: Comment submitted by Z. Kilmer
Comment:
Administrator Pruitt,

I am writing in regards to the potential withdrawal of the previously proposed determination to restrict the Pebble Mine's use of the Bristol Bay watershed as its disposal site. By withdrawing this determination, the EPA will be undoubtedly exposing one of the worlds greatest migrations of a wild species to an immense risk. And consequently disregarding the livelihood of the thousands of people who rely on this migration for their wellbeing and prosperity. 

When exploring the success of Pacific Salmon throughout the western coast of the United States, it is clear that human involvement in the area has significantly reduced the size and strength of Salmon migrations in California, Oregon, and Washington. This being simply due to the disturbance caused by human infrastructure and presence in an ecosystem; regardless of the occurrence of large scale polluting events due to infrastructure failure. However, with little human disturbances at hand, Alaska's Salmon runs remain in a primitive state providing the entire world with one of the last wild sources of consumer food products. Protecting this fragile ecosystem from human intervention is vital in insuring the presence of the species for generations to come

Secondly, a major selling of the point of the Pebble Mine is the employment that it will bring to the area. While true, this creates a major friction point in my opinion. By allowing Pebble Mine to operate in this area, you are simply holding the jobs of mining workers and those profiting off of the unprecedented volume of geologic material to a higher importance than those involved in the fishing industry and who have been living off of the products of the land for centuries. 

As both a research scientist in Earth's systems and resources and a commercial fisherman, I can not in words express my grave concern of the consequences that will result from the withdrawal of the original proposed determination. I there for ask the Environmental Protection Agency, as a voice to the prosperity of our nations wild places, to stand for the ecological success of this impeccable watershed instead of simply seeing its products as a momentary value worth taking. 

Thank you for your time and consideration,


Zoe Kilmer
Oregon State University 
Corvallis, Oregon
kilmerz@oregonstate.edu

Title: Comment submitted by N. Morgan
Comment:
Hello,

I am here to tell you that the creation of the Pebble Creek Mine, one of the world's largest proposed copper mines, would mean the utter destruction of one of the world's largest wild salmon runs. Destroying this population is a fact that 3 years of scientific data showed would happen if a 404 permit to release waste water from the mine is granted. Copper destroys the salmon sense of direction and "smell". That is scientific fact. Creating the worlds largest open pit mine would put a nail in the largest sockeye salmon runs. 13 tribes opposed the creation of the Pebble Creek mine because over 14,000 workers would be unemployed from the collapsed industry. Alaska's native salmon runs would collapse and lead to economic disaster.

The EPA administrator reversed the injunction without even reading the scientific reports on the effects of the mine. Do not withdraw the proposed determination to restrict use. Doing so will destroy 56 million sockeye salmon and a way of life for Alaskans.

Thank you,
Nathan Morgan

Title: Comment submitted by M. Dischner
Comment:
Dear Mr. Pruitt,

I've lived in Dillingham for 2.5 years, but I've opposed Pebble from afar for more than a decade. I was excited to move to a place where people fought to protect salmon, and where we believed that the federal government was willing to listen to Tribes and take a stand in favor of protecting wild salmon, pristine lands, and the cultures that rely on them. I was excited to move to a place where I believed the salmon would keep returning, just as they always have.

But this year, when the EPA moved to withdraw the protections, some of that excitement was taken away. Because EPA's move could open up Bristol Bay to be just another mining district. Another place where the federal government has ignored its trust responsibility to listen to the people, instead favoring foreign mining companies. PLEASE CHANGE THIS COURSE OF ACTION.

Bristol Bay is America's last great wild salmon fishery. Annual returns of tens of millions of wild salmon return to support more than 14,000 American jobs in the commercial and sport fishing industries. They are the cultural cornerstone for the region's Yup'ik, Dena'ina, and Alutiq indigenous peoples, whose salmon-based cultures have thrived in Bristol Bay for thousands of years. Over half the world's wild sockeye salmon supply, an indigenous way of life, and long-established American businesses and jobs are at risk from the foreign-owned proposed Pebble Mine. 

Please do not withdraw or rescind the Proposed Determination for Docket EPA-R10-OW-2017-0369. Instead, please finalize the protections for the last great wild-sockeye salmon fishery on the planet.

Quyana!

Molly Dischner

Please abide by the conclusions that your own agency came to, or provide us with new analyses which show that there are flaws in the previous work.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
Hello,

I am writing to express my opposition to the proposed withdrawal of the EPA in the Bristol Bay Area.  I am a fisheries biologist and have extensively studied aquatic sciences for years, so please take my comments with sincerity and credibility. 

The most important part of understanding ecosystems is understanding that everything within the food web is connected either directly or indirectly, and a minor disturbance or introduction of a contaminant (for example, sediment runoff from mining) could cascade through the food web with catastrophic effects. If a river system becomes contaminated by heavy sediment, it will fill in and destroy valuable spawning habitat for several fish species. If those species can't reproduce, their numbers will decline rapidly, and another species that depends on those species for food will also die out. Chances are, there is another species that needs that species that died out from starvation, and so on. Eventually mining contaminants will at some point negatively affect the salmon, which happens to be a VERY important food source and income source for the majority of people in that area. That is just one example of the cascading effects. I am not writing to give an entire ecology lecture, but I do want to stress that protecting this area from mine contaminants could protect way more than just some random tiny fish that most people have never heard of nor care about. 

The majority of people don't seem to understand or care about a problem until it is directly in their backyard, and the way we prevent those problems from happening is by starting with the small things like protecting clean water. By doing so, we save peoples' food sources, way of life, and income, not to mention the extensive list of fish and wildlife species that depend on Bristol Bay for survival. This is an issue bigger than ourselves, and we need to take action to protect what truly matters.

Thank you for your time.

To Whom It May Concern:

There is overwhelming scientific evidence indicating that the development of this mine, even on the smallest scale that the Pebble partnership has proposed, would be drastically harmful to the sockeye salmon runs of Bristol Bay.

Regarding the decision to withdraw the restrictions, Tom Collier, the CEO of the Pebble Partnership, said that "It's not a science decision, its a process decision." I disagree. There is not a tradeoff with the results of this decision, whether the salmon runs remain intact or the mine is completed are mutually exclusive. If the Pebble mine is developed the sockeye salmon runs and pristine landscape of Bristol Bay will cease to exist as we know it. Do not withdraw the restrictions.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
Ask Canada, a country with a depth of experience dealing with extractive industry.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mount_Polley_mine_disaster

The Mount Polley mine disaster is an environmental disaster in the Cariboo region of central British Columbia, Canada, that
began 4 August 2014 with a breach of the Imperial Metals-owned Mount Polley copper and gold mine tailings pond, releasing
its water and slurry with years worth of mining waste into Polley Lake. Imperial Metals had a history of operating the pond
beyond capacity since at least 2011. The spill flooded Polley Lake, its outflow Hazeltine Creek, and continued into nearby
Quesnel Lake and Cariboo River.

.... a "slurry of toxic water and mud" continued to pour into the once pristine Quesnel Lake, the cleanest deep water lake
in the world. By the end of the day the four square kilometres sized tailings pond was "virtually empty". Mine safety experts
and media articles have called the spill one of the biggest environmental disasters in modern Canadian history.

Anyone who says this won't/can't happen with Pebble is a liar or a fool.

Title: Comment submitted by M. G. Sims
Comment:
To:  Administrator E. Scott Pruitt

October 17, 2017

Dear Mr. Pruitt,

I cannot comprehend any reason on earth that justifies destroying irrevocably the pristine natural resource that is Bristol Bay, Alaska. Bristol Bay's preservation free of industry and pollution is crucial to the continuing health, for generations to come, of our people, our environment, our water, the wild Alaska salmon whose spawning ground is located here and the thriving industry that depends on this wildlife

What is it that you are going to gain that is so valuable to you that it warrants this nuclear-grade level and scope of annihilation of such a treasured, useful and healthily productive area of our environment?

And consider, as a food source, the wild Alaskan salmon who spawn here.  Pregnant women need to eat a substantial amount of Omega-3 fats (found in wild salmon) which is crucial to infant brain development. Wild Alaskan salmon is an excellent, dependable source of this nutrient that is vital to the continuing health and well-being of generations of Americans to come. I have deep and grave concerns that my grandchildren and their children may not be able to eat confidently anywhere in this country, knowing that their food sources and their water supplies are free of manufacturing toxic runoffs

At the present time, not only pregnant women but all of us are cautioned not to eat Atlantic salmon. Why?  Because it's already polluted by mercury from manufacturing toxin runoff!  

Is this a reasonable trade-off? A perpetually contaminating mine and additional income to the owners of the Pebble Mine versus the health of the American people and their environment--for the ages?  

I say no contest. Cancel the Pebble Mine deal, save the environment and our health, and be remembered as a visionary patriot who took the long view on behalf of our country and all who of us who live here.

Please restore the restrictions  previously set in place to protect Bristol Bay from any mining. I thank you for reading my comment.

Sincerely, 
Mary G. Sims
3774 State Route 31, Apt 1507
Liverpool, NY  13090
Tel:  315-622-3167
Email:  MGS24L@aol.com

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I am opposed to EPAs proposal to rescind the 2014 Proposed Determination designed to protect Bristol Bays world class fisheries. Please stand with American jobs and communities and preserve the Bristol Bay Proposed Determination.In coming years may you recall whether the protections provided by the EPA or your rejection of them 
by destroying our environment (OUR FUTURE), even though it may well be too late.!

Bristol Bay, Alaska, is one of America's last great wild salmon fisheries. Each year, tens of millions of wild salmon return, supporting upwards of 14,000 jobs in the commercial and sport fishing industries, and serving as a one-in-a-lifetime destination for anglers from around the world as well as the cultural cornerstone for the region's communities. These long-established businesses are at risk from a foreign-owned mining company that wants to build the proposed Pebble Mine, which is opposed by more than 65 percent of Alaskans and more than 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents. 

In 2014, led by Alaska Native Tribes, interests including commercial fishing business owners and sportsmen asked the EPA step in to ensure that this mine wouldn't jeopardize Bristol Bay. The EPA responded by listening to over 1.5 million Americans, hosting dozens of community meetings, reviewing Pebble's many detailed filings with state and federal agencies, and conducting a twice peer-reviewed scientific assessment of the potential impacts to the region. Withdrawing the proposed determination ignores the overwhelming majority of Alaskans and puts the short-term interests of a foreign mining company above thousands of local jobs. 

For the sake of our wildlife, waterways, and communities, I urge you to protect Bristol Bay and prevent this horrible open-pit mine from destroying one of our nation's most precious ecosystems.

Bristol Bay represents the largest salmon fishery in the United States, and provides thousands of jobs across the entire region. These jobs are not "boom and bust" as are mining jobs--the fishery jobs are generational, promising employment decade after decade.  As well, the fish themselves provide food for millions of people across the world, most notably in the United States.

Meanwhile, mining has a tragic and terrible environmental record, leaving vast areas contaminated, always leaving taxpayers to pay the bills for "cleanup" long after the minerals are taken and the mining companies have left.  Every mine, even in modern history has resulted in significant environmental degradation that taxpayers, not the mining companies have to pay to mitigate (note:  not clean up since it is impossible to clean up such material/sites).  Factor in that many foreign companies come to the United States, take billions of dollars worth of minerals and pay pennies on the millions as "royalties" and this is a terrible "lose-lose" for the taxpayers and citizens of the United States.

Do NOT ALLOW PEBBLE MINE.

Title: Comment submitted by M. A. Taylor
Comment:
Administrator E. Scott Pruitt
Dear Administrator Pruitt,
The environment in Alaska is growing more fragile every year. This is a
pristine area and should remain so. Lives and wildlife depend on this
remaining an area free of toxins that come along with mining.
I write in support of the communities of Alaska's Bristol Bay and ask
you not to withdraw the proposed determination to adopt restrictions
protecting the habitat of Bristol Bay's world-renowned salmon.
The proposed determination was made at the request of local communities
and adopted only after years of rigorous scientific study, public
participation and peer review. The EPA was correct in 2014 when it
found that the Pebble Mine would have "significant and
unacceptable adverse effects" on "one of the most productive,
pristine, valuable and vulnerable ecosystems remaining in North America
today."
The EPA has noted that commercial fishing in Bristol Bay generates $300
million annually in direct sales of commercially caught salmon,
generating 11,000 jobs. These salmon support not only the commercial
and sportfishing industries, but a traditional Native way of life that
has endured for millennia and thrives today.
The EPA should stand by its proposed determination and take all
necessary actions to protect the Bristol Bay watershed.

Sincerely,

Michael Andrew Taylor
4104 Christiana Meadows
Bear, Delaware 19701
mtaylor@weavingmedia.com

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I am a U.S. citizen stakeholder who has relevant expertise biogeochemist and ecologist. I oppose the withdrawal of this Clean Water Act (CWA) Proposed Determination. I dispute the EPA Administrator's rationale to withdraw the CWA proposed determination, a decision that hinges upon providing Pebble Limited Partnership, a foreign owned company, the opportunity to submit a permit application to Army Corps without having an open and unresolved section CWA 404(c) review.The CWA 404(c) review should be completed first, so that Bristol Bay is properly protected before mine permits will be considered. 

Truly, the CWA proposed determination should be reviewed and finalized. Restricting mine waste disposal in the Pebble Deposit will ensure the protection of the Bristol Bay watershed, which is worth far more to U.S. citizens as a protected sockeye salmon fishery than it could ever be worth as a gold-copper mine. Evidence of risks the sockeye salmon fishery are reported in the EPA 2014 peer-reviewed study An Assessment of Potential Mining Impacts on Salmon Ecosystems of Bristol Bay, Alaska. As a citizen stakeholder with science expertise, I concur with the assumptions and methods used in EPA's ecological risk assessment. It is my opinion as a scientist and U.S. citizen that the findings of this study, especially that disposal of mine tailings in the South Fork Koktuli River, North Fork Koktuli River, and Upper Talarik Creek watersheds jeopardizes the sockeye salmon population health, are sufficient evidence to justify use of the Clean Water Act to restrict the deposit of mine waste in these waters. 

It cannot be emphasized enough that this CWA proposed determination does not outright ban mining in the watershed. If a mining company intends to pursue development of the Pebble Deposit, the company has full capacity to determine alternative waste disposal options! Thousands of Americans rely on the ecological resources of Bristol Bay watershed for their economy, livelihood, and culture- personally, I am a consumer of salmon products and hope to have sockeye salmon available throughout my life and for generations to come. Additionally, I present the Milltown Reservoir/Clark Fork River Superfund Site as an example of how improper protection of a fishery from mine tailings dam can cost the American taxpayers millions of dollars, and it takes decades of investment to recover lost fisheries (https://semspub.epa.gov/work/08/1570716.pdf ).

Before any mine permitting process proceeds, I insist that the EPA Region 10's CWA proposed determination is justly reviewed, preferably finalized, and of course, NOT withdrawn.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Anonymous public comment

It would also indirectly impact the public health of the American people as less salmon would be available to consume, which is a wonderful food resource to reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease (the number 1 cause of death for US citizens). Please view the big picture and how this withdrawal would impact more people negatively than it would enrich.

Title: Anonymous Public Comment
Comment:
I am opposed to EPAs proposal to rescind the 2014 Proposed Determination designed to protect Bristol Bays world class fisheries. Please stand with American jobs and communities and preserve the Bristol Bay Proposed Determination.

Bristol Bay, Alaska, is one of America's last great wild salmon fisheries. Each year, tens of millions of wild salmon return, supporting upwards of 14,000 jobs in the commercial and sport fishing industries, and serving as a one-in-a-lifetime destination for anglers from around the world as well as the cultural cornerstone for the region's communities. These long-established businesses are at risk from a foreign-owned mining company that wants to build the proposed Pebble Mine, which is opposed by more than 65 percent of Alaskans and more than 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents. 

In 2014, led by Alaska Native Tribes, interests including commercial fishing business owners and sportsmen asked the EPA step in to ensure that this mine wouldn't jeopardize Bristol Bay. The EPA responded by listening to over 1.5 million Americans, hosting dozens of community meetings, reviewing Pebble's many detailed filings with state and federal agencies, and conducting a twice peer-reviewed scientific assessment of the potential impacts to the region. Withdrawing the proposed determination ignores the overwhelming majority of Alaskans and puts the short-term interests of a foreign mining company above thousands of local jobs. 

For the sake of our wildlife, waterways, and communities, I urge you to protect Bristol Bay and prevent this horrible open-pit mine from destroying one of our nation's most precious ecosystems.

Of all the heinous, nefarious, cruel, short-sighted, money-grubbing policies and people in this sinister administration, let the world know that Scott Pruitt is the cruelest, meanest, most widely hated one of all.
And let us all note that as he disassembles all our clean air, clean water, and environmental standards, he is single-handedly sending our country and the planet to hell in a hand basket.

There aren't enough awful things to say about you, Mr. Pruitt. Go away and leave us alone, you disgusting, grotesque creature.

Title: Comment submitted by A. Farrow
Comment:
I am absolutely opposed to, and appalled at, the EPA's proposal to withdraw its July 2014 Clean Water Act Proposed Determination that would, if finalized, have imposed restrictions on the discharge of dredged or fill material associated with the potential "Pebble Mine" in Alaska's Bristol Bay watershed.  

I and my family have traveled to many of the national parks, especially in the southwest, and have a deep appreciation of the value of preserving our country's wild, natural habitats.  

The proposal to allow "Pebble Mine," a subsidiary of a non-American/Canadian conglomerate, to build an open pit mine in one of our country's most pristine, natural habitats, should be rejected for many reasons, the least of which is that it would destroy forever the whole ecosystem in the area.  Bad laws, bad policies can eventually be reworked, but a natural ecosystem, once destroyed, is gone forever..

The ecosystem at issue is the habitat for many fish species, especially salmon, that thrive in the crystal clear waters of Bristol Bay.  Many carnivores also thrive in this pristine area.  Indigenous Indian tribes have lived in the area for thousands of years, and participate in a $480-million economy based on the natural resources found in Bristol Bay.  The aquatic, carnivores, and native peoples are all interdependent on each other, and have generated a successful way of life that benefits all.

The proposed Pebble Mine open pit mine would destroy all this.  I and my family have been to the King mine in southern AZ and it is really amazing to behold. But it demonstrates how degraded the land becomes as the mine destroys everything in its footprint, as well as adjacent lands into which the mining debris is dumped.  In Bristol Bay, the debris would be dumped into "certain waters of the South Fork Koktuli River, North Fork Koktuli River, and Upper Talarik Creed watersheds in SW Alaska as disposal sites  for dredged or fill material associated with mining the Pebble deposit, a copper-, gold-, and molybdenum-bearing ore body." 

This is totally unacceptable!  Destroying this ecosystem can only have a negative impact on adjoining areas.  

The fact that this proposal is being entertained at all by the EPA is at odds with the best interest of our country.  Why would the EPA be willing to allow a commercial company destroy the Bristol Bay ecosystem?  It does not benefit our national or economic interests.

I fervently hope these comments are taken into consideration, and I fervently hope that there are enough legal and economic entities willing to fight to preserve the Bristol Bay ecosystem and deny Pebble Mine the rights to go forward with mining.

Anne Farrow
Norwalk, CT 06854

Title: Comment submitted by J. Farrow
Comment:
This submission registers my opposition to the EPA's proposal to withdraw the July 2014 Proposed Determination to restrict the use of certain waters in the South Fork Koktuli River, North Fork Koktuli River, and Upper Talarik Creek watersheds in southwest Alaska as disposal sites for dredged or fill material associated with mining the Pebble deposit.

As the world's most valuable wild salmon fishery, the area described above already produces significant, unsubsidized economic benefits, including 14,000 jobs for citizens in the local area and beyond. These benefits are sustainably realized at no cost to the local environment, which includes the greatest home for sockeye salmon on the planet - fifty percent of the world's total - in Alaska's Bristol Bay.

Withdrawing the Proposed Determination will put these benefits, as well as the preservation of a natural area of unique and pristine beauty, at risk in order to aid a foreign mining conglomerate. Withdrawal would serve oil, chemical and mining interests rather than the interest of the local population and would constitute an affront to the citizens of the United States through irreversible degradation of a unique environment. In effect, wild salmon - which need only clean water and healthy oceans - would be sacrificed for precious metals. And the sacrifice would be permanent.

Voting on the issue in 2014, Alaskans went overwhelmingly on record in support of protecting Bristol Bay and its environs from the billions of tons of toxic waste that would be produced by industrial-level mining operations.

I have personally witnessed long-term environmental degradation caused by operations such as the Copper Queen Mine in southern Arizona. While some might make the case that such effects in areas of open Southwestern desert are an acceptable tradeoff against the benefits accruing to private industry, I believe that no case can be supported that extends them to a unique and irreplaceable area of pristine beauty and finite natural bounty.

I strongly support the EPA's earlier conclusion that major mining operations in the area covered by the proposed withdrawal would have a "catastrophic" impact on the bay and just as strongly oppose the proposal to withdraw the July 2014 Proposed Determination.

Thank you.

Jason Farrow
6 Harbor View Avenue
Norwalk CT 06854
jfmaps01@optonline.net

Title: Anonymous Public Comment
Comment:
Salmon fisheries in Bristol Bay are a source of hundreds of millions of dollars per year. The value of ores that could be extracted from this area per year is a mere fraction of the value found in fisheries. In addition, fisheries replenish every year while minerals do not. The benefit of a mine is low-value and short-term when compared to the salmon fisheries. Opening the area to mining activities would diminish water quality and would permanently (or at least for many, many generations) maim the salmon fisheries in Bristol Bay (an area that is home to half of the world's sockeye salmon, one of the most economically important salmon species). This would result in a great deal of food insecurity, lack of income, and job loss for the fisherman of Bristol Bay and cripple the region's economy. We have work to do to make the fisheries as sustainable as possible but the fisheries, even as is, are vastly more economically and culturally valuable than any mineral output that could be generated by mineral extraction. 

Casting environmental concerns completely aside: a simple economic cost-benefit analysis of opening the area to mineral extraction vs. maintaining sustainable fisheries shows that reversing protections in Bristol Bay is a fiscally poor decision.poor decision.

Title: Anonymous Public Comment
Comment:
I am STRONGLY opposed to removing these clean water regulations, thus allowing Pebble Limited Partnership's proposed mine in the Bristol Bay watershed.  In this I am joined with communities (including Native Peoples) in the area, as well as my Senators Murray and Cantwell and Rep Jayapal (1), environmental groups, commercial recreational groups, and local commercial and recreational fishers (2).

As my Congressional representatives noted in their letter to the Trump Administration: "A three-year Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) study in 2014 found that the proposed mine would, even in the course of normal, safe mine operations, destroy 24 to 94 miles of salmon-producing waterways and pristine environment."

The original regulation was developed over years, with extensive input from stakeholders and scientists.  The suggested overturn of the regulation ignored that thorough process, and was made after Scott Pruitt met with the CEO of Pebble Limited.  This is an egregious violation of the mission of the EPA.


(1) https://www.murray.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/2017/10/sens-cantwell-murray-wa-house-dems-to-trump-admin-listen-to-our-fishermen-and-save-bristol-bay-wa-fishing-jobs
(2) https://www.seattletimes.com/seattle-news/environment/trumps-epa-decision-on-alaska-mining-project-reignites-battle-over-protecting-wild-salmon/

Title: Comment submitted by K. Flanagan
Comment:
Dear EPA and Region 10 Administrators, Legislators, Representatives, and all others whom this issue concerns,

The Pebble Mine project proposal must be withdrawn, and expressly and permanently destroyed, to protect the sanctity of Southwest Alaska.

I work as a fly fishing guide in Southwest Alaska precisely in the impact zone of the proposed mine and subsequent tailings. Rainbow King Lodge, in Iliamna AK, is where I spend my summers working to provide a remote wilderness experience to guests from around the world. We, as well as the native populations of these villages, thrive on these fisheries. I speak for those who are employed by the countless guiding outfits and lodges in this region of Alaska when I say that the Pebble Mine would devastate our way of life and ability to make a living. Most of my income is provided by the summer season when the largest wild salmon run in the world enters Lake Iliamna via Bristol Bay, followed by folks from around the world that come to be a part of, and experience such a beautiful and rare natural phenomenon. The risk of poisoning the watersheds mentioned in the proposal (Upper Talarik is, for example, one that we fish very often), due to accidental leeching or outright spilling of mine tailings and/or industrial waste, is simply too high.

This region of Southeast Alaska is one of those rare gems of our planet where wild things of all kind still exist, do not corrupt it with a profiteering venture for a foreign company. Around the world salmon runs have dwindled or been stamped out by human industry. In Russia. In Japan. In the Pacific Northwest. Once these runs are gone, they will not return. They are destroyed forever. Do not be the ones to tempt fate or gamble with such a poetic, unique, and irreplaceable resource. Do not allow this to be your legacy. Do not allow the Pebble partnership to establish this mine.

Kevin Flanagan

Title: Comment submitted by M. Lang
Comment:
Dear Mr. Pruitt and EPA Staff, 

Watching the slow destruction of natural wildlife, habitat and the environment in the name of corporate profit is devastating. I do not consider myself an extreme environmental activist, but the current climate in the EPA and the policy choices that have been made in the Trump era EPA have me extremely frightened and, frankly, depressed. 

As human beings, we have been gift and the curse of our own abilities.  We are now using those abilities irresponsibly, allowing industry to trump nature.  This most recent development with lifting Bristol Bay protections to build a mine is irresponsible, its wrong, and humans and animals will pay for this poor judgement with their lives and quality of life.  It will be one domino in a long line of bad decisions, putting development and money over what is just. 

It is not up to us to play god and decide what animals should keep their lives and their habitat, and what animal's lives are worth less than gold and copper.  We only have one planet, we are destroying it by systematically removing animal's abilities to live and thrive. We do not need more copper, we do not need more gold, we need to keep this planet alive and thriving for the future of human kind.  With great power comes great responsibility. 

Please use your power to put the Bristol Bay protections back in place, and leave Bristol Bay to the Salmon and the Native people of Alaska who depend on the salmon of this region for life. 

Sincerely, 


Mara Lang
Redondo Beach, CA

Title: Comment submitted by D. Frank
Comment:
To whom it may concern:

I am writing to implore the EPA to maintain its protections of the Pebble Deposit Area in Alaska's Bristol Bay watershed.  It is widely recognized that that area is home to the world's largest salmon fishery.  Removing the protections that are in place for that particular area threatens to destroy large portions, if not all, of that fishery.  This would have significant financial, societal and environmental costs to America and its citizens.  

Financially, the fishery supports thousands of jobs linked to salmon fishing.  Those jobs would be lost by removing the existing protections in the area.  A three-year study conducted by the EPA concluded in 2014 that the allowance of mining activities by companies like Northern Dynasty Minerals (a Canadian, not American, company) would result in a complete loss of salmon habitat in significant portions of the watershed.  What's more, the jobs created by Northern Dynasty Minerals' mining operations would be fewer than the fishing jobs that would be lost as a result of salmon habitat destruction by Northern Dynasty.  The net effect would be to reduce available jobs rather than to increase them.

From a societal standpoint, the watershed produces nearly half of the world's annual sockeye salmon catch.  Salmon is a prominent part of the American and world diet, with Americans consuming it raw in sushi/sashimi, smoked, and grilled, broiled, and baked.  A growing segment of the world's population has come to appreciate wild, rather than farm-raised, salmon.  Destruction of this fishery will significantly curtail the availability of wild salmon in grocery stores and restaurants. Most Americans, along with those who purchase our salmon will feel this loss.

From an environmental perspective it should be recognized that fisheries, like the one located at Bristol Bay, take many centuries to develop.  They cannot be easily replaced or repaired.  

Destroying our fisheries, poisoning a pristine environment, eliminating jobs, and reducing a significant portion of the world's salmon population does not Make America Great Again.  It, instead, undermines America.

Please maintain the existing protections of the Pebble Deposit Area and its salmon fishery.  

Thank you,

Doug Frank

Title: Anonymous Public Comment
Comment:
I am an ecologist at the University of Washington School of Aquatic and Fishery Sciences. In reviewing this regulation (Proposal to Withdraw Proposed Determination to Restrict the Use of an Area as a Disposal Site; Pebble Deposit Area, Southwest Alaska, Docket ID EPA-R10-OW-2017-0369), I have reached the decision not to support the proposed withdrawal, and if such a withdrawal is made, I believe the administrator should review and reconsider the withdrawal decision for the ecological reasons I have stated here.

In destroying spawning habitat, disposal of mine waste at the proposed sites would affect far more than the fish population in just that stretch of water through increasing risk to the population and species as a whole. I encourage review of the "portfolio effect" documented in salmon species (Schindler et al. 2010), which finds that species and populations are more stable and sustainable with greater life history diversity (i.e. with many subpopulations that return to different tributaries). This ensures that environmental variation in one year that affects a certain area of habitat, but not others, does not wipe out an entire population or species.

Furthermore, use of the proposed sites for mine waste disposal would have rippling effects throughout the ecosystem. I study brown bears who forage on sockeye salmon in tributaries of Iliamna Lake. Use these sites as disposal sites would prove detrimental to bears on a number of levels. First, bears are averse to human activity, and alter foraging patterns to avoid encountering humans (Ordiz et al. 2016, Martin et al. 2010). The large scale operations associated with Pebble Mine and the process of disposing mine waste are significant enough disturbances that bears may avoid foraging at nearby salmon streams entirely. If these are primary foraging grounds for some bears, this may impact bear growth and reproductive success, in turn potentially leading to reductions in bear populations, as growth and reproduction in bears are linked to salmon consumption (Hilderbrand et al. 1999a). Additionally, bears serve a critical role as transporters of marine-derived nutrients (Hilderbrand et al. 1999b) as they move salmon carcasses onto land where they can be used by a suite of secondary scavengers or decompose into components taken up by vegetation. If bears avoid salmon streams within a certain radius of mining activity, salmon-derived nutrients will not be integrated into these other pieces of the ecosystem, which may otherwise contribute to increased plant growth, which in turn improves stream habitat for juvenile salmonids (Helfield and Naiman, 2001).

I would also like to bring to the EPA's attention that withdrawing the proposed determination goes against several pieces of the EPA mission statement. First, this does not protect Americans from risks to human and environmental health, as it would allow exposure to mine waste contaminants when containment efforts inevitably fail. Second, it does not reduce environmental risks, as contaminants from spills will incorporate into organisms throughout the environment. Third this decision would not make ecosystems more sustainable and economically productive, as it may reduce salmon populations and hurt the large economy associated with the Bristol Bay salmon fishery. By retaining the proposed determination, the U.S. and EPA would prove to be a global leader in environmental protection, as we should strive to be.

1.	Schindler, D. E., R. Hilborn, B. Chasco, C. P. Boatright, T. P. Quinn, L. A. Rogers, and M. S. Webster. 2010. Population diversity and the portfolio effect in an exploited species. Nature 465:609-612.
2.	Ordiz, A., S. Sb, J. Kindberg, J. E. Swenson, and O. G. Sten. 2016. Seasonality and human disturbance alter brown bear activity patterns: implications for circumpolar carnivore conservation? Animal Conservation 20(1):51-60.
3.	Martin, J., M. Basille, B. Van Moorter, J. Kindberg, D. Allain, and J. E. Swenson. 2010. Coping with human disturbance: spatial and temporal tactics of brown bear (Ursus arctos). Canadian Journal of Zoology 88(9):875-883.
4.	Hilderbrand, G. V., C. C. Schwartz, C. T. Robbins, M. E. Jacoby, T. A. Hanley, S. M. Arthur, and C. Servheen. 1999a. The importance of meat, particularly salmon, to body size, population productivity, and conservation of North American brown bears. Canadian Journal of Zoology 77:132-138.
5.	Hilderbrand, G. V., T. A. Hanley, C. T. Robbings, and C. C. Schwartz. 1999b. Role of brown bears (Ursus arctos) in the flow of marine nitrogen into a terrestrial ecosystem. Oecologia 121(4):546-550.
6.	Helfield, J. M., and R. J. Naiman. 2001. Effects of salmon-derived nitrogen on riparian forest growth and implications for stream productivity. Ecology 82(9):2403-2409.

Comment: This situation keeps me up at night. A heartless mining company is willing to destroy an entire species' habitat for their own gain. Title: Anonymous Public Comment
Comment:
As a concerned citizen, I strongly oppose the proposal to withdraw the EPA Region 10 July 2014 Proposed Determination that was issued pursuant of the Clean Water Act. Bristol Bay, Alaska, is one of America's last great wild salmon fisheries. Tens of millions of wild salmon return annually, which support upwards of 14,000 American jobs in the commercial and sport fishing industries, serve as a one-in-a-lifetime destination for anglers from around the world, and are the cultural cornerstone for the region's communities.

These long-established American businesses and jobs are at risk from a foreign-owned mining company that wants to build the proposed Pebble Mine, which is opposed by more than 65 percent of Alaskans and more than 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents. 

In 2010, led by Alaska Native Tribes, interests including commercial fishing business owners and sportsmen asked the EPA step in to ensure that this mine wouldn't jeopardize Bristol Bay. The EPA responded by listening to over 1.5 million Americans, hosting dozens of community meetings, reviewing Pebble's many detailed filings with state and federal agencies, and conducting a twice peer-reviewed scientific assessment of the potential impacts to the region.Withdrawing the proposed determination ignores the overwhelming majority of Alaskans and puts the short-term interests of a foreign mining company above thousands of American jobs. 

The Bristol Bay watershed is essential to the health, environment and economy of Alaska.

Title: Comment submitted by Laurie Rich, Executive Director, David Brower Center
Comment:
Dear EPA:
 
Please do not withdraw Clean Water Act restrictions for mining in the Bristol Bay watershed!
 
The upper Bristol Bay watershed is rare and precious because remains virtually pristine. Its many waterways support subsistence hunters, fishing tourism, and a diverse array of wildlife. Along with grizzly bears and bald eagles, the area boasts the world's most productive salmon run, where an incredible 30 million to 50 million fish return every summer to spawn. With its $1.5 billion sustainable commercial fishery, Bristol Bay supplies half of all sockeye salmon on the global market.  
 
The Pebble Mine would end all of this for all time because the chemicals used to separate the gold and copper deposits from the rest of the rock would create an unimaginable amount of toxic waste. It's no secret that dams leak, especially in wet and earthquake-prone regions like Bristol Bay. According to conclusions the EPA previously published, the mine would have the potential to destroy 94 miles of streams and 5,350 acres of wetlands, ponds, and lakes. It would also remove an extra 35 billion gallons of water from salmon habitat every year.
 
And that's only the mine itself. The necessary infrastructureroads, a major power plant, and a new deep-water port (adjacent to Cook Inlet, where belugas are currently fighting for survival) would also take their toll, bringing noise, water, and air pollution to the extended region and laying a solid foundation for other mining companies to move right in. It's undeniable: Pebble Mine would destroy Bristol Bay's wild salmon fishery and devastate the livelihoods of the people and communities that depend on it.

This is a environmental justice and human rights issue!
 
Please protect the Bristol Bay watershed.  Say no to mining there.
 
Thank you,

Laurie Rich

Executive Director
David Brower Center

Title: Comment submitted by S. O'Neil
Comment:
Dear Administrator Pruitt and  Acting Regional Administrator Pirzadeh,
Thank you for the opportunity to comment. I disagree with the proposal to withdraw the 2014 determination that was issued pursuant of the Clean Water Act, to restrict the use of certain waters in the South Fork Koktuli River, North Fork Koktuli River, and Upper Talarik Creek watersheds in southwest Alaska as disposal sites for dredged or fill material associated with mining the Pebble deposit.
