Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment: I strongly oppose this proposal!  It is appallingly misguided and short-sighted.  All of Alaska and much of the world relies upon our wild salmon.  It is the subsistence lifeline of many people, most especially of the Alaska Natives in the Bristol Bay area. Our state has worked hard to protect this important natural resource.  Yet Alaska Natives have worked much harder and longer--protecting and harvesting it responsibly for the past 4,000 years!  I have lived in Anchorage, Alaska for 36 years and I, too, depend upon salmon as a weekly food source.  If such Clean Water protections are lifted, it is sadly easy for me to predict the outcome because of these reasons: I remember the U.S. waterways (and skies) before EPA regulations; I am a teacher committed to researching multiple trustworthy sources and viewpoints on critical issues, such as this one; and I was raised in two scientific communities due to my father's occupation as a nuclear physicist.  Therefore, I know that it is not a matter of IF there will be an environmental disaster as a result of withdrawing these protections, which are the next salvo in getting the Pebble Mine approved, but WHEN.  Such an impact would be catastrophic, irreversible, unconscionable, and tragic, especially given how preventable.  There is no logical or ethical justification for easing safeguards to allow businesses to prosper in the short-term while leaving the communities they (ab)use to shoulder the long-term effects.  In closing, may I remind you that your agency is the EPA, not the EDA, which means your job is to PROTECT the environment, not devastate or decimate it.

Title: Comment submitted by Travis Anderson, Gilder, Gagnon Howe & Co. LLC
Abstract: Travis Anderson Gilder Gagnon Howe & Co. LLC
Comment:
Pebble Project Proposed Determination Removal  docket  EPA-R10-OW-2017-0369

To Whom it May Concern,

I  write in favor of the EPA's Withdrawal of the Proposed Determination against the Pebble Mine Project.

First of all, the legal and recognized way for vetting such a project is well established and has been used by all responsible government agencies and mining companies for years: the legally mandated NEPA permitting process.  Pebble Limited partnership (PLP) had not even completed the filing of an EIA, yet the EPA via its proposed Determination violated the law, and not for the first time, by manipulating, making up, and claiming that the PLP would carry out construction of a mine that was quite different from what PLP was planning to propose. It is time for the EPA to follow the law and procedures established under NEPA.

Given the illegal and bad faith behavior of the EPA in this procedural farce to date, PLP in all fairness should be allowed a guarantee that their project go forward.   I believe a fair court would be outraged by the EPA's behavior and grant a permit simply for recompense for the immense cost to Pebble in reputation and effort.  But the company is asking no guarantee.  Magnanimously, PLP is asking only that their project be treated as fairly as other projects are entitled to be treated; the right to go through the NEPA process and prove via that process that that their project deserves to be approved on the merits, and that they can (and will) prove they can mitigate any impacts their project could have on the local ecosystem.

Secondly, during the permitting process no harm will come to the environment.  In good faith, PLP has followed the law and the thicket of regulations of the State of Alaska, on whose land the project will sit, the EPA, and local regulations.  It is time for the EPA to also act in a legal, good faith manner, and allow the Army Corps of Engineers to lead this evaluation, as NEPA requires.

Third, the Pebble Project has become a "cause celebre" of fact-free and fantasy-filled environmental activists' claims.  No doubt the EPA will receive many form letters from those wishing to preemptively stop the Pebble project.  But it is time to do the right thing, follow the law, and give the PLP the due process it deserves, by withdrawing the proposed determination.

Sincerely,

Travis Anderson

-- 
Travis Anderson
Gilder Gagnon Howe & Co. LLC
475 Tenth Avenue
New York, NY  10018
Phone: 212-765-2500
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

SOMEONE WHO CARES ABOUT OUR WORLD COULD TAKE ACTION AGAINST YOU AND YOUR FMILY  Please stand with American jobs and communities and preserve the Bristol Bay Proposed Determination.

Bristol Bay, Alaska, is one of America's last great wild salmon fisheries. Each year, tens of millions of wild salmon return, supporting upwards of 14,000 jobs in the commercial and sport fishing industries, and serving as a one-in-a-lifetime destination for anglers from around the world as well as the cultural cornerstone for the region's communities. These long-established businesses are at risk from a foreign-owned mining company that wants to build the proposed Pebble Mine, which is opposed by more than 65 percent of Alaskans and more than 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents. 

In 2014, led by Alaska Native Tribes, interests including commercial fishing business owners and sportsmen asked the EPA step in to ensure that this mine wouldn't jeopardize Bristol Bay. The EPA responded by listening to over 1.5 million Americans, hosting dozens of community meetings, reviewing Pebble's many detailed filings with state and federal agencies, and conducting a twice peer-reviewed scientific assessment of the potential impacts to the region. Withdrawing the proposed determination ignores the overwhelming majority of Alaskans and puts the short-term interests of a foreign mining company above thousands of local jobs. 

For the sake of our wildlife, waterways, and communities, I urge you to protect Bristol Bay and prevent this horrible open-pit mine from destroying one of our nation's most precious ecosystems.

Title: Comment submitted by J. Bradin
Comment:
My name is John Bradin. I am an independent Colorado voter from a Republican family. I am not a hair-on-fire libtard. 
My values have typically crossed party lines although I admit to not understanding what, if any, values are represented by
 the party that now controls every branch of the federal government.

Bristol Bay is an outstanding habitat for sockeye salmon. Like many such resources, it has recreational and economic values 
resulting from its value as a fish habitat. For example, see the link below.

https://www.worldwildlife.org/stories/why-is-bristol-bay-important-for-salmon-and-seven-other-bristol-bay-facts 

Using this important and beautiful area as a disposal site is the antithesis of the central mission of the EPA. There is no
pressing need for this use of Bristol Bay. The history of the mining industry should make anyone extremely skeptical about
any means of retaining toxic mining tailings. This proposal withdraws restrictions on this sort of dumping. The earth belongs 
everyone, not just those with mineral rights. Mineral rights are not without restriction; just because Pebble Limited Partnership
may have mineral rights doesn't mean that they can turn Bristol Bay into another Superfund site. This planet is the only one 
we have, unless you consider cold, dry, airless, 36-million-mile-distant Mars to be a viable alternative.

There is no pressing reason to mine this site, especially with reduced or eliminated restrictions on "disposal". There are
pressing reasons not to. 

The EPA was created under Richard Nixon and has been a valiant steward of the environment until January, 2017. 
This is not about reversing Obama legacy; the EPA has had bipartisan support for decades, and for good reason. Turning
the EPA into a rubber stamp for looney projects is immoral. At some point, the electorate will revolt; that point could easily 
be 2018. If you can't do what is right, do what makes sense.

Title: Comment submitted by A. Roche
Comment:
Jennifer Simpson of Seattle, WA (formerly of Baton Rouge, LA) and I strongly object to EPA head Scott Pruitt's decision to withdraw the Obama protections for Bristol Bay for the benefit of Pebble Limited Partnership (Dynasty Minerals -- a Canadian mining company). The EPA must not withdraw its protections for the largest sustainable salmon run on Earth (56 million annually), thousands of American fishing jobs, clean water (a human right), and rights of the indigenous people who have honored & lived on the salmon runs for thousands of years.
The EPA has already conducted an extensive review about the disastrous nature of this project: "a larger-scale mine would result in the "complete loss" of salmon habitat in some areas of the watershed." Furthermore, experts like University of Washington Fisheries Professor Ray Hillborn have stated "The idea you could store highly toxic waste (from a mine) forever behind a dam is just ridiculous" as he notes that the very reason the area is so productive for salmon (gravel beds) means it's very difficult to keep out mining toxins.
I do not see why Tom Collier (foreign Pebble CEO)'s secret meeting with Mr. Pruitt gives him the right to exploit one of the United States' greatest renewable resources. Why should a renewable, sustainable resource that belongs to Americans be exploited for foreign profit, so Pebble can construct the "largest open pit mine ever constructed in North America... cover an area the size of Manhattan... a pit as 80% as deep as Grand Canyon."
Please do not withdraw the protections for Bristol Bay! As a Washingtonian, I purchase wild-caught Alaska salmon all the time. It is a beautiful, amazing resource and I love visiting beautiful, unique Alaska.

Love and Cat Cuddlez, 

Aaron Roche 

2855 S Orcas St
Seattle, WA 98108

My Husband along his side are myself (his wife) and our three boys (17) (13)(9) whom all have been raised up subsistence gathering in Bristol Bay and know that is the only way of life.  My family lives 95% off the land, I would eat the fish and have it kill me before I go on Assistance.  
WE have never asked for assistance from the State and if we did not live off the land we will then be living off the state and the assistance programs that exist (housing,heating,food,medical,exc...) 

You know already that the MINE activity endangers salmon populations because of natural spawning grounds in every stream.  There where reports 2017 fishing season that every stream and river was plugged with fish and all Natural and them FISH come from here..
There home, there natural habitat.  

For the Health and Economic and well being for all animals and humans living off the land please no not remove the Clean water restrictions.  

Thank you!
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
To Whom it May Concern:

Bristol Bay is a stronghold of diversity for both fish species and fisherman on the west coast of the US. The fishery supports not only Alaskan fisherman, but boats that transit up form other states. The impact of damaging the Bristol Bay watershed and ecosystem would not only hurt the salmonid and other fish species that live there, but the livelihoods of fisherman and related industries across multiple states. The number of jobs created by a mine would likely be far fewer than the fisheries (and related industries) in Bristol Bay currently support. Additionally, the profits from a mine would be concentrated in the hands of fewer people rather than spread over many as a public resource, thus furthering the equality gap which has been growing in the US. It does not make sense to alter the Bristol Bay watershed and ecosystem, in terms of jobs or in terms of ecology. Given that salmon runs in so many areas are imperiled for gone completely, it would be wise to maintain locations where these fish still thrive. 

Thank you for your time, please consider doing the largest amount of good, for the largest number of people, AND the environment, when making this decision.

The mineral extraction is going to have negative impacts on the salmon and the local and state wide economy. People come from all around the world to fish in Alaska - and if this mine happens then fishermen will no longer want to spend tens of thousands of dollars each to go fish in pristine Alaskan waters. Please please please, please do not allow this mine to happen.

Title: Comment submitted by J. Wittkop
Comment:
Please do not withdraw or rescind the Proposed Determination for Docket EPA-R10-OW-2017-0369. Instead, please finalize the protections for the last great wild-sockeye salmon fishery on the planet.

Bristol Bay, Alaska is the last remaining place on earth that produces naturally occurring salmon runs with annual returns in the  tens of millions of wild salmon.  The importance of an ecosystem that can support and naturally produce a salmon run of that size cannot be understated.  History and science both have taught us repeatedly that even small changes to these types of ecosystems can have catastrophic results.  The temporary gains from mining in the Bristol Bay watershed could never outweigh the potential long term losses that could result from the loss of a salmon run that has existed for thousands of years.  Myself, and nearly all other residents of Bristol Bay, depend heavily on the salmon for food and subsistence.  Beyond that the commercial and sport fisheries in the are by by far the largest employers and sources of income in the area.  Any damage, no matter how small or large, to one of the last remaining intact ecosystems in America would be an irreversible tragedy.  The salmon of Bristol Bay are just one piece of an intricately connected natural system.  The fish feed the people of the area through sport and subsistence fishing and the people of the world through the commercial fishery.  But the fish also feed the environment by transporting and depositing essential nutrients from the ocean upriver when they return there to spawn and die.  Bears and other animals rely on the salmon for food as well so they would also suffer from a loss of the salmon.

The money generated from a mine could never equal the value of one of the last great wild areas in the country, and the world.           Please do not withdraw or rescind the Proposed Determination for Docket EPA-R10-OW-2017-0369. Instead, please finalize the protections for the last great wild-sockeye salmon fishery on the planet.

Thank you for considering my concerns,

Joe Wittkop
PO Box 835
Dillingham, AK 99576

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I am opposed to EPAs proposal to rescind the 2014 Proposed Determination designed to protect Bristol Bays world class fisheries. Please stand with American jobs and communities and preserve the Bristol Bay Proposed Determination.

Bristol Bay, Alaska, is one of America's last great wild salmon fisheries. Each year, tens of millions of wild salmon return, supporting upwards of 14,000 jobs in the commercial and sport fishing industries, and serving as a one-in-a-lifetime destination for anglers from around the world as well as the cultural cornerstone for the region's communities. These long-established businesses are at risk from a foreign-owned mining company that wants to build the proposed Pebble Mine, which is opposed by more than 65 percent of Alaskans and more than 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents. 

In 2014, led by Alaska Native Tribes, interests including commercial fishing business owners and sportsmen asked the EPA step in to ensure that this mine wouldn't jeopardize Bristol Bay. The EPA responded by listening to over 1.5 million Americans, hosting dozens of community meetings, reviewing Pebble's many detailed filings with state and federal agencies, and conducting a twice peer-reviewed scientific assessment of the potential impacts to the region. Withdrawing the proposed determination ignores the overwhelming majority of Alaskans and puts the short-term interests of a foreign mining company above thousands of local jobs. 

I am very strongly opposed to developing ANY mines and believe that we must move forward with clean energy, not dirty coal.  This area is so much more important to me than an ugly, destructive mine will ever be.  Please  do not allow this to happen. 

For the sake of our wildlife, waterways, and communities, I urge you to protect Bristol Bay and prevent this horrible open-pit mine from destroying one of our nation's most precious ecosystems.

Please do not withdraw the EPA Region 10 July 2014 Proposed Determination.

Impacts to keystone salmon species, endangered Beluga whales, endangered Southern Resident killer whales who also depend on some of these salmon, local communities economic welfare, and the entire ecosystem, can not be mitigated.
Withdrawing  the EPA Region 10 July 2014 Proposed Determination, allowing disposal site use of these areas is also not allowed under the Endangered Species Act designated critical habitat of endangered Beluga whales that NOAA just invested another 1.3 million dollars in recovery efforts.
Exploitation and destruction of the earth and marine ecosystems for short term benefits exclusive to few, ultimately leaves long term habitat loss, death, and extinction of many species including humans.
The hand- earth, that breathes waters feeds us, can only sustain so many bites.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I do not support the proposed changes regarding the Pebble Mine project. The mine would impact an incredibly important fishing ground in Bristol Bay. Many residents and non residents depend on the economic structure regarding the salmon fishery in the area. Opening the Pebble mine would have a detrimental affect to these families, and to the salmon industry. 

Many other fish species could be affected as well. The area where the Pebble Mine would be located is an incredibly important area for nesting seabirds. These seabird colonies are already struggling from mass mortality events related to lack of food resources. A mass mortality event involves at least hundreds of confirmed dead animals washing ashore, but most recent events have been in the thousands. I have spent the past 9 years working at the Alaska SeaLife Center in Seward, AK, assisting researchers who are monitoring the mortality events around Resurrection Bay. Climate change is having an enormous impact on the bottom of our ocean's food chain, and we are watching a trophic cascade as the lack of food begins impacting animals up the food chain. We have seen mass mortalities of common murres, tufted puffins, northern fulmars, and fork-tailed storm petrels in just the past three years from Resurrection Bay through the Aleutians and as far north as the Pribilof Islands. These die-offs are followed by extremely poor breeding seasons. In 2016, there was 0% breeding success in all monitored common murre colonies. This is the case in many colonies across the state as well. We should not provide even more environmental stress in such an important ecosystem as Bristol Bay.  

The Pebble Mine would impact an incredibly important food supply area for many of the animals that come to Alaska for the bounty of food our oceans create in the summer. While Alaska is home to over 60% of the north pacific's breeding seabirds, this also includes whales and sharks that migrate north to feed. The impacts of the Pebble mine would be drastic and would be felt on every level. 

This is not a project that should happen in an already struggling ecosystem. I do not support this, and I will not support any pubic official who backs the Pebble mine.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment: I'm writing to express concern with Docket ID No. EPA-R10-OW-2017-0369.  I strongly object to the EPA disregarding previous findings, leading to the withdrawal of the proposed determination. I believe the EPA was correct when it determined, in its 2014 report titled "An Assessment of Potential Mining Impacts on Salmon Ecosystems of Bristol Bay, Alaska", that Pebble Mine would have "significant and unacceptable adverse effects" on Bristol Bay. Again, I urge the EPA to use its authority under the Clean Water Act to protect Bristol Bay.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
The proposed Clean Water Act determination should NOT be withdrawn. The potential impacts of the proposed Pebble Mine on the health of the Bristol Bay watershed and the livelihood of thousands of people in Alaska are far too great. Those risks include loss of up to up to 94 miles of salmon-supporting streams and up to 4,900 acres of wetlands and ponds, and the very real potential of wastewater dam failure resulting in damage to or destruction of the salmon fishery. The watershed supports the largest sockeye salmon fishery in the world and 25 federally recognized tribes who for 4,000 years have depended on the fishery for their subsistence-based culture. The overwhelming majority of residents of Bristol Bay are opposed to the project, and a statewide majority of voters also oppose it. The watersheds unique ecological resources generate significant economic benefits and employment. EPAs original watershed assessment was scientifically robust and thoroughly peer-reviewed. That assessment and related public comments should strongly influence any future action.

References:
U.S. EPA. An Assessment of Potential Mining Impacts on Salmon Ecosystems of Bristol Bay, Alaska (Final Report). U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Washington, DC, EPA 910-R-14-001A-C, ES, 2014.
EPA Region 10, Proposed Determination Pursuant to Section 404(c) of the Clean Water Act for Pebble Deposit Area, Southwest Alaska, July 21, 2014.
2017 EPA and Pebble Limited Partnership Agreement.
U.S. EPA. An Assessment of Potential Mining Impacts on Salmon Ecosystems of Bristol Bay, Alaska (Final Report). U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Washington, DC, EPA 910-R-14-001A-C, ES, 2014. Chapter 5.
United Tribes of Bristol Bay. Opposition to Pebble Mine Reiterated by local tribes, fishermen, business owners.
Alaska Bristol Bay Mining Ban, Ballot Measure 4 (2014).

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I have never been lucky enough to visit Bristol Bay Alaska.  I have read about it, watched videos about, heard stories from friends about it, and all too often seen pictures of the amazing fish that grace its tributary streams.  I hope to one day be fortunate enough to visit and fish these hallowed waters.  As fly fisherman, environmental attorney, former guide, and Montana native, I have witnessed first hand both the power of a pristine fishery and the destructive force of mining activities on those resources.  In Montana, we have a history of mining.  My family were miners many generations ago.  But today I live with the deadly consequences that have lasted for more than 100 years from that history.  Today, tax payers from around the country pick up the tab for cleaning up the Clark Fork River, silver bow creek, Mike Horse Creek, and many others.  The Bull trout and cutthroat fisheries which once thrived in these streams are just a distant memory that modern day citizens can only dream about.  

Are we really willing to risk the greatest salmon fishery on the planet for a private company to make money?  How does that benefit the public?  How long will we remain attached to the vestiges of the Old West, where land grabs and gold rushes were thought to serve a public purpose?  We know better today.  There is no mine that is 100% safe.  Who will bear the burden of the loss if it occurs?  Will it be Pebble Partnership, or will it be the people of the United States and the world?  

Please don't make the same mistake we have made for generations.  This is an opportunity to say, "not now and not here."  Somethings are more valuable than gold.  No Pebble mine!

Title: Comment submitted by R. Lovitt
Comment:
I am writing to express my opposition to EPA's proposal to rescind the 2014 Proposed Determination designed to protect Bristol Bay's world class fisheries.

The EPA has noted that commercial fishing in Bristol Bay generates $300 million annually in direct sales of commercially caught salmon, generating 11,000 jobs. These salmon support not only the commercial and sportfishing industries, but a traditional Native way of life that has endured for millennia and thrives today.

The EPA should stand by its proposed determination, stand with saving American jobs and communities, and preserve the 2014 Bristol Bay Proposed Determination. With highest regard for our precious planet and for the health sake of all communities - wild AND human, I urge you to protect Bristol Bay and prevent this horrible open-pit mine from destroying one of our nation's most precious ecosystems.

Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
As a Washingtonian, I value that the Bristol Bay fishery supports thousands of jobs in my state, throughout the Pacific Northwest and in California, generating $674 million in economic activity.   I value that this fishery generates over 20 thousand American jobs from Alaska to Maine in salmon fishing and related industries, such as shipbuilding. I value that the fishery provides over half the word's sockeye salmon and that Native Alaskans have relied on this fishery for subsistence and livelihood for centuries.

I respect the rigorous science behind the EPA's findings that even a small mine would pose unacceptable risks to the fishery.  I respect the model process by which the EPA involved all stakeholders in deliberaions leading up to the proposed July 2014 Determination  under the Clean Water Act. I am grateful for the support various members of Congress from Washington gave early on and continue to give for protections from open pit mining in Bristol Bay.

I feel duty bound to comment here on Pebble Limited Partnership's (PLP)  lawsuits against the EPA, I note the following: U.S. District Court Judge H. R. Holland dismissed PLP's challenge to the EPA's authority to perform a Bristol Bay Watershed Assessment; the 9th Circuit Court of Appeals upheld this decision. Judge Holland also ruled that PLP does not have a valid legal basis for stopping EPA's deliberations about whether it should block large scale mining.  Regarding the remaining litigation, concerning whether the EPA acted improperly under the Federal Advisory Committee -   by his unilateral decision to work behind the scenes with PLP and stop the litigation process, Administrator Pruitt excused PLP from having to provide proof for its allegations; there is high likelihood that the allegations were not supported by facts.  Mr. Pruitt's actions robbed the EPA of a fair hearing and the public of the right to see evidence.  I see no justification for Mr. Pruitt's actions here, actions connected with the proposal to withdraw the July 2014 Determination.

I oppose withdrawing the EPA's July 2014 Determination "for the reasons stated."  Withdrawing the July 20d14 Determination would create more regulatory uncertainty, not less, as claimed.  No justification for giving priority to PLP's possible "perceived" uncertainty is given nor is any justification apparent.  No explanation for why the withdrawal is "appropriate" is given. 

The proposal to withdraw the July 2014 Determination was made arbitrarily without due process after a private meeting with Tom Collier, CEO of PLP and without consulting with EPA staff.

Section 404(c) of the Clean Water Act authorizes he EPA to prohibit, deny or restrict discharge of dredged material at defined sites if unacceptable adverse impacts on fisheries, wildlife, recreational areas exist.  Existing law and evidence-based science should be guiding the EPA's decisions, which is not the case currently.

Thank you for this opportunity to comment.

Comment: A wise investment would be to protect the long-term health of a 1.5 billion dollar annual fishery, rather than support the short-term gain of a select few mining corporations. You cannot have both in an a porous environment like this. That is why you've never seen a clean open pit mine in a wetland. What you have seen time and again are the creation of Superfund sites that then become the financial burden of the American people at the cost of hundreds of millions to billions of dollars as taxpayers are left to clean up the mess. You risk losing a much more important fishing industry, enormous environmental justice and health issues, and the destruction of an incredible gem of the United States. Allowing the application for or the approval of mining in Bristol Bay causes more problems than it solves.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
Dear Scott Pruitt,

The fact that you approved the Pebble Partnership Open Pit Mine without even a second though shows you are not responsible for the charge your office of duty has placed on you. You are a public servant and your job is to do what is best for society as a whole and not just thr wealthy few. Approving this mine without even looking at scientific evidence is irresponsible and wrong on multiple levels. 

The environment is a valuable natural resource and this mine will endanger the entire Bristol Bay watershed. This type of thinking is very short sighted and is not thinking of the consequences ok future generations. Please put profit aside and do what is best for the community as a whole. 

Stop the Pebble Partnership open pit mine and protect the Bristol Bay watershed by making it a preserve or wildlife refuge.

Title: Mass Comment Campaign sponsored by Save Bristol Bay (web)
Comment:
The attached file is a list of people who signed onto this letter when Administrator Pruitt first started with the EPA: 

Congratulations on your new job as Administrator of the United States Environmental Protection Agency. I'm writing to let you know that I, and the majority of Alaskans, expect that you will continue the excellent science-based work that the EPA has done in Bristol Bay, Alaska. I understand from the news that you are opposed to regulations that hurt jobs. Bristol Bay already supports 14,000 American jobs in the fishing industry and those jobs will be hurt by any favorable regulations you put in place for the Pebble mine - owned by a foreign company.

Bristol Bay, Alaska is home to the world's largest runs of sockeye salmon and those fish are an economic engine that contribute $1.5 billion to the United States economy. These salmon have sustained Alaska Native cultures for generations, and today fuel the dreams of hunters and anglers around the world who come to hunt and fish in Bristol Bay. This is the reason that an unprecedented bi-partisan coalition in Alaska is fighting against the Pebble project. 

This is also the reason that Alaskans overwhelmingly supported a state-wide anti-Pebble initiative two years ago. Nearly all of the local elected officials and tribal leaders oppose the mine - despite what Pebble has told you on the record. 

We are grateful that EPA has listened to Alaskans about the Pebble Mine. We hope that you will continue to listen to those who have the most to lose if Pebble gets built. Salmon are, and will continue to be, the cornerstone of our history, culture, and economy in Alaska. It is imperative that we protect American jobs from this foreign mining company.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment submitted by Brian Benson, Area Vice President, Air Liquide America Corp, LP
Comment:
No matter what the project is, it should be allowed public scrutiny and vetting by scientific analysis.  Ultimately, the protection of the environment is important, but absolute withdrawal from human interaction should not be solely within the perview of the EPA.  The interests of the state division of natural resources, local residents, and effective land use to provide jobs and other industry to the rest of the state must be considered. 
     We've seen a presumptive removal of the state and people's interests in this project by the Environmental Protection Agency that disregards the scientific process, or even a proposed plan.  The validity of the merits of the project must consider all the social, environmental, and economic impacts that will be developed through a unbiased NEPA permitting process.  Please disregard the hype and unfounded rumor to allow for this to continue through it's due course.

As a lifelong Alaskan, there is no way I want to see wholesale destruction of our environment, but feel strongly that mining has come a long way, the plan is well thought out, and this project will bring good jobs and independance to the people of western Alaska.  Please support the process and bring the Pebble mine into permitting.

Brian Benson
Area Vice President,
Air Liquide America Corp, LP
Anchorage, ALaska

Title: Comment submitted by R. Cella
Comment:
Dear Administrator Pruitt and decision makers:
I am opposed to EPA's proposal to rescind the 2014 Proposed Determination designed to save Bristol Bay's world class fisheries. Please stand with American jobs and communities and preserve the Bristol Bay Proposed Determination.
As you know, Bristol Bay, Alaska, is one of America's last great wild salmon fisheries. Tens of millions of wild salmon return annually. This supports upwards of 14,000 American jobs in the commercial and sport fishing industries, serves as a one-in-a-lifetime destination for anglers from around the world, and is the cultural cornerstone for the region's communities.
These long-established American businesses and jobs are at risk from a foreign-owned mining company that wants to build the proposed Pebble Mine. Although Alaskans typically support resource development, more than 65 percent of Alaskans and more than 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents oppose the proposed Pebble Mine. 
Over the course of the EPA's own comment and public review processes, the EPA received more than 1.5 million comments asking for strong protections for Bristol Bay. Withdrawing the proposed determination would fly in the face of an overwhelming majority of Alaskans and put the short-term interests of a foreign mining company above thousands of American jobs. 
Today I ask that you stand with American jobs and communities and not withdraw the proposed determination. Please do not trade American businesses and jobs or our wild salmon for the shallow promises of a foreign mining company.
Sincerely,
Rachel Cella

Title: Comment submitted by M. Miller
Comment:
Please hear and act on my opposition to withdrawal of the EPA's Proposed Determination to Restrict the use of an area as a disposal site for the Pebble mine application.  We (the Miller family) as Alaskans, fishermen, Americans, instruct the EPA to follow the evidence based finding from the EPA research conducted with public support. The EPA's findings agreed with public input that the risk to habitat, salmon, waterways, people and the economy were greater than the benefits of the proposed Pebble mine. The EPA mission of protecting the people and it's assets supports maintenance of the Proposed Determination as is.  The Bristol Bay watershed as a public asset trumps any mine interests. Process does include proactive protection. The Determination to Restrict the Use of an Area as Disposal Site; Pebble Deposit Area, Southwest  Alaska, is an appropriate part of the proactive protection process for public assets. Withdrawal is unacceptable. Thank you for your time.
Melisa Miller, Arctic Queen Sub. #4, Halibut Cove, Alaska.

Title: Comment submitted by M. Burner

Title: Comment submitted by C. Marsh
Comment:
To the attention of the EPA / Mr. Pruitt, regarding the review of the the Pebble Mine 2014 determination:

The 2014 ruling was made in good faith and should not be changed in order to fit the wishes of a corporate entity that stands to profit from the change. Far too many people, who are true stakeholders in Alaska's economy and general well-being, stand to lose if the proposed change is made. Few advantages will adhere to those same people (and indeed, to the public at large) if the mine is established. This is not a scientifically verifiable issue, it is an issue of political justice and US sovereignty.

Approval of the changes will place control of a significant set of Alaskan (US) resources beyond the effective control of Alaska and perhaps even the US government, to which past, present and no doubt future, superfund sites stand in testimony as proof of the unacceptable risk involved in such transactions. The issue is more pressing when the resources concerned are irreplaceable, in fact, invaluable. 

Apart from US experiences with corporate environmental crimes, observations from all over the world demonstrate the fact that corporate actions are taken with one aim, to maximize profit, very often, perhaps even usually, at the expense of environmental and political justice. How does a scientifically verifiable process address such injustice? Whether or not the EPA mandate includes such considerations, in actual fact, they are the crux of the problem concerning the Pebble Mine. Reconsideration of the EPA's original ruling is beyond defense.

Cindy Marsh
Cambridge, MA 02139
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment submitted by N. Stocker
Comment:
Bristol Bay is geographically a different place.  It has been much more isolated from development than many parts of Alaska.  Shoals, sandbars and shallows, along with high winds and the eighth most extreme tides in the world make it difficult for large ships to navigate.  This isolation has allowed fish to maintain their health and abundance.  Bristol Bay is one of the outstanding salmon fisheries left in the world.  Every year salmon fishing, for both commerce and sport, brings about $310 million to Alaska. This flow of healthy food and Alaskan income can continue for the foreseeable future if we don't interfere with it. 

The world's human population is exploding.  This is putting pressure already on our ability to feed all people, particularly the ability to get everyone adequate, healthy protein.  The oil in salmon is well known to be good for the cardiovascular system.  

No one can say for sure how long salmon would last in Bristol Bay if the Pebble Mine goes forward.  Behind a huge dam would be an unlined lake containing 10 billion tons of such toxic chemicals as sulfuric acid, mercury, arsenic, lead, zinc, and cadmium.  Furthermore, there are many other corporately held mine leases in the region that are currently inactive.  If the Pebble Mine's large corporate owners invested in the infrastructure for their mine, it likely would make it possible for smaller companies to become active on their leases.

The salmon might end through relatively slow attrition, as water is diverted to mining operations and impurities flow through the soil into the water remaining in the rivers.  Or it might end suddenly with the collapse of one of the dams holding back the impounded toxic chemicals that are inevitably a by-product of mining.  Either way, a major source of food for the world and income for Alaska will be lost forever.

No one could say it better than Ted Williams in Audubon Magazine, Nov/Dec 2012:

"What possibly could unite these diverse and in some cases adversarial players in outrage and action: 700 businesses; 700 hunting and angling groups; 77 commercial fishing groups; 200 chefs and restaurant owners; the National Council of Churches, representing 45 million people; major newspapers; leading jewelry retailers; and ultra-conservative legislators?

It would be a plan to gouge and hack the Bristol Bay watershed of southwest Alaska with the continent's biggest strip mine."

Please use your authority under the Clean Water Act to prohibit the proposed construction of the horribly destructive Pebble Mine.   

Nancy Stocker
2885 S Gilpin St
Denver, CO 80210

This is a repeat of a previous comment, in which I did not include my identifying information.

Let the science not be drowned out by that of money rolling from one wealthy human to another. Title: Comment submitted by S. Dalheim
Comment:
October 17, 2017

Administrator E. Scott Pruitt

Dear Administrator Pruitt,

Subject: 	Docket ID No. EPA-R10-OW-2017-0369
Maintain protections for Bristol Bay Watershed

I am writing in opposition to the proposal to withdraw the EPA Region 10 July 2014 Proposed Determination that was issued pursuant of the Clean Water Act, to restrict mining activity associated with the Pebble deposit, a copper-, gold-, and molybdenum-bearing ore body.

The Bristol Bay region of Alaska is one of the great ecologic resources of the world. It is the site of the largest remaining run of wild sockeye salmon, and it produces roughly 50% of the world's commercial supply of wild sockeye salmon. It is the home of Alaska Native people who continue the subsistence fishing and hunting traditions of their ancestors. It is an important economic driver for the commercial fishing, sport hunting and sport fishing industries of North America.

The Pebble gold and copper deposit is found in association with sulfides, which could generate acid mine drainage when extracted. Acid mine drainage is a potentially severe water pollution issue and the most significant liability associated with mining.

The ecological, economic, and social value of the Bristol Bay salmon fishery should be protected. Mining threatens that value - the risk is far too great and we cannot be confident that mining company steps to mitigate that risk will succeed.  

This is an economic argument. A report published by the Natural Capital Declaration, November 2015 called Towards Including Natural Resource Risks in Cost of Capital, State of play and the way forward, Natural Capital Declaration, 2015, addresses the economic value of natural ecosystems.  Quoting from that report:

"The value that nature provides to revenue-generating activities, depends on the stocks and flows and the quality of ecosystem goods and services available. This is "natural capital", and is being eroded rapidly and globally. Over-exploitation, pollution and environmental degradation are undermining the earth's capacity to deliver the natural resources and stable environmental operating conditions required to sustain economic activities and a growing world population."  

http://www.unepfi.org/fileadmin/documents/NCD-NaturalResourceRisksScopingStudy.pdf

Allowing a mine to be built in an area that threatens one of the largest sources of sustainable salmon protein in the world does not make sense. The EPA 2014 proposed determination recognized this threat and the restriction of mining activity should be maintained. 

Sincerely,



Stu Dalheim
7981 Eastern Avenue, #105
Silver Spring, MD 20910

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I agree with the EPA's finding that mining activity in the Bristol Bay watershed poses unacceptable risks to the Bristol Bay salmon fishery. If approved, the Pebble Mine would be the largest mine of its type in North America. The mine itself would cover up to 6.9 square miles, with an 18 square mile wastewater pond to store the 10 billion tons of potentially toxic waste the mine is expected to generate.  It isn't just the potential for an irreversible environmental catastrophe that is driving widespread opposition to the Pebble Mine. As of 2009, the Bristol Bay watershed generated hundreds of millions of dollars in economic activity annually and 14,000 jobs, primarily in the fishing industry. All of that could be at risk if the disastrous Pebble Mine project is allowed to move forward.

Please move forward with a Final Determination on the proposed Pebble Mine under Section 404(c) of the Clean Water Act without delay.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I am writing to ask the EPA, it's Administrator and it's Region 10 Administrator to please NOT WITHDRAW the July 2014 Proposed Determination and, if a final withdrawal decision is made following this comment period, to please have the EPA Administrator and Region 10 Administrator (if possible) provide additional review for reconsideration of the withdrawal decision.  There has been so much extensive analysis, and from the executive summary it seems this is still considered to be a conservative analysis of adverse effects, done for this July 14 Proposed Determination, but the conclusion was still that the planned mining project would result in unacceptable adverse effects on the environment and beyond. It seems the Region 10 Administrator supports the findings in this proposed determination and I am very glad to see that.  I hope the "EPA may use its scientific assessment regarding the Bristol Bay Watershed without limitation" portion of the May 2017 settlement means that all this extensive analysis and information will be considered throughout the entire process that decides upon the future of the Bristol Bay watershed area .The proposed mine pit itself, which seems to be the largest pit known thus far, and its possible discharges seem to be a perfect setup for massive and irreversible environmental damage with potential long-term adverse effects for the region, its people and the world.  I cannot see why all this would be considered acceptable to appease the narrow-minded interests of the few.  Although I have many thoughts and feelings about this issue, I will try to express them through my favorite John Muir quotes of :

"Everybody needs beauty as well as bread, places to play in and pray in, where nature may heal and give strength to body and soul."

"When we try to pick out anything by itself, we find it hitched to everything else in the Universe"

"God never made an ugly landscape. All that the sun shines on is beautiful, so long as it is wild."

I hope the soul-stirring truths above are taken into strong consideration by all those who are involved in deciding the fate of this pristine and amazing ecosystem and all of the lives intertwined with it.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I am opposed to EPAs proposal to rescind the 2014 Proposed Determination designed to protect Bristol Bays world class fisheries. Please stand with American jobs and communities and preserve the Bristol Bay Proposed Determination.

Corporate America does NOT represent the health and safety of the American public and the environment of this planet.  The energy industry should be putting its vast resources into developing clean, sustainable energy, not energy that taints everything it comes into contact with.

Bristol Bay, Alaska, is one of America's last great wild salmon fisheries. Each year, tens of millions of wild salmon return, supporting upwards of 14,000 jobs in the commercial and sport fishing industries, and serving as a one-in-a-lifetime destination for anglers from around the world as well as the cultural cornerstone for the region's communities. These long-established businesses are at risk from a foreign-owned mining company that wants to build the proposed Pebble Mine, which is opposed by more than 65 percent of Alaskans and more than 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents. 

In 2014, led by Alaska Native Tribes, interests including commercial fishing business owners and sportsmen asked the EPA step in to ensure that this mine wouldn't jeopardize Bristol Bay. The EPA responded by listening to over 1.5 million Americans, hosting dozens of community meetings, reviewing Pebble's many detailed filings with state and federal agencies, and conducting a twice peer-reviewed scientific assessment of the potential impacts to the region. Withdrawing the proposed determination ignores the overwhelming majority of Alaskans and puts the short-term interests of a foreign mining company above thousands of local jobs. 

For the sake of our wildlife, waterways, and communities, I urge you to protect Bristol Bay and prevent this horrible open-pit mine from destroying one of our nation's most precious ecosystems.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I am adamantly opposed to removing protection of Bristol Bay. As a lover of wild places and wild life, development of this area directly affects me.  The headwaters of the world's greatest salmon fishery is an incredibly stupid place to build a open pit copper, gold and molybdenum mine that would trap 10 billion tons of toxic mining waste behind a several mile-long, 700 foot-high, earthen dam in a region known to experience earthquakes; a dam that would have to be maintained for thousands of years into the future.

The idea that Bristol Bay is the world's greatest salmon fishery isn't hyperbole. Almost half (46%) of the world's salmon harvest each year comes from Bristol Bay. It supports 14,000 jobs and is worth an estimated $1.5 billion annually. And it is the sustaining force behind 4,000 year old native Alaskan cultures that continue rely on Bristol Bay's natural plenty to survive.

In 2014, Canada's Mount Polley minewhich, though much smaller, is very similar to the type of mine that Pebble would come to beoffered the world a glimpse at what future could await Bristol Bay if Pebble were built and its tailing dam were to fail. When Polley's tailings dam burst, it released its toxic tailings slurry into Polley Lake, Hazeltine Creek, Quesnel Lake and Cariboo Creek. It has been characterized as one of the greatest environmental disasters in modern Canadian historyflooding nearby waters and wetlands with arsenic, selenium and other heavy metals. Prior to the disaster, Polley was one of the mines that the Pebble Limited Partnership (PLP) had held out as an example of mines and fisheries co-existing. PLP even hired the same engineering firm that Mount Polley hada firm that had rebutted the EPA's findings, stating that dams don't fail.

Both the science and the voice of the American public have made it entirely clear that Bristol Bay is the wrong place to build a open pit ore mine that would place a pristine ecosystem, the world's greatest salmon fishery, the jobs of 14,000 Americans and several thousand year-old native cultures in grave and serious peril.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
Do not withdraw the Clean Water Act Proposed Determination. If you do, you will be making the wrong decision by every moral and scientific standard. If you allow this to go through, you will be remembered in history as a thoughtless villain, motivated only by the prospect of profits in the short term, with no regards to the future consequences of your actions. Instead of thinking about  potential corporate profits, think about how this would destroy existing jobs (i.e. sockeye salmon fishers) and the importance of Clean Water as described in the Act that is meant to protect it. 

The Clean Water Act was created and put into place based on scientific conclusions. As an administration that is obligated to listen to science rather than corporations, if you want to roll back the progress made by the Clean Water Act, you need to base that decision on strong peer-reviewed scientific evidence that suggests the opposite-- and you'll find that no such evidence exists. It is your duty to PROTECT THE ENVIRONMENT. That is LITERALLY YOUR TITLE. So unless you can scientifically prove that withdrawing this Proposed Determination will serve to protect the environment, you must not withdraw it. Refusing to abide by these simple standards would be a disgrace to the EPA and to the country.

Do the right thing.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
Do not withdraw the EPA Region 10 July 2014 Proposed Determination that was issued pursuant of the Clean Water Act, to restrict the use of certain waters in southwest Alaska as disposal sites for dredged or fill material from Pebble deposit mining.

What's at stake? 

The largest sustainable salmon fishery in the world, typically supplying almost half of the world's wild sockeye salmon ("The Economic Importance of the Bristol Bay Salmon Industry" by the Institute of Social and Economic Research, University of Alaska - Anchorage). In 2010, harvesting, processing, and retailing Bristol Bay salmon and the multiplier effects of these activities created $1.5 billion in output or sales value across the United States. In 2010, Bristol Bay salmon fishermen harvested 29 million sockeye salmon worth $165 million in direct harvest value alone. That represented 31% of the total Alaska salmon harvest value, and was greater than the total value of fish harvests in 41 states. Salmon processing in Bristol Bay increased the value by $225 million, for a total first wholesale value after processing of $390 million. The total value of Bristol Bay salmon product exports in 2010 was about $250 million, or about 6% of the total value of all U.S. seafood exports. In 2010, the Bristol Bay sockeye salmon fishery supported 12,000 fishing and processing jobs during the summer salmon fishing season. Measuring these as year-round jobs, and adding jobs created in other industries, the Bristol Bay salmon fishery created the equivalent of almost 10,000 year-round American jobs across the country, and brought Americans $500 million in income. For every dollar of direct output value created in Bristol Bay fishing and processing, more than two additional dollars of output value are created in other industries, as payments from the Bristol Bay fishery ripple through the economy. These payments create almost three jobs for every direct job in Bristol Bay fishing and processing. As a significant associated benefit, a positive health trend in the United States is increased consumption of fish, supported by Bristol Bay frozen sockeye salmon.

Other critical values include ecosystems that depend upon this keystone group, subsistence fishers, Native American culture that relies upon salmon for existence and religious practices, the integrity of U.S. National Park lands (Katmai and Lake Clark), and the ecotourism industry.

Salmon are keystone species relied upon by many aquatic and terrestrial organisms, including forests dependent on nutrients brought from the ocean by migrating fish.  Bears, such as the Brown bears at Katmai, depend upon salmon for a large portion of their energy uptake.  The ecotourism industry depends upon a functioning and pristine ecosystem and the creatures that inhabit those places.

What's the problem?

We live in West Virginia, and formerly Kentucky, and we know what mining does to streams and fish.  Groundwater and surface waters are contaminated through leaching and outright spills from permanent tailings reservoirs, resulting in contaminated game fish and local extinctions of invertebrates and fishes.  Specifically, copper is a distinct toxin to fish, and can injure the salmon ability to "smell" and thereby impair return rates to natal streams.  Road development, slurry pipelines, and other infrastructure disrupt watersheds, terrestrial ecosystems, and add fine sediments to streams.  The impairment of Bristol Bay and surrounding lands will occur, there is no doubt.

What's the potential gain?

1000 direct jobs. Significant short-term profits for the owners.

What's the conclusion?

To put an entire ecosystem and its benefits at risk for short term gains in mineral wealth is irresponsible and inviting disaster.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment: No!!! Protect the Earth. Protect our waters. I ask that you please stop all pursuits of selfish capitalistic pursuit. Recognize the rich earth who needs help and stop mining and creating waste. Let's create a clean up initiative instead. Save the waters save the earth save ourselves
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I strongly believe that mankind should be the stewards of Earth.  Yet, history has proved otherwise. Habitat destruction is one of the major causes of population decline in species and biodiversity.  Of the five Pacific Salmon (Chinook, Coho, Pink, and Sockeye), all are either threatened or endangered.  It is imperative that Bistrol Bay Fishery in Alaska be preserved for future generations.  Bristol Bay is one of the world's most productive fisheries, mining would have a detrimental effect on this wetland, and our environment should be protected.

Bristrol Bay is one of the most valuable wild fisheries on Earth (CNN).  This important fishery produces nearly half of the world's sockeye salmon catch. In addition, this area's ecological resources support almost 4,000-year-old cultures as well as 14,000 full and part time jobs

The Clean Water Act was educed to safeguard Bristol Bay from loss of fish habitat due to elimination, dewatering, and fragmentation of streams, wetlands, and other aquatic resources from mining (CNN).
This mine would result in irreversible elimination of the salmon and would be detrimental to surrounding aquatic resources.

In an era that is marked with more animal and plant extinction than during the dinosaurs' demise 65 million years ago, we need to think of our planet's health first. Therefore, the only responsible decision for EPA should be a denial to the proposal to withdraw proposed determination to restrict the use an area as a disposal site.

I understand that Scott Pruit, the head of the US Environmental Protection Agency, met with Tom Collier, Pebble Limited Partnership and shortly afterward started to withdraw a plan that protects the watershed of Bristol Bay. According to Liz Bowman on CNN, an EPA spokeswoman, "The meeting was an opportunity for Administrator Pruit to let {Pebble Limited Partnership} know that they are simply being granted a fair opportunity to apply; he did not prejudge the outcome of the process, nor make any assurances about the final decision on the project.

However, I was concerned when Pruit met with a mining CEO and proceeded to go forward with this suspicious project.  Adversely, the Obama administration wanted to protect the fishery after finding out that a mine would result in complete loss of fish habitat due to elimination, dewatering, and fragmentation of waterways.  All of these losses would be irreversible!  I can only wonder what political or monetary motivations are afoot.

There are always two sides to every story, but I believe that there is only one right answer to this dilemma.  The world would suffer from a loss of the valuable area.  Not only would the losses would be irreversible, but also the disappearance of this environment would cause an ecological ripple effect. Bristol Bay Fishery needs to be preserved.  Revoking this determination would be a drastic mistake.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment: I strongly oppose all attempts to withdrawal clean water regulations from Bristol Bay. The Bristol Bay salmon fishery holds one of the largest salmon spawns in the world. It attracts outdoor enthusiasts from all around the world and characterizes one of the great wildernesses in America. The surrounding communities of Bristol Bay rely heavily on the strong salmon populations as a source of economic income. Disturbing the salmon spawn would not only be detrimental to the economies of the surrounding communities, but also destroy the cultural legacy that Bristol Bay carries. The Natural beauty of Bristol Bay is irreplaceable, and belongs to all Americans. Not a single corperation. Allowing an iconic site of natural beauty and importance to be given off to a private mining business will be taken by the American people as an insult to the legacy that makes America the great country it is. On the behalf of the common American, I urge you to keep the clean water act in place and protect Bristol Bay.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
The Pebble Mine and the surrounding area are in a very sensitive part of our world. I can see how the project would benefit 
Alaskans as far as jobs go. I can also be afraid of the long term affects that large scale mining would have on the environment
  Large scale mining creates huge lagoons of hazardous materials that would impact the watershed in the area south of the
proposed mine site. It would be in the best interest of Alaska, the salmon industry and the world if a compromise could take
place. Would it be possible to mine the ore in a responsible manner and have the ore shipped to an area less sensitive for
processing? It appears it would cost more, but in the long run everyone is a winner- Mother Earth and our fresh water supply.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment: It is vital that the Clean Water restrictions on mining the Pebble Deposit be upheld.  This deposit would be located in one of the last and most valuable salmon fisheries in the world.  It generates thousands of jobs and over $400 million in revenue for the local economy and plays an important part in the culture of Native Americans who have inhabited the area for centuries.  Thorough scientific reviews over several years have validated the ecological importance of the site, and investigations have determined that, because of the geology of the area, even minimal pollution from the mine would have drastic and far-reaching effects on the salmon population.  As an aquatic biologist, I have seen firsthand the damage that mine runoff can do...it is extensive and very difficult (if not impossible) to clean up.  North American salmon populations have been decimated by dams, habitat fragmentation and destruction, and development.  This location, a special and critical place for these fish, must be preserved.

Title: Comment submitted by A. G. Rappoport
Comment:
Dear Mr. Pruitt -

I am writing in response to the public comment period regarding whether the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) should withdraw the EPA Region 10 July 2014 Proposed Determination that was issued pursuant to Section 404(c) of the Clean Water Act, to restrict the use of certain waters in the South Fork Koktuli River, North Fork Koktuli River, and Upper Talarik Creek watersheds in southwest Alaska as disposal sites for dredged or fill material associated with mining the Pebble deposit, a copper-, gold-, and molybdenum-bearing ore body. The answer is an emphatic NO, as I will describe below.

In response to a 2010 petition from Bristol Bay's tribes, Native corporations, commercial fishers, the sports and recreation industry, and many others, to protect Bristol Bay from the risks posed by the proposed Pebble mine, the EPA initiated an extensive review and study process. Those risks were to salmon, waterways, people, and the economy, and included the Native Alaskan people who live in Southwest Alaska and depend for their food, livelihood, culture, and way of life, on the salmon and associated ecosystems of Bristol Bay. The subsequent EPA Assessment was undertaken in cooperation with state and federal agencies, universities, and other experts with responsibility and knowledge of the fishery and associated resources in the area, the well-being of the area's residents, the sportfish, hunting, and other recreational values of the area, and the economic dependence of tens of thousands of other Americans on these resources.

As a wildlife biologist and supervisor of the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service's Anchorage Fish and Wildlife Field Office until my retirement at the end of 2012, I am well aware of the depth and breadth of the studies that were completed and which were the justification for the EPA's appropriate 2014 determination and action. As Field Supervisor, I participated in numerous meetings and oversaw staff completion of a report on the terrestrial resources in the area and their dependence on marine derived nutrients - i.e., the salmon eaten as prey or carrion by bears, eagles, and other wildlife, and that become decaying nutrients taken up by plants or which enrich Bristol Bay waterways. (Appendix C of the EPA Watershed Assessment: Wildlife Resources of the Nushagak and Kvichak River Watersheds, Alaska, subsequently published as a U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service report: Brna, P. J. and L. A. Verbrugge (eds). 2013. Wildlife resources of the Nushagak and Kvichak River watersheds, Alaska. Final Report. Anchorage Fish and Wildlife Field Office, U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Anchorage, AK. 177 pp. Available: http://alaska.fws.gov/fisheries/fieldoffice/anchorage/environmental.htm). 

The process undertaken by the EPA involved two draft reports, a scientific review panel, scientific and technical peer reviews, and many public meetings and comment periods. Over 300,000 comments were received by EPA, the huge majority of which supported the withdrawal of Bristol Bay watersheds from mining, due to the expected harm to the salmon and people, livelihoods, way of life, and state and federal economies supported by those watersheds. A quick review of even just the executive summary of your agency's 2014 Assessment provides ample scientific and technical information in support of EPA's determination then. There is no new information to show that a tailings dam will never fail, or that mining can be done in an environmentally sound manner in this area! Even permitting a very small mine means it is just a matter of time before the mining spreads and expands throughout the area. Look at what has happened with Prudhoe Bay - providing the infrastructure for one development ensures the development of adjacent areas.

Compromising Bristol Bay for a mine is unacceptable. EPA proposed scientifically backed protections for the Bristol Bay watershed. I implore you not to withdraw those proposed protections! Listen to the people - over 60 % of Alaskans, and over 80 % of Bristol Bay residents want to protect this area from mining.

Thank you for your attention to my concerns, and the concerns of hundreds of thousands of other Alaskans and Americans!

Sincerely, 
Ann G. Rappoport
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I am writing you today to ask that you stand with American jobs and communities and not withdraw the Bristol Bay Proposed Determination, which it made pursuant to the Clean Water Act in 2014.

As you know, Bristol Bay, Alaska, is one of America's last great wild salmon fisheries. Tens of millions of wild salmon return annually, which support upwards of 14,000 American jobs in the commercial and sport fishing industries, serve as a one-in-a-lifetime destination for anglers from around the world, and are the cultural cornerstone for the region's communities.

These long-established American businesses and jobs are at risk from a foreign-owned mining company that wants to build the proposed Pebble Mine, which is opposed by more than 65 percent of Alaskans and more than 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents. 

In 2010, led by Alaska Native Tribes, interests including commercial fishing business owners and sportsmen asked the EPA step in to ensure that this mine wouldn't jeopardize Bristol Bay. The EPA responded by listening to over 1.5 million Americans, hosting dozens of community meetings, reviewing Pebble's many detailed filings with state and federal agencies, and conducting a twice peer-reviewed scientific assessment of the potential impacts to the region.

Withdrawing the proposed determination ignores the overwhelming majority of Alaskans and puts the short-term interests of a foreign mining company above thousands of American jobs. 

Please do not withdraw the proposed determination.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment submitted by D. B. Irons
Comment:
Dear Mr. Pruitt - 

I am strongly opposed to your proposal to withdraw the protections established by Region 10 of the Environmental Protection Agency in their July 2014 Proposed Determination about Bristol Bay waters. That determination was made with regard to Section 404(c) of the Clean Water Act, and would restrict the use of certain waters in the South Fork Koktuli River, North Fork Koktuli River, and Upper Talarik Creek watersheds in southwest Alaska as disposal sites for dredged or fill material associated with mining the Pebble deposit, a copper-, gold-, and molybdenum-bearing ore body.

It is unacceptable to compromise Bristol Bay for a mine! EPA recognized the threat of the mine to the area when proposing scientifically backed protections for the Bristol Bay watershed. Those protections were based on several years of scientific and technical studies, countless public hearings, peer-reviews, and hundreds of thousands of public comments, all clearly pointing to the need to protect the salmon in this area. By protecting the salmon, we allow thousands of Native Alaskans to continue to subsist on these resources and their associated ecosystem as they have for thousands of years, and we do not jeopardize a $1.5 billion seafood industry. We also protect the recreational hunting and fishing enjoyed by thousands of other Alaskans and Americans. 

The bottom line is that there is no new information leading to a different conclusion than the one in EPA's 2014 Determination. STOP now and DO NOT withdraw those proposed protections! Large-scale industrial mining does not belong here. 

If the EPA ignores the science and throws out the proposed protections, we risk losing the last greatest wild sockeye salmon fishery in Alaska and the country. This is not worth some deal with a foreign mining company. Our future is at stake. I am opposed to the Pebble mine. 
  
Sincerely, David B. Irons, Ph.D.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment: DO NOT withdraw the EPA Region 10 July 2014 Proposed Determination. Keep the waters clean!

Title: Comment submitted by J. DeVoe
Comment:
Dear Mr. Pruitt, 

EPA should not withdraw the July 2014 Proposed Determination at this timeor everbecause EPA's Section 404(c) preemptive veto was appropriate in the case of Pebble Mine. The Proposed Determination should remain in place, and the Bristol Bay watershed should be withdrawn from mineral development indefinitely.

The July 2014 Proposed Determination was the correct decision in this case because Pebble Mine is so clearly inappropriate for this setting and the American people. The E.P.A. should leave the July 2014 Proposed Determination in placenot withdraw itand should never allow the Pebble Mine to be applied for, permitted, or developed.

For Rivers,

John DeVoe 
Portland, Oregon

We simply cannot afford to trade our permanent natural resources like this one for shortterm profit for a few.  The jobs this project will create for Alaskans are short-lived and not especially wellpaid.  The corporations that will make the profits are not even U.S. corporations.  Giving the go ahead to this project is simply suicide for Alaskans, U.S. citizens, and the world community that depends on eating healthy fish.  Please do the right thing.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
Please preserve the EPA's 2014 Bristol Bay Proposed Determination. No mining should occur in this valuable watershed for legal, environmental, and cultural reasons.

Section 404 of the Clean Water Act gives clear discretionary authority to the EPA to use its expertise to determine whether the pollution of dredge or fill materials is permissible in light of potential environmental harms. The science is clear: The salmon, the rivers, the watershed, the entire ecosystem of this region are too precious and vulnerable to long-term harm if mining were to be permitted. The 2014 decision clearly stated the science to support this finding and should thus be upheld and defended by the EPA today. 

The importance of this watershed to the ecosystem cannot be overstated. Salmon runs are declining across the country, and maintaining a healthy environment for sockeye, chinook, and all Pacific salmon which utilize these waters is vital. Beyond the salmon are many other marine species that are essential to a healthy system that extends far beyond these waters and can have impacts throughout the world. 

And, just as importantly, Alaska depends on these waters to provide a healthy fishery to sustain jobs, traditional subsistence practices, and the culture of this region. Fishing is not just a job, it is a way of life. The importance of maintaining a healthy fishery is apolitical. Livelihoods, food security, traditional culture, recreation, and more, all rely on keeping these waters clean. 

As an Alaska resident, I ask that you listen to the voices of the people in this community who hope to have these healthy ecosystems for the next seven generations.

Thank you.

The risk to the fishery and the larger ecosystem is infinitely higher than the benefit of short term profits and access to finite resources

Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I worked as a commercial fisherman in Bristol Bay and contractor for Alaska General Seafoods out of Egegik, I have family & friends who're captains & deckhands on fishing boats throughout the Ugashik, Mushagak, Naknek, Kvichak districts, I've explored the Iliamna watershed with a fly rod, and my family business is selling seafood (including lots of Bristol Bay Salmon). I'm lucky to have worked & lived on Bristol Bay, which fosters the most valuable and prolific salmon fishery in the world.   

The proposed Pebble Mine sits at the headwaters of specific rivers which boast the largest runs in the world. The acid drainage potential from the tailings could be terminal to the fishery by itself, not to mention the mine's network of roads, bridges, and culverts that would do significant harm to the upper reaches of the fishery. 85% of commercial fishermen and 80% of the local community around Bristol Bay oppose the Pebble Mine. 

The University of Alaska's own ISER found that the economic benefits of the fishery greatly outweigh the alleged economic benefit of the mine. Furthermore, the Pebble Limited Partnership itself estimates that the mine would only provide a maximum of 1,000 fulltime employees for the first 20 years (after which, that number will greatly decrease, just like the mineral reserves). The Bristol Bay salmon fishery provides 14,000 jobs a year, to people who harvest a renewable resource in a sustainable economic model that can go on in perpetuity if this fishery is protected. A copper and gold mine, however, cannot provide a sustainable economic model as it's based on a finite resource. That finite resource will be torn and blown from the headwaters of Bristol Bay watershed which is crucial to a sustainable economic resource, salmon. The harvest of salmon provides over 10 times as many jobs as the mine ever will in the (maybe) 15-20 years before it goes cold and most the mine staff is laid off.    

The Pebble Limited Partnership is entirely owned by Northern Dynasty Minerals, a foreign company. The largest institutional shareholder (by a significant margin) of Northern Dynasty Minerals is Vertex One, and also a foreign company. Any pro-mine argument claiming some kind of economic benefit is actually (if anything) an argument on behalf of foreign companies, who are the profiteers of this mine - no on behalf of Alaskan job opportunities. 

The destructive potential from and public disdain for this mining operation has been recognized by some of the world's largest mining and investment entities, as well. Mitsubishi, Anglo American, and Rio Tinto are just a few of the former partners that have chosen to abandon the Pebble Mine development due to the comprehensively-acknowledged harms it would create for the world famous fishery, and the entire salmon industry at large.   

This mine will not just hurt the fishery in its early years, but its toxicity will continue harm to the watershed long after the handful of people who benefit from the mine it are gone. 

The EPA's approval of this mine would, objectively, put the priorities of a foreign multinational corporation over Alaskans and Americans who participate in and depend on the salmon industry in Bristol Bay. It would also put the wallets of a few foreign corporate executives over the livelihoods of thousands of living and yet-to-be-born Americans. The EPA should leave the July 2014 Proposed Determination in place, and never approve the development of Pebble Mine (or give a foreign corporation a green-light to harm a sustainable resource many Americans depend on). 

Americans who are one year-old right now won't even be done with high school when (A) the mineral deposits are significantly depleted, and (B) the majority of the "maybe 1,000 jobs" Pebble Mine claims it can provide "only for the first 20 years or so" no longer exist. Alternatively, that same one year-old American's great grand children could provide for their families and enjoy the sustainable natural resource of Bristol Bay salmon (if we protect it). Pleasing the foreign beneficiaries of the Pebble Mine and protecting the future cultural and economic benefits to Americans that Bristol Bay can provide are indeed mutually exclusive in this circumstance.

After the production of a voluminous peer-reviewed scientific record of the harms this mine would cause, and a decade of bipartisan wholesale opposition to it - from environmentalists to tribal leaders to commercial fishermen to loggers - It's ridiculous this is still being considered, and its a pretty simple call here guys: 

EPA: Tell Northern Dynasty Minerals to go blow up mountains and pollute rivers somewhere that won't harm the healthiest and most valuable salmon run on earth, because Alaskans and concerned Americans in the lower 48 (and, indisputably, the VAST majority of stakeholders) don't want economic and ecological harm to our sustainable resources for the benefit of a few (already incredibly wealthy) foreign mining moguls.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment submitted by J. Bubenik
Comment:
I vehemently oppose the withdrawal of the July 2014 Proposed Determination. As a recreational angler who visits the Bristol Bay watersheds for a week on a yearly basis, I have experienced firsthand the relatively untouched wilderness and reaped the benefits of excellent salmon runs on these streams. Having also experienced the dismal conditions of the Pacific Northwest and California, it is clear the impacts that development, especially an operation that leads to mass erosion and leaching, such as mining, can have on river ecosystems and on salmon runs. It is for this simple reason that I urge the EPA to keep the July 2014 Proposed Determination in place to protect Bristol Bay and its salmon runs for future generations.

Sincerely,

Justin Bubenik
