Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I lived in Alaska for thirty years and traveled extensively as Director of Special Events.  I respect and treasure the pristine beauty of that state and am absolutely OPPOSED to Pebble Mine's plan to create a mine that could have devastating consequences to the marine environment of the Bristol Bay and its valuable return of salmon each year.  

The Alaska fishing industry has learned from the mistakes in other states that do not have a viable fishing ecosystem by monitoring returns and limiting harvest until a substantial escapement has been assured.  This project is too risky to proceed as planned with the inevitable possibility of spillage.

Remember the EXXON!!!

Comment:
This is important to the future of our families and preserving the last open clear piece of the United States. The impact to the wildlife alone should be a good enough reason to not rescind. 
I am opposed to EPAs proposal to rescind the 2014 Proposed Determination designed to protect Bristol Bays world class fisheries. Please stand with American jobs and communities and preserve the Bristol Bay Proposed Determination.

Bristol Bay, Alaska, is one of America's last great wild salmon fisheries. Each year, tens of millions of wild salmon return, supporting upwards of 14,000 jobs in the commercial and sport fishing industries, and serving as a one-in-a-lifetime destination for anglers from around the world as well as the cultural cornerstone for the region's communities. These long-established businesses are at risk from a foreign-owned mining company that wants to build the proposed Pebble Mine, which is opposed by more than 65 percent of Alaskans and more than 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents. 

In 2014, led by Alaska Native Tribes, interests including commercial fishing business owners and sportsmen asked the EPA step in to ensure that this mine wouldn't jeopardize Bristol Bay. The EPA responded by listening to over 1.5 million Americans, hosting dozens of community meetings, reviewing Pebble's many detailed filings with state and federal agencies, and conducting a twice peer-reviewed scientific assessment of the potential impacts to the region. Withdrawing the proposed determination ignores the overwhelming majority of Alaskans and puts the short-term interests of a foreign mining company above thousands of local jobs. 

For the sake of our wildlife, waterways, and communities, I urge you to protect Bristol Bay and prevent this horrible open-pit mine from destroying one of our nation's most precious resources.

I now know what tyranny is.  I now know how our fore-fathers felt when they chose to fight and die for a cause. Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment: The  2014 proposed determination for a portion of the Bristol Bay watershed  was based on the EPA's own study that found "the extraction, storage, treatment, and transportation activities associated with building, operating, and maintaining one of the largest mines ever built would pose significant risks to the unparalleled ecosystem that produces one of the greatest wild salmon fisheries left in the world. In simple terms, the infrastructure necessary to mine the Pebble deposit jeopardizes the longterm health and sustainability of the Bristol Bay ecosystem". I can't fathom why the EPA is now proposing to rescind a determination based on its own (3-year, peer-reviewed) study, except for the fact that the guy now running the agency is owned by corporate interests.

Pleasing the foreign beneficiaries of the Pebble Mine and protecting the future cultural and economic benefits to Americans that Bristol Bay can provide are indeed mutually exclusive in this circumstance.

After the production of a voluminous peer-reviewed scientific record of the harms this mine would cause, and a decade of bipartisan wholesale opposition to it - from environmentalists to tribal leaders to commercial fishermen to loggers - It's ridiculous this is still being considered, and its a pretty simple call here guys: 

EPA: Tell Northern Dynasty Minerals to go blow up mountains and pollute rivers somewhere that won't harm the healthiest and most valuable salmon run on earth, because Alaskans and concerned Americans in the lower 48 (and, indisputably, the VAST majority of stakeholders) don't want economic and ecological harm to our sustainable resources for the benefit of a few (already incredibly wealthy) foreign mining moguls.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment submitted by M. Titus
Comment:
Dear EPA - 

I have spent 24 years of my life in the salmon industry in Alaska and the last six years making a film about the sacredness of salmon called The Breach.  Bristol Bay is a place of profound beauty, economic value and spiritual significance to the people who've lived there for thousands of years.  Salmon is the centerpiece of their life, spiritual practice and livelihoods.  

Bristol Bay's significance is hard to articulate unless you've been there.  This summer of 2017, I was able to spend several weeks fishing out of Egegik and saw firsthand the vast biological treasure that sockeye salmon are to the region.  Over 56 million fish returned this year - the 4th largest return in history.  It's impossible not to be moved in a profound way when encountering a natural wonder of this magnitude.

Whether to allow a large, open-pit, low-grade sulphur mine at the headwaters of a salmon run like this should not be taken lightly.  And your agency clearly did not when they spent three years and millions of taxpayer dollars conducting an intensive, scientific watershed assessment of the region and what would likely happen if a mine like Pebble was built in Bristol Bay.  

As a common-sense idea, it doesn't take much to reach the conclusion that a mine like Pebble would irreparably cause significant change at least and catastrophic disaster at worst to the people, water and wild salmon of Bristol Bay.  As a 3-year scientific study, that's precisely the conclusion your agency came to. 

Nothing else matters in the argument about whether to put a mine in Bristol Bay and effectively turn it into a mining district than one simple question:  Is it worth the risk?  Those owning and operating the mine and their shareholders stand to make half a trillion dollars on the prospect.  If something goes wrong, as your watershed assessment concludes will likely happen eventually, EVERYONE else loses.  A 100 year mine is not an equitable trade for a thousands-years-old, sustainable salmon run that feeds the world and can continue in perpetuity if not disrupted or destroyed.

Please consider this risk intently when considering these comments.

Sincerely,

Mark Titus

There is an accepted process to evaluate mining projects, and the EPA violated this process with their pre-emptive ruling on the proposed Pebble Mine project.  It is time to withdraw this proposed determination against Pebble, and allow the normal and usual permitting review to go forward.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
Please do not open the door for the Pebble Mine!!!!

I am opposed to EPAs proposal to rescind the 2014 Proposed Determination designed to protect Bristol Bays world class fisheries. Please stand with American jobs and communities and preserve the Bristol Bay Proposed Determination.

Bristol Bay, Alaska, is one of America's last great wild salmon fisheries. Each year, tens of millions of wild salmon return, supporting upwards of 14,000 jobs in the commercial and sport fishing industries, and serving as a one-in-a-lifetime destination for anglers from around the world as well as the cultural cornerstone for the region's communities. These long-established businesses are at risk from a foreign-owned mining company that wants to build the proposed Pebble Mine, which is opposed by more than 65 percent of Alaskans and more than 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents.

We cannot allow the destruction of the Bristol Bay extensive estuary, upper bay, and feeding river systems. The mine would destroy one of the world's best sustainable fisheries, and the sustainable jobs it supports. The short term profiteering by the mining company will be a disaster for generations of Americans. It should not be allowed! EPA administrators are supposed to protect the environment, not enable its destruction!!  

In 2014, led by Alaska Native Tribes, interests including commercial fishing business owners and sportsmen asked the EPA step in to ensure that this mine wouldn't jeopardize Bristol Bay. The EPA responded by listening to over 1.5 million Americans, hosting dozens of community meetings, reviewing Pebble's many detailed filings with state and federal agencies, and conducting a twice peer-reviewed scientific assessment of the potential impacts to the region. Withdrawing the proposed determination ignores the overwhelming majority of Alaskans and puts the short-term interests of a foreign mining company above thousands of local jobs. 

For the sake of our wildlife, waterways, and communities, I urge you to protect Bristol Bay and prevent this horrible open-pit mine from destroying one of our nation's most precious ecosystems.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I'm writing today to ask you to stand with American sportsmen, Alaska communities and the thousands of businesses that depend on Bristol Bay's robust fishery and cold, clean waters by upholding the Bristol Bay Proposed Determination, which was made pursuant to the Clean Water Act in 2014. We get one chance to ruin this ecosystem, but protecting it requires continued action. Allowing the mine could be a death sentence to an amazing ecosystem, and to the region's economy. It makes absolutely no sense to privilege gold and copper extraction over the ecology. 

Bristol Bay is home to one of America's last great wild salmon fisheries. Tens of millions of wild salmon return annually to the bay, resulting in a range of benefits that include the following: 
-It supports 14,000 fishing related jobs.
-It attracts anglers from around the world.
-It serves as the cultural cornerstone for the region's native tribes and communities.

These established American businesses are at risk from a foreign-owned mining company behind the Pebble proposal, which is opposed by more than 65 percent of Alaskans and more than 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents. 

In 2010, the EPA initiated a formal review process aimed at ensuring the proposed Pebble Mine wouldn't jeopardize Bristol Bay's healthy fishery. In response, over 1.5 million Americans weighed in urging the EPA to protect Bristol Bay. In addition, the EPA hosted dozens of community meetings, reviewed Pebble's many detailed filings with state and federal agencies, and conducted a twice peer-reviewed scientific assessment of the potential impacts to the region.

The results of this public process remain clear: The risks posed to the Bristol Bay fishery and the thousands of Alaskan jobs that it supports far outweigh the potential benefits associated with developing the Pebble Mine. 

Please stand with American sportsmen in maintaining Bristol Bay's fishery. Please do not withdraw the proposed determination.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
Bristol Bay is an incomparable fishery resource and deserves the fullest protection we can give it. We don't have all that many robust fisheries left, nationwide, so it is all the more important to protect Bristol Bay.  
Mines like Pebble are ill-considered and a waste of commonly held resources.  The marine environment is already at risk from so many other factors like ocean acidification and unusually warm water, and pollution from this mine which will degrade it.
Public comment should be considered heavily in making this decision:  only a few people benefit from developing the mine, whereas all Alaskans have something to lose.

I understand from individuals who work in this area that this critical area is essential to the Bristol Bay sockeye run, a very

general American public.  This is one of our all-too- few remaining, true incredible natural resources which we should
consider valuable especially in today's world climate where food independence should be regarded as paramount. 
Additionally, this pristine natural habitat should be protected for the future of the Alaskan wildlife and those of us in America and the 
greater world who value clean, pure water and land as well as for every generation succeeding us who will view this resource
as an even greater wonder, considering how quickly we are, unfortunately losing resources such as this.  Please, please take 
this vote seriously and protect this area by restricting any mining disposal.  Thank You.

Title: Comment submitted by K. Laird
Comment:
The EPA must not withdraw its limitation on mining in the Bristol Bay watershed.  I do not live or work in Bristol Bay, but I live in another Alaskan fishing town, so I know exactly what pollution could mean to the region and the salmon fishery. 

The Bristol Bay fishery is one of the most significant fisheries in the world. The salmon are under numerous environmental threats - from microplastics in the Pacific, to changes of habitat upstream, to the "blob" an area of unusually hot water in the Pacific ocean over the last several years. The Pebble Mine would be the worst of these threats. In a mine of this size, in a watershed this permeable, catastrophic pollution is a question of when, not if. Alaska is a high earthquake area, the ground is permeable - the proposed containment efforts are doomed.

Sockeye salmon are the most vulnerable salmon species up stream. They reproduce in lakes far from the sea - the Kitoi hatchery personnel refer to them as "prima donnas." In the Gulkhana hatchery, hatchery personnel note that if you lightly bump a box of hatchery fish in the first few weeks, 90% of the fish will die. It is illegal to drive 4-wheelers through salmon streams as a result. 

The Pebble Mine is so much more invasive and destructive than a 4-wheeler! To support the Pebble Mine is to support a foreign entity (Pebble mine is wholly owned by Northern Dynasty, a Canadian company) over the lives and livelihoods of Alaskan - American - fishermen, their families and their communities. This is not a partisan issue: this is people's livelihoods, and the health and sustainability of one America's most important fisheries.

It is the Environmental Protection Agency's job -- it says so right in the name -- to protect the environment and save this region of Alaska - protect the Bristol Bay watershed from foreign corporations, and preserve this fishery and its fish habitat for this and future generations of Alaskans.

Kate Laird
Cordova, AK

Title: Anonymous public comment

Title: Comment submitted by E. Wolf
Comment:
To whom it may concern:

Do not withdraw the EPA Region 10 July 2014 Proposed Determination that was issued pursuant of the Clean Water Act. Protect all the tributaries of Bristol Bay from the impacts of proposed mining development at the Pebble Mine, and other forms of development incompatible with the salmon fishery supported by Bristol Bay.

Prioritize the 14,000 American jobs and more than $1.5 billion in economic activity supported by the salmon resource of Bristol Bay -- in perpetuity.

Emphasize jobs, livelihoods, and stewardship. Do not put these precious things at risk. Use Clean Water Act provisions to protect Bristol Bay and its tributaries, do not withdraw protections and jeopardize a living resource of worldwide importance.

Edward Wolf
Portland, Oregon

creator and co-author of Salmon Nation: People, Fish, and Our Common Home (1999 and 2003)

Title: Comment submitted by J. Quinn
Comment:
Dear Administrator, 

I'm writing in reference to Docket # EPA-HQ-ORD-2012-0276. Please prohibit the disposal of mine waste in Alaska's Bristol Bay watershed. This mine would be a huge detriment to the surrounding wildlife and subsequently those who live there. With so much of the world's sockeye salmon population reliant on this area, we would effectively be dooming the species to unnecessary extinction. And that is incredibly harmful, not just to the fish, but the ecosystem that they are apart of, an ecosystem that humans similarly rely on.

We need to work to preserve as much of our planet's natural beauty as we can, while we still can. Not just because it is sad to see such mass extinctions in so short a period of time, but because we are backing ourselves into a corner. We cannot live on a barren planet and that is where we are headed if we keep sacrificing natural environments for short term financial gain.  I urge the EPA to take immediate action to use existing provisions of the Clean Water Act to protect this large and irreplaceable wild salmon fishery. Please.

Sincerely, 
James Quinn
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Comment submitted by G. Bancroft
Comment: My name is George Bancroft and I have major concerns about using the Bristol Bay area as a mining site for Northern Dynasty Minerals. The area is the largest spawning site in the world for Sockeye Salmon as nearly half the entire population spawns there. The Salmon are also a prime food source for other wildlife and people who live in the area. The Salmon industry  generates over 14,000 full and part time jobs per year which generates nearly $500 million annually. If the original mining plans for the Pebble Mine are approved and Northern Dynasty Minerals  is allowed to mine in Bristol Bay, the Sockeye Salmon habitat will be completely destroyed, causing thousands to be unemployed, massive financial losses and impact on a culture that has been dependent on the species for thousands of years. I question Scott Pruitt's decision to lift the protection of Bristol Bay without first consulting  the scientists and researches who have spent decades studying the area. The ecological value of Bristol Bay is very important to protect and if the EPA fails to deny a permit to Northern Dynasty Minerals, than I question if the current administration has the ability to protect any areas of ecological importance.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I urge the EPA to uphold the restrictions on use of certain waters in the South Fork Koktuli River, North Fork Koktuli River, and Upper Talarik Creek watersheds (located within the larger Bristol Bay watershed) as disposal sites for dredged or fill material associated with mining the Pebble deposit. As an informed Alaskan and citizen of the United States of America, I know that it is a bad trade-off to prioritize the relatively short term benefits of this mining proposal over the long-term benefits of the renewable fisheries resources produced in the Bristol Bay region, home to the largest wild salmon run on Earth. 

The proposed mining activity will have irreversible, devastating consequences on the renewable resources of the region. Please uphold the restrictions on disposal of dredged and fill material in these watersheds. Any actions to permit dredging and fill activities in the navigable waters of the Bristol Bay region, including the South Fork Koktuli River, North Fork Koktuli River, and Upper Talarik Creek watersheds, will have significant, adverse effects on the structure and function of the navigable waters of the United States, impairing the ecosystems that are critical to Alaska and the nation's economy and food resources.

Title: Comment submitted by W. Courshon
Comment:
I respectfully urge the EPA to rescind its proposal to withdraw the 2014 Clean Water Act Proposed Determination to restrict the use of the Pebble deposit area in the Bristol Bay watershed in Southeast  Alaska as a disposal site.  The serious risk of potential elimination of millions of wild salmon that populate the pristine Bristol Bay watershed, supported by the EPA's own 2014 findings based upon accepted scientific research, see 79 Federal Register 42314, July 21, 2014, far outweighs any perceived economic or political advantage in reversing the prior administration's policies by withdrawing the 2014 Clean Water Act Proposed Determination.  The withdrawal of the Proposed Determination would materially and detrimentally impact on the Alaska commercial fishing and tourism industries, the livelihood and culture of Alaskan Native peoples, fly fishers, and other sport fishers.  Please reconsider this regrettable action.

Respectfully submitted,

William Courshon
Board Member, Overlake Fly Fishing Club,
Bellevue, Washington

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I am opposed to EPAs proposal to rescind the 2014 Proposed Determination designed to protect Bristol Bays world class fisheries. Please stand with American jobs and communities and preserve the Bristol Bay Proposed Determination. 
Each year we order salmon caught in Bristol Bay to enjoy all winter..a healthy addition to our diet that supports the local Alaskan fishing industry.

Bristol Bay, Alaska, is one of America's last great wild salmon fisheries. Each year, tens of millions of wild salmon return, supporting upwards of 14,000 jobs in the commercial and sport fishing industries, and serving as a one-in-a-lifetime destination for anglers from around the world as well as the cultural cornerstone for the region's communities. These long-established businesses are at risk from a foreign-owned mining company that wants to build the proposed Pebble Mine, which is opposed by more than 65 percent of Alaskans and more than 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents. 

The 2014 EPA decision was based on  listening to Alaskan businesses and citizens as well as over 1.5 million other Americans, hosting dozens of community meetings, reviewing Pebble's many detailed filings with state and federal agencies, and conducting a twice peer-reviewed scientific assessment of the potential impacts to the region. Withdrawing the proposed determination ignores the overwhelming majority of Alaskans and puts the short-term interests of a foreign mining company above thousands of local jobs. 

Bristol Bay needs EPA protection to prevent this mine from destroying one of our nation's most precious ecosystems.
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment: No pebble mine! Keep Bristol Bay Pristine!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I have the unique experience of having worked both in Bristol Bay for a commercial seafood company and on the site of an old copper mine turned $500m remediation site.
The proposed Pebble Mine is many order of magnitude larger than the former Howe Sound Mine in Chelan, Washington. Yet the ecological scar that the Howe Sound Mine left on the pristine mountain wilderness has persisted for fifty years and will require nearly a century of further care to restore balance to the environment.
Commercial fishing in Bristol Bay provides a vital source of income and sustenance for thousands. And while fishing is not necessarily an environmentally friendly operation it relies on a healthy ecosystem to be sustainable. The health of the Bristol Bay watershed is currently ensured in large part by the ADF&G.
Usage of headwaters for mining operations has the potential to not only disrupt a pristine ecosystem but the livelihoods of those who live and fish in the area.

And while I understand that the EPA's current director, Scott Purit, is actively attempting to rollback all regulations that purportedly hamper big business, instead of protecting health and the environment, I still must try my small part to make a difference in this world, even if I am only adding to the chorus of 300,000 other citizens of this great nation who understand that our greatness comes not from the coffers of multinationals but the livelihood of all individuals who wholeheartedly believe that we cannot be great unless we care for, preserve, and protect all diversity of life.
So, in inclusion, I believe it is shortsighted and foolish to withdraw the restricted use area requirement.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment: I strongly object to EPA head Scott Pruitt's decision to withdraw the Obama protections for Bristol Bay for the benefit of Pebble Limited Partnership (Dynasty Minerals -- a Canadian mining company). The EPA must not withdraw its protections for the largest sustainable salmon run on Earth (56 million annually), thousands of American fishing jobs, clean water (a human right), and rights of the indigenous people who have honored & lived on the salmon runs for thousands of years.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment: I say NO to the withdrawal of Clean Water Act restrictions on discharge at the proposed Pebble Mine and to the mine itself. Gold, copper, and molybdenum mining discharge will decimate sockeye salmon populations and the birds, bears, wolves, and people that depend on them.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I am writing to implore you not to withdraw the EPA Region 10 July 2014 Proposed Determination that was issued pursuant to Section 404(c) of the Clean Water Act. Of course we MUST restrict the use of waters in the South Fork Koktuli River, North Fork Koktuli River, and Upper Talarik Creek watersheds in southwest Alaska as disposal sites for dredged or fill material associated with mining the Pebble deposit. This proposed determination was based on a rigorous, peer-reviewed scientific study concluding that the proposed mine would have unacceptable adverse effects on the rich salmon fishery. There was an extensive amount of input from the public, during meetings and public comment periods, and the response was overwhelmingly supportive. In addition, the EPA has noted that commercial fishing in Bristol Bay generates $300 million annually in direct sales of commercially caught salmon, generating 11,000 jobs. These salmon support not only the commercial and sportfishing industries, but a traditional Native way of life that has endured for millennia and thrives today. What will happen to these jobs, and the livelihood of all these people, if this watershed is destroyed? How can we ignore these findings now and reverse course? There may be a new administration in office, but none of the facts have changed! 

I also ask that if a final withdrawal decision is made following this comment period, I ask that the Administrator review and reconsider the withdrawal decision.

Please, for the sake of "one of the most productive, pristine, valuable and vulnerable ecosystems remaining in North America" I ask that the EPA do its job, stand by its proposed determination and take all necessary actions to protect the Bristol Bay watershed.

Title: Anonymous public comment

I am opposed to EPAs proposal to rescind the 2014 Proposed Determination designed to protect Bristol Bays world class fisheries. Please stand with American jobs and communities and preserve the Bristol Bay Proposed Determination.
It is unthinkable that you would consider jeopardizing the livelihood and industry that Bristol Bay already supports for such an short-sighted economic and environmental disaster.  How about applying some REAL economics to this situation to understand how there is no economic support for destroying this natural resource?  Or are you so bent on environmental destruction to benefit a very few that logic and reason are not considerations?

Bristol Bay, Alaska, is one of America's last great wild salmon fisheries. Each year, tens of millions of wild salmon return, supporting upwards of 14,000 jobs in the commercial and sport fishing industries, and serving as a one-in-a-lifetime destination for anglers from around the world as well as the cultural cornerstone for the region's communities. These long-established businesses are at risk from a foreign-owned mining company that wants to build the proposed Pebble Mine, which is opposed by more than 65 percent of Alaskans and more than 80 percent of Bristol Bay residents. 

In 2014, led by Alaska Native Tribes, interests including commercial fishing business owners and sportsmen asked the EPA step in to ensure that this mine wouldn't jeopardize Bristol Bay. The EPA responded by listening to over 1.5 million Americans, hosting dozens of community meetings, reviewing Pebble's many detailed filings with state and federal agencies, and conducting a twice peer-reviewed scientific assessment of the potential impacts to the region. Withdrawing the proposed determination ignores the overwhelming majority of Alaskans and puts the short-term interests of a foreign mining company above thousands of local jobs. 

For the sake of our wildlife, waterways, and communities, I urge you to protect Bristol Bay and prevent this horrible open-pit mine from destroying one of our nation's most precious ecosystems.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
Administrator Pruitt:

The EPA should not withdraw the July 2014 determination to restrict dumping of mining wastes in the Bristol Bay watershed.

I do not understand why the federal agency created to protect the environment would propose action that would allow damage to a pristine watershed that sustains one of the world's most important fisheries.

EPA's peer-reviewed assessment found that unrestricted dumping of metal-containing mining wastes in the Bristol Bay watershed could potentially destroy salmon-supporting streams, ponds and wetlands, jeopardizing the fishery and the livelihood of thousands of Alaskans.

Thewatershed's ecological resources generated nearly $480 million in direct economic expenditures and sales and provided employment for over 14,000 full- and part-time workers in 2009. (Source: U.S. EPA. An Assessment of Potential Mining Impacts on Salmon Ecosystems of Bristol Bay, Alaska (Final Report). U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Washington, DC, EPA 910-R-14-001A-C, ES, 2014. Chapter 5.)

Contrary to comments by the backers of the Pebble Mine project, EPA's watershed assessment was scientifically based and thoroughly peer-reviewed, and the public has had an extensive opportunity to comment on it. The assessment and public comments received should be key components of any future action on this issue.

A majority of Alaska voters oppose mining development that would harm wild salmon within the fisheries preserve, as evidenced by voter approval of the 2014 state-wide ballot measure.  The measure was designed to give the legislature the power to prohibit mining projects in Bristol Bay if legislators determine the activity to be harmful to wild salmon within the fisheries reserve. [Source: Alaska Bristol Bay Mining Ban, Ballot Measure 4, 2014. https://ballotpedia.org/Alaska_Bristol_Bay_Mining_Ban,_Ballot_Measure_4_(2014).]  Also, the overwhelming majority of residents of Bristol Bay are opposed to the proposed Pebble Mine project.  (Source: United Tribes of Bristol Bay. Opposition to Pebble Mine Reiterated by local tribes, fishermen, business owners.http://utbb.org/opposition-to-pebble-mine-reiterated-by-local-tribes-fishermen-business-owners/

Thank you for the opportunity to comment.

A concerned citizen
Columbia, Missouri
Display Properties (Name, Label, Tooltip: pageCount, Page Count, Number of pages In the content file

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
Commodity prices, such as those of minerals like gold and copper that the Pebble Partnership has proposed extracting, are subject to tumultuous swings in price and subsequently demand. Given the volatile market of global commodities, it is not a stretch to consider that over it's lifetime the Pebble Mine would be inoperative, waiting for more favorable market conditions to develop. Thus, the claimed economic benefits that the mine would bring to the state of Alaska would be temporary at best and completely absent at worst. To favor the industry with the ostensibly greater profit margins but no guarantee of success is a serious gamble that mortgages the livelihoods and health of the people who live around and depend on Bristol Bay. 

The economic and ecological reasons for not developing the mine are convincing, but it is the cultural element of this debate that is possibly the most persuasive argument of all. Alaska natives, whose livelihoods and way of life depend upon salmon, are facing a future where this lifestyle will no longer be possible. Given the importance of salmon to the native people, it seems ironic at best that the Pebble Partnership would argue that the people of the region will benefit from the project.

Title: Anonymous public comment
Comment:
I oppose any development of the Bristol Bay Pebble Mine due to the economic, ecological, and environmental risks. It is frustrating to me that EPA administrators directed the EPA to agree to initiate a proposed withdrawal process. Southwest Alaska is a magical place, acknowledged by the presence of national parks, national wildlife refuges, and national monuments in the area. The risk the dredge and fill material pose is not worth the short-term profits to be had. 

As an environmental protection scientist for water, this issue is very close to my professional focus. Unfortunately, I do not have the time to write scientifically about the many reasons this should not happen. I will take the time to list some of the major issues I see with the proposed withdrawal process. 

Salmon are a keystone species within this watershed. Their habitat and their wellbeing could easily be destroyed for generations if there were a  natural disaster which caused the release of dredge or fill material into the environment. Salmon are not only key to the health of that watershed's ecosystem, they are also key to the people who fish them for a living or subsistence. 

Environmental pollution from mining is long lasting and not easily cleaned up, especially in such a remote place. The dredge and fill material could pollute waterways and soil for generations. 

Withdrawing Clean Water Act Restrictions just sounds bad. I remember learning about the status of the environment in the country, which led to Congress writing and approving the Clean Water Act. The rivers were so polluted, they could catch fire. 

People live there. People live within this watershed. They recreate and harvest food in that watershed. By withdrawing the Clean Water Act restrictions, it is sending a message that those people don't matter. There is a long human history in that part of Alaska and it would be disrespectful to the people of the past, present, and future to destroy a landscape which was, is and will be their home. 

Protect the salmon, protect the environment, and protect the bush communities of Southwest Alaska from the catastrophe that could occur, if the EPA were to withdraw proposed Clean Water Act restrictions on mining Pebble Deposit. Do not withdraw the proposed Clean Water Act restrictions on mining Pebble Deposit.
